E=\frac{-M_{p} K^{2}}{2 L^{2}} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{M_{p} v^{2}}{R}=\frac{K}{R^{2}}, \quad L=M_{p} R v,
$$

we have

$$
R=\frac{L^{2}}{M_{p} K} .
$$

Let $L^{\prime}$ and $E^{\prime}$ be respectively the angular momentum and total energy of the planet after the explosion. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L^{\prime} &=L, \\
E^{\prime} &=E+\frac{G\left(M-M^{\prime}\right) M_{p}}{R} .
\end{aligned}
$$

With $K=G M M_{p}$ and $K^{\prime}=G M^{\prime} M_{p}$ we have for the eccentricity $e$ of the orbit after the explosion 

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{2} &=1+\frac{2 E^{\prime} L^{\prime 2}}{M_{p} K^{2}} \\
&=1+\frac{2\left[-\frac{M_{p} K^{2}}{2 L^{2}}+\frac{M_{p} K}{L^{2}} G\left(M-M^{\prime}\right) M_{p}\right] L^{2}}{M_{p} K^{\prime 2}} \\
&=1+\left(\frac{M}{M^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\left(1-\frac{2 M^{\prime}}{M}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
e=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{M}{M^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\left(1-\frac{2 M^{\prime}}{M}\right)} .
$$

\section{9}

A satellite traveling in an elliptical orbit about the earth is acted on by two perturbations:

(a) a non-central component to the earth's gravitational field arising from polar flattening,

(b) an atmospheric drag which, because of the rapid decrease in pressure with altitude, is concentrated near the perigee.

Give qualitative arguments showing how these perturbations will alter the shape and orientation of a Keplerian orbit.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Owing to polar flattening of the earth (shaded area in Fig. 1.46), the equipotential surface in the neighboring space is a flattened sphere (dashed ellipsoid).

Suppose the orbital plane $N$ of the satellite makes an angle $\theta$ with the equatorial plane $M$ of the earth.

As the equipotential surface deviates from the spherical shape, the earth's gravitational force acting on the satellite, which is normal to the equipotential surface, does not direct toward the center of the earth (e.g, the forces on the satellite at $A$ and $B$ in Fig. 1.46). As the effect is quite small, the orbit of the satellite can still be considered, to first approximation, as circular. The effect of the non-radial component of the force cancels out over one period, but its torque with respect to the center of the earth does 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-121.jpg?height=388&width=682&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=473)

Fig. 1.46.

not. This "equivalent" torque is directed into the plane of the paper and is perpendicular to the orbiting angular momentum $\mathrm{L}$ of the satellite, which is perpendicular to the orbit plane $N$ and is in the plane of the paper. It will cause the total angular momentum vector to precess about $L$.

(b) Because the atmospheric drag is concentrated near the perigee, it makes the satellite slow down at the perigee and reduces the energy and angular momentum of the satellite every time it crosses the perigee. This will make the apogee of the satellite's orbit come closer and closer to the earth and finally the orbit will become a circle with a radius equal to the distance of the perigee to the center of the earth. Further action by the drag will further reduce its distance to the earth until it falls to the earth.

\section{0}

A particle of mass $m$ moves under the influence of an attractive central force $f(r)$.

(a) Show that by a proper choice of initial conditions a circular orbit can result.

The circular orbit is now subjected to a small radial perturbation.

(b) Determine the relation that must hold among $f(r), r$ and $\partial f / \partial r$ for this orbit to be stable.

Now assume that the force law is of the form $f(r)=-K / r^{n}$.

(c) Determine the maximum value of $n$ for which the circular orbit can be stable. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The effective potential of the particle is

$$
V^{*}=\frac{J^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+V(r),
$$

where $J$ is a constant and $V$ is related to $f$ by $f=\frac{-d V}{d r}$, in terms of which the total energy is

$$
E=\frac{m \dot{r}^{2}}{2}+V^{*} .
$$

The motion can then be treated as one-dimensional, along the radial direction. The circular motion of the particle in the $V$ field corresponds to the particle being at rest in the equilibrium position in the $V^{*}$ field.

At the equilibrium position $r=r_{0}$,

$$
\frac{\partial V^{*}}{\partial r}=0,
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial r}=\frac{J^{2}}{m r^{3}} .
$$

If the initial condition satisfies the above equality and $E=V^{*}\left(r_{0}\right)$, the orbit is a circular one.

(b) For the orbit to be stable, $V^{*}$ must be minimum at $r=r_{0}$. This requires that

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V^{*}}{\partial r^{2}}\right)_{r=r_{0}}>0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{3 J^{2}}{m r^{4}}+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial r^{2}}>0, \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{3 J^{2}}{m r^{4}}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial r}>0,
$$

at $r=r_{0}$.

(c) If $f=-K / r^{n}$, then $\partial f / \partial r=n K / r^{n+1}$ and (1) gives

$$
J^{2}=m K / r_{0}^{n-3} \text {. }
$$

Hence the condition

$$
\frac{3 J^{2}}{m r^{4}}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial r}>0,
$$

i.e. 

$$
\frac{3 K}{r^{n+1}}-\frac{n K}{r^{n+1}}>0
$$

requires that $n<3$ for the circular orbit to be stable.

\section{1}

Consider a planet of mass $m$ moving in a nearly circular orbit of radius $R$ around a star of mass $M$. There is, in addition to gravitation, a repulsive force on the planet proportional to the distance $r$ from the star, $\mathbf{F}=A \mathbf{r}$. Compute the angular velocity of precession of the periastron (point of closest approach to the star).

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

The force on the planet is

$$
f=\frac{-G M m}{r^{2}}+A r .
$$

With $u=\frac{1}{r}$, Binet's formula (Problem 1055) gives the equation for the orbit:

$$
-m h^{2} u^{2}\left(\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+u\right)=-G M m u^{2}+\frac{A}{u} .
$$

For nearly circular orbit we set $u=u_{0}+\delta u$, where $\delta u$ is a small quantity. The above equation then gives, retaining only the lowest-order small quantities,

$$
\begin{aligned}
m h^{2}\left[\frac{d^{2}(\delta u)}{d \theta^{2}}+u_{0}+\delta u\right] &=G M m-\frac{A}{u_{0}^{3}\left(1-\frac{\delta u}{u_{0}}\right)^{3}} \\
& \approx G M m-\left(\frac{A}{u_{0}^{3}}\right)\left(1-\frac{3 \delta u}{u_{0}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the orbit is exactly circular, $u=u_{0}, \delta u=0$, the above becomes

$$
m h^{2} u_{0}=G M m-\frac{A}{u_{0}^{3}} .
$$

Using this equation in (1) we obtain

$$
m h^{2}\left[\frac{d^{2}(\delta u)}{d \theta^{2}}+\delta u\right]=\frac{3 A}{u_{0}^{4}} \delta u,
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2}(\delta u)}{d \theta^{2}}+\left(1-\frac{3 A}{m h^{2} u_{0}^{4}}\right) \delta u=0 .
$$

Choosing suitable coordinate axes we can write its solution as

$$
\delta u=B \sin (a \theta),
$$

where

$$
a=\sqrt{1-\frac{3 A}{m h^{2} u_{0}^{4}}}=\sqrt{1-\frac{3 A R^{3}}{G M m-A R^{3}}}
$$

as $h^{2} u_{0}=G M-A / m u_{0}^{3}, u_{0}=1 / R$. Then if $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ are the angles for two successive periastrons, we have

$$
a \theta_{2}-a \theta_{1}=2 \pi .
$$

or

$$
\Delta \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{a} .
$$

As $a<1$, the angle of precession is

$$
\Delta \theta_{p}=\Delta \theta-2 \pi=\frac{2 \pi(1-a)}{a} .
$$

The time required for the line joining the periastron and the star to rotate through an angle $\Delta \theta_{p}$ is

$$
\Delta t=\frac{\Delta \theta}{\dot{\theta}}=\frac{2 \pi}{a \dot{\theta}} .
$$

Hence the angular velocity of precession is

$$
\omega_{p}=\frac{\Delta \theta_{p}}{\Delta t}=(1-a) \dot{\theta} .
$$

As the angular velocity of revolution of the planet is by the definition of $h$

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{h}{R^{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R^{3}}-\frac{A}{m}},
$$

we have

$$
\omega_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R^{3}}-\frac{A}{m}}-\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R^{3}}-\frac{4 A}{m}} .
$$



\section{2}

(a) A planet of mass $m$ is orbiting a star of mass $M$. The planet experiences a small drag force $\mathbf{F}=-\alpha \mathbf{v}$ due to motion through the star's dense atmosphere. Assuming an essentially circular orbit with radius $r=r_{0}$ at $t=0$, calculate the time dependence of the radius.

(b) Now ignore the drag force. Assume that in addition to the Newtonian gravitational potential, the planet experiences a small additional potential so that its potential energy is actually

$$
V(r)=-\frac{G M m}{r}+\frac{\varepsilon}{r^{2}},
$$

where $\varepsilon$ is a small constant.

Calculate the rate of precession of the planetary perihelion, to lowest order in $\varepsilon$. You may assume the orbit is almost circular. In other words, you are to calculate the angle $\varphi$ sketched in Fig. $1.47$.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-125.jpg?height=285&width=291&top_left_y=948&top_left_x=590)

Fig. 1.47.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the drag force $\mathbf{F}$ is small, it can be considered as a small perturbation on the circular motion of the planet under the gravitational force of the star. The unperturbed energy equation is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{r} .
$$

If the orbit is circular with radius $r$, we have

and thus

$$
\dot{r}=0, \quad m r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G M m}{r^{2}}
$$

$$
E=-\frac{G M m}{2 r} .
$$

The drag force causes energy loss at the rate

$$
-\mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{v}=\alpha \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{v}=\alpha v^{2}=\frac{\alpha G M}{r} .
$$

This must be equal to

$$
-\frac{d E}{d t}=-\frac{G M m \dot{r}}{2 r^{2}},
$$

giving rise to

$$
\dot{r}=-\frac{2 \alpha}{m} r,
$$

whose integration gives

$$
r=r_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \alpha t}{m}},
$$

where we have used $r=r_{0}$ at $t=0$.

(b) The planet is now moving in a central potential $V(r)=-\frac{G M m}{r}+\frac{\varepsilon}{r^{2}}$ and its total energy is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{J^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+V(r),
$$

where $J$ is the conserved angular momentum, $J=m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}$.

As

$$
\dot{r}=\frac{d r}{d \varphi} \frac{d \varphi}{d t}=\dot{\varphi} \frac{d r}{d \varphi},
$$

we have

$$
d r=\sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}} \cdot\left(\frac{r^{2}}{J}\right) d \varphi,
$$

or

$$
\varphi=\int \frac{J d r}{r^{2} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}}}+\text { const. }
$$

In the unperturbed field $V_{0}=-G M m / r$, the orbit is in general an ellipse. However, in the perturbed field $V$, the orbit is not closed. During the time in which $r$ varies from $r_{\text {min }}$ to $r_{\max }$ and back to $r_{\min }$ again, the radius vector has turned through an angle $\Delta \varphi$ given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi &=2 \int_{r_{\min }}^{r_{\max }} \frac{J d r}{r^{2} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}}} \\
&=-2 \frac{\partial}{\partial J} \int_{r_{\min }}^{r_{\max }} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}} d r .
\end{aligned}
$$

Writing $V=\frac{-G M m}{r}+\frac{\varepsilon}{r^{2}}=V_{0}+\delta V$, we expand the integrand as a Taylor series in powers of $\delta V$ :

$$
f(V)=f\left(V_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{1 !}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial V}\right)_{V=V_{0}} \delta V+\frac{1}{2 !}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} f}{2 V^{2}}\right)_{V=V_{0}}(\delta V)^{2}+\cdots
$$

The zero-order term gives $2 \pi$ as the corresponding orbit is an ellipse. The first-order term gives

$$
\varphi=\frac{\partial}{\partial J} \int_{r_{\min }}^{r_{\max }} \frac{2 m \delta V d r}{\sqrt{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}}},
$$

the angle shown in Fig. $1.47$.

The variable over which the integration is to be carried out can be changed in the following way. We have

$$
\dot{r}=\dot{\varphi} \frac{d r}{d \varphi}=\frac{J}{m r^{2}} \frac{d r}{d \varphi},
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m\left(E-V_{0}\right)-\frac{J^{2}}{r^{2}}}=\frac{J}{m r^{2}} \frac{d r}{d \varphi} .
$$

So the last integral can be written as

$$
\varphi=\frac{\partial}{\partial J}\left[\frac{2 m}{J} \int_{0}^{\pi} r^{2} \delta V d \varphi\right]
$$

With $\delta V=\varepsilon / r^{2}$ we obtain

$$
\varphi=\frac{\partial}{\partial J}\left[\frac{2 m}{J} \int_{0}^{\pi} \varepsilon d \varphi\right]=-\frac{2 \pi \varepsilon m}{J^{2}}
$$

\section{3}

(a) Find the central force which results in the following orbit for a particle:

$$
r=a(1+\cos \theta) .
$$

(b) A particle of mass $m$ is acted on by attractive force whose potential is given by $U \propto r^{-4}$. Find the total cross section for capture for the particle coming from infinity with an initial velocity $V_{\infty}$. Note: Parts (a) and (b) may refer to different forces.

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the central force field, the equations of motion for the particle are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=F(r), \\
&r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { const. }=h, \text { say } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{h}{r^{2}}, \quad \ddot{\theta}=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{h}{r^{2}}\right)=\frac{-2 h \dot{r}}{r^{3}} .
$$

With $r=a(1+\cos \theta)$, we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{r} &=-a \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, \\
\ddot{r} &=-a\left(\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta\right)=-\frac{a h^{2}}{r^{4}}\left(\frac{2 \sin ^{2} \theta}{1+\cos \theta}+\cos \theta\right) \\
&=\frac{-a h^{4}}{r^{4}}(2-\cos \theta)=h^{2}\left(\frac{r-3 a}{r^{4}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the above we can write (1) as

$$
F(r)=m\left[\frac{h^{2}(r-3 a)}{r^{4}}-r\left(\frac{h}{r^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]=-\frac{3 m h^{2} a}{r^{4}},
$$

which is the central force required.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-128.jpg?height=277&width=367&top_left_y=1555&top_left_x=622)

Fig. 1.48. (b) As $U=-\frac{\alpha}{r^{4}}$, the effective potential is

$$
U_{\text {eff }}=\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}-\frac{\alpha}{r^{4}},
$$

where $L=m b V_{\infty}$ is the angular momentum, which is conserved in a central force field, $b$ being the impact parameter. To find the maximum of $U_{\text {eff }}$, consider

$$
\frac{d U_{\text {eff }}}{d r}=\frac{-L^{2}}{m r^{3}}+\frac{4 \alpha}{r^{5}}=0,
$$

which gives

$$
r_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{4 m \alpha}{L^{2}}}
$$

as the distance where $U_{\text {eff }}$ is maximum. Then

$$
\left(U_{\mathrm{eff}}\right)_{\max } \equiv U_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 m^{2} \alpha} .
$$

The form of $U_{\text {eff }}$ is shown in Fig. 1.48. It is seen that only particles with total energy $E>U_{0}$ will "fall" to the force center. Thus the maximum impact parameter for capture is given by $E=U_{0}$, or

$$
\frac{m^{4} b^{4} V_{\infty}^{4}}{16 m^{2} \alpha}=\frac{1}{2} m V_{\infty}^{2},
$$

giving

$$
b_{\max }=\left(\frac{8 \alpha}{m V_{\infty}^{2}}\right)^{1 / 4} .
$$

Hence the total capture cross section is

$$
\sigma=\pi b_{\max }^{2}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2 \alpha}{m V_{\infty}^{2}}} .
$$

\section{4}

(a) A particle of mass $m$ moves in a potential $V(r)=k / r^{2}, k>0$. Consider motion in the $X-Y$ plane, letting $r$ and $\phi$ be the polar coordinates in that plane, and solve for $r$ as a function of $\phi$, angular momentum $l$ and energy $E$ (Fig. 1.49).

(b) Use the result of part (a) to discuss (classical) scattering in this potential. Let $\theta$ be the scattering angle. Relate the impact parameter to $\theta$ 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-130.jpg?height=305&width=481&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.49.

and $E$ and thereby compute the differential cross section as a function of $\theta$ and $E$.

(Princeton )

\section{Solution:}

(a) The force on the particle is

$$
F=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial r}=\frac{2 k}{r^{3}} .
$$

Binet's formula (Problem 1055) then becomes

$$
h^{2} u^{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial \phi^{2}}+u\right)=-\frac{F}{m}=-\frac{2 k}{m} u^{3},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial \phi^{2}}+\left(1+\frac{2 k}{m h^{2}}\right) u=0,
$$

where $h=r^{2} \dot{\phi}, u=1 / r$. Its solution is

$$
u=A \sin (\omega \phi+\psi),
$$

where $\omega^{2}=1+2 k / m h^{2}$, and $A$ and $\psi$ are constants of integration to be determined from the initial conditions.

It can be seen from Fig. $1.49$ that for $r \rightarrow \infty$, i.e. $u \rightarrow 0, \phi \rightarrow 0$. Hence $\psi=0$. Also for $r \rightarrow \infty, \dot{r} \rightarrow \dot{r}_{\infty}$ given by $E=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}_{\infty}^{2}$, i.e. $\dot{r}_{\infty}=-\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{m}}$, where the minus sign is chosen because for incidence $r$ decreases with increasing $t$. Then as

$$
\dot{r}=\frac{d r}{d \phi} \dot{\phi}=\frac{d r}{d \phi} \frac{h}{r^{2}}=-h \frac{d u}{d \phi}=-A h \omega \cos (\omega \phi),
$$

we have, with $l=h m$,

$$
A=\frac{1}{l \omega} \sqrt{2 m E}
$$

and hence

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{\sqrt{2 m E}}{l \omega} \sin (\omega \phi),
$$

where $\omega$ is given by

$$
\omega^{2}=1+\frac{2 m k}{l^{2}} .
$$

(b) From the above result it can be seen that $r$ is at a minimum when $\omega \phi=\frac{\pi}{2}$, i.e. at $\phi=\phi_{0}=\frac{\pi}{2 \omega}$. This is the distance of closest approach $O C$ shown in Fig. 1.49. Due to the symmetry of the scattering, the scattering angle is

$$
\theta=\pi-2 \phi_{0}=\pi\left(1-\frac{1}{\omega}\right) .
$$

Then as $l^{2}=m^{2} b^{2} \dot{r}_{\infty}^{2}=2 b^{2} m E$, we have

$$
1-\frac{\theta}{\pi}=\left(1+\frac{2 m k}{l^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\left(1+\frac{k}{b^{2} E}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}},
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{\theta^{2}}{\pi^{2}}-\frac{2 \theta}{\pi}=-\frac{k}{b^{2} E+k},
$$

giving

$$
b^{2}=\frac{k}{E} \frac{(\pi-\theta)^{2}}{(2 \pi-\theta) \theta}
$$

as the relation between $\theta$ and $b$.

Particles with impact parameters between $b$ and $b+d b$ will be scattered into angles between $\theta$ and $\theta+d \theta$, i.e. into a solid angle $d \Omega=2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta$. Hence the differential cross section at scattering angle $\theta$ per unit solid angle is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega} &=\left|\frac{2 \pi b d b}{2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta}\right|=\left|\frac{b}{\sin \theta} \frac{d b}{d \theta}\right| \\
&=\frac{k}{E \sin \theta} \frac{\pi^{2}(\pi-\theta)}{(2 \pi-\theta)^{2} \theta^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{5}

Derive formulas and calculate the values of (a) the gravitational acceleration at the surface of the moon, and (b) the escape velocity from the moon.

(SUNY, Buffalo )

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $M$ and $R$ be the mass and radius of the moon respectively. Then by the law of universal gravitation and the definition of gravitational acceleration at the surface of the moon we have

$$
\frac{G M m}{R^{2}}=m g,
$$

where $m$ is the mass of a body on the surface of the moon. The relation gives the gravitational acceleration at the surface of the moon as

$$
g=\frac{G M}{R^{2}}=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 7.35 \times 10^{22}}{\left(1.74 \times 10^{6}\right)^{2}}=1.62 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} .
$$

(b) The potential energy of a projectile of mass $m$ at infinite distance from the moon $\rho \rightarrow \infty$ is

$$
-\frac{G m M}{\rho}=-\frac{m g R^{2}}{\rho} \rightarrow 0 .
$$

Its kinetic energy, a positive quantity, is at least zero. Hence for the projectile to reach infinity from the surface of the moon, its total mechanical energy must be at least zero, by the conservation of energy.

At the surface of the moon, the projectile has total energy

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^{2}-m g R .
$$

If $v_{0}$ is the escape velocity, we require $E=0$, or

$$
v_{0}=\sqrt{2 g R}=\sqrt{2 \times 1.62 \times 1.74 \times 10^{6}}=2.37 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

\section{6}

Consider the motion of a particle of mass $m$ under the influence of a force $\mathbf{F}=-K \mathbf{r}$, where $K$ is a positive constant and $\mathbf{r}$ is the position vector of the particle. (a) Prove that the motion of the particle lies in a plane.

(b) Find the position of the particle as a function of time, assuming that at $t=0, x=a, y=0, V_{x}=0, V_{y}=V$.

(c) Show that the orbit is an ellipse.

(d) Find the period.

(e) Does the motion of the particle obey Kepler's laws of planetary motion?

(SUNY, Buffalo)

Solution:

(a) For a central force field $\mathbf{F}=-K \mathbf{r}$

$$
\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F}=K \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{r}=0 .
$$

Then as $\mathbf{F}=m d \mathbf{V} / d t$ we have

$$
\mathbf{r} \times \frac{d \mathbf{V}}{d t}=0
$$

or

$$
\frac{d(\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{V})}{d t}=\mathbf{V} \times \mathbf{V}+\mathbf{r} \times \frac{d \mathbf{V}}{d t}=0 .
$$

Integrating we obtain

$$
\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{V}=\mathbf{h},
$$

a constant vector.

It follows that

$$
\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{h}=\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{V}=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{V}=0,
$$

which shows that $\mathbf{r}$ is perpendicular to the constant vector $\mathbf{h}$, i.e. $\mathbf{r}$ lies in a plane perpendicular to $h$. This proves that the motion of the particle is confined to a plane. We shall choose the plane as the $x y$ plane with the origin at the center of the force.

(b) The equation of the motion of the particle is

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}=-K \mathbf{r},
$$

or, in Cartesian coordinates,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=0, \\
&\ddot{y}+\omega^{2} y=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega^{2}=K / m$. The general solution of the above set of equations is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x=A_{1} \sin \left(\omega t+\phi_{1}\right), \\
&y=A_{2} \sin \left(\omega t+\phi_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

With the initial conditions given, i.e.

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x=A_{1} \sin \phi_{1}=a, \\
&y=A_{2} \sin \phi_{2}=0, \\
&\dot{x}=A_{1} \omega \cos \phi_{1}=0, \\
&\dot{y}=A_{2} \omega \cos \phi_{2}=V_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

we find $\phi_{1}=\pi / 2, \phi_{2}=0, A_{1}=a, A_{2}=V_{0} / \omega=\sqrt{m / K} V_{0}$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
x &=a \sin \left(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} t+\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \\
y &=\sqrt{\frac{m}{K}} V_{0} \sin \left(\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The last set of equations describes an ellipse. Eliminating the parameter $t$ we obtain the standard equation for an ellipse:

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1,
$$

with

$$
b=\sqrt{\frac{m}{K}} V_{0} .
$$

(d) $(x, y)$ return to the same values when $t$ increases by $T$ such that

$$
\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} T=2 \pi .
$$

Hence the period is

$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{K}} .
$$

(e) Kepler's third law states that ratio of the square of the period of revolution of a planet to the cube of the length of the semimajor axis of its orbit is a constant. Hence we have 

$$
\frac{\text { (period) }^{2}}{\text { (length of semimajor axis) }^{3}}= \begin{cases}\frac{4 \pi^{2} m}{K a^{3}} & \text { if } a>b, \\ \frac{4 \pi^{2}}{V_{0}^{3}} \sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} & \text { if } a<b .\end{cases}
$$

As this ratio depends on $m$ and $a$ or $m$ and $V_{0}$, Kepler's third law is not obeyed.

\section{7}

(a) A particle of mass $m$ moves in a central field of potential energy $U(r)$. From the constants of the motion obtain the equation of the trajectory. Express the polar angle $\varphi$ in terms of $r$.

(b) If the particle moves in from infinitely far away with initial speed $V_{0}$, impact parameter $b$, and is scattered to a particular direction $\theta$, define the differential cross section in terms of $b$.

(c) Calculate the differential and total cross section for the scattering from a hard sphere.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) If a particle of mass $m$ moves in a central force field of potential energy $U(r)$, its mechanical energy $E$ and angular momentum with respect to the center of the force $m h$ are conserved quantities. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}\right)+U(r)=E, \\
&r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=h, \quad \text { or } \quad \dot{\varphi}=\frac{h}{r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As we also have

$$
\dot{r}=\frac{d r}{d t}=\frac{d r}{d \varphi} \frac{d \varphi}{d t}=\dot{\varphi} \frac{d r}{d \varphi}=\frac{h}{r^{2}} \frac{d r}{d \varphi},
$$

the energy equation becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left[\frac{h^{2}}{r^{4}}\left(\frac{d r}{d \phi}\right)^{2}+r^{2} \frac{h^{2}}{r^{4}}\right]+U(r)=E
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-136.jpg?height=281&width=436&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=575)

Fig. 1.50.

i.e.

$$
d \phi=\frac{h d r}{r \sqrt{\frac{2 r^{2}}{m}[E-U(r)]-h^{2}}},
$$

or

$$
\phi=\int \frac{h d r}{r \sqrt{\frac{2 r^{2}}{m}[E-U(r)]-h^{2}}},
$$

which express $\phi$ in terms of $r$.

(b) The orbit of the particle in the central force field is symmetrical with respect to the line joining the center of the force to the point of closest approach (OA in Fig. 1.50). The angle of scattering of the particle is then

$$
\theta=\pi-2 \varphi_{0}
$$

with $\varphi_{0}$ given by

$$
\varphi_{0}=\int_{r_{\min }}^{\infty} \frac{h d r}{r \sqrt{\frac{2 r^{2}}{m}[E-U(r)]-h^{2}}},
$$

where $r_{\mathrm{min}}$ is given by $\dot{r}=0$ in the energy equation, or $E=U(r)+\frac{m h^{2}}{2 r^{2}}$. The conservation laws give

$$
E=\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}, \quad m h=m b V_{0},
$$

so that

$$
\varphi_{0}=\int_{r_{\text {inin }}}^{\infty} \frac{b d r}{r^{2} \sqrt{1-\frac{b^{2}}{r^{2}}-\frac{2 U(r)}{m V_{0}^{2}}}} .
$$

The scattering angle $\theta$ can then be determined. Let $d N$ denote the number of particles scatterred per unit time into the solid angle corresponding to scattering angles $\theta$ and $\theta+d \theta$, and $n$ denote the number of particles passing through unit cross sectional area of the beam per unit time. The differential cross section is defined as

$$
d \sigma=\frac{d N}{n} .
$$

As the scattering angle $\theta$ corresponds to a unique impact parameter $b$, we have

$$
d N=2 \pi n b d b,
$$

i.e.

$$
d \sigma=2 \pi b d b .
$$

We can write the above as

$$
d \sigma=2 \pi b\left|\frac{d b}{d \theta}\right| d \theta=\frac{b}{\sin \theta}\left|\frac{d b}{d \theta}\right| d \Omega,
$$

where $d \Omega$ is the solid angle between two right circular cones of opening angles $\theta$ and $\theta+d \theta$ :

$$
d \Omega=2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta .
$$

Note that $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$ is known as the differential cross section per unit solid angle.

(c) A particle moves freely before it hits the hard sphere. Because it cannot enter into the interior of the sphere, momentum conservation requires that the incidence and reflected angles are equal as shown in Fig. 1.51.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-137.jpg?height=302&width=348&top_left_y=1524&top_left_x=611)

Fig. 1.51. Then

$$
b=a \sin \varphi_{0}=a \sin \left(\frac{\pi-\theta}{2}\right)=a \cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\frac{b a}{2 \sin \theta} \sin \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)=\frac{a^{2}}{4} .
$$

As this is independent of the scattering angle, the total scattering cross section is $\sigma=4 \pi \frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\pi a^{2}$, which is equal to the geometrical cross section of the hard sphere.

\section{8}

When displaced and released, the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass in Fig. $1.52$ oscillates on the frictionless horizontal surface with period $\pi / 6$ seconds.

(a) How large a force is necessary to displace the mas $2 \mathrm{~cm}$ from equilibrium?

(b) If a small mass is placed on the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block and the coefficient of static friction between the small mass and the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block is $0.1$, what is the maximum amplitude of oscillation before the small mass slips? (Assume the period is unaffected by adding the small mass.)

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-138.jpg?height=120&width=421&top_left_y=1328&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 1.52.

\section{Solution:}

Let $k$ be the spring constant. The equation of the motion of the mass is

$$
2 \ddot{x}+k x=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=0,
$$

where $x$ is the displacement of the block from its equilibrium postition, and $\omega^{2}=\frac{k}{2}$. The general solution is

$$
x=A \cos (\omega t+\phi) .
$$

The period of oscillation is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2}{k}}=\frac{\pi}{6},
$$

giving $\omega=12 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, k=288 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}$. If $\dot{x}=x_{0}$ at $t=0$, then $\phi=0, A=x_{0}$ and the solution is $x=x_{0} \cos (12 t)$.

(a) The force needed is

$$
f=k x=288 \times 2 \times 10^{-2}=5.76 \mathrm{~N} .
$$

(b) If the small mass moves together with the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block, it has the same acceleration as the latter, i.e. $\ddot{x}=-144 x_{0} \cos (12 t)$. Let its mass be $m$. When it starts to slip, the maximum horizontal force on it just exceeds the static friction:

$$
0.1 \times m g=144 m x_{0},
$$

giving

$$
x_{0}=\frac{0.98}{144}=6.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} \text {. }
$$

If $x_{0}$ exceeds this value $m$ will slip. Hence it gives the maximum amplitude for no slipping.

\section{9}

Two synchronous tuning forks of identical frequency and loudness produce zero net intensity at some point $A$. However if either one is sounded alone, a loudness $I$ is heard at $A$. Explain in detail, as to a sophomore, what became of the law of conservation of energy.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $s_{1}$ and $s_{2}$ be the distances between a point in space and the two tuning forks. Each of the forks alone produces oscillations at this point represented by 

$$
y_{1}=I_{1} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{s_{1}}{c}\right)\right]
$$

and

$$
y_{2}=I_{2} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{s_{2}}{c}\right)\right] \text {, }
$$

where $c$ is the speed of sound.

If $s_{1}$ and $s_{2}$ are both much larger than the distance between the two forks, we can regard $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ as approximately the same, i.e. $I_{1} \approx I_{2} \approx I_{0}$. Then the resultant oscillation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
y &=y_{1}+y_{2}=I_{0}\left\{\sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{s_{1}}{c}\right)\right]+\sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{s_{2}}{c}\right)\right]\right\} \\
&=2 I_{0} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{s_{1}+s_{2}}{2 c}\right)\right] \cos \left[\omega\left(\frac{s_{2}-s_{1}}{2 c}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $y=0$ if

$$
\frac{\omega\left(s_{2}-s_{1}\right)}{2 c}=(2 n+1) \frac{\pi}{2}, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots .
$$

Thus the resultant oscillation is zero at points where $s_{2}-s_{1}$ is some odd multiple of $\lambda / 2$. This does not violate the law of conservation of energy as is evident when we consider the energy stored in the whole wave field. Although the amplitude and energy of oscillation are zero at the nodes, at the antinodes, the amplitude of oscillation is twice and the energy is four times that of the individual value. Detailed calculations will demonstrate that the energy of the resultant oscillation is equal to the sum of that of the individual oscillations.

\section{0}

A mass $m$ moves in a plane in uniform circular motion with angular frequency $\omega$. The centripetal force is provided by a spring whose force constant is $K$ (ignore gravity). A very small radial impulse is given to the mass. Find the frequency of the resulting radial oscillation.

(Wisconsin) 

\section{Solution:}

In polar coordinates the equations of motion for the mass are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=-K\left(r-r_{0}\right), \\
&m(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta})=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equation gives

$$
r^{2} \theta=\text { const. }
$$

Let $R$ be the radius of the uniform circular motion of the mass. We have

$$
m R \omega^{2}=K\left(R-r_{0}\right), \quad r^{2} \dot{\theta}=R^{2} \omega .
$$

Let $r^{\prime}=r-R$ for departure from uniform circular motion. The radial equation can be written as

$$
\ddot{r}-\frac{r^{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{r^{3}}=\ddot{r}^{\prime}-\frac{R^{4} \omega^{2}}{\left(R+r^{\prime}\right)^{3}}=-\frac{K}{m}\left(r^{\prime}+R-r_{0}\right) .
$$

If the radial impulse is very small, $r^{\prime} \ll R$ and the above becomes

$$
\ddot{r^{\prime}}-R \omega^{2}\left(1-\frac{3 r^{\prime}}{R}\right)=\frac{-K r^{\prime}}{m}-\frac{K\left(R-r_{0}\right)}{m},
$$

or

$$
\ddot{r}^{\prime}+\left(3 \omega^{2}+\frac{K}{m}\right) r^{\prime}=0 .
$$

It follows that the frequency of radial oscillation is $\omega^{\prime}=\sqrt{3 \omega^{2}+\frac{K}{m}}$.

\section{1}

A particle of mass $m$ moves under the action of a restoring force $-K x$ and a resisting force $-R v$, where $x$ is the displacement from equilibrium and $v$ is the particle's velocity. For fixed $K$ and arbitrary initial conditions, find the value of $R=R_{c}$ giving the most rapid approach to equilibrium. Is it possible to pick initial conditions (other than $x=v=0$ ) so that the approach is more rapid for $R>R_{c}$ and $R<R_{c}$ ? Explain.

(Wisconsin) 

\section{Solution:}

The equation of motion is $m \ddot{x}+R \dot{x}+K x=0$. Assume $x=A e^{\alpha t}$, we obtain the indicial equation $m \alpha^{2}+R \alpha+K=0$, giving

$$
\alpha=\frac{-R \pm \sqrt{R^{2}-4 K m}}{2 m} .
$$

In general, if $R=R_{c}=2 \sqrt{K m}$ (critical damping), the mass approaches equilibrium most rapidly. However, if $R>R_{c}$, the mass may approach equilibrium even more rapidly under certain particular conditions. For now the general solution is

$$
x=A \exp \left(\frac{-R+\sqrt{R^{2}-4 K m}}{2 m}\right) t+B \exp \left(\frac{-R-\sqrt{R^{2}-4 K m}}{2 m}\right) t
$$

We can choose initial conditions so that $A=0$. Then the remaining term has a damping coefficient

$$
-\alpha=\frac{R+\sqrt{R^{2}-4 K m}}{2 m}=\frac{R+\sqrt{R^{2}-\overline{R_{c}^{2}}}}{2 m}>\frac{R_{c}}{2 m},
$$

so that approach to equilibrium is even faster than for critical damping. If $R<R_{c}$, we have

$$
\alpha=\frac{-R \pm i \sqrt{R_{c}^{2}-R^{2}}}{2 m},
$$

so that the general solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
x=& A \exp \left(-\frac{R t}{2 m}\right) \exp \left(\frac{i \sqrt{R_{c}^{2}-R^{2}} t}{2 m}\right) \\
&+B \exp \left(-\frac{R t}{2 m}\right) \exp \left(\frac{-i \sqrt{R_{c}^{2}-R^{2}} t}{2 m}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the approach to equilibrium is oscillatory with a damping coefficient

$$
\frac{R}{2 m}<\frac{R_{c}}{2 m} .
$$

The approach is always slower than for critical damping. 

\section{2}

A freely running motor rests on a thick rubber pad to reduce vibration (Fig. 1.53). The motor sinks $10 \mathrm{~cm}$ into the pad. Estimate the rotational speed (revolutions per minute, i.e. RPM) at which the motor will exhibit the largest vertical vibration.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-143.jpg?height=221&width=568&top_left_y=538&top_left_x=526)

Fig. 1.53.

\section{Solution:}

Let the elastic coefficient of the rubber pad be $k$. Then $k x=m g$, where $m$ is the mass of the motor. As $x=0.1 \mathrm{~m}, \frac{k}{m}=\frac{g}{x}=98 \mathrm{~s}^{-2}$. Then the natural frequency of the system is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=9.9 \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$

Hence when the motor is rotating at a rate

$$
\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{60 \times 9.9}{2 \pi}=94.5 \mathrm{RPM} \text {, }
$$

resonance will take place and the motor will exhibit the largest vertical vibration.

\section{3}

A car is traveling in the $x$-direction and maintains constant horizontal speed $v$. The car goes over a bump whose shape is described by $y_{0}=$ $A[1-\cos (\pi x / l)]$ for $0 \leq x \leq 2 l ; y_{0}=0$ otherwise (Fig. 1.54). Determine the motion of the center of mass of the car while passing over the bump. Represent the car as a mass $m$ attached to a massless spring of relaxed length $l_{0}$ and spring constant $k$. Ignore friction and assume that the spring is vertical at all times. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-144.jpg?height=261&width=487&top_left_y=230&top_left_x=543)

Fig. 1.54.

\section{Solution:}

Let the location of the mass at time $t$ be $(x, y)$. Choose the origin so that $x(0)=0$. Then $x(t)=v t$. The equation of the motion of the mass in the $y$-direction is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{y} &=-k\left(y-y_{0}-l_{0}\right)-m g \\
&=-k\left(y-A-l_{0}+\frac{m g}{k}\right)-k A \cos \left(\frac{\pi v t}{l}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting $Y=y-A-l_{0}+m g / k$, we can write the above equation as

$$
m \ddot{Y}+k Y=-k A \cos \left(\frac{\pi v t}{l}\right) .
$$

This equation describes the motion of a driven harmonic oscillator. Trying a particular solution of the form $Y=B \cos \left(\frac{\pi \nu t}{l}\right)$, we find

$$
-m B\left(\frac{\pi v}{l}\right)^{2}+k B=-k A,
$$

i.e.

$$
B=\frac{k l^{2} A}{m \pi^{2} v^{2}-k l^{2}} .
$$

Hence, the general solution of the equation of motion for the mass is

$$
y=C_{1} \cos (\omega t)+C_{2} \sin (\omega t)+B \cos \left(\frac{\pi v t}{l}\right)+A+l_{0}-\frac{m g}{k},
$$

with $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$.

The initial conditions are $y(0)=l_{0}-m g / k, \dot{y}(0)=0$, giving $C_{2}=0$, $C_{1}=-(B+A)=m \pi^{2} v^{2} A /\left(k l^{2}-m \pi^{2} v^{2}\right)$. Therefore the motion of the center of mass of the car is described by 

$$
y(t)=C_{1} \cos (\omega t)+B \cos \left(\frac{\pi v t}{l}\right)+A+l_{0}-\frac{m g}{k}
$$

with $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, C_{1}=-\frac{m \pi^{2} v^{2} A}{m \pi^{2} v^{2}-k l^{2}}, B=\frac{k l^{2} A}{m \pi^{2} v^{2}-k l^{2}}$.

\section{4}

A thin ring of mass $M$ and radius $r$ lies flat on a frictionless table. It is constrained by two extended identical springs with relaxed length $l_{0}$ $\left(l_{0} \gg r\right)$ and spring constant $k$ as shown in Fig. $1.55$. cies?

(a) What are the normal modes of small oscillations and their frequen-

(b) What qualitative changes in the motion would occur if the relaxed lengths of the springs were $2 l_{0}$ ?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-145.jpg?height=143&width=469&top_left_y=1019&top_left_x=488)

Fig. 1.55.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $l_{0} \gg r$, any rotation of the ring will cause a negligible change of length in the springs, any elastic force so arising is also negligible. Newton's second law then gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x}=&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-l_{0}\right] \frac{2 l_{0}+x}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
&+k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-l_{0}\right] \frac{2 l_{0}-x}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}}, \\
M \ddot{y}=&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-l_{0}\right] \frac{y}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-l_{0}\right] \frac{y}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x, y$ give the displacement of the center of the ring from the equilibrium position. Neglecting terms higher than the first order in the small quantities $x, y$, we have

$$
\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0} \pm x\right)^{2}+y^{2}} \approx \sqrt{4 l_{0}^{2} \pm 4 l_{0} x} \approx 2 l_{0}\left(1 \pm \frac{x}{2 l_{0}}\right) \approx 2 l_{0} \pm x .
$$

The above equations then become

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}=-2 k x, \\
&m \ddot{y}=-k y,
\end{aligned}
$$

with solutions

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x=A_{x} \cos \left(\omega_{x} t+\varphi_{x}\right), \\
&y=A_{y} \cos \left(\omega_{y} t+\varphi_{y}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{x}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{M}}, \omega_{y}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}$, and the constants $A_{x}, A_{y}, \varphi_{x}, \varphi_{y}$ are determined by the initial conditions. These are the two normal modes of small oscillations.

(b) With the relaxed length increased to $2 l_{0}$, during the motion, one spring is extended while the other compressed. The latter will exert an elastic force on the ring opposite to that when extended. Assuming that the spring constant is the same for compression as for extension, the equations of motion are now

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x}=&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-2 l_{0}\right] \frac{2 l_{0}+x}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-2 l_{0}\right] \frac{2 l_{0}-x}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
\approx &-2 k x, \\
M \ddot{y}=&-k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-2 l_{0}\right] \frac{y}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}+x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
&+k\left[\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}-2 l_{0}\right] \frac{y}{\sqrt{\left(2 l_{0}-x\right)^{2}+y^{2}}} \\
\approx &-\frac{k x y}{l_{0}},
\end{aligned}
$$

retaining only the lowest order terms in the small qualities $x, y$. It can be seen that the motion of the ring in the $x$-direction is similar to that in part (a) while the motion in the $y$-direction, though quite complicated, is of a higher order.

\section{5}

Two particles are connected by a spring of spring constant $K$ and zero equilibrium length. Each particle has mass $m$ and positive charge $q$. A constant horizontal electric field $\mathbf{E}=E_{0} \mathbf{i}$ is applied. Take into account the particles' Coulomb interaction but neglect magnetic effects, radiation, relativistic effects, etc. Assume the particles do not collide.

(a) If the particles slide along a frictionless straight wire in the $x$ direction and the distance $d$ between them is constant, find $d$.

(b) Find the acceleration of the center of mass in (a).

(c) In (a), suppose the distance $d(t)$ undergoes small oscillations around the equilibrium value you found. What is the frequency?

(d) Suppose the particles slide along a horizontal frictionless table instead of the wire. Find the general solution of the equations of motion. You may leave your answer in terms of integrals.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Considering the forces on the two particles as shown in Fig. 1.56, we obtain the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&q E+k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)-F_{c}=m \ddot{x}_{1}, \\
&q E+k\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)+F_{c}=m \ddot{x}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $F_{c}$ is the mutual Coulomb force between the particles

$$
F_{c}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{q^{2}}{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}} .
$$

As $x_{2}-x_{1}=d$, a constant, $\ddot{x}_{2}=\ddot{x}_{1}$. Subtracting (2) from (1), we obtain

$$
2 k d=2 F_{c}=\frac{2}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{q^{2}}{d^{2}},
$$


![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-148.jpg?height=274&width=568&top_left_y=262&top_left_x=212)

Fig. 1.56.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-148.jpg?height=385&width=306&top_left_y=204&top_left_x=919)

Fig. 1.57.

or

$$
d=\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{q^{2}}{k}\right)^{1 / 3}
$$

(b) Adding (1) and (2) we have

$$
2 q E=m\left(\ddot{x}_{1}+\ddot{x}_{2}\right)
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}_{0}=\frac{q E}{m},
$$

where $x_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)$ is the center of mass of the system.

(c) Subtracting (1) from (2) we obtain

$$
m\left(\ddot{x}_{2}-\ddot{x}_{1}\right)+2 k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)=\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}}
$$

Putting $x_{2}-x_{1}=d+\Delta d$, where $\Delta d \ll d$, the above becomes

$$
m(\Delta \ddot{d})+2 k(d+\Delta d)=\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}(d+\Delta d)^{2}}
$$

where $\Delta \ddot{d} \equiv \frac{d^{2} \Delta d}{d t^{2}}$. As $d^{3}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{q^{2}}{k}$ and $\Delta d \ll d$, the above can be written as

$$
m \Delta \ddot{d}+6 k \Delta d=0
$$

by retaining only the first order terms in $\frac{\Delta d}{d}$. It follows that the angular frequency of small oscillations is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{6 k}{m}} .
$$

(d) With $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}$ and $\theta$ as defined in Fig. 1.57, we can write the equations of the two-dimensional motion as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}=q E \mathbf{i}+k\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)-\mathbf{F}_{c}, \\
&m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}=q E \mathbf{i}+k\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)+\mathbf{F}_{c},
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\mathbf{F}_{c}=\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{1}\right|^{3}} .
$$

Adding (3) and (4) we obtain

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}+\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}=\left(\frac{2 q E}{m}\right) \mathbf{i},
$$

which is equivalent to two scalar equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}_{1}+\ddot{x}_{2}=\frac{2 q E}{m}, \\
&\ddot{y}_{1}+\ddot{y}_{2}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Integration gives}

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}+x_{2}=\frac{q E t^{2}}{m}+C_{1} t+C_{2}, \\
&y_{1}+y_{2}=D_{1} t+D_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{1}, C_{2}, D_{1}, D_{2}$ are constants of integration. Subtracting (3) from (4) we obtain

$$
m\left(\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}-\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}\right)=2 \mathbf{F}_{c}-2 k\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{1}\right) .
$$

Put $\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{1}=\mathbf{r}$ and rewrite the above as

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\frac{1}{m}\left(\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}-2 k r\right) \mathbf{e}_{r} .
$$

In polar coordinates we have

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) \mathbf{e}_{r}+(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}) \mathbf{e}_{\theta},
$$

so that

$$
r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}=\frac{1}{r} \frac{d}{d t}\left(r^{2} \dot{\theta}\right)=0,
$$

giving

$$
r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }=H, \text { say } .
$$

We also have

$$
\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m r^{2}}-\frac{2 k r}{m} .
$$

As

$$
\ddot{r}=\frac{d \dot{r}}{d t}=\dot{r} \frac{d \dot{r}}{d r}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d}{d r}\left(\dot{r}^{2}\right), \quad r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{H^{2}}{r^{3}},
$$

it can be written as

$$
\frac{d}{d r}\left(\dot{r}^{2}\right)=\frac{q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0} m r^{2}}+\frac{2 H^{2}}{r^{3}}-\frac{4 k r}{m} .
$$

Integrating we obtain

$$
\dot{r}^{2}=F-\frac{q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0} m r}-\frac{2 k r^{2}}{m}-\frac{H^{2}}{r^{2}},
$$

where $F$ is a constant. Integrating again we obtain

$$
\int \frac{d r}{r} \frac{d}{\sqrt{F-\frac{q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0} m r}-\frac{2 k r^{2}}{m}-\frac{H^{2}}{r^{2}}}}=t+W,
$$

where $W$ is a constant. Also, as

$$
r=\sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}}
$$

we have

$$
H=r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\left[\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}\right] \frac{d}{d t}\left[\arctan \left(\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}\right)\right]
$$

or

$$
H t+V=\int\left[\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}\right] d\left[\arctan \left(\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}\right)\right],
$$

where $V$ is a constant.

The four equations (5)-(8) allow us to find $x_{1}, x_{2}, y_{1}$ and $y_{2}$ as functions of $t$. Note that the constants of integrations $C_{1}, C_{2}, D_{1}, D_{2}, H, V, F$ and $W$ are to be determined from the initial conditions.

\section{6}

A clockwork governor employs a vibrating weight on the end of a horizontal flywheel-driven (i.e. uniformly rotating) shaft, as shown in Fig. 1.58. The flat spring has a spring constant $K$ and can neither twist nor bend except in a direction perpendicular to its (relaxed) flat side. The angular velocity $\omega$ of the shaft, externally driven, gradually increases until a "resonance" occurs ("resonance" here means that the weight swings in a circular orbit). Air friction (proportional to the velocity of the weight) dissipates the input energy and this limits the resonance to a finite amplitude. You may assume the spring deviation to be so small that the spring is always in its linear regime. For this problem, you need not explicitly include the air friction.

(a) Show that there are two different angular frequencies at which a "resonance" can occur. What are the frequencies?

(b) Describe the orbit of the weight for each of the two resonant frequencies (i.e. draw a picture of what the problem looks like).

(c) At the lower frequency resonance, write down an equation for the steady-state shaft torque as a function of $\omega$ and time.

(d) Show that there is an upper bound on the shaft torque at the lower resonance. What happens if the driving clock spring yields a torque greater than this upper bound?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-151.jpg?height=234&width=566&top_left_y=1147&top_left_x=529)

Fig. 1.58.

\section{Solution:}

(a) When the fywheel rotates with angular velocity $\omega$, the mass $m$ undergoes three-dimensional motion. However, as the longitudinal oscillation of the spring is small, we can consider the mass as not moving in the direction of the axis. As the spring can only bend in one direction, let $r$ be the displacement of $m$ in that direction, as shown in Fig. 1.59. The angular velocity is constant when "resonance" occurs and we shall consider the equation of the motion at resonance. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-152.jpg?height=370&width=595&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=510)

Fig. 1.59.

As the elastic force is $-K r$ and the component of the gravitational force in the direction of $r$ is $m g \cos (\omega t)$, we can, neglecting the air friction, write the equation of the motion of the vibrating weight as

$$
m g \cos (\omega t)-K r=m\left(\ddot{r}-r \omega^{2}\right),
$$

i.e.

$$
\ddot{r}+\lambda^{2} r=g \cos (\omega t),
$$

where

$$
\lambda^{2}=\frac{K}{m}-\omega^{2} .
$$

Trying a particular solution $r=A \cos (\omega t)$, we find $A=\frac{g}{\lambda^{2}-\omega^{2}}$. The homogeneous equation $\ddot{r}+\lambda^{2} r=0$ has general solution

$$
r=B \cos (\lambda t)+C \sin (\lambda t) .
$$

Then assuming the initial conditions $r(0)=a, \dot{r}(0)=b$, we obtain the general solution

$$
r=a \cos (\lambda t)+\frac{b}{\lambda} \sin (\lambda t)+\frac{g}{\omega^{2}-\lambda^{2}}[\cos (\lambda t)-\cos (\omega t)] .
$$

A circle of radius $R$ can be described by an equation in polar coordinates of the form

$$
r=2 R \cos \theta .
$$

Equation (1) can be written in this form under certain particular conditions as follows. If we let $\lambda$ in (1) to go to zero, we shall obtain

$$
r=a+b t+\frac{g}{\omega^{2}}(1-\cos \omega t) .
$$

If we then put

$$
a+b t+\frac{g}{\omega^{2}}=0,
$$

we obtain the equation of a circular orbit:

$$
r=-\frac{g}{\omega^{2}} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

This solution can be realized under the initial conditions $a=-\frac{g}{\omega^{2}}, b=0$, and with the angular velocity $\omega$ satisfying $\lambda=0$, or

$$
\omega=\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}},
$$

which is one of the resonant frequencies.

Another resonance is obtained if we put $\lambda=\omega$ in (1), which then becomes

$$
r=a \cos (\omega t)+\frac{b}{\omega} \sin (\omega t)+\frac{g t}{2 \omega} \sin (\omega t) .
$$

The last term on the right-hand side has an amplitude which diverges as time goes on. However, the air friction will dissipate the input energy and limit the resonance to a finite amplitude. Thus this term can be set to zero (which can be seen by inserting a damping term $-\beta \dot{r}$ in the equation). We therefore neglect the last term and obtain

$$
r=a \cos (\omega t)+\frac{b}{\omega} \sin (\omega t)=A \cos (\omega t-\alpha),
$$

which again describes a circular orbit. The corresponding resonant frequency is given by $\lambda=\omega$, or

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{2 m}} .
$$

(b) The orbits corresponding to the resonances are shown in Fig. 1,60. For the resonance at $\omega_{1}$, the initial conditions must be chosen properly. On the other hand, the resonance at $\omega_{2}$ can occur under any initial conditions which, however, determine the amplitude $A$ and the angle $\alpha . \omega_{2}$ is therefore the practical resonance frequency.

(c) Consider the equation of the transverse motion of the mass

$$
F-m g \sin (\omega t)=m(r \dot{\omega}+2 \omega \dot{r}) .
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-154.jpg?height=296&width=304&top_left_y=261&top_left_x=422)

$w_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-154.jpg?height=308&width=353&top_left_y=230&top_left_x=786)

$w_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{2 m}}$

Fig. 1.60.

At the lower resonance, $r=A \cos (\omega t-\alpha)$, we have $\dot{\omega}=0, \dot{r}=-\omega A \sin (\omega t-$ $\alpha)$, so that

$$
F=m\left[-2 A \omega^{2} \sin (\omega t-\alpha)+g \sin (\omega t)\right]
$$

giving the torque as

$$
\tau=F r=m A \cos (\omega t-\alpha)\left[-2 A \omega^{2} \sin (\omega t-\alpha)+g \sin (\omega t)\right] .
$$

(d) There is no loss of generality in putting $\alpha=0$. Then

$$
\tau=m A\left(\frac{g}{2}-A \omega^{2}\right) \sin (2 \omega t) .
$$

Hence $\tau \leq m A\left(\frac{g}{2}-A \omega^{2}\right)$ for the lower resonance. If the torque yielded by the driving clock spring is greater than this upper bound, $\omega$ will increase and the resonant state will no longer hold.

\section{7}

A mass $m_{1}$ moves around a hole on a frictionless horizontal table. The mass is tied to a string which passes through the hole. A mass $m_{2}$ is tied to the other end of the string (Fig. 1.61).

(a) Given the initial position $\mathbf{R}_{0}$ and velocity $\mathbf{V}_{0}$ in the plane of the table and the masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$, find the equation that determines the maximum and minimum radial distances of the orbit. (Do not bother to solve it!) 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-155.jpg?height=278&width=367&top_left_y=232&top_left_x=563)

Fig. 1.61.

(b) Find the frequency of oscillation of the radius of the orbit when the orbit is only sightly different from circular.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The equations of motion of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m_{1}\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=-T, \\
&m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=m_{1} h, \\
&T-m_{2} g=m_{2} \ddot{r},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m_{1} h$ is the angular momentum, a constant. Eliminating $T$ from (1) and (3), we obtain

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{1} r \dot{\theta}^{2}+m_{2} g=0 .
$$

Equations (2) and (4) give

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-\frac{m_{1} h^{2}}{r^{3}}=-m_{2} g .
$$

As $\ddot{r}=\dot{r} \frac{d \dot{r}}{d r}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{r}^{2}}{d r}$, the above can be readily integrated to give

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{m_{1} h^{2}}{2 r^{2}}=-m_{2} g r+C .
$$

At $t=0, r=R_{0}, \dot{r}=V_{0} \cos \phi, r \dot{\theta}=V_{0} \sin \phi$, so that $h=R_{0} V_{0} \sin \phi$, where $\phi$ is the angle between $\mathbf{R}_{0}$ and $\mathbf{V}_{0}$. Then the constant of integration $C$ can be evaluated as

$$
C=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) V_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2} \phi+m_{1} V_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \phi\right]+m_{2} g R_{0} .
$$

For $r$ to be an extremum, $\dot{r}=0$, with which (6) becomes

$$
2 m_{2} g r^{3}-2 C r^{2}+m_{1} h^{2}=0,
$$

whose solution gives the maximum and minimum radial distances of $r$.

(b) When the orbit of $m_{1}$ is circular, $\ddot{r}=0$, and (5) gives

$$
h^{2}=\frac{m_{2} g r_{0}^{3}}{m_{1}},
$$

where $r_{0}$ is the radius of the circular orbit. When the orbit is slightly different from circular, let $r=r_{0}+x$, where $x \ll r_{0}$. Equation (5) then becomes

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}-m_{1} h^{2} /\left(r_{0}+x\right)^{3}=-m_{2} g .
$$

As

the above becomes

$$
\left(r_{0}+x\right)^{-3}=r_{0}^{-3}\left(1+\frac{x}{r_{0}}\right)^{-3} \approx r_{0}^{-3}\left(1-\frac{3 x}{r_{0}}\right),
$$

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}-m_{1} h^{2}\left(r_{0}^{-3}-3 x r_{0}^{-4}\right)=-m_{2} g .
$$

Then using (7) we have

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}+\frac{3 m_{2} g x}{r_{0}}=0 .
$$

This shows that $x$ oscillates simple-harmonically with frequency

$$
\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) r_{0}}} .
$$

\section{8}

(a) Consider a damped, driven harmonic oscillator (in one dimension) with equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x-\gamma \dot{x}+A \cos (\omega t) .
$$

What is the time-averaged rate of energy dissipation?

(b) Consider an anharmonic oscillator with equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x+\alpha x^{2}+A \cos (\omega t),
$$

where $\alpha$ is a small constant. At time $t=0, x=0$ and $\dot{x}=0$. Solve for the subsequent motion, including terms of first order in $\alpha$.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The equation of motion is the real part of

$$
m \ddot{z}+m \omega_{0}^{2} z+\gamma \dot{z}=A e^{i \omega t} .
$$

For the steady-state solution we $\operatorname{try} z=z_{0} e^{i \omega t}$. Substitution gives

$$
z_{0}=\frac{A}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+i \gamma \omega}=B e^{-i \phi},
$$

with

$$
B=\frac{A}{\sqrt{m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}}}, \quad \phi=\arctan \frac{\gamma \omega}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

The rate of work done by the force $F=\operatorname{Re}\left(A e^{i \omega t}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\operatorname{Re} F \cdot \operatorname{Re} \dot{z}=\frac{1}{4}\left(F+F^{*}\right)\left(\dot{z}+\dot{z}^{*}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4}\left(F \dot{z}+F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}+F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right)=\frac{1}{4}\left(F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

when averaged over one period as $F \dot{z}$ and $F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}$ each carries a time factor $e^{\pm 2 i \omega t}$ which vanishes on integration over one period. Thus the average work done is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle P\rangle &=\frac{i \omega A B}{4}\left(e^{-i \varphi}-e^{i \varphi}\right)=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \sin \varphi \\
&=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \frac{B}{A} \gamma \omega=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} B^{2}}{2}=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} A^{2}}{2\left[m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

In steady state, this is equal to the rate of energy dissipation of the oscillator, which is given by the work done against the dissipative term, i.e.

$$
\left\langle P^{\prime}\right\rangle=\gamma(R e \dot{z})^{2}=\gamma \frac{\dot{z} \dot{z}^{*}}{2}=\gamma \frac{\omega^{2} B^{2}}{2} .
$$

As noted, the two approaches give the same result.

(b) The equation of motion is now

$$
m \ddot{x}+m \omega_{0}^{2} x-A \cos (\omega t)=\alpha x^{2} .
$$

As $\alpha$ is a small number, we can write the solution as

$$
x=x_{0}+\alpha x_{1}+\alpha^{2} x_{2}+\cdots \approx x_{0}+\alpha x_{1}
$$

in first approximation. $x_{0}$ is the solution for $\alpha=0$, i.e. of

$$
m \ddot{x}_{0}+m \omega_{0}^{2} x_{0}=A \cos (\omega t) .
$$

A particular solution is obtained by putting $x_{0}=B^{\prime} \cos (\omega t)$. Substitution gives $B^{\prime}=\frac{A}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}$. The general solution of the homogeneous part of the equation is harmonic. Hence the complete general solution is

$$
x_{0}=C \cos \left(\omega_{0} t+\psi\right)+B^{\prime} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

The initial condition $x_{0}=\dot{x}_{0}=0$ at $t=0$ then gives $\psi=0, C=-B^{\prime}$, or

$$
x_{0}=B^{\prime}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] .
$$

Substituting $x=x_{0}+\alpha x_{1}$ in (1) and neglecting powers of $\alpha$ higher than one, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega_{0}^{2} x_{1} \approx \frac{x_{0}^{2}}{m} \\
&=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right]^{2} \\
&=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m}\left\{1+\frac{1}{2} \cos (2 \omega t)+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)-\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]-\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

or, in complex form,

$$
\ddot{z}_{1}+\omega_{0}^{2} z_{1} \approx \frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m}\left[1+\frac{1}{2} e^{i 2 \omega t}+\frac{1}{2} e^{i 2 \omega_{0} t}-e^{i\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t}-e^{i\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t}\right] .
$$

For a particular solution try

$$
z_{1}=a+b e^{i 2 \omega t}+c e^{i 2 \omega_{0} t}+d e^{i\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t}+f e^{i\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t} .
$$

\section{Substitution gives}

$$
\begin{gathered}
a=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}, \quad b=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{2 m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-4 \omega^{2}\right)}, \quad c=-\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{6 m \omega_{0}^{2}}, \\
d=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m\left(\omega^{2}-2 \omega \omega_{0}\right)}, \quad f=\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{m\left(\omega^{2}+2 \omega \omega_{0}\right)} .
\end{gathered}
$$

The general solution of (1), to first order in $\alpha$, is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
x=& x_{0}+\alpha x_{1} \\
=& B^{\prime}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] \\
&+\alpha\left\{D \cos \left(\omega_{0} t+\theta\right)+a+b \cos (2 \omega t)+\cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)\right.\\
&\left.+d \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]+f \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial conditions $x=\dot{x}=0$ at $t=0$ then give $\theta=0$ and

$$
D=-(a+b+c+d+f)=\frac{10 B^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}}{3 m \omega_{0}^{2}\left(\omega^{2}-4 \omega_{0}^{2}\right)\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-4 \omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

Hence the motion of the anharmonic oscillator is described approximately by

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & \approx \frac{A\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right]}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}+\frac{10 \alpha A^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)}{3 m^{3} \omega_{0}^{2}\left(\omega^{2}-4 \omega_{0}^{2}\right)\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-4 \omega^{2}\right)}+\frac{\alpha A^{2}}{m^{3}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}} \\
& \times\left\{\frac{1}{\omega_{0}^{2}}+\frac{\cos (2 \omega t)}{2\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-4 \omega^{2}\right)}-\frac{\cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)}{6 \omega_{0}^{2}}+\frac{\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{\omega^{2}-2 \omega \omega_{0}}+\frac{\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{\omega^{2}+2 \omega \omega_{0}}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{9}

It is well known that if you drill a small tunnel through the solid, non-rotating earth of uniform density from Buffalo through the earth's center and to Olaffub on the other side, and drop a small stone into the hole, it will be seen at Olaffub after a time $T_{1}=\frac{\pi}{\omega_{0}}$, where $\omega_{0}$ is a constant. Now, instead of just dropping the stone, you throw it into the hole with an initial velocity $v_{0}$. How big should $v_{0}$ be, so that it now appears at Olaffub after a time $T_{2}=T_{1} / 2$ ? Your answer should be given in terms of $\omega_{0}$ and $R$, the radius of the earth.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

Let $r$ be the distance of the stone, of mass $m$, from the center of the earth. The gravitational force on it is $F=-\frac{G m 4 \pi r^{3} \rho}{3 r^{2}}=-\omega_{0}^{2} m r$, where $\omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi G \rho}{3}}, \rho$ being the density of the uniform earth. The equation of the motion of the stone is then 

$$
\ddot{r}=-\omega_{0}^{2} r .
$$

Thus the stone executes simple harmonic motion with a period $T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}}$. Then if the stone starts from rest at Buffalo, it will reach Olaffub after a time $T_{1}=\frac{T}{2}=\frac{\pi}{\omega_{0}}$.

The solution of the equation of motion is

$$
r=A \cos (\omega t+\varphi) .
$$

Suppose now the stone starts at $r=R$ with initial velocity $\dot{r}=-v_{0}$. We have

$$
R=A \cos \varphi, \quad-v_{0}=-A \omega_{0} \sin \varphi,
$$

giving

$$
\varphi=\arctan \left(\frac{v_{0}}{R \omega_{0}}\right), \quad A=\sqrt{R^{2}+\left(\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{0}}\right)^{2}} .
$$

To reach Olaffub at $t=\frac{T_{1}}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2 \omega_{0}}$, we require

$$
-R=\sqrt{R^{2}+\left(\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{0}}\right)^{2}} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}+\varphi\right)=-\sqrt{R^{2}+\left(\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{0}}\right)^{2}} \sin \varphi .
$$

As $\sin ^{2} \varphi+\cos ^{2} \varphi=1$, we have

$$
\frac{R^{2}}{R^{2}+\left(\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{0}}\right)^{2}}+\frac{R^{2}}{R^{2}+\left(\frac{v_{0}}{\omega}\right)^{2}}=1
$$

giving

$$
v_{0}=R \omega_{0} .
$$

\section{0}

(a) A particle of mass $m$ moves under a conservative force with potential energy $V(x)=c x /\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)$, where $c$ and $a$ are positive constants. Find the position of stable equilibrium and the period of small oscillations about it.

(b) If the particle starts from this point with velocity $v$, find the range of values of $v$ for which it (1) oscillates, (2) escapes to $-\infty$, (3) escapes to $+\infty$ 

\section{Solution:}

(a) At the equilibrium position, $F=-d V / d x=0$, i.e.

$$
\frac{d V}{d x}=\frac{\mathrm{c}\left(a^{2}-x^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{2}}=0 .
$$

Thus there are two equilibrium positions, $x_{1}=a, x_{2}=-a$. Consider

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}=\frac{2 \mathrm{c} x\left(x^{2}-3 a^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3}} .
$$

We have

$$
\left.\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{1}}<0,\left.\quad \frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{2}}>0 .
$$

It follows that $x_{1}$ is a position of unstable equilibrium and $x_{2}$ is a position of stable equilibrium.

For small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium, let $x=$ $-a+x^{\prime}$, where $x^{\prime} \ll a$. Then the equation of motion becomes

$$
m \frac{d^{2} x^{\prime}}{d t^{2}}=-\frac{c x^{\prime}\left(2 a-x^{\prime}\right)}{\left[\left(x^{\prime}-a\right)^{2}+a^{2}\right]^{2}} \approx-\frac{c x^{\prime}}{2 a^{3}} .
$$

Hence the period of small oscillations about $x=-a$ is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2 m a^{3}}{c}}=2 \pi a \sqrt{\frac{2 m a}{c}} .
$$

(b) The total energy of the particle is

$$
E=\frac{m v^{2}}{2}+V(-a)=\frac{m v^{2}}{2}-\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2 a} .
$$

(1) For the particle to be confined in a region, we require $E<0$, i.e.

$$
v<\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{c}}{m a}} .
$$

(2) As $E=\frac{m \dot{x}^{2}}{2}+V(x)$, for the particle to reach $x=-\infty$, we require $E>V(-\infty)=0$, i.e.

$$
v>\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{c}}{m a}} .
$$

(3) To escape to $+\infty$, the particle must pass through the point $x_{2}=+a$ at which the potential energy is maximum. Hence we require $E>V(a)=$ $\frac{c}{2 a}$, i.e.

$$
v>\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m a}} \text {. }
$$

\section{1}

A 3-4-5 inclined plane is fixed to a rotating turntable. A block rests on the inclined plane and the coefficient of static friction between the inclined plane and the block is $\mu_{s}=1 / 4$. The block is to remain at a position $40 \mathrm{~cm}$ from the center of rotation of the turntable (see Fig. 1.62). Find the minimum angular velocity $\omega$ to keep the block from sliding down the plane (toward the center).

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l o)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-162.jpg?height=345&width=386&top_left_y=1025&top_left_x=311)

Fig. 1.62.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-162.jpg?height=344&width=335&top_left_y=997&top_left_x=919)

Fig. 1.63.

\section{Solution:}

As shown in Fig. 1.63, the forces acting on the block are the gravitational force $m g$, the normal reaction $\mathbf{N}$, the static friction $\mathbf{f}$, and the centrifugal force with $f=\mu_{s} N, P=m \omega^{2} r$. Thus the conditions for equilibrium are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta &=P \cos \theta+\mu_{s} N, \\
N &=m g \cos \theta+P \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Hence}

$$
m g \sin \theta=P \cos \theta+\mu_{s} m g \cos \theta+\mu_{s} P \sin \theta,
$$

giving

$$
P=\left(\frac{\sin \theta-\mu_{s} \cos \theta}{\cos \theta+\mu_{s} \sin \theta}\right) m g=m \omega^{2} r
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\left(\frac{\sin \theta-\mu_{s} \cos \theta}{\cos \theta+\mu_{s} \sin \theta}\right) \frac{g}{r}=\left(\frac{\frac{3}{5}-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5}}{\frac{4}{5}+\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{3}{5}}\right) \cdot \frac{9.8}{0.4}=10.3
$$

i.e.

$$
\omega=3.2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

\section{2}

A mass $m$ hangs in equilibrium by a spring which exerts a force $F=$ $-K(x-l)$, where $x$ is the length of the spring and $l$ is its length when relaxed. At $t=0$ the point of support to which the upper end of the spring is attached begins to oscillate sinusoidally up and down with amplitude $A$, angular frequency $\omega$ as shown in Fig. 1.64. Set up and solve the equation of motion for $x(t)$.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-163.jpg?height=347&width=139&top_left_y=1148&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 1.64.

\section{Solution:}

Take the upper end of the spring, $P$, as the origin of the $x$ coordinate of the mass $m$. At $t=0, P$ starts to oscillate sinusoidally, so the distance of $P$ from the fixed support is $A \sin (\omega t)$. Then the mass $m$ has equation of motion

$$
m \frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}[x+A \sin (\omega t)]=m g-K(x-l) .
$$

Let $y=x-l-\frac{m g}{K}, \omega_{0}^{2}=\frac{K}{m}$. The above can be written as

$$
\ddot{y}+\omega_{0}^{2} y=\omega^{2} A \sin (\omega t) \text {. }
$$

Try a particular solution $y=B \sin (\omega t)$. Substitution gives

$$
B=\frac{\omega^{2} A}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}} .
$$

Hence the general solution is

$$
y=C \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+D \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+\frac{\omega^{2} A \sin (\omega t)}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}} .
$$

Using the initial condition

$$
m g=K(x-l), \text { i.e. } x=\frac{m g}{K}+l, \text { or } y=0
$$

and $\dot{y}=0$, we have

$$
C=0, \quad D=\frac{\omega^{3} A}{\omega_{0}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}
$$

and hence

$$
x(t)=\frac{\omega^{2} A}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}\left[\sin (\omega t)-\frac{\omega}{\omega_{0}} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right]+\frac{m g}{K}+l .
$$

\section{3}

A block of mass $m$ slides without friction on an inclined plane of mass $M$ which in turn is free to slide without friction on a horizontal table (Fig. 1.65). Write sufficient equations to find the motion of the block and the inclined plane. You do not need to solve these equations.

\section{Solution:}

(Wisconsin)

As shown in Fig. 1.65, let $x, y$ be a coordinate frame attached to the inclined plane, whose horizontal coordinate in the laboratory frame is denoted by $X$. The forces on the block and the inclined plane are as shown in the diagram. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-165.jpg?height=340&width=540&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=458)

Fig. 1.65.

We have for the inclined plane

$$
M \ddot{X}=N \sin \alpha,
$$

for the motion of the block along the $x$ direction

$$
m(\ddot{x}+\ddot{X} \cos \alpha)=-m g \sin \alpha,
$$

and for the motion of the block along the $y$ direction

$$
-m \ddot{X} \sin \alpha=N-m g \cos \alpha .
$$

These three equations for the three unknowns $N, x$ and $X$ can be solved to find the motion of the system.

\section{4}

A merry-go-round (carousel) starts from rest and accelerates with a constant angular acceleration of $0.02$ revolution per second per second. A woman sitting on a chair 6 meters from the axis of revolution holds a $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ ball (see Fig. 1.66). Calculate the magnitude and direction of the force she must exert to hold the ball 5 seconds after the merry-go-round begins to rotate. Specify the direction with respect to the radius of the chair on which she is sitting.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Consider two coordinate frames $L, R$ with the same origin. $L$ is fixed to the laboratory and $R$ rotates with angular velocity $\omega$. The time derivatives of a vector $\mathbf{A}$ in the two frames are related by 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-166.jpg?height=239&width=256&top_left_y=255&top_left_x=642)

Fig. 1.66.

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{A} .
$$

Then for a point of radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ from the origin we have

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times \mathbf{r}
$$

and

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d}{d t}\right)_{L}\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}+\left(\frac{d \omega}{d t}\right)_{L} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{d}{d t}\right)_{L}\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R} &=\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{R}+\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}, \\
\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}) .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Putting}

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{R}=\mathbf{a}^{\prime}, \quad\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}=\mathbf{v}^{\prime}, \quad\left(\frac{d \omega}{d t}\right)_{L}=\dot{\omega},
$$

we have

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}=\mathbf{a}^{\prime}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+\dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

In the rotating frame attached to the carousel, the equation of the motion of the ball $\mathbf{F}=m\left(\frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}$ then gives

$$
m \mathbf{a}^{\prime}=\mathbf{F}+m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}-m \dot{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime},
$$

as $\boldsymbol{\omega} \perp \mathbf{r}$ so that $\mathbf{r} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})=-\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}$. As the ball is held stationary with respect to the carousel, $\mathbf{a}^{\prime}=0, \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=0$, and

$$
\mathbf{F}=-m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}+m \dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

For the rotating frame $R$, take the $z$-axis along the axis of rotation and the $x$-axis from the center toward the chair. Then

$$
\dot{\omega}=\dot{\omega} \mathbf{k}, \quad \mathbf{r}=r \mathbf{i} .
$$

The force $\mathbf{F}$ acting on the ball is the resultant of the holding force $\mathbf{f}$ exerted by the woman and the gravity of the earth:

$$
\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{f}-m g \mathbf{k} .
$$

\section{Hence}

$$
\mathbf{f}=-m \omega^{2} r \mathbf{i}+m \dot{\omega} r \mathbf{j}+m g \mathbf{k} \text {. }
$$

With $\dot{\omega}=0.02 \times 2 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, \omega=5 \dot{\omega}, m=2 \mathrm{~kg}, r=6 \mathrm{~m}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{f}=-4.74 \mathbf{i}+1.51 \mathbf{j}+19.6 \mathbf{k} N
$$

of magnitude $=20.2 \mathrm{~N}$.

\section{5}

A planet of uniform density spins about a fixed axis with angular velocity $\omega$. Due to the spin the planet's equatorial radius $R_{E}$ is slightly larger than its polar radius $R_{P}$ as described by the parameter $\varepsilon=\left(R_{E}-\right.$ $\left.E_{P}\right) / R_{E}$. The contribution to the gravitational potential resulting from this distortion is

$$
\Phi(R, \theta)=\frac{2 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} P_{2}(\cos \theta)}{5 R^{3}}
$$

where $\theta$ is the polar angle and $P_{2}(\cos \theta)=\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta}{2}-\frac{1}{2}$. State a reasonable condition for equilibrium of the planet's surface and compute the value of $\varepsilon$ in terms of the parameter $\lambda=\frac{\omega^{2} R_{E}}{g}$, where $g$ is the gravitational acceleration. Make a numerical estimate of $\varepsilon$ for the earth. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-168.jpg?height=429&width=603&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=507)

Fig. $1.67$.

\section{Solution:}

The forces acting on a mass element $\Delta m$ on the surface of the planet are gravity, centrifugal force, and the constraint exerted by the rest of the planet. The condition for equilibrium of the surface is that the resultant of gravity and centrifugal force is perpendicular to the surface, i.e. it has no tangential component.

Suppose the surface of the planet is an ellipsoid of revolution with the $z$-axis as its axis of symmetry as shown in Fig. 1.67. The line of intersection of the ellipsoid with the $x z$-plane is an ellipse:

$$
z=R_{P} \cos \alpha, \quad x=R_{E} \sin \alpha,
$$

where $\alpha$ is a parameter. The polar angle $\theta$ of a point on the ellipse is given by

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{x}{z}=\frac{R_{E}}{R_{P}} \tan \alpha .
$$

The unit tangent $\tau$ to the ellipse at this point is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\tau} & \propto \mathbf{i} d x+\mathbf{k} d z=\left(\mathbf{i} \frac{d x}{d \alpha}+\mathbf{k} \frac{d z}{d \alpha}\right) d \alpha \\
&=\left(\mathbf{i} R_{E} \cos \alpha-\mathbf{k} R_{P} \sin \alpha\right) d \alpha=\frac{\cos \alpha}{R_{E}}\left(\mathbf{i} R_{E}^{2}-\mathbf{k} R_{P}^{2} \tan \theta\right) d \alpha .
\end{aligned}
$$

The centrifugal force $f_{1}$ on $\Delta m$ is

$$
\mathrm{f}_{1}=\mathrm{i} \Delta m R \omega^{2} \sin \theta
$$

and the gravitational force on it is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{f}_{2} &=-\nabla V=\nabla\left[\frac{G M_{e} \Delta m}{R}+\frac{2 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} \Delta m}{5 R^{3}} P_{2}(\cos \theta)\right] \\
&=G M_{e} \Delta m\left(-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} P_{2}(\cos \theta)\right) \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{6 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} \Delta m}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{e}_{r}=\mathbf{i} \sin \theta+\mathbf{k} \cos \theta, \\
\mathbf{e}_{\theta}=\mathbf{i} \cos \theta-\mathbf{k} \sin \theta, \\
\mathbf{f}_{2}=G M_{e} \Delta m\left[-\frac{\sin \theta}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta P_{2}(\cos \theta)-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta \cos ^{2} \theta\right] \mathbf{i} \\
+G M_{e} \Delta m\left[-\frac{\cos \theta}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{e}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \cos \theta P_{2}(\cos \theta)+\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin ^{2} \theta \cos \theta\right] \mathbf{k} \\
=G M_{e} \Delta m\left\{\mathbf{i}\left[-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-b\left(\frac{3}{2} \cos ^{2} \theta-\frac{1}{2}+\cos ^{2} \theta\right)\right] \sin \theta\right. \\
\left.+\mathbf{k}\left[-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-b\left(\frac{3}{2} \cos ^{2} \theta-\frac{1}{2}-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)\right] \cos \theta\right\},
\end{gathered}
$$

with $b=6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} / 5 R^{4}$.

The condition for equilibrium of the surface is

$$
\left(\mathbf{f}_{1}+\mathbf{f}_{2}\right) \cdot \boldsymbol{T}=0,
$$

which gives for $R \approx R_{P} \approx R_{E}$

$$
R_{E}^{3} \omega^{2} \sin \theta-R_{E}^{2} b G M_{e} \sin \theta \approx 0 .
$$

Hence

$$
\varepsilon=\frac{5 R_{E}^{2} b}{6} \approx \frac{5 R_{E}^{3} \omega^{2}}{6 G M_{e}}=\frac{5 R_{E} \omega^{2}}{6 g}=\frac{5 \lambda}{6}
$$

as $g=\frac{G M_{e}}{R_{E}^{2}}$. For earth, $R_{E}=6378 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~m}, \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{24 \times 3600} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, g=$ $9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$, we have

$$
\varepsilon \approx 2.9 \times 10^{-3} .
$$



\section{6}

A satellite moves in a circular orbit around the earth. Inside, an astronaut takes a small object and lowers it a distance $\Delta r$ from the center of mass of the satellite towards the earth. If the object is released from rest (as seen by the astronaut), describe the subsequent motion as seen by the astronaut in the satellite's frame of reference.

\section{(Wisconsin)}

\section{Solution:}

The satellite revolves around the earth with an angular velocity $\omega$. We assume that one side of the satellite always faces the earth, i.e. its spin angular velocity is also $\omega$. Choose a coordinate frame attached to the satellite such that the origin is at the center of mass of the satellite and the center of the earth is on the $y$-axis as shown in Fig. 1.68, where $R$ is the distance of the satellite from the center of the earth.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-170.jpg?height=372&width=371&top_left_y=946&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 1.68.

The equation of the motion of the small object of mass $m$ in the satellite frame is given by (Problem 1094)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\omega \times \mathbf{r})+2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}+m \dot{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} \\
&=m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}-m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}+2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}}=0, \boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \mathbf{r}=0$. Thus

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\mathbf{F}+m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}} .
$$

In the above, $\mathbf{F}$ is the gravitational force exerted by the earth: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
