\mathbf{F} &=\frac{G M m}{|\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{r}|^{3}}(\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{r}) \approx \frac{G M m}{R^{3}} \frac{(\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{r})}{\left(1-\frac{\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{R}}{R^{2}}\right)^{3}} \\
& \approx \frac{G M m}{R^{3}}\left(1+\frac{3 y}{R}\right)(\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{r}) \\
& \approx \frac{G M m}{R^{3}} \mathbf{R}-\frac{G M m}{R^{3}} \mathbf{r}+\frac{3 G M m y}{R^{3}} \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}$ is the centrifugal force and

$$
\begin{aligned}
-2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}} &=-2 m \omega \mathbf{e}_{z} \times\left(\dot{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+\dot{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}+\dot{z} \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) \\
&=-2 m \omega\left(\dot{x} \mathbf{e}_{y}-\dot{y} \mathbf{e}_{x}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is the Coriolis force.

As initially, $\mathbf{r}=\Delta r \mathbf{e}_{y}$, and all the forces are in the $x y$-plane, the object always moves in this plane. Then $\mathbf{r}=x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{y}$. If the satellite has mass $m^{\prime}$, we have

$$
\frac{G M m^{\prime}}{R^{2}}=m^{\prime} R \omega^{2},
$$

or $\omega^{2}=\frac{G M}{R^{3}}$. Then the second term of $\mathbf{F}$ cancels out the centrifugal force. The first term of $\mathbf{F}$ acts on the satellite as a whole and is of no interest to us. Hence the equation of motion becomes

$$
\ddot{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+\ddot{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}=3 \omega^{2} y \mathbf{e}_{y}-2 \omega\left(\dot{x} \mathbf{e}_{y}-\dot{y} \mathbf{e}_{x}\right)
$$

or, in component form,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{y}=3 \omega^{2} y-2 \omega \dot{x}, \\
&\ddot{x}=2 \omega \dot{y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating (2) and making use of the initial conditions $\dot{x}=0, y=\Delta r$ at $t=0$, we find

$$
\dot{x}=2 \omega(y-\Delta r) .
$$

Substitution in (1) gives

$$
\ddot{y}=-\omega^{2} y+4 \omega^{2} \Delta r,
$$

whose general solution is $y=A \cos (\omega t)+B \sin (\omega t)+4 \Delta r, A, B$ being constants. With the initial conditions $y=\Delta r, \dot{y}=0$ at $t=0$, we find

$$
y=-3 \Delta r \cos (\omega t)+4 \Delta r \text {. }
$$

Equation (3) now becomes

$$
\dot{x}=6 \omega \Delta r[1-\cos (\omega t)] .
$$

Integrating and applying the initial condition $x=0$ at $t=0$, we obtain

$$
x=6 \Delta r[\omega t-\sin (\omega t)] \text {, }
$$

Hence, the subsequent motion as seen by the astronaut in the satellite's frame of reference is described by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x=6 \Delta r[\omega t-\sin (\omega t)], \\
&y=\Delta r[4-3 \cos (\omega t)] .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{7}

Consider a hoop of radius $a$ in a vertical plane rotating with angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical diameter. Consider a bead of mass $m$ which slides without friction on the hoop as indicated in Fig. 1.69.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-172.jpg?height=448&width=225&top_left_y=1131&top_left_x=672)

Fig. 1.69.

(a) Under what specific condition will the equilibrium of the bead at $\theta=0$ be stable?

(b) Find another value of $\theta$ for which, in certain circumstances, the bead will be in stable equilibrium. Indicate the values of $\omega$ for which this stable equilibrium takes place. (c) Explain your answer with the aid of appropriate graphs of the potential energy versus $\theta$ as measured in the rotating frame.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Consider a coordinate frame $(r, \theta)$ attached to the hoop and use the derivation in Problem 1094. As $\omega$ is constant, we have in the rotating frame

$$
\mathbf{g}=\ddot{\mathbf{r}}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}) .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{g} &=-g \mathbf{e}_{z}=g \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-g \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} \\
\ddot{\mathbf{r}} &=-a \dot{\theta}^{2} \mathbf{e}_{r}+a \ddot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta} \\
\boldsymbol{\omega} &=\omega \mathbf{e}_{z}=-\omega \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}+\omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \\
\mathbf{r} &=a \mathbf{e}_{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have the equation of the motion of the bead in the $\mathbf{e}_{\theta}$ direction in the rotating frame as

$$
a \ddot{\theta}=-g \sin \theta+a \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta .
$$

To find the equilibrium positions, let $\ddot{\theta}=0$. The above then gives, for equilibrium, $\theta=0$ and $\cos \theta=\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}$.

(a) When $\theta$ is in the neighborhood of zero,

$$
\sin \theta \approx \theta, \quad \cos \theta \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2} .
$$

We can approximate (1) to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \ddot{\theta}\left(\frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}\right) \theta=0 \quad \text { if } \quad \frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2} \neq 0, \\
& \ddot{\theta}+\frac{\omega^{2}}{2} \theta^{3}=0 \quad \text { if } \quad \frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}=0 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

It is evident that if and only if $\omega^{2} \leq g / a$, in which case the resultant force acting on the bead is always directed toward the equilibrium position, will the equilibrium of the bead at $\theta=0$ be stable.

(b) The other value of $\theta$ for which the bead will be in equilibrium is

$$
\theta_{0}=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

Let $\theta=\theta_{0}+\delta \theta$, where $\delta \theta \ll \theta_{0}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\sin \theta=\sin \left(\theta_{0}+\delta \theta\right) \approx \sin \theta_{0}+\cos \theta_{0} \delta \theta \\
&\cos \theta=\cos \left(\theta_{0}+\delta \theta\right) \approx \cos \theta_{0}-\sin \theta_{0} \delta \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitution in (1) gives

$$
\frac{d^{2} \delta \theta}{d t^{2}}+\left(1-\frac{g^{2}}{a^{2} \omega^{4}}\right) \omega^{2} \delta \theta=0 .
$$

Hence the condition of stable equilibrium is

$$
1-\frac{g^{2}}{a^{2} \omega^{4}}>0, \quad \text { or } \quad \omega>\sqrt{\frac{g}{a}} .
$$

(c) The potential energy of the bead in the rotating frame consists of two parts, i.e. gravitational potential energy $V_{1}$ and centrifugal potential energy $V_{2}$, given by

$$
-\frac{\partial V_{\mathbf{1}}}{\partial z}=-m g,
$$

i.e.

$$
\begin{gathered}
V_{1}=m g z=m g a(1-\cos \theta) \\
-\frac{\partial V_{2}}{\partial r}=m r \omega^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

i.e.

$$
V_{2}=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} r^{2}=-\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

Thus

$$
V=V_{1}+V_{2}=m g a(1-\cos \theta)-\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

The two equilibrium positions are given by $\frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta}=0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin \theta &=0, & & \text { or } & & \theta=0, \\
\cos \theta &=\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}, & & \text { or } & & \theta=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Figures $1.70$ (a), (b), and (c) are the graphs of the potential energy versus $\theta$ as measured in the rotating frame for $\omega<\sqrt{g / a}, \omega=\sqrt{g / a}$ and $\omega>\sqrt{g / a}$ respectively. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-175.jpg?height=322&width=337&top_left_y=252&top_left_x=141)

(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-175.jpg?height=322&width=332&top_left_y=252&top_left_x=528)

(b)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-175.jpg?height=322&width=441&top_left_y=254&top_left_x=901)

(c)

Fig. $1.70$

The potential energy $V$ must be a minimum for the equilibrium to be stable. This is the case for $\theta=0$ in Figs. (a) and (b) and for $\theta=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}\right)$ in Fig. (c). The point $\theta=0$ in Fig. (c) is an equilibrium position but the equilibrium is unstable as $V$ is a maximum there.

\section{8}

A perfectly smooth horizontal disk is rotating with an angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical axis passing through its center. A person on the disk at a distance $R$ from the origin gives a perfectly smooth coin (negligible size) of mass $m$ a push toward the origin. This push gives it an initial velocity $V$ relative to the disk. Show that the motion for a time $t$, which is such that $(\omega t)^{2}$ is neglegible, appears to the person on the disk to be a parabola, and give the equation of the parabola.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Use a Cartesian coordinate frame attached to the disk such that the $z$-axis is along the axis of rotation and the $x$-axis is opposite to the initial velocity $V$ of the coin, both $x, y$-axis being on the plane of the disk. In this rotating frame, we have (Problem 1094),

$$
\frac{m d \mathbf{v}}{d t}=\mathbf{F}-\frac{m d \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r}-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v} .
$$

As there is no horizontal force on the coin after the initial push and $\omega=\omega \mathbf{k}$, $\dot{\omega}=0$, the above gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}=\omega^{2} x+2 \omega \dot{y}, \\
&\ddot{y}=\omega^{2} y-2 \omega \dot{x} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $z=x+i y$. Then $(1)+(2) \times i$ gives

$$
\ddot{z}+2 i \omega \dot{z}-\omega^{2} z=0 .
$$

With $z=e^{\gamma t}$, we have the characteristic equation

$$
\gamma^{2}+2 i \omega \gamma-\omega^{2}=(\gamma+i \omega)^{2}=0 .
$$

This has a double root $\gamma=-i \omega$, so that the general solution of (3) is

$$
z=(A+i B) e^{-i \omega t}+(C+i D) t e^{-i \omega t} .
$$

The initial conditions are $x=R, y=0, \dot{x}=-V, \dot{y}=0$, or $z=R, \dot{z}=-V$, at $t=0$, which give

$$
R=A+i B, \quad-V=\omega B+C+i(D-\omega A),
$$

or

$$
A=R, \quad B=0, \quad C=-V, \quad D=\omega R .
$$

Hence

$$
z=[(R-V t)+i R \omega t] e^{-i \omega t}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x=(R-V t) \cos (\omega t)+R \omega t \sin (\omega t), \\
&y=-(R-V t) \sin (\omega t)+R \omega t \cos (\omega t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Neglecting the $(\omega t)^{2}$ terms, the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x \approx R-V t, \\
&y \approx-(R-V t) \omega t+R \omega t=V \omega t^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the trajectory is approximately a parabola $y=\frac{\omega}{V}(R-x)^{2}$. 

\section{9}

A body is dropped from rest at a height $h$ above the surface of the earth and at a latitude $40^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$. For $h=100 \mathrm{~m}$, calculate the lateral displacement of the point of impact due to the Coriolis force.

(Columbia )

\section{Solution:}

If the body has mass $m$, in the rotating frame of the earth, a Coriolis force $-2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}$ is seen to act on the body. We choose a frame with origin at the point on the earth's surface below the starting point of the body, with $x$-axis pointing south, $y$-axis pointing east and $z$-axis pointing vertically up (Fig. 1.71). Then the equation of the motion of the body in the earth frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{r} &=-m g \mathbf{k}-2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}} \\
&=-m g \mathbf{k}-2 m\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
-\omega \cos 40^{\circ} & 0 & \omega \sin 40^{\circ} \\
\dot{x} & \dot{y} & \dot{z}
\end{array}\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-177.jpg?height=378&width=349&top_left_y=1149&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1,71

From the above, expressions for $\ddot{x}, \ddot{y}$ and $\ddot{z}$, can be obtained, which are readily integrated to give $\dot{x}, \dot{y}$ and $\dot{z}$. These results are then used in the expressions for $\ddot{x}, \ddot{y}$ and $\ddot{z}$. As the time of the drop of the body is short compared with the period of rotation of the earth, we can ignore terms of order $\omega^{2}$ and write the following: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}=0, \\
&\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos 40^{\circ}, \\
&\ddot{z}=-g .
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating the above twice and using the initial conditions, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
x &=0 \\
y &=\frac{1}{3} g t^{2} \omega \cos 40^{\circ}, \\
z-h &=-\frac{g t^{2}}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation gives the time of arrival of the body at the earth's surface $z=0$ :

$$
t=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}} .
$$

Then the lateral displacement of the body at impact is

$$
y=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{8 h^{3}}{g}} \omega \cos 40^{\circ}=0.017 \mathrm{~m} \text {. }
$$

\section{0}

(a) What are the magnitude and direction of the deflection caused by the earth's rotation to the bob of a plumb-line hung from the top to the bottom of the Sather Tower (Companile).

(b) What is the point of impact of a body dropped from the top?

Assume that Berkeley is situated at $\theta^{\circ}$ north latitude and that the tower is $L$ meters tall. Give numerical values for (a) and (b) based on your estimates of $L$ and $\theta$.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In Fig. 1.72, $\mathbf{F}_{e}$ is the fictitious centrifugal force, $\alpha$ is the angle that $m g$, the apparent gravity, makes with the direction pointing to the center of the earth. The gravity $m \mathbf{g}_{0}$ for a non-rotating earth is related to the above quantities by

$$
m \mathbf{g}=m \mathbf{g}_{0}+\mathbf{F}_{e} .
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-179.jpg?height=357&width=400&top_left_y=218&top_left_x=589)

Fig, 1,72,

Then by the force triangle, we have

$$
\frac{\mathrm{F}_{e}}{\sin \alpha}=\frac{m g}{\sin \theta}
$$

or

$$
\sin \alpha=\frac{F_{e} \sin \theta}{m g}=\frac{m R \omega^{2} \cos \theta \sin \theta}{m g}=\frac{R \omega^{2} \sin 2 \theta}{2 g} .
$$

Hence the magnitude of the deflection of the bob is

$$
L \alpha=L \arcsin \left(\frac{R \omega^{2} \sin 2 \theta}{2 g}\right) .
$$

(b) The lateral displacement of a body falling from rest at height $L$ in the northern hemisphere due to the Coriolis force is to the east and has magnitude (Problem 1099)

$$
\delta=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{8 L^{3}}{g}} \omega \cos \theta .
$$

\section{1}

Under especially favorable conditions, an ocean current circulating counter-clockwise when viewed from directly overhead was discovered in a well-isolated layer beneath the surface. The period of rotation was 14 hours. At what latitude and in which hemisphere was the current detected?

(Columbia) 

\section{Solution:}

We choose a coordinate frame attached to the earth with origin at the point on the earth's surface where the ocean current is, $x$-axis pointing south, $y$-axis pointing east and $z$-axis pointing vertically upward. The circulation in the ocean is due to the Coriolis force which causes an additional acceleration (Problem 1094)

$$
\mathbf{a}=-2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v},
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\omega}=\omega \cos \theta \mathbf{i}+\omega \sin \theta \mathbf{k}$ is the earth's rotational angular velocity, $\theta$ is the latitude, and $\mathbf{v}$ is the velocity of ocean current. Thus

$$
\mathbf{a}=-2 \omega\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
-\cos \theta & 0 & \sin \theta \\
v_{x} & v_{y} & 0
\end{array}\right|
$$

The horizontal component of the acceleration which affects the circulation of the ocean current is

$$
\mathbf{a}_{H}=-2 \omega \sin \theta\left(-v_{y} \mathbf{i}+v_{x} \mathbf{j}\right)=-2 \omega_{z} \mathbf{k} \times \mathbf{v} .
$$

As $\mathbf{a}_{H}$ is always normal to $\mathbf{v}$, it does not change the magnitude of the latter but only its direction. It causes the current to circulate in a circular path. Let $\Omega$ be the angular velocity of the circular motion. Then

$$
\left|\mathbf{a}_{H}\right|=2 \omega v \sin \theta=\frac{v^{2}}{r}=v \Omega,
$$

where $r$ is the radius of the circular path. Hence

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{\Omega}{2 \omega}=\frac{2 \pi}{14} \cdot \frac{24}{4 \pi}=\frac{6}{7},
$$

or

$$
\theta=59^{\circ} .
$$

If the ocean current is on the northern hemisphere, $\omega_{z} \mathbf{k}$ points toward the north pole and $\mathbf{a}_{H}$ always points to the right of the velocity $\mathbf{v}$. This makes $\mathbf{v}$ turn right and gives rise to clockwise circulation. In a similar way, in the southern hemisphere, the Coriolis force causes counter-clockwise circulation. Hence the circulating ocean current was detected at a latitude of $59^{\circ} \mathrm{S}$. 

\section{2}

A small celestial object, held together only by its self-gravitation, can be disrupted by the tidal forces produced by another massive body, if it comes near enough to that body. For an object of diameter $1 \mathrm{~km}$ and density $2 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, find the critical distance from the earth (Roche limit).

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the earth is fixed in space and the small celestial object orbits around it at a distance $l$ away as shown in Fig. 1.73. Let $M$ be the mass of the earth, $m$ the mass and $\rho$ the density of the small celestial object. Consider a unit mass of the object on the line $O C$ at distance $x$ from $C$. We have from the balance of forces on it

$$
(l-x) \omega^{2}=\frac{G M}{(l-x)^{2}}-\frac{G\left(\frac{4}{3}\right) \pi x^{3} \rho}{x^{2}} .
$$

We also have for the celestial body

$$
m l \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{l^{2}},
$$

which gives $\omega^{2}$ to be used in the above. Then as $\frac{x}{l} \ll 1$, retaining only the lowest order in $\frac{x}{l}$, we have

$$
l=\left(\frac{9 M}{4 \pi \rho}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}
$$

With $M=6 \times 10^{27} \mathrm{~g}, \rho=2 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, we find

$$
l=1.29 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~cm}=1.29 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~km} .
$$

If $l$ is less than this value, the earth's attraction becomes too large for the unit mass to be held by the celestial body and disruption of the latter occurs.

If the unit mass is located to the right of $C$ on the extended line of $O C$, $x$ is negative but the above conclusion still holds true. We may also consider a unit mass located off the line $O C$ such as the point $P$ in Fig. 1.74. We now have

$$
\sqrt{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}} \omega^{2} \cos \theta=\frac{G M}{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}} \cos \theta-\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \cos \varphi,
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-182.jpg?height=214&width=306&top_left_y=209&top_left_x=289)

Fig. 1.73.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-182.jpg?height=200&width=463&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=708)

Fig. $1.74$

with

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{l-x}{\sqrt{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}}}, \quad \cos \varphi=\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}} \text {. }
$$

As $x / l \ll 1, y / l \ll 1$, and retaining only the first-order terms we would obtain the same result.

\section{3}

A merry-go-round (MGR) has two orthogonal axes $(x, y)$ painted on it, and is rotating on the earth (assume to be an inertial frame $x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}$ ) with constant angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical axis. A bug of mass $m$ is crawling outward without slipping along the $x$-axis with constant velocity $v_{0}$ (Fig. 1.75). What is the total force $F_{b}$ exerted by the MGR on the bug? Give all components of $F_{b}$ in the earth-frame coordinates $x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}$ of the bug.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-182.jpg?height=300&width=407&top_left_y=1300&top_left_x=540)

Fig. $1.75$.

\section{Solution:}

In the rotating coordinate system $(x, y, z)$, the bug, which crawls with constant velocity $v_{0}$ along the $x$-axis, has no acceleration, so that the horizontal force acting on it by the MGR is (Problem 1094) 

$$
\mathbf{F}=2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}),
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\omega}=\omega \mathbf{e}_{z}, \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=v_{0} \mathbf{e}_{x}, \mathbf{r}=x \mathbf{e}_{x}$. The bug has a weight $-m g \mathbf{e}_{z}$, so that the MGR exerts a reaction force $m g \mathbf{e}_{z}$ on the bug. Hence the total force exerted by the MGR on the bug is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{b}=2 m v_{0} \omega \mathbf{e}_{y}-m \omega^{2} x \mathbf{e}_{x}+m g \mathbf{e}_{z} .
$$

Choose the earth frame $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}\right)$ such that at $t=0$, the corresponding axes coincide with those of the rotating frame. Then, denoting the unit vectors along the $x_{0^{-}}, y_{0^{-}}, z_{0^{-}}$-axes by $\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}, \mathbf{k}$ respectively, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{e}_{x}=\cos (\omega t) \mathbf{i}+\sin (\omega t) \mathbf{j} \\
&\mathbf{e}_{y}=-\sin (\omega t) \mathbf{i}+\cos (\omega t) \mathbf{j} \\
&\mathbf{e}_{z}=\mathbf{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

For simplicity, assume that the bug was at the origin at $t=0$, then $x=v_{0} t$. In the earth frame, $\mathbf{F}_{b}$ can thus be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F}_{b}=&-m v_{0} \omega[2 \sin (\omega t)+\omega t \cos (\omega t)] \mathbf{i} \\
&+m v_{0} \omega[2 \cos (\omega t)-\omega t \sin (\omega t)] \mathbf{j}+m g \mathbf{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{4}

Consider a collection of charged particles, all with the same charge/mass ratio $(e / m)$, interacting via conservative central forces. Prove that the motion of the particles in a small magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ is identical with that in the absence of the field, when viewed in a coordinate system rotating with an appropriately chosen angular velocity $\omega$ (Larmor's theorem). What is the appropriate value of $\omega$ and what is meant by "small"?

(Chicago )

\section{Solution:}

Assume the magnetic field to be uniform and let the central force on a particle be $\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})$. Consider two coordinate frames $L$ and $R$ with origins at the force center such that $R$ rotates with angular velocity $\omega$ about the common origin. Problem 1094 gives the equation of motion (in SI units) 

$$
\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})+e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}=m \mathbf{a}
$$

in $L$ and

$$
\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})+e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}=m \mathbf{a}^{\prime}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})
$$

in $R$. As $\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{v}^{\prime}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}$, (2) can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \mathbf{a}^{\prime} &=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})+e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\mathbf{v}-\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}) \\
&=\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})+\mathbf{v} \times(e \mathbf{B}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega})+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}) .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $R$ is chosen with

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=-\frac{e \mathbf{B}}{2 m}
$$

and if the centrifugal term $m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})$ can be neglected, the above becomes

$$
\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{r})=m \mathbf{a}^{\prime},
$$

i.e. the motion of the particle when viewed in the rotating frame is the same as that in the absence of the magnetic field.

This conclusion applies to a system of particles with the same $e / m$ and subject to central forces with the same center. The particles will move as if the magnetic field were absent but the system as a whole precesses in the laboratory frame with angular velocity $\boldsymbol{\omega}$.

We have assumed that for every particle in the system,

$$
m|\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})| \ll 2 m|\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}|,
$$

i.e.

$$
\omega \ll \frac{2 v}{r},
$$

or

$$
B \ll \frac{4 m v}{e r},
$$

which limits the strength of the field.

\section{5}

The pivot point of a rigid pendulum is in forced vertical oscillation, given by $\eta(t)=\eta_{0} \cos (\omega t)$. The pendulum consists of a massless rod of length $L$ with a mass $m$ attached at the end. (a) Derive an equation of motion for $\theta$, where $\theta$ is the pendulum angle indicated in Fig. 1.76. Assume $\theta \ll 1$ and $\eta_{0} \ll L$.

(b) Solve the equation to first order in $\eta_{0}$ for the initial conditions

$$
\text { (i) } \quad \theta=a, \quad \dot{\theta}=0 \text {, }
$$

and (ii) $\theta=0, \quad \dot{\theta}=a \sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}$.

(c) Evaluate the solutions for (i) and (ii) at resonance and describe the difference in the two motions.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-185.jpg?height=428&width=252&top_left_y=722&top_left_x=609)

Fig. 1.76.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use Cartesian coordinates with origin at point $O$ in Fig. 1.76, $x$-axis horizontal and $y$-axis vertically downward. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x &=L \sin \theta, & y &=L \cos \theta+\eta_{0}[1-\cos (\omega t)], \\
m \ddot{x} &=-F \sin \theta, & m \ddot{y} &=m g-F \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\theta \ll 1 \mathrm{rad}$, we can omit terms involving $\theta^{2}$ and take the approximation $\cos \theta \approx 1, \sin \theta \approx \theta$. Then

$$
\ddot{x} \approx-L \theta \dot{\theta}^{2}+L \ddot{\theta}, \quad \ddot{y} \approx-L \theta \ddot{\theta}+\eta_{0} \omega^{2} \cos (\omega t),
$$

and the equation of motion for $\theta$ is

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{1}{L}\left[g-\eta_{0} \omega^{2} \cos (\omega t)\right] \theta=0 .
$$

(b) For an approximate solution to first order in $\alpha=\frac{\eta_{0}}{L}$, let

$$
\theta=\varphi+\alpha \xi(t),
$$

where $\varphi$ satisfies the equation $\ddot{\varphi}+\omega_{0}^{2} \varphi=0$, with $\omega_{0}^{2}=\frac{g}{L}$, as well as the initial conditions for $\theta$.

(i) For initial conditions $\theta=a, \dot{\theta}=0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\varphi=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
&\theta=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+\alpha \xi(t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitution of the above in (1) gives, retaining only first order terms of $\alpha$,

$$
\ddot{\xi}+\omega_{0}^{2} \xi=a \omega^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \cos (\omega t)=\frac{a \omega^{2}}{2}\left\{\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]+\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]\right\} \text {. }
$$

This has a particular solution

$$
\xi=\frac{a \omega}{2}\left\{-\frac{\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{2 \omega_{0}+\omega}+\frac{\cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{2 \omega_{0}-\omega}\right\},
$$

so that the general solution is

$$
\xi=C_{1} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+C_{2} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-\frac{a \omega \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)}+\frac{a \omega \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)} .
$$

The initial conditions $\xi=0, \dot{\xi}=0$ at $t=0$ then give

$$
C_{1}=\frac{-a \omega^{2}}{\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}, \quad C_{2}=0,
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta &=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
&+\frac{\eta_{0}}{L}\left\{-\frac{a \omega^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)}{\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}-\frac{a \omega \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)}+\frac{a \omega \cos \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) For initial conditions $\theta=0, \dot{\theta}=a \sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}=a \omega_{0}$, let

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\varphi=a \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right), \\
&\theta=a \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+\alpha \xi(t) .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{Substitution in (1) gives}

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\xi}+\omega_{0}^{2} \xi &=a \omega^{2} \cos (\omega t) \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
&=\frac{a \omega^{2}}{2}\left\{\sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]+\sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

which has general solution

$$
\xi=D_{1} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+D_{2} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-\frac{a \omega \sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)}+\frac{a \omega \sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)} .
$$

The initial conditions $\xi=0, \dot{\xi}=0$ at $t=0$ then give

$$
D_{1}=0, \quad D_{2}=\frac{a \omega^{2}}{\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta=& a \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
&+\frac{\eta_{0}}{L}\left\{\frac{a \omega^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)}{\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}-\frac{a \omega \sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}+\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}+\omega\right)}+\frac{a \omega \sin \left[\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right) t\right]}{2\left(2 \omega_{0}-\omega\right)}\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Resonance occurs at $\omega=2 \omega_{0}$. As $\omega \approx 2 \omega_{0}$, we have for case (i)

$$
\theta=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-\frac{\eta_{0} a}{4 L} \cos \left(3 \omega_{0} t\right)=a\left[1+\frac{3 \eta_{0}}{4 L}-\frac{\eta_{0}}{L} \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)
$$

and for case (ii)

$$
\theta=a \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-\frac{\eta_{0} a}{4 L} \sin \left(3 \omega_{0} t\right)=a\left[1-\frac{3 \eta_{0}}{4 L}+\frac{\eta_{0}}{L} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
$$

It is seen that the amplitude at resonance is limited to $\approx a$ in both cases. However, the two resonances occur at phases differing by $\frac{\pi}{2}$.

\section{6}

A hemispherical bowl of radius $R$ rotates around a vertical axis with constant angular speed $\Omega$. A particle of mass $M$ moves on the interior surface of the bowl under the influence of gravity (Fig. 1.77). In addition, this particle is subjected to a frictional force $\mathbf{F}=-k \mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }}$, where $k$ is a constant and $\mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }}$ is the velocity of the particle relative to the bowl. (a) If the particle is at the bottom of the bowl $(\theta=0)$, it is clearly in equilibrium. Show that if $\Omega>\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}}$, there is a second equilibrium value of $\theta$ and determine its value.

(b) Suppose the particle is in equilibrium at the bottom of the bowl. To describe the motion of the particle in the vicinity of the equilibrium point, we construct a local inertial Cartesian coordinate system $(x, y, z)$ and neglect the curvature of the bowl except in calculating the gravitational restoring force. Show that for $|x| \ll R,|y| \ll R$, the particle position satisfies $x=\operatorname{Re}\left(x_{0} e^{\lambda t}\right), y=\operatorname{Re}\left(y_{0} e^{\lambda t}\right)$, where

$$
\left(\lambda^{2}+\frac{k \lambda}{M}+\frac{g}{R}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{k}{M}\right)^{2} \Omega^{2}=0 .
$$

(c) Find the angular speed of the bowl, $\Omega_{0}$, for which the particle's motion is periodic.

(d) There is a transition from stable to unstable at $\Omega=\Omega_{0}$. By considering behavior of frequencies in the vicinity of $\Omega_{0}$, prove that the motion is stable for $\Omega<\Omega_{0}$ and unstable for $\Omega>\Omega_{0}$.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-188.jpg?height=384&width=338&top_left_y=1097&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 1.77.

\section{Solution:}

In a frame rotating with angular velocity $\boldsymbol{\Omega}$, the equation of motion of a particle of mass $M$ is by Problem 1094

$$
\mathbf{F}=M \mathbf{a}^{\prime}+2 M \mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+M \boldsymbol{\Omega} \times(\mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{r})+M \dot{\Omega} \times \mathbf{r},
$$

where $\mathbf{a}^{\prime}, \mathbf{v}^{\prime}$ are the acceleration and velocity in the rotating frame. For the rotating frame, choose a spherical frame $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ attached to the bowl with origin $O$ at the center of the bowl, then $\dot{\Omega}=0$. In the spherical coordinate frame, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\mathbf{e}}_{r} &=\dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\varphi}, \\
\dot{\mathbf{e}}_{\theta} &=-\dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{r}+\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, \\
\dot{\mathbf{e}}_{\varphi} &=-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then for a particle at $\mathbf{r}=r \mathbf{e}_{r}$, the velocity is

$$
\mathbf{v}=\dot{r} \mathbf{e}_{r}+r \dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+r \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi},
$$

and the acceleration is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{a}=&\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \mathbf{e}_{r} \\
&+\left(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta\right) \mathbf{e}_{\theta} \\
&+(r \ddot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 \dot{r} \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 r \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta) \mathbf{e}_{\varphi} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) For the particle in the rotating bowl, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{\Omega}=-\Omega \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}+\Omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} \\
\mathbf{r}=R \mathbf{e}_{r}, \quad \dot{r}=\ddot{r}=0, \quad \quad \mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }}=R \dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+R \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, \\
\mathbf{F}=M_{\mathbf{g}}+\mathbf{N}-k \mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }}
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \mathbf{g} &=M g \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-M g \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, \\
\mathbf{N} &=-N \mathbf{e}_{r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the equations of the motion of the particle in the rotating frame in the $e_{\theta}$ and $e_{\varphi}$ directions are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M R \ddot{\theta}-M R \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta \\
&=-M g \sin \theta-k R \dot{\theta}-2 M R \Omega \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \theta+M R \Omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
M R \ddot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 M R \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta=-k R \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 M R \Omega \dot{\theta} \cos \theta .
$$

At equilibrium, $\dot{\theta}=0, \dot{\varphi}=0, \ddot{\theta}=0, \ddot{\varphi}=0$, and we obtain

$$
-M g \sin \theta+M R \Omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta=0,
$$

which gives

$$
\sin \theta=0, \quad \text { or } \quad \cos \theta=\frac{g}{R \Omega^{2}} \text {. }
$$

Hence $\theta=0$ is an equilibrium position. If $\Omega>\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}}$ there is another equilibrium position

$$
\theta=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{R \Omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

(b) Use Cartesian coordinates $(x, y, z)$ for the local inertial frame with origin at $\theta=0$ at the bottom of the bowl and the $z$-axis along the axis of rotation. In this frame, the position vector of the particle, which is near the bottom of the bowl, is

$$
\mathbf{r}^{\prime}=x \mathbf{i}+y \mathbf{j}+z \mathbf{k} \approx x \mathbf{i}+y \mathbf{j}
$$

neglecting the curvature of gthe bowl, and its equation of motion is

$$
M \ddot{\mathbf{r}}^{\prime}=M \mathbf{g}-k \mathbf{V}_{\mathrm{rel}}+\mathbf{N} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-190.jpg?height=434&width=413&top_left_y=1181&top_left_x=543)

Fig. 1.78.

As shown in Fig. 1.78, the component of the force $\mathbf{N}$ along $\mathbf{r}$ is approximately zero and the component of $M g$ along $\mathbf{r}$ is

$$
-M g \sin \theta \cos \varphi \mathbf{i}-M g \sin \theta \sin \varphi \mathbf{j} \approx-\frac{M g x}{R} \mathbf{i}-\frac{M g y}{R} \mathbf{j}
$$

as $\sin \theta \approx \frac{r^{\prime}}{R}, \cos \varphi \approx \frac{x}{r^{\prime}}, \sin \varphi \approx \frac{y}{r^{\prime}}$. Also as $\dot{\mathbf{r}}^{\prime}=\mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }}+\Omega \times \mathbf{r}^{\prime}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
-k \mathbf{V}_{\text {rel }} &=-k \dot{\mathbf{r}}^{\prime}+k \Omega \times \mathbf{r}^{\prime} \\
&=-k(\dot{x}+y \Omega) \mathbf{i}-k(\dot{y}-x \Omega) \mathbf{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x=x_{0} e^{\lambda t}, y=y_{0} e^{\lambda t}$ and the above becomes

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(\lambda^{2}+\frac{k}{M} \lambda+\frac{g}{R}\right) x_{0}+\frac{k \Omega}{M} y_{0}=0, \\
-\frac{k \Omega}{M} x_{0}+\left(\lambda^{2}+\frac{k}{M} \lambda+\frac{g}{R}\right) y_{0}=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

For a non-zero solution, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\lambda^{2}+\frac{k}{M} \lambda+\frac{g}{R} & \frac{k \Omega}{M} \\
-\frac{k \Omega}{M} & \lambda^{2}+\frac{k \lambda}{M}+\frac{g}{R}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\lambda^{2}+\frac{k \lambda}{M}+\frac{g}{R}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{k \Omega}{M}\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

Hence if this condition holds, we can describe the particle's position by

$$
x=\operatorname{Re}\left(x_{0} e^{\lambda t}\right), \quad y=\operatorname{Re}\left(y_{0} e^{\lambda t}\right) .
$$

This conclusion is valid only for $|x| \ll R,|y| \ll R$ since we have neglected the curvature and considered the particle as moving in a horizontal plane.

(c) The left-hand side of (1) can be factorized and shown to have solutions

$$
\lambda^{2}+\frac{k \lambda}{M}+\frac{g}{R}=\pm i \frac{k \Omega}{M} .
$$

For periodic motion, $\lambda$ must be imaginary, $\lambda=i \omega$, where $\omega$ is real. Equating the real and imaginary parts on both sides, we have

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{g}{R} \quad \text { and } \quad \omega=\pm \Omega .
$$

To satisfy these we require that

$$
\Omega=\pm \sqrt{\frac{g}{R}}=\pm \Omega_{0}
$$

for the motion to be periodic. Note that the ' $+$ ' and '-' signs correspond to two opposite directions of rotation.

(d) As has been shown in (a), if $\Omega<\Omega_{0}$, there is only one equilibrium position $\theta=0$. The equilibrium at this point is stable. For $\Omega>\Omega_{0}$, there are two equilibrium positions $\theta=0$ and $\theta=\arccos \left(\frac{\Omega_{0}^{2}}{\Omega^{2}}\right)$. However the equilibrium at the former position is now unstable, so that the stable equilibrium is shifted to the latter position if $\Omega>\Omega_{0}$. Hence for $\theta=0$, there is a transition from stable to unstable at $\Omega=\Omega_{0}$.

\section{7}

A particle of mass $m$ can slide without friction on the inside of a small tube bent in the form of a circle of radius $a$. The tube rotates about a vertical diameter at a constant rate of $\omega \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}$ as shown in Fig. 1.79. Write the differential equation of motion. If the particle is disturbed slightly from its unstable equilibrium position at $\theta=0$, find the position of maximum kinetic energy.

(SUNY, Buffalo )

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-192.jpg?height=434&width=340&top_left_y=983&top_left_x=590)

Fig. $1.79$.

\section{Solution:}

In a rotating coordinate frame $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ attached to the circular tube, we have (Problem 1094)

$$
\mathbf{F}=m \mathbf{a}^{\prime}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}),
$$

with 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=m \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{N} \\
&=-m g \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}+m g \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+N \mathbf{e}_{r}, \\
\boldsymbol{\omega} &=\omega \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, \\
\mathbf{a}^{\prime} &=-a \dot{\theta}^{2} \mathbf{e}_{r}+a \ddot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, \\
\mathbf{v}^{\prime} &=a \dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, \quad \mathbf{r}=a \mathbf{e}_{r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The equation for the motion in the $\mathbf{e}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ direction is then

$$
m a \ddot{\theta}=m g \sin \theta+m a \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta .
$$

As $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{d \dot{\theta}}{d \theta} \frac{d}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$, the above with the initial condition $\theta=\dot{\theta}=0$ at $t=0$ gives

$$
a \dot{\theta}^{2}=a \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2 g(1-\cos \theta) .
$$

In an inertial frame that instantaneously coincides with the rotating frame, the velocity of the particle is

$$
\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{v}^{\prime}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}=a \dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+a \omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi},
$$

and its kinetic energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+a^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left[\omega^{2} a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2 g a(1-\cos \theta)+\omega^{2} a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right] \\
&=m a\left[\omega^{2} a \sin ^{2} \theta+g(1-\cos \theta)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $E$ to be a maximum at $\theta_{0}$, we require

$$
\left(\frac{d E}{d \theta}\right)_{\theta_{0}}=0, \quad\left(\frac{d^{2} E}{d \theta^{2}}\right)_{\theta_{0}}<0 .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d E}{d \theta} &=m a\left[2 \omega^{2} a \sin \theta \cos \theta+g \sin \theta\right]=0 \\
\frac{d^{2} E}{d \theta^{2}} &=m a\left[4 \omega^{2} a \cos ^{2} \theta+g \cos \theta-2 \omega^{2} a\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

we have for the position of maximum kinetic energy 

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \theta_{0}=\pi \quad \text { if } \quad \omega^{2}<\frac{g}{2 a} \text {, } \\
& \theta_{0}=\arccos \left(\frac{-g}{2 \omega^{2} a}\right) \quad \text { if } \quad \omega^{2}>\frac{g}{2 a} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{8}

Let $S$ be a set of axes centered at the earth's center, with the $z$-axis pointing north, forming an inertial frame. Let $S^{\prime}$ be similarly placed, but rotating with the earth.

(a) Write down the non-relativistic equation giving the transformation of the time derivative of any vector from $S^{\prime}$ to $S$. Use this to derive an expression for the Coriolis force experienced by a body moving in $S^{\prime}$. Define all symbols.

(b) In the northern hemisphere, find the direction of the Coriolis force on a body moving eastward and on one moving vertically upward.

(c) Consider a body dropped from a height of 10 feet at a latitude of $30^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$. Find, approximately, the horizontal deflection due to the Coriolis effect when it reaches the ground. Neglect air resistance.

$(S U N Y$, Buffalo $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $X Y Z$ be the inertial reference frame $S$ and $X^{\prime} Y^{\prime} Z^{\prime}$ the rotating frame $S^{\prime}$ fixed to the earth which rotates with angular velocity $\omega$. In $S^{\prime}$, an arbitrary vector $\mathbf{A}$ can be written as

$$
\mathbf{A}=A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k} .
$$

In $S$, the time derivative of $\mathbf{A}$ is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\left(\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k}\right)+\left(A_{x} \frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}+A_{y} \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}+A_{z} \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}\right) .
$$

Let $d^{*} / d t$ denote time derivative in $S^{\prime}$, then

$$
\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k} .
$$

The kinematics of a rigid body gives 

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{i}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{j}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{k} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d^{*} A}{d t}+\omega \times\left(A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k}\right)=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}+\omega \times \mathbf{A}
$$

Thus for the radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ to a point $P$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t} &=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} \\
\frac{d^{2} r}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{d^{*}}{d t}\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right)+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right) \\
&=\frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+\frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that in the above

$$
\frac{d^{*} \omega}{d t}=\frac{d \omega}{d t}-\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}=\frac{d \omega}{d t} .
$$

Newton's second law applies to the inertial fraine, so for a particle of mass $m$ at $P$ acted on by a force $\mathbf{F}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{F}=m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=m \frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+m \frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

Denoting $\frac{d^{*}}{d t}$ by a dot and noting that for the earth $\dot{\omega}=0$, we write the above as

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\mathbf{F}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})
$$

for the rotating frame. This shows that Newton's second law can still be considered valid if, in addition to $F$, we introduce two fictitious forces: $-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}$, the Coriolis force, and $-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})$, the centrifugal force. Thus a body of mass $m$ moving on earth with a velocity $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}$ is seen by an observer on the earth to suffer a Coriolis force $-2 m \omega \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}$.

(b) Choose for $S^{\prime}$ a frame fixed at a point on the surface of the earth at latitude $\lambda$ and let its orthogonal unit vectors $\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}, \mathbf{k}$ be directed toward the south, the east and vertically upward respectively. Then

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=-\omega \cos \lambda \mathbf{i}+\omega \sin \lambda \mathbf{k} .
$$

(1) When the body moves eastward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{y} \mathbf{j}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{\varepsilon}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \dot{y} \sin \lambda \mathbf{i}+2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda \mathbf{k},
$$

which has magnitude

$$
\left|\mathbf{F}_{c}\right|=\sqrt{(2 m \omega \dot{y} \sin \lambda)^{2}+(2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda)^{2}}=2 m \omega \dot{y}
$$

and is pointing south at an inclination angle $\phi$ given by

$$
\tan \phi=\frac{\cos \lambda}{\sin \lambda}=\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\lambda\right) .
$$

(2) When the body moves upward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{z} \mathbf{k}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{c}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=-2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda \mathbf{j} \text {, }
$$

which has magnitude $2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda$ and direction toward the west.

(c) The equations of motion for the free-fall body in $S^{\prime}$ are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
m \ddot{x}=2 m \omega \dot{y} \sin \lambda, \\
m \ddot{y}=-2 m \omega(\dot{x} \sin \lambda+\dot{z} \cos \lambda), \\
m \ddot{z}=-m g+2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda,
\end{array}\right.
$$

with initial conditions $x=y=0, z=h=10 \mathrm{ft}, \dot{x}=\dot{y}=\dot{z}=0$ at $t=0$. Integrating and using the initial conditions, we obtain

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{x}=2 \omega y \sin \lambda, \\
\dot{y}=-2 \omega[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda], \\
\dot{z}=-g t+2 \omega y \cos \lambda .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Substituting these into the original set of equations, we obtain

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\ddot{x}=-4 \omega^{2}[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda] \sin \lambda, \\
\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos \lambda-4 \omega^{2} y, \\
\ddot{z}=-g-4 \omega^{2}[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda] \cos \lambda .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Neglecting the terms involving $\omega^{2}$, we have approximately

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\ddot{x}=0, \\
\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos \lambda y, \\
\ddot{z}=-g .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Integrating, applying the initial conditions and eliminating $t$, we obtain

$$
y^{2}=\left(\frac{8 \omega^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda}{9 g}\right)(h-z)^{3} .
$$

When the body reaches the ground, $z=0$,

$$
y=\left(\frac{2 \omega \cos \lambda}{3}\right) \sqrt{\frac{2 h^{3}}{g}} .
$$

With $h=10 \mathrm{ft}=3.05 \mathrm{~m}, \lambda=30^{\circ}$, we find $y=1.01 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$. Hence the deflection due to the Coriolis effect is toward the east and has a magnitude $0.01 \mathrm{~cm}$.

\section{DYNAMICS OF A SYSTEM OF POINT MASSES (1109-1144)}

\section{9}

A cart of mass $M$ has a pole on it from which a ball of mass $\mu$ hangs from a thin string attached at point $P$. The cart and ball have initial velocity $V$. The cart crashes onto another cart of mass $m$ and sticks to it (Fig. 1.80). If the length of the string is $R$, show that the smallest initial velocity for which the ball can go in circles around point $P$ is $V=[(m+M) / m] \sqrt{5 g R}$. Neglect friction and assume $M, m \gg \mu$.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-197.jpg?height=256&width=448&top_left_y=1227&top_left_x=495)

Fig. $1.80$.

\section{Solution:}

As $\mu \ll m, M$, momentum conservation

$$
M V=(M+m) V^{\prime}
$$

gives for the velocity of the two carts after collision, 

$$
V^{\prime}=\frac{M V}{M+m} .
$$

Consider the circular motion of the ball atop the cart $M$ if it were stationary. If at the lowest and highest points the ball has speeds $V_{1}$ and $V_{2}$ respectively, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2} \mu V_{1}^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} \mu V_{2}^{2}+2 \mu g R, \\
\frac{\mu V_{2}^{2}}{R} &=T+\mu g,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $T$ is the tension in the string when the ball is at the highest point. The smallest $V_{2}$ is given by $T=0$. Hence the smallest $V_{1}$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2} \mu V_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mu g R+2 \mu g R,
$$

i.e.

$$
V_{1}=\sqrt{5 g R} .
$$

With the cart moving, $V_{1}$ is the velocity of the ball relative to the cart. As the ball has initial velocity $V$ and the cart has velocity $V^{\prime}$ after the collision, the velocity of the ball relative to the cart after the collision is $V-V^{\prime}$. Hence the smallest $V$ for the ball to go round in a circle after the collision is given by

$$
V-V^{\prime}=V-\frac{M V}{M+m}=\sqrt{5 g R},
$$

i.e.

$$
V=\frac{M+m}{m} \sqrt{5 g R} .
$$

\section{0}

A cart of mass $m$ moves with speed $v$ as it approaches a cart of mass $3 m$ that is initially at rest. The spring is compressed during the head-on collision (Fig. 1.81).

(a) What is the speed of the cart with mass $3 \mathrm{~m}$ at the instant of maximum spring compression assuming conservation of energy?

(b) How would your answer differ if energy is not conserved? (c) What is the final velocity of the heavier cart after a long time has passed, if energy is conserved?

(d) Give the final velocity of the heavier cart in a completely inelastic collision.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) When the spring is at maximum compression, the two carts are nearest each other and at that instant move with a velocity $v^{\prime}$, say. Conservation of momentum gives

$$
m v=(m+3 m) v^{\prime},
$$

i.e.

$$
v^{\prime}=\frac{v}{4} \text {. }
$$

Thus the heavier cart has speed $\frac{v}{4}$ at that instant.

(b) Even if mechanical energy is not conserved, the above result still holds since it has been derived from conservation of momentum which holds as long as no external force is acting.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-199.jpg?height=136&width=433&top_left_y=1099&top_left_x=496)

Fig. $1.81$.

(c) Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{m v^{2}}{2} &=\frac{m v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{3 m v_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2}, \\
m v &=m v_{1}^{1}+3 m v_{2}^{\prime},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v_{1}^{\prime}, v_{2}^{\prime}$ are respectively the velocities after collision of the lighter and heavier carts. Hence the heavier cart has final velocity

$$
v_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{2 m v}{m+3 m}=\frac{v}{2} .
$$

(d) If the collision is completely inelastic, the two carts will move together after collision. Their velocity is then $\frac{v}{4}$ as given in (a). 

\section{1}

In terms of $G, L$ and the masses:

(a) What is the rotational period of an equal-mass $\left(M_{1}=M_{2}=M\right)$ double star of separation $L$ ?

(b) What is the period of an unequal-mass $\left(M_{1} \neq M_{2}\right)$ double star of separation $L$ ?

(c) What is the period of an equal-mass equilateral-triangle (side $L$ ) triple star?

(d) What is the period of an unequal-mass $\left(M_{1} \neq M_{2} \neq M_{3}\right)$ equilateral triple star?

(Wisconsin )

\section{Solution:}

(a) Equal-mass double star

The gravitational force on each star is $f=G M^{2} / L^{2}$. The radius of circular orbit of each star with respect to the center of mass frame of the double star is $R=L / 2$. The centripetal acceleration of each star is $a=v^{2} / R$, where $v$ is the speed of each star in the cms frame. Using these, we have

$$
\frac{M v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M^{2}}{L^{2}},
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{G M R}{L^{2}}=\frac{G M}{2 L} .
$$

Hence the period of the double star is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi R}{v}=\frac{\pi L}{\sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 L}}}=\pi L \sqrt{\frac{2 L}{G M}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-200.jpg?height=107&width=397&top_left_y=1671&top_left_x=578)

Fig. $1.82$. (b) Unequal-mass double star

Let $O$ be the center of mass of the double star. Then, as in Fig. 1.82,

$$
l_{1}=\frac{M_{2} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}}, \quad l_{2}=\frac{M_{1} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}} .
$$

For $M_{1}, f=G M_{1} M_{2} / L^{2}$, the radius of circular motion is $l_{1}$, and the centripetal acceleration is $a_{1}=v_{1}^{2} / l_{1}$. Hence

$$
\frac{M_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{l_{1}}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{2}}{L^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
v_{1}^{2}=\frac{G M_{2}}{L} \frac{l_{1}}{L}=\frac{G M_{2}}{L} \frac{M_{2}}{M_{1}+M_{2}} .
$$

The rotational period of $M_{1}$ is then

$$
T_{1}=2 \pi \frac{l_{1}}{v_{1}}=2 \pi \frac{M_{2} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}} \frac{\sqrt{L\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}}{M_{2} \sqrt{G}}=2 \pi L \sqrt{\frac{L}{G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}} .
$$

Interchange of the subscripts 1 and 2 shows that this is also the period $T_{2}$ of $M_{2}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-201.jpg?height=310&width=286&top_left_y=1137&top_left_x=590)

Fig. 1.83.

(c) Equal-mass equilateral-triangle triple star

Let $O$ be the center of mass of the triple star (Fig. 1.83). Geometry gives $l_{1}=\sqrt{3} L / 3$. For $M_{1}$, the resultant of the gravitational forces due to the other two stars points towards $O$ and has magnitude $\left(2 G M^{2} / L^{2}\right) \cos 30^{\circ}=$ $\sqrt{3} G M^{2} / L^{2}$. If its speed is $v$, we have

$$
\frac{M v^{2}}{l_{1}}=\frac{\sqrt{3} G M^{2}}{L^{2}}
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{\sqrt{3} G M}{L} \frac{l_{1}}{L}=\frac{G M}{L} \text {, }
$$

so the period of the triple star is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi l_{1}}{v}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{3} \pi L \sqrt{\frac{L}{G M}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-202.jpg?height=277&width=318&top_left_y=593&top_left_x=624)

Fig. $1.84$

(d) Unequal-mass equilateral triple star

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 1.84. The coordinates of $M_{1}, M_{2}$ and $M_{3}$ are $(0,0),(L, 0)$ and $\left(L / 2, \frac{\sqrt{3} L}{2}\right)$ respectively, and the radius vector of the center of mass $C$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{c}=\frac{\sum_{i} M_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i}}{\sum_{i} M_{i}} &=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\left(M_{2} \mathbf{i}+\frac{1}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right) \\
&=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\left[\left(M_{2}+\frac{1}{2} M_{3}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The attractive forces exerted by $M_{2}$ and $M_{3}$ on $M_{1}$ are respectively

$$
\mathbf{f}_{12}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{2}}{L^{2}} \mathbf{i}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{3}}{L^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathbf{j}\right) \text {, }
$$

so that the resultant force on $M_{1}$ is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{f}_{1} &=\mathbf{f}_{12}+\mathbf{f}_{13} \\
&=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}}\left[\left(M_{2}+\frac{M_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that $\mathbf{f}_{\mathbf{1}}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{r}_{c}$. Its magnitude is

$$
f_{1}=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}} \sqrt{\left(\frac{M_{2}+M_{3}}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{3 M_{3}^{2}}{4}}=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}} .
$$

The radius of the circular orbit about the center of mass in which $M_{1}$ moves is

$$
R_{1}=r_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}} .
$$

Then the equation of the motion of $M_{1}$ is

$$
\frac{M_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}}\right) \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}
$$

giving for the speed $v_{1}$ of $M_{1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{1}^{2} &=\frac{G}{L} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}\left(\frac{R_{1}}{L}\right) \\
&=\frac{G}{L}\left(\frac{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the rotational period of $M_{1}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{1} &=\frac{2 \pi R_{1}}{v_{1}} \\
&=2 \pi L \sqrt{\frac{L}{G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}\right)}},
\end{aligned}
$$

which is obviously also the period of $M_{2}$ and $M_{3}$.

\section{2}

A particle of mass $m$, charge $q$, and initial velocity $v$ collides head-on with an identical particle initially at rest. What is the distance of closest approach between the two particles (in classical mechanics)? What is the velocity of each particle at the instant of closest approach? What is the final velocity of each particle? Justify your answers.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The relative velocity is zero when the two particles are at closest approach. Conservation of momentum then gives $m v=2 m v^{\prime}$ and $v^{\prime}=$ $v / 2$ as the velocity of each particle at the instant of closest approach. Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{2}=\frac{m v^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m v^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{r}
$$

and thus

$$
r=\frac{4 q^{2}}{m v^{2}}
$$

as the distance of closest approach. The final velocity of the incident particle is zero and that of the particle initially at rest is $v$. This can be seen from the symmetry of the problem.

\section{3}

Two steel spheres, the lower of radius $2 a$ and the upper of radius $a$, are dropped from a height $h$ (measured from the center of the large sphere) above a steel plate as shown in Fig. 1.85. Assuming the centers of the spheres always lie on a vertical line and all collisions are elastic, what is the maximum height the upper sphere will reach?

Hint: Assume the larger sphere collides with the plate and recoils before it collides with the small sphere.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let the mass of the smaller sphere be $m_{1}$ and that of the larger one $m_{2}$. Then $m_{2}=8 m_{1}$. The landing velocity of the larger sphere is $v_{2}=$ $\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}$ and its velocity immediately after bouncing back from the steel plate is still $v$ in magnitude. At this point, the descending velocity of the smaller sphere is $v_{1}=\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}=v_{2}$. Let the velocities of the larger and smaller spheres after elastic collision be $v_{2}^{\prime}$ and $v_{1}^{\prime}$ respectively 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-205.jpg?height=419&width=250&top_left_y=249&top_left_x=610)

Fig. $1.85$.

and take the upward direction as positive. Conservation of momentum and of mechanical energy give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{2} v_{2}-m_{1} v_{1} &=m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime}+m_{1} v_{2}^{\prime} \\
\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

whose solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&v_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{5 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{5}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}, \\
&v_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{23 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{23}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Conservation of the mechanical energy of the smaller sphere thus gives the maximum height (measured from the steel plate) of the smaller sphere as

$$
H=3 a+\frac{v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2 g}=3 a+\frac{529}{81}(h-2 a) .
$$

\section{4}

A railroad flatcar of mass $M$ can roll without friction along a straight horizontal track as shown in Fig. 1.86. $N$ men, each of mass $m$, are initially standing on the car which is at rest. (a) The $N$ men run to one end of the car in unison; their speed relative to the car is $V_{r}$ just before they jump off (all at the same time). Calculate the velocity of the car after the inen have jumped off.

(b) The $N$ men run off the car, one after the other (only one man running at a time), each reaching a speed $V_{r}$ relative to the car just before jumping off. Find an expression for the final velocity of the car.

(c) In which case, (a) or (b), does the car attain the greater velocity?

(CUSPEA)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-206.jpg?height=145&width=383&top_left_y=656&top_left_x=591)

Fig. 1.86.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As there is no horizontal external force acting, the center of mass of the system consisting of the flatcar and $N$ men remains stationary. Taking the $x$-axis along the track, we have for the center of mass,

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{\mathrm{cm}} &=\frac{M x_{\mathrm{car}}+N m x_{\operatorname{man}}}{M+N m}, \\
\dot{x}_{\mathrm{cm}} &=0=M \dot{x}_{\mathrm{car}}+N m \dot{x}_{\operatorname{man}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\dot{x}_{\text {car }}$ and $\dot{x}_{\text {man }}$ are respectively the velocities of the car and each man after the men have jumped off. Writing $\dot{x}_{\text {car }}=V_{\text {car }}$ and noting that $\dot{x}_{\text {man }}=V_{\text {car }}-V_{r}$, we have

$$
M V_{\text {car }}+N m\left(V_{\text {car }}-V_{r}\right)=0,
$$

giving

$$
V_{\text {car }}=\frac{N m V_{r}}{M+N m} .
$$

(b) Consider the transition from $n$ men to $(n-1)$ men on the car. Let $V_{n}$ be the velocity of the car when $n$ men are left on it. The total momentum of the car with the $n$ men is

$$
P_{n}=M V_{n}+n m V_{n} .
$$

When the $n$th man jumps off the car with a speed $V_{r}$ relative to the car, the momentum of the system consisting of the car and $n$ men is

$$
P_{n-1}=M V_{n-1}+(n-1) m V_{n-1}+m\left(V_{n-1}-V_{r}\right) .
$$

Momentum conservation $P_{n-1}=P_{n}$ gives

$$
(M+n m) V_{n}=(M+n m) V_{n-1}-m V_{r},
$$

or

$$
V_{n-1}=V_{n}+\frac{m V_{r}}{M+n m}
$$

Hence

$$
V_{n-s}=V_{n}+\sum_{i=1}^{s} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+(n-i+1) m} .
$$

As $n=N, V_{N}=0$ initially, we have for $s=N$,

$$
V_{0}=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+(N-i+1) m}=\sum_{n=1}^{N} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+n m} .
$$

(c) As

$$
\sum_{n=1}^{N} \frac{1}{M+n m}>\frac{N}{M+N m},
$$

the car in case (b) attains a greater final velocity.

\section{5}

A projectile of mass $m$ is shot (at velocity $V$ ) at a target of mass $M$, with a hole containing a spring of constant $k$. The target is initially at rest and can slide without friction on a horizontal surface (Fig. 1.87) . Find the distance $\Delta x$ that the spring compresses at maximum.

(CUSPEA)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-207.jpg?height=143&width=518&top_left_y=1684&top_left_x=460)

Fig. 1.87. 

\section{Solution:}

At the instant the spring compresses at maximum, the projectile $m$ and the target $M$ move with the same velocity $V_{e}$. Conservation of energy

$$
\frac{m V^{2}}{2}=\frac{m V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{M V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{k(\Delta x)^{2}}{2},
$$

and conservation of momentum

$$
m V=(m+M) V_{e}
$$

give

$$
\Delta x=\sqrt{\frac{m M}{k(m+M)}} V .
$$

\section{6}

A heavy star of mass $M$ and radius $R$ moves with velocity $\mathbf{V}$ through a very dilute gas of mass density $\rho$. It pulls particles toward itself by its gravitational field and captures all of the atoms that strike its surface. Find the drag force on the star with the approximation that the thermal velocities of the atoms are negligible relative to $|\mathbf{V}|$ and the interactions of atoms with each other can be neglected.

(CUSPEA)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-208.jpg?height=206&width=499&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=494)

Fig. $1.88$

\section{Solution:}

In a frame moving with the star, gas atoms move with velocity $-\mathbf{V}$ toward the star from infinity. Under the influence of the star's gravitational field, the trajectories of the gas atoms are as shown in Fig. 1.88. Let $b$ be the largest impact parameter for which a gas atom can just be captured by the star and $v$ the velocity of the gas atom just before capturing. Conservation of angular momentum gives

$$
v R=b V,
$$

and conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{v^{2}}{2}-\frac{G M}{R}=\frac{V^{2}}{2},
$$

from which we obtain

$$
b^{2}=\frac{R^{2}}{V^{2}}\left(V^{2}+\frac{2 G M}{R}\right) .
$$

The drag force on the star is equal to the momentum absorbed per unit time:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=\frac{d \mathbf{P}}{d t}=\lim _{\Delta t \rightarrow 0} \frac{\pi b^{2} V \Delta t \cdot \rho(-\mathbf{V})}{\Delta t} \\
&=-\pi b^{2} \rho V \mathbf{V}=-\frac{\pi R^{2} \rho}{V}\left(V^{2}+\frac{2 G M}{R}\right) \mathbf{V} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{7}

Consider a collection of point particles of mass $m$ moving in circular orbits about a common center each with the same kinetic energy. If the only force present is the mutual (Newtonian) gravitational force, what is the particle density as a function of radius $r$ from the center in order that the density remains constant in time?

(Assume that the density is spherically symmetric.)

\section{Solution:}

(Columbia)

Let $T$ be the kinetic energy of each particle. As it moves in a circular orbit of radius $r$ under the action of the mutual gravitational forces, we have

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G M m}{r^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{G M m}{2 r},
$$

giving

$$
M(r)=\frac{2 T r}{G m}
$$

as the total mass of the particles which move in a sphere of radius $r$ at the common center. As

$$
d M=4 \pi r^{2} \rho(r) d r
$$

we have

$$
\rho(r)=\frac{1}{4 \pi r^{2}} \frac{d M}{d r}=\frac{T}{2 \pi r^{2} G m},
$$

from which we obtain the particle density

$$
n(r)=\frac{\rho}{m}=\frac{T}{2 \pi r^{2} G m^{2}} .
$$

\section{8}

Given a system of $N$ point-masses with pairwise additive central forces, use Newton's second and third laws to demonstrate that the total angular momentum of this system is a constant. Does this calculation depend upon what point is chosen as the origin of coordinates?

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

The angular momentum of a system of $N$ point-masses about a fixed origin is by definition

$$
\mathbf{L}=\sum_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{p}_{i} .
$$

Newton's second law $\mathbf{F}_{i}=\frac{d \mathbf{p}_{i}}{d t}$ then gives

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=\sum_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{F}_{i}=\sum_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times \sum_{j \neq i} \mathbf{f}_{i j}=\sum_{i} \sum_{j \neq i} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{f}_{i j},
$$

where $\mathbf{f}_{i j}$ is the force the $j$ th mass exerts on the $i$ th mass. For two masses $i$ and $j$, Newton's third law gives

$$
\mathbf{f}_{i j}=-\mathbf{f}_{j i},
$$

and so

$$
\mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{f}_{i j}+\mathbf{r}_{j} \times \mathbf{f}_{j i}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{i}-\mathbf{r}_{j}\right) \times \mathbf{f}_{i j}=0,
$$

since $\mathbf{r}_{i}-\mathbf{r}_{j}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{f}_{i j}$. As the sum $\sum_{i} \sum_{j \neq i}\left(\mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{f}_{i j}\right)$ is due to pairs of forces like $\mathbf{f}_{i j}$ and $\mathbf{f}_{j i}$, we have

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\mathbf{L}=\text { constant } .
$$

As the origin in this proof is arbitrary, the conclusion is independent of the choice of the origin of coordinates.

\section{9}

Two stars with masses $M$ and $m$ separated by a distance $d$ are in circular orbits around the stationary center of mass. The stars may be approximated by point masses. In a supernova explosion, the star of mass $M$ loses a mass $\Delta M$. The explosion is instantaneous, spherically symmetric, and exerts no reaction force on the remnant. It also has no direct effect on the other star. Show that the remaining binary system is bound when $\Delta M<(M+m) / 2$.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-211.jpg?height=504&width=455&top_left_y=1147&top_left_x=507)

Fig. 1.89.

\section{Solution:}

Take the center of mass as the origin of a fixed frame and let $r_{1}, r_{2}$ be the distance from the center of mass to $M, m$ respectively before the explosion. We have

$$
r_{1}+r_{2}=d, \quad r_{1}=\frac{m d}{M+m}, \quad r_{2}=\frac{M d}{M+m} .
$$

The angular velocity $\omega$ of the circular motion of $M$ satisfies

$$
M r_{1} \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{d^{2}}, \quad m r_{2} \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{d^{2}}
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{G(M+m)}{d^{3}} .
$$

After $M$ explodes a mass $\Delta M$ leaves the star. As the explosion exerts no reaction force on the remnant and has no direct effect on the other star, the total potential and kinetic energies of the two stars in a frame attached to the new center of mass are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&V=\frac{-G(M-\Delta M) m}{d} \\
&T=\frac{(M-\Delta M)\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}}{2}+\frac{m\left(r_{2} \omega\right)^{2}}{2}-T_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $T_{0}$ is the kinetic energy of the new system in the fixed frame if its total mass were concentrated at the center of mass. The momentum of the new system in the fixed frame (Fig. $1.89$ ) is

$$
(M-\Delta M+m) v=m r_{2} \omega-(M-\Delta M) r_{1} \omega=r_{1} \omega \Delta M
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of the center of mass of the new system, as the momentum of the original system $m r_{2} \omega-M r_{1} \omega=0$. Therefore, the total energy of the new system in the new center of mass frame is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
T+V=&-\frac{G(M-\Delta M)}{d} m+\frac{1}{2}(M-\Delta M)\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(r_{2} \omega\right)^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2}(M-\Delta M+m) \cdot \frac{(\Delta M)^{2}}{(M-\Delta M+m)^{2}}\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{G M m}{d}+\frac{1}{2} M\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(r_{2} \omega\right)^{2}+\frac{G m \Delta M}{d} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} \Delta M\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}-\frac{(\Delta M)^{2}\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}}{2(M-\Delta M+m)} \\
=&-\frac{G M m}{2 d}+\frac{G m \Delta M}{d}-\frac{1}{2} \Delta M\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}-\frac{(\Delta M)^{2}}{2\left(M-\Delta M+m^{2}\right)}\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2} \\
=&-\frac{1}{2} M d r_{1} \omega^{2}+d r_{1} \omega^{2} \Delta M-\frac{1}{2} \Delta M\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}-\frac{(\Delta M)^{2}\left(r_{1} \omega\right)^{2}}{2(M-\Delta M+m)} \\
=&-\frac{1}{2} r_{1} \omega^{2}\left[M d-2 d \Delta M+r_{1} \Delta M+\frac{r_{1}(\Delta M)^{2}}{M-\Delta M+m}\right] \\
=&-\frac{d r_{1} \omega^{2}}{2(M-\Delta M+m)}(2 \Delta M-M-m)(\Delta M-M) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition for the new two-star system to be bound is $T+V<0$, i.e.

$$
2 \Delta M<M+m, \quad \Delta M<M,
$$

or

$$
2 \Delta M>M+m, \quad \Delta M>M .
$$

As $\Delta M<M$, the required condition is

$$
\Delta M<\frac{M+m}{2} .
$$

\section{0}

The captain of a small boat becalmed in the equatorial doldrums decides to resort to the expedience of raising the anchor $(m=200 \mathrm{~kg})$ to the top of the mast $(s=20 \mathrm{~m})$. The rest of the boat has a mass of $M=1000 \mathrm{~kg}$.

(a) Why will the boat begin to move?

(b) In which direction will it move? (c) How fast will it move?

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The vertical motion of the anchor causes a Coriolis force $-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}$, where $\mathbf{v}$ is the velocity of the anchor and $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ the angular velocity of the earth, and so the boat moves.

(b) As $\omega$ points to the north and $\mathbf{v}$ is vertically upward, the Coriolis force points toward the west. Hence the boat will move westward.

(c) As the total angular momentum of the boat and anchor with respect to the center of mass of the earth in an inertial frame is conserved, we have

$$
(M+m) r^{2} \omega_{0}=\left[M r^{2}+m(r+s)^{2}\right] \omega,
$$

where $\omega_{0}$ and $\omega$ are the angular velocities of the earth and the boat respectively, $r$ is the radius of the earth, giving

$$
\frac{\omega}{\omega_{0}} \approx \frac{(M+m) r^{2}}{(M+m) r^{2}+2 m r s},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\omega-\omega_{0}}{\omega_{0}} \approx \frac{-2 m s}{(M+m) r+2 m s} \approx \frac{-2 m s}{(M+m) r} .
$$

Hence the relative velocity of the boat with respect to the earth is

$$
u=r\left(\omega-\omega_{0}\right)=\frac{-2 m s \omega_{0}}{M+m}=-4.9 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The negative sign indicates that the boat moves westward.

\section{1}

A simple classical model of the $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ molecule would be a linear structure of three masses with the electrical forces between the ions represented by two identical springs of equilibrium length $l$ and force constant $k$, as shown in Fig. 1.90. Assume that only motion along the original equilibrium line is possible, i.e. ignore rotations. Let $m$ be the mass of $\mathrm{O}^{-}$and $M$ be the mass of $\mathrm{C}^{++}$.

(a) How many vibrational degrees of freedom does this system have?

(b) Define suitable coordinates and determine the equation of motion of the masses. (c) Seek a solution to the equations of motion in which all particles oscillate with a common frequency (normal modes) and calculate the possible frequencies.

(d) Calculate the relative amplitudes of the displacements of the particles for each of these modes and describe the nature of the motion for each mode. You may use a sketch as part of your description.

(e) Which modes would you expect to radiate electromagnetically and what is the multipole order of each?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-215.jpg?height=140&width=305&top_left_y=692&top_left_x=275)

Fig. 1.90.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-215.jpg?height=148&width=341&top_left_y=682&top_left_x=887)

Fig. 1.91.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The system has two vibrational degrees of freedom.

(b) Let $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and $x_{3}$ be the displacements of $\mathrm{O}^{-}, \mathrm{C}^{++}$, and $\mathrm{O}^{-}$ from their equilibrium positions respectively, as shown in Fig. 1.91. The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x}_{1} &=k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right), \\
M \ddot{x}_{2} &=k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)-k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)=k\left(x_{1}-2 x_{2}+x_{3}\right), \\
m \ddot{x}_{3} &=-k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Let $x_{1}=A_{1} \cos \omega t, x_{2}=A_{2} \cos \omega t$ and $x_{3}=A_{3} \cos \omega t$ in the equations above. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right) A_{1}-k A_{2} &=0, \\
-k A_{1}+\left(2 k-M \omega^{2}\right) A_{2}-k A_{3} &=0, \\
-k A_{1}+\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right) A_{3} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $A_{1}, A_{2}, A_{3}$ not to be identically zero, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
k-m \omega^{2} & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-M \omega^{2} & -k \\
0 & -k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

which has solutions

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 m+M) k}{m M}}, \quad \text { and } \quad \omega_{3}=0 .
$$

Angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ correspond to possible vibrations, while $\omega_{3}$ corresponds to the translational oscillations of the molecule as a whole.

(d) Substituting $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ into the equations for $A_{1}, A_{2}$ and $A_{3}$, we find that relative amplitudes are $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ 0 \\ -1\end{array}\right)$ for $\omega_{1}$ and $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ \frac{-2 m}{M} \\ 1\end{array}\right)$ for $\omega_{2}$, as depicted in Fig. $1.92$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-216.jpg?height=304&width=337&top_left_y=732&top_left_x=608)

Fig. 1.92.

(e) The $\omega_{1}$ mode will not give rise to radiation because the center of the charges remains stationary in the oscillations. The $\omega_{2}$ mode can give rise to dipole radiation, while quadruple and higher multipole radiations are possible for both $\omega_{2}$ and $\omega_{3}$ modes.

\section{2}

Take a very long chain of beads connected by identical springs of spring constant $K$ and equilibrium length $a$, as shown in Fig. 1.93. Each bead is free to oscillate along the $x$ direction. All beads have mass $m$ except for one which has mass $m_{0}<m$. The mass of the spring is negligibly small.

(a) Far from the "special" bead, what is the relation between the wave vector and the frequency of the resulting oscillation?

(b) For a wave of wave vector $k$, what is the reflection probability when the wave hits the special bead?

Hint for part (b): Try a solution of the form 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-217.jpg?height=221&width=779&top_left_y=220&top_left_x=346)

Fig, $1.93$.

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
x_{n}=A e^{i k a n}+B e^{-i k a n} & \text { for } & n<0, \\
x_{n}=C e^{i k a n} & \text { for } & n>0,
\end{array}
$$

where $A, B$, and $C$ are functions of time.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) For $n \neq 0$,

$$
\ddot{x}_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left[\left(x_{n}-x_{n-1}\right)+\left(x_{n}-x_{n+1}\right)\right]=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2 x_{n}-x_{n+1}-x_{n-1}\right) .
$$

Setting $x_{n}=A e^{i(k a n-\omega t)}$ in the above, we obtain

$$
-\omega^{2} x_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2-e^{i k a}-e^{-i k a}\right) x_{n}=-\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] x_{n},
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] .
$$

(b) Try a solution of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{n}=\left(A e^{i k a n}+B e^{-i k a n}\right) e^{-i \omega t} \quad \text { for } \quad n \leq 0, \\
& x_{n}=C e^{i(k a n-\omega t)} \quad \text { for } \quad n \geq 0 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

For $n=0$, the above implies $C=A+B$. Substituting the solution into the equation of the motion of the $n=0$ bead,

$$
\ddot{x}_{0}=-\frac{K}{m_{0}}\left(2 x_{0}-x_{1}-x_{-1}\right),
$$

we find

$$
\frac{\omega^{2} m_{0}}{K}(A+B)=2(A+B)-(A+B) e^{i k a}-A e^{-i k a}-B e^{i k a}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
A &=\left[\frac{m_{0}}{m-m_{0}}-\frac{m}{m-m_{0}} \frac{1-e^{i k a}}{1-\cos (k a)}\right] B \\
&=\left\{-1+\frac{i m \sin (k a)}{\left(m-m_{0}\right)[1-\cos (k a)]}\right\} B
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the reflection probability is

$$
\left|\frac{B}{A}\right|^{2}=\left\{1+\left(\frac{m}{m-m_{0}}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{\sin (k a)}{1-\cos (k a)}\right]^{2}\right\}^{-1}
$$

\section{3}

Three bodies of equal mass $m$ and indicated by $i=1,2,3$ are constrained to perform small oscillations along different coplanar axes forming $120^{\circ}$ angles at their common intersection, as shown in Fig. 1.94. Identical coupling springs hold these bodies near equilibrium positions which are at a distance $l$ from the intersection on each axis, that is, the equilibrium length of each spring is $\sqrt{3} l$. The following questions can be answered without resorting to general analytic procedures.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-218.jpg?height=492&width=479&top_left_y=1231&top_left_x=494)

Fig, 1.94.

(a) Show that the equations of motion of the three bodies are represented by the coupled system 

$$
\frac{m d^{2} x_{i}}{d t^{2}}=-K x_{i}-k\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right),
$$

where $x_{i}(t)+l$ indicates their respective distances from the intersection. (Specifically, both $K$ and $k$ equal $3 / 4$ of each spring constant.)

(b) Verify that one normal mode is totally symmetric:

$$
x_{1}(t)=x_{2}(t)=x_{3}(t),
$$

and determine its frequency.

(c) Show that the remaining normal modes are degenerate and determine their frequency.

(d) Find a pair of real solutions $\left\{x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t), x_{3}(t)\right\}$ that represent orthogonal degenerate normal modes.

(e) Find an alternative pair of complex conjugate solutions that represent orthogonal degenerate normal modes.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let the constant of each spring be $\eta$ and consider particles $i$ and $j$ which are located at $x_{i}$ and $x_{j}$ from their respective equilibrium positions. The stretch of the spring between the two particles is $\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right) \cos 30^{\circ}$, so the potential energy of the system is

$$
U=\frac{3 \eta}{8}\left[\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{2}+x_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}+x_{1}\right)^{2}\right] .
$$

The force acting on the $i$ th particle is then

$$
-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x_{i}}=-\frac{3 \eta}{4}\left(x_{i}+\sum_{j} x_{j}\right)
$$

giving its equation of motion as

$$
