m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i}-k\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right)
$$

with $K=k=\frac{3 \eta}{4}$.

(b) If $x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}$, all the three equations reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-(K+3 k) x_{i} .
$$

The solution is

$$
x_{i}=a \cos (\omega t+\varphi)
$$

with

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+3 k}{m}} .
$$

(c) The remaining two normal modes are orthogonal to the above symmetric mode. They satisfy the condition

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=0,
$$

for which the equations of motion reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i} .
$$

Setting $x_{i}=b_{i} \cos \left(\omega^{\prime} t+\varphi^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
\sum_{i} b_{i}=0, \quad \omega^{\prime 2}=\frac{K}{m} .
$$

The frequency is the same for both modes, and hence they are degenerate.

(d) The two orthogonal degenerate normal modes have amplitudes $b_{1}$, $b_{2}, b_{3}$ satisfying $\sum_{i} b_{i}=0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& b_{1}=0, \quad b_{2}=-b_{3}=c, \\
& b_{1}=c, \quad b_{2}=b_{3}=-\frac{c}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

give a pair of real solutions, where $c$ is an arbitrary real number.

(e) Alternatively, allowing complex amplitudes,

$$
b_{1}=d, \quad b_{2}=d e^{\pm \frac{i 2 \pi}{3}}, \quad b_{3}=d e^{\mp \frac{i 2 \pi}{3}},
$$

where $d$ is a real number, give a pair of orthogonal degenerate normal mode solutions.

\section{4}

Three identical objects, each of mass $m$, are connected by springs of spring constant $K$, as shown in Fig. 1.95. The motion is confined to one dimension.

At $t=0$, the masses are at rest at their equilibrium positions. Mass $A$ is then subjected to an external time-dependent driving force $F(t)=$ $f \cos (\omega t), t>0$. Calculate the motion of mass $C$. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-221.jpg?height=213&width=419&top_left_y=225&top_left_x=544)

Fig. $1.95$.

\section{Solution:}

Let $x_{A}, x_{B}, x_{C}$ be the coordinates of the three masses and $a$ the relaxed length of each spring. The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t)+K\left(x_{B}-x_{A}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{A}, \\
K\left(x_{C}-x_{B}-a\right)-K\left(x_{B}-x_{A}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{B}, \\
-K\left(x_{C}-x_{B}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{C} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The above set of equations can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t) &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}+\ddot{x}_{B}+\ddot{x}_{C}\right), \\
f \cos (\omega t)-2 a K &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}-\ddot{x}_{C}\right)+K\left(x_{A}-x_{C}\right), \\
f \cos (\omega t) &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}-2 \ddot{x}_{B}+\ddot{x}_{C}\right)+3 K\left(x_{A}-2 x_{B}+x_{C}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t) &=m \ddot{y}_{1}, \\
f \cos (\omega t)-2 a K &=m \ddot{y}_{2}+K y_{2}, \\
f \cos (\omega t) &=m \ddot{y}_{3}+3 K y_{3},
\end{aligned}
$$

with $y_{1}=x_{A}+x_{B}+x_{C}, y_{2}=x_{A}-x_{C}, y_{3}=x_{A}-2 x_{B}+x_{C}$. It can be seen that $y_{1}, y_{2}$ and $y_{3}$ are the three normal coordinates of this vibrational system. The initial conditions are that at $t=0$,

$$
x_{A}=0, \quad x_{B}=a, \quad x_{C}=2 a, \quad \dot{x}_{A}=\dot{x}_{B}=\dot{x}_{C}=0,
$$

or

$$
y_{1}=3 a, \quad y_{2}=-2 a, \quad y_{3}=0, \quad \dot{y}_{1}=\dot{y}_{2}=\dot{y}_{3}=0 .
$$

Equation (1) can be integrated, with the use of initial conditions, to give

$$
y_{1}=\frac{f}{m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)]+3 a .
$$

To solve (2), we try a particular solution

$$
y_{2}=A_{2} \cos (\omega t)+B_{2}
$$

and obtain $A_{2}=\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}, B_{2}=-2 a$. The general solution is

$$
y_{2}=\frac{f \cos (\omega t)}{K-m \omega^{2}}-2 a+C_{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+D_{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)
$$

where $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}$. Initial conditions then give

$$
C_{2}=-\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}, \quad D_{2}=0 .
$$

To solve (3), we try a particular solution

$$
y_{3}=A_{3} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and obtain $A_{3}=f /\left(3 K-m \omega^{2}\right)$. The general solution is

$$
y_{3}=\frac{f \cos (\omega t)}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}+C_{3} \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D_{3} \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right),
$$

where $\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{m}}$. Initial conditions then give

$$
C_{3}=-\frac{f}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}, \quad D_{3}=0 .
$$

Therefore the solutions are as follows:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
y_{1}=\frac{f}{m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)]+3 a \\
y_{2}=\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right]-2 a \\
y_{3}=\frac{f}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right]
\end{array}\right.
$$

The motion of $C$ is a linear combination of $y_{1}, y_{2}$ and $y_{3}$ : 

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{C}=\frac{y_{1}}{3}-\frac{y_{2}}{2}+\frac{y_{3}}{6}=& 2 a+\frac{f}{3 m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)] \\
&+\frac{f}{2 m\left(\omega_{2}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \\
&+\frac{f}{6 m\left(\omega_{3}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\omega_{2}$ and $\omega_{3}$ are the normal frequencies of the system.

\section{5}

A model of benzene ring useful for some purposes is a wire ring strung with 6 frictionless beads, with springs taut between the beads, as shown in Fig. 1.96. The beads each has mass $m$ and the springs all have spring constant $K$. The masses have been numbered for the grader's convenience. The ring is fixed in space.

(a) Calculate, or write down by intuition, the eigenfrequencies of the normal modes, indicating any degeneracies. In Fig. 1.97, picture each mode by drawing an arrow near each mass indicating the direction of motion and shading those masses at rest.

(b) With what frequencies can the center of mass oscillate?

(c) Which modes could be related to the modes of the real benzene molecule?

Hint: Much algebra can be eliminated by considering the symmetries of the problem.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=236&width=241&top_left_y=1526&top_left_x=276)

Fig. $1.96$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=128&width=151&top_left_y=1489&top_left_x=707)

(1) $=$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=128&width=142&top_left_y=1685&top_left_x=718)

$w=$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=129&width=144&top_left_y=1491&top_left_x=905)

$w=$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=139&width=179&top_left_y=1686&top_left_x=908)

(w) $=$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=119&width=136&top_left_y=1500&top_left_x=1107)

$w=$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-223.jpg?height=136&width=182&top_left_y=1690&top_left_x=1105)

$\omega=$

Fig, 1.97. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\psi_{n}$ be the displacement of the $n$th bead. Its equation of motion is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{\psi}_{n} &=K\left(\psi_{n+1}-\psi_{n}\right)-K\left(\psi_{n}-\psi_{n-1}\right) \\
&=K\left(\psi_{n-1}+\psi_{n+1}-2 \psi_{n}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Setting $\psi_{n}=A_{n} e^{i \omega t}$, we obtain

$$
-m \omega^{2} A_{n}=K\left(A_{n-1}+A_{n+1}-2 A_{n}\right),
$$

or

$$
A_{n-1}+\varepsilon A_{n}+A_{n+1}=0, \quad n=1,2, \ldots, 6,
$$

where

$$
\varepsilon=\frac{m \omega^{2}}{K}-2 .
$$

For the set of linear homogeneous equations to have a non-zero solution, the following determinant must vanish, i.e.

$$
\left|\begin{array}{llllll}
\varepsilon & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
1 & \varepsilon & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & \varepsilon & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & \varepsilon & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & \varepsilon & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & \varepsilon
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
\varepsilon^{6}-6 \varepsilon^{4}+9 \varepsilon^{2}-4=(\varepsilon+1)^{2}(\varepsilon-1)^{2}(\varepsilon+2)(\varepsilon-2)=0 .
$$

Thus the solutions are

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\varepsilon_{1}=2, & \varepsilon_{2}=-2, & \varepsilon_{3}=1, \\
\varepsilon_{4}=1, & \varepsilon_{5}=-1, & \varepsilon_{6}=-1
\end{array}
$$

The corresponding eigenfrequencies are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{4 K}{m}, \quad \omega_{2}^{2}=0, \quad \omega_{3}^{2}=\frac{3 K}{m}, \\
& \omega_{4}^{2}=\frac{3 K}{m}, \quad \omega_{5}^{2}=\frac{K}{m}, \quad \omega_{6}^{2}=\frac{K}{m} . 
\end{aligned}
$$

It can be seen that modes 3 and 4 as well as modes 5 and 6 are degenerate. Substituting $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}, \ldots, \varepsilon_{6}$ one by one into the set of equations $A_{n-1}+\varepsilon A_{n}+$ $A_{n+1}=0$, we can find the ratios of amplitudes for each normal mode. The results are depicted in Fig. 1.98. The displacements of the six beads have the same magnitude in modes $1,2,3$, and 5 except in modes 3 and 5 the first and fourth beads are stationary. Their directions are shown in the figure. Mode 2 corresponds to rotation of the system as a whole. In mode 4 , the displacements of the second bead and the fifth bead are twice as large as those of the others, and in mode 6 , the displacements of the third bead and the sixth bead are also twice as large as those of the others. These larger displacements are indicated by two arrows in the same direction in the figures.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-225.jpg?height=534&width=668&top_left_y=780&top_left_x=374)

Fig. $1.98$.

(b) It is seen from Fig. $1.98$ that only in modes 5 and 6 can the center of mass oscillate with a frequency $\sqrt{\mathrm{k} / \mathrm{m}}$.

(c) As the center of mass of a real benzene molecule cannot oscillate, only modes $1,2,3$, and 4 can be related to the real benzene molecule.

\section{6}

Consider a classical system of point masses $m_{i}$ with position vectors $\mathbf{r}_{i}$, each experiencing a net applied force $\boldsymbol{F}_{i}$.

(a) Consider the quantity $\sum_{i} m_{i} \dot{\mathbf{r}_{i}} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i}$, assumed to remain finite at all times, and prove the virial theorem 

$$
T=-\frac{1}{2} \overline{\sum_{i} \mathbf{F}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i}},
$$

where $T$ is the total kinetic energy of the system and the bar denotes time average.

(b) In the case of a single particle acted on by a central inverse-square law force, show that

$$
T=-\frac{\bar{V}}{2},
$$

where $V$ is the potential energy.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $Q(t)=\sum_{i} m_{i} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{Q}(t) &=\sum_{i} m_{i} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} \cdot \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}+\sum_{i} m_{i} \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i} \\
&=\sum_{i} m_{i} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}^{2}+\sum_{i} \mathbf{F}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The time average of $\dot{Q}(t)$ is

$$
\frac{1}{\tau} \int_{0}^{\tau} \dot{Q}(t) d t=\frac{1}{\tau} \int_{0}^{\tau} \sum_{i} m_{i} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}^{2} d t+\frac{1}{\tau} \int_{0}^{\tau} \sum_{i} \mathbf{F}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i} d t,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{1}{\tau}[Q(\tau)-Q(0)]=2 \bar{T}+\overline{\sum_{i} \mathbf{F}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i}}
$$

where $\tau$ is the period if the motions are periodic with the same period, or $\tau \rightarrow \infty$ otherwise. In both cases, the left-hand side of the equation is equal to zero and we have

$$
2 \bar{T}+\sum_{i} \overline{\mathbf{F}_{i} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{i}}=0
$$

as stated.

(b) For a single particle acted on by a central inverse-square law force,

$$
F=\frac{C}{r^{2}}, \quad \text { or } \quad V=\frac{C}{r},
$$

where $C$ is a constant. The virial theorem then gives

$$
\bar{T}=-\frac{1}{2} \overline{\frac{C}{r^{3}} \mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}}=-\frac{1}{2} \overline{\left(\frac{C}{r}\right)}=-\frac{\bar{V}}{2} .
$$

\section{7}

Three masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$, placed at the corners of an equilateral triangle of side $s$, attract each other according to Newton's law of gravitation. Determine the rotational motion which leaves the relative separation of each mass unchanged.

Hint: Write down the force in c.m. system on one of the particles.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-227.jpg?height=341&width=371&top_left_y=879&top_left_x=556)

Fig. 1.99.

\section{Solution:}

In the Cartesian frame shown in Fig. 1.99, the three mass $m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}$ have coordinates $(0,0),(s, 0)$ and $\left(\frac{s}{2}, \frac{\sqrt{3} s}{2}\right)$ respectively. The position of the center of mass $C$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{0} &=\frac{\sum_{i} m_{i} r_{i}}{\sum_{i} m_{i}} \\
&=\frac{s}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\left[\left(m_{2}+\frac{m_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} m_{3} \mathbf{j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now consider the forces acting on $m_{1}$. There are two attractive forces 

$$
\mathbf{f}_{12}=\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{s^{2}} \mathbf{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G m_{1} m_{3}}{s^{2}}\left(\frac{\mathbf{i}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3} \mathbf{j}}{2}\right)
$$

due to $m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$ respectively. Their resultant is

$$
\mathbf{f}_{1}=\mathbf{f}_{12}+\mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G m_{1}}{s^{2}}\left[\left(m_{2}+\frac{m_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} m_{3} \mathbf{j}\right]
$$

As $\mathbf{f}_{1}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{r}_{0}$ and both originate from the same point $O, \mathbf{f}_{1}$ passes through the center of mass $C$. Thus $m_{1}$ is acted upon by a central force with center at $C$ and hence $m_{1}$ moves in a circle about the center of mass C. The radius of this circular orbit is

$$
R_{1}=\left|\mathbf{r}_{0}\right|=\left(\frac{s}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\right) \sqrt{m_{2}^{2}+m_{3}^{2}+m_{2} m_{3}} .
$$

The linear velocity of $m_{1}$ is $v_{1}$ given by $\frac{m v_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\left|\mathbf{f}_{1}\right|$, or

$$
v_{1}^{2}=\frac{R_{1}}{m_{1}}\left|\mathbf{f}_{1}\right|=\frac{G}{s}\left(\frac{m_{2}^{2}+m_{3}^{2}+m_{2} m_{3}}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\right) .
$$

By permutation of the indices, the above result applies also to $m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$. Hence the rotational motion which leaves the separation of each pair of masses unchanged is a circular motion of period

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi R_{1}}{v_{1}}=2 \pi s \sqrt{\frac{s}{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}\right)}},
$$

which is the same for all three masses.

\section{8}

Two non-relativistic particles of equal energy and equal mass as shown in Fig. $1.100$ collide almost head-on. In a coordinate frame (the center of mass frame) moving with velocity $\mathbf{V}$, the particles appear to collide head-on.

(a) Find V, the velocity of the center of mass frame.

(b) Compare the total energy in the center of mass system to the original total energy. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-229.jpg?height=258&width=374&top_left_y=210&top_left_x=571)

Fig. 1,100.

Express your answers in terms of the velocity $u$ and the collision angle $\theta_{0}$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Use the laboratory frame as shown in Fig. $1.100$ and take the instant of the collision to be $t=0$. The position vectors of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ at $t<0$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{r}_{1}=u t \mathbf{i} \\
&\mathbf{r}_{2}=-u t\left(\cos \theta_{0} \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the position vector of the center of mass is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{\mathrm{c}} &=\frac{m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{\mathbf{r}_{1}+\mathbf{r}_{2}}{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} u t\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

as $m_{1}=m_{2}=m$, say.

(a) The velocity of the center of mass, i.e. of the center of mass frame, is

$$
\mathbf{V}=\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right] .
$$

(b) In the center of mass frame, the velocity of $m_{1}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{V}_{1}^{\prime} &=\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}-\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{\mathrm{c}}=u \mathbf{i}-\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1+\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and the velocity of $m_{2}$ is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{V}_{2}^{\prime} &=\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}-\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{\mathrm{c}}=-u\left[\cos \theta_{0} \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right]-\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right] \\
&=-\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1+\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The total energy of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ is then

$$
E^{\prime}=\frac{m V_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m V_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2}=\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}\left(1+\cos \theta_{0}\right) .
$$

As the original total energy is

$$
E=\frac{m_{1} u^{2}}{2}+\frac{m_{2} u^{2}}{2}=m u^{2},
$$

the ratio of the two energies is

$$
\frac{E^{\prime}}{E}=\frac{1+\cos \theta_{0}}{2} .
$$

\section{9}

A rocket is projected straight up and explodes into three equally massive fragments just as it reaches the top of its flight (Fig. 1.101). One of the fragments is observed to come straight down in a time $t_{1}$, while the other two land at a time $t_{2}$, after the burst. Find the height $h\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ at which the fragmentation occurred.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-230.jpg?height=256&width=324&top_left_y=1359&top_left_x=623)

Fig. $1.101$.

\section{Solution:}

The velocity and momentum of the rocket are zero when it reaches the top of its flight. Conservation of momentum gives, after the burst, 

$$
m_{1} \mathbf{v}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{v}_{2}+m_{3} \mathbf{v}_{3}=0 .
$$

As

$$
m_{1}=m_{2}=m_{3}, \quad v_{1}+v_{2}+v_{3}=0 .
$$

As the second and third fragments land at the same time, the vertical components of $\mathbf{v}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{3}$ are the same. As $\mathbf{v}_{1}$ is vertically downward the vertical components of $\mathbf{v}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{3}$ are each $-v_{1} / 2$. Hence for the first and second fragments we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&h=v_{1} t_{1}+\frac{g t_{1}^{2}}{2}, \\
&h=\frac{-v_{1} t_{2}}{2}+\frac{g t_{2}^{2}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{1} &=\frac{g\left(t_{2}^{2}-t_{1}^{2}\right)}{2 t_{1}+t_{2}}, \\
h &=\frac{g t_{1} t_{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{t_{1}+2 t_{2}}{2 t_{1}+t_{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{0}

A satellite of mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ with speed $v$ about the earth. It abruptly absorbs a small mass $\delta m$ which was stationary prior to the collision. Find the change in the total energy of the satellite and, assuming the new orbit is roughly circular, find the radius of the new orbit.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Before picking up the small mass, the satellite moves in a circular orbit so that

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}},
$$

giving $R v^{2}=G M$, where $M$ is the mass of the earth. Hence its total energy is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R}=-\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} .
$$

After absorbing the stationary small mass $\delta m$, the speed of the satellite changes to (considering the new orbit as roughly circular, although it is actually elliptic)

$$
v^{\prime}=\frac{m v}{m+\delta m},
$$

and its total energy becomes

$$
E^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2}(m+\delta m) v^{\prime 2}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{m^{2} v^{2}}{m+\delta m} .
$$

Hence the energy loss due to the collision is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime}-E &=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\left(1-\frac{m}{m+\delta m}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \frac{\delta m}{m+\delta m} \\
& \approx \frac{1}{2} v^{2} \delta m .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the new radius is $R^{\prime}$ we also have

$$
R^{\prime} v^{\prime 2}=G M=R v^{2},
$$

giving

$$
R^{\prime}=\left(\frac{v}{v^{\prime}}\right)^{2} R=\left(\frac{m+\delta m}{m}\right)^{2} R \approx\left(1+\frac{2 \delta m}{m}\right) R .
$$

\section{1}

For the system of 2 identical masses and massless springs shown in Fig. 1.102, calculate the period of oscillation if the masses are released from the initial symmetrical configuration shown.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-232.jpg?height=153&width=436&top_left_y=1646&top_left_x=571)

Fig, 1,102. 

\section{Solution:}

Due to symmetry, the oscillations of the two masses are the same. Consider one of them and write down the equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-K x-K^{\prime}(x+x)=-\left(K+2 K^{\prime}\right) x,
$$

where $x$ is the displacement from the respective equilibrium position. Then the angular frequency of oscillation is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+2 K^{\prime}}{m}},
$$

and the period of oscillation is

$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{K+2 K^{\prime}}} .
$$

Note that generally speaking, there are two modes of linear vibration for this system corresponding to two normal modes. But the symmetrical initial condition determines that only one mode is excited.

\section{2}

Consider the earth-moon system and for simplicity assume that any interaction with other objects can be ignored. The moon, which moves around the earth more slowly than the earth rotates, creates tides on the earth. A similar situation exists on Mars, but with the difference that one of its moons revolves about Mars faster than the planet rotates. Show that one consequence of tidal friction is that in one system the moon-planet distance is increasing, and in the other it is decreasing. In which one is it decreasing?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

For the earth-moon system, the frictional force caused by the tides slows down the rotational speed of the earth. However, the total angular momentum of the earth-moon system is conserved because the interaction between this system and other objects can be ignored. The decrease in the earth's rotational angular momentum will lead to an increase in the angular momentum of the moon about the earth (to be exact, about the center of mass of the system). The angular momentum of the moon is $J=m R^{2} \omega$. As

$$
m R \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}},
$$

we have

$$
J=m R^{2} \sqrt{\frac{G M}{R^{3}}}=m \sqrt{G M R} .
$$

Here we consider the center of the earth to be approximately fixed, so that $R$ is the earth-moon distance. Then as $J$ increases, $R$ will increase also. Thus for the earth-moon system, the effect of tides is to increase the distance between the moon and the earth.

For the Mars-moon system, the moon revolves about Mars faster than the latter rotates, so the frictional force caused by tides will speed up the rotation of Mars, whose rotational angular momentum consequently increases. As the total angular momentum is conserved, the angular momentum of the moon will decrease. The argument above then shows that the distance between Mars and its moon will decrease.

\section{3}

Two mass points, each of mass $m$, are at rest on a frictionless horizontal surface. They are connected by a spring of equilibrium length $l$ and constant $K$. An impulse $I$ is given at time $t=0$ to one of the mass points in a direction perpendicular to the spring. Assume that the spring always lines up along the connecting length $l$, i.e. there is no bending.

(a) After a time $t$, what will be the total energy and total momentum of the two mass points?

(b) What will be the velocity of the center of mass (including direction) and the total angular momentum about the center of mass?

(c) What will be the maximum separation between the two mass points during the motion that follows the impulse?

(d) What will be the maximum instantaneous speed achieved by either particle? Explain your answer.

(UC, Berkeley) 

\section{Solution:}

(a) On account of the conservation of momentum and of mechanical energy, the total momentum and total energy of the two mass points at time $t$ are the same as those at time $t=0$ just after the impulse is applied:

$$
\mathbf{P}=\mathbf{I}, \quad E=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{I^{2}}{2 m} .
$$

(b) The system has total mass $2 m$, total momentum $I$, so that the center of mass has velocity

$$
v_{c}=\frac{I}{2 m} .
$$

Just after the impulse is given, the angular momentum of the system about the center of mass is $L=\frac{I l}{2}$. By the conservation of angular momentum in the center of mass frame, $L$ is the angular momentum about the center of mass at all later times.

(c) Let $l_{M}$ denote the maximum separation required. Conservation of angular momentum and of mechanical energy

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 m\left(\frac{l_{M}}{2}\right)^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\frac{I l}{2}, \\
m\left(\frac{l_{M}}{2} \dot{\varphi}\right)^{2}+m\left(\frac{I}{2 m}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K\left(l_{M}-l\right)^{2}=\frac{I^{2}}{2 m}
\end{gathered}
$$

give

$$
2 m K l_{M}^{4}-4 m K l l_{M}^{3}+\left(2 m K l^{2}-I^{2}\right) l_{M}^{2}+I^{2} l^{2}=0,
$$

whose positive real root is the maximum distance between the two mass points during the motion that follows the impulse.

(d) Let $x$ denote the distance between the two masses. Conservation of mechanical energy gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 m\left[\left(\frac{x}{2} \dot{\varphi}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\dot{x}}{2}\right)^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 m\left(\frac{I}{2 m}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K(x-l)^{2}=\frac{I^{2}}{2 m},
$$

or

$$
\frac{m}{4}\left(x^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{x}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} K(x-l)^{2}=\text { constant },
$$

shows that when $x=l$, the kinetic energy of the two mass points, given by the first term on the left-hand side, is maximum. This is the case at $t=0$. Also, at $t=0$, only the mass that had been given the impulse has a velocity while the other mass is still instantaneously at rest. Thus the first mass achieves a maximum speed

$$
v_{M}=\frac{I}{m}
$$

at time $t=0$.

The condition that $x=l$ can be satisfied again from time to time. However, as the speed of the first mass will not be zero, the second mass cannot achieve this maximum speed. Therefore the maximum speed that can be achieved by the second mass is less than $v_{m}$.

\section{4}

A chain with mass/length $=u$ hanging vertically from one end, where an upward force $F$ is applied to it, is lowered onto a table as shown in Fig. 1.103. Find the equation of motion for $h$, the height of the end above the table ( $h$ is the length of chain hanging freely).

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-236.jpg?height=323&width=275&top_left_y=1207&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 1.103.

\section{Solution:}

As this problem involves variable mass it is more convenient to work with momentum. Consider the change of momentum of the chain during a time interval $t$ to $t+\Delta t$. If $h$ and $v$ are respectively the height and velocity of the freely-hanging portion of the chain at time $t$, its momentum is $\mu h v$ at $t$ and $\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)$ at $t+\Delta t$ (see Fig. 1.104). As a portion $\Delta h$ of the chain has reached the table and transferred a momentum $\approx \mu \Delta h v$ to the latter during the interval, the momentum theorem gives

$$
\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)+\mu \Delta h v-\mu h v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t,
$$

or, retaining only the first-order terms,

$$
\mu h \Delta v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t .
$$

With $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$, the above becomes

$$
\mu h \dot{v}=\mu h g-F .
$$

As $v=-\dot{h}$, we have the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{h}=\frac{F}{\mu h}-g .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-237.jpg?height=325&width=402&top_left_y=924&top_left_x=559)

Fig. 1.104.

\section{5}

Use the rocket equation to find the rocket residual mass $m$ (in terms of the initial mass) at which the momentum of the rocket is a maximum, for a rocket of mass $m$ starting at rest in free space. The exhaust velocity is a constant $v_{0}$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The equation of motion for a rocket, velocity $v$, in free space is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{d t},
$$

i.e.

\section{Integrating, we obtain}

$$
d v=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{m} .
$$

$$
v=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right),
$$

where $m_{0}$ is the rocket mass at firing. The momentum of the rocket is

$$
P=m v=-m v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right) .
$$

For it to be a maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d P}{d m}=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right)-v_{0}=0 .
$$

Hence the rocket has maximum momentum when its residual mass is

$$
m=\frac{m_{0}}{e} .
$$

\section{6}

A rocket is fired straight up with no initial velocity. It is propelled by ejection of mass with a constant velocity of ejection $u$ relative to the rocket and at a constant rate so determined that the initial acceleration is zero. Assuming constant acceleration due to gravity,
(a) find the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time;
(b) show how you would find the height of the rocket as a function of time.

(It is not necessary to do the integrals.)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $v$ be the velocity of the rocket. The equation of motion is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=-\frac{u d m}{d t}-m g .
$$

As $d m / d t=$ constant and $m=m_{0}, d v / d t=0$ at $t=0$, the above gives

$$
\frac{d m}{d t}=-\frac{m_{0} g}{u}
$$

at any time $t$ after firing. Integrating we obtain

$$
m=m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion now becomes

$$
m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) \frac{d v}{d t}=\left(m_{0}-m\right) g=\frac{m_{0} g^{2} t}{u},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{g^{2} t}{u-g t},
$$

which expresses the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time.

(b) The velocity at time $t$ is

$$
v=\int_{0}^{t} g\left(\frac{g t^{\prime}}{u-g t^{\prime}}\right) d t^{\prime}=-g t+u \ln \left(\frac{u}{u-g t}\right) .
$$

Further integration gives the height of the rocket as a function of time:

$$
h=\int_{0}^{t}\left(-g t^{\prime}+u \ln \frac{u}{u-g t^{\prime}}\right) d t^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2} g t^{2}+u \int_{0}^{t} \ln \frac{u}{u-g t^{\prime}} d t^{\prime} .
$$

\section{7}

A bucket of mass $M$ (when empty) initially at rest and containing a mass of water is being pulled up a well by a rope exerting a steady force $P$. The water is leaking out of the bucket at a steady rate such that the bucket is empty after a time $T$. Find the velocity of the bucket at the instant it becomes empty,

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let the total mass of the bucket and water be $M^{\prime}$. Then

$$
M^{\prime}=M+m-\frac{m t}{T},
$$

where $m$ is the initial mass of the water. As the leaking water has zero velocity relative to the bucket, the equation of motion is

$$
M^{\prime} \frac{d v}{d t}=P-M^{\prime} g,
$$

or

$$
d v=\frac{P-M^{\prime} g}{M^{\prime}} d t=\left(\frac{P}{M+m-\frac{m}{T} t}-g\right) d t
$$

The velocity of the bucket at the instant it becomes empty is

$$
v=\int_{0}^{T} \frac{P d t}{M+m-\frac{m}{T} t}-g T=\frac{P T}{m} \ln \left(\frac{M+m}{M}\right)-g T .
$$

\section{8}

A rocket ship with mass $M_{0}$ and loaded with fuel of mass $m_{0}$ takes off vertically in a uniform gravitational field as shown in Fig. 1.105. It ejects fuel with velocity $U_{0}$ with respect to the rocket ship. The fuel is completely ejected during a time $T_{0}$.

(a) Find the equation of motion of the rocket in terms of $d M / d t, U_{0}, g$, and $M$, where $M$ is the mass of the rocket at time $t$.

(b) What is the velocity of the vehicle at the instant $t_{0}$ when all the fuel has been ejected, in terms of $M_{0}, m_{0}, g$ and $t_{0}$ ?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-240.jpg?height=303&width=159&top_left_y=1505&top_left_x=705)

Fig. $1.105$. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a rocket, having mass $M$ and velocity $V$, in time interval $\Delta t$ ejecting a mass $\Delta M$ at a velocity $U_{0}$ relative to the rocket and gaining an additional velocity $\Delta V$. Taking the vertical upward direction as positive, we have by the momentum theorem

$$
(M-\Delta M)(V+\Delta V)+\left(V+U_{0}\right) \Delta M-M V=-M g \Delta t,
$$

i.e.

or, in the limit $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$

$$
M \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta t}=-U_{0} \frac{\Delta M}{\Delta t}-M g,
$$

$$
M \frac{d V}{d t}=-U_{0} \frac{d M}{d t}-M g .
$$

(b) The equation can be rewritten as

$$
d V=-U_{0} \frac{d M}{M}-g d t .
$$

Integrating we obtain

$$
V=-U_{0} \ln M-g t+K .
$$

As $M=M_{0}+m_{0}, V=0$ at $t=0$,

$$
K=U_{0} \ln \left(M_{0}+m_{0}\right) .
$$

Hence when $M=M_{0}$ at $t=t_{0}$, we have

$$
V=U_{0} \ln \left(\frac{M_{0}+m_{0}}{M_{0}}\right)-g t_{0} .
$$

\section{9}

A droplet nucleates in uniform quiescent fog. It then falls, sweeping up the fog which lies in its path. Assume that it retains all the fog which it collects, that it remains spherical and experiences no viscous drag. Asymptotically, it falls with a uniform acceleration $a$ :

$$
V(t) \rightarrow a t, \quad \text { for large } t .
$$

\section{Find $a$.}



\section{Solution:}

Let $\rho_{1}, \rho_{2}$ be the densities of the droplet and fog respectively, $R(t)$ be the radius and $V(t)$ the velocity of the droplet, and assume that the buoyancy of the air can be neglected. Making use of the "rocket equation" in Problem 1138, with

$$
M=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} p_{1}, \quad U_{0}=0-(-V)=V,
$$

and the replacement

$$
\begin{gathered}
V \rightarrow-V, \\
\frac{d M}{d t} \rightarrow-\frac{d M}{d t},
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{1} \frac{d V}{d t}+V \frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{1}\right)=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{1} g
$$

or

$$
R \frac{d V}{d t}+3 V \frac{d R}{d t}=R g .
$$

The droplet sweeps out a cylinder $\pi R^{2} V$ in unit time so the rate of change of its mass $m$ is

$$
\frac{d m}{d t}=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho_{1}\right)=4 \pi \rho_{1} R^{2} \frac{d R}{d t}=\pi R^{2} V \rho_{2},
$$

giving

$$
V=4 \eta \dot{R},
$$

where $\eta=\rho_{1} / \rho_{2}$. We thus have

$$
4 \eta R \ddot{R}+12 \eta \dot{R}^{2}=R g .
$$

As for large $t, V=a t$ or $\dot{R}=\frac{a t}{4 \eta}$, we set $R=b t^{2}+c$, where $b, c$ are constants, and substitute it in the differential equation. Equating the coefficients of $t^{2}$ and $t^{0}$ separately on the two sides of the equation, we have

$$
56 \eta b-g=0, \quad(8 \eta b-g) c=0 .
$$

For a consistent solution, we take

$$
b=\frac{g}{56 \eta}, \quad c=0 \text {. }
$$

Hence $V=4 \eta \dot{R}=8 \eta b t=\frac{9}{7} t$, i.e. the asymptotic acceleration is

$$
a=\frac{g}{7} .
$$

\section{0}

An hour glass sits on a scale. Initially all the sand (mass $m$ ) in the glass (mass $M$ ) is held in the upper reservoir. At $t=0$, the sand is released. If it exits the upper reservoir at a constant rate $d m / d t=\lambda$, draw (and label quantitatively) a graph showing the reading of the scale at all times $t>0$.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-243.jpg?height=361&width=238&top_left_y=789&top_left_x=279)

Fig. 1.106.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-243.jpg?height=341&width=603&top_left_y=861&top_left_x=693)

Fig. 1.107,

\section{Solution:}

Suppose all the sand falls to the bottom of the lower reservoir so that for all grains the falling height is $h$. A grain falling through this distance will acquire a velocity $V=\sqrt{2 g h}$ when it reaches the bottom and the whole trip takes a time $t_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}}$.

For the reading of the scale, consider the following four periods of time:

Period 1: The time $t=0$ when the sand is released, to the time $t_{1}$ when the sand begins to arrive at the bottom of the lower reservoir. The reading of the scale in this period is

$$
W_{1}=(M+m) g-\lambda t g, \quad 0<t<t_{1},
$$

where $t_{1}=\sqrt{2 g h}$. Period 2: The time $t_{1}$ when the sand begins to arrive at the bottom, to the time $t_{2}$ when all the sand has left the upper reservoir. In this period, the force on the scale consists of two parts: weight of the sand as given by the above equation with $t=t_{1}$ and a part due to the impulse of the sand on the bottom of the reservoir with magnitude

$$
V \frac{d m}{d t}=\lambda \sqrt{2 g h} .
$$

Hence the scale reads

$$
W_{2}=\left[(M+m) g-\lambda t_{1} g\right]+\lambda \sqrt{2 g h}=(M+m) g, \quad t_{1}<t<t_{2},
$$

where $t_{2}=m / \lambda$.

Period 3: The time $t_{2}$ when all the sand has left the upper reservoir to the time $t_{3}$ when all sand has reached the bottom. The scale reads

$$
W_{3}=W_{2}+\lambda\left(t-t_{2}\right) g, \quad t_{2}<t<t_{3}
$$

where $t_{3}=t_{2}+t_{1}$.

Period 4: The time after all the sand has reached the bottom. The reading of the scale is constant at

$$
W_{4}=(M+m) g, \quad t>t_{3} .
$$

The reading of the scale is depicted in Fig. 1.107.

\section{1}

A rocket of instantaneous mass $m$ achieves a constant thrust $F$ by emitting propellant at a low rate with high relative speed. The rocket directs its thrust always along the direction of its instantaneous velocity $\mathbf{u}$. By so doing it moves from an initial radius $\mathbf{r}_{1}$ (measured from the center of the earth) to a larger radius $r_{2}$, remaining in the same plane and following a path roughly like a spiral. The starting radius $r_{1}$ is close to the earth's radius $r_{0}$, where the gravitational acceleration is $g$, while $r_{2} \gg r_{0}$. The angular coordinate from the earth's center is $\phi$.

(a) Is the angular momentum of the rocket per unit mass a constant of the motion? Discuss. (b) In terms of $r, r_{0}, \dot{r}$, and $\dot{\phi}$, derive expressions for the instantaneous velocity $u$ and the gravitational acceleration $g$.

(c) Derive expressions for $\ddot{r}$ and $\ddot{\phi}$ in terms of the quantities listed above. (Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use polar coordinates $(r, \phi)$ as given. The angular momentum of the rocket per unit mass is $j=r^{2} \dot{\phi}$. Although gravity is a central force, the rocket thrust is not. Hence the angular momentum is not a conserved quantity.

(b) The instantaneous velocity of the rocket is

$$
\mathbf{u}=u_{r} \mathbf{e}_{r}+u_{\varphi} \mathbf{e}_{r}=\dot{r} \mathbf{e}_{r}+r \dot{\varphi} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}
$$

with magnitude

$$
u=\sqrt{\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}} .
$$

The gravitational acceleration $g$ is

$$
g=\frac{G M}{r^{2}} .
$$

As $g_{0}=\frac{G M}{r_{0}^{2}}$, it can be written as

$$
g=g_{0} \frac{r_{0}^{2}}{r^{2}} .
$$

(c) The equation of the motion of the rocket is

$$
\mathbf{f}=m \frac{d \mathbf{u}}{d t},
$$

where $\mathbf{f}=\mathbf{F}+m \mathbf{g}, m=m(t)$, terms involving $\frac{d m}{d t}$ having been neglected. As the thrust $F$ is always parallel to $u$, its components are $F_{r}=F \frac{\dot{r}}{u}$, $F_{\varphi}=F \frac{r \dot{\varphi}}{u}$. The gravitational acceleration is $\mathbf{g}=-g \mathrm{e}_{r}$. Hence the equation of motion has component equations

$$
\begin{gathered}
m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\phi}^{2}\right)=f_{r}=\frac{F \dot{r}}{\sqrt{\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\phi}^{2}}}-\frac{m g_{0} r_{0}^{2}}{r^{2}}, \\
m(r \ddot{\phi}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\phi})=f_{\phi}=\frac{F r \dot{\phi}}{\sqrt{\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\phi}^{2}}},
\end{gathered}
$$

from which the expressions for $\ddot{r}$ and $\ddot{\phi}$ can be obtained. 1142

A rocket ship far from any gravitational field has a source of energy $E$ on board. The ship has initial mass $m_{1}$ and final mass $m_{2}$.

(a) Find the maximum velocity $v$ that the ship can achieve starting from rest. $E, m_{1}$, and $m_{2}$ are fixed, but the exhaust velocity $w$ (relative to the ship) may vary as a function of the instantaneous mass $m$ of the ship.

(b) What is the maximum velocity $v$ that can be obtained if the exhaust velocity $w$ is constrained to be constant?

(Princeton $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Integrating the equation of motion for the rocket ship (Problem 1138)

$$
m \frac{d v}{d t}=-w(m) \frac{d m}{d t}
$$

and taking account of the initial conditions $v=0, m=m_{1}$ at $t=0$, we have

$$
v=-\int_{m_{1}}^{m} \frac{w(m)}{m} d m .
$$

Hence the maximum velocity is

$$
v_{\max }=-\int_{m_{1}}^{m_{2}} \frac{w(m)}{m} d m .
$$

(b) If $w$ is constant, the maximum velocity is

$$
v_{\max }=w \ln \frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}} .
$$

1143

A spherical dust particle falls through a water mist cloud of uniform density such that the rate of accretion onto the droplet is proportional to the volume of the mist cloud swept out by the droplet per unit time. If the droplet starts from rest in the cloud, find the value of the acceleration of the drop for large times.

(Princeton) 

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the spherical dust particle initially has mass $M_{0}$ and radius $R_{0}$. Take the initial position of the dust particle as the origin and the $x$-axis along the downward vertical. Let $M(t)$ and $R(t)$ be the mass and radius of the droplet at time $t$ respectively. Then

$$
M(t)=M_{0}+\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R^{3}-R_{0}^{3}\right) \rho,
$$

where $\rho$ is the density of the water mist, giving

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\rho 4 \pi R^{2} \frac{d R}{d t} .
$$

The droplet has a cross section $\pi R^{2}$ and sweeps out a cylinder of volume $\pi R^{2} \dot{x}$ in unit time, where $\dot{x}$ is its velocity. As the rate of accretion is proportional to this volume, we have

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\alpha \pi R^{2} \dot{x},
$$

$\alpha$ being a positive constant. Hence

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \dot{R} .
$$

The momentum theorem gives

$$
M(t+d t) \dot{x}(t+d t)-M(t) \dot{x}(t)=M g d t .
$$

Using Taylor's theorem to expand $M(t+d t)$ and $\dot{x}(t+d t)$ and retaining only the lowest-order terms, we obtain

$$
\dot{x} \frac{d M}{d t}+M \ddot{x}=M g .
$$

For large $t, M(t) \approx \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho, d M / d t \approx 3 M \dot{R} / R$, and the above becomes

$$
\ddot{R}+\frac{3 \dot{R}^{2}}{R}=\frac{\alpha g}{4 \rho} .
$$

For a particular solution valid for large $t$, setting

$$
R(t)=a t^{2},
$$

where $a$ is a constant, in the above we obtain

$$
a=\frac{\alpha g}{56 \rho} .
$$

Thus for large $t$,

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \cdot 2 a t=\frac{g t}{7} .
$$

Hence the acceleration for large times is $g / 7$.

\section{4}

Suppose a spacecraft of mass $m_{0}$ and cross-sectional area $A$ is coasting with velocity $v_{0}$ when it encounters a stationary dust cloud of density $\rho$ as shown in Fig. 1.108. If the dust sticks to the spacecraft, solve for the subsequent motion of the spacecraft. Assume $A$ is constant over time.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-248.jpg?height=221&width=685&top_left_y=1049&top_left_x=440)

Fig. $1.108$.

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the dust offers no resistance to the spacecraft. Newton's second law

$$
\frac{d(m v)}{d t}=0,
$$

or

$$
m \frac{d v}{d t}+v \frac{d m}{d t}=0
$$

implies that $m v=m_{0} v_{0}$. Then as

$$
d m=\rho v A d t, \quad \frac{d m}{d t}=\rho A v
$$

we have

$$
\frac{d v}{v^{3}}+\frac{\rho A d t}{m_{0} v_{0}}=0
$$

Integrating, we obtain

$$
\frac{1}{v^{2}}=\frac{2 \rho A t}{m_{0} v_{0}}+C,
$$

where $C$ is a constant. If we measure time from the instant the spacecraft first encounters the dust, then $v=v_{0}$ at $t=0$, giving $C=v_{0}^{-2}$. Hence the motion of the spacecraft can be described by

$$
\frac{1}{v^{2}}=\frac{1}{v_{0}^{2}}+\frac{2 \rho A t}{m_{0} v_{0}} .
$$

\section{DYNAMICS OF RIGID BODIES (1145-1223)}

\section{5}

Two circular metal disks have the same mass $M$ and the same thickness $t$. Disk 1 has a uniform density $\rho_{1}$ which is less than $\rho_{2}$, the uniform density of disk 2. Which disk, if either, has the larger moment of inertia?

\section{(Wisconsin)}

\section{Solution:}

Let the radii of the disks be $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$ respectively.

Since the disks have the same mass and thickness, we have $\rho_{1} R_{1}^{2}=\rho_{2} R_{2}^{2}$, or

$$
\frac{R_{1}^{2}}{R_{2}^{2}}=\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{1}} .
$$

The moments of inertia of the disks are

$$
I_{1}=\frac{M R_{1}^{2}}{2}, \quad I_{2}=\frac{M R_{2}^{2}}{2},
$$

so

$$
\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{R_{1}^{2}}{R_{2}^{2}}=\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{1}} .
$$

As $\rho_{1}<\rho_{2}, I_{1}>I_{2}$. Hence disk 1 has the larger moment of inertia. 

\section{6}

Given that the moment of inertia of a cube about an axis that passes through the center of mass and the center of one face is $I_{0}$, find the moment of inertia about an axis through the center of mass and one corner of the cube.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Use Cartesian coordinates with origin at the center of mass and the axes through the centers of the three pairs of faces of the cube. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{x x}=I_{y y}=I_{z z}=I_{0}, \\
&I_{x y}=I_{y z}=I_{z x}=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

The moment of inertia about an axis having direction cosines $\lambda, \mu, \nu$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\lambda^{2} I_{x x}+\mu^{2} I_{y y}+\nu^{2} I_{z z}-2 \mu \nu I_{y z}-2 \nu \lambda I_{z x}-2 \lambda \mu I_{x y} \\
&=\left(\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}\right) I_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

To find the direction cosines of a radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ from the origin to one corner of the cube, without loss of generality, we can just consider the corner with its $x, y, z$ coordinates all positive. Then

$$
\mathbf{r}=a \mathbf{i}+a \mathbf{j}+a \mathbf{k},
$$

where we have taken $2 a$ as the length of a side of the cube. As $|\mathbf{r}|=\sqrt{3} a$ we have

$$
\lambda=\mu=\nu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}},
$$

so that

$$
I=I_{0} \text {. }
$$

\section{7}

A thin disk of radius $R$ and mass $M$ lying in the $x y$-plane has a point mass $m=5 M / 4$ attached on its edge (as shown in Fig. 1.109). The moment of inertia of the disk about its center of mass is (the $z$-axis is out of the paper) 

$$
I=\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right]
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-251.jpg?height=269&width=347&top_left_y=423&top_left_x=611)

Fig. 1.109.

(a) Find the moment of inertia tensor of the combination of disk and point mass about point $A$ in the coordinate system shown.

(b) Find the principal moments and the principal axes about point $A$.

(c) The disk is constrained to rotate about the $y$-axis with angular velocity $\omega$ by pivots at $A$ and $B$. Describe the angular momentum about $A$ as a function of time and find the vector force applied at $B$ (ignore gravity).

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The contribution of a mass element $\Delta m$ at radius vector $\mathbf{r}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right.$, $\left.x_{3}\right)$ to the moments and products of inertia about the origin is

$$
I_{i j}=\Delta m\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right),
$$

where $\delta_{i j}=1$ if $i=j, \delta_{i j}=0$ if $i \neq j$. Thus the moment of inertia tensor of the point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{5 M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
1 & -1 & 0 \\
-1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The moment of inertia tensor of the disk about $A$, according to the theorem of parallel axes, is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{lll}
5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 6
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence the moment of inertia tensor of the disk and point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
10 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(b) To find the principal axes and moments of inertia, solve the secular equation

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
10-\gamma & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6-\gamma & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16-\gamma
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
(16-\gamma)\left(\gamma^{2}-16 \gamma+35\right)=0
$$

The solutions are

$$
\gamma_{1}=16, \quad \gamma_{2}=8-\sqrt{29}, \quad \gamma_{3}=8+\sqrt{29} .
$$

Hence the three principal moments of inertia about $A$ are

$$
I_{1}=4 M R^{2}, \quad I_{2}=\left(2-\frac{\sqrt{29}}{4}\right) M R^{2}, \quad I_{3}=\left(2+\frac{\sqrt{29}}{4}\right) M R^{2} .
$$

The direction cosines $(\lambda, \mu, \nu)$ of the principal axes corresponding to $I_{1}$ are given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
-6 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & -10 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\begin{gathered}
-6 \lambda-5 \mu=0 \\
-5 \lambda-10 \mu=0 \\
0 \nu=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

The solution is $\lambda=\mu=0, \nu=$ arbitrary. As

$$
\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=1,
$$

by definition, the direction cosines are

$$
\lambda=0, \quad \mu=0, \quad \nu=1 .
$$

The principal axes for $I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ have direction cosines given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
2 \pm \sqrt{29} & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & -2 \pm \sqrt{29} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 8 \pm \sqrt{29}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\begin{aligned}
(2 \pm \sqrt{29})) \lambda-5 \mu &=0, \\
-5 \lambda+(-2 \pm \sqrt{29}) \mu &=0 \\
(8 \pm \sqrt{29}) \nu &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the top sign is for $I_{2}$ and the bottom sign, $I_{3}$.

The solutions are

$$
\frac{\lambda}{\mu}=\frac{-2 \pm \sqrt{29}}{5}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.677 \\
-1.477
\end{array}, \quad \nu=0 .\right.
$$

Then as $\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}=1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&|\mu|=\left(\frac{\lambda^{2}}{\mu^{2}}+1\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.828 \\
0.561
\end{array}\right. \\
&|\nu|=\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.561 \\
0.828
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

We also require that the principal axes for $I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ be orthogonal:

$$
\lambda_{2} \lambda_{3}+\mu_{2} \mu_{3}+\nu_{2} \nu_{3}=0 .
$$

We therefore take the principal axes as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(0,0,1), \\
&(0.561,0.828,0), \\
&(-0.828,0.561,0)
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The moment of inertia tensor $I$ of the system of disk and mass point about the origin $A$ found in (a) refers to a coordinate frame $(x, y, z)$ attached to the disk. In this frame the angular momentum of the system rotating with angular velocity $\omega$ is

$$
L=I \omega,
$$

or

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
L_{x} \\
L_{y} \\
L_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
10 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\omega \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\frac{M R^{2} \omega}{4}\left(\begin{array}{r}
-5 \\
6 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

Consider a laboratory frame $\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}\right)$ having the same $y$-axis as the rotating frame $(x, y, z)$ such that the respective axes coincide at $t=0$, as shown in Fig. $1.110$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-254.jpg?height=466&width=437&top_left_y=571&top_left_x=577)

Fig. $1.110$.

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x^{\prime}=x \cos (\omega t)+z \sin (\omega t), \quad y^{\prime}=y \\
&z^{\prime}=-x \sin (\omega t)+z \cos (\omega t)
\end{aligned}
$$

we can define a transformation tensor

$$
S=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos (\omega t) & 0 & \sin (\omega t) \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
-\sin (\omega t) & 0 & \cos (\omega t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

so that a vector $V$ is transformed according to

$$
V^{\prime}=S V .
$$

Applying the above to the angular momentum vector, we find the angular momentum about $A$ in the laboratory frame:

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
L_{x}^{\prime} \\
L_{y}^{\prime} \\
L_{z}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right)=S L=\frac{M R^{2} \omega}{4}\left(\begin{array}{c}
-5 \cos (\omega t) \\
6 \\
5 \sin (\omega t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

i.e.

$$
L_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{-5 M R^{2} \omega}{4} \cos (\omega t), \quad L_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{3 M R^{2} \omega}{2}, \quad L_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{5 M R^{2} \omega}{4} \sin (\omega t)
$$

considering the disk alone. The $y$-axis is a principal axis of inertia and so rotation about it will not cause any force to be exerted on the pivots. Hence the forces on the pivots are due entirely to the rotating mass point. In the rotating frame the mass point suffers a centrifugal force of magnitude $\frac{5 M R \omega^{2}}{4}$, which is balanced by forces exerted on the disk by the pivots. The forces on the pivots are reactions to these forces. Hence pivot $B$ suffers a force of magnitude $\frac{5 M R \omega^{2}}{8}$ in the same direction as the centrifugal force on the mass point. In the laboratory frame this force rotates with angular velocity $\omega$

\section{8}

Four masses, all of value $m$, lie in the $x y$-plane at positions $(x, y)=$ $(a, 0),(-a, 0),(0,+2 a),(0,-2 a)$. These are joined by massless rods to form a rigid body.

(a) Find the inertial tensor, using the $x-, y-, z$-axes as reference system. Exhibit the tensor as a matrix.

(b) Consider a direction given by unit vector $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ that lies "equally between" the positive $x$-, $y$-, $z$-axes, i.e. it makes equal angles with these three directions. Find the moment of inertia for rotation about this axis.

(c) Given that at a certain time $t$ the angular velocity vector lies along the above direction $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$, find, for that instant, the angle between the angular momentum vector and $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$.

\section{(UC, Berkeley)}

\section{Solution:}

(a) The elements $I_{i j}$ of the inertial tensor are given by

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r_{n}^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{n_{i}} n_{n_{j}}\right)
$$

where

$$
r_{n}^{2}=x_{n_{1}}^{2}+x_{n_{2}}^{2}+x_{n_{3}}^{2} .
$$

As at least one of the coordinates of each mass is zero, $x_{i} x_{j}=0$ so that $I_{i j}=0$ for all $i \neq j$. For $i=j$, because of symmetry we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{11}=2 m\left(a^{2}-a^{2}\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=8 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{22}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-4 a^{2}\right)=2 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{33}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=10 m a^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the inertial tensor is given by the matrix

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
8 m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 10 m a^{2}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(b) As the given direction makes the same angle with the axes, its direction cosines $\lambda, \mu, \nu$ are equal. The moment of inertia about this direction is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\lambda^{2} I_{11}+\mu^{2} I_{22}+\nu^{2} I_{33}-2 \mu \nu I_{23}-2 \nu \lambda I_{31}-2 \lambda \mu I_{12} \\
&=\left(8 m a^{2}+2 m \omega^{2}+10 m a^{2}\right) \lambda^{2} \\
&=20 m a^{2} \lambda^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The direction cosines are subject to the condition

$$
\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=3 \lambda^{2}=1,
$$

giving $\lambda^{2}=\frac{1}{3}$. Hence

$$
I=\frac{20}{3} m a^{2} .
$$

(c) The direction $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is given by

$$
\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=\lambda\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

At time $T, \omega$ is parallel to $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ :

$$
\omega=\omega \hat{\mathbf{n}}=\lambda \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The angular momentum at this instant is given by

$$
L=I \omega,
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{L}=\lambda m a^{2} \omega\left(\begin{array}{c}
8 \\
2 \\
10
\end{array}\right)
$$

with magnitude

$$
L=\lambda m a^{2} \omega \sqrt{8^{2}+2^{2}+10^{2}}=\sqrt{168} \lambda m a^{2} \omega .
$$

The angle $\phi$ between $\mathrm{L}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is then given by

$$
\cos \phi=\frac{\mathbf{L} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}}{L}=\frac{\lambda^{2} m a^{2} \omega(8+2+10)}{\lambda m a^{2} \omega \sqrt{168}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \frac{20}{\sqrt{168}}=0.891
$$

i.e.

$$
\phi=27^{\circ}
$$

\section{9}

Due to polar flattening, the earth has a slightly larger moment of inertia about its polar axis than about its equatorial axis. Assume axial symmetry about the polar axis.

(a) Show that the dominant terms of the gravitational potential above the surface of the earth can be expressed as

$$
U=-\frac{G M}{r}\left[1-\frac{C-A}{M a^{2}}\left(\frac{a}{r}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta-1}{2}\right)\right]
$$

where $C$ and $A$ are the moments of inertia about the polar and equatorial axes respectively, $M$ is the earth's mass, $a$ is the mean earth radius and $r$ is the distance to the center of mass of the earth. The coefficient $(C-A) / M a^{2}$ is about $10^{-3}$.

(b) What secular effect will the second term have upon a satellite traveling in a circular orbit around the earth?

(c) If the normal to the plane of the satellite is inclined at an angle $\alpha$ to the polar axis of the earth, derive an expression for the magnitude of this effect by taking a time average over the circular orbit.

(UC, Berkeley) 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Choose the polar axis as the $z$-axis and the equatorial plane as the $x y$ plane. Let a mass element $d M$ of the earth have position vector $\mathbf{r}^{\prime}=\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}\right)$ and let a satellite above the surface of the earth have position vector $\mathbf{r}=(x, y, z)$. Then the gravitational potential energy per unit mass of the satellite is

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=-\int \frac{G d M}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|}=-\int \frac{G d M}{\left[r^{2}-2 \mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}+r^{\prime 2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}} \\
&=-\int \frac{G d M}{r}\left[1-\frac{2 \mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}}{r^{2}}+\frac{r^{2}}{r^{2}}\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

integrating over the entire earth. Taylor expansion gives, neglecting terms of order higher than $\left(\frac{r^{\prime}}{r}\right)^{2}$

$$
U=-\int \frac{G d M}{r}\left[1+\frac{\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}}{r^{2}}-\frac{r^{\prime 2}}{2 r^{2}}+\frac{3}{2} \frac{\left(\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)^{2}}{r^{4}}\right] .
$$

As $\mathbf{r}$ is a constant vector and the earth is assumed to be a symmetrical ellipsoid,

$$
\int \mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime} d M=\mathbf{r} \cdot \int \mathbf{r}^{\prime} d M=0
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
U=&-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int\left[\frac{3}{2} \frac{\left(\mathbf{r} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)^{2}}{r^{2}}-\frac{r^{\prime 2}}{2}\right] d M \\
=&-\frac{G M}{r} \\
&-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int\left[\frac{3\left(x x^{\prime}+y y^{\prime}+z z^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(x^{\prime 2}+y^{\prime 2}+z^{\prime 2}\right)}{2 r^{2}}\right] d M .
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to the symmetry of the earth, the integrals of $x^{\prime} y^{\prime}, y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ and $z^{\prime} x^{\prime}$ are all zero and we have 

$$
\begin{aligned}
U=&-\frac{G M}{r} \\
&-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int\left[2\left(x^{2} x^{\prime 2}+y^{2} y^{\prime 2}+z^{2} z^{\prime 2}\right)\right.\\
&\left.-\left(x^{2} y^{\prime 2}+x^{2} z^{\prime 2}+y^{2} x^{\prime 2}+y^{2} z^{\prime 2}+z^{2} x^{\prime 2}+z^{2} y^{\prime 2}\right)\right] \frac{d M}{2 r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, the choice of the $x$ - and $y$-axes is arbitrary (as long as they are in the equatorial plane), so that the integral of $x^{\prime}$ is equal to that of $y^{\prime}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int\left[\frac{x^{2} x^{\prime 2}+y^{2} y^{\prime 2}+2 z^{2} z^{\prime 2}-x^{2} z^{2}-y^{2} z^{\prime 2}-2 z^{2} x^{\prime 2}}{2 r^{2}}\right] d M \\
&=-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int\left[\frac{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) x^{\prime 2}-2 z^{2} x^{\prime 2}+\left(2 z^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}\right) z^{\prime 2}}{2 r^{2}}\right] d M \\
&=-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}} \int \frac{\left(3 z^{2}-r^{2}\right)\left(z^{\prime 2}-x^{2}\right)}{2 r^{2}} d M \\
&=-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}}\left(\frac{3 z^{2}}{2 r^{2}}-\frac{1}{2}\right) \int\left[\left(z^{2}+y^{2}\right)-\left(x^{\prime 2}+y^{2}\right)\right] d M \\
&=-\frac{G M}{r}-\frac{G}{r^{3}}\left(\frac{3 z^{2}}{2 r^{2}}-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(I_{x}-I_{y}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As $I_{x}=I_{y}=A, I_{z}=C, z=r \cos \theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle between $\mathrm{r}$ and the polar axis, the above can be written as

$$
U=-\frac{G M}{r}\left[1-\frac{C-A}{M a^{2}}\left(\frac{a}{r}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta-1}{2}\right)\right] .
$$

(b) Equation (1) can be written as $U=U_{1}+U_{2}$. $U_{1}=-\frac{G M}{r}$ is the potential energy per unit mass the satellite would have if the earth were a perfect sphere. $U_{2}$ arises from polar flattening. It gives rise to an additional force per unit mass of the satellite of $\mathbf{F}=-\nabla U_{2}$. As $\nabla r=\frac{\mathbf{r}}{r}, \nabla r^{-5}=\frac{-5 \mathbf{r}}{r^{7}}$, $\nabla r^{-3}=\frac{-3 \mathbf{r}}{r^{\delta}}, \nabla z^{2}=2 z \mathbf{k}$

$$
\mathbf{F}=\frac{3 G(A-C)}{2 r^{5}}\left[\left(1-\frac{5 z^{2}}{r^{2}}\right) \mathrm{r}+2 z \mathbf{k}\right] .
$$

Note that the first part in the square brackets is still a central force, albeit not of the inverse-square type. It does not change the magnitude and direction of the angular momentum about the center of the earth; hence it has no effect on the plane of orbit, but only makes the satellite deviate from circular orbit slightly. The second part,

$$
\mathbf{F}_{2}=\frac{3 G(A-C)}{r^{5}} z \mathbf{k}
$$

is not a central force; it makes the orbit plane precess about the $z$-axis.

(c) As the motion of the satellite is very nearly a uniform circular motion with center at the origin, because of symmetry the integral of $\mathrm{F}_{2} d t$ over a period of the circular motion is equal to zero, so that its average effect on the motion is zero. The torque caused by $\mathbf{F}_{2}$ with respect to the center of the earth is

$$
\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F}_{2}=\frac{3 G(C-A)}{r^{5}}(-y z \mathbf{i}+x z \mathbf{j}) .
$$

Let the intersection of the orbital plane and the equatorial plane of the earth be the $x$-axis (Fig. 1.111). In the course of rotation, $y z$ is always positive while the average value of $z x$ is zero. So over one period, the average torque is directed in the $-x$ direction. As the angula, momentum vector lies in the $y z$-plane and is thus perpendicular to the average torque, the latter does not change the magnitude of the angular momentum.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-260.jpg?height=435&width=417&top_left_y=1125&top_left_x=589)

Fig. $1.111$.

The angular momentum vector $\mathbf{L}$ has two components $L_{y}$ and $L_{z}$. As the average torque, which is in the $-x$ direction, is perpendicular to $L_{z}$, it does not affect the latter. Hence it does not change the angle $\alpha$ between $L$ and the $z$-axis. The result is that $\mathrm{L}$ will precess about the $z$-axis, describing a cone of semivertex angle $\alpha$ in a frame fixed to a distant star. As the $(x, y, z)$ frame is fixed with respect to the orbit, the $x$-axis will rotate around the center of the earth in the equatorial plane.

Let $\theta$ be the angle between the position vector of the satellite and the $x$-axis. Setting $\theta=0$ at time $t=0$, we have $\theta=\omega t, \omega$ being the angular velocity of the satellite. As $y=r \sin \theta \sin \alpha, z=r \sin \theta \cos \alpha$, the average of $\mathbf{M}$ over one period $T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle\mathbf{M}\rangle &=\mathrm{i} \frac{3 G(C-A)}{r^{5} T} \int_{0}^{T}-y z d t \\
&=-\frac{\mathrm{i} 3 G(C-A) \sin (2 \alpha)}{2 r^{3} T} \int_{\theta}^{T} \sin ^{2}(\omega t) d t \\
&=-\mathrm{i} \frac{3 G(C-A) \sin (2 \alpha)}{4 r^{3}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\langle\mathbf{M}\rangle$ is perpendicular to the angular momentum $\mathbf{L}$, this will cause the angular momentum vector to precess about the $z$-axis with angular velocity

$$
\dot{\phi}=\frac{|\langle\mathbf{M}\rangle|}{r^{2} \omega}=\frac{3 G(C-A) \sin (2 \alpha)}{4 r^{5} \omega} .
$$

\section{0}

A flywheel in the form of a uniformly thick disk $4 \mathrm{ft}$ in diameter weighs $600 \mathrm{lbs}$ and rotates at $1200 \mathrm{rpm}$. Calculate the constant torque necessary to stop it in $2.0 \mathrm{~min}$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The equation of motion for the flywheel is

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M,
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia and $M$ is the stopping torque. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\omega_{0}-\frac{M t}{I} .
$$

When the flywheel stops at time $t, \dot{\theta}=0$ and 

$$
M=\frac{I \omega_{0}}{t} .
$$

With $I=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}=1200 \mathrm{lb} \mathrm{ft}^{2}, \omega_{0}=40 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, t=120 \mathrm{~s}$,

$$
M=400 \pi \mathrm{pdl} \mathrm{ft}=39 \mathrm{lb} \mathrm{ft} .
$$

\section{1}

A structure is made of equal-length beams, 1 to 11 , as shown in Fig. 1.112, hinged at the joints $A, B, \ldots, G$. Point $A$ is supported rigidly while $G$ is only supported vertically. Neglect the beam weights. A weight $w$ is placed at $E$. Each member is under pure tension $T$ or compression $C$. Solve for the vertical support forces at $A$ and $G$ and find the tension $T$ or compression $C$ in each member.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-262.jpg?height=230&width=468&top_left_y=1025&top_left_x=212)

Fig. 1.112.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-262.jpg?height=308&width=502&top_left_y=1007&top_left_x=819)

Fig. 1.113.

\section{Solution:}

Consider the structure as a whole. The equilibrium conditions for forces at $A$ and $G$ and for torques about $A$ give

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{A X} &=0, \\
N_{A Y}+N_{G Y}-W &=0 \\
\overline{A E} \cdot W-\overline{A G} \cdot N_{G Y} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
N_{A X}=0, \quad N_{A Y}=\frac{W}{3}, \quad N_{G Y}=\frac{2 W}{3} .
$$

Then let the tensions and compressions in the rods be as shown in Fig. 1.113. Considering the equilibrium conditions for joint $A$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{A Y}-T_{1} \sin 60^{\circ} &=0, \\
C_{2}-T_{1} \cos 60^{\circ} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding

$$
T_{1}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{2}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{9} W .
$$

Consider the balance of vertical forces at $B, C, D, G, F$. We obtain by inspection of Fig. $1.113$

$$
\begin{gathered}
C_{3}=T_{1}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad T_{5}=C_{3}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{7}=T_{5}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \\
T_{11}=\frac{N_{G Y}}{\sin 60^{\circ}}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{9}=T_{11}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W .
\end{gathered}
$$

Then considering the balance of horizontal forces at $B, C, E, F$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T_{4}-\left(T_{1}+C_{3}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}=0 \\
&C_{6}-\left(C_{3}+T_{5}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}-C_{2}=0 \\
&C_{10}-\left(C_{9}-C_{7}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}-C_{6}=0 \\
&T_{8}-\left(T_{11}+C_{9}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding

$$
T_{4}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{6}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} W, \quad C_{10}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad T_{8}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W .
$$

\section{2}

A uniform thin rigid rod of mass $M$ is supported by two rapidly rotating rollers, whose axes are separated by a fixed distance $a$. The rod is initially placed at rest asymmetrically, as shown in Fig. $1.114$.

(a) Assume that the rollers rotate in opposite directions as shown in the figure. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the bar and the rollers is $\mu$. Write down the equation of motion of the bar and solve for the displacement 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-264.jpg?height=206&width=415&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=263)

Fig. 1.114.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-264.jpg?height=124&width=421&top_left_y=248&top_left_x=886)

Fig, 1.115.

$x(t)$ of the center $C$ of the bar from roller 1 assuming $x(0)=x_{0}$ and $\dot{x}(0)=0$.

(b) Now consider the case in which the directions of rotation of the rollers are reversed, as shown in Fig. 1.115. Calculate the displacement $x(t)$, again assuming $x(0)=x_{0}$ and $\dot{x}(0)=0$.

(Princeton $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-264.jpg?height=225&width=424&top_left_y=895&top_left_x=573)

Fig. 1.116.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The forces exerted by the rollers on the rod are as shown in Fig. 1.116. For equilibrium along the vertical direction we require

$$
N_{1}+N_{2}=M g, \quad a N_{2}=x M_{g},
$$

giving

$$
N_{1}=\left(1-\frac{x}{a}\right) M g, \quad N_{2}=\frac{x}{a} M g .
$$

The kinetic friction forces are

$$
f_{1}=\mu N_{1}, \quad f_{2}=\mu N_{2},
$$

with directions as shown in the figure. Note that as the rollers rotate rapidly, a change in the direction of motion of the rod will not affect the directions of these forces. Newton's second law then gives 

$$
M \ddot{x}=f_{1}-f_{2}=\frac{\mu M g}{a}(a-2 x) .
$$

With $\xi=2 x-a$, the above becomes

$$
\ddot{\xi}=-\frac{2 \mu g}{a} \xi,
$$

which is the equation of motion of a harmonic oscillator. With the initial conditions $\xi=2 x_{0}-a, \dot{\xi}=0$ at $t=0$, the solution is

$$
\xi=\left(2 x_{0}-a\right) \cos (\omega t),
$$

where

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mu g}{a}} .
$$

Hence

$$
x=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right) \cos (\omega t)+\frac{a}{2} .
$$

(b) With the directions of rotation of the rollers reversed, the friction forces also reverse directions and we have

$$
M \ddot{x}=f_{2}-f_{1},
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\xi}=\frac{2 \mu g}{a} \xi,
$$

where $\xi=2 x-a$ as before. The motion is no longer simple harmonic. With the same initial conditions, the solution is

$$
\xi=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right)\left(e^{-\omega t}+e^{\omega t}\right)=\left(2 x_{0}-a\right) \cosh (\omega t),
$$

i.e.

$$
x=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right) \cosh (\omega t)+\frac{a}{2},
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mu g}{a}}$. Note that if $x_{0} \neq \frac{a}{2}$, the rod will move in one direction until it loses contact with one roller, at which time the equation ceases to apply.

\section{3}

A torsion pendulum consists of a vertical wire attached to a mass which may rotate about the vertical. Consider three torsion pendulums which consist of identical wires from which identical homogeneous solid cubes are hung. One cube is hung from a corner, one from midway along an edge, and one from the middle of a face, as shown in Fig. 1.117. What are the ratios of the periods of the three pendulums?

$(M I T)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-266.jpg?height=208&width=514&top_left_y=494&top_left_x=525)

Fig. 1.117,

\section{Solution:}

In all the three cases, the vertical wire passes through the center of mass of the solid cube. As the ellipsoid of inertia of a homogeneous solid cube is a sphere, the rotational inertia about any direction passing through the center of mass is the same. Hence the periods of the three torsion pendulums are equal.

\section{4}

Figure $1.118$ shows a simple-minded abstraction of a camshaft with point masses $m$ and $2 m$ fixed on massless rods, all in a plane. It rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$ around the axis $O O^{\prime}$ through the long shaft, held by frictionless bearings at $O$ and $O^{\prime}$.

(a) What is the torque with respect to the mid-point of the long shaft exerted by the bearings? (Give magnitude and direction.)

(b) Locate an axis, fixed in the plane of the masses, around which the thing could rotate with zero torque when the angular velocity is constant. $(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Choose a coordinate system attached to the shaft with origin at the mid-point $C$ of the long shaft, the $z$-axis along the axis $O O^{\prime}$ and the $x$-axis in the plane of the point masses, as shown in Fig. 1.119. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-267.jpg?height=246&width=621&top_left_y=226&top_left_x=373)

Fig, 1.118.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-267.jpg?height=294&width=684&top_left_y=613&top_left_x=360)

Fig. $1.119$.

The inertia tensor with respect to $C$ is calculated using the formula $I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r_{n}^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{n i} x_{n j}\right)$, where $r_{n}^{2}=x_{n 1}^{2}+x_{n 2}^{2}+x_{n 3}^{2}$. As the masses have coordinates

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
2 m:(0,0, l), & m:(l, 0-l), \\
2 m:(0,0,-l), & m:(-l, 0, l),
\end{array}
$$

we have

$$
\mathbf{I}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
6 m l^{2} & 0 & 2 m l^{2} \\
0 & 8 m l^{2} & 0 \\
2 m l^{2} & 0 & 2 m l^{2}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Considering the angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ and torque $\mathbf{M}$ about $C$, we have

$$
\mathbf{M}=\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{J}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{J}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{J}
$$

where the star denotes differentiation with respect to the rotating coordinate system $(x, y, z)$, as the angular velocity is constant. As

$$
\mathbf{J}=I \boldsymbol{\omega}=I\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
0 \\
\omega
\end{array}\right)=2 m l^{2} \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

we find

$$
\mathbf{M}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{J}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
0 & 0 & \omega \\
2 m l^{2} \omega & 0 & 2 m l^{2} \omega
\end{array}\right|=2 m l^{2} \omega^{2} \mathbf{j} .
$$

The torque with respect to the mid-point of the shaft exerted by the bearings has magnitude $2 m l^{2} \omega^{2}$ and is in the $y$ direction.

(b) Denote the axis in the $x z$-plane about which the torque is zero as the $z^{\prime}$-axis and suppose it makes an angle $\theta$ with the $z$-axis. As shown in Fig. 1.119, the $x^{\prime}-, y^{\prime}$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes form a Cartesian frame, where the $x^{\prime}$-axis is also in the $x z$-plane. In this frame, the angular velocity $\omega$ is

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{J}=I \boldsymbol{\omega}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
6 m l^{2} \omega \sin \theta+2 m l^{2} \omega \cos \theta \\
0 \\
2 m l^{2} \omega \sin \theta+2 m l^{2} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M} &=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{J} \\
&=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
\omega \sin \theta & 0 & \omega \cos \theta \\
m l^{2} \omega(6 \sin \theta+2 \cos \theta) & 0 & 2 m l^{2} \omega(\cos \theta+\sin \theta)
\end{array}\right| \\
&=2 m l^{2} \omega^{2}(\sin 2 \theta+\cos 2 \theta) \mathbf{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\mathbf{M}=0$, we require that

$$
\tan 2 \theta=-1,
$$

i.e. $\theta=-22.5^{\circ}$ or $67.5^{\circ}$. Note that the $z^{\prime}$-axis, about which the torque vanishes, is a principal axis of inertia. As such it can also be found by the method of Problem 1147. 

\section{5}

A coin with its plane vertical and spinning with angular velocity $\omega$ in its plane as shown in Fig. $1.120$ is set down on a flat surface. What is the final angular velocity of the coin? (Assume the coin stays vertical; neglect rolling friction.)

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-269.jpg?height=261&width=287&top_left_y=561&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.120.

\section{Solution:}

The spinning coin is on a horizontal plane. As the forces acting on the coin, namely, the supporting force $\mathbf{F}$ and gravity $\mathbf{P}$, both pass through the center of mass, the angular momentum of the coin about its center of mass is conserved. Hence the angular velocity is still $\omega$ after it is set down on the surface.

\section{6}

Human legs are such that a person of normal size finds it comfortable to walk at a natural, swinging pace of about one step per second, but uncomfortable to force a pace substantially faster or slower. Neglecting the effect of the knee joint, use the simplest model you can to estimate the frequency which determines this pace, and to find what characteristic of the leg it depends on.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Consider the human leg to be a uniform pole of length $l$. In the simplest model, the swinging frequency of the leg should be equal to the characteristic frequency of the pole when it swings about its end as a fixed point. The motion is that of a compound pendulum described by

$$
\frac{1}{3} m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}=-\frac{1}{2} m g l \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{3 g}{2 l} \theta=0,
$$

for $\theta$ small. Then the frequency of swing is $\nu=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}}$. If we take $l \approx 0.4 \mathrm{~m}, \nu \approx 1 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

\section{7}

Cylinder $C$ (mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $0.070 \mathrm{~m}$ ) rolls without slipping on hill $H$ as shown in Fig. 1.121. The string does not stretch and is wrapped around the cylinder $C$.

(a) How far vertically upward does $C$ move when the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass moves down one meter?

(b) What are the magnitude and direction of the acceleration?

(c) What are the magnitude and direction of the force of static friction at the contact point $P$ ?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-270.jpg?height=394&width=585&top_left_y=1427&top_left_x=494)

Fig. 1.121. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the string is unstretchable, when the center of $C$ moves up the inclined plane a distance $\Delta x$, the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass will also drop $\Delta x$. However, as an additional length $\Delta x$ of the string is also released in the process, the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass will actually drop $2 \Delta x$. Thus when the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass moves down one meter, $C$ will move up the inclined plane $0.5 \mathrm{~m}$, or vertically up $0.5 \sin 30^{\circ}=0.25 \mathrm{~m}$.

(b) The forces involved are shown in Fig. 1.121. The above effect means that for the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass we have

$$
2 m \ddot{x}=m g-F .
$$

For the cylinder we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x} &=F+f-M g \sin 30^{\circ}, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=(F-f) R,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$. Furthermore, as the cylinder rolls without slipping we also have

$$
\ddot{x}=R \ddot{\theta} .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\ddot{x}=\left(\frac{4 m-M}{8 m+3 M}\right) g=-0.0435 g=-0.426 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} .
$$

Thus the acceleration has magnitude $0.426 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$ and acts downward along the inclined plane.

(c) $f=4 M(\ddot{x}+g)=40 \times 0.574 g=23.0$ N. Its direction is upward along the inclined plane.

\section{8}

A uniform hoop of mass $M$ and radius $R$ hangs in a vertical plane supported by a knife edge at one point on the inside circumference. Calculate the natural frequency of small oscillations.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The moment of inertia of the hoop about the supporting knife edge is

$$
I=M R^{2}+M R^{2}=2 M R^{2} .
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-272.jpg?height=277&width=200&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=660)

Fig. 1.122.

Referring to Fig. 1.122, we have the equation of motion

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M g R \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M g R \theta
$$

for small oscillations. Hence the frequency is

$$
\nu=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{M g R}{I}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}} .
$$

\section{9}

An ultra-high speed rotor consists of a homogeneous disc of mass $M$, radius $R$ and width $2 l$. It is mounted on a shaft supported on bearings separated by a distance $2 d$ as shown in Fig. 1.123. The two additional masses, of equal mass $m$, are arranged symmetrically so that the rotor remains in "static" balance. Find the time-varying force on the bearings if the rotor turns at angular velocity $\omega$.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-272.jpg?height=241&width=371&top_left_y=1569&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 1.123. 

\section{Solution:}

In the rotating frame attached to the disk, the additional masses each suffers a centrifugal force $m R \omega^{2}$, resulting in a torque $T=2 m R \omega^{2} l$. This torque is balanced by a torque of the same magnitude but opposite in direction, supplied by the bearings which are separated by a distance $2 d$. Hence the bearings each suffers a force $\frac{T}{2 d}=\frac{m R \omega^{2} l}{d}$ in the same direction as that of the centrifugal force on the nearer mass. In the fixed frame these rotate with angular velocity $\omega$.

\section{0}

A $100 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$ solar panel is coupled to a flywheel such that it converts incident sunlight into mechanical energy of rotation with $1 \%$ efficiency.
