(a) With what angular velocity would a solid cylindrical flywheel of mass $500 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $50 \mathrm{~cm}$ be rotating (if it started from rest) at the end of 8 hours of exposure of the solar panel?

Take the solar constant to be $2 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{min}$, for the full time interval. $(1 \mathrm{cal}=4.2$ Joules $)$

(b) Suppose the flywheel, whose axle is horizontal, were suddenly released from its stationary bearings and allowed to start rolling along a horizontal surface with kinetic coefficient of friction $\mu=0.1$. How far will it roll before it stops slipping?

(c) With what speed is the center of mass moving at that moment?

(d) How much energy was dissipated in heat?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The kinetic energy of rotation of the flywheel is $E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega_{0}^{2}$, where $I=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}$, giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 0.01 \times 100 \times 10^{4} \times 8 \times 60 \times 2 \times 4.2}{\frac{1}{2} \times 500 \times 0.5^{2}}} \\
&=1136 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Measure time from the instant the flywheel is released, when it is rotating with angular velocity $\omega_{0}$. After its release the only horizontal force 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-274.jpg?height=182&width=304&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 1.124.

on the flywheel is the frictional force as shown in Fig. 1.124. The equations of motion are

$$
I \dot{\omega}=-f R, \quad m \dot{v}=f .
$$

At time $t_{1}$ when the flywheel stops slipping, let its angular velocity be $\omega_{1}$. The boundary conditions are $\omega=\omega_{0}, v=0$ at $t=0, \omega=\omega_{1}, v=v_{1}=R \omega_{1}$ at $t=t_{1}$. The above equations integrate to give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I\left(\omega_{1}-\omega_{0}\right)=-f R t_{1}, \\
&m v=m R \omega_{1}=f t_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that these equations can also be obtained directly by an impulse consideration. Solving these we have

$$
\omega_{1}=\frac{\omega_{0}}{3}, \quad t_{1}=\frac{\omega_{0} R}{3 \mu g},
$$

as $I=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}, f=\mu m g$. The distance covered by the flywheel before it stops slipping is

$$
S=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{f}{m}\right) t_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mu g\left(\frac{\omega_{0} R}{3 \mu g}\right)^{2}=\frac{\left(\omega_{0} R\right)^{2}}{18 \mu g}=18290 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

(c) At $t_{1}$ the speed of the center of mass is

$$
v_{1}=R \omega_{1}=\frac{\omega_{0} R}{3}=189.3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} .
$$

(d) At time $0<t<t_{1}$, the equation of motion integrates to

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\left(\omega-\omega_{0}\right) &=-f R t \\
m v &=f t .
\end{aligned}
$$

At $0<t<t_{1}$, the flywheel both slips and rolls. Only the slipping part of the motion causes dissipation of energy into heat. The slipping velocity is

$$
v-R \omega=\frac{3 f t}{m}-R \omega_{0}
$$

and the total dissipation of energy into heat is

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q &=-\int_{0}^{t_{1}}(v-R \omega) f d t \\
&=-\frac{3 f^{2} t_{1}^{2}}{2 m}+R \omega_{0} f t_{1} \\
&=\frac{m R^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{6}=2.688 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~J} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This can also be obtained by considering the change in the kinetic energy of the flywheel:

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q &=\frac{1}{2} I \omega_{0}^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{2} I \omega_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{m R^{2}}{4} \cdot \frac{8 \omega_{0}^{2}}{9}-\frac{m}{2} \frac{\left(R \omega_{0}\right)^{2}}{9}=\frac{m R^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

same as the above.

\section{1}

A man wishes to break a long rod by hitting it on a rock. The end of the rod which is in his hand rotates without displacement as shown in Fig. 1.125. The man wishes to avoid having a large force act on his hand at the time the rod hits the rock. Which point on the rod should hit the rock? (Ignore gravity).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-275.jpg?height=432&width=353&top_left_y=1424&top_left_x=224)

Fig. 1.125. (CUSPEA)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-275.jpg?height=223&width=333&top_left_y=1570&top_left_x=858)

Fig. 1.126. 

\section{Solution:}

Let the point of impact be at distance $x$ from the end $O$ held by the hand and the reaction to the force acting on the hand as a result of the application of $F$ be $F^{\prime}$, as shown in Fig. 1.126. Considering the motion of the center of mass $C$, we have

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\int\left(F-F^{\prime}\right) d t=m v \\
\int\left[F\left(x-\frac{l}{2}\right)-F^{\prime} \frac{l}{2}\right] d t=I \omega
\end{array}
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of $C, \omega$ the angular velocity about $C$ immediately after the application of $F$, and $I=\frac{m l^{2}}{12}, m$ being the mass of the rod. As $O$ is to remain stationary, we require

$$
v-\frac{\omega l}{2}=0
$$

or

$$
v=\frac{\omega l}{2} .
$$

We also require $F^{\prime} \approx 0$, so that

$$
\int F d t=m v, \quad\left(x-\frac{l}{2}\right) \int F d t=I \omega
$$

which give

$$
x=\frac{l}{6}+\frac{l}{2}=\frac{2 l}{3} .
$$

\section{2}

The two flywheels in Fig. $1.127$ are on parallel frictionless shafts but initially do not touch. The larger wheel has $f=2000 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min}$ while the smaller is at rest. If the two parallel shafts are moved until contact occurs, find the angular velocity of the second wheel after equilibrium occurs (i.e. no further sliding at the point of contact), given that $R_{1}=2 R_{2}, I_{1}=16 I_{2}$. 
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-277.jpg?height=248&width=374&top_left_y=238&top_left_x=524)

Fig, 1.127.

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the impulse of the interacting force between the two wheels from contact to equilibrium is $J$. Then the torque of the impulse acting on the larger wheel is $J R_{1}$ and that on the smaller wheel is $J R_{2}$.

We have $I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\omega_{1}^{\prime}\right)=J R_{1}, I_{2} \omega_{2}^{\prime}=J R_{2}$, where $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{1}^{\prime}$ are the angular velocities of the larger wheel before contact and after equilibrium respectively, and $\omega_{2}^{\prime}$ is the angular velocity of the smaller wheel after equilibrium. As there is no sliding between the wheels when equilibrium is reached,

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime} R_{1}=\omega_{2}^{\prime} R_{2} .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\omega_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{I_{1} R_{1} R_{2} \omega_{1}^{\prime}}{I_{1} R_{2}^{2}+I_{2} R_{1}^{2}}=1.6 \omega_{1}=3200 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min} .
$$

\section{3}

Two uniform cylinders are spinning independently about their axes, which are parallel. One has radius $R_{1}$ and mass $M_{1}$, the other $R_{2}$ and $M_{2}$. Initially they rotate in the same sense with angular speeds $\Omega_{1}$ and $\Omega_{2}$ respectively as shown in Fig. 1.128. They are then displaced until they touch along a common tangent. After a steady state is reached, what is the final angular velocity of each cylinder?

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ be the final angular velocities of the two cylinders respectively after steady state is reached. Then 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-278.jpg?height=188&width=317&top_left_y=225&top_left_x=595)

Fig. 1.128.

$$
\omega_{1} R_{1}=-\omega_{2} R_{2} .
$$

Let $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ be the time-integrated torque 2 exerts on 1 and 1 on 2 , then

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{J_{1}}{R_{1}}=\frac{J_{2}}{R_{2}}, \\
J_{1}=I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right), \quad J_{2}=I_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right) ;
\end{gathered}
$$

or

$$
\frac{I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right)}{R_{1}}=\frac{I_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right)}{R_{2}} .
$$

As $I \propto M R^{2}$, the last equation becomes

$$
M_{1} R_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right)=M_{2} R_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right),
$$

i.e.

$$
M_{1} R_{1} \omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \omega_{2}=M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
\omega_{1}=\frac{M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}}{R_{1}\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}, \\
\omega_{2}=\frac{M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}-M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}}{R_{2}\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)} .
\end{gathered}
$$

1164

Three identical cylinders rotate with the same angular velocity $\boldsymbol{\Omega}$ about parallel central axes. They are brought together until they touch, keeping the axes parallel. A new steady state is achieved when, at each contact line, a cylinder does not slip with respect to its neighbor as shown in Fig. 1.129. How much of the original spin kinetic energy is now left? (The precise order in which the first and second touch, and the second and third touch, is irrelevant.)

(CUSPEA)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-279.jpg?height=124&width=698&top_left_y=444&top_left_x=345)

Fig. 1.129.

\section{Solution:}

As there is no slipping, if $\Omega^{\prime}$ is the final angular velocity of cylinder 1 , then cylinders 2 and 3 have final angular velocities $-\Omega^{\prime}$ and $\Omega^{\prime}$ respectively. Let $I$ be the moment of inertia of each cylinder about its axis of rotation, $M_{i j}$ be the angular impulse imparted to the $i$ th cylinder with respect to its axis of rotation by the $j$ th cylinder. Newton's third law requires that, as the cylinders have the same radius,

$$
M_{i j}=M_{j i} . \quad(i, j=1,2,3 ; \quad i \neq j)
$$

Dynamical considerations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I\left(\Omega^{\prime}-\Omega\right)=M_{12} \\
&I\left(-\Omega^{\prime}-\Omega\right)=M_{21}+M_{23}, \\
&I\left(\Omega^{\prime}-\Omega\right)=M_{32}
\end{aligned}
$$

$(1)+(3)-(2)$ gives

$$
I\left(3 \Omega^{\prime}-\Omega\right)=0,
$$

or

$$
\Omega^{\prime}=\frac{\Omega}{3} .
$$

The ratio of the spin kinetic energies after and before touching is

$$
\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}=\frac{\frac{1}{2}\left(3 I \Omega^{\prime 2}\right)}{\frac{1}{2}\left(3 I \Omega^{2}\right)}=\left(\frac{\Omega^{\prime}}{\Omega}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{9} .
$$



\section{5}

Find the ratio of the periods of the two torsion pendula shown in Fig. 1.130. The two differ only by the addition of cylindrical masses as shown in the figure. The radius of each additional mass is $1 / 4$ the radius of the disc. Each cylinder and disc have equal mass.

(Wisconsin $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-280.jpg?height=390&width=518&top_left_y=528&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.130.

\section{Solution:}

Let $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ be the moments of inertia of the two torsion pendula respectively. If $A$ is the restoring coefficient of each wire, then the equations of motion are $I_{1} \ddot{\theta}+A \theta=0, I_{2} \ddot{\theta}+A \theta=0$. Hence the angular frequencies of oscillation of the torsion pendula are $\omega_{1}=\sqrt{A / I_{1}}$ and $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{A / I_{2}}$. For the first pendulum, $I_{1}=M R^{2} / 2$, and for the second,

$$
I_{2}=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}+2\left[\frac{M}{2}\left(\frac{R}{4}\right)^{2}+M\left(\frac{3 R}{4}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{27}{16} M R^{2} \text {. }
$$

Hence the ratio of the periods is

$$
\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}=\sqrt{\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} .
$$



\section{6}

A long thin uniform bar of mass $M$ and length $L$ is hung from a fixed (assumed frictionless) axis at $A$ as shown in Fig. 1.131. The moment of inertia about $A$ is $M L^{2} / 3$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-281.jpg?height=271&width=234&top_left_y=470&top_left_x=613)

Fig. 1.131.

(a) An instantaneous horizontal impulse $J$ is delivered at $B$, a distance $a$ below $A$. What is the initial angular velocity of the bar?

(b) In general, as a result of $J$, there will be an impulse $J^{\prime}$ on the bar from the axis at $A$. What is $J^{\prime}$ ?

(c) Where should the impulse $J$ be delivered in order that $J^{\prime}$ be zero? (Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) $J a=I\left(\omega-\omega_{0}\right)$, where $\omega_{0}$ is the angular velocity of the bar before the impulse is delivered. As $\omega_{0}=0$, the initial angular velocity is

$$
\omega=\frac{J a}{I}=\frac{3 J a}{M L^{2}} .
$$

(b) The initial velocity of the center of mass of the bar is $v=\omega L / 2$. So the change in the momentum of the bar is $M v=M \omega L / 2$. As this is equal to the total impulse on the bar, we have

$$
J+J^{\prime}=\frac{M \omega L}{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
J^{\prime}=\frac{M \omega L}{2}-J=J\left(\frac{3 a}{2 L}-1\right) .
$$

(c)

$$
J^{\prime}=0, \quad \text { if } \quad a=\frac{2 L}{3} .
$$

Hence there will be no impulse from the axis if $J$ is delivered at a point $2 L / 3$ below $A$.

\section{7}

The crankshaft shown in Fig. $1.132$ rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$. Calculate the resultant forces on the bearings. In a sketch show the directions of these reactions and the direction of the angular momentum.

(Assume the crankshaft is made of thin rods with uniform density).

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-282.jpg?height=235&width=517&top_left_y=752&top_left_x=227)

Fig. 1.132.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-282.jpg?height=207&width=483&top_left_y=795&top_left_x=824)

Fig. $1.133$.

\section{Solution:}

Consider the motion in a frame attached to the crankshaft as shown in Fig. 1.133. As the rods are either parallel or perpendicular to the axis of rotation, the centrifugal force on each rod can be considered as that on a point of the same mass located at its center of mass. Let $N$ denote the constraint force exerted by the bearing on each shaft. As there is no rotation about the $z$-axis, we require that the moments of the forces about $O$ should balance:

$$
2 b \cdot N+\frac{b}{2} \cdot \rho b \cdot a \omega^{2}=\frac{3 b}{2} \cdot \rho b \cdot a \omega^{2}+2 b \cdot \rho a \cdot \frac{a}{2} \omega^{2},
$$

giving

$$
N=\frac{\rho a \omega^{2}}{2}(a+b),
$$

where $\rho$ is the mass per unit length of the rods. The reactions on the bearings are equal and opposite to $N$ as shown in Fig. 1.131. In a fixed frame these forces are rotating, together with the crankshaft, with angular velocity $\omega$ about the axle. The angular momentum of the crankshaft is given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
L_{x} \\
L_{y} \\
L_{z}
\end{array}\right)=I\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
I_{x x} \omega \\
I_{y x} \omega \\
I_{z x} \omega
\end{array}\right),
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia tensor about $O$ with elements

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} \Delta m_{n}\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right) .
$$

As all $z=0, I_{z x}=0$. Furthermore it can be seen that $I_{x x}>0, I_{y x}<0$. Hence the angular momentum $L$ has direction in the rotating coordinate frame as shown in Fig. 1.133. Note that gravity has been neglected in the calculation, otherwise there is an additional constant force acting on each bearing, $(2 a+b) \rho g$ in magnitude and vertically downward in direction in the fixed frame.

\section{8}

Two equal point masses $M$ are connected by a massless rigid rod of length $2 A$ (a dumbbell) which is constrained to rotate about an axle fixed to the center of the rod at an angle $\theta$ (Fig. 1.134). The center of the rod is at the origin of coordinates, the axle along the $z$-axis, and the dumbbell lies in the $x z$-plane at $t=0$. The angular velocity $\omega$ is a constant in time and is directed along the $z$-axis.

(a) Calculate all elements of the inertia tensor. (Be sure to specify the coordinate system you use.)

(b) Using the elements just calculated, find the angular momentum of the dumbbell in the laboratory frame as a function of time.

(c) Using the equation $\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}$, calculate the angular momentum and show that it is equal to the answer for part (b).

(d) Calculate the torque on the axle as a function of time.

(e) Calculate the kinetic energy of the dumbbell.

\section{Solution:}

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

(a) Use a coordinate frame $x y z$ attached to the dumbbell such that the two point masses are in the $x z$-plane. The elements of the inertia tensor about $O$, given by $I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right)$, are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-284.jpg?height=281&width=366&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=610)

Fig. 1.134.

$$
\begin{gathered}
I_{x x}=2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta, \quad I_{y y}=2 M A^{2}, \quad I_{z z}=2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
I_{x y}=I_{y z}=0, \quad I_{z x}=-2 M A^{2} \cos \theta \sin \theta=-M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus

$$
\mathbb{I}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta & 0 & -M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
0 & 2 M A^{2} & 0 \\
-M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta & 0 & 2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(b) Use a laboratory frame $x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ such that the $z^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the $z$-axis of the rotating frame in (a) and that all the respective axes of the two frames coincide at $t=0$. The unit vectors along the axes of the two frames are related by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
\mathbf{e}_{1} \\
\mathbf{e}_{2} \\
\mathbf{e}_{3}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \omega t & \sin \omega t & 0 \\
-\sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\mathbf{e}_{1}^{\prime} \\
\mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime} \\
\mathbf{e}_{3}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

Then the inertia tensor in the laboratory frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{I}^{\prime} &=S^{\prime} \mathbb{I} S=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \omega t & -\sin \omega t & 0 \\
\sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta & 0 & -M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
0 & 2 M A^{2} & 0 \\
-M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta & 0 & 2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \omega t & \sin \omega t & 0 \\
-\sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the angular momentum of the dumbbell in the laboratory frame is

$$
\mathbf{L}=\mathbb{I}^{\prime}\left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
0 \\
\omega
\end{array}\right)=M A^{2} \omega\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\sin 2 \theta \cos \omega t \\
-\sin 2 \theta \sin \omega t \\
2 \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

(c) The radius vectors of $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$ from $O$ are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{r}_{1}=A(\sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta) \\
&\mathbf{r}_{2}=A(-\sin \theta, 0,-\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

in the rotating frame. Using the transformation for the unit vectors we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{1} &=A\left[\sin \theta\left(\mathbf{e}_{1}^{\prime} \cos \omega t+\mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime} \sin \omega t\right)+\mathbf{e}_{3}^{\prime} \cos \theta\right] \\
&=A(\sin \theta \cos \omega t, \sin \theta \sin \omega t, \cos \theta) \\
\mathbf{r}_{2} &=A(-\sin \theta \cos \omega t,-\sin \theta \sin \omega t,-\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

in the laboratory frame. The angular momentum of the system in the laboratory frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{L}=& \sum \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{p}=\sum M \mathbf{r} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})=\sum M\left[r^{2} \omega-(\mathbf{r} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega}) \mathbf{r}\right] \\
=& 2 M A^{2} \omega \mathbf{e}_{3}^{\prime} \\
&-M A^{2} \omega \cos \theta\left(\mathbf{e}_{1}^{\prime} \sin \theta \cos \omega t+\mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime} \sin \theta \sin \omega t+\mathbf{e}_{3} \cos \theta\right) \\
&+M A^{2} \omega \cos \theta\left(-\mathbf{e}_{1}^{\prime} \sin \theta \cos \omega t-\mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime} \sin \theta \sin \omega t-\mathbf{e}_{3}^{\prime} \cos \theta\right) \\
=& M A^{2} \omega\left(-\mathbf{e}_{1}^{\prime} \sin 2 \theta \cos \omega t-\mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime} \sin 2 \theta \sin \omega t+\mathbf{e}_{3}^{\prime} 2 \sin ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

same as that obtained in (b).

(d) The torque on the axle is

$$
\tau=\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=M A^{2} \omega^{2}\left[\sin 2 \theta \sin \omega t \mathrm{e}_{1}^{\prime}-\sin 2 \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{2}^{\prime}\right] .
$$

(e) As $\boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega)$ the rotational kinetic energy of the dumbbell is

$$
T=\frac{I_{z z} \omega^{2}}{2}=M A^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
$$

\section{9}

A squirrel of mass $m$ runs at a constant speed $V_{0}$ relative to a cylindrical exercise cage of radius $R$ and moment of inertia $I$ as shown in Fig. 1.135. The cage has a damping torque proportional to its angular velocity. Neglect the dimensions of the squirrel compared with $R$. If initially the cage is at rest and the squirrel is at the bottom and running, find the motion of the squirrel relative to a fixed coordinate system in the small oscillation, underdamped case. Find the squirrel's angular velocity in terms of its angle relative to the vertical for arbitrary angular displacements for the undamped case. Discuss any design criteria for the cage in this case.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-286.jpg?height=250&width=201&top_left_y=573&top_left_x=358)

Fig. 1.135.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-286.jpg?height=361&width=248&top_left_y=522&top_left_x=958)

Fig. 1.136.

\section{Solution:}

In a fixed coordinate frame, define $\theta$ as shown in Fig. 1.136. For the squirrel, the equation of motion is

$$
m R \ddot{\theta}=f-m g \sin \theta,
$$

and for the cage the equation of motion is

$$
I \ddot{\varphi}=-f R-k \dot{\varphi},
$$

where $f$ is the friction between the squirrel and the cage and $k$ is a constant. In addition, as the squirrel has a constant speed $V_{0}$ relative to the cage, we have

$$
R(\dot{\theta}-\dot{\varphi})=V_{0},
$$

which means $\ddot{\varphi}=\ddot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}=\dot{\theta}-\frac{V_{0}}{R}$. Making use of these and eliminating $f$ from the equations of motion give

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+k \dot{\theta}+m g R \sin \theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{R} .
$$

For small oscillations, $\theta \ll 1$ and the above reduces to

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+k \dot{\theta}+m g R \theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{R} .
$$

A particular solution of this equation is

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}},
$$

while for underdamping the general solution for the homogeneous equation is

$$
\theta=e^{-b t}(A \sin \omega t+B \cos \omega t)
$$

where

$$
b=\frac{k}{2\left(I+m R^{2}\right)}, \quad \omega=\sqrt{\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}}-b^{2}} .
$$

Hence the general solution of the above equation is

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}+e^{-b t}(A \sin \omega t+B \cos \omega t) .
$$

Using the initial condition that at $t=0, \theta=0, \varphi=0, \dot{\varphi}=0, \dot{\theta}=\frac{V_{0}}{R}$, we find

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}-\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}\left[\cos \omega t+\left(\frac{b}{\omega}-\frac{m g R}{\omega K}\right) \sin \omega t\right] e^{-b t}
$$

For the undamped case $(k=0)$, the differential equation is

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+m g R \theta=0
$$

or, as $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$,

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) d \dot{\theta}^{2}=-2 m g R \theta d \theta,
$$

which integrates to

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\left(\frac{V_{0}}{R}\right)^{2}-\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}} \theta^{2}
$$

using the initial condition for $\dot{\theta}$. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{V_{0}}{R}\right)^{2}-\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}} \theta^{2}} \text {. }
$$

We require $I+m R^{2} \gg k$ for the undamped case to hold. Hence the cage should be designed with a large moment of inertia. 

\section{0}

A thin square plate with side length $a$ rotates at a constant angular frequency $\omega$ about an axis through the center tilted by an angle $\theta$ with respect to the normal to the plate.

(a) Find the principal moments of inertia.

(b) Find the angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ in the laboratory system.

(c) Calculate the torque on the axis.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-288.jpg?height=378&width=552&top_left_y=664&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.137.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take origin at the center $O$ of the square. For a coordinate frame attached to the square, take the plane of the square as the $x y$-plane with the $x$ - and $y$-axis parallel to the sides. The $z$-axis, which is along the normal, makes an angle $\theta$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the laboratory frame about which the square rotates, as shown in Fig. 1.137. We also assume that the $x$-, $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are coplanar.

Then by symmetry the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of inertia about $O$, with corresponding moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=I_{y y}=\frac{m a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{m a^{2}}{6},
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the square.

(b) The angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ resolved along the rotating frame coordinate axes is 

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
J_{x} \\
J_{y} \\
J_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{6}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

We can choose the laboratory frame so that its $y^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the $y$-axis at $t=0$. Then the unit vectors of the two frames are related by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathbf{e}_{x}=\cos \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{y}=-\sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{z}=-\sin \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}-\sin \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the angular momentum resolved along the laboratory frame coordinate axes is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{c}
J_{x^{\prime}} \\
J_{y^{\prime}} \\
J_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right) &=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \theta \cos \omega t & -\sin \omega t & -\sin \theta \cos \omega t \\
\cos \theta \sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & -\sin \theta \sin \omega t \\
\sin \theta & 0 & \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \cos \omega t \\
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \sin \omega t \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega\left(1+\cos ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The torque on the axis is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{lab}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{J}=\omega \times \mathbf{J} \\
& =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\mathbf{e}_{x} & \mathbf{e}_{y} & \mathbf{e}_{z} \\\omega \sin \theta & 0 & \omega \cos \theta \\\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta & 0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta\end{array}\right| \\
& =-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta e_{y} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

The torque can be expressed in terms of components in the laboratory frame:

$$
\mathbf{M}=-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta\left(-\sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}\right) .
$$

This can also be obtained by differentiating $\mathbf{L}$ in the laboratory frame:

$$
\mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\text {Iab }} .
$$



\section{1}

A thin flat rectangular plate, of mass $M$ and sides $a$ by $2 a$, rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$ about an axle through two diagonal corners, as shown in Fig. 1.138. The axle is supported at the corners of the plate by bearings which can exert forces only on the axle. Ignoring gravitational and frictional forces, find the force exerted by each bearing on the axle as a function of time.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-290.jpg?height=314&width=464&top_left_y=605&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.138.

\section{Solution:}

Use a coordinate frame attached to the plate with the origin at the center of mass $O$, the $y$-axis along the normal, and the $z$-axis parallel to the long side of the rectangle, as shown in Fig. 1.138. Then the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes with principal moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=\frac{M a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{y y}=\frac{5 M a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{4 M a^{2}}{12} .
$$

Let $z^{\prime}$ denote the axis of rotation and $\alpha$ the angle between the $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes. The angular momentum of the plate is

$$
\mathbf{L}=\frac{M a^{2}}{12}\left(\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 4
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \alpha \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right)=\frac{M a^{2} \omega}{12}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sin \alpha \\
0 \\
4 \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right)
$$

The torque on the axle of the plate is then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\tau} &=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {fxed }}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{L}=\omega \times \mathbf{L} \\
&=\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{12}\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{e}_{x} & \mathbf{e}_{y} & \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
\sin \alpha & 0 & \cos \alpha \\
\sin \alpha & 0 & 4 \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right| \\
&=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{4} \cos \alpha \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{y}=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{10} \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\sin \alpha=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}, \cos \alpha=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}$. Let $N_{A}, N_{B}$ be the constraint forces exerted by the bearings on the axle at $A, B$ respectively. Rotate the coordinate frame $O x y z$ about the $y$-axes so that the $z$ and $z^{\prime}$-axis coincide. The new coordinate axes are the $x^{\prime}$-axis, $y^{\prime}$-axis which is identical with the $y$-axis, and $z^{\prime}$-axis shown in Fig. 1.138. As the center of mass is stationary, we have

$$
N_{A x^{\prime}}+N_{B x^{\prime}}=0, \quad N_{A y^{\prime}}+N_{B y^{\prime}}=0 .
$$

Considering the torque about $O$ we have

$$
N_{B x^{\prime}} d-N_{A x^{\prime}} d=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{10}, \quad N_{A y^{\prime}} d-N_{B y^{\prime}} d=0,
$$

where $d=\frac{1}{2} \overline{A B}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} a$. The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&N_{A y^{\prime}}=N_{B y^{\prime}}=0 \\
&N_{A x^{\prime}}=\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{20 d}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}}, \\
&N_{B x^{\prime}}=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{20 d}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

These forces are fixed in the rotating frame. In a fixed coordinate frame they rotate with angular velocity $\omega$. In a fixed frame $O x^{\prime \prime} y^{\prime \prime} z^{\prime \prime}$ with the same $z^{\prime}$-axis and the $x^{\prime \prime}$-axis coinciding with the $x^{\prime}$-axis at $t=0$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{A x^{\prime \prime}}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \cos \omega t, & N_{A y^{\prime \prime}}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \sin \omega t, \\
N_{B x^{\prime \prime}}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \cos \omega t, & N_{B y^{\prime \prime}}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \sin \omega t .
\end{array}
$$



\section{2}

A homogeneous thin rod of mass $M$ and length $b$ is attached by means of an inextensible cord to a spring whose spring constant is $k$. The cord passes over a very small and smooth pulley fixed at $P$. The rod is free to rotate about $A$ without friction throughout the angular range $-\pi<\theta \leq \pi$ (Fig. 1.139). When $c=0$ the spring has its natural length. It is assumed that $b<a$ and that gravity acts downward.

(a) Find the values of $\theta$ for which the system is in static equilibrium, and determine in each case if the equilibrium is stable, unstable or neutral.

(b) Find the frequencies for small oscillations about the points of stable equilibrium.

(Note: line $P A$ is parallel to $\mathbf{g}$ ).

(SUNY, Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-292.jpg?height=300&width=366&top_left_y=833&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.139.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take the direction pointing out of the paper as the positive direction of the torques. The torque about point $A$ due to gravity is

$$
L_{g}=-\frac{M g b}{2} \sin \theta,
$$

and that caused by the restoring force due to the spring is $L_{k}=k c b \sin \theta_{1}$, where $\theta_{1}$ is the angle formed by the rod with the rope, or, using the sine theorem

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{c}{\sin \theta}=\frac{a}{\sin \theta_{1}}, \\
&L_{k}=k b a \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

For equilibrium, we require $L_{g}+L_{k}=0$, or $k a \sin \theta=\frac{M g}{2} \sin \theta$. i) If $k a=M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied for all $\theta$ and the equilibrium is neutral.

ii) If $k a<M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied if $\theta=0$ or $\theta=\pi$. Consider the equilibrium at $\theta=0$. Let $\theta=0 \pm \epsilon$, where $\epsilon>0$ is a small angle. Then

$$
L=L_{k}+L_{g} \approx \mp b\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=+\epsilon \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=-\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $L$ tends to increase $\epsilon$ in both cases and the equilibrium is unstable. For the equilibrium at $\theta=\pi \pm \epsilon$, we have

$$
L=\pm\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=\pi-\epsilon, \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=\pi+\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case $L$ tends to reduce $\epsilon$ and the equilibrium is stable.

iii) If $k a>M g / 2$, the situation is opposite to that of (ii). Hence in this case $\theta=0$ is a position of stable equilibrium and $\theta=\pi$ is a position of unstable equilibrium.

(b) Take the case of $k a>M g / 2$ where $\theta=0$ is a position of stable equilibrium. Let $\theta=\epsilon$ where $\epsilon$ is a small angle. The equation of motion is

$$
b\left(k a-\frac{M g}{2}\right) \sin \epsilon=-\frac{M b^{2}}{3} \ddot{\epsilon},
$$

or for small oscillations

$$
b(2 k a-M g) \epsilon+\frac{2 M b^{2}}{3} \ddot{\epsilon}=0 .
$$

Hence the frequency of oscillation is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3(2 k a-M g)}{2 M b}} .
$$

Similarly in the case $k a<M g / 2$, the frequency of small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium at $\theta=\pi$ is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3(M g-2 k a)}{2 M b}} .
$$

\section{3}

A thin ring of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is pivoted at $P$ on a frictionless table, as shown in Fig. 1.140. A bug of mass $m$ runs along the ring with speed $v$ with respect to the ring. The bug starts from the pivot with the ring at rest. How fast is the bug moving with respect to the table when it reaches the diametrically opposite point on the ring (point $X$ )?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-294.jpg?height=258&width=231&top_left_y=924&top_left_x=659)

Fig. 1.140.

\section{Solution:}

The moment of inertia of the ring with respect to the pivot $P$ is

$$
I=M R^{2}+M R^{2}=2 M R^{2} .
$$

When the bug reaches point $X$, its velocity with respect to the table is $v-2 R \omega$ and the angular momentum of the ring about $P$ is

$$
J=2 M R^{2} \omega,
$$

where $\omega$ is the angular velocity of the ring about $P$ at that instant. Initially the total angular momentum of the ring and bug about $P$ is zero. Conservation of angular momentum then gives

$$
2 M R^{2} \omega-2 m R(v-2 R \omega)=0,
$$

or

$$
\omega=\frac{m v}{R(M+2 m)}
$$

The velocity of the bug at point $X$ with respect to the table is

$$
v-2 R \omega=\frac{M v}{M+2 m} .
$$

\section{4}

A cone of height $h$ and base radius $R$ is constrained to rotate about its vertical axis, as shown in Fig. 1.141. A thin, straight groove is cut in the surface of the cone from apex to base as shown. The cone is set rotating with initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ around its axis and a small (point-like) bead of mass $m$ is released at the top of the frictionless groove and is permitted to slide down under gravity. Assume that the bead stays in the groove, and that the moment of inertia of the cone about its axis is $I_{0}$.

(a) What is the angular velocity of the cone when the bead reaches the bottom?

(b) Find the speed of the bead in the laboratory just as it leaves the cone.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-295.jpg?height=357&width=303&top_left_y=1232&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.141.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the total angular momentum of the system is conserved, the angular velocity $\omega$ of the cone at the time when the bead reaches the bottom satisfies the relation 

$$
I_{0} \omega_{0}=\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right) \omega .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}} .
$$

(b) As the energy of the system is conserved, the velocity $v$ of the bead when it reaches the bottom satisfies

$$
\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}+m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega^{2}
$$

with

$$
v^{2}=v_{\|}^{2}+v_{\perp}^{2}=v_{\|}^{2}+R^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

where $v_{\|}$is velocity of the bead parallel to the groove and $v_{\perp}$ is that perpendicular to the groove. Thus

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{\|}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}+m g h-\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m R^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

giving

$$
v_{\|}^{2}=I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}-\frac{\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right)}{m} \frac{I_{0}^{2} \omega^{2}}{\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right)^{2}}+2 g h=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h .
$$

Hence the velocity of the bead when it reaches the bottom is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{v} &=v_{\perp} \mathbf{i}+v_{\|} \mathbf{j} \\
&=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0} R}{I_{0}+m R^{2}} \mathbf{i}+\sqrt{\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h} \mathbf{j},
\end{aligned}
$$

$i$ and $j$ being unit vectors along and perpendicular to the groove respectively, with magnitude

$$
v=\sqrt{\left(\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0} R}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}\right)^{2}+\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h} .
$$

This speed could have been obtained directly by substituting the expression for $\omega$ in the energy equation.

\section{5}

A thin uniform disc, radius $a$ and mass $m$, is rotating freely on a frictionless bearing with uniform angular velocity $\omega$ about a fixed vertical axis passing through its center, and inclined at angle $\alpha$ to the symmetry axis of the disc. What is the magnitude and direction of the torque, and of the net force acting between the disc and the axis?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-297.jpg?height=357&width=318&top_left_y=466&top_left_x=593)

Fig. $1.142$.

\section{Solution:}

Take a coordinate frame $O x y z$ attached to the disc with the origin at its center $O$, the $z$-axis along the normal to the disc, and the $x$-axis in the plane of the $z$-axis and the axis of rotation $z^{\prime}$, as shown in Fig. 1.142. The $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of the disc with principal moments of inertia

$$
I_{x}=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}, \quad I_{y}=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}, \quad I_{z}=\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} .
$$

The angular momentum about $O$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{L} &=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1}{4} m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{4} m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{1}{2} m a^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \alpha \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}\left(\omega \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+2 \omega \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the torque is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M} &=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {fixed }}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{L}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{L} \\
&=\left(\omega \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+\omega \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) \times \frac{1}{4} m a^{2} \omega\left(\sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+2 \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) \\
&=-\frac{1}{4} m a^{2} \omega \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

The torque is in the plane of the disc and is perpendicular to the plane formed by the normal to the disc and the axis of rotation. It rotates with the disc. As the center of mass of the disc is stationary, the net force on the disc is zero.

\section{6}

A moon of mass $m$ orbits with angular velocity $\omega$ around a planet of mass $M$. Assume $m \ll M$. The rotation of the moon can be neglected but the planet rotates about its axis with angular velocity $S$. The axis of rotation of the planet is perpendicular to the plane of the orbit. Let $I=$ moment of the inertia of the planet about its axis and $D=$ distance from the moon to the center of the planet.

(a) Find expressions for the total angular momentum $L$ of the system about its center of mass and for the total energy $E$. Eliminate $D$ from both these expressions.

(b) Generally the two angular velocities $\omega$ and $\Omega$ are unequal. Suppose there is a mechanism such as tidal friction which can reduce $E$ if $\omega \neq \Omega$, but conserves angular momentum. By examining the behavior of $E$ as a function of $\omega$, show that there is a range of initial conditions such that eventually $\omega=\Omega$ and a stable final configuration obtains.

Famous examples of this effect occur in the orbits of the moons of Mercury and Venus. (However, it is the lighter body whose rotation is relevant in these examples.)

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $M \gg m$, the position of the planet can be considered to be fixed in space. The total angular momentum about the center of mass and the total energy of the system of moon and planet are then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=I \Omega+m D^{2} \omega, \\
E &=\frac{1}{2} I \Omega^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m D^{2} \omega^{2}-\frac{G M m}{D} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering the gravitational attraction between the two bodies we have

$$
\frac{G M m}{D^{2}}=m D \omega^{2}
$$

or

$$
D=\left(\frac{G M}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}
$$

Substituting this in the above gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L=I \Omega+m\left(\frac{G^{2} M^{2}}{\omega}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}, \\
&E=\frac{1}{2} I \Omega^{2}-\frac{m}{2}(G M \omega)^{\frac{2}{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As angular momentum is to be conserved, $d L=0$, giving

$$
\frac{d \Omega}{d \omega}=\frac{m D^{2}}{3 I} .
$$

For a configuration to be stable, the corresponding energy must be a minimum. Differentiating (1), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d E &=I \Omega d \Omega-\frac{m}{3}(G M)^{\frac{3}{2}} \omega^{-\frac{1}{3}} d \omega \\
&=\frac{m D^{2}}{3}(\Omega-\omega) d \omega \\
\frac{d^{2} E}{d \omega^{2}} &=\frac{2 m D}{3}(\Omega-\omega) \frac{d D}{d \omega}+\frac{m D^{2}}{3}\left(\frac{d \Omega}{d \omega}-1\right) \\
&=\frac{m D^{2}}{9}\left(\frac{m D^{2}}{I}+1-\frac{4 \Omega}{\omega}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for the configuration to be stable, we require that

$$
\Omega \approx \omega,
$$

and furthermore that

$$
\frac{m D^{2}}{I}+1>\frac{4 \Omega}{\omega} .
$$

This latter condition can be satisfied by a range of initial conditions.

\section{7}

A pendulum consists of a uniform rigid rod of length $L$, mass $M$, a bug of mass $M / 3$ which can crawl along the rod. The rod is pivoted at one end and swings in a vertical plane. Initially the bug is at the pivot-end of the rod, which is at rest at an angle $\theta_{0}\left(\theta_{0} \ll 1 \mathrm{rad}\right)$ from the vertical as shown in Fig. 1.143, is released. For $t>0$ the bug crawls slowly with constant speed $V$ along the rod towards the bottom end of the rod.

(a) Find the frequency $\omega$ of the swing of the pendulum when the bug has crawled a distance $l$ along the rod.

(b) Find the amplitude of the swing of the pendulum when the bug has crawled to the bottom end of the $\operatorname{rod}(l=L)$.

(c) How slowly must the bug crawl in order that your answers for part (a) and (b) be valid?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-300.jpg?height=387&width=237&top_left_y=1242&top_left_x=658)

Fig. 1.143.

\section{Solution:}

(a) When the bug has crawled a distance $l$, the moment of inertia of the rod and bug about the pivot is 

$$
I=\frac{1}{3} M L^{2}+\frac{1}{3} M l^{2}=\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion of the pendulum is

$$
\frac{\dot{d}}{d t}(I \dot{\theta})=-M g \frac{L}{2} \sin \theta-\frac{1}{3} M g l \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+\frac{2}{3} M l \dot{\theta}=-M g \sin \theta\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{l}{3}\right) .
$$

For small oscillations it becomes

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{2 l i \dot{\theta}}{L^{2}+l^{2}}+\frac{g\left(l+\frac{3 L}{2}\right) \theta}{L^{2}+l^{2}}=0 .
$$

If the bug crawls so slowly that the change in $l$ in a period of oscillation is negligible, i.e. $i=v \ll l \omega$, we can ignore the second term and write

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)} \theta=0
$$

Hence the angular frequency of oscillation $\omega$ is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}} .
$$

(b) Consider the motion of the bug along the rod,

$$
\frac{M}{3}\left(\ddot{l}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=\frac{M g \cos \theta}{3}-f,
$$

where $f$ is the force exerted on the bug by the rod. As the bug crawls with constant speed, $\ddot{l}=0$. Also for small oscillations, $\cos \theta \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2}$. The above gives

$$
f=\frac{M g}{3}-\frac{M g}{6} \theta^{2}+\frac{M l \dot{\theta}^{2}}{3} .
$$

The work done by $f$ as the bug crawls a distance $d l$ is then

$$
d W=-f d l=-\frac{M g}{3} d l+\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \theta^{2}}{2}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d l
$$

which is stored as energy of the system. The first term on the right-hand side is the change in the potential energy of the bug, while the second term is the change in the energy of oscillation $E$ of the system, 

$$
d E=\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \theta^{2}}{2}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d l .
$$

Under the condition $i \ll l \omega, l$ hardly changes in a period of oscillation and can be taken to be constant. For each $l$, when we consider a full period, the kinematic quantities in the above equation can be replaced by their average values

$$
d E=\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \overline{\theta^{2}}}{2}-\overline{\overrightarrow{\theta^{2}}}\right) d l .
$$

Now, in single harmonic oscillations the potential and kinetic energy are equal on average, so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{T} &=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{M}{3}\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{E}{2}, \\
\bar{V} &=\frac{M g L}{2}(1-\overline{\cos \theta})+\frac{M g l}{3}(1-\overline{\cos \theta}) \\
&=\frac{M g}{2}\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{l}{3}\right) \overline{\theta^{2}}=\frac{E}{2} ;
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\theta^{2}} &=\frac{3 E}{M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}, \\
\overline{\theta^{2}} &=\frac{6 E}{M g(3 L+2 l)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting these in the energy equation we have

$$
\frac{d E}{E}=\left(\frac{1}{3 L+2 l}-\frac{l}{L^{2}+l^{2}}\right) d l
$$

or

$$
\ln E=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(\frac{3 L+2 l}{L^{2}+l^{2}}\right)+K,
$$

where $K$ is a constant. Initially, $l=0, E=E_{0}$, i.e.

$$
\ln E_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(\frac{3}{L}\right)+K,
$$

and we thus have

$$
\ln \frac{E}{E_{0}}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left[\frac{(3 L+2 l) L}{3\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}\right] .
$$

When $l=L$

$$
\ln \frac{E}{E_{0}}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \frac{5}{6},
$$

i.e.

$$
E=\sqrt{\frac{5}{6}} E_{0} .
$$

$\theta$ is equal to the amplitude when $\dot{\theta}=0$ i.e. $T=0$ and $E=V$. When $l=L$, the amplitude $\theta_{\max }$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2} M g\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{L}{3}\right) \theta_{\max }^{2}=E .
$$

When $l=0$, we have

$$
\frac{1}{2} M g \cdot \frac{L}{2} \theta_{0}^{2}=E_{0} .
$$

Then as $E=\sqrt{\frac{5}{6}} E_{0}$, the above expressions give

$$
\theta_{\max }=\left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}} \theta_{0} .
$$

(c) We have neglected the radial velocity of the bug as compared with its tangential velocity: $i \ll l \omega$. This is the condition that must be assumed for the above to be valid.

\section{8}

A uniform rod of mass $m$ and length $l$ has its lower end driven sinusoidally up and down as shown in Fig. $1.144$ with amplitude $A$ and angular frequency $\omega$. It is a fact that for suitable choices of the parameters $m, l, A$ and $\omega$, the pendulum will undergo oscillations around the statically unstable position $\theta=0$. (The motion is confined to the plane of the diagram.)

(a) List all the components of all forces on the rod.

(b) Is the angular momentum of the rod conserved?

(c) Is the linear momentum of the rod conserved?

(d) Is the energy of the rod conserved?

(e) Find the components of the acceleration of the center of mass as functions of time expressed in terms of $\theta(t)$. (f) Write down the equation of angular motion of the rod in terms of the forces on it.

(g) Use (e) and (f) to find an equation of motion for $\theta(t)$.

YOU ARE NOT ASKED TO SOLVE THIS EQUATION OF MOTION, BUT TO INTERPRET IT:

(h) Qualitatively, what kind of motion is predicted when $A=0$ ?

(i) Physically, how is it that oscillations about the upright position can occur?

(Hint: how do you expect the frequency of the $\theta$ motion to be related to $\omega ?)$

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-304.jpg?height=280&width=248&top_left_y=870&top_left_x=347)

Fig. 1.144.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-304.jpg?height=411&width=369&top_left_y=802&top_left_x=873)

Fig. 1.145.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The forces on the rod are the gravity $m g$, and the components $f_{x}$, $f_{y}$ of the force $f$ exerted by the moving pivot.

(b) The angular momentum of the rod is not conserved.

(c) The linear momentum of the rod is not conserved.

(d) The energy of the rod is not conserved.

(e) Use a moving coordinate frame $O^{\prime} x^{\prime} y^{\prime}$ as shown in Fig. $1.145$ with the axes parallel to the corresponding axes of the fixed frame $O x y$, and the origin $O^{\prime}$ moving along the $y$-axis such that its radius vector from $O$ is

$$
\mathbf{r}_{0}=A \cos \omega t \mathbf{j} .
$$

Then the radius vector of the center of mass of the rod is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r} &=\mathbf{r}_{0}+\frac{l}{2} \sin \theta \mathbf{i}+\frac{l}{2} \cos \theta \mathbf{j} \\
&=\frac{l}{2} \sin \theta \mathbf{i}+\left(A \cos \omega t+\frac{l}{2} \cos \theta\right) \mathbf{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t} &=\frac{l}{2} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta \dot{\mathbf{i}}-\left(A \omega \sin \omega t+\frac{l}{2} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta\right) \mathbf{j} \\
\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{l}{2}\left(\ddot{\theta} \cos \theta-\dot{\theta}^{2} \sin \theta\right) \mathbf{i}-\left(A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t+\frac{l}{2} \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+\frac{l}{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta\right) \mathbf{j} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation gives the $x$ and $y$ components of the acceleration of the center of mass.

(f) (g) Let $x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}$ be the coordinates of the center of mass of the rod in the moving frame. Then

$$
x=x^{\prime}, \quad y=y^{\prime}+A \cos \omega t,
$$

and hence

$$
\ddot{x}=\ddot{x^{\prime}}, \quad \ddot{y}=\ddot{y^{\prime}}-A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t .
$$

Newton's second law gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x^{\prime}}=m \ddot{x}=f_{x}, \\
&m \ddot{y^{\prime}}=m \ddot{y}+m A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t=f_{y}+m A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus to apply Newton's second law in the moving frame, a fictitious force $m A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t \mathbf{j}^{\prime}$ has to be added.

Consider the rotation of the rod in the moving frame about the origin $O^{\prime}$. We have

$$
\frac{1}{3} m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}=m g \cdot \frac{l}{2} \sin \theta-m A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t \cdot \frac{l}{2} \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{3}{2 l}\left(g-A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t\right) \sin \theta .
$$

(h) If $A=0$, the motion is just that of rotation of a rod under the action of gravity, there being no difference between the moving and fixed frames.

(i) Suppose the rod oscillates about the upright position $\theta=0$. Then $\theta \approx 0$ and the equation of angular motion becomes 

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{3}{2 l}\left(A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t-g\right) \theta=0 .
$$

Thus, if $A \neq 0$ the torque of the fictitious force may sometimes act as restoring torque. For a certain interval of time we may have $A \omega^{2} \cos \omega t-g>$ 0 and oscillations about the upright position may occur.

\section{9}

A yo-yo of mass $M$ lies on a smooth horizontal table as shown in Fig. 1.146. The moment of inertia about the center may be taken as $\frac{1}{2} M A^{2}$. A string is pulled with force $F$ from the inner radius $B$ as indicated in Fig. 1.147.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-306.jpg?height=239&width=323&top_left_y=845&top_left_x=326)

Fig. 1.146.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-306.jpg?height=231&width=318&top_left_y=849&top_left_x=841)

Fig. 1.147.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-306.jpg?height=213&width=174&top_left_y=856&top_left_x=1183)

$\theta=\pi$

(a) In what direction will the yo-yo roll if $\theta=0, \pi / 2, \pi$ ?

(b) For what value of $\theta$ will the yo-yo slide without rolling independent of the roughness (coefficient of friction) of the table or the magnitude of $F$ ?

(c) At what angle $\theta$ will the yo-yo roll, independent of the smoothness of the table?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Assume that the yo-yo is at rest before the application of the force $F$.

(a) As there is no friction acting on the yo-yo, the direction of rolling is only determined by the direction of the torque of the applied force $F$ about its center. The direction of rolling is shown in Fig. $1.147$ for $\theta=0, \pi / 2$ or $\pi$

(b) The friction acting on the yo-yo is $f=\mu N$, where $N$ is the normal reaction of the table, as shown in Fig. 1.146. The yo-yo will slide without rolling if 

$$
F B=\mu N A \text {. }
$$

The acceleration $a$ of the center of mass of the yo-yo is given by

$$
F \cos \theta-\mu N=M a \text {. }
$$

Thus

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{M a}{F}+\frac{B}{A} .
$$

If this condition is satisfied, $\theta$ is independent of $\mu$. It still depends on $F$ unless $a=0$, i.e. no motion.

(c) Let the acceleration of the center of mass of the yo-yo and its angular acceleration about the center be $a$ and $\alpha$ respectively. We have (Fig. 1.146)

$$
\begin{aligned}
F \cos \theta-f &=M a, \\
f A-F B &=\frac{1}{2} M A^{2} \alpha .
\end{aligned}
$$

For rolling without slipping, $a=-A \alpha$. Eliminating $\alpha$ and $a$ gives

$$
f=\frac{2 F}{A}\left(B-\frac{1}{2} A \cos \theta\right) \text {. }
$$

As

$$
f \leq \mu N=\mu(M g-F=\sin \theta),
$$

for the yo-yo to roll without slipping irrespective of the smoothness of the table, i.e. independent of $\mu$, we require

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{M g}{F}, \quad \cos \theta=\frac{2 B}{A},
$$

or

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{A}{2 B} \frac{M g}{F} .
$$

Thus we require that, first of all, $2 B<A, M g<F$. Then two values of $\theta$, one positive and one negative, with the same $|\sin \theta|$ are possible.

\section{0}

A bowling ball of uniform density is thrown along a horizontal alley with initial velocity $v_{0}$ in such a way that it initially slides without rolling. The ball has mass $m$, coefficient of static friction $\mu_{s}$ and coefficient of sliding friction $\mu_{d}$ with the floor. Ignore the effect of air friction. Compute the velocity of the ball when it begins to roll without sliding. (Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

When the bowling ball slides without rolling the friction $f=\mu_{d} m g$ gives rise to an acceleration

$$
a=-\frac{f}{m}=-\mu_{d} g .
$$

The moment of $f$ gives rise to an angular acceleration $\alpha$ given by

$$
f R=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2} \alpha
$$

as the ball has a moment of inertia $\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}$ about an axis through its center, $R$ being its radius. Suppose at time $t$ the ball begins to roll without sliding. We require

$$
R \alpha t=v_{0}+a t,
$$

giving

$$
t=\frac{v_{0}}{R \alpha-a}=\frac{2 m v_{0}}{7 f}=\frac{2 v_{0}}{7 \mu_{d} g} .
$$

The velocity of the ball when this happens is

$$
v=v_{0}+a t=v_{0}-\mu_{d} g t=\frac{5}{7} v_{0} .
$$

\section{1}

A coin spinning about its axis of symmetry with angular frequency $\omega$ is set down on a horizontal surface (Fig. 1.148). After it stops slipping, with what velocity does it roll away?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Take coordinates as shown in Fig. 1.149. Before the coin stops slipping, the frictional force is $f=\mu m g$, where $\mu$ is the coefficient of sliding friction. Let $x_{c}$ be the $x$ coordinate of the center of mass of the coin. The equations of motion of the coin before it stops slipping are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x}_{c} &=-\mu m g, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=-\mu m g R,
\end{aligned}
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-309.jpg?height=155&width=195&top_left_y=300&top_left_x=324)

Fig. 1.148.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-309.jpg?height=267&width=357&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=890)

Fig. 1.149.

where $m$ and $R$ are respectively the mass and radius of the coin, and $I=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}$. Integrating and using initial conditions $\dot{x}_{c}=0, \dot{\theta}=\omega$ at $t=0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{x}_{c} &=-\mu g t, \\
\dot{\theta} &=\omega-\frac{2 \mu g t}{R} .
\end{aligned}
$$

When the coin rolls without slipping, we have

$$
\dot{x}_{c}=-\dot{\theta} R \text {. }
$$

Suppose this happens at time $t$, then the above give

$$
-\mu g t=-\omega R+2 \mu g t
$$

or

$$
t=\frac{\omega R}{3 \mu g} \text {. }
$$

At this time, the velocity of the center of mass of the coin is

$$
\dot{x}_{c}=-\mu g t=-\frac{1}{3} \omega R,
$$

which is the velocity with which the coin rolls away without slipping.

\section{2}

A wheel of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is projected along a horizontal surface with an initial linear velocity $V_{0}$ and an initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ as shown in Fig. 1.150, so it starts sliding along the surface $\left(\omega_{0}\right.$ tends to produce rolling in the direction opposite to $V_{0}$ ). Let the coefficient of friction between the wheel and the surface be $\mu$.

(a) How long is it till the sliding ceases?

(b) What is the velocity of the center of mass of the wheel at the time when the slipping stops?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-310.jpg?height=196&width=404&top_left_y=573&top_left_x=672)

Fig. 1.150.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take the positive $x$ direction as towards the right and the angular velocity $\dot{\theta}$ as positive when the wheel rotates clockwise. Assume the wheel has moment of inertia $\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$ about the axle. We then have two equations of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x} &=-\mu M g, \\
\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} \ddot{\theta} &=\mu M g R .
\end{aligned}
$$

Making use of the initial conditions $\dot{x}_{c}=V_{0}, \dot{\theta}_{c}=-\omega_{0}$ at $t=0$ we obtain by integration

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{x}=V_{0}-\mu g t, \\
&\dot{\theta}=-\omega_{0}+\frac{2 \mu g t}{R} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $T$ be the time when sliding ceases. Then at $T$

$$
\dot{x}=R \dot{\theta},
$$

or

$$
V_{0}-\mu g T=-R \omega_{0}+2 \mu g T,
$$

giving

$$
T=\frac{V_{0}+R \omega_{0}}{3 \mu g} .
$$

(b) The velocity of the center of mass of the wheel at the time when slipping stops is

$$
\dot{x}=V_{0}-\mu g T=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 V_{0}-R \omega_{0}\right) .
$$

\section{3}

A thin hollow cylinder of radius $R$ and mass $M$ slides across a frictionless floor with speed $V_{0}$. Initially the cylinder is spinning backward with angular velocity $\omega_{0}=2 V_{0} / R$ as shown in Fig. 1.151. The cylinder passes onto a rough area and continues moving in a straight line. Due to friction, it eventually rolls. What is the final velocity $\mathbf{V}_{f}$ ?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-311.jpg?height=179&width=332&top_left_y=1067&top_left_x=313)

Fig. 1.151.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-311.jpg?height=182&width=269&top_left_y=1088&top_left_x=923)

Fig. 1.152.

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the cylinder enters the rough area at time $t=0$ and starts to roll without slipping at time $t=t_{0}$. At $0<t<t_{0}$ the equations of motion of the cylinder are (Fig. 1.152)

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-f=M \frac{d V}{d t}, \\
&f R=I \frac{d \omega}{d t}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=M R^{2}$. Integrating we obtain 

$$
M\left(V_{f}-V_{0}\right)=-\int_{0}^{t_{0}} f d t,
$$

or

$$
I\left[\omega_{f}-\left(-\omega_{0}\right)\right]=R \int_{0}^{t_{0}} f d t
$$

giving

$$
I\left(\omega_{f}+\omega_{0}\right)=M R\left(V_{0}-V_{f}\right) .
$$

The cylinder rolls without slipping at $t=t_{0}$, when $V_{f}=\omega_{f} R$. We are also given $\omega_{0} R=2 V_{0}$. The last equation then gives

$$
V_{f}=-\frac{1}{2} V_{0} .
$$

Hence the cylinder will eventually move backward with a speed $\frac{1}{2} V_{0}$.

\section{4}

Calculate the minimum coefficient of friction necessary to keep a thin circular ring from sliding as it rolls down a plane inclined at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the horizontal plane.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-312.jpg?height=270&width=399&top_left_y=1255&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 1.153.

\section{Solution:}

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $1.153$ and write down the equations of motion for the ring:

$$
m \ddot{x}=m g \sin \theta-f, \quad I \ddot{\varphi}=f R,
$$

where $m$ and $R$ are the mass and radius of the ring respectively, $I=m R^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the ring about its axis of symmetry and $f$ is the static friction on the ring. The above equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{x}+R \ddot{\varphi}=g \sin \theta .
$$

The condition for no sliding is $R \dot{\varphi}=\dot{x}$, or $R \ddot{\varphi}=\ddot{x}$, giving

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{1}{2} g \sin \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
f=m g \sin \theta-m \ddot{x}=\frac{1}{2} m g \sin \theta .
$$

The normal reaction of the inclined plane is $N=m g \cos \theta$, and for no slipping we require $f<\mu N$, or

$$
\frac{1}{2} m g \sin \theta<\mu m g \cos \theta \text {, }
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{1}{2} \tan \theta<\mu .
$$

Hence the minimum coefficient of friction necessary to keep the ring from slipping is $\mu=\frac{1}{2} \tan \theta$.

\section{5}

A solid uniform cylinder of mass $m$, radius $R$ is placed on a plane inclined at angle $\theta$ relative to the horizonte] as shown in Fig. 1.154. Let $g$ denote the usual acceleration due to gravity, and let $a$ be the acceleration along the incline of the axis of the cylinder. The coefficient of friction between cylinder and plane is $\mu$.

For $\theta$ less than some critical angle $\theta_{c}$, the cylinder will roll down the incline without slipping.

(a) What is the angle $\theta_{c}$ ?

(b) For $\theta<\theta_{c}$, what is the acceleration $a$ ?

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

Let $f$ denote the frictional force and $\alpha$ the angular acceleration about the axis of the cylinder. The equations of motion are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-314.jpg?height=207&width=238&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 1.154.

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta-f &=m a, \\
f R &=I \alpha,
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} .
$$

(a) If there is no slipping, we require $a=R \alpha, f<\mu N$, where $N$, the normal reaction of the inclined plane, equals $m g \cos \theta$. The equations of motion give

$$
f=\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta .
$$

Hence we require

$$
\mu m g \cos \theta>\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
3 \mu>\tan \theta .
$$

Let $\tan \theta_{c}=3 \mu$. Then we require $\tan \theta<\tan \theta_{c}$ for no slipping. Therefore the critical angle is $\theta_{c}=\arctan 3 \mu$.

(b) For $\theta<\theta_{c}$, the cylinder rolls without slipping and the above gives

$$
a=g \sin \theta-\frac{f}{m}=\frac{2}{3} g \sin \theta .
$$

\section{6}

A wheel of radius $r$, mass $m$, and moment of inertia $I=m R^{2}$ is pulled along a horizontal surface by application of a horizontal force $\mathbf{F}$ to a rope unwinding from an axle of radius $b$ as shown in Fig. 1.155. You may assume there is a frictional force between the wheel and the surface such that the wheel rolls without slipping. In the expression $I=m R^{2}$ the quantity $R$ is a constant with dimensions of length.

(a) What is the linear acceleration of the wheel?

(b) Calculate the frictional force that acts on the wheel.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $x$ be the displacement of the center of mass of the wheel along the horizontal direction and $\theta$ the angular displacement of the wheel from an initial direction through its center of mass.

(a) The equations of motion of the wheel are (Fig. 1.155)

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=F-f, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=F b+f r .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-315.jpg?height=242&width=422&top_left_y=931&top_left_x=590)

Fig. 1.155.

The constraint for no sliding is $\dot{x}=r \dot{\theta}$ or $\ddot{x}=r \ddot{\theta}$. Hence

$$
\frac{m R^{2}}{r} \ddot{x}=F b+(F-m \ddot{x}) r,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{F(b+r) r}{m\left(R^{2}+r^{2}\right)},
$$

which is the linear acceleration of the wheel.

(b) The frictional force is

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=F-m \ddot{x} \\
&=F\left[1-\frac{(b+r) r}{R^{2}+r^{2}}\right]=\frac{F\left(R^{2}-b r\right)}{R^{2}+r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{7}

A flat disc of mass $m=1.8 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $r=0.2 \mathrm{~m}$ lies on a frictionless horizontal table. A string wound around the cylindrical surface of the disc exerts a force of 3 Newtons in the northerly direction (Fig. 1.156). Find the acceleration (magnitude and direction) of the center of mass $a$ and the angular acceleration $\alpha$ about the center of mass. Is $a=r \alpha$ ? Explain.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-316.jpg?height=203&width=221&top_left_y=615&top_left_x=674)

Fig. 1.156.

\section{Solution:}

The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=m a \\
f r &=I \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I=m r^{2} / 2$, giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a=\frac{f}{m}=1.7 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
&\alpha=\frac{2 f}{m r}=17 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The direction of $a$ is the same as that of $f$. It is seen that $a \neq \alpha r$. This is because as the disc lies on its flat surface the two motions are not related even though they are due to the same force.

\section{8}

A wheel of radius $R$ and moment of inertia $I$ is mounted on a frictionless axle at $O$. A flexible, weightless cord is wrapped around the rim of the 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-317.jpg?height=413&width=225&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 1.157.

wheel and carries a body of mass $M$ which begins descending as shown in Fig. 1.157. What is the tension in the cord?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $F$ be the tension in the cord, $x$ the position of the center of mass of the body and $\dot{\theta}$ the angular velocity of the body as shown in Fig. 1.157. We have the following equations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
I \ddot{\theta} &=F R, \\
M \ddot{x} &=M g-F, \\
\ddot{x} &=R \ddot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield

$$
F=\frac{M g I}{I+M R^{2}} .
$$

\section{9}

Two uniform discs in a vertical plane of masses $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$ with radii $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$ respectively have a thread wound about their circumferences, and are thus connected as shown in Fig. 1.158.

The first disc has fixed frictionless horizontal axis of rotation through its center. Set up the equations to determine the acceleration of the center of mass of the second disc if it falls freely. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-318.jpg?height=370&width=383&top_left_y=254&top_left_x=628)

Fig. 1.158.

(You need not solve the equations.)

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $F$ be the tension in the thread, $x_{1}$ the distance of the center of mass of disc 2 from that of disc 1 , and $\dot{\theta}_{1}, \dot{\theta}_{2}$ the angular velocities of the discs, as shown in Fig. 1.158. We have the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{2} \ddot{x} &=M_{2} g-F, \\
I_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1} &=F R_{1}, \\
I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2} &=F R_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I_{1}=m_{1} R_{1}^{2} / 2, I_{2}=m_{2} R_{2}^{2} / 2$. $W_{2}$ also have the constraint

$$
\dot{x}=R_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1}+R_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}=R_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1}+R_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2} .
$$

From the four equations the unknowns $\ddot{\theta}_{1}, \ddot{\theta}_{2}, \ddot{x}$ and $F$ can be determined.

\section{0}

A yo-yo of mass $M$ is composed of 2 large disks of radius $R$ and thickness $t$ separated by a distance $t$ with a shaft of radius $r$. Assume a uniform density throughout. Find the tension in the massless string as the yo-yo descends under the influence of gravity. 

\section{Solution:}

Let the density of the yo-yo be $\rho$, then its moment of inertia and mass are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \pi t \rho R^{4}+\frac{1}{2} \pi t \rho r^{4}, \\
M &=2 \pi t \rho R^{2}+\pi t \rho r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
I=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\frac{2 R^{4}+r^{4}}{2 R^{2}+r^{2}}\right) .
$$

The equations of motion of the yo-yo are

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x} &=M g-F, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=F r,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $F$ is the tension in the string. We also have the constraint $\ddot{x}=r \ddot{\theta}$. From the above we obtain

$$
F=\frac{I M g}{I+M r^{2}}=\frac{\left(2 R^{4}+r^{4}\right) M g}{2 R^{4}+4 R^{2} r^{2}+3 r^{4}} .
$$

\section{1}

A sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R\left(I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}\right)$ rests on the platform of a truck. The truck starts from rest and has a constant acceleration $A$. Assuming that the sphere rolls without slipping, find the acceleration of the center of mass of the ball relative to the truck.

(Wisconsin)
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-319.jpg?height=240&width=532&top_left_y=1602&top_left_x=509)

Fig. 1.159. 

\section{Solution:}

Let $O x y$ and $O^{\prime} x^{\prime} y^{\prime}$ be coordinate frames attached to the truck and fixed in space respectively with the $x$ - and $x^{\prime}$-axes along the horizontal as shown in Fig. 1.159. Denoting $\overline{O^{\prime} O}=\xi$, we have for the center of mass of the sphere

$$
x^{\prime}=x+\xi, \quad \text { or } \quad \ddot{x^{\prime}}=\ddot{x}+\ddot{\xi} \text {. }
$$

As the force acting on the sphere is the friction $f$, Newton's second law gives, writing $A$ for $\ddot{\xi}$,

$$
f=M \ddot{x^{\prime}}=M \ddot{x}+M A,
$$

or

$$
M \ddot{x}=f-M A .
$$

Thus in the moving frame there is a fictitious force $F=-M A$ acting on the sphere through the center of mass, in addition to the friction $f$. Considering the torque about the center of mass, we have

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=f R
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$. We also have the constraint for no slipping, $\dot{x}=-R \dot{\theta}$, or $\ddot{x}=-R \ddot{\theta}$. These three equations give $\ddot{x}=-\frac{5}{7} A$, which is the acceleration of the center of mass of the sphere relative to the truck.

\section{2}

Referring to Fig. 1.160, find the minimum height $h$ (above the top position in the loop) that will permit a spherical ball of radius $r$ (which rolls without slipping) to maintain constant contact with the rail of the loop. (The moment of inertia of a sphere about the center is $\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}$.)

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Conservation of mechanical energy requires that the kinetic energy of the sphere at the top position in the loop is equal to the decrease $m g h$ in potential energy as it falls from the initial position to this position. The kinetic energy of the sphere is composed of two parts: the translational kinetic energy of the sphere and the rotational kinetic energy of the sphere 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-321.jpg?height=260&width=403&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=505)

Fig. $1.160$.

about its center of mass. Let $m, T, v, \omega$ be respectively the mass, kinetic energy, velocity of the center of mass, and angular velocity about the center of mass of the sphere. Then

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}$. As the sphere rolls without slipping, $v=\omega r$ and

$$
T=\frac{1}{2}\left(m v^{2}+\frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \frac{v^{2}}{r^{2}}\right)=\frac{7}{10} m v^{2} .
$$

In the critical case, the force exerted by the loop on the sphere is zero when the latter reaches the top of the loop. In other words, the centripetal force needed for the circular motion of the sphere is supplied entirely by gravity:

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m g,
$$

whence $v^{2}=R g$ and

$$
T=\frac{7}{10} m R g=m g h .
$$

Hence $h=7 R / 10$ is the minimum initial height required.

\section{3}

A sphere of radius $b$ is at rest at $\theta=0$ upon a fixed sphere of radius $a>b$. The upper sphere is moved slightly to roll under the influence of gravity as shown in Fig. 1.161. The coefficient of static friction is $\mu_{s}>0$, the coefficient of sliding friction is $\mu=0$. (a) Briefly describe and explain the sequence of sphere motions in terms of rolling, sliding and separation.

(b) Write the equation of constraint for pure rolling of the upper sphere on the lower sphere.

(c) Write the equation of motion in terms of $\ddot{\theta}$ and $\theta$ for the part of the motion where the sphere rolls without slipping.

(d) Find a related equation between $\dot{\theta}$ and $\theta$.

(e) Solve this equation for $\theta(t)$, assuming $0<\theta(0) \ll \theta(t)$. You may wish to use the relation

$$
\int \frac{d x}{\sin \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)}=2 \ln \tan \left(\frac{x}{4}\right) .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-322.jpg?height=261&width=330&top_left_y=903&top_left_x=630)

Fig. 1.161.

\section{Solution:}

(a) At first the upper sphere rolls without slipping, the angular velocity becoming larger and the normal pressure on it smaller with increasing $\theta$. When the condition for pure rolling is not satisfied, the sphere begins to slide and finally when the centripetal force is not large enough to maintain the circular motion of the upper sphere, it will separate from the lower sphere.

(b) Suppose initially $O, A, O^{\prime}, B$ are on the same vertical line. As the upper sphere rolls by an angle $\varphi$, its center has traveled through a path $\overline{O O^{\prime}} \theta$, as shown in Fig. 1.161. Hence the condition for pure rolling is

$$
(a+b) \theta=b \varphi .
$$

(c) The equations of motion of the upper sphere are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} &=m g \sin \theta-f, \\
I \ddot{\varphi} &=\frac{2}{5} m b^{2} \ddot{\varphi}=f b,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f$ is the static friction on the sphere. When the sphere rolls without slipping, we have from (b)

$$
(a+b) \ddot{\theta}=b \ddot{\varphi} \text {. }
$$

Then the equations of motion give

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{5 g \sin \theta}{7(a+b)} .
$$

(d) As

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta},
$$

the last equation gives

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=-\frac{10 g \cos \theta}{7(a+b)}+K .
$$

With $\dot{\theta}=0$ at $\theta=0, K=\frac{10 g}{7(a+b)}$. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{10 g(1-\cos \theta)}{7(a+b)}
$$

(e) As

$$
\frac{d \theta}{d t}=\sqrt{\frac{10 g(1-\cos \theta)}{7(a+b)}}=\sqrt{\frac{20 g}{7(a+b)}} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}
$$

we have, with $\theta_{0}=\theta(0)$ at $t=0$

$$
\int_{\theta_{0}}^{\theta} \frac{d \theta}{\sin \frac{\theta}{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{20 g}{7(a+b)}} \int_{0}^{t} d t
$$

or

$$
\ln \left(\frac{\tan \frac{\theta}{4}}{\tan \frac{\theta_{0}}{4}}\right)=\alpha t,
$$

where $\alpha=\sqrt{\frac{5 g}{7(a+b)}}$. Hence

$$
\theta=4 \arctan \left(e^{\alpha t} \tan \frac{\theta_{0}}{4}\right),
$$

valid for the part of the motion where the sphere rolls without slipping.

$$
1194
$$

A sphere of mass $m$, radius $a$, and moment of inertia $\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}$ rolls without slipping from its initial position at rest atop a fixed cylinder of radius $b$ (see Fig. 1.162).

(a) Determine the angle $\theta_{\max }$ at which the sphere leaves the cylinder.

(b) What are the components of the velocity of the sphere's center at the instant it leaves the cylinder?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-324.jpg?height=299&width=382&top_left_y=1032&top_left_x=627)

Fig. $1.162$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The forces on the sphere are as shown in Fig. 1.162. The equations of motion for the center of mass of the sphere are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} &=m g \sin \theta-f, \\
m(a+b) \dot{\theta}^{2} &=m g \cos \theta-N,
\end{aligned}
$$

and that for the rotation of the sphere is

$$
\frac{2}{5} m a^{2} \ddot{\varphi}=f a .
$$

The condition for it to roll without slipping is

$$
(a+b) \dot{\theta}=a \dot{\varphi}, \quad \text { or } \quad(a+b) \ddot{\theta}=a \ddot{\varphi} .
$$

From (3) and (4), we found

$$
f=\frac{2}{5} m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} .
$$

Substitution in (1) gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{5 g \sin \theta}{7(a+b)} .
$$

As $\theta=\dot{\theta}=0$ at $t=0$ and $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$, it gives

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{10 g(1-\cos \theta)}{7(a+b)} .
$$

Substitution in (2) gives

$$
N=m g \cos \theta-\frac{10}{7} m g(1-\cos \theta)=m g\left(\frac{17 \cos \theta}{7}-\frac{10}{7}\right) \text {. }
$$

After the sphere leaves the cylinder, $N=0$. We assume that the coefficient of friction is large enough for the period of both rolling and slipping which occurs before the sphere leaves the cylinder to be negligible. Then at the instant $N$ becomes zero, $\theta=\theta_{\max }$ given by

$$
\cos \theta_{\max }=\frac{10}{17} \text {. }
$$

(b) At that instant the velocity of the center of the sphere has magnitude

$$
v=(a+b) \dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{17} g(a+b)},
$$

and is parallel to the tangential direction of the cylinder at the point where $\theta=\theta_{\max }$.

\section{5}

In Fig. 1.163, the ball on the left rolls horizontally without slipping at speed $V$ toward an identical ball initially at rest. Each ball is a uniform sphere of mass $M$. Assuming that all the frictional forces are small enough to have a negligible effect during the instant of collision, and that the instantaneous collision is perfectly elastic, calculate:

(a) The velocity of each ball a long enough time after the collision when each ball is again rolling without slipping.

(b) The fraction of the initial energy transformed by the frictional forces to thermal energy.

The moment of inertia of a sphere of mass $M$, radius $R$ about its center is $\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-326.jpg?height=159&width=330&top_left_y=672&top_left_x=626)

Fig. 1,163.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Before the collision

$$
V_{1}=V, \quad V_{2}=0, \quad \omega_{1}=\frac{V}{R}, \quad \omega_{2}=0 .
$$
