During the collision, as friction can be neglected, the forces with which the balls interact are directed through the centers so that the angular momentum about the center of each ball is conserved. Thus

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime}=\omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{2}^{\prime}=0 .
$$

As the collision is elastic, conservation of translational momentum and that of kinetic energy then require

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=0, \quad V_{2}^{\prime}=V_{1}=V .
$$

In the above, single primes denote quantities immediately after the collision. After some time, the balls again roll without slipping. Let the quantities at this time be denoted by double primes. The positive directions of these quantities are shown in Fig. 1.164.

The angular momentum of each ball about some fixed point in the plane of motion is conserved. Consider the angular momentum of each ball about the point of contact with the horizontal plane. For ball 1 ,

$$
M R V_{1}^{\prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime}=M R V_{1}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime \prime} \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\frac{I V}{R}=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{1}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{\frac{M R^{2}}{I}+1}=\frac{2}{7} V .
$$

For ball 2 ,

$$
M R V_{2}^{\prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime}=M R V_{2}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime \prime}
$$

or

$$
M R V=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{2}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{2}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}}=\frac{5}{7} V .
$$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-327.jpg?height=594&width=288&top_left_y=1248&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.164. (b) The initial and final energies of the system are

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{i} &=\frac{1}{2} M V_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(M V^{2}+\frac{2}{5} M R^{2} \cdot \frac{V^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5}, \\
W_{f} &=\frac{1}{2} M\left(V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} I\left(\omega_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+\omega_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M\left[V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}+\frac{2}{5}\left(V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5} \cdot \frac{29}{49} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the loss of energy is

$$
W_{i}-W_{f}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{20}{49},
$$

and the fractional loss is $\frac{20}{49}$.

\section{6}

A small homogeneous sphere of mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls without sliding on the outer surface of a larger stationary sphere of radius $R$ as shown in Fig. 1.165. Let $\theta$ be the polar angle of the small sphere with respect to a coordinate system with origin at the center of the large sphere and $z$-axis vertical. The smaller sphere starts from rest at the top of the larger sphere $(\theta=0)$

(a) Calculate the velocity of the center of the small sphere as a function of $\theta$

(b) Calculate the angle at which the small sphere flies off the large one.

(c) If one now allows for sliding with a coefficient of friction $\mu$, at what point will the small sphere start to slide?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of the small sphere is a constant of the motion when it rolls without sliding, we have 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-329.jpg?height=314&width=271&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 1.165.

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \cdot \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g(R+r) \cos \theta=m g(R+r)
$$

with $v=r \dot{\varphi}=(R+r) \dot{\theta}$, whence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} \frac{(1-\cos \theta) g}{(R+r)}} .
$$

The velocity of the center of the small sphere is

$$
v=(R+r) \dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7}(R+r)(1-\cos \theta) g} .
$$

(b) At the moment of flying off, the support force on the small sphere $N=0$. From the force equation

$$
m g \cos \theta-N=\frac{m v^{2}}{R+r},
$$

we find the angle $\theta_{c}$ at which the small sphere flies off the large sphere as given by

$$
\cos \theta_{c}=\frac{10}{17} .
$$

Thus

$$
\theta_{c}=\arccos \left(\frac{10}{17}\right) .
$$

Note that this derivation applies only for sufficiently large coefficient of friction. (c) When the small sphere rolls without sliding, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta-f &=m \dot{v}, \\
f r &=\frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \ddot{\varphi}, \\
v &=(R+r) \dot{\theta}=r \dot{\varphi},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f$ is the frictional force on the sphere. From these we find

$$
f=\frac{2}{7} m g \sin \theta .
$$

At the moment when the sphere starts to slide, the frictional force is

$$
f=\mu N,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{2}{7} m g \sin \theta=\mu\left(m g \cos \theta-\frac{m v^{2}}{R+r}\right) .
$$

Then, using the expression for $v$ from (a), we have

$$
2 \sin \theta=17 \mu \cos \theta-10 \mu \text {. }
$$

Solving this we find that the angle $\theta_{s}$ at which the small sphere starts to slide is given by

$$
\cos \theta_{s}=\frac{170 \mu^{2} \pm \sqrt{756 \mu^{2}+4}}{289 \mu^{2}+4} .
$$

However, we require that $\theta_{c}>\theta_{s}$, or $\cos \theta_{s}>\cos \theta_{c}$. Where this can be satisfied by the value of $\mu$, we generally have to take the upper sign. Hence

$$
\theta_{s}=\arccos \left(\frac{170 \mu^{2}+\sqrt{756 \mu^{2}+4}}{289 \mu^{2}+4}\right) \text {. }
$$

\section{7}

A spherical ball of radius $r$ is inside a vertical circular loop of radius $(R+r)$ as shown in Fig. 1.166. Consider two cases (i) rolling without sliding (ii) frictionless sliding without rolling. (a) In each case what minimum velocity $v_{1}$ must the sphere have at the bottom of the loop so as not to fall at the top?

(b) For a $10 \%$ smaller $v_{1}$ and the sliding case, where on the loop will falling begin?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-331.jpg?height=369&width=369&top_left_y=484&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 1.166.

\section{Solution:}

(a) For rolling without sliding, $R \theta=r \varphi$. Hence

$$
\omega=\dot{\varphi}=\frac{R \dot{\theta}}{r}=\frac{v}{r},
$$

where $v$ is velocity of the center of the ball. In order that the ball does not fall at the top of the loop, the force $N_{t}$ the loop exerts on the ball at the top must be such that

$$
N_{t}=\frac{m v^{2}}{R}-m g \geq 0 .
$$

Thus we require that

$$
v^{2} \geq R g .
$$

The minimum velocity $v_{t}$ that satisfies such condition is $v_{t}^{2}=R g$ and the corresponding kinetic energy is

$$
T_{t}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{t}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \cdot \omega^{2}=\frac{7}{10} m v_{t}^{2} .
$$

At the bottom of the loop, if the ball has the required minimum velocity $v_{1}$, we have

$$
T_{b}=T_{t}+V_{t},
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{7}{10} m v_{1}^{2}=\frac{7}{10} m v_{t}^{2}+2 m R g
$$

giving

$$
v_{1}^{2}=v_{t}^{2}+\frac{20}{7} R g=\frac{27}{7} R g,
$$

or

$$
v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{27}{7} R g} .
$$

(ii) For sliding without rolling, we still require that $v^{2} \geq R g$ at the top of the loop, i.e. the minimum velocity at the top is given by

$$
v_{t}^{2}=R g,
$$

and the corresponding kinetic energy is

$$
T_{t}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{t}^{2} .
$$

Thus we have

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{t}^{2}+2 m g R,
$$

giving

$$
v_{1}^{2}=5 R g,
$$

or

$$
v_{1}=\sqrt{5 R g} .
$$

(b) Suppose falling begins at $\theta$. At that moment the velocity $v$ of the center of the ball is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left(0.9 v_{1}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+m g(R-R \cos \theta),
$$

and

$$
N-m g \cos \theta=\frac{m v^{2}}{R}
$$

with

$$
N=0 .
$$

These equations give

$$
3 R g \cos \theta=2 R g-0.81 v_{1}^{2}=-2.05 R g
$$

i.e.

$$
\cos \theta=-0.683 \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\theta=133.1^{\circ} .
$$

\section{8}

A uniform plank of length $2 a$ is held temporarily so that one end leans against a frictionless vertical wall and the other end rests on a frictionless floor making an angle $\theta=\theta_{0}$ with the floor. When the plank is released, it will slide down under the influence of gravity.

(a) Find the expression (as an integral if you like) for the time that it will take for the plank to reach a new angle $\theta$.

(b) At what value of $\theta$ will the upper end of the plank leave the wall?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-333.jpg?height=285&width=403&top_left_y=1264&top_left_x=538)

Fig. 1.167.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As no friction is involved mechanical energy is conserved, which gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g a \sin \theta=m g a \sin \theta_{0},
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{2}{3} a \dot{\theta}^{2}=g\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)
$$

or

$$
\dot{\theta}=-\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 a}\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)} .
$$

Note that the factor $\frac{1}{3} m a^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the plank about a horizontal axis through its center of mass, and that the negative sign is to be used for $\dot{\theta}$ as $\theta$ decreases as $t$ increases.

Thus

$$
t=\int_{0}^{t} d t=-\int_{\theta_{0}}^{\theta} \frac{d \theta}{\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 a}\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)}} .
$$

(b) Take coordinates as shown in Fig. 1.167. The center of mass of the plank has horizontal coordinate

$$
x=a \cos \theta .
$$

Thus

$$
\ddot{x}=-a\left(\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta+\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta\right) .
$$

The forces on the plank are as shown in Fig. 1.167. At the instant the plank ceases to touch the wall, $N_{1}=m \ddot{x}=0$, i.e.

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta=-\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta .
$$

Differentiating (1) we have

$$
\ddot{\theta}=-\frac{3 g}{4 a} \cos \theta .
$$

Substituting this and (1) in the above we have

$$
\sin \theta=2\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right),
$$

or

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{2}{3} \sin \theta_{0},
$$

i.e.

$$
\theta=\arcsin \left(\frac{2}{3} \sin \theta_{0}\right),
$$

being the value of $\theta$ when the upper end of the plank leaves the wall. 

\section{9}

A thin uniform stick of mass $m$ with its bottom end resting on a frictionless table is released from rest at an angle $\theta_{0}$ to the vertical (Fig. 1.168). Find the force exerted by the table upon the stick at an infinitesimally small time after its release.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-335.jpg?height=292&width=283&top_left_y=562&top_left_x=579)

Fig. $1.168$.

\section{Solution:}

As there is no friction, the forces acting on the stick are the normal support $N$ and the gravity $m g$ as shown in Fig. 1.168. Within an infinitesimal time of the release of the stick, the equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
N-m g &=m \ddot{y}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N L \sin \theta_{0} &=\frac{1}{12} m L^{2} \ddot{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y$ is the vertical coordinate of the center of mass and $\frac{1}{12} m L^{2}$ is the moment of inertia about a horizontal axis through the center of mass of the stick. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y=\frac{1}{2} L \cos \theta, \\
&\ddot{y}=-\frac{1}{2} L\left(\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta+\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta\right)=-\frac{1}{2} L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

as initially

$$
\dot{\theta}=0, \quad \theta=\theta_{0} .
$$

Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=m g+m \ddot{y} \\
&=m g-\frac{1}{2} m L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0} \\
&=m g-3 N \sin ^{2} \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
N=\frac{m g}{1+3 \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}} .
$$

1200

Two long uniform rods $A$ and $B$ each $1 \mathrm{~m}$ long and of masses $1 \mathrm{~kg}(A)$ and $2 \mathrm{~kg}(B)$ lie parallel to each other on a frictionless horizontal plane $(x, y) . \operatorname{Rod} B$ is initially at rest at $y=0, x=0$ to $x=1 \mathrm{~m}$. Rod $A$ is moving at $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ in the positive $y$ direction, and it extends from $x=(-1+\epsilon) \mathrm{m}$ to $x=\epsilon \mathrm{m},(\epsilon \ll 1 \mathrm{~m})$ as shown in Fig. 1.169. $\operatorname{Rod} A$ reaches $y=0$ at $t=0$ and collides elastically with $B$. Find the subsequent motion of the rods, ignoring the possibility of subsequent collisions. Check for equality of energy before and after collision.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-336.jpg?height=234&width=337&top_left_y=1345&top_left_x=341)

Fig. 1.169.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-336.jpg?height=300&width=424&top_left_y=1283&top_left_x=902)

Fig. 1.170.

\section{Solution:}

Let I be the impulse $\operatorname{rod} A$ exerts on rod $B$ during the collision. Its direction is the direction of the motion of $A$, i.e. the positive $y$ direction. Let $v_{A}, \omega_{A}, v_{B}, \omega_{B}$, be the velocity of the center of mass and the angular velocity about the center of mass of $A$ and $B$ respectively, as shown in Fig. 1.170. Denoting the masses of $A, B$ by $m_{A}, m_{B}$ respectively, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-I &=m_{A}\left(v_{A}-10\right) \\
\frac{1}{2} I &=\frac{1}{12} m_{A} \omega_{A} \\
I &=m_{B} v_{B} \\
\frac{1}{2} I &=\frac{1}{12} m_{B} \omega_{B}
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition of elastic collision means that the relative velocity of the points of collision remains the same in magnitude but reverses in direction:

$$
\left(v_{B}+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{B}\right)-\left(v_{A}-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{A}\right)=10 .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\frac{5 m_{A} m_{B}}{m_{A}+m_{B}}=\frac{10}{3} \mathrm{Ns} \\
v_{A} &=10-\frac{I}{m_{A}}=\frac{20}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
\omega_{A} &=\frac{6 I}{m_{A}}=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\
v_{B} &=\frac{I}{m_{B}}=\frac{5}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
\omega_{B} &=\frac{6 I}{m_{B}}=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

for the subsequent motion. The energy of the two rods before collision is

$$
E_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1 \cdot 10^{2}=50 \mathrm{~J}
$$

and after collision is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{f} &=\frac{1}{2} m_{A} v_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{B} v_{B}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{12} m_{A} \omega_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{12} m_{B} \omega_{B}^{2} \\
&=\frac{225}{9}+\frac{300}{12}=50 \mathrm{~J}=E_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the equality of energy holds. 

$$
1201
$$

A billiard ball of radius $R$ and mass $M$ is struck with a horizontal cue stick at a height $h$ above the billiard table as shown in Fig. 1.171. Given that the moment of inertia of a sphere is $\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$, find the value of $h$ for which the ball will roll without slipping.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-338.jpg?height=176&width=371&top_left_y=567&top_left_x=594)

Fig. 1.171.

\section{Solution:}

Suppose that $f$ is the impact force on the ball exerted by the stick and that it acts for a time $\Delta t$ causing a change of momentum of the ball of $M \Delta v$ and a change of its angular momentum about the center of mass of $I \Delta \omega$. We have the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \Delta v &=f \Delta t, \\
I \Delta \omega &=f(h-R) \Delta t
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$, which yield

$$
\Delta v=\frac{2 R^{2} \Delta \omega}{5(h-R)} .
$$

As the ball is at rest initially, the velocity of its center of mass and the angular velocity after impact satisfy

$$
v=\frac{2 R^{2} \omega}{5(h-R)} .
$$

The ball will roll without slipping if $v=R \omega$. Hence we require

$$
5(h-R)=2 R,
$$

or

$$
h=\frac{7}{5} R .
$$



\section{2}

A uniform solid ball of radius $a$ rolling with velocity $v$ on a level surface collides inelastically with a step of height $h<a$, as shown in Fig. 1.172. Find, in terms of $h$ and $a$, the minimum velocity for which the ball will "trip" up over the step. Assume that no slipping occurs at the impact point, and remember that the moment of inertia of a solid sphere with respect to an axis through its center is $\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}$.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-339.jpg?height=205&width=369&top_left_y=653&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.172.

\section{Solution:}

Let $\omega$ and $\omega^{\prime}, J$ and $J^{\prime}$ be the angular velocity of the ball with respect to its center of mass and its angular momentum about the point of impact $A$ before and after collision with the step, respectively. We have

$$
J=m v(a-h)+\frac{2}{5} m a^{2} \omega=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h
$$

as $v=a \omega$ for rolling without slipping, and

$$
J^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}\right) \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}
$$

as the center of mass of the ball is momentarily at rest after the collision. Conservation of angular momentum requires

$$
\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right) \frac{v}{a} .
$$

In order that the ball can just trip up over the step, its kinetic energy must be sufficient to provide for the increase in potential energy:

$$
\frac{1}{2} I^{\prime} \omega^{\prime 2}=m g h,
$$

where $I^{\prime}=\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the ball about a horizontal axis through $A$. Hence the minimum velocity required is given by

$$
\frac{7}{10} m a^{2}\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{v}{a}\right)^{2}=m g h,
$$

yielding

$$
v=\frac{a \sqrt{70 g h}}{7 a-5 h} .
$$

\section{3}

A parked truck has its rear door wide open as shown in the plane view in Fig. 1.173(a). At time $t=0$ the truck starts to accelerate with constant acceleration $a$. The door will begin to close, and at a later time $t$ the door will be passing through the position shown in Fig. 1.173(b) such that the door makes an angle $\theta$ with its original orientation. You may assume that the door has mass $m$ uniformally distributed along its length $L$.

(a) Using $\theta$ and its time derivatives to describe the motion, write down dynamic equations relating the two components, $F_{\|}$and $F_{\perp}$, of the force exerted on the door at the hinge to the kinematic quantities. $F_{\|}$is the component of the force parallel to the door in the plane of the diagram and $F_{\perp}$ is the component perpendicular to the door.

(b) Express $\ddot{\theta}=d^{2} \theta / d t^{2}, F_{\|}$and $F_{\perp}$ in terms of $\theta, m, L$ and $a$.

(c) Write down, but do not attempt to integrate, an expression for the total time elapsed from the start of acceleration to the closing of the door. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-341.jpg?height=219&width=401&top_left_y=223&top_left_x=194)

(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-341.jpg?height=215&width=366&top_left_y=227&top_left_x=577)

(b)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-341.jpg?height=217&width=372&top_left_y=226&top_left_x=919)

(c)

Fig. 1.173.

\section{Solution:}

(a) In a frame attached to the accelerating truck, the center of mass of the door has components of acceleration $\frac{1}{2} L \ddot{\theta}$ perpendicular to the door and $-\frac{1}{2} L \dot{\theta}^{2}$ parallel to the door. The directions of $F_{\|}$and $F_{\perp}$ are as shown in Fig. 1.173(c). In this frame a fictitious force $-m a$ acting at the center of mass is included in the equations of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{\perp}-m a \cos \theta &=-\frac{1}{2} m L \ddot{\theta}, \\
F_{\|}-m a \sin \theta &=\frac{1}{2} m L \dot{\theta}^{2}, \\
\frac{1}{2} L F_{\perp} &=\frac{1}{12} m L^{2} \ddot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\frac{1}{12} m L^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the door about an axis perpendicular to the top edge of the door through the center of mass.

(b) The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\theta} &=\frac{3 a \cos \theta}{2 L}, \\
F_{\perp} &=\frac{1}{4} m a \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$, integrating the expression for $\ddot{\theta}$ and noting that $\theta=\dot{\theta}=0$ initially we have

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{3 a \sin \theta}{L},
$$

whence

$$
F_{\|}=m a \sin \theta+\frac{3}{2} m a \sin \theta=\frac{5}{2} m a \sin \theta .
$$

(c) As

$$
\frac{d \theta}{d t}=\sqrt{\frac{3 a \sin \theta}{L}},
$$

the total time elapsed from start of acceleration to the closing of the door is

$$
t=\int_{0}^{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{L}{3 a \sin \theta}} d \theta .
$$

1204

Consider a solid cylinder of mass $m$ and radius $r$ sliding without rolling down the smooth inclined face of a wedge of mass $M$ that is free to move on a horizontal plane without friction (Fig. 1.174).

(a) How far has the wedge moved by the time the cylinder has descended from rest a vertical distance $h$ ?

(b) Now suppose that the cylinder is free to roll down the wedge without slipping. How far does the wedge move in this case?

(c) In which case does the cylinder reach the bottom faster? How does this depend on the radius of the cylinder?

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-342.jpg?height=256&width=518&top_left_y=1270&top_left_x=493)

Fig. 1.174.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\xi$ be the distance of the center of mass of the cylinder from its initial position. In a fixed coordinate frame, let $x$ be the horizontal coordinate of the center of mass of the wedge. The horizontal component of the velocity of the cylinder in the fixed frame is $\dot{x}-\dot{\xi} \cos \theta$. As the total momentum of the system in the $x$ direction is conserved, we have, since the system is initially at rest,

$$
M \dot{x}+m(\dot{x}-\dot{\xi} \cos \theta)=0,
$$

giving

$$
(M+m) \dot{x}=m \dot{\xi} \cos \theta \text {. }
$$

Without loss of generality we set $\xi=x=0$ at $t=0$. Integration of the above then gives

$$
(M+m) x=m \xi \cos \theta .
$$

When the cylinder has descended a vertical distance $h$, it has moved a distance $\xi=\frac{h}{\sin \theta}$, and the wedge has moved a distance

$$
x=\frac{m \xi}{M+m} \cos \theta=\frac{m h}{M+m} \cot \theta .
$$

(b) If the cylinder is allowed to roll, conservation of the horizontal component of the total linear momentum of the system still holds. It follows that the result obtained in (a) is also valid here.

(c) Conservation of the total mechanical energy of the system holds for both cases. As the center of mass of the cylinder has velocity $(\dot{x}-$ $\dot{\xi} \cos \theta,-\dot{\xi} \sin \theta)$ and that of the wedge has velocity $(\dot{x}, 0)$, we have for the sliding cylinder,

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}-\dot{\xi} \cos \theta)^{2}+\dot{\xi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right]+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}=m g \xi \sin \theta,
$$

and for the rolling cylinder,

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}-\dot{\xi} \cos \theta)^{2}+\dot{\xi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right]+\frac{1}{2} I \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}=m g \xi \sin \theta
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}, \dot{\varphi}=\frac{\dot{\xi}}{r}$ for rolling without sliding. As

$$
\dot{x}=\left(\frac{m}{M+m}\right) \dot{\xi} \cos \theta,
$$

the above respectively reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{m}{2(M+m)}\left(M+m \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \dot{\xi}^{2}=m g \xi \sin \theta, \\
& \frac{m}{4(M+m)}\left[3 M+m\left(1+2 \sin ^{2} \theta\right)\right] \dot{\xi}^{2}=m g \xi \sin \theta . 
\end{aligned}
$$

These equations have the form $\dot{\xi}=b \sqrt{\xi}$. As $\xi=0$ at $t=0$, integration gives $t=\frac{2}{b} \sqrt{\xi}$. Hence for the same $\xi=\frac{h}{\sin \theta}, t \propto \frac{1}{b}$. As

$$
3 M+m\left(1+2 \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-2\left(M+m \sin ^{2} \theta\right)=M+m>0
$$

the sliding cylinder will take a shorter time to reach the bottom.

\section{5}

A stepladder consists of two legs held together by a hinge at the top and a horizontal rope near the bottom, and it rests on a horizontal surface at $60^{\circ}$ as shown in Fig. $1.175$. If the rope is suddenly cut, what is the acceleration of the hinge at that instant? Assume the legs to be uniform, identical to each other, and neglect all friction.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-344.jpg?height=184&width=273&top_left_y=1166&top_left_x=293)

Fig. 1.175.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-344.jpg?height=318&width=368&top_left_y=1041&top_left_x=923)

Fig. 1.176.

\section{Solution:}

Consider the instant when the horizontal rope is suddenly cut.

By symmetry the forces which the two legs exert on each other at the hinge $A$ are horizontal and the acceleration of $A, \mathbf{a}_{A}$, is vertically downward.

Consider one leg of the stepladder. The forces acting on it are as shown in Fig. 1.176. Let $l$ be the length of the leg and $\mathbf{a}_{C}$ the acceleration of its center of mass $C$ at the instant the rope is cut. We have 

$$
\begin{gathered}
m g-N=m a_{C y}, \\
F=m a_{C x}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N l \cos 60^{\circ}-\frac{1}{2} F l \sin 60^{\circ}=I \ddot{\theta}
\end{gathered}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} m l^{2}$, or

$$
N-\sqrt{3} F=\frac{1}{3} m l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

The velocity of $A$ in terms of the velocity of $C$ are given by

$$
\dot{x}_{A}=\dot{x}_{C}-\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin 60^{\circ}, \quad \dot{y}_{A}=\dot{y}_{C}+\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ} .
$$

Hence $\mathbf{a}_{\boldsymbol{A}}$, which is in the $y$ direction, has components

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 &=a_{C x}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \\
a_{A} &=a_{C y}+\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider now the acceleration $\mathbf{a}_{B}$ of point $B$. At the instant the rope is cut it has only a horizontal component. Thus $a_{B_{y}}=0$, i.e.

$$
a_{C y}-\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ}=a_{C y}-\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta}=0 .
$$

\section{The above consideration gives}

$$
a_{C x}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \quad a_{C y}=\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

Using these in the equations of motion for $C$ we find

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{3 g}{4 l},
$$

which gives the acceleration of the hinge as

$$
a_{A}=\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta}=\frac{3}{8} g,
$$

directed vertically downward. 

\section{6}

A particle of mass $m$ and speed $v$ collides elastically with the end of a uniform thin rod of mass $M$ as shown in Fig. 1.177. After the collision, $m$ is stationary. Calculate $M$.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-346.jpg?height=213&width=134&top_left_y=498&top_left_x=695)

Fig. 1.177.

\section{Solution:}

Let $v_{c}$ be the velocity of the center of mass of the rod and $\omega$ the angular velocity of the rod about the center of mass. Conservation of momentum and that of energy of this system give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m v &=M v_{c}, \\
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} M v_{c}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} M l^{2}, l$ being the length of the rod. Conservation of the angular momentum of the system about a fixed point located at the center of the rod before collision gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} l m v=I \omega .
$$

The above equations give

$$
M=4 m .
$$

\section{7}

A uniform thin cylindrical rod of length $L$ and mass $m$ is supported at its ends by two massless springs with spring constants $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$. In equilibrium the rod is horizontal, as shown in Fig. 1.178. You are asked to consider small-amplitude motion about equilibrium under circumstances where the springs can move only vertically.

(a) First consider the special case $k_{1}=k_{2}$. Find the eigenfrequencies of the normal modes and describe the corresponding normal mode motions. Here you might well be guided by intuitive reasoning.

(b) Now consider the general case where $k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ are not necessarily equal. Find the normal mode eigenfrequencies.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-347.jpg?height=333&width=503&top_left_y=649&top_left_x=539)

Fig. 1.178.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $y_{1}$ and $y_{2}$ be the vertical displacements from the equilibrium position of the two ends of the rod as shown in Fig. 1.178. As the displacement of the center of mass $C$ is $\frac{1}{2}\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)$, its equation of translational motion is

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left(\ddot{y}_{1}+\ddot{y}_{2}\right)=-k_{1} y_{1}-k_{2} y_{2} .
$$

For small-amplitude rotation about the center of mass, we have

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-\frac{1}{2} L\left(k_{1} y_{1}-k_{2} y_{2}\right)
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} m L^{2}, \theta \approx \frac{y_{1}-y_{2}}{L}$. For $k_{1}=k_{2}=k$, the equations of motion reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{y}_{1}+\ddot{y}_{2} &=-\frac{2 k}{m}\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right), \\
\ddot{y}_{1}-\ddot{y}_{2} &=-\frac{6 k}{m}\left(y_{1}-y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence there exist two normal modes.

(i) Symmetric mode

$$
y_{s}=y_{1}+y_{2}
$$

with eigenfrequency $\omega_{s}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}$. This mode corresponds to vertical harmonic oscillation of the rod as a whole.

(ii) Asymmetric mode

$$
y_{a}=y_{1}-y_{2}
$$

with eigenfrequency $\omega_{a}=\sqrt{\frac{6 k}{m}}$. This mode corresponds to harmonic oscillation about a horizontal axis perpendicular to the rod and through its center of mass.

(b) For the general case $k_{1} \neq k_{2}$, let $y_{1}=A_{1} e^{i \omega t}, y_{2}=A_{2} e^{i \omega t}$, where $\omega$ is the eigenfrequency of oscillation. The equations of motion now give

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(k_{1}-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\right) A_{1}+\left(k_{2}-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\right) A_{2}=0, \\
\left(\frac{I \omega^{2}}{L}-\frac{1}{2} L k_{1}\right) A_{1}+\left(\frac{1}{2} L k_{2}-\frac{I \omega^{2}}{L}\right) A_{2}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

For a non-zero solution we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ll}
k_{1}-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} & k_{2}-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} \\
\frac{I \omega^{2}}{L}-\frac{1}{2} L k_{1} & \frac{1}{2} L k_{2}-\frac{I \omega^{2}}{L}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{I m \omega^{4}}{L}-\left(\frac{I}{L}+\frac{1}{4} m L\right)\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right) \omega^{2}+L k_{1} k_{2}=0,
$$

or

$$
m^{2} \omega^{4}-4 m\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right) \omega^{2}+12 k_{1} k_{2}=0 .
$$

Solving for $\omega^{2}$ we obtain the eigenfrequencies

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2}{m}\left[\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(k_{1}^{2}-k_{1} k_{2}+k_{2}^{2}\right)}\right]} .
$$

Note that for $k_{1}=k_{2}=k$, this expression gives $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}, \sqrt{\frac{6 k}{m}}$, in agreement with (a). 

\section{8}

A rigid wheel has principal moments of inertial $I_{1}=I_{2} \neq I_{3}$ about its body-fixed principal axes $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{1}, \hat{\mathbf{x}}_{2}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{3}$, as shown in Fig. 1.179. The wheel is attached at its center of mass to a bearing which allows frictionless rotation about one space-fixed axis. The wheel is "dynamically balanced", i.e. it can rotate at constant $\omega \neq 0$ and exert no torque on its bearing. What conditions must the components of $\omega$ satisfy? Sketch the permitted $\operatorname{motion}(\mathrm{s})$.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-349.jpg?height=488&width=321&top_left_y=727&top_left_x=593)

Fig. $1.179$.

\section{Solution:}

Setting $I_{1}=I_{2}=I$ in Euler's equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{1}+\left(I_{3}-I_{2}\right) \omega_{3} \omega_{2}=0 \\
&I_{2} \dot{\omega}_{2}+\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) \omega_{1} \omega_{3}=0 \\
&I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{3}+\left(I_{2}-I_{1}\right) \omega_{2} \omega_{1}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

we see that (3) can be readily integrated to give

$$
\omega_{3}=\text { constant }=\Omega, \text { say } .
$$

We then rewrite (1) and (2) as 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{\omega}_{1}=-\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I}\right) \Omega \omega_{2}, \\
&\dot{\omega}_{2}=\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I}\right) \Omega \omega_{1},
\end{aligned}
$$

which are the conditions that must be satisfied. Differentiating these equations gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\omega}_{1} &=-\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I} \Omega\right) \dot{\omega}_{2}=-\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I} \Omega\right)^{2} \omega_{1}=-\alpha^{2} \omega_{1}, \\
\ddot{\omega}_{2} &=-\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I} \Omega\right)^{2} \omega_{2}=-\alpha^{2} \omega_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha=\left(\frac{I_{3}-I}{I}\right) \Omega$. The general solution is

$$
\omega_{1}=\omega_{0} \cos (\alpha t+\varepsilon), \quad \omega_{2}=\omega_{0} \sin (\alpha t+\varepsilon) .
$$

Hence the total angular velocity has magnitude

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\Omega^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2}}=\sqrt{\Omega^{2}+\omega_{0}^{2}},
$$

which is a constant. As $\omega_{3}=\Omega$ is a constant the total angular velocity vector $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ makes a constant angle $\theta$ with the $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{3}$-axis as shown in Fig. 1.179. Furthermore the plane of $\omega$ and $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{3}$ rotates about the $\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{3}$-axis with an angular velocity $\alpha$, or a period

$$
\frac{2 \pi}{\alpha}=\frac{2 \pi I}{\left(I_{3}-I\right) \Omega} .
$$

The motion, which is the only one allowed, is sketched in Fig. 1.179.

\section{9}

A rigid body is in space. All external influences (including gravity) are negligible.

(a) Use Newton's law to show that angular momentum is conserved; mention any assumptions made. (b) Suppose the center of mass of the body is at rest in an inertial frame. Must its axis of rotation have a fixed direction? Justify your answer briefly. $(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The angular momentum of a rigid body about a fixed point $O$ is defined as

$$
\mathbf{L}=\sum_{i}^{n} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times m_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}_{i}$ is the radius vector from $O$ of a particle $m_{i}$ of the rigid body, which consists of $n$ particles. As there are no external forces, only internal forces act, and according to Newton's second law

$$
m_{i} \ddot{\mathrm{r}}_{i}=\sum_{j \neq i}^{n} \mathbf{F}_{i j},
$$

where $\mathbf{F}_{i j}$ is the force acting on $m_{i}$ by particle $m_{j}$ of the rigid body. Consider

$$
\sum_{i}^{n} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times m_{i} \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=\sum_{i}^{n} \sum_{j \neq i}^{n} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{F}_{i j} .
$$

By Newton's third law, the internal forces $\mathbf{F}_{i j}$ occur in pairs such that

$$
\boldsymbol{F}_{i j}=-\mathbf{F}_{j i},
$$

both acting along the same line joining the two particles. This means that the double-summation on the right-hand side of $(1)$ consists of sums like

$$
\mathbf{r}_{i} \times \mathbf{F}_{i j}+\mathbf{r}_{j} \times \mathbf{F}_{j i} .
$$

As shown in Fig. 1.180, each such sum adds up to zero. Hence

$$
\sum_{r}^{n} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=0 .
$$

Then

$$
\dot{\mathbf{L}}=\sum_{i}^{n} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} \times m \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}+\sum_{i}^{n} \mathbf{r}_{i} \times m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=0
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{L}=\text { constant } .
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-352.jpg?height=262&width=324&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=623)

Fig. $1.180$.

That is, the angular momentum of a rigid body about an arbitrary point is conserved.

(b) The above argument holds also for a point fixed in an inertial frame, so that the angular momentum $L$ of the body about the center of mass is a constant vector in the inertial frame. However, the angular velocity $\omega$ of the body about the center of mass need not be in the same direction as $\mathbf{L}$. Only when the axis of rotation is along a principal axis of the body is $\omega$ parallel to $\mathbf{L}$. Hence, in general the axis of rotation is not fixed even though the direction of $\mathbf{L}$ is.

\section{0}

The trash can beside the Physics Department mailboxes has a conicalshaped lid which is supported by a pivot at the center. Suppose you tip the cone of the lid and spin it rapidly with spin velocity $\omega$ about the symmetry axis of the cone (Fig. 1.181). Does the lid precess in the same or opposite sense to the spin direction of $\omega$ ? Document your answer with appropriate formula and vector diagram.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The torque of gravity about $O$ is

$$
\mathbf{M}=\overline{\mathbf{O C}} \times m \mathrm{~g} .
$$

In a fixed frame we have

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=\mathbf{M}=-\frac{\overline{O C} \mathbf{L}}{L} \times m \mathbf{g}=\frac{\overline{O C}}{L} m \mathbf{g} \times \mathbf{L}=\omega_{p} \times \mathbf{L},
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=425&width=267&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=261)

Fig. $1.181$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=437&width=202&top_left_y=263&top_left_x=940)

Fig. $1.182$.

where $\omega_{p}=\frac{\overline{O C} m \text { g }}{L}$. Thus $\mathrm{L}$ and hence the axis of symmetry of the lip precess with angular velocity $\omega_{p}=\frac{\overline{O C} m g}{L}$ about the vertical axis in a sense opposite to that of the spin, as shown in Fig. $1.182$.

\section{1}

A rigid square massless frame contains 4 disks rotating as shown in Fig. 1.183. Each disk has mass $m$, moment of inertia $I_{0}$, and rotational velocity $\omega_{0}$. The frame is horizontal and pivots freely about a support at one corner. What is the precession rate?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=295&width=486&top_left_y=1534&top_left_x=162)

Fig. 1.183.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=297&width=398&top_left_y=1541&top_left_x=807)

Fig. 1.184. 

\section{Solution:}

The angular momentum of each disk about its axis of rotation is $I_{0} \omega_{0}$ with directions as shown in Fig. 1.184. The total angular momentum of the system about the pivot has magnitude $L=2 \sqrt{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}$ and a direction along $\overline{\mathbf{O C}}, C$ being the center of mass of the system. Note that $\mathbf{L}$ is horizontal as the frame is horizontal. The torque due to gravity is

$$
\mathbf{M}=\overline{\mathbf{O C}} \times 4 m g=\frac{D}{\sqrt{2}} \frac{\mathbf{L}}{L} \times 4 m \mathbf{g} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=\mathbf{M}=-\frac{2 \sqrt{2} D m}{L} \mathbf{g} \times \mathbf{L}=\Omega \times \mathbf{L},
$$

where

$$
\boldsymbol{\Omega}=-\frac{2 \sqrt{2} D m \mathbf{g}}{2 \sqrt{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}}=-\frac{D m}{I_{0} \omega_{0}} \mathbf{g}
$$

is the precessional angular velocity. Hence the precession has a rate $\frac{D m g}{I_{0} \omega_{0}}$ and is anticlockwise when seen from above.

\section{2}

We consider an ideal free gyro, i.e. a rotationally symmetric rigid body (with principal moments of inertia $I_{1}=I_{2}<I_{3}$ ) so suspended that it can rotate freely about its center of gravity, and move under the influence of no torque. Let $\omega(t)$ be the instantaneous angular velocity vector, and let $\mathbf{L}(t)$ be the instantaneous angular momentum. Let the unit vector $\mathbf{u}(t)$ point along the symmetry axis of the body (associated with the moment of inertia $I_{3}$ ). These vectors are in an inertial frame with respect to which the body rotates. Derive expressions for $\mathbf{L}(t), \boldsymbol{\omega}(t)$, and $\mathbf{u}(t)$ in terms of initial values $\mathbf{u}_{0}=\mathbf{u}(0)$ and $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{0}=\boldsymbol{\omega}(0)$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Let $t=0$ be an instant when $\mathbf{L}, \boldsymbol{\omega}$ and the axis of symmetry of the gyro, u, are coplanar. Use a fixed coordinate frame $O x y z$ with origin at the center of mass of the gyro which at $t=0$ has the $z$-axis along the angular momentum vector $L$ and the $y$-axis perpendicular to the angular velocity $\omega_{0}$. Also use a rotating coordinate frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ attached to the gyro such that the $z^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the axis of symmetry and the $x^{\prime}$-axis is in the plane of $z^{\prime}$-and $z$-axes at $t=0$. The relation between the two frames is shown in Fig. 1.185, which also defines the Eulerian angles $\theta, \varphi, \psi$. Note that initially the $y^{\prime}$ - and $y$-axes coincide and $\psi_{0}=\varphi_{0}=0$.

As seen from Fig. 1.185, the angular velocity $\omega(t)$ of the gyro can be expressed in the rotating frame in terms of the Eulerian angles as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{x^{\prime}}=\dot{\theta} \sin \psi-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \psi, \\
&\omega_{y^{\prime}}=\dot{\theta} \cos \psi+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \sin \psi, \\
&\omega_{z^{\prime}}=\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta+\dot{\psi} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the $x^{\prime}-, y^{\prime}$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are principal axes, $\mathrm{L}$ can be expressed as

$$
\mathbf{L}=I_{1} \omega_{x^{\prime}} \mathbf{i}^{\prime}+I_{1} \omega_{y^{\prime}} \mathbf{j}^{\prime}+I_{3} \omega_{z^{\prime}} \mathbf{k}^{\prime}
$$

for $I_{1}=I_{2}$. As there is no torque acting on the gyro, $L=$ constant and is along the $z$-axis. Furthermore, the Euler equation

$$
I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{z^{\prime}}-\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right) \omega_{x^{\prime}} \omega_{y^{\prime}}=0
$$

gives for $I_{1}=I_{2}$,

$$
\omega_{z^{\prime}}=\text { constant }=\omega_{0 z^{\prime}} .
$$

As

$$
L=\sqrt{I_{1}^{2}\left(\omega_{x^{\prime}}^{2}+\omega_{y^{\prime}}^{2}\right)+I_{3}^{2} \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}^{2}}=\text { constant }
$$

we have

$$
\omega_{x^{\prime}}^{2}+\omega_{y^{\prime}}^{2}=\text { constant }=\omega_{0 x^{\prime}}^{2}+\omega_{0 y^{\prime}}^{2}=\omega_{0 x^{\prime}}^{2}
$$

since $\omega_{0 y^{\prime}}=\omega_{0 y}=0$. Hence

$$
\mathbf{L}=\sqrt{I_{1}^{2} \omega_{0 x^{\prime}}^{2}+I_{3}^{2} \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}^{2}} \mathbf{k} .
$$

It can also be expressed in terms of the Eulerian angles as (Fig. 1.185)

$$
\mathbf{L}=-L \sin \theta \cos \psi \mathbf{i}^{\prime}+L \sin \theta \sin \psi \mathbf{j}^{\prime}+L \cos \theta \mathbf{k}^{\prime}
$$

in the rotating frame. Comparing this with (1) we find

$$
L \cos \theta=I_{3} \omega_{0 z^{\prime}},
$$

showing that $\cos \theta=$ constant $=\cos \theta_{0}$, say, and thus $\dot{\theta}=0$. Furthermore,

$$
-L \sin \theta \cos \psi=I_{1} \omega_{x^{\prime}}=-I_{1} \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \psi,
$$

giving

$$
\dot{\varphi}=\frac{L}{I}=\text { constant }
$$

Similarly,

$$
L \cos \theta=I_{3} \omega_{z \prime}=I_{3}(\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta+\dot{\psi}),
$$

giving

$$
\dot{\psi}=\frac{L \cos \theta}{I_{3}}-\frac{L \cos \theta}{I_{1}}=\left(1-\frac{I_{3}}{I_{1}}\right) \frac{L \cos \theta}{I_{3}}=\left(1-\frac{I_{3}}{I_{1}}\right) \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}=\text { constant } .
$$

What the above means is that the motion of the free, symmetric gyro consists of two steady motions: a spin of angular velocity $\dot{\psi}$ about the axis of symmetry and a precession of angular velocity $\dot{\varphi}$ about the constant angular momentum vector $\mathbf{L}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-356.jpg?height=406&width=408&top_left_y=814&top_left_x=243)

Fig. 1.185.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-356.jpg?height=396&width=317&top_left_y=842&top_left_x=873)

Fig. $1.186$.

Consider now the unit vector $\mathbf{u}(t)$, which is along the axis of symmetry, in the fixed frame (Fig. 1.185):

$$
\mathbf{u}(t)=\sin \theta \cos \varphi \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta \sin \varphi \mathbf{j}+\cos \theta \mathbf{k} .
$$

As $\theta=\theta_{0}$ and at $t=0, \varphi=0$, we have

$$
\mathbf{u}(0)=\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{i}+\cos \theta_{0} \mathbf{k},
$$

and, as $\varphi=\dot{\varphi} t$,

$$
\mathbf{u}(t)=u_{0 x} \cos (\dot{\varphi} t) \mathbf{i}+u_{0 x} \sin (\dot{\varphi} t) \mathbf{j}+u_{0 z} \mathbf{k} .
$$
time $t$

Consider the angular velocity $\boldsymbol{\omega}$. In the rotating frame, we have for 

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=\left(-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta_{0} \cos \psi, \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta_{0} \sin \psi, \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta_{0}+\dot{\psi}\right),
$$

as $\theta=\theta_{0}, \dot{\theta}=0$, and for time $t=0$

$$
\omega_{0}=\left(-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta_{0}, 0, \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta_{0}+\dot{\psi}\right)=\left(\omega_{0 x^{\prime}}, 0, \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}\right) .
$$

Thus

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=\left(\omega_{0 x^{\prime}} \cos \psi,-\omega_{0 x^{\prime}} \sin \psi, \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}\right)
$$

with

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\omega_{0 x^{\prime}}^{2}+\omega_{0 z^{\prime}}^{2}}=\omega_{0} .
$$

Hence $\omega$ has a constant magnitude. It makes an angle $\alpha$ with the $z$-axis given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \alpha &=\frac{\omega_{z}}{\omega}=\frac{\boldsymbol{\omega} \cdot \mathbf{L}}{\omega L} \\
&=\frac{1}{\omega}\left(\dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta_{0} \cos ^{2} \psi+\dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta_{0} \sin ^{2} \psi+\dot{\varphi} \cos ^{2} \theta_{0}+\dot{\psi} \cos \theta_{0}\right) \\
&=\frac{\dot{\varphi}+\dot{\psi} \cos \theta_{0}}{\omega},
\end{aligned}
$$

which is a constant as $\dot{\varphi}, \dot{\psi}, \omega$ are all constants. It makes an angle $\beta$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis given by

$$
\cos \beta=\frac{\omega_{z^{\prime}}}{\omega}=\frac{\omega \cdot \mathbf{k}^{\prime}}{\omega}=\frac{\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta_{0}+\dot{\psi}}{\omega},
$$

which is also a constant. In the fxed frame,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\omega} &=(\dot{\psi} \sin \theta \cos \varphi-\dot{\theta} \sin \varphi, \dot{\psi} \sin \theta \sin \varphi-\dot{\theta} \cos \varphi, \dot{\psi} \cos \theta+\dot{\varphi}) \\
&=\left(\dot{\psi} \sin \theta_{0} \cos \varphi, \dot{\psi} \sin \theta_{0} \sin \varphi, \dot{\psi} \cos \theta_{0}+\dot{\varphi}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\theta=\theta_{0}, \dot{\theta}=0$. At $t=0, \varphi=\psi=0$ so that

$$
\omega_{0}=\left(\dot{\psi} \sin \theta_{0}, 0, \dot{\psi} \cos \theta_{0}+\dot{\varphi}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}(t)=\omega_{0 x} \cos (\dot{\varphi} t) \mathbf{i}+\omega_{0 x} \sin (\dot{\varphi} t) \mathbf{j}+\omega_{0 z} \mathbf{k} .
$$

The precessions of $\omega$ about $L$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are depicted in Fig. 1.186. Note that $\mathbf{u}$ itself precesses about $\mathbf{L}$.

\section{3}

Let $I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}$ be the principal moments of inertia (relative to the center of mass) of a rigid body and suppose these moments are all different with $I_{1}>I_{2}>I_{3}$. If the body in free space is set to spin around one of the principal axes, it will continue spinning about that axis. However, we are concerned about the stability. What happens if the initial spin axis is very close to, but not exactly aligned with, a principal axis? Stability implies that the spin axis never wanders far from that principal axis. One finds that the motion is in fact stable for the principal axes corresponding to $I_{1}$ and $I_{3}$, the largest and the smallest moments of inertia. Explain this analytically using Euler's equations.

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ be the components of the angular velocity along the principal axes. Then, using Euler's equations for zero torque

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{1}-\omega_{2} \omega_{3}\left(I_{2}-I_{3}\right)=0 \\
&I_{2} \dot{\omega}_{2}-\omega_{3} \omega_{1}\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right)=0 \\
&I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{3}-\omega_{1} \omega_{2}\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

we consider the following cases.

(i) Suppose initially $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ directs almost parallel to the $x$-axis, i.e. $\omega_{1} \gg$ $\omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$. If $\omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ remain small in the subsequent rotation, the motion is stable. As $|\boldsymbol{\omega}|=$ constant and $\omega=\sqrt{\omega_{1}^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2}+\omega_{3}^{2}} \approx \omega_{1}$, we can take $\omega_{1}$ to be constant to first order. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\omega}_{2} &=\frac{\omega_{1}\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right)}{I_{2}} \dot{\omega}_{3}=\frac{\omega_{1}^{2}\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right)\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right)}{I_{2} I_{3}} \omega_{2}, \\
\ddot{\omega}_{3} &=\frac{\omega_{1}^{2}\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right)\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right)}{I_{3} I_{2}} \omega_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $I_{1}>I_{2}, I_{3}$, the coefficients on the right-hand side of the above are both negative and the equations of motion have the form of that of a harmonic oscillator. Thus $\omega_{2}$ and $\omega_{3}$ will oscillate about same equilibrium values and remain small. Hence the motion is stable. The same conclusion is drawn if $\omega$ is initially almost parallel to the $z$-axis. gives

(ii) If $\omega$ initially is almost parallel to the $y$-axis. The same consideration

$$
\begin{gathered}
\ddot{\omega}_{1}=\frac{\omega_{2}^{2}\left(I_{2}-I_{3}\right)\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right)}{I_{1} I_{3}} \omega_{1}, \\
\ddot{\omega}_{3}=\frac{\omega_{2}^{2}\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right)\left(I_{2}-I_{3}\right)}{I_{3} I_{1}} \omega_{3} .
\end{gathered}
$$

As $I_{2}>I_{3}, I_{1}>I_{2}$, the coefficients on the right-hand side are both positive and the motion is unstable at least in first-order approximation.

\section{4}

A spherical ball of mass $m$, radius $R$ and uniform density is attached to a massless rigid rod of length $l$ in such a way that the ball may spin around the rod. The ball is in a uniform gravitational field, say that of the earth. Supposing the ball and the rod rotate about the $z$-axis without nutation (i.e. $\theta$ is fixed), the angular velocity of the rod and ball about the $z$-axis is $\omega$, and the ball spins about the rod with angular velocity $\Omega$. Give the relation between $\omega$ and $\Omega$ (you may assume $R / l \ll 1$ though this is not necessary for the form of the solution). Does the ball move in a right-handed or a left-handed sense about the $z$-axis?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-359.jpg?height=304&width=303&top_left_y=1527&top_left_x=592)

Fig. $1.187$. 

\section{Solution:}

The orientation of the ball can be described in terms of the Eulerian angles $\theta, \varphi, \psi$ (Problem 1212). As there is no nutation, $\dot{\theta}=0$. The angular momentum of the ball about the origin $O$ (Fig. 1.187) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{L} &=\frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \dot{\varphi} \mathbf{e}_{r}+l \sin \theta \cdot \dot{\varphi} m l \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
&=\frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \Omega \mathbf{e}_{r}+m l^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta \omega \mathbf{e}_{z}
\end{aligned}
$$

in cylindrical coordinates. As $\mathbf{e}_{z}$ is fixed, $\theta$ is a constant, we have

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=\frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \Omega \frac{d \mathbf{e}_{r}}{d t}=\mathbf{M},
$$

where $M$ is the torque due to gravity. As

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{e}_{r}}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}=\omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}
$$

the above becomes

$$
\frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \Omega \omega \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}=l \mathbf{e}_{r} \times m g\left(-\mathbf{e}_{z}\right)=l m g \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\varphi} .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega=\frac{5 l g}{2 R^{2} \Omega} .
$$

As $\dot{\varphi} \equiv \omega>0$, the ball moves in a right-handed sense about the $z$-axis.

\section{5}

A gyroscope at latitude $45^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ is mounted on bearings in such a way that the axis of spin is constrained to be horizontal but otherwise no torques occur in the bearings. Taking into account the rotation of the earth, show that an orientation with the axis of spin along the local north-south is stable and find the period for small oscillations of the spin axis about this direction. Assume that the rotor can be approximated by a thin circular ring (i.e. the spokes and other parts are of negligible mass). (In working out this problem it is simpler when writing the angular velocity of the rotor 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-361.jpg?height=448&width=337&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=538)

Fig. 1.188.

about the $x$-axis (Fig. 1.188) to lump together the spin term and the term due to rotation of the earth).

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Use an inertial frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ fixed with respect to a distant star which, at the instant under consideration, has the origin $O$ at the center of mass of the rotor, the $z^{\prime}$-axis pointing vertically up and the $x^{\prime}$-axis pointing north, and a rotating frame Oxyz attached to the earth with the same $z$-axis but with the $x$-axis at that instant along the spin axis of the rotor as shown in Fig. 1.188. Denote the spin angular velocity by $\omega$, and the moments of inertia about the $x$-, $y$-, $z$-axes, which are the principal axes of the gyroscope, by $C, A, A$ respectively. The angular momentum then has components

$$
(C \omega, 0, A \dot{\theta})
$$

in the rotating frame, and

$$
(C \omega \cos \theta, C \omega \sin \theta, A \dot{\theta})
$$

in the fixed frame. Note that the $z$ component which is the same in both frames is contributed by the precession. In the fixed frame, the earth's rotational angular velocity at latitude $\lambda=45^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ has components

$$
\Omega\left(\cos 45^{\circ}, 0, \sin 45^{\circ}\right)=\frac{\Omega}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,1) .
$$

Also, the only torques are those that constrain the spin axis to the horizontal so that

$$
M_{z^{\prime}}=0 .
$$

As

$$
\mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\Omega \times \mathbf{L}=0,
$$

its $z$ component is

$$
A \ddot{\theta}+\frac{C \omega \Omega \sin \theta}{\sqrt{2}}=0,
$$

or

$$
A \ddot{\theta}+\frac{C \omega \Omega}{\sqrt{2}} \theta=0
$$

for small $\theta$. Note that for $\Omega \times \mathrm{L}$ we have resolved the vectors in the fixed frame. The last equation shows that the spin axis oscillates harmonically about the local north-south direction with angular frequency

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{C \omega \Omega}{\sqrt{2} A}}
$$

and the orientation is stable. The period is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{2} A}{C \omega \Omega}} .
$$

If the rotor is approximated by a thin circular ring of mass $M$ and radius $R$, we have

$$
C=M R^{2}, \quad A=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}, \quad T=\frac{2 \pi}{\sqrt{\sqrt{2} \omega \Omega}} .
$$

\section{6}

A thin disk of mass $M$ and radius $A$ is connected by two springs of spring constant $k$ to two fixed points on a frictionless table top. The disk is free to rotate but it is constrained to move in a plane. Each spring has an unstretched length of $l_{0}$, and initially both are stretched to length $l>l_{0}$ in the equilibrium position, as shown in Fig. 1.189. What are the frequencies 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-363.jpg?height=122&width=350&top_left_y=269&top_left_x=556)

Fig. 1.189.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-363.jpg?height=223&width=601&top_left_y=535&top_left_x=406)

Fig. $1.190$.

of the normal modes of oscillation for small vibrations? Sketch the motion for each mode.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

The motion of the disk is confined to the vertical plane. Let the displacement of the center of mass from equilibrium be $x$ and the angular displacement be $\theta$, as shown in Fig. 1.190. To first order in $\theta$, the restoring forces are

$$
F_{1}=k\left(l+x-l_{0}\right), \quad F_{2}=k\left(l-x-l_{0}\right) .
$$

The equations of motion are then

$$
M \ddot{x}=F_{2}-F_{1}=-2 k x,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}+\frac{2 k}{M} x=0,
$$

and

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=\left(F_{2}+F_{1}\right) A \sin \varphi,
$$

where $I=\frac{1}{2} M A^{2}$ and $\varphi$ is given by

$$
\frac{\sin (\pi-\varphi)}{l+A+x}=\frac{\sin \theta}{l+x},
$$

or

$$
\sin \varphi \approx\left(\frac{l+A}{l}\right) \sin \theta \approx\left(\frac{l+A}{l}\right) \theta
$$

i.e.

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{4 k\left(l-l_{0}\right)(l+A)}{M l A} \theta=0 .
$$

Equation (1) gives the angular frequency for linear oscillation,

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{M}}
$$

Equation (2) gives the angular frequency for rotational oscillation,

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{4 k\left(l-l_{0}\right)(l+A)}{M l A}} .
$$

The normal mode frequencies of small oscillations are therefore

$$
\frac{\omega_{1}}{2 \pi}, \quad \frac{\omega_{2}}{2 \pi},
$$

and the motions of the two normal modes are as shown in Fig. 1.191.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-364.jpg?height=146&width=434&top_left_y=1088&top_left_x=543)

Fig. $1.191$.

\section{7}

A simple symmetrical top consists of a disk of mass $M$ and radius $r$ mounted on the center $C$ of the massless cylindrical rod of length $l$ and radius $a$ as shown in Fig. 1.192. The top is rotated with large angular velocity $\omega(t)$ and is placed at an angle $\theta$ to the vertical on a horizontal surface with a small coefficient of friction. Neglect nutation and assume that the rate of slowing of $\omega(t)$ is small in one period of procession.

(a) Describe the entire subsequent motion of the top.

(b) Compute the angular frequency of the (slow) precession. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-365.jpg?height=477&width=405&top_left_y=206&top_left_x=506)

Fig. 1.192.

(c) Estimate the time required before the axis of the top becomes vertical.

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The motion of the top consists mainly of three components:

(1) spinning with angular velocity $\omega$ about its axis of symmetry,

(2) a slow procession $\Omega$ about the vertical axis due to gravity,

(3) motion of the axis of symmetry to come to the vertical gradually due to the effect of the frictional torque.

(b) Use two coordinate frames with origin $O$ as shown in Fig. 1.192: a fixed frame Oxyz with the $z$-axis along the upward vertical, and a rotating frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis along the axis of symmetry in the same direction as the spin angular velocity $\omega$, both the $x$ - and $x^{\prime}$-axes being taken in the plane of the $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes at the instant under consideration. We have

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{rot}}+\mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{L} .
$$

Under the condition that the spin angular velocity $\omega$ is very large, the total angular momentum can be taken to be approximately

$$
\mathbf{L}=I_{3} \omega \mathbf{k}^{\prime} .
$$

Further, as $\omega$ does not change appreciably in a period of precession, $\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }} \approx 0$. We then have 

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{L}=\mathbf{r}_{C} \times M \mathbf{g}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\boldsymbol{\Omega}=\Omega(-\sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta), \\
&\mathbf{L}=\left(0,0, I_{3} \omega\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in the rotating frame, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{C} &=\left(0,0, \frac{l}{2}\right), \\
\mathbf{g} &=g(\sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta) .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the fixed frame, the above gives

$$
I_{3} \omega \Omega \sin \theta=\frac{1}{2} M l g \sin \theta,
$$

i.e.

$$
\Omega=\frac{M l g}{2 I_{3} \omega}=\frac{l g}{r^{2} \omega},
$$

as

$$
I_{3}=\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} .
$$

(c) When the axis of symmetry makes an angle $\theta$ with the vertical, the frictional force $f$ on the contact point of the rod with the ground is approximately $\mu \mathrm{Mg}$. Actually only the left edge of the bottom end touches the ground. The frictional force is opposite to the slipping velocity of the contact point and has the direction shown in Fig. 1.192. This force causes an acceleration of the center of mass $C$ of the top and generates a torque about $C$ at the same time. Neglecting any specific condition of the rod, we can take the torque about $C$ as approximately

$$
\tau \approx \mu M g \cdot \frac{1}{2} l \mathbf{j} \text {. }
$$

This torque changes the magnitude of the angle $\theta$ and causes the axis of symmetry to eventually become vertical.

When the axis is vertical, the bottom of the rod contacts the ground evenly so that the frictional force is distributed symmetrically. The total torque about $C$ due to friction is then zero. Actually the torque of the frictional force about the $z^{\prime}$-axis (relating to the $z^{\prime}$ component of $\mathbf{L}$ ) does not vanish altogether, but as the rod is so thin the torque is quite small and causes $\omega$ to decrease only slowly. We have for the frictional torque approximately

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}_{C}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \mu M g l \mathbf{j},
$$

i.e.

$$
-\dot{\theta} I_{3} \omega=\frac{1}{2} \mu M g l,
$$

or

$$
\frac{d \theta}{d t}=-\frac{\mu g l}{r^{2} \omega},
$$

which gives

$$
t=-\int_{\theta}^{0} \frac{r^{2} \omega}{\mu g l} d \theta=\frac{r^{2} \omega}{\mu g l} \theta .
$$

\section{8}

A heavy symmetrical top with one point fixed is precessing at a steady angular velocity $\Omega$ about the vertical axis $z$. What is the minimum spin $\omega^{\prime}$ about its symmetrical axis $z^{\prime}\left(z^{\prime}\right.$ is inclined at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the $z$-axis)? The top has mass $m$ and its center of gravity is at a distance $h$ from the fixed point. Use the coordinate systems indicated in Fig. 1.193, with the axes $z, z^{\prime}, x$ and $x^{\prime}$ in the same plane at the time under consideration and assume $I_{1}=I_{2}$.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-367.jpg?height=354&width=263&top_left_y=1467&top_left_x=597)

Fig. $1.193$. 

\section{Solution:}

Referring to the Eulerian angles defined in Problem 1212, the torque due to gravity is in a direction perpendicular to the $x z$-plane and in the rotating frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ attached to the top has components

$$
m g h \sin \theta \sin \psi, \quad m g h \sin \theta \cos \psi, \quad 0 .
$$

Euler's equations, which apply in the rotating frame, are, for $I_{1}=I_{2}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{x^{\prime}}-\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) \omega_{y^{\prime}} \omega_{z^{\prime}} &=m g h \sin \theta \sin \psi, \\
I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{y^{\prime}}-\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right) \omega_{x^{\prime}} \omega_{z^{\prime}} &=m g h \sin \theta \cos \psi, \\
I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{z^{\prime}} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The angular velocity vector $\omega$ in the rotating frame has components

$$
-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \psi, \quad \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \sin \psi, \quad \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta+\dot{\psi}
$$

as $\dot{\theta}=0$. So writing $\Omega$ for $\dot{\varphi}$ and noting that $\ddot{\varphi}=0$ for steady precession, the first Euler's equation becomes

$$
\Omega^{2}\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) \cos \theta-\Omega I_{3} \dot{\psi}+m g h=0
$$

giving

$$
\omega^{\prime} \equiv \dot{\psi}=\frac{m g h+\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) \Omega^{2} \cos \theta}{I_{3} \Omega} .
$$

However for $\Omega$ to be real we require that

$$
I_{3}^{2} \omega^{\prime 2}-4\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) m g h \cos \theta \geq 0,
$$

or

$$
\omega^{\prime} \geq \frac{1}{I_{3}} \sqrt{4\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) m g h \cos \theta} .
$$

\section{9}

The game of "Jacks" is played with metal pieces that can be approximated by six masses on orthogonal axes of length $l$ with total mass $M$, as shown in Fig $1.194$.

(a) If you spin the jack around one of the axes so that there is a steady precession around the vertical (Fig. 1.195) what is the relation between the spin velocity $s$, the precession rate, and the angle $\theta$ between the vertical and the rotation axis of the jack?

(b) What must the spin velocity be for the jack to spin stably around a vertical axis (i.e. $\theta=0$ )?

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-369.jpg?height=120&width=133&top_left_y=595&top_left_x=264)

Side view

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-369.jpg?height=117&width=120&top_left_y=590&top_left_x=456)

Top view

Fig. 1.194.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-369.jpg?height=291&width=221&top_left_y=495&top_left_x=984)

Fig. $1.195$.

\section{Solution:}

Use fixed frame $O x y z$ and rotating frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ as in Problem 1212 with $O$ at the point of contact with the ground and the latter frame attached to the jack. The $z$-axis is along the upward vertical and the $z^{\prime}$-axis is along the axis of spin as shown in Fig. 1.195. The moments of inertia about the $x^{\prime}$-, $y^{\prime}$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{2}=4 m l^{2}+6 m l^{2}=10 m l^{2}, \\
&I_{3}=4 m l^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

with $m=\frac{M}{6}$.

(a) In the rotating frame, the torque due to gravity has components

$$
6 m g l \sin \theta \sin \psi, \quad 6 m g l \sin \theta \cos \psi, \quad 0,
$$

and the angular velocity $\omega$ has components

$$
\dot{\theta} \sin \psi-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \psi, \quad \dot{\theta} \cos \psi+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \sin \psi, \quad \dot{\psi}+\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta .
$$

Euler's equations then give 

$$
\begin{gathered}
5 \dot{\omega}_{x^{\prime}}-3 \omega_{y^{\prime}} \omega_{z^{\prime}}=\frac{3 g}{l} \sin \theta \sin \psi, \\
5 \dot{\omega}_{y^{\prime}}+3 \omega_{z^{\prime}} \omega_{x^{\prime}}=\frac{3 g}{l} \sin \theta \cos \psi, \\
4 \dot{\omega}_{z^{\prime}}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

The last equation gives

$$
\omega_{z^{\prime}}=\dot{\psi}+\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta=s+\Omega \cos \theta=\text { constant } .
$$

where $\Omega$ is the precession rate.

(b) If the spin axis is nearly vertical, $\theta \approx 0$ and we take the approximations $\sin \theta \approx \theta, \cos \theta \approx 1$. Then $\sin \psi \times(1)+\cos \psi \times(2)$ gives

$$
5 \ddot{\theta}+\left(2 \Omega s-3 \Omega^{2}-\frac{3 g}{l}\right) \theta=0
$$

with $\Omega=\dot{\varphi}, s=\dot{\psi}$. Hence for stable spin at $\theta=0$ we require

$$
2 \Omega s-3 \Omega^{2}-\frac{3 g}{l}>0,
$$

or

$$
s>\frac{3 \Omega}{2}+\frac{3 g}{2 l \Omega} .
$$

1220

A propeller-driven airplane flies in a circle, counterclockwise when viewed from above, with a constant angular velocity $\chi$ with respect to an inertial frame. Its propeller turns at a constant angular velocity $d \psi / d t$ clockwise as seen by the pilot.

(a) For a flat, four-bladed propeller, what relations exist among the moments of inertia?

(b) Find the magnitude and direction of the torque that must be applied to the propeller shaft by the bearings to maintain level flight in a circle.

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take a fixed frame $O x y z$ at the instantaneous position of the center of the propeller with the $z$-axis pointing vertically up and a rotating frame 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-371.jpg?height=365&width=372&top_left_y=239&top_left_x=572)

Fig. 1.196.

$O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ fixed to the propeller such that the $x^{\prime}$-axis is along the spin axis, and the $z^{\prime}$-axis is along a propeller blade, the $x$-axis being taken to coincide with the $x^{\prime}$-axes at the instant under consideration, as shown in Fig. 1.196. The rotating coordinate axes are then the principal axes with moments of inertia

$$
I_{2}=I_{3}=I,
$$

and $I_{1}=2 I$ by the perpendicular axis theorem. The angular velocity has components in the rotating frame of

$$
\dot{\psi}, \quad \chi \sin \psi, \quad \chi \cos \psi,
$$

where $\psi=\dot{\psi} t$. Euler's equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{x^{\prime}}-\left(I_{2}-I_{3}\right) \omega_{y^{\prime}} \omega_{z^{\prime}}=M_{x^{\prime}}, \\
&I_{2} \dot{\omega}_{y^{\prime}}-\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right) \omega_{z^{\prime}} \omega_{x^{\prime}}=M_{y^{\prime}}, \\
&I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{z^{\prime}}-\left(I_{1}-I_{2}\right) \omega_{x^{\prime}} \omega_{y^{\prime}}=M_{z^{\prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

then give for the torque $\mathbf{M}$ exerted on the propeller shaft

$$
M_{x^{\prime}}=0,
$$

as $\dot{\psi}=$ constant and $I_{2}=I_{3}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M_{y^{\prime}}=2 I \dot{\psi} \chi \cos (\dot{\psi} t), \\
&M_{z^{\prime}}=-2 I \dot{\psi} \chi \sin (\dot{\psi} t),
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\chi=$ constant. Hence

$$
M=2 I \dot{\psi} \chi
$$

and as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M_{x^{\prime}}=0, \\
&M_{y^{\prime}}=M \cos \psi, \\
&M_{z^{\prime}}=-M \sin \psi,
\end{aligned}
$$

$\mathbf{M}$ is in the plane of the propeller and has a direction along the $y$-axis of the fixed frame.

\section{1}

A perfectly uniform ball $20 \mathrm{~cm}$ in diameter and with a density of $5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$ is rotating in free space at $1 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{s}$. An intelligent flea of $10^{-3} \mathrm{~g}$ resides in a small (massless) house fixed to the ball's surface at a rotational pole as shown in Fig. 1.197. The flea decides to move the equator to the house by walking quickly to a latitude of $45^{\circ}$ and waiting the proper length of time. How long should it wait? Indicate how you obtain this answer. Note: Neglect the small precession associated with the motion of the flea on the surface of the ball.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-372.jpg?height=272&width=156&top_left_y=1276&top_left_x=361)

Fig. 1.197.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-372.jpg?height=336&width=387&top_left_y=1250&top_left_x=920)

Fig. 1.198.

\section{Solution:}

After the flea moves to a position of latitude $45^{\circ}$, the angular velocity $\omega$ no longer coincides with a principal axis of the system. This causes the ball to precess. As the mass of the flea is much smaller than that of the ball, the center of mass of the system can be taken to be at the center of the ball 0 . Use a fixed frame $O x y z$ with the $z$-axis along the original direction of $\omega$ and a rotating frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ attached to the ball with the $z^{\prime}$-axis through the new position of the flea, with both the $x$ - and $x^{\prime}$-axes in the plane of the $z$-and $z^{\prime}$-axes at $t=0$ as shown in Fig. 1.198. As the system is in free space, there is no external force. We assume that the flea moves so quickly to the new position that $\omega$ remains the same at $t=0$ as for $t<0$.

The rotating axes are the new principal axes. Let the corresponding moments of inertia be $I_{1}, I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ with $I_{1}=I_{2}$ for symmetry. Euler's equations are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{x^{\prime}}-\left(I_{1}-I_{3}\right) \omega_{y^{\prime}} \omega_{z^{\prime}}=0, \\
&I_{1} \dot{\omega}_{y^{\prime}}-\left(I_{3}-I_{1}\right) \omega_{z^{\prime}} \omega_{x^{\prime}}=0, \\
&I_{3} \dot{\omega}_{z^{\prime}}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Equation (3) shows that

$$
\omega_{z^{\prime}}=\text { constant }=\omega_{0 z^{\prime}} .
$$

Equations (2) and (3) then give

$$
\ddot{\omega}_{x^{\prime}}+\Omega^{2} \omega_{x^{\prime}}=0
$$

with $\Omega=\left|\frac{I_{3}-I_{1}}{I_{1}}\right| \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}$.Its solution is

$$
\omega_{x^{\prime}}=A \cos (\Omega t+\phi),
$$

where $A$ and $\phi$ are constants. Equation (2) then gives

$$
\omega_{y^{\prime}}=A \sin (\Omega t+\phi) \text {. }
$$

Initially, $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ has components in the rotating frame

$$
\omega_{0 x^{\prime}}=-\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}}, \quad \omega_{0 y^{\prime}}=0, \quad \omega_{0 z^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} .
$$

These give

$$
A=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}}, \quad \phi=\pi .
$$

Hence at time $t, \omega$ has components 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{x^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} \cos (\Omega t+\pi), \\
&\omega_{y^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} \sin (\Omega t+\pi), \\
&\omega_{z^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, both the magnitude and the $z^{\prime}$ component of $\omega$ are constant, and the angular velocity vector $\omega$ describes a cone in the rigid body with axis along the $z^{\prime}$-axis. In other words, $\omega$ precesses about the $z^{\prime}$-axis with an angular rate

$$
\Omega=\left|\frac{I_{3}-I_{1}}{I_{1}}\right| \frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} .
$$

For the equator at be at the flea house, the angular velocity $\boldsymbol{\omega}$ must be midway between the $x^{\prime}$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes, i.e.

$$
\omega_{x^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}}, \quad \omega_{y^{\prime}}=0, \quad \omega_{z^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}} .
$$

This means that $\Omega t=\pi$, or that the time required is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\pi}{\Omega} &=\frac{\sqrt{2} \pi}{\omega}\left|\frac{I_{1}}{I_{3}-I_{1}}\right| \approx \frac{\sqrt{2} \pi}{\omega} \frac{2 M R^{2}}{5 m R^{2}} \\
&=\frac{2 \sqrt{2} \pi}{5 \omega m}\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho\right)=\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3} \pi \times 10^{6}=6 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{2}

A horizontal bar of mass $m$ and length $2 a$ hangs by 2 parallel strings of length $2 a$ attached to its two ends. The rod is suddenly given an angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical axis through its center. Calculate

(a) the distance $h$ to which the bar rises,

(b) the initial increase in tension in each string.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $1.199$ with origin at the center of the bar, the $z$-axis vertically upward and the $x$-axis along the initial direction of the bar. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-375.jpg?height=227&width=221&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=641)

Fig, 1.199.

(a) Take the $x y$-plane as the reference level for potential energy. The total mechanical energy of the bar at $t=0$ at which instant it is given an angular velocity $\omega$ is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{m a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6}
$$

as $I=\frac{1}{3} m a^{2}$. When the bar is at its highest position $h$, it has only a potential energy $m g h$. Conservation of mechanical energy then gives

$$
m g h=\frac{1}{6} m a^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

or

$$
h=\frac{a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6 g} .
$$

(b) Due to symmetry, the bar is always horizontal during the motion while it rotates about the $z$-axis. Let the height of the bar be $z$ and the angle it makes with the $x$-axis be $\theta$ at time $t$. Assume the strings to be unstretchable then the distance between a point of support $A^{\prime}$ and the corresponding end of the bar $A$ is constant. The coordinates of $A$ and $A^{\prime}$ are respectively $(a \cos \theta, a \sin \theta, z)$ and $(a, 0,2 a)$. Thus

$$
a^{2}(1-\cos \theta)^{2}+a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+(2 a-z)^{2}=4 a^{2},
$$

i.e.

$$
z^{2}-4 a z+2 a^{2}(1-\cos \theta)=0 .
$$

Differentiating twice with respect to time we obtain

$$
\dot{z}^{2}+z \ddot{z}-2 a \ddot{z}+a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2 a-z}\left[\dot{z}^{2}+a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta\right] .
$$

At $t=0, \theta=0, z=0, \dot{z}=0, \dot{\theta}=\omega$, we have $\ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2} a \omega^{2}$. Thus the vertical force on the bar is increased by $m \ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2} m a \omega^{2}$. As this is shared equally by the two supporting strings the initial increase in the tension of each string is

$$
\Delta T=\frac{1}{2} m \ddot{z}=\frac{1}{4} m a \omega^{2} .
$$

\section{3}

A uniform rod of length $2 a$ and mass $M$ is rotated with constant angular velocity $\omega$ in a horizontal circle of center $B$ and radius $b$. The rod is hinged at $A$ so that it can move freely only in the vertical plane containing it. The angle between the vertical and the rod is $\theta$ as shown in Fig. 1.200. The earth's gravitational field is in the vertical direction.

(a) Compute the kinetic and potential energies of the rod as a function of $\theta, \dot{\theta}$ and $\omega$.

(b) Find a general expression for the possible equilibrium positions of the rod.

(c) Solve the expression found in part (b) by a graphical technique to find the equilibrium positions in each quadrant of $\theta$ between 0 and $2 \pi$.

(d) Which of these equilibrium positions are stable? Unstable? For each quadrant of $\theta$ how does the existence of the equilibrium position(s) depend on the parameters $\omega, b$ and $a$ ?

(e) For each quadrant of $\theta$ make a force diagram to verify qualitatively the existence and nature of the equilibrium positions.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-376.jpg?height=279&width=335&top_left_y=1519&top_left_x=264)

Fig. $1.200$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-376.jpg?height=327&width=556&top_left_y=1497&top_left_x=771)

Fig. $1.201$. 

\section{Solution:}

Use a coordinate frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ such that the origin $O$ coincides with $B$, the $z^{\prime}$-axis is along the axis of rotation of angular velocity $\omega$ and the $x^{\prime}$-axis is in the vertical plane containing the $z^{\prime}$-axis and the rod.

(a) In this rotating frame the kinetic energy of the system is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} I_{A} \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{4}{3} m a^{2} \cdot \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{2}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} .
$$

The potential energy consists of two parts, a centrifugal potential and a gravitational potential. In the rotating frame, a fictitious centrifugal force $m \omega^{2} x^{\prime}$ must be introduced on every mass point $m$, corresponding to a potential $-\frac{1}{2} m x^{\prime 2} \omega^{2}$. For the entire system this fictitious centrifugal potential is $-\frac{1}{2} I_{z^{\prime}} \omega^{2}$, where $I_{z^{\prime}}=\frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m(b+a \sin \theta)^{2}$. As the gravitational potential is $m g a \cos \theta$, we have

$$
V=-\frac{1}{2} m\left[\frac{1}{3} a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+(b+a \sin \theta)^{2}\right] \omega^{2}+m g a \cos \theta \text {. }
$$

(b) For equilibrium, $\frac{d V}{d \theta}=0$, which gives the equation for possible equilibrium positions of the rod,

$$
-m \omega^{2}\left(b+\frac{4}{3} a \sin \theta\right) \cdot a \cdot \cos \theta-m g a \sin \theta=0,
$$

or

$$
\tan \theta=-\frac{a \omega^{2}}{g}\left(\frac{b}{a}+\frac{4}{3} \sin \theta\right) .
$$

(c) Let the left-hand side of the above equation be $f_{1}$ and the right-hand side be $f_{2}$ and draw these curves in Fig. 1.201. The equilibrium positions are given by their intersections. It can be seen that one equilibrium position occurs in each of the second and fourth quadrants of $\theta$. In the third quadrant, $f_{1}=\tan \theta$ is positive, and

$$
f_{2}=\left(-\frac{a}{g}+\frac{4 a}{3 g}|\sin \theta|\right) \omega^{2}
$$

as $\sin \theta$ is negative. It is seen that only if $f_{2}$ is positive and sufficiently large can there be one or two equilibrium positions, otherwise there will be none.

(d) For an equilibrium position to be stable, we require that

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d \theta^{2}}>0
$$

at that position. As

$$
\frac{d V}{d \theta}=-m \omega^{2}\left(b+\frac{4}{3} a \sin \theta\right) a \cos \theta-m g a \sin \theta,
$$

we require that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^{2} V}{d \theta^{2}} &=-\frac{4}{3} m a^{2} \omega^{2}\left(\cos ^{2} \theta-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)+m a b \omega^{2} \sin \theta-m g a \cos \theta \\
&=\frac{m a \cos ^{2} \theta}{\sin \theta}\left(\frac{4}{3} a \omega^{2} \sin \theta \tan ^{2} \theta+b \omega^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b \omega^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{m a \cos ^{2} \theta}{\sin \theta}\left(-g \tan ^{3} \theta+b \omega^{2}\right)>0
\end{aligned}
$$

for an equilibrium position $\theta$ to be stable.

When $\theta$ is in the second quadrant $\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$, as $\sin \theta>0$, $\tan \theta<0$, we have

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d \theta^{2}}>0
$$

and the equilibrium is stable.

When $\theta$ is in the fourth quadrant $\left[\frac{3 \pi}{2}, 2 \pi\right]$, as $\sin \theta<0, \tan \theta<0$, we have

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d \theta^{2}}<0
$$

and the equilibrium is unstable.

When $\theta$ is in the third quadrant $\left[\pi, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right]$, we write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^{2} V}{d \theta^{2}} &=\frac{m a \cos ^{2} \theta}{\sin \theta}\left(\frac{4}{3} a \omega^{2} \sin \theta \tan ^{2} \theta+b \omega^{2} \sec ^{2} \theta\right) \\
