&=\frac{m a \omega^{2}}{\sin \theta}\left(\frac{4}{3} a \sin ^{3} \theta+b\right)=-\frac{m a \omega^{2}}{|\sin \theta|}\left(b-\frac{4}{3} a|\sin \theta|^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\sin \theta<0$. Then if $b<\frac{4}{3} a|\sin \theta|^{3}$, the equilibrium is stable, and if $b>\frac{4}{3} a|\sin \theta|^{3}$, the equilibrium is unstable. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-379.jpg?height=302&width=270&top_left_y=218&top_left_x=211)

(i)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-379.jpg?height=295&width=215&top_left_y=234&top_left_x=612)

(ii)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-379.jpg?height=270&width=233&top_left_y=234&top_left_x=976)

(iii)

Fig. 1.202.

(e) The force diagram for each equilibrium situation is shown in Fig. 1.202, where (i), (ii) and (iii), are for the second, third and fourth quadrants respectively, with $T$ and $F$ denoting the support force by the hinge and the fictitious centrifugal force. By considering a small deviation $\delta \theta$ from equilibrium, we see that (i) is stable and (iii) is unstable, while for (ii) the situation is more complicated; whether it is stable or not depends on the relative values of the parameters.

\section{DYNAMICS OF DEFORMABLE BODIES (1224-1272)}

\section{4}

A string is stretched between two rigid supports $100 \mathrm{~cm}$ apart. In the frequency range between 100 and $350 \mathrm{cps}$ only the following frequencies can be excited: $160,240,320 \mathrm{cps}$. What is the wavelength of each of these modes of vibration?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

As the two ends of the string are fixed, we have $n \lambda=2 L$, where $L$ is the length of the string and $n$ an integer. Let the wavelengths corresponding to frequencies $160,240,320 \mathrm{~Hz}$ be $\lambda_{0}, \lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}$ respectively. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
n \lambda_{0}=(n+1) \lambda_{1}=(n+2) \lambda_{2}=200 \\
160 \lambda_{0}=240 \lambda_{1}=320 \lambda_{2} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence $n=2$, and

$$
\lambda_{0}=100 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad \lambda_{1}=67 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad \lambda_{2}=50 \mathrm{~cm} .
$$

\section{5}

(a) Give the equation which relates the fundamental frequency of a string to the physical and geometrical properties of the string.

(b) Derive your result from Newton's equations by analysing what happens to a small section of the string.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-380.jpg?height=327&width=457&top_left_y=867&top_left_x=507)

Fig. 1.203.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\omega$ be the fundamental frequency of a string of length $l$, linear density $\rho$ and tension $F$. The equation relating $F, l$ and $\rho$ is

$$
\omega=\frac{\pi}{l} \sqrt{\frac{F}{\rho}} .
$$

(b) Consider a small length $\Delta l$ of a string along the $x$ direction undergoing small oscillations and let $F_{1}, F_{2}$ be the tensions at its two ends, as shown in Fig. 1.203. For small oscillations, $\theta \approx 0$ and $\Delta \theta$ is a second-order small quality. Furthermore as there is no $x$ motion, we can take the $x$-component of the net force on $\Delta l$ to be zero. Thus 

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{x} &=F_{2} \cos (\theta+\Delta \theta)-F_{1} \cos \theta \\
& \approx\left(F_{2}-F_{1}\right) \cos \theta-F_{2} \Delta \theta \sin \theta \\
& \approx F_{2}-F_{1}=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

or $F_{2} \approx F_{1}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{y} &=F \sin (\theta+\Delta \theta)-F \sin \theta \approx F \frac{d \sin \theta}{d \theta} \Delta \theta \\
&=F \cos \theta \frac{d \theta}{d x} \Delta x \approx F \frac{d \theta}{d x} \Delta x .
\end{aligned}
$$

For small $\theta$

$$
\theta \approx \frac{d y}{d x}, \quad \frac{d \theta}{d x}=\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}},
$$

and the above becomes

$$
\rho \Delta l \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=F \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}} \Delta x
$$

by Newton's second law. As $\Delta l \approx \Delta x$, this gives

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\rho}{F} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0,
$$

which is the equation for a wave with velocity of propagation

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{F}{\rho}} .
$$

For the fundamental mode in a string of length $l$ with the two ends fixed, the wavelength $\lambda$ is given by $l=\lambda / 2$. Hence the fundamental angular frequency is

$$
\omega=\frac{2 \pi v}{\lambda}=\frac{\pi v}{l}=\frac{\pi}{l} \sqrt{\frac{F}{\rho}} .
$$

1226

A violin string on a violin is of length $L$ and can be considered to be fastened at both ends. The fundamental of the open string has a frequency $f_{0}$. The violinist bows the string at a distance $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string lightly at the midpoint. (a) Under these conditions, what is the lowest frequency he can excite? Sketch the shape of the string.

(b) What is the frequency of the first overtone under these conditions? (Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-382.jpg?height=91&width=374&top_left_y=529&top_left_x=606)

Fig. 1.204.

\section{Solution:}

(a) For the open string, the wavelength $\lambda_{0}$ corresponding to the fundamental frequency $f_{0}$ is given by $\lambda_{0} / 2=L$. When the violinist bows at $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string at $L / 2$, the former point is a node and the latter point an antinode so that $\lambda_{0}=L$. Hence the string has the shape shown in Fig. $1.204$ and, as $f_{0} \propto 1 / \lambda_{0}$, the fundamental frequency is $2 f_{0}$.

(b) The frequency of the first overtone is $4 f_{0}$.

\section{7}

A guitar string is $80 \mathrm{~cm}$ long and has a fundamental frequency of $400 \mathrm{~Hz}$. In its fundamental mode the maximum displacement is $2 \mathrm{~cm}$ at the middle. If the tension in the string is $10^{6}$ dynes, what is the maximum of that component of the force on the end support which is perpendicular to the equilibrium position of the string?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-382.jpg?height=233&width=479&top_left_y=1606&top_left_x=576)

Fig, 1,205. 

\section{Solution:}

Use Cartesian coordinates with the $x$-axis along the equilibrium position of the string and the origin at one of its fixed ends. Then the two fixed ends are at $x=0$ and $x=l=80 \mathrm{~cm}$, as shown in Fig. 1.205. At $x=0$, the $y$-component of the force on the support is

$$
F_{y}=T \sin \theta \simeq T \theta \simeq T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x},
$$

where $T$ is the tension in the string. The guitar string has a sinusoidal form

$$
y=y_{0} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{x}{v}\right)\right]
$$

with $\omega=\frac{2 \pi v}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi v}{2 l}=\frac{\pi v}{80}, y_{0}=2 \mathrm{~cm}$. Thus

$$
y=2 \sin \left(\omega t-\frac{\pi x}{80}\right) \mathrm{cm} \text {. }
$$

Hence at $x=0$,

$$
F_{y}=-\frac{2 \pi T}{80} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and

$$
F_{y \max }=\frac{\pi T}{40}=7.85 \times 10^{4} \text { dynes } .
$$

\section{8}

A transverse traveling sinusoidal wave on a long stretched wire of mass per unit length $\rho$ has frequency $\omega$ and wave speed $c$. The maximum amplitude is $y_{0}$, where $y_{0} \ll \lambda$. The wave travels toward increasing $x$.

(a) Write an expression for the amplitude $y$ as a function of $t$ and $x$, where $x$ is distance measured along the wire.

(b) What is the energy density (energy/unit length)?

(c) What is the power transmitted along the wire?

(d) If the wave is generated by a mechanical device at $x=0$, find the transverse force $F_{y}(t)$ that it exerts on the wire.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) $y=y_{0} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{x}{c}\right)\right]$. (b) Every point the wave travels through undergoes simple harmonic motion. Consider an element of the wire from $x$ to $x+\Delta x$. The mechanical energy of the element is the sum of its potential and kinetic energies and is a constant equal to the maximum of its kinetic energy. As

$$
\dot{y}=\omega y_{0} \cos \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{x}{c}\right)\right],
$$

the maximum vibrational velocity of the element is $\omega y_{0}$ and its total mechanical energy is

$$
\frac{1}{2} \Delta m \cdot \omega^{2} y_{0}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \rho \omega^{2} y_{0}^{2} \Delta x .
$$

Hence the energy per unit length of the string is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} \rho \omega^{2} y_{0}^{2} .
$$

(c) As the wave travels at a speed $c$, the energy that passes through a point on the string in time $t$ is Ect. Hence the power transmitted is

$$
\frac{1}{2} \rho c \omega^{2} y_{0}^{2} .
$$

(d) The tension $T$ in the string is given by $c=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\rho}}$ (Problem 1225). The transverse force the mechanical device exerts on the wire at $x=0$ is (Problem 1227)

$$
F_{y}(t)=-T\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x=0}=\rho c \omega y_{0} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

\section{9}

A violin string, $0.5 \mathrm{~m}$ long, has a fundamental frequency of $200 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

(a) At what speed does a transverse pulse travel on this string?

(b) Draw a pulse before and after reflection from one end of the string.

(c) Show a sketch of the string in the next two higher modes of oscillation and give the frequency of each mode. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-385.jpg?height=97&width=151&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=346)

Before reflection

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-385.jpg?height=102&width=215&top_left_y=424&top_left_x=279)

After reflection

Fg, 1.206.
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-385.jpg?height=190&width=450&top_left_y=292&top_left_x=820)

Fig. 1.207.

\section{Solution:}

(a) For a string of length $l$ fastened at both ends, the wavelength $\lambda$ of the fundamental mode is given by $\lambda / 2=l$. Hence

$$
v=\lambda \nu=2 l \nu=2 \times 0.5 \times 200=200 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

(b) Figure $1.206$ shows the shape of a pulse before and after reflection from one end of the string.

(c) The frequencies of the next two higher modes are $400 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and $600 \mathrm{~Hz}$. The corresponding shapes of the string are as shown in Fig. 1.207.

$$
1230
$$

A piano string of length $l$ is fixed at both ends. The string has a linear mass density $\sigma$ and is under tension $T$.

(a) Find the allowed solutions for the vibrations of the string. What are the allowed frequencies and wavelengths?

(b) At time $t=0$ the string is pulled a distance $s$ from equilibrium position at its midpoint so that it forms an isosceles triangle and is then released $(s \ll l$, see Fig. 1.208). Find the ensuing motion of the string, using the Fourier analysis method.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The vibration of the string is described by the wave equation (Problem 1225) 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-386.jpg?height=244&width=588&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.208.

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\sigma}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0
$$

subject to the conditions

$$
y(0, t)=y(l, t)=0
$$

for all $t$. Let

$$
y(x, t)=X(t) A(t)
$$

and obtain from the above

$$
\frac{1}{X} \frac{d^{2} X}{d x^{2}}=\frac{\sigma}{T A} \frac{d^{2} A}{d t^{2}} .
$$

As the left-hand side depends only on $x$ and the right-hand side only on $t$, each must be equal to a constant; let it be $-k^{2}$. We then have the ordinary differential equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d^{2} X}{d x^{2}}+k^{2} X=0 \\
&\frac{d^{2} A}{d t^{2}}+v^{2} k^{2} A=0
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\sigma}}$.

Solutions of the above equations are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
X(x) &=c_{1} \cos (k x)+c_{2} \sin (k x), \\
A(t) &=b_{1} \cos (v k t)+b_{2} \sin (v k t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

With the boundary conditions $X(0)=X(l)=0$, we have

$$
c_{1}=0, \quad c_{2} \sin (k l)=0 .
$$

As $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ cannot both be zero (otherwise $y(x, t)$ would be identically zero), we have to choose $\sin (k l)=0$ or

$$
k l=n \pi, \quad n=1,2,3 \ldots
$$

Thus the allowed general solution is

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left[A_{n} \cos \left(\frac{n \pi v t}{l}\right)+B_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi v t}{l}\right)\right] \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{l}\right),
$$

where we have replaced the integration constants $b_{1} c_{2}$ by $A_{n}$ and $b_{2} c_{2}$ by $B_{n}$ for integer $n$. Each term in the general solution is an allowed solution corresponding to an allowed mode. The period for the $n$th mode is given by

$$
\frac{n \pi v}{l} T_{n}=2 \pi,
$$

the frequency being

$$
\nu_{n}=\frac{1}{T_{n}}=\frac{n}{2 l} v=\frac{n}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\sigma}},
$$

and the wavelength being

$$
\lambda_{n}=\frac{v}{\nu_{n}}=\frac{2 l}{n} .
$$

(b) Initially the string is as shown in Fig. 1.208. As

$$
\frac{y}{x}=\frac{y}{l-x}=\frac{s}{\frac{l}{2}},
$$

the initial conditions are

$$
y(x, 0)=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}
\frac{2 s x}{l} & \text { for } & 0 \leq x \leq \frac{l}{2}, \\
\frac{2 s(l-x)}{l} & \text { for } & \frac{l}{2} \leq x \leq l .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Furthermore, the string is initially at rest so

$$
\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}\right)_{t=0}=0 \text {. }
$$

376

Problems \& Solutions on Mechanics

Hence

and the $A_{n}$ are given by

$$
y(x, 0)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{l}\right) .
$$

Multiply both sides by $\sin (m \pi x / l)$ and integrate from 0 to $l$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{l} y(x, 0) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x &=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} A_{n} \int_{0}^{l} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{l}\right) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x \\
&=A_{m} \int_{0}^{l} \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{A_{m} l}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin ^{2} \xi d \xi=\frac{1}{2} A_{m} l .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{m} &=\frac{2}{l} \int_{0}^{l} y(x, 0) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{2}{l}\left[\frac{2 s}{l} \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}} x \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x+2 s \int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{l}\left(1-\frac{x}{l}\right) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{l}\right) d x\right] \\
&=\frac{8 s}{(m \pi)^{2}} \sin \left(\frac{m \pi}{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

use having been made of the formulae

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin (m x) \sin (n x) d x &=\frac{1}{2} \pi \delta_{m n}, \\
\int x \sin (a x) d x &=\frac{1}{a^{2}} \sin (a x)-\frac{x}{a} \cos (a x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the motion of the string is described by

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{8 s}{(n \pi)^{2}} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{n \pi v t}{l}\right) \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{l}\right)
$$

with $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\sigma}}$. 

\section{1}

A spring of rest length $X$ and force constant $k$ has a mass $m$. One end is fixed and the other end is attached to a mass $M$. The orientation is horizontal, and $M$ moves on a frictionless surface.

(a) Derive a wave equation for longitudinal oscillation of this system.

(b) Find the frequency of the lowest mode as a function of mass for the case where $M$ and $k$ are finite and $m \ll M$.

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-389.jpg?height=141&width=519&top_left_y=662&top_left_x=461)

Fig. 1.209.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take the $x$-axis along the length of the spring with origin at the fixed end and consider a section of length $\Delta x$ extending from $x$ to $x+\Delta x$ as shown in Fig. 1.209. Then as $M$ moves to the right, the point $x$ moves to $x+\xi$ and the point $x+\Delta x$ moves to $x+\Delta x+\xi+\Delta \xi$ as shown in Fig. 1.210.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-389.jpg?height=114&width=650&top_left_y=1367&top_left_x=478)

Fig. 1.210.

Let $\sigma$ be the Young's modulus of the spring. The restoring force $F$ is given by $F=a \sigma \Delta l / l$, where $a$ is the area of the cross section of the spring and $\Delta l / l$ is the extension per unit length. Write $K_{0}$ for $a \sigma$. The net force on the section under consideration is

$$
F_{x+\Delta x}-F_{x}=K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x}
$$

which by Newton's second law is equal to $\rho \Delta x\left(\partial^{2} \xi / \partial t^{2}\right)_{x}, \rho$ being the mass per unit length of the spring, assumed constant for small extensions. Thus

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}\right)_{x}=\frac{K_{0}}{\rho} \frac{\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x}}{\Delta x}=\frac{K_{0}}{\rho}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{m}{K_{0} X} \frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}=0 .
$$

This is the equation for propagation of longitudinal waves along the spring and gives the velocity of propagation as

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{K_{0} X}{m}}=X \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}},
$$

as $k=K_{0} / X$ by definition.

(b) Try a solution of the form

$$
\xi(x, t)=\xi_{0}(x) \cos (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

where $\omega, \varphi$ are constants. Substitution in the wave equation gives

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \xi_{0}}{\partial x^{2}}+K^{2} \xi_{0}=0,
$$

where

$$
K^{2}=\frac{m \omega^{2}}{K_{0} X}=\frac{\omega^{2}}{v^{2}} .
$$

Its general solution is

$$
\xi_{0}=A \sin (K x)+B \cos (K x),
$$

$A, B$ being constants of integration. The boundary condition $\xi_{0}=0$ at $x=0$ gives $B=0$. We also have from Newton's second law

$$
M\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}\right)_{X}=-K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{X}
$$

or

$$
K X \tan (K X)=\frac{m}{M},
$$

which can be solved to give a series of $K$, and hence of the vibrational frequencies of the spring.

For $m \ll M$ and the lowest frequency, $\tan (K X) \simeq K X$ and the above becomes

$$
\frac{\omega^{2} m}{k} \approx \frac{m}{M},
$$

giving the lowest angular frequency as

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}} .
$$

Note that this is just the vibrational frequency of an oscillator which consists of a massless spring of force constant $k$ with one end fixed and the other end connected to a mass $M$.

To obtain a more accurate approximate solution, expand

$$
\tan (K X)=K X+\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{3}+\cdots
$$

and retain the first two terms only. We then have

$$
(K X)^{2}=\frac{m}{M}\left[1+\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{2}\right]^{-1} \approx \frac{m}{M}\left[1-\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{2}\right]
$$

or

$$
K^{2}=\frac{3 m}{(3 M+m) X^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{3 M+m}} .
$$

1232

(a) Suppose you have a string of uniform mass per unit length $\rho$ and length $l$ held at both ends under tension $T$. Set up the equation for small transverse oscillations of the string and then find the eigenfrequencies.

(b) Now consider the case where the string is free at one end and attached to a vertical pole at the other end, and is rotating about the pole at an angular frequency $\omega$ (neglect gravity) as shown in Fig. 1.211. Set up the equation for small transverse oscillations for this case. (c) Find the eigenfrequencies.

(Hint: the equation you get should look familiar in terms of the Legendre polynomials.)

$(C U S P E A)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-392.jpg?height=205&width=258&top_left_y=447&top_left_x=672)

Fig. 1.211.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a section of the string as shown in Fig. 1.212. The $y^{-}$ component of the tension at $x$ is

$$
F_{y}(x)=-T \sin \theta \approx-T \theta \approx-T\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x} .
$$

Similarly at $x+\Delta x$

$$
F_{y}(x+\Delta x) \approx T\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x} \text {. }
$$

Note that $T$ is constant. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{y}(x+\Delta x)-F_{y}(x) &=T\left[\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x}\right]=T \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right) \cdot \Delta x \\
&=T \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}} \cdot \Delta x .
\end{aligned}
$$

The section has length $\Delta x$, mass $\rho \Delta x$, and by applying Newton's second law to the section we have

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\rho}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0 .
$$

This is the wave equation for small transverse oscillations, the velocity of propagation being $v=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\rho}}$. The general solution is (Problem 1230) 

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(A_{n} \cos \frac{n \pi v t}{l}+B_{n} \sin \frac{n \pi v t}{l}\right) \sin \frac{n \pi x}{l} .
$$

The eigenfrequencies are

$$
\nu_{n}=\frac{\omega_{n}}{2 \pi}=\frac{n \pi v}{2 \pi l}=\frac{n v}{2 l} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-393.jpg?height=196&width=411&top_left_y=538&top_left_x=530)

Fig. 1.212.

(b) Take a rotating frame $O x y z$ attached to the spring with the $y$-axis along the axis of rotation and the $x$-axis along the string. There is a fictitious centrifugal force acting on the string which is balanced by the tension. Consider a section $\Delta x$ of the string. The difference of tension across its ends is

$$
-\Delta T=\rho \Delta x \cdot x \omega^{2},
$$

whence

$$
\frac{d T}{d x}=-\rho \omega^{2} x .
$$

Integrating and applying the boundary condition $T=0$ at $x=l$ we find

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} \rho \omega^{2}\left(l^{2}-x^{2}\right) .
$$

Following the procedure of (a) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{y}(x+\Delta x)-F_{y}(x) &=\left(T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-\left(T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x} \\
& \approx \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho \omega^{2}\left(l^{2}-x^{2}\right) \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right] \Delta x .
\end{aligned}
$$

Newton's second law gives

$$
\rho \Delta x \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho \omega^{2}\left(l^{2}-x^{2}\right) \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right] \Delta x
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\left(l^{2}-x^{2}\right) \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right]=\frac{2}{\omega^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}},
$$

for small transverse oscillations.

(c) Try a solution of the type $y \sim e^{-i \Omega t}$ and let $\xi=\frac{x}{i}$. The above equation then becomes

$$
\left(1-\xi^{2}\right) \frac{\partial^{2} y}{d \xi^{2}}-2 \xi \frac{\partial y}{\partial \xi}+\frac{2 \Omega^{2}}{\omega^{2}} y=0
$$

with $0 \leq \xi \leq 1$. This differential equation has finite solutions if

$$
\frac{2 \Omega^{2}}{\omega^{2}}=n(n+1)
$$

$n$ being an integer. The equation is then known as Legendre's differential equation and the solutions are known as Legendre's polynomials. Thus the eigenfrequencies are given by

$$
\frac{\Omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2} n(n+1)},
$$

where $n=1,2,3, \ldots$ However we still have to satisfy the boundary condition $y=0$ at $\xi=0$. This limits the allowable $n$ to odd integers $1,3,5, \ldots$ since Legendre's polynomials $P_{n}(\xi)=0$ at $\xi=0$ only for odd values of $n$.

\section{3}

A long string of linear density (mass per unit length) $\mu$ is under tension $T$. A point mass $m$ is attached at a particular point of the string. A wave of angular frequency $\omega$ traveling along the string is incident from the left.

(a) Calculate what fraction of the incident energy is reflected by the mass $m$.

(b) Suppose that the point mass $m$ is replaced by a string of linear density $\mu_{m} \gg \mu$ and short length $l$ such that $l=m / \mu_{m}$. For what range of $l$ values (for fixed $m$ ) does the answer for (a) remain approximately correct?

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

Divide the space into two regions with separation at the location of $m$, which is taken to be the origin of the $x$-axis, as shown in Fig. 1.213. In 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-395.jpg?height=163&width=497&top_left_y=228&top_left_x=557)

Fig. 1.213.

region 1 , let the wave function be

$$
y^{(1)}=e^{i k x}+A e^{-i k x},
$$

where $k=\omega / v, v=\sqrt{T / \mu}$ being the velocity of the wave (Problem 1225), and the second term of the right-hand side represents the reflected wave. In region 2 we have

$$
y^{(2)}=B e^{i k x} .
$$

At $x=0$, where the mass $m$ is located, we require that

$$
y^{(1)}=y^{(2)}
$$

i.e.

$$
1+A=B \text {. }
$$

Furthermore, considering the forces on the point mass $m$ we have

$$
m \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=T \frac{\partial y^{(2)}}{\partial x}-T \frac{\partial y^{(1)}}{\partial x},
$$

where for $y$ we can use either $y^{(1)}$ or $y^{(2)}$. Then

$$
-m \omega^{2} B=i k T(B-1+A) .
$$

Solving (1) and (2) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
A &=\frac{-m \omega^{2}}{2 i k T+m \omega^{2}}, \\
B &=\frac{2 i k T}{2 i k T+m \omega^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the fraction of the incident energy that is reflected is

$$
|A|^{2}=\frac{m^{2} \omega^{4}}{4 k^{2} T^{2}+m^{2} \omega^{4}} .
$$

(b) The calculation in (a) still applies provided $l \ll \lambda$, where $\lambda$ is the wavelength, being

$$
\frac{2 \pi}{k}=\frac{2 \pi v}{\omega}=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}} .
$$

Hence the condition that the answer to (a) remains approximately correct is

$$
l \ll \frac{2 \pi}{\omega} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}} .
$$

1234

A perfectly flexible string with uniform linear mass density $\rho$ and length $L$ is hanging from a fixed support with its bottom end free, as shown in Fig. 1.214.

(a) Derive the partial differential equation describing small transverse (in one plane) oscillations of the string, and from it, the differential equation for the form of the normal modes.

(b) Solve this differential equation using standard (power series) methods (the trick for transforming it into Bessel's equation is not what is wanted), and, using approximate numerical methods, solve for the frequency of the lowest normal mode.

(Princeton $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-396.jpg?height=304&width=186&top_left_y=1302&top_left_x=640)

Fig. $1.214$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinate frame $O x y z$ as shown in Fig. 1.214. following the procedure of Problem 1232, we have, by Newton's second law, for a section $\Delta x$ of the string 

$$
\rho \Delta x \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=\left(T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-\left(T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right)_{x}
$$

or

$$
\rho \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right) .
$$

The tension $T$ in the string at $x$ is related to the gravity by

$$
T=\int_{x}^{L} \rho g d x=\rho g(L-x),
$$

so the above equation becomes

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=g \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[(L-x) \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\right] \text {. }
$$

This is the partial differential equation for small transverse oscillations of the string. Applying the method of separation of variables by putting

$$
y(x, t)=\xi(x) \tau(t),
$$

we obtain

$$
\frac{1}{g \tau} \frac{d^{2} \tau}{d t^{2}}=\frac{1}{\xi} \frac{d}{d x}\left[(L-x) \frac{d \xi}{d x}\right] .
$$

As the left-hand side depends on $t$ alone and the right-hand side depends on $x$ alone, each must be equal to a constant, say $-\lambda, \lambda$ being a positive number. We thus have the equivalent ordinary differential equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{d x}\left[(L-x) \frac{d \xi}{d x}\right]+\lambda \xi &=0, \\
\frac{d^{2} \tau}{d t^{2}}+\lambda g \tau &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The boundary conditions are

$$
y(0, t)=0, \quad y(L, t)=\text { finite },
$$

i.e.

$$
\xi(0)=0, \quad \xi(L)=\text { finite } .
$$

(b) The $\xi$-equation can be written as

$$
(x-L) \xi^{\prime \prime}+\xi^{\prime}-\lambda \xi=0 \text {. }
$$

As $x=L$ is a regular singular point, the equation has a solution of the form

$$
\xi=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{n}(x-L)^{n}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi^{\prime} &=\sum_{1}^{\infty} n a_{n}(x-L)^{n-1}=\sum_{0}^{\infty}(n+1) a_{n+1}(x-L)^{n}, \\
\xi^{\prime \prime} &=\sum_{1}^{\infty} n(n+1) a_{n+1}(x-L)^{n-1}=\sum_{2}^{\infty}(n-1) n a_{n}(x-L)^{n-2}, \\
(x-L) \xi^{\prime \prime} &=\sum_{2}^{\infty}(n-1) n a_{n}(x-L)^{n-1}=\sum_{1}^{\infty} n(n+1) a_{n+1}(x-L)^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the $\xi$-equation becomes

$$
\left(a_{1}-\lambda a_{0}\right)+\sum_{1}^{\infty}\left[(n+1)^{2} a_{n+1}-\lambda a_{n}\right](x-L)^{n}=0 .
$$

Equating the coefficients of $(x-L)^{n}$ on both sides of the equation, we find

$$
a_{1}=\lambda a_{0}, \quad a_{n+1}=\frac{\lambda}{(n+1)^{2}} a_{n} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{2} &=\frac{\lambda}{2^{2}} a_{1}=\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2^{2}} a_{0} \\
a_{3} &=\frac{\lambda}{3^{2}} a_{2}=\frac{\lambda^{3}}{(3 \cdot 2)^{2}} a_{0}, \\
& \cdots \cdots \\
a_{n} &=\frac{\lambda^{n}}{(n !)^{2}} a_{0} \\
& \cdots \cdots,
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\xi(x)=a_{0} \sum_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\lambda^{n}}{(n !)^{2}}(x-L)^{n} .
$$

The boundary condition $\xi(0)=0$ then yields

$$
f(\lambda L)=\sum_{0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}(\lambda L)^{n}}{(n !)^{2}}=1-\lambda L+\frac{1}{4} \lambda^{2} L^{2}-\ldots=0 .
$$

This equation can be solved to find the roots $\lambda L$, which then give the frequencies of the various modes, $\sqrt{\lambda g} / 2 \pi$, according to the $\tau$-equation.

For an approximate solution we retain only the terms up to $n=2$ in $f(\lambda L)$

$$
f(\lambda L) \approx 1-\lambda L+\frac{1}{4}(\lambda L)^{2},
$$

Newton's approximate method gives a better approximate root of $f(\lambda L)=$ $0, \alpha_{k+1}$, if we input an approximate $\operatorname{root} \alpha_{k}$ by calculating

$$
\alpha_{k+1}=\alpha_{k}-\frac{f\left(\alpha_{k}\right)}{f^{\prime}\left(\alpha_{k}\right)} .
$$

As

$$
f^{\prime}(\lambda L) \approx-1+\frac{1}{2} \lambda L,
$$

if we take $\alpha_{1}=0$, then

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\alpha_{2}=1, & f\left(\alpha_{2}\right) \approx 0.25 \\
\alpha_{3}=1-\frac{0.25}{-0.5}=1.5, & f\left(\alpha_{3}\right) \approx 0.625
\end{array}
$$

As $f\left(\alpha_{3}\right)$ is quite close to zero we can consider $\alpha_{3}=1.5$ as the smallest positive root. Thus

$$
\lambda_{\min }=\frac{1.5}{L} .
$$

for the lowest mode. Then for this mode

$$
\tau=A \cos (\sqrt{\lambda g} t)+B \sin (\sqrt{\lambda g} t)
$$

and the frequency is

$$
\nu_{\min } \approx \frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 L}} .
$$



\section{5}

A common lecture demonstration is as follows: hold or clamp a onemeter long thin aluminium bar at the center, strike one end longitudinally (i.e. parallel to the axis of the bar) with a hammer, and the result is a sound wave of frequency $2500 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

(a) From this experiment, calculate the speed of sound in air.

(b) From this experiment, calculate the speed of sound in aluminium.

(c) Where might you hold the bar to excite a frequency of $3750 \mathrm{~Hz}$ ? Explain. Does it matter which end of the bar is struck? Explain.

(d) Suppose you hold the bar at the center as before, but strike the bar transverse to its length, rather longitudinally. Qualitatively explain why the resultant sound wave is of lower frequency than before.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The point where the bar is struck is an antinode and the point where it is held a node. With the bar held at the center and its one end struck, the wavelength $\lambda$ is related to its length $L$ by $\lambda=2 L$. Hence the speed of sound propagation in the aluminium bar is

$$
v_{\mathrm{Al}}=\nu \lambda=2 \nu L=2 \times 2500 \times 1=5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The speed of sound in a solid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{Y}{\rho}},
$$

where $Y$ is the Young's modulus of its material and $\rho$ its density. The speed of sound in a fluid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{M}{\rho}}
$$

where $M$ is its bulk modulus and $\rho$ its density. For adiabatic compression of a gas, $M=\gamma p$, where $p$ is its pressure and $\gamma$ the ratio of its principal specific heats; $\gamma=1.4$ for air, a diatomic gas. Hence

$$
\frac{v_{\text {air }}}{v_{\mathrm{Al}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.4 p \rho_{\mathrm{Al}}}{Y \rho_{\mathrm{air}}}} .
$$

With

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=1.013 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \quad(\text { standard atmosphere) }\\
Y &=7.05 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\
\rho_{\mathrm{Al}} &=2.7 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\
\rho_{\text {air }} &=1.165 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \quad\left(\text { at } 30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\
v_{\text {air }} &=6.83 \times 10^{-2} \times 5000=341 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) $v_{\mathrm{Al}}=5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

(c) Suppose the bar is held at distance $x$ from the struck end. We have

$$
x=\frac{\lambda}{4}=\frac{v}{4 \nu}=\frac{5000}{4 \times 3750}=\frac{1}{3} m .
$$

Hence the bar is to be held at $\frac{1}{3} m$ from the struck end. If it is so held but struck at the other end, we would have

$$
\frac{2}{3}=\frac{v}{4 \nu}
$$

and the frequency would become $1875 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

(d) If the bar is struck transversely, the wave generated will be transverse, not compressional, and the velocity of propagation is then given by

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{N}{\rho}},
$$

where $N$ is the shear modulus. As the shear modulus of a solid is generally smaller than its bulk modulus, $v$ is now smaller. And as

$$
\nu=\frac{v}{2 L}
$$

the frequency generated is lower.

$$
1236
$$

(a) A violin string of length $L$ with linear density $\mu \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}$ and tension $T$ newtons undergoes small oscillations (Fig. 1.215 (a)). Write the solutions for the fundamental and first harmonic, and sketch their $x$-dependences. Give the angular frequency $\omega_{1}$ of the fundamental and $\omega_{2}$ of the first harmonic.

(b) The left-hand $1 / 3$ of the string is wrapped so as to increase its linear density to $4 \mu \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}$ (Fig. $1.215$ (b)). Repeat part (a), i.e. derive and sketch the new fundamental and first harmonic, and express the new $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ in terms of the original $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ of part (a).

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-402.jpg?height=340&width=504&top_left_y=570&top_left_x=231)

Fig. 1.215.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-402.jpg?height=137&width=402&top_left_y=606&top_left_x=824)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-402.jpg?height=118&width=400&top_left_y=773&top_left_x=825)

Fig. 1.216.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 1.215 (a). The equation of motion for the string is (Problem 1225)

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\mu}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0,
$$

from which it is seen that the wave propagating along the string has velocity $v=\sqrt{T / \mu}$. As the two ends of the string are fixed the fundamental mode (Fig. $1.216$ (a)) has wavelength $\lambda_{1}$ given by

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} \lambda_{1} .
$$

Hence the fundamental angular frequency is

$$
\omega_{1}=\frac{2 \pi v}{\lambda_{1}}=\frac{\pi}{L} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}} .
$$

The solution for the fundamental mode is

$$
y_{1}=A_{1} \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{L}\right) \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right),
$$

where $A_{1}, \varphi_{1}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions. The wavelength for the first harmonic (Fig. $1.216(\mathrm{~b})$ ) is $\lambda_{2}=L$. Hence for the first harmonic the angular frequency is

$$
\omega_{2}=\frac{2 \pi v}{\lambda_{2}}=\frac{2 \pi}{L} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}
$$

and the solution is

$$
y_{2}=A_{2} \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi x}{L}\right) \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right),
$$

where $A_{2}, \varphi_{2}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions.

(b) The equations of motion for the two sections are

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{4 \mu}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0, & 0 \leq x \leq \frac{L}{3}, \\
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\mu}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0, & \frac{L}{3} \leq x \leq L
\end{array}
$$

The boundary conditions are that for all $t, y=0$ at $x=0, L$, and $y$ and $\partial y / \partial x$ are continuous at $x=L / 3$. Thus the solutions of the equations of motion are

$$
y(x, t)= \begin{cases}\left(A_{1} \cos \omega t+B_{1} \sin \omega t\right) \sin \left(\frac{\omega}{v_{1}} x\right), & 0 \leq x \leq \frac{L}{3}, \\ \left(A_{2} \cos \omega t+B_{2} \sin \omega t\right) \sin \left[\frac{\omega}{v_{2}}(L-x)\right], & \frac{L}{3} \leq x \leq L\end{cases}
$$

with

$$
v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{T}{4 \mu}}, \quad v_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}=2 v_{1}
$$

and 

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(A_{1} \cos \omega t+B_{1} \sin \omega t\right) \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \\
=\left(A_{2} \cos \omega t+B_{2} \sin \omega t\right) \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \\
\frac{\omega}{v_{1}}\left(A_{1} \cos \omega t+B_{1} \sin \omega t\right) \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \\
=-\frac{\omega}{2 v_{1}}\left(A_{2} \cos \omega t+B_{2} \sin \omega t\right) \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

Equating separately the coefficients of $\cos \omega t$ and $\sin \omega t$ on the two sides of the last two equations gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
&A_{1} \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)-A_{2} \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)=0, \\
&A_{1} \frac{\omega}{v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)+A_{2} \frac{\omega}{2 v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)=0, \\
&B_{1} \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)-B_{2} \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)=0, \\
&B_{1} \frac{\omega}{v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)+B_{2} \frac{\omega}{2 v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $A_{1}, A_{2}, B_{1}, B_{2}$ not all zero we require

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\begin{array}{rl}
\sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) & -\sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \\
\frac{\omega}{v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) & \frac{\omega}{2 v_{1}} \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)
\end{array}\right| &=\frac{3 \omega}{2 v_{1}} \sin \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \cos \left(\frac{L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right) \\
&=\frac{3 \omega}{4 v_{1}} \sin \left(\frac{2 L \omega}{3 v_{1}}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{2 L \omega}{3 v_{1}}=n \pi, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

Hence the new fundamental and first harmonic angular frequencies are 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{3 \pi v_{1}}{2 L}=\frac{3 \pi}{4 L} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}=\frac{3}{4} \omega_{1}, \\
&\omega_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{6 \pi v_{1}}{2 L}=\frac{3 \pi}{2 L} \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}=\frac{3}{2} \omega_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the fundamental frequency $\omega_{1}^{\prime}$,

$$
A_{2}=A_{1}, \quad B_{2}=B_{1} .
$$

For the first harmonic frequency $\omega_{2}^{\prime}$,

$$
A_{2}=-2 A_{1}, \quad B_{2}=-2 B_{1} .
$$

The corresponding wave forms are sketched in (a) and (b) of Fig. $1.217$ respectively.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-405.jpg?height=237&width=487&top_left_y=947&top_left_x=478)

Fig. 1.217.

\section{7}

A string of infinite length has tension $T$ and linear density $\sigma$. At $t=0$, the deformation of the string is given by the function $f(x)$, and its initial velocity distribution by $g(x)$. What is the motion of the string for $t>0$ ?

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

The deformation of the string travels as a wave following the wave equation

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{1}{v^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0
$$

with

$$
v=\pm \sqrt{\frac{T}{\sigma}} .
$$

The general solution is a sum of waves traveling in the $-x$ and $+x$ directions:

$$
y=f_{1}(x+v t)+f_{2}(x-v t) .
$$

The initial conditions give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x)=f(x) \\
&f_{1}^{\prime}(x)-f_{2}^{\prime}(x)=\frac{g(x)}{v}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
f_{1}^{\prime}(x)=\left(\frac{\partial f_{1}(\xi)}{\partial \xi}\right)_{t=0}, \quad f_{2}^{\prime}(x)=\left(\frac{\partial f_{2}(\xi)}{\partial \xi}\right)_{t=0}
$$

with $\xi=x+v t, \xi=x-v t$ respectively. Integrating (2) gives

$$
f_{1}(x)-f_{2}(x)=\frac{1}{v} \int^{x} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}+C,
$$

$C$ being an arbitrary constant. Combining Eqs. (1) and (3) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{1}(x) &=\frac{1}{2}\left[f(x)+\frac{1}{v} \int^{x} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}+C\right] \\
f_{2}(x) &=\frac{1}{2}\left[f(x)-\frac{1}{v} \int^{x} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}-C\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
y(x, t)=& f_{1}(x+v t)+f_{2}(x-v t) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}\left\{\left[f(x+v t)+\frac{1}{v} \int^{x+v t} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}+C\right]\right.\\
&\left.+\left[f(x-v t)-\frac{1}{v} \int^{x-v t} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}-C\right]\right\} \\
=& \frac{1}{2}\left[f(x+v t)+f(x-v t)+\frac{1}{v} \int_{x-v t}^{x+v t} g\left(x^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{8}

A long wave packet with amplitude $A$ composed predominantly of frequencies very near $\omega_{0}$ propagates on an infinitely long string of linear mass density $\mu$ stretched with a tension $T$ as shown in Fig. 1.218. The packet encounters a bead of mass $m$ attached to the string as shown in the sketch.

(a) What is the amplitude of the transmitted wave packet?

(b) In the limit of large $m$ and high frequency (large $\omega_{0}$ ), how does the amplitude of the transmitted wave depend on $\omega_{0}$ ?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-407.jpg?height=182&width=384&top_left_y=768&top_left_x=477)

Fig. 1.218.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The equation of motion for the string for small transverse oscillations is a wave equation (Problem 1225)

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\mu}{T} \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=0,
$$

the velocity of wave propagation being $v=\pm \sqrt{T / \mu}$. For waves of angular frequency $\omega$, define wave number

$$
k=\frac{\omega}{v}=\omega \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{T}} .
$$

For waves with angular frequencies very nearly $\omega_{0}$, the wave equation has solutions

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
y_{1}=A e^{i\left(k x-\omega_{0} t\right)}+B e^{-i\left(k x-\omega_{0} t\right)} & \text { for } x<0, \\
y_{2}=C e^{i\left(k x-\omega_{0} t\right)} & \text { for } x>0,
\end{array}
$$

where $A, B, C$ are the amplitudes of the incident, reflected and transmitted waves respectively, and the position of the bead is taken to be the origin of the $x$-axis. The continuity of the displacement at the boundary requires $y_{1}=y_{2}$ at $x=0$ for all $t$, i.e.

$$
A+B=C .
$$

The equation of the motion of the bead is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m\left(\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}\right)_{x=0} &=-T \sin \theta_{1}+T \sin \theta_{2} \\
& \approx-T \theta_{1}+T \theta_{2} \\
& \approx-T\left(\frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x}\right)_{x=0}+T\left(\frac{\partial y_{2}}{\partial x}\right)_{x=0},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ are the angles the string makes with the $x$-axis for $x<0$ and $x>0$ respectively as shown in Fig. 1.219. Thus

$$
-m \omega_{0}^{2} C=-i k T(A-B)+i k T C,
$$

or

$$
A-B=\left(1+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{i k T}\right) C
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-408.jpg?height=287&width=340&top_left_y=1343&top_left_x=623)

Fig. 1.219.

As $A+B=C$ we have

$$
C=\frac{2 A}{\left(2+\frac{m w_{0}^{2}}{i k T}\right)},
$$

and the amplitude of the transmitted wave is

$$
|C|=\sqrt{C^{*} C}=\frac{2 A}{\sqrt{4+\frac{m^{2} \omega_{0}^{4}}{k^{2} T^{2}}}}=\frac{2 A}{\sqrt{4+\frac{m^{2} \omega_{0}^{4}}{\mu T}}} .
$$

(b) In the limit of large $m$ and large $\omega_{0}$ we have

$$
|C| \approx \frac{2 A}{m \omega_{0}} \sqrt{\mu T} \propto \frac{1}{\omega_{0}} .
$$

1239

A uniform string has length $L$ and mass per unit length $\rho$. It undergoes small transverse vibration in the $(x, y)$ plane with its endpoints held fixed at $(0,0)$ and $(L, 0)$ respectively. The tension is $K$. A velocity-dependent frictional force is present: if a small piece of length $\delta l$ has transverse velocity $v$ the frictional force is $-k v \delta l$. Using appropriate approximations, the following equations hold for the vibration amplitude $y(x, t)$ :
(i) $\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}+a \frac{\partial y}{\partial t}=b \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}$,
(ii) $y(0, t)=0=y(L, t)$.

(a) Find the constants $a$ and $b$ in (i). If you cannot do this part, take $a$ and $b$ as given positive constants and go on.

(b) Find all solutions of (i) and (ii) which have the product form $y=$ $X(x) T(t)$. You may assume $a^{2}<b / L^{2}$.

(c) Suppose $y(x, 0)=0$,

$$
\dot{y}(x, 0)=A \sin \left(\frac{3 \pi x}{L}\right)+B \sin \left(\frac{5 \pi x}{L}\right) .
$$

Here $A$ and $B$ are constants. Find $y(x, t)$.

(d) Suppose, instead, that $a=0$ and $\dot{y}(x, 0)=0$ while

$$
y(x, 0)= \begin{cases}A x, & 0 \leq x \leq \frac{L}{2} \\ A(L-x), & \frac{L}{2} \leq x \leq L\end{cases}
$$

Find $y(x, t)$

(UC, Berkeley) 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The frictional force acting on unit length of the string is $-k v=$ $-k \partial y / \partial t$, so the transverse vibration of the string is described by

$$
\rho \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}=K \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}}-k \frac{\partial y}{\partial t},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial t^{2}}+\left(\frac{k}{\rho}\right) \frac{\partial y}{\partial t}=\left(\frac{K}{\rho}\right) \frac{\partial^{2} y}{\partial x^{2}} .
$$

Hence $a=k / \rho, b=K / \rho$. obtain

(b) Setting $y=X(x) T(t)$ and substituting it in the wave equation we

$$
\frac{T^{\prime \prime}}{T}+\frac{a T^{\prime}}{T}=\frac{b X^{\prime \prime}}{X} .
$$

As the left-hand side depends only on $t$ and the right-hand side depends only on $x$, each must be equal to a constant, say $-b \lambda^{2}$. Thus we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
X^{\prime \prime}+\lambda^{2} X &=0, \\
T^{\prime \prime}+a T^{\prime}+b \lambda^{2} T &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the boundary conditions

$$
y(0, t)=y(L, t)=0 \text {, i.e. } X(0)=X(L)=0,
$$

we obtain the solutions for the first equation

$$
X_{n}(x)=A_{n} \sin \left(\lambda_{n} x\right)=A_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right),
$$

where $A_{n}$ is a constant and $n=1,2,3, \ldots$. The second equation then becomes

$$
T^{\prime \prime}+a T^{\prime}+b\left(\frac{n \pi}{L}\right)^{2} T=0 .
$$

Letting $T(t)=e^{p t}$ we obtain the characteristic equation

$$
p^{2}+a p+\frac{n^{2} \pi^{2} b}{L^{2}}=0
$$

whose solutions are

$$
p_{\pm}=\frac{-a \pm \sqrt{a^{2}-4 n^{2} \pi^{2} b / L^{2}}}{2}=-\frac{a}{2} \pm i \omega_{n}
$$

where

$$
\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{n^{2} \pi^{2} b}{L^{2}}-\frac{a^{2}}{4}}
$$

is real as $b / L^{2}>a^{2}$. Hence the solution of the second equation can be written as

$$
T_{n}=\left[C_{n}^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{n} t\right)+D_{n}^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{n} t\right)\right] e^{-\frac{a t}{2}}
$$

and thus

$$
y_{n}=\sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right)\left[C_{n} \sin \left(\omega_{n} t\right)+D_{n} \cos \left(\omega_{n} t\right)\right] e^{-\frac{a t}{2}}
$$

grouping the constants in each term into one. The general solution of the wave equation is thus

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} y_{n}(x, t) .
$$

(c) As $y(x, 0)=0, D_{n}=0$ for all $n$ and we have

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} C_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right) \sin \left(\omega_{n} t\right) e^{-\frac{a t}{2}} .
$$

and

$$
\dot{y}(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} C_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right)\left[\omega_{n} \cos \left(\omega_{n} t\right)-\frac{a}{2} \sin \left(\omega_{n} t\right)\right] e^{-\frac{a t}{2}}
$$

Then as

$$
\dot{y}(x, 0)=A \sin \left(\frac{3 \pi x}{L}\right)+B \sin \left(\frac{5 \pi x}{L}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} C_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right) \omega_{n},
$$

we have

$$
C_{3}=\frac{A}{\omega_{3}}, \quad C_{5}=\frac{B}{\omega_{5}}
$$

and all other $C_{n}=0$. Hence

$$
y(x, t)=\left[\frac{A}{\omega_{3}} \sin \left(\frac{3 \pi x}{L}\right) \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+\frac{B}{\omega_{5}} \sin \left(\frac{5 \pi x}{L}\right) \sin \left(\omega_{5} t\right)\right] e^{-\frac{a t}{2}}
$$

with

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{9 \pi^{2} b}{L^{2}}-\frac{a^{2}}{4}}, \quad \omega_{5}=\sqrt{\frac{25 \pi^{2} b}{L^{2}}-\frac{a^{2}}{4}} .
$$

(d) Starting with the general solution

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right)\left[C_{n} \sin \left(\omega_{n} t\right)+D_{n} \cos \left(\omega_{n} t\right)\right] e^{-\frac{a t}{2}},
$$

we find $C_{n}=0$ for all $n$ as $\dot{y}(x, 0)=0$. Then

$$
y(x, 0)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} D_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right)= \begin{cases}A x, & 0 \leq x \leq L / 2 \\ A(L-x), & L / 2 \leq x \leq L\end{cases}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{L} y(x, 0) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{L}\right) d x &=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{L} D_{n} \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{L}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{L D_{m}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{m} &=\frac{2}{L} \int_{0}^{L} y(x, 0) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{L}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{2}{L} \int_{0}^{L / 2} A x \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{L}\right) d x+\frac{2}{L} \int_{L / 2}^{L} A(L-x) \sin \left(\frac{m \pi x}{L}\right) d x \\
&=\frac{4 A L}{m^{2}} \frac{2}{\pi^{2}} \sin \left(\frac{m \pi}{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that we have used the formula

$$
\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin (m x) \sin (n x) d x=\frac{\pi}{2} \delta_{m n}
$$

in the above. Finally we have

$$
y(x, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(\frac{4 A L}{n^{2} \pi^{2}}\right) \sin \left(\frac{n \pi}{2}\right) \sin \left(\frac{n \pi x}{L}\right) \cos \left(\omega_{n} t\right),
$$

where

$$
\omega_{n}=\frac{n \pi}{L} \sqrt{b}
$$

as $a=0$. (a) Plot the pressure and air displacement diagrams along a pipe closed at one end for the second mode.

(b) What is the frequency of this mode relative to the fundamental?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-413.jpg?height=386&width=568&top_left_y=505&top_left_x=327)

Fig. 1.220.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The pressure and air displacement as functions of distance from the closed end are sketched in Fig. 1.220.

(b) For this mode, $L=3 \lambda / 4$, while for the fundamental mode, $L=\lambda / 4$. Hence if $\omega_{0}$ is the fundamental frequency, the frequency of this mode is $3 \omega_{0}$.

\section{1}

An organ pipe of length $l$ open on both ends is used in a subsonic wind tunnel to measure the Mach number $v / c$ of air in the tunnel as shown in Fig. 1.221. The pipe when fixed in the tunnel is observed to resonate with a fundamental period $t$. If $v / c=1 / 2$, calculate the ratio of periods $t / t_{0}$ where $t_{0}$ is the fundamental period of the pipe in still air.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

As the organ pipe is open at both ends, the fundamental wavelength of sound in resonance with it is given by $\lambda / 2=l$. The corresponding period is 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-414.jpg?height=135&width=353&top_left_y=234&top_left_x=542)

Fig. 1.221.

$$
t=\frac{\lambda}{v}=\frac{2 l}{v} \text {, }
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of sound relative to the pipe.

When the air in the pipe is still, $v$ is equal to the velocity of sound in still air, $c$, and the fundamental period is

$$
t_{0}=\frac{2 l}{c} .
$$

When the air in the pipe moves with velocity $c / 2$, the pipe can be considered to move with velocity $-c / 2$ in still air. Thus $v=c-(-c / 2)=$ $3 \mathrm{c} / 2$ and the period is

$$
t=\frac{2 l}{\frac{3 c}{2}}=\frac{4 l}{3 c} .
$$

Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{t}{t_{0}}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

\section{2}

The speed of sound in a gas is calculated as

$$
V=\sqrt{\frac{\text { adiabatic bulk modulus }}{\text { density }}} .
$$

(a) Show that this is a dimensionally-correct equation.

(b) This formula implies that the propagation of sound through air is a quasistatic process. On the other hand, the speed for air is about $340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$ at a temperature for which the rms speed of an air molecule is about $500 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$. How then can the process be quasistatic? 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The dimensions of the bulk modulus are the same as those of pressure while the adiabatic factor is dimensionless. Thus dimensionally

$$
\frac{\text { adiabatic bulk modulus }}{\text { density }} \sim \frac{\mathrm{g} / \mathrm{cm} \cdot \mathrm{s}^{2}}{\mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}}=\mathrm{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{s}^{2},
$$

which are the dimensions of $v^{2}$. Hence the formula is dimensionally correct.

(b) Consider for example sound of frequency $1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$. Its wavelength is about $0.34 \mathrm{~m}$. Although the $\mathrm{rms}$ speed of an air molecule is large, its collision mean free path is only of the order of $10^{-5} \mathrm{~cm}$, much smaller than the wavelength of sound. So the motion of the air molecules does not affect sound propagation through air, which is still adiabatic and quasistatic.

\section{3}

A vertical cylindrical pipe, open at the top, can be partially filled with water. Successive resonances of the column with a $512 \mathrm{sec}^{-1}$ tuning fork are observed when the distance from the water surface to the top of the pipe is $15.95 \mathrm{~cm}, 48.45 \mathrm{~cm}$, and $80.95 \mathrm{~cm}$.

(a) Calculate the speed of sound in air.

(b) Locate precisely the antinode near the top of the pipe.

(c) The above measurements are presented to you by a team of sophomore lab students. How would you criticize their work?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-415.jpg?height=431&width=623&top_left_y=1383&top_left_x=558)

Fig. 1.222. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The wave forms of the successive resonances in the air column are shown in Fig. 1.222. It is seen that for successive resonances, the air columns differ in height by half a wavelength: $d=\lambda / 2$. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&d=48.45-15.95=80.95-48.45=32.50 \mathrm{~cm}, \\
&\lambda=2 d=65.00 \mathrm{~cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The velocity in air is then

$$
v=\lambda \nu=0.6500 \times 512=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
$$

(b) As $\lambda / 4=16.25 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $16.25 \mathrm{~cm}-15.95 \mathrm{~cm}=0.30 \mathrm{~cm}$, the uppermost antinode is located at $0.30 \mathrm{~cm}$ above the top of the pipe.

(c) This method of measuring sound velocity in air is rather inaccurate as the human ear is not sensitive enough to detect precisely small variations in the intensity of sound, and the accuracy of measurement is rather limited. Still, the data obtained are consistent and give a good result. The students ought to be commended for their careful work.

\section{4}

Two media have a planar, impermeable interface as shown in Fig. 1.223. Plane acoustic waves of pressure amplitude $A$ and frequency $f$ are generated in medium (1), directed toward medium (2). Take $A$ and $f$ as given quantities and assume the wave propagation is normal to the interface. Medium (1) has density $\rho_{1}$ and sound velocity $c_{1}$, while medium (2) has density $\rho_{2}$ and sound velocity $c_{2}$.

(a) What are the appropriate boundary conditions at the interface?

(b) Apply these boundary conditions to derive the pressure amplitude $A_{r}$ of the wave reflected back into medium (1) and the pressure amplitude $B$ of the wave transmitted into medium (2).

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The boundary conditions at the interface are

(i) the pressure is continuous, 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-417.jpg?height=328&width=419&top_left_y=220&top_left_x=493)

Fig. 1.223.

(ii) the component of the rate of fluid displacement perpendicular to the interface is continuous, otherwise the interface would be permeable.

(b) Take the $z$-axis perpendicular to the interface with the origin on the interface and let the pressure be

$$
\begin{aligned}
A e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{1} z\right)} & \text { for the incident wave, } \\
A_{r} e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{1} z\right)} & \text { for the reflected wave } \\
B e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{2} z\right)} & \text { for the transmitted wave }
\end{aligned}
$$

with $k_{j}=\omega / c_{j}, c_{j}$ being the velocity of sound in the $j$ th medium. The boundary condition (i) gives

$$
A+A_{r}=B .
$$

The velocity of sound in a fluid is given by

$$
c=\sqrt{\frac{M}{\rho}},
$$

where $M=-p(\Delta v / v)^{-1}$ is the bulk modulus, $\Delta v$ being the change of the original volume $v$ by an excess pressure $p$. For a compressional wave, $\Delta v$ is solely longitudinal so that

$$
\frac{\Delta v}{v} \approx \frac{\Delta \xi}{\Delta z} \approx \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial z},
$$

where $\xi$ is the displacement of fluid layers from their equilibrium positions. Thus

$$
p=-\rho c^{2} \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial z}
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial z}=\frac{-p}{\rho c^{2}} \sim-\frac{e^{i(\omega t \mp k z)}}{\rho c^{2}}
$$

Integrating we have

$$
\xi \sim \pm \frac{e^{i(\omega t \mp k z)}}{i k \rho c^{2}} .
$$

For the three waves we have respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi_{A} &=\frac{1}{\rho_{1} c_{1}^{2}}\left(\frac{A}{i k_{1}}\right) e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{1} z\right)} \\
\xi_{A_{r}} &=\frac{-1}{\rho_{1} c_{1}^{2}}\left(\frac{A_{r}}{i k_{1}}\right) e^{i\left(\omega t+k_{1} z\right)} \\
\xi_{B} &=\frac{1}{\rho_{2} c_{2}^{2}}\left(\frac{B}{i k_{2}}\right) e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{2} z\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\xi}_{A} &=\frac{A}{\rho_{1} c_{1}} e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{1} z\right)}, \\
\dot{\xi}_{A_{r}} &=\frac{-A_{r}}{\rho_{1} c_{1}} e^{i\left(\omega t+k_{1} z\right)}, \\
\dot{\xi}_{B} &=\frac{B}{\rho_{2} c_{2}} e^{i\left(\omega t-k_{2} z\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The boundary condition(ii) states that at $z=0$,

$$
\dot{\xi}_{A}+\dot{\xi}_{A_{r}}=\dot{\xi}_{B},
$$

or

$$
\frac{A}{\rho_{1} c_{1}}-\frac{A_{r}}{\rho_{1} c_{1}}=\frac{B}{\rho_{2} c_{2}} \text {. }
$$

Combining Eqs. (1) and (2) we obtain the amplitudes of the reflected and transmitted pressure waves:

$$
\begin{aligned}
A_{r} &=A \frac{\rho_{2} c_{2}-\rho_{1} c_{1}}{\rho_{1} c_{1}+\rho_{2} c_{2}} \\
B &=\frac{2 A \rho_{2} c_{2}}{\rho_{1} c_{1}+\rho_{2} c_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{5}

Let the speed of sound in air be $c$ and the velocity of a source of sound moving through the air be $v$ in the $x$-direction.

(a) For $v<c$ : a pulse of sound is emitted at the origin at time $t=0$. Sketch the relationship of the wavefront at time $t$ to the position of the sound at time $t$. Label your sketch carefully. Write an equation for the position of the wavefront as seen from the source at time $t$.

(b) For $v>c$ : a source emits a continuous signal. Sketch the wavefront set up by the moving source. Indicate on your sketch the construction which leads to your result. Write an equation relating the shape of the wavefront to other known factors in the problem.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-419.jpg?height=386&width=479&top_left_y=881&top_left_x=545)

Fig. $1.224$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $S$ be the position of the source at time $t$. Take coordinate frames $O x y, S x^{\prime} y^{\prime}$ with origins at $O$ and $S$, the $x$-, $x^{\prime}$-axes along $O S$, and the $y^{-}$, $y^{\prime}$-axes parallel to each other as shown in Fig. 1.224. We have

$$
x^{\prime}=x-v t, \quad y^{\prime}=y .
$$

The wavefront at time $t$ is given by $x=c t \cos \varphi, y=c t \sin \varphi$, with $0 \leq \varphi \leq$ $2 \pi$. Then the wavefront as seen from the source is given by $x^{\prime}=c t \cos \varphi-v t$, $y^{\prime}=c t \sin \varphi$

(b) Suppose the source moves from point $O$ to point $S$ in the time interval $t=0$ to $t=t$ and consider the signals emitted at $t=0$ and intermediate instants $t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots$, when the source is at $S_{1}, S_{2}, \ldots$, with $O S_{1}=v t_{1}, O S_{2}=v t_{2}, \ldots$. Each signal will propagate from the point of emission as a spherical wave. At time $t$, the wavefronts of the signals emitted at $O, S_{2}, S_{2}, \ldots$ will have radii $c t, c\left(t-t_{1}\right), c\left(t-t_{2}\right), \ldots$, respectively. As

$$
\frac{c t}{v t}=\frac{c\left(t-t_{1}\right)}{v\left(t-t_{1}\right)}=\frac{c\left(t-t_{2}\right)}{v\left(t-t_{2}\right)}=\ldots,
$$

all these wavefronts will be enveloped by a cone with vertex at $S$ of semivertex angle $\theta$ given by

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{c t}{v t}=\frac{c}{v},
$$

as shown in Fig, 1.225. Hence the resultant wavefront of the continuous signal is a cone of semi-vertex angle $\arcsin (c / v)$ with the vertex at the moving source.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-420.jpg?height=428&width=715&top_left_y=951&top_left_x=357)

Fig. $1.225$.

\section{6}

The velocity of sound in the atmosphere is $300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. An airplane is traveling with velocity $600 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ at an altitude of $8000 \mathrm{~m}$ over an observer as shown in Fig. 1.226. How far past the observer will the plane be when he hears the sonic boom? 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-421.jpg?height=298&width=519&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=142)

Fig. 1.226.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-421.jpg?height=285&width=516&top_left_y=257&top_left_x=711)

Fig. 1.227.

\section{Solution:}

As the velocity $v$ of the source $S$ is greater than the velocity $c$ of sound propagation, the wavefront is a cone with vertex at the moving source (Problem 1245). The observer at $A$ will hear the sonic boom, which was emitted when the source was at $O$, when the cone sweeps past him, as shown in Fig. 1.227. The source is now at $S$. Let $A^{\prime}$ be a point on the path of the source directly above $A$. We have

$$
O A \perp A S, \quad O A=c t, \quad O S=v t,
$$

and

$$
\frac{h}{x}=\frac{c t}{A S}=\frac{c t}{\sqrt{O S^{2}-O A^{2}}}=\frac{c}{\sqrt{v^{2}-c^{2}}}
$$

or

$$
x=h \sqrt{\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2}-1}=8000 \sqrt{2^{2}-1}=1.39 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~m} .
$$

This is the horizontal distance of the plane from the observer when he hears the sonic boom. Note that the semi-vertex angle of the cone is $\theta=\arcsin (c / v)$ as required.

\section{7}

It is a curious fact that one occasionally hears sound from a distant source with startling clarity when the wind is blowing from the source toward the observer.

(a) Show that this effect cannot be explained by "the wind carrying the sound along with it", i.e. a uniform wind velocity cannot account for the effect. (b) Wind blowing over the ground has a vertical velocity gradient which can be well represented near the ground by the formula $v=k y^{2}$, where $y$ is the height above the ground and $k$ is a constant which depends on the wind speed outside of the boundary layer where the parabolic velocity profile is a good approximation. For a given value of $k$ and of the speed of sound $v_{s}$, calculate the distance $s$, downwind from a sound source, where the maximum enhancement of sound intensity occurs.

HINT: You may assume that the sound rays follows low, arc-like paths which are well represented by

$$
y=h \sin \left(\frac{\pi x}{s}\right) .
$$

(c) One also notices an enhancement of the transmission of sound over a lake, even for no wind. What is happening in this case?

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The effect cannot be explained by the wind carrying the sound with it, for across the path of a uniformly moving wind, all observers would then hear the sound with equal clarity. This not being the case the effect is in fact due to refraction of sound brought about by the variation of the sound velocity, with respect to a fixed observer, at different points of the medium. This may arise from two possible causes, temperature gradient or velocity gradient in the moving wind. The velocity of compressional waves in a gas varies with temperature $T$ as $\sqrt{T}$. It also varies if the velocity of the medium itself varies. Refraction of sound changes the direction of its wavefront. Near the surface of the earth, both gradients may be present and the path of sound can bend in different ways, making it possible for a distant observer to hear it with startling clarity.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-422.jpg?height=299&width=544&top_left_y=1544&top_left_x=579)

Fig. 1.228. (b) Take coordinate axes as shown in Fig. 1.228. It is assumed that the wind velocity near ground is horizontal with a vertical gradient, i.e.

$$
v=v_{x}=k y^{2},
$$

so the medium can be considered as consisting of horizontal layers with different sound velocities. The law of refraction is

$$
\frac{\sin \theta}{V}=\text { constant },
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle between the direction of sound propagation in the layer and the vertical, and $V$ is the velocity of sound with respect to the ground. Consider two points on the sound path with variables

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\theta_{1}=\theta, & V_{2}=v_{s}+v_{x} \sin \theta=v_{s}+v \sin \theta, \\
\theta_{2}=\theta+d \theta, & V_{2}=v_{s}+(v+d v) \sin (\theta+d \theta) .
\end{array}
$$

The law of refraction then gives

$$
\frac{v_{s}+(v+d v) \sin (\theta+d \theta)}{v_{s}+v \sin \theta}=\frac{\sin (\theta+d \theta)}{\sin \theta} .
$$

As $\sin (\theta+d \theta) \approx \sin \theta+\cos \theta d \theta$, retaining only the lowest order terms we have

$$
\frac{d v}{v_{s}}=\frac{d \sin \theta}{\sin ^{2} \theta} .
$$

Thus

$$
\int_{0}^{h} 2 k y \frac{d y}{v_{s}}=\int_{\theta_{0}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{d \sin \theta}{\sin ^{2} \theta},
$$

or

$$
\frac{k h^{2}}{v_{s}}=\frac{1}{\sin \theta_{0}}-1 .
$$

On the other hand the given sound path yields

$$
\cot \theta=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\pi h}{s} \cos \frac{\pi x}{s},
$$

or

$$
\frac{1}{\sin \theta}=\sqrt{1+\cot ^{2} \theta}=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\pi h}{s}\right)^{2} \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi x}{s}},
$$

in particular,

$$
\frac{1}{\sin \theta_{0}}=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\pi h}{s}\right)^{2}} \text {. }
$$

Substituting this in the above gives the path length $s$, downwind from the sound source, where maximum enhancement of sound intensity occurs as

$$
s=\frac{\pi v_{s}}{\sqrt{k\left(2 v_{s}+k h^{2}\right)}}
$$

(c) The speed of sound in a gas varies with absolute temperature $T$ as $\sqrt{T}$. Vertically above a lake, for some range of heights, the temperature increases during daytime and establishes a vertical gradient. So does the speed of sound. Refraction of sound occurs during daytime similar to that described in (b).

\section{8}

Consider a plane standing sound wave of frequency $10^{3} \mathrm{~Hz}$ in air at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. Suppose the amplitude of the pressure variation associated with this wave is $1 \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ (compared with the ambient pressure of $10^{6} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ ). Estimate (order of magnitude) the amplitude of the displacement of the air molecules associated with this wave.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

The longitudinal displacement $\xi$ from equilibrium of a point in a plane stationary compressional wave in the $x$ direction can be expressed as

$$
\xi=\xi_{0} \sin (k x) e^{-i \omega t},
$$

with $k=n \pi / l, l$ being the thickness of the gas and $n=1,2, \ldots$. The velocity of the wave is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{M}{\rho}} .
$$

Here the bulk modulus $M$ is by definition

$$
M=-p\left(\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right)^{-1},
$$

$p$ being the excess pressure and $V$ the original volume. Consider a cylinder of the gas of cross-sectional area $A$ and length $\Delta x$. We have

$$
\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\frac{A \Delta \xi}{A \Delta x} \approx \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=-M \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x} \\
&=-M k \xi_{0} \cos (k x) e^{-i \omega t} \\
&=-p_{0} \cos (k x) e^{-i \omega t},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{0}=M k \xi_{0}=\rho v^{2} k \xi_{0}$ is the amplitude of the excess pressure. Hence

$$
\xi_{0}=\frac{p_{0}}{\rho v^{2} k} .
$$

For the lowest mode

$$
\begin{gathered}
n=1, \quad \lambda=2 l, \\
k=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi \nu}{v},
\end{gathered}
$$

$\nu$ being the frequency of the sound wave. Thus

$$
\xi_{0}=\frac{p_{0}}{2 \pi \rho v \nu} .
$$

For an ideal gas

$$
p_{a} V=\frac{m}{M} R T,
$$

giving

$$
\rho=\frac{m}{V}=\frac{p_{a} M}{R T},
$$

where $p_{a}, T$ are the ambient pressure and temperature respectively. As $p_{0}=1 \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}=10^{-1} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}, p_{a}=10^{6} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}=10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}, M=$ $29 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{mol}, R=8.31 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mol} / \mathrm{K}, T=300 \mathrm{~K}, v=340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, $\nu=10^{3} \mathrm{~Hz}$, we find $\xi_{0}=4 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~m}$ as the amplitude of the displacement of the air molecules. 

\section{9}

An acoustical motion detector emits a $50 \mathrm{kHz}$ signal and receives the echo signal. If the echoes have Doppler shift frequency components departing from $50 \mathrm{kHz}$ by more than $100 \mathrm{~Hz}$, a "moving object" is registered. For a sound velocity in air of $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$, calculate the speed with which an object must move toward (or away from) the detector in order to be registered as a "moving object".

\section{(Wisconsin)}

\section{Solution:}

Consider a source emitting sound of frequency $\nu$. The Doppler effect has it that if an observer moves with velocity $v$ toward the source he will detect the frequency as

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c}\right) \nu,
$$

$c$ being the speed of sound propagation. On the other hand, if the source moves with velocity $v$ toward the observer, who is stationary, then

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c}{c-v}\right) \nu .
$$

Thus the object, moving toward the detector, receives a signal of frequency

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c}\right) \nu,
$$

and the signal after reflection by the object is detected by the detector as having frequency

$$
\nu^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{c}{c-v}\right) \nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \nu .
$$

For the moving object to be registered, we must have $\nu^{\prime \prime}=\nu \pm \Delta \nu$, where $\Delta \nu \geq 10^{2} \mathrm{~Hz}$. Then

$$
\nu \pm \Delta \nu=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \nu,
$$

or

$$
v=\pm \frac{c \Delta \nu}{2 \nu \pm \Delta \nu} \approx \pm \frac{c \Delta \nu}{2 \nu},
$$

as $\Delta \nu \ll \nu$. Hence the object must be moving toward or receding from the detector at 

$$
v \geq \frac{330 \times 10^{2}}{2 \times 5 \times 10^{4}}=0.330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}
$$

for it to be registered.

\section{0}

A student near a railroad track hears a train's whistle when the train is coming directly toward him and then when it is going directly away. The two observed frequencies are 250 and $200 \mathrm{~Hz}$. Assume the speed of sound in air to be $360 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. What is the train's speed?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\nu_{0}, \nu_{1}, \nu_{2}$ be respectively the frequency of the whistle emitted by the train, and the frequencies heard by the student when the train is coming and when it is moving away. The Doppler effect has it that

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\nu_{1}=\left(\frac{c}{c-v}\right) \nu_{0}, \\
&\nu_{2}=\left(\frac{c}{c+v}\right) \nu_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $c$ is the speed of sound and $v$ is the speed of the train, and thus

$$
\frac{\nu_{1}}{\nu_{2}}=\frac{c+v}{c-v} .
$$

Putting in the data, we have

$$
1.25=\frac{360+v}{360-v},
$$

or

$$
\frac{2.25}{0.25}=\frac{720}{2 v},
$$

and thus

$$
v=\frac{360}{9}=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
$$



\section{1}

The velocity of blood flow in an artery can be measured using Dopplershifted ultrasound. Suppose sound with frequency $1.5 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~Hz}$ is reflected straight back by blood flowing at $1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Assuming the velocity of sound in tissue is $1500 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and that the sound is incident at a very small angle as shown in Fig. 1.229, calculate the frequency shift between the incident and reflected waves.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-428.jpg?height=129&width=636&top_left_y=662&top_left_x=411)

Fig. 1.229.

\section{Solution:}

As the sound is incident at a very small angle, the blood can be considered to be flowing directly away. Then the results of Problem 1249 can be applied with $v$ replaced by $-v$ :

$$
\nu^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{c-v}{c+v}\right) \nu .
$$

The frequency shift is then

$$
\nu^{\prime \prime}-\nu=-\frac{2 v \nu}{c+v} \approx-\frac{2 v \nu}{c}=-2 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~Hz} .
$$

\section{2}

A car has front- and back-directed speakers mounted on its roof, and drives toward you with a speed of $50 \mathrm{ft} / \mathrm{s}$, as shown in Fig. 1.230. If the speakers are driven by a $1000 \mathrm{~Hz}$ oscillator, what beat frequency will you hear between the direct sound and the echo off a brick building behind the car? (Take the speed of sound as $1000 \mathrm{ft} / \mathrm{s}$.) 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-429.jpg?height=165&width=399&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=546)

Fig. $1.230$.

\section{Solution:}

The sound from the back-directed speaker has Doppler frequency

$$
\nu_{b}=\left(\frac{c}{c+v}\right) \nu,
$$

where $c$ and $v$ are the speeds of sound and the car respectively, and $\nu$ is the frequency of the sound emitted. As the wall is stationary with respect to the observer, $\nu_{b}$ is also the frequency as heard by the latter. The sound from the front-directed speaker has Doppler frequency

$$
\nu_{f}=\left(\frac{c}{c-v}\right) \nu .
$$

Hence the beat frequency is

$$
\nu_{f}-\nu_{b}=c \nu\left(\frac{1}{c-v}-\frac{1}{c+v}\right)=\frac{2 v c \nu}{c^{2}-v^{2}} \approx \frac{2 v \nu}{c}=100 \mathrm{~Hz}
$$

\section{3}

A physics student holds a tuning fork vibrating at $440 \mathrm{~Hz}$ and walks at $1.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ away from a wall. Does the echo from the wall have a higher or lower pitch than the tuning fork? What beat frequency does he hear between the fork and the echo? The speed of sound is $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

As the tuning fork, which emits sound of frequency $\nu$, moves away from the wall at speed $v$, the sound that is incident on the wall has frequency

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c}{c+v}\right) \nu .
$$

Then the student, who is moving away from the wall at speed $v$, hears the reflected frequency

$$
\nu^{\prime \prime}=\left(\frac{c-v}{c}\right) \nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{c-v}{c+v}\right) \nu .
$$

As

$$
\nu^{\prime \prime}-\nu=-\frac{2 v \nu}{c+v}<0 .
$$

the echo has a lower frequency. The beat frequency between the fork and the echo is

$$
\frac{2 v \nu}{c+v} \approx \frac{2 v \nu}{c}=3.2 \mathrm{~Hz} .
$$

1254

A rope is attached at one end to a wall and is wrapped around a capstan through an angle $\theta$. If someone pulls on the other end with a force $F$ as shown in Fig. 1.231(a), find the tension in the rope at a point between the wall and the capstan in terms of $F, \theta$ and $\mu_{s}$, the coefficient of friction between the rope and capstan.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-430.jpg?height=242&width=157&top_left_y=1268&top_left_x=441)

(a)

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-430.jpg?height=213&width=213&top_left_y=1268&top_left_x=929)

(b)

Fig. 1.231.

\section{Solution:}

Consider an element of the rope as shown in Fig. 1.231(b). The forces acting on the element are the tensions $T$ and $T+\Delta T$ at its two ends, the reaction $N$ exerted by the capstan, and the friction $f$. As the element is in equilibrium we have 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&f+(T+\Delta T) \cos \left(\frac{\Delta \theta}{2}\right)-T \cos \left(\frac{\Delta \theta}{2}\right)=0 \\
&N-(T+\Delta T) \sin \left(\frac{\Delta \theta}{2}\right)-T \sin \left(\frac{\Delta \theta}{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

In first-order approximation the above equations become

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
f+(T+\Delta T)-T=0, & \text { or } & f=-\Delta T \\
N-T \frac{\Delta \theta}{2}-T \frac{\Delta \theta}{2}=0, & \text { or } & N=T \Delta \theta
\end{array}
$$

Then as $f=\mu_{s} \mathrm{~N}$, we find

$$
\frac{\Delta T}{\Delta \theta}=-\mu_{s} T,
$$

or, letting $\Delta \theta \rightarrow 0$,

$$
\frac{d T}{d \theta}=-\mu_{s} T
$$

Integrating we have

$$
T=C e^{-\mu_{s} \theta} \text {, }
$$

where $C$ is a constant. As $T=F$ at $\theta=0, C=F$. Hence

$$
T=F e^{-\mu_{\alpha} \theta} .
$$

\section{5}

A uniform, very flexible rope of length $L$ and mass per unit length $\rho$ is hung from two supports, each at height $h$ above a horizontal plane, separated by a distance $2 x_{0}$, as shown in Fig. 1.232.

(a) Derive the shape of the curve assumed by the rope.

HINT: A parameter in your solution will depend on a transcendental equation, which need not be solved. However, any differential equations which you encounter should be solved.

(b) Find an expression for the tension in the rope at the supports.

Suppose the supports are now replaced by frictionless pulleys of negligible size, and a uniform rope of infinite length is hung over the two pulleys (see Fig. 1.232). There is no friction between the rope and the table. In 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-432.jpg?height=203&width=415&top_left_y=289&top_left_x=577)

Fig. $1.232$.

this case the shape of the curve assumed by the rope depends only on a dimensionless parameter $\alpha=h / x_{0}$.

(c) Assuming that the rope hangs in a smooth curve with minimum height $c$, derive a transcendental equation relating $h / c$ to $\alpha$.

(d) Find an exact solution for the shape of the rope when $\alpha \ll 1$.

(e) Relate the shape of the rope in parts (c) and (d) to the shape of a soap film stretched between two circular wires of radius $h$ and separation $2 x_{0}$ as shown in Fig. 1.233.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-432.jpg?height=289&width=436&top_left_y=1241&top_left_x=245)

Fig. $1.233$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-432.jpg?height=345&width=504&top_left_y=1203&top_left_x=853)

Fig. 1.234.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $1.234$ and let the tension in the rope be $T=T(x)$. Consider an infinitesimal element between the points $x$ and $x+d x$. Conditions for equilibrium are 

$$
\begin{gathered}
(T \cos \theta)_{x+d x}-(T \cos \theta)_{x}=0 \\
(T \sin \theta)_{x+d x}-(T \sin \theta)_{x}=\rho g \sqrt{(d x)^{2}+(d y)^{2}}=\rho g \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}} d x .
\end{gathered}
$$

The first equation gives

$$
\frac{d(T \cos \theta)}{d x}=0, \quad \text { or } \quad T \cos \theta=\text { constant }=A, \quad \text { say } .
$$

The second equation gives

$$
\frac{d(T \sin \theta)}{d x}=\rho g \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}} .
$$

As

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{d y}{d x} \equiv y^{\prime}
$$

we have

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{y^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}}, \quad \cos \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}}
$$

and the above equations become

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=A \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}, \\
A y^{\prime \prime} &=\rho g \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Writing (2) as

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}} \frac{d y^{\prime}}{d x}=\frac{\rho g}{A},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left(\sinh ^{-1} y^{\prime}\right)=\frac{\rho g}{A}
$$

and integrating, we obtain

$$
y^{\prime}=\sinh \left(\frac{\rho g x}{A}+C\right),
$$

where $C$ is a constant. As $y^{\prime}=0$ at $x=0, C=0$ and

$$
y^{\prime}=\sinh \left(\frac{\rho g x}{A}\right) \text {. }
$$

Further integrating gives

$$
y=\frac{A}{\rho g} \cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x}{A}\right)+B .
$$

With the boundary condition $y=h$ at $x=x_{0}$, we find

$$
B=h-\frac{A}{\rho g} \cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x_{0}}{A}\right) .
$$

Hence the shape of the rope is described by
