$$
y(x)=\frac{A}{\rho g}\left[\cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x}{A}\right)-\cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x_{0}}{A}\right)\right]+h
$$

with the constant $A$ yet to be determined. Consider the tensions $T\left(\pm x_{0}\right)$ at the supports $x=\pm x_{0}$. Their $y$-components satisfy

$$
2 T \sin \theta=L \rho g,
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{2 T y^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}}=L \rho g
$$

Using Eqs. (1) and (3), we can write this as

$$
2 A \sinh \left(\frac{\rho g x_{0}}{A}\right)=L \rho g,
$$

from which $A$ can be determined. The tensions in the rope at $x=\pm x_{0}$ are given by (1) to be

$$
T\left(\pm x_{0}\right)=\left.A \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}\right|_{x=x_{0}}=A \cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x_{0}}{A}\right),
$$

use having been made of Eq. (3).

(c) The tensions $T\left(\pm x_{0}\right)$ in the rope on the two sides of each pulley are equal. Hence

$$
T\left(\pm x_{0}\right)=h \rho g
$$

or, by Eq. (5),

$$
A \cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x_{0}}{A}\right)=h \rho g .
$$

Substituting this in (4) gives the equation describing the shape of the rope between the pulleys:

$$
y(x)=\frac{A}{\rho g} \cosh \left(\frac{\rho g x}{A}\right) .
$$

Let $y=c$ at $x=0$, then $c=A / \rho g$. As $y=h$ at $x=x_{0}$, we have

$$
h=c \cosh \left(\frac{x_{0}}{c}\right) \text {, }
$$

Or

$$
\frac{h}{c}=\cosh \left(\frac{h}{c \alpha}\right) \text {. }
$$

This equation determines $h / c$ as a function of $\alpha=h / x_{0}$ only. Equation (6) can be written as

$$
\frac{y}{h}=\frac{c}{h} \cosh \left(\frac{h}{c} \frac{x}{h}\right) \text {. }
$$

If we scale the coordinates by $h$, i.e.

$$
\xi=\frac{x}{h}, \quad \eta=\frac{y}{h}
$$

we have

$$
\eta=\frac{c}{h} \cosh \left(\frac{h}{c} \xi\right)
$$

This equation, which describes the shape of the curve, depends only on $h / c$, which in term depends only on $\alpha=h / x_{0}$ through Eq. (7).

(d) Physically, $c<h$, so that if $\alpha \ll 1, \cosh (h / c \alpha) \gg 1$. Then for $h$ to remain finite, we require $c \rightarrow 0$ as indicated by Eq. (7). This means that the whole rope is lying on the ground.

(e) Let $\sigma$ be the coefficient of surface tension of the soap. For equilibrium in the horizontal direction at a point $(x, y)$ on the film, we have

$$
(\sigma \cdot 2 \pi y \cos \theta)_{x+d x}-(\sigma \cdot 2 \pi y \cos \theta)_{x}=0
$$

Or

$$
\frac{d}{d x}(2 \pi \sigma y \cos \theta)=0
$$

i.e.

$$
y \cos \theta=\text { constant }
$$

Suppose $y=c$ at $x=0$, then as $\theta=0$ for $x=0$, the constant is equal to c. Furthermore, as

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{d x}{\sqrt{(d x)^{2}+(d y)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}}
$$

we have

$$
y=c \sqrt{1+y^{\prime 2}}
$$

or

$$
d x=\frac{c d u}{\sqrt{u^{2}-1}}
$$

with $u=y / c$. Integrating we have

$$
x=c \cosh ^{-1}\left(\frac{y}{c}\right)+\text { constant } .
$$

As $y=c$ at $x=0$, the constant is zero. Hence

$$
y=c \cosh \left(\frac{x}{c}\right)
$$

which is identical with Eq. (6) of part (c).

\section{6}

(a) A bounded, axially symmetric body has mass density $\rho(x, y, z)=$ $\rho(r, \theta)$. At large distances from the body its gravitational potential has the form

$$
\phi=-\frac{G M}{r}+\frac{f(\theta)}{r^{2}}+\ldots,
$$

where

$$
M=\int \rho\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}\right) d x^{\prime} d y^{\prime} d z^{\prime}=2 \pi \int \rho\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 2} \sin \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime}
$$

is the total mass. Find $f(\theta)$.

(b) A small test body has mass density $\sigma(x, y, z)$ and is placed in a gravitational potential $\phi(x, y, z)$. What is its gravitational potential energy?

(c) Suppose the body in (a) is spherically symmetric, i.e. $\rho=\rho(r)$, then $\phi=\phi(r)$. Suppose the body is made of gas and supported against its own gravity by a pressure $p(r)$. Denote its radius by $R$. Some of the following integrals correctly represent the gravitational potential energy of the body, others are incorrect by simple numerical factors (positive or negative). Identify the correct ones and find the missing factors for the others. That is, if $U=$ potential energy/ $4 \pi$, then is 

$$
U=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\text { (i) }-\int_{0}^{R} \rho \frac{d \phi}{d r} r^{3} d r \quad ? \\
\text { (ii) } \frac{1}{4 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2} r^{2} d r \quad ? \\
\text { (iii) } \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{R} \rho \phi r^{2} d r \quad ? \\
\text { (iv) }-\int_{0}^{R} p r^{2} d r \quad ?
\end{array}\right.
$$

(d) The test body in (b) is placed with its center of mass at $\left(0,0, r_{0}\right)$ in a spherically symmetric potential

$$
\phi(r)=-\frac{M G}{r} .
$$

For large $r_{0}$ the gravitational potential energy has the form

$$
-\frac{m G M}{r_{0}}+\frac{d}{r_{0}^{3}}+O\left(\frac{1}{r_{0}^{4}}\right),
$$

where $m=\int \sigma d^{3} x$. Find $d$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-437.jpg?height=400&width=376&top_left_y=1217&top_left_x=258)

Fig. 1.235.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-437.jpg?height=369&width=232&top_left_y=1245&top_left_x=994)

Fig. 1.236.

\section{Solution:}

(a) As in Fig. $1.235$ take $z$-axis along the axis of symmetry and origin $O$ inside the body. The gravitational potential (potential energy per unit mass of test body) at a distant point $P$ due to the body is 

$$
\phi=-\int_{V^{\prime}} \frac{G \rho\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} d V^{\prime}
$$

where $V^{\prime}$ is the volume of the body.

As

$$
\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=r^{2}+r^{2}-2 r r^{\prime} \cos \left(\theta^{\prime}-\theta\right),
$$

for large distances from the bod $\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|^{-1}$ can be approximated:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\left|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right|} &=\frac{1}{r}\left[1+\left(\frac{r^{\prime}}{r}\right)^{2}-\frac{2 r^{\prime}}{r} \cos \left(\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right)\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \approx \frac{1}{r}\left[1+\frac{r^{\prime}}{r} \cos \left(\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting it in the integral gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi=&-\frac{G}{r} \cdot 2 \pi \int \rho\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 2} \sin \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} \\
&-\frac{G}{r^{2}} \cdot 2 \pi \int \rho\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 3} \sin \theta^{\prime} \cos \left(\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right) d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing it with the given form

$$
\phi \approx-\frac{G M}{r}+\frac{f(\theta)}{r^{2}},
$$

we find

$$
f(\theta)=-2 \pi G \int \rho\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 3} \sin \theta^{\prime} \cos \left(\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right) d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} .
$$

(b) In a gravitational potential $\phi(x, y, z)$ the potential energy of a test body with mass density $\sigma(x, y, z)$ and volume $V$ is

$$
W=\int_{V} \sigma(x, y, z) \phi(x, y, z) d V .
$$

(c) For a closed system of mass density $\rho$ and volume $V$ the gravitational energy is

$$
W=\frac{1}{2} \int_{V} \rho \phi d V .
$$

Then for a spherically symmetric gaseous body of radius $R$ we have

$$
W=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{R} \rho(r) \phi(r) 4 \pi r^{2} d r,
$$

taking the origin at its center. Thus

$$
U=\frac{W}{4 \pi}=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{R} \rho \phi r^{2} d r .
$$

Thus integral (iii) is correct.

Consider a spherical shell of the gaseous body of radius $r$ and thickness $\Delta r$. As the body is supported against its own gravity by pressure $p$, we require that for equilibrium

$$
4 \pi r^{2}[p(r)-p(r+\Delta r)]-4 \pi r^{2} \rho \frac{d \phi}{d r} \Delta r=0
$$

or

$$
\frac{d p}{d r}=-\rho \frac{d \phi}{d r} .
$$

Poissons's equation for attracting masses is

$$
\nabla^{2} \phi=4 \pi G \rho,
$$

or, for spherical symmetry,

$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)=4 \pi G \rho
$$

giving

$$
\rho=\frac{1}{4 \pi G} \cdot \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d p}{d r}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi G} \cdot \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right) \frac{d \phi}{d r} .
$$

Outside the spherical body, $p$ is zero and $d p / d r=0$. Hence

$$
\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)_{r=R}=0 .
$$

Equation (1) can then be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=\frac{1}{8 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R} \phi \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right) d r \\
&=\frac{1}{8 \pi G}\left[\left.r^{2} \phi \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right|_{0} ^{R}-\int_{0}^{R} r^{2}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2} d r\right] \\
&=-\frac{1}{8 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R} r^{2}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2} d r .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus integral (ii) has to be multiplied by a factor $-\frac{1}{2}$. Consider now integral (i). It can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-\frac{1}{4 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R} r \frac{d}{d r}\left(r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right) \cdot \frac{d \phi}{d r} d r \\
=&-\frac{1}{4 \pi G}\left[\left.r^{3}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2}\right|_{0} ^{R}-\int_{0}^{R} r^{2} \frac{d \phi}{d r} \cdot d\left(r \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)\right] \\
=&\left.\frac{1}{8 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R} r d\left(r \frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2}\right] \\
=& \frac{1}{8 \pi G}\left[\left.r^{3}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2}\right|_{0} ^{R}-\int_{0}^{R} r^{2}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2} d r\right] \\
=&-\frac{1}{8 \pi G} \int_{0}^{R} r^{2}\left(\frac{d \phi}{d r}\right)^{2} d r,
\end{aligned}
$$

which is the same as Eq. (2). Hence integral (i) is correct.

Integral (iv) can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{1}{3} \int_{0}^{R} p d r^{3} &=-\frac{1}{3}\left[\left.p r^{3}\right|_{0} ^{R}-\int_{0}^{R} r^{3} \frac{d p}{d r} d r\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{3} \int_{0}^{R} r^{3} \frac{d p}{d r} d r \\
&=-\frac{1}{3} \int_{n}^{R} \rho r^{3} \frac{d \phi}{d r} d r .
\end{aligned}
$$

Compared with integral (i), which is correct, it has to be multiplied by a factor 3.

(d) Let $C$ be the center of mass of the test body, and consider a volume element $d V^{\prime}$ at radius vector $\mathbf{r}^{\prime}$ from $C$ as shown in Fig. 1.236. We have

$$
\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{0}+\mathbf{r}^{\prime},
$$

or

$$
r^{2}=r_{0}^{2}+r^{\prime 2}+r_{0} r^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime},
$$

giving

$$
r^{-1}=r_{0}^{-1}\left[1+\frac{r^{\prime}}{r_{0}} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\left(\frac{r^{\prime}}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}} \approx r^{-1}\left[1-\frac{r^{\prime}}{2 r_{0}} \cos \theta^{\prime}+O\left(\frac{r^{2}}{r_{0}^{2}}\right)\right] \text {. }
$$

The gravitational potential energy of the test body is

$$
W=\int_{V^{\prime}} \sigma \phi d V^{\prime}=-\int_{V^{\prime}} \sigma\left(\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\right) \frac{G M}{r_{0}}\left(1-\frac{r^{\prime}}{2 r_{0}} \cos \theta^{\prime}+O\left(\frac{r^{\prime}}{r_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2}\right) d V^{\prime}
$$

where $V^{\prime}$ is the volume of the test body. Use spherical coordinates $\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right)$ with origin at $C$, we have

$$
d V^{\prime}=r^{\prime 2} \sin \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} d \varphi^{\prime}
$$

and can write the above as

$$
W=-\frac{G M m}{r_{0}}+\frac{G M}{2 r_{0}^{2}} \int \sigma\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 3} \sin 2 \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} d \varphi^{\prime}+O\left(\frac{1}{r_{0}^{3}}\right) \text {. }
$$

Hence

$$
d=\frac{G M r_{0}}{2} \int \sigma\left(r^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right) r^{\prime 3} \sin 2 \theta^{\prime} d r^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} d \varphi^{\prime}
$$

\section{7}

A beam of seasoned oak, 2 in $\times 4$ in in cross section is built into a concrete wall so as to extend out $6 \mathrm{ft}$, as shown in Fig. 1.237. It is oriented so as to support the load $L$ with the least amount of bending. The elastic limit for oak is a stress of $7900 \mathrm{lb} /$ in $^{2}$. The modulus of elasticity, $l(d p / d l)$, is $1.62 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{lb} / \mathrm{in}^{2}$. What is the largest load $L$ that can be supported without permanently deforming the beam and what is the displacement of the point $P$ under this load? In working this problem make reasonable approximations, including that it is adequate to equate the radius of the curvature of the beam to $-\left(d^{2} y / d x^{2}\right)^{-1}$ instead of the exact expression.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-442.jpg?height=283&width=533&top_left_y=503&top_left_x=525)

Fig. 1.237.

\section{Solution:}

Neglect shear stresses and assume pure bending. During bending, the upper fibers will be extended while the lower fibers are compressed, and there is a neutral plane $N^{\prime} N$ which remains unstrained. Consider fibers a distance $\xi$ from $N^{\prime} N$ as shown in Fig. 1.237. Let the radius of curvature of $N^{\prime} N$ be $r$ and that of the fibers under consideration $r+\xi$. The latter thus suffer a longitudinal strain

$$
\frac{(r+\xi)-r}{r}=\frac{\xi}{r} .
$$

Consider a cross section $A$ of the beam at $x$. The longitudinal stress at $\xi$ from the neutral axis in which the cross section intersects the neutral plane is

$$
T(\xi)=\frac{E \xi}{r},
$$

where $E$ is the Young's modulus of the material. The total moment of the longitudinal stresses about the neutral axis is

$$
M(x)=\int T \xi d A=\frac{E}{r} \int \xi^{2} d A=\frac{E I}{r} .
$$

$I$ is the moment of inertia of the cross-sectional area about the neutral axis. The maximum bending moment occurs at the cross section $x=0$ and the maximum stress occurs at the upper and lower boundaries. As 

$$
\begin{gathered}
T=\frac{E \xi}{r}=\frac{M(x) \xi}{I}, \\
T_{\max }=\frac{M(0) h}{I}=\frac{L l h}{I} .
\end{gathered}
$$

For least bending the beam should be mounted so that its height is $2 h=4$ in and width $w=2$ in. Thus

$$
I=\int \xi^{2} d A=\omega \int_{-h}^{h} \xi^{2} d \xi=\frac{2}{3} \omega h^{3}=\frac{32}{3} \text { in }^{4} .
$$

With $l=72 \mathrm{in}$, limiting stress $T_{\max }=7900 \mathrm{lb} / \mathrm{in}^{2}$, this gives the maximum load as

$$
L=\frac{7900 \times 32}{3 \times 72 \times 2}=585 \mathrm{lb} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-443.jpg?height=279&width=424&top_left_y=943&top_left_x=540)

Fig. 1.238.

Figure $1.238$ shows the bending of the neutral plane $N^{\prime} N$. Equation (1) gives

$$
-\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} \approx \frac{1}{r}=\frac{M(x)}{E I}=\frac{L(l-x)}{E I} .
$$

Integrating and noting that $d y / d x=0$ at $x=0$, we have

$$
\frac{d y}{d x}=-\frac{L}{E I}\left(l x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right) .
$$

Further integration with $y=0$ at $x=0$ gives

$$
y=\frac{L}{E I}\left(\frac{x^{3}}{6}-\frac{l x^{2}}{2}\right) .
$$

The displacement of the point $P$ is therefore

$$
\frac{L}{E I}\left(\frac{l^{3}}{6}-\frac{l^{3}}{2}\right)=-\frac{L l^{3}}{3 E I}=-4.21 \text { in } .
$$

\section{8}

Many elementary textbooks quote Pascal's principle for hydrostatics as "any change in the pressure of a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished and instantaneously to all other parts of the fluid". Is this a violation of relativity? Explain clearly what "instantaneously" must mean here.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Pascal's principle does not really violate relativity. It assumes the fluid to be incompressible, which is a simplified model and does not correspond to a real fluid.

A change in the pressure at a point of a fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid with the speed of sound. As the size of an ordinary container is very small compared with the distance traversed by sound in a short time, the change in pressure appears to be transmitted to all parts of the fluid instantaneously.

\section{9}

A beam balance is used to measure the mass $m_{1}$ of a solid of volume $V_{1}$ which has a very low density $\rho_{1}$. This solid is placed in the left-hand balance pan and metal weights of a very high density $\rho_{2}$ are placed in the right-hand pan to achieve balance.

(a) If the balancing is first carried out in air and then the balance casing is evacuated, will the apparatus remain balanced? If not, which pan will go down?

(b) Determine the percentage error (if any) in the measured mass $m_{1}$ when the balancing is carried out in air (density of air $=\rho_{A}$ ). 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The apparatus will not remain balanced after the balance casing is evacuated. The left-hand pan, which carries a lower density solid, and hence an object of a larger volume, will go down, as it had been supported more by air in the earlier balancing.

(b) Let the true and apparent masses of the solid be $m$ and $m_{1}$ respectively. Then

$$
m g-\frac{m}{\rho_{1}} \rho_{A} g=m_{1} g-\frac{m_{1}}{\rho_{2}} \rho_{A} g
$$

or

$$
m-m_{1}=\left(\frac{m}{\rho_{1}}-\frac{m_{1}}{\rho_{2}}\right) \rho_{A} \approx \frac{m_{1}}{\rho_{1}} \rho_{A}
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{\Delta m_{1}}{m_{1}} \approx \frac{\rho_{A}}{\rho_{1}} .
$$

1260

A bucket of water is rotated at a constant angular velocity $\omega$ about its symmetry axis. Determine the shape of the surface of the water after everything has settled down.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-445.jpg?height=419&width=438&top_left_y=1414&top_left_x=545)

Fig. 1.239. 

\section{Solution:}

Consider a particle of water of mass $m$ at the surface. Two forces act on it: a force $\mathbf{F}$ normal to the surface due to neighboring water particles, and gravity $m \mathrm{~g}$, as shown in Fig. 1.239. As it moves in a circular orbit with constant angular velocity $\omega$, in a cylindrical coordinate system with origin at the lowest point of the surface we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F \cos \theta=m g, \\
&F \sin \theta=m \omega^{2} r,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle formed by the normal to the water surface and the $z$-axis. Hence

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{\omega^{2} r}{g} .
$$

As $\tan \theta$ is the slope of the curve representing the shape of the surface,

$$
\frac{d z}{d r}=\frac{\omega^{2} r}{g},
$$

giving

$$
z=\frac{\omega^{2} r^{2}}{2 g},
$$

as $z=0$ for $r=0$. Hence the surface is a paraboloid generated by rotating the above parabola about the $z$-axis.

\section{1}

A device consisting of a thin vertical tube and wide horizontal tube joined together in the way shown in Fig. $1.240$ is immersed in a fluid of density $\rho_{f}$. The density and pressure of the external atmosphere are $\rho_{a}$ and $p_{a}$ respectively. The end of the horizontal tube is then sealed, and subsequently the device is rotated as shown with constant angular velocity $\omega$. You may treat the air everywhere as an ideal gas at fixed temperature, and you may ignore the variation of density with altitude. Finally, ignore capillarity and surface friction.

Find the height $h$ to which the fluid rises in the vertical tube to second order in $\omega$. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-447.jpg?height=331&width=404&top_left_y=220&top_left_x=560)

Fig. $1.240$.

\section{Solution:}

The pressure $p$ and density $\rho$ of the air in the horizontal tube are not uniform. Consider a vertical layer of the air of thickness $d x$ at distance $x$ from the axis of rotation as shown in Fig. 1.240. As the tube is rotating with angular velocity $\omega$, we have

$$
[p(x+d x)-p(x)] A=\omega^{2} x \rho A d x,
$$

$A$ being the cross-sectional area of the tube, or

$$
\frac{d p}{d x}=\omega^{2} x \rho .
$$

Treating air as an ideal gas of molecular weight $M$, we have

$$
p V=\frac{m}{M} R T,
$$

or

$$
\rho=\frac{p M}{R T},
$$

where $R$ is the gas constant. Hence

$$
d \rho=\frac{M}{R T} d p
$$

and

$$
\frac{d \rho}{\rho}=\frac{M \omega^{2}}{R T} x d x .
$$

Integration of the above gives

$$
\ln \left(\frac{\rho}{\rho_{0}}\right)=\frac{M \omega^{2}}{2 R T} x^{2},
$$

where $\rho_{0}$ is the density of the air at $x=0$. Thus

$$
\rho=\rho_{0} e^{\alpha x^{2}}
$$

with $\alpha=M \omega^{2} / 2 R T$. $\rho_{0}$ can be determined by considering the total mass of the air in the tube:

$$
\int_{0}^{L} \rho S d x=\rho_{a} S L,
$$

i.e.

$$
\rho_{0} \int_{0}^{L} e^{\alpha x^{2}} d x=\rho_{a} L .
$$

For moderate $\omega, \alpha$ is a small number. As

$$
e^{\alpha x^{2}}=1+\alpha x^{2}+\frac{\alpha^{2} x^{4}}{2 !}+\ldots \approx 1+\alpha x^{2},
$$

the above becomes approximately

$$
\rho_{0} L\left(1+\frac{\alpha L^{2}}{3}\right) \approx \rho_{a} L
$$

or

$$
\rho_{0} \approx\left(1-\frac{\alpha L^{2}}{3}\right) \rho_{a} .
$$

As $p$ is proportional to $\rho$ since the temperature is assumed the same everywhere, we have the pressure at $x=0$ as

$$
p_{0}=\left(1-\frac{\alpha L^{2}}{3}\right) p_{a} .
$$

Consider now the liquid in the thin vertical tube. For equilibrium we have

$$
p_{a}=p_{0}+g h \rho_{f},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\alpha L^{2}}{3} p_{a}=g h \rho_{f},
$$

giving

$$
h=\frac{M \omega^{2} L^{2} p_{a}}{6 R T g \rho_{f}}=\frac{\omega^{2} L^{2}}{6 g} \cdot \frac{\rho_{a}}{\rho_{f}} .
$$



\section{2}

A cylindrical container of circular cross section, radius $R$, is so supported that it can rotate about its vertical axis. It is first filled with a liquid (assumed to be incompressible) of density $\rho$ to a level $h$ above its flat bottom. The cylinder is then set in rotation with angular velocity $\omega$ about its axis. The angular velocity is kept constant, and we wait for a while until a steady state is achieved. It is assumed that the liquid does not overflow, and it is also assumed that no portion of the bottom is "dry".

(a) Find the equation for the upper surface of the liquid.

(b) Find an expression for the pressure $p(z)$ on the cylindrical surface at a height $z$ above the bottom.

(c) Find an expression for the pressure $p_{0}(z)$ along the axis at a height $z$ above the bottom.

(d) Is the fluid flow as viewed by a stationary observer irrotational? The liquid is, of course, subject to the influence of gravity, and we assume that the normal atmospheric pressure $p_{a}$ prevails in the environment.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-449.jpg?height=469&width=314&top_left_y=1042&top_left_x=543)

Fig. 1.241.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a vertical plane containing the axis of rotation. Let $\alpha$ be the angle made by the tangent to the upper surface of the liquid with the horizontal at a point distance $\xi$ from the rotational axis and height $\eta$ above the lowest point of the upper surface, as shown in Fig. 1.241. Following Problem 1260 we have 

$$
\tan \alpha=\frac{d \eta}{d \xi}=\frac{\omega^{2} \xi}{g} .
$$

Its integration gives the parabola

$$
\eta=\frac{\omega^{2} \xi^{2}}{2 g} .
$$

The upper surface is obtained by rotating this parabola about the axis of rotation.

(b) The upper surface of the liquid is an isobaric surface with a pressure equal to the atmosphere pressure $p_{a}$. Note that each such revolving parabola in the liquid is an isobaric surface, the difference in pressure between it and the upper surface being determined by the distance between the two surfaces along the rotational axis. Let $h$ be the height of the lowest point of the upper surfaces above the bottom of the container. The height of the highest point of the upper surface above the bottom is then

$$
h_{1}=h+\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{2 g} .
$$

If $S=\pi R^{2}$ and $h_{0}$ is the height of the liquid when it is not rotating, the total volume of the liquid is

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{0} S &=h_{1} S-\int_{0}^{\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{2 g}} \pi \xi^{2} d \eta=h_{1} S-\int_{0}^{R} \frac{\pi \omega^{2}}{g} \xi^{3} d \xi \\
&=h_{1} S-\frac{\pi \omega^{2} R^{4}}{4 g}=\left(h_{1}-\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{4 g}\right) \pi R^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
h_{1}=h_{0}+\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{4 g},
$$

and hence

$$
h=h_{0}-\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{4 g} .
$$

The pressure on the cylindrical surface at a height $z$ above the bottom is therefore

$$
p(z)=p_{a}+\left(h_{1}-z\right) \rho g=p_{a}+\left(h_{0}+\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{4 g}-z\right) \rho g .
$$

(c) The pressure along the axis at a height $z$ above the bottom is

$$
p_{0}(z)=p_{a}+(h-z) \rho g=p_{a}+\left(h_{0}-\frac{\omega^{2} R^{2}}{4 g}-z\right) \rho g .
$$

(d)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla \times \mathbf{v} &=\nabla \times(\omega \times \mathbf{r})=\nabla \times\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
0 & 0 & \omega \\
x & y & z
\end{array}\right| \\
&=\nabla \times(-\omega y \mathbf{i}+\omega x \mathbf{j}) \\
&=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
-\omega y & \omega x & 0
\end{array}\right|=2 \omega \mathbf{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\nabla \times \mathbf{v} \neq 0$, the fluid flow is rotational.

\section{3}

Given that the angular diameter of the moon and that of the sun are nearly equal and that the tides raised by the moon are about twice as high as those raised by the sun, what statement can you derive about the relative densities of the sun and moon?

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Let $R_{e}, R_{m}, R_{s}$ be the radii, $M_{e}, M_{m}, M_{s}$ the masses of the earth, moon and sun, and denote by $h_{m}, h_{s}$ the heights of the tides raised by the moon and sun at a point on earth, and by $D_{m}, D_{s}$ the distances of the moon and sun from the center of the earth, respectively. The disturbing effect of the moon at a point on the earth's surface may be represented by a potential which is approximately

$$
\frac{3}{2} \frac{G M_{m} R_{e}^{2}}{D_{m}^{3}}\left(\frac{1}{3}-\cos \theta\right),
$$

where $\theta$ is the moon's zenith distance at that point. This being equal to $g h_{m}$, where 

$$
g=\frac{G M_{e}}{R_{e}^{2}}
$$

is the acceleration due to the earth's gravity, we have

$$
h_{m}=\frac{3}{2} \frac{R_{e}^{4} M_{m}}{D_{m}^{3} M_{e}}\left(\frac{1}{3}-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

For the same zenith distance,

$$
\frac{h_{m}}{h_{s}}=\left(\frac{D_{s}}{D_{m}}\right)^{3} \frac{M_{m}}{M_{s}}=\left(\frac{D_{s}}{D_{m}}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{R_{m}}{R_{s}}\right)^{3} \frac{\rho_{m}}{\rho_{s}},
$$

with $\rho_{m}, \rho_{s}$ denoting the average densities of the moon and sun respectively. As the angular diameters of the moon and sun as seen from the earth are approximately equal, we have

$$
\frac{R_{m}}{D_{m}}=\frac{R_{s}}{D_{s}},
$$

and hence

$$
\frac{\rho_{m}}{\rho_{s}}=\frac{h_{m}}{h_{s}}=2,
$$

which is the density of the moon relative to that of the sun.

\section{4}

A hypothetical material out of which an astronomical object is formed has an equation of state

$$
p=\frac{1}{2} K \rho^{2},
$$

where $p$ is the pressure and $\rho$ the mass density.

(a) Show that for this material, under conditions of hydrostatic equilibrium, there is a linear relation between the density and the gravitational potential. The algebraic sign of the proportionality term is important.

(b) Write a differential equation satisfied at hydrostatic equilibrium by the density. What boundary conditions or other physical constraints should be applied?

(c) Assuming spherical symmetry, find the radius of the astronomical object at equilibrium.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$ 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Suppose the fluid is acted upon by an external force $F$ per unit volume. Consider the surfaces normal to the $x$-axis of a volume element $d \tau=d x d y d z$ of the fluid. At equilibrium $\mathbf{F}$ is balanced by the pressure in the fluid, thus

$$
F_{x} d \tau=[p(x+d x)-p(x)] d y d z=\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} d \tau
$$

i.e.

$$
F_{x}=\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{F}=\nabla p .
$$

Then if $f$ is the external force per unit mass of the fluid, we have

$$
\mathbf{f}=\frac{1}{\rho} \nabla p .
$$

As $p$ is given by the equation of state, we have

$$
\nabla p=K \rho \nabla \rho
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{f}=K \nabla \rho .
$$

If the external force is due to gravitational potential $\phi$, then

$$
\mathbf{f}=-\nabla \phi .
$$

A comparison with the above gives

$$
\nabla \phi+K \nabla \rho=0,
$$

or

$$
\phi+K \rho=\text { constant } .
$$

Hence $\phi$ and $\rho$ are related linearly.

(b) Poisson's equation

$$
\nabla^{2} \phi=4 \pi G \rho
$$

then gives

$$
\nabla^{2} \rho+\frac{4 \pi G \rho}{K}=0 .
$$

This is the differential equation that has to be satisfied by the density at equilibrium. The boundary condition is that $\rho$ is zero at the edge of the astronomical object.

(c) For spherical symmetry use spherical coordinates with origin at the center of the object. The last equation then becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} \rho}{d r^{2}}+\frac{2}{r} \frac{d \rho}{d r}+\frac{4 \pi G \rho}{K}=0 .
$$

Let $u=\rho r, \omega^{2}=4 \pi G / K$ and write the above as

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d r^{2}}+\omega^{2} u=0
$$

which has solution

$$
u=u_{0} \sin (\omega r+\beta),
$$

giving

$$
\rho=\frac{r_{0} \rho_{0}}{r} \sin (\omega r+\beta),
$$

where $r_{0}, \rho_{0}$ and $\beta$ are constants. The boundary condition $\rho=0$ at $r=R$, where $R$ is the radius of the astronomical object, requires

$$
\omega R+\beta=n \pi, \quad n=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

However, the density $\rho$ must be positive so that $\omega r+\beta \leq \pi$. This means that $n=1$ and $\omega R+\beta=\pi$. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{f} &=K \nabla \rho \\
&=K\left[-\frac{r_{0} \rho_{0}}{r^{2}} \sin (\omega r+\beta)+\frac{r_{0} \rho_{0}}{r} \omega \cos (\omega r+\beta)\right] \mathbf{e}_{r} \\
&=-K \frac{\rho_{0} r_{0}}{r^{2}} \cos (\omega r+\beta)[\tan (\omega r+\beta)-\omega r] \mathbf{e}_{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to symmetry we require $f=0$ at $r=0$. This means that as $r \rightarrow 0$

$$
\tan (\omega r+\beta)-\omega r=\beta+\frac{1}{3}(\omega r+\beta)^{3}+\ldots \rightarrow 0 .
$$

Hence $\beta=0$ and $\omega R=\pi$, giving the radius as

$$
R=\sqrt{\frac{\pi K}{4 G}} .
$$



\section{5}

Consider a self-gravitating slab of fluid matter in hydrostatic equilibrium of total thickness $2 h$ and infinite lateral extent (in the $x$ and $y$ directions). The slab is uniform such that the density $\rho(z)$ is a function of $z$ only, and the matter distribution is furthermore symmetric about the midplane $z=0$. Derive an expression for the pressure $p$ in this midplane in terms of the quantity

$$
\sigma=\int_{0}^{h} \rho(z) d z
$$

without making any assumption about the equation of state.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-455.jpg?height=349&width=465&top_left_y=833&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 1.242.

\section{Solution:}

In hydrostatic equilibrium the applied force on unit mass of the fluid is (Problem 1264)

$$
\mathbf{f}=\frac{1}{\rho} \nabla p .
$$

As there is variation only in the $z$-direction,

$$
f=\frac{1}{\rho} \frac{d p}{d z} .
$$

Consider the gravitational force acting on unit mass at a point at $z_{0}$, as shown in Fig. 1.242, by a layer of the fluid of thickness $d z$ at $z$ : 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{G \rho(z) d z \cdot 2 \pi r d r}{r^{2}+\left(z_{0}-z\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{z_{0}-z}{\sqrt{r^{2}+\left(z_{0}-z\right)^{2}}} \\
&=-2 \pi G \rho(z)\left(z_{0}-z\right) d z \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{r d r}{\left[r^{2}+\left(z_{0}-z\right)^{2}\right]^{\frac{3}{2}}} \\
&=-2 \pi G \rho(z)\left(z_{0}-z\right)\left[\frac{-1}{\sqrt{r^{2}+\left(z_{0}-z\right)^{2}}}\right]_{0}^{\infty} d z \\
&=\frac{-2 \pi G \rho(z)\left(z_{0}-z\right) d z}{\left|z_{0}-z\right|}
\end{aligned}
$$

The total gravitational force acting on the unit mass at $z=z_{0}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(z_{0}\right) &=-2 \pi G\left[\int_{-h}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z-\int_{z_{0}}^{h} \rho(z) d z\right] \\
&=-2 \pi G \int_{-z_{0}}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\rho(z)$ is symmetric with respect to the plane $z=0$. Applying Eq. (1) to the point $z=z_{0}$ and integrating, we have

$$
p(h)-p(0)=\int_{0}^{h} d p\left(z_{0}\right)=-2 \pi G \int_{0}^{h} \rho\left(z_{0}\right) d z_{0} \int_{-z_{0}}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z
$$

This gives for symmetric $\rho(z)$

$$
p(h)-p(0)=-4 \pi G \int_{0}^{h} \rho\left(z_{0}\right) d z_{0} \int_{0}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z .
$$

Setting $\varphi\left(z_{0}\right)=\int_{0}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z$, we have $d \varphi / d z_{0}=\rho\left(z_{0}\right)$ and

$$
\int_{0}^{h} \rho\left(z_{0}\right) d z_{0} \int_{0}^{z_{0}} \rho(z) d z=\int_{0}^{h} \rho\left(z_{0}\right) \varphi\left(z_{0}\right) \frac{d \varphi}{\rho\left(z_{0}\right)}=\int_{0}^{\sigma} \varphi d \varphi=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2},
$$

where $\sigma=\int_{0}^{h} \rho(z) d z$. Using the boundary condition $p(h)=0$ we finally obtain

$$
p(0)=2 \pi G \sigma^{2} .
$$



\section{6}

(a) A boat of mass $M$ is floating in a (deep) tank of water with vertical sidewalls. A rock of mass $m$ is dropped into the boat. How much does the water level in the tank rise? If the rock misses the boat and falls into the water, how much does the water level rise then?

[You may assume any reasonable shapes for the tank, boat and rock, if you require.]

(b) A U-tube with arms of different cross-sectional areas $A_{1}, A_{2}$ is filled with an incompressible liquid to a height $d$, as shown in Fig. 1.243. Air is blown impulsively into one end of the tube. Describe quantitatively the subsequent motion of the liquid. You may neglect surface tension effects and the viscosity of the fluid.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-457.jpg?height=209&width=335&top_left_y=862&top_left_x=229)

Fig. 1.243.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-457.jpg?height=221&width=417&top_left_y=860&top_left_x=808)

Fig. 1.244.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\rho_{w}$ and $\rho_{r}$ be the densities of water and the rock, $S_{t}$ and $S_{h}$ the horizontal cross-sectional areas of the tank and boat, respectively. With the rock in the boat, the boat will sink a distance (from water surface) $\Delta h$ such that an additional buoyancy is made available of magnitude

$$
m g=\rho_{w} S_{b} \Delta h g,
$$

giving

$$
\Delta h=\frac{m}{\rho_{w} S_{b}} .
$$

This will cause the water level in the tank to rise by $\Delta H$ given by

$$
S_{t} \Delta H=S_{b} \Delta h,
$$

or

$$
\Delta H=\frac{m}{\rho_{w} S_{t}} .
$$

If the rock misses the boat and falls into the water, it drops to the bottom of the tank. This increases the "water" volume by $m / \rho_{r}$, which then causes the water level in the tank to rise a height

$$
\Delta H=\frac{m}{\rho_{r} S_{t}} .
$$

(b) The motion of the fluid is irrotational and non-steady, and is described by Bernoulli's equation of the form

$$
\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+p+U-\rho \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial t}=\text { constant },
$$

which holds for all points of the fluid at any given time $t$. Here $U$ is the potential of the external force $\mathbf{F}$ defined by $\mathbf{F}=-\nabla U$, and $\phi$ is the velocity potential defined by $v=-\nabla \phi$. Consider two surface points 1,2 , one on each arm of the vessel, at distances $x_{1}, x_{2}$ from the equilibrium level $d$, as shown in Fig. 1.244. Bernoulli's equation gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{1}^{2}+p_{1}+U_{1}-\rho \frac{\partial \phi_{1}}{\partial t}=\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{2}^{2}+p_{2}+U_{2}-\rho \frac{\partial \phi_{2}}{\partial t}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{1} &=p_{2}=\text { atmospheric pressure } \\
U_{1} &=\left(d+x_{1}\right) \rho g, \quad U_{2}=\left(d-x_{2}\right) \rho g \\
v_{1} &=\dot{x}_{1}, \quad v_{2}=\dot{x}_{2}, \\
\frac{\partial \phi_{1}}{\partial t} &=-\int_{0}^{d+x_{1}} \frac{\partial v_{1}}{\partial t} d x \approx-\ddot{x}_{1} d, \\
\frac{\partial \phi_{2}}{\partial t} &=-\int_{0}^{d-x_{1}}-\frac{\partial v_{2}}{\partial t} d x \approx \ddot{x}_{2} d
\end{aligned}
$$

retaining only first order terms of the small quantities $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and their time derivations. In the same approximation, Bernoulli's equation becomes

$$
\left(\ddot{x}_{1}+\ddot{x}_{2}\right)+\frac{g}{d}\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)=0 .
$$

\section{Making use of the continuity equation}

$$
A_{1} x_{1}=A_{2} x_{2},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}_{1}+\frac{g x_{1}}{d}=0, \\
&\ddot{x}_{2}+\frac{g x_{2}}{d}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the subsequent motion of the liquid is that of harmonic vibration with angular frequency $\omega=\sqrt{g / d}$.

\section{7}

A space station is made from a large cylinder of radius $R_{0}$ filled with air. The cylinder spins about its symmetry axis at angular speed $\omega$ to provide acceleration at the rim equal to the gravitational acceleration $g$ at the earth's surface.

If the temperature $T$ is constant inside the station, what is the ratio of air pressure at the center to the pressure at the rim?

\section{Solution:}

Consider a cylindrical shell of air of radius $r$ and thickness $\Delta r$. The pressure difference across its curved surfaces provides the centripetal force for the rotating air. Thus

$$
[p(r+\Delta r)-p(\Delta r)] 2 \pi r l=\omega^{2} r \cdot 2 \pi r l \rho \Delta r,
$$

where $\rho$ is the density of the air and $l$ is the length of the cylinder, giving

$$
\frac{d p}{d r}=\rho \omega^{2} r .
$$

The air follows the equation of state of an ideal gas

$$
p V=\frac{m}{M} R T,
$$

or

$$
\rho=\frac{M}{R T} p,
$$

where $T$ and $M$ are the absolute temperature and molecular weight of air and $R$ is the gas constant. Hence 

$$
\frac{d p}{d r}=\frac{M \omega^{2}}{R T} p r .
$$

Integrating we have

$$
\int_{p(0)}^{p\left(R_{0}\right)} \frac{d p}{p}=\frac{M \omega^{2}}{R T} \int_{0}^{R_{0}} r d r
$$

i.e.

$$
\ln \left[\frac{p\left(R_{0}\right)}{p(0)}\right]=\frac{M \omega^{2} R_{0}^{2}}{2 R T}=\frac{M R_{0} g}{2 R T},
$$

as the acceleration at the $\operatorname{rim}, \omega^{2} R_{0}$, is equal to $g$. Hence the ratio of the pressures is

$$
\frac{p(0)}{p\left(R_{0}\right)}=\exp \left(-\frac{M R_{0} g}{2 R T}\right)
$$

\section{8}

Calculate the surface figure of revolution describing the equatorial bulge attained by a slowly rotating planet. Assume that the planet is composed entirely of an incompressible liquid of density $\rho$ and total mass $M$ that rotates with uniform angular velocity $\omega$. When rotating, the equilibrium distance from the center of the planet to its poles is $R_{p}$.

(a) Write down the equation of hydrostatic equilibrium for this problem.

(b) Solve for the pressure near the surface of the planet using the crude approximation that the gravitational field near the surface can be written as $-G M \mathbf{r} / r^{2}$.

(c) Find an equation for the surface of the planet.

(d) If the equatorial bulge $\left(R_{e}-R_{p}\right)$ is a small fraction of the planetary radius, find an approximation to the expression obtained in (c) to describe the deviation of the surface from sphericity.

(e) For the case of earth $\left(R_{p}=6400 \mathrm{~km}, M=6 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{~kg}\right)$ make a numerical estimate of the height of the equatorial bulge.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinate as shown in Fig. $1.245$ and consider a point $P$ in the planet. In equilibrium the external forces are balanced by the pressure force per unit volume, 

$$
\nabla p=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial r}, \frac{\partial p}{r \partial \theta}, 0\right)
$$

in spherical coordinates with the assumption that the planet is symmetric with respect to the axis of rotation.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-461.jpg?height=384&width=369&top_left_y=492&top_left_x=226)

Fig. 1.245.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-461.jpg?height=381&width=453&top_left_y=493&top_left_x=822)

Fig. $1.246$.

Now use a rotating coordinate frame attached to the planet such that the $z^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the axis of rotation and the $x^{\prime} z^{\prime}$-plane contains $O P$. In this frame a fictitious centrifugal force per unit volume, $\rho \omega^{2} r \cos \lambda$, where $\lambda=\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta$ is the latitude, has to the introduced. Let $F$ be the gravitational force per unit volume. Then the forces involved are as shown in Fig. 1.246. As $d \theta=-d \lambda$, we can write $\partial p / \partial \theta=-\partial p / \partial \lambda$ and have, in the $x^{\prime}$ and $z^{\prime}$ directions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial p}{\partial r} \cos \lambda-\frac{\partial p}{r \partial \lambda} \sin \lambda=F_{x^{\prime}}+\rho \omega^{2} r \cos \lambda, \\
&\frac{\partial p}{\partial r} \sin \lambda+\frac{\partial p}{r \partial \lambda} \cos \lambda=F_{y^{\prime}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The gravitational force per unit volume at $P$, as given, has components

$$
F_{x^{\prime}}=-\frac{\rho G M \cos \lambda}{r^{2}}, \quad F_{y^{\prime}}=-\frac{\rho G M \sin \lambda}{r^{2}} .
$$

Substitution in Eq. (2) gives

$$
\frac{\partial p}{r \partial \lambda}=-\left(\frac{\rho G M}{r^{2}}+\frac{\partial p}{\partial r}\right) \tan \lambda,
$$

which, with Eq. (1), then gives

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial r}=\rho \omega^{2} r \cos ^{2} \lambda-\frac{\rho G M}{r^{2}} .
$$

As $p=0$ at $r=R$, its integration gives

$$
p=\frac{1}{2}\left(r^{2}-R^{2}\right) \rho \omega^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda+\left(\frac{1}{r}-\frac{1}{R}\right) \rho G M
$$

For a point a depth $h$ under the surface at latitude $\lambda$, we have, as $r=R-h$ with $h \ll R$,

$$
r^{2}-R^{2} \approx-2 R h, \quad \frac{1}{r}-\frac{1}{R} \approx \frac{h}{R^{2}}
$$

and

$$
p \approx\left(-R \omega^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda+\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\right) \rho h .
$$

(c) The surface of the planet is an equipotential surface. The potential (potential energy per unit mass) at the surface due to gravitational force is

$$
U=-\frac{G M}{R}+\text { constant } .
$$

The potential $\phi$ due to the centrifugal force is given by

$$
-\nabla \phi=\left(-\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r}, \frac{\partial \phi}{r \partial \lambda}\right)=\left(\omega^{2} r \cos ^{2} \lambda, \omega^{2} r \cos \lambda \sin \lambda\right) .
$$

Thus

$$
\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r}=-\omega^{2} r \cos ^{2} \lambda,
$$

or

$$
\phi=-\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2} r^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda+f(\lambda) .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \phi}{r \partial \lambda} &=\omega^{2} r \cos \lambda \sin \lambda+\frac{1}{r} f^{\prime}(\lambda)=\omega^{2} r \cos \lambda \sin \lambda, \\
f^{\prime}(x) &=0 \quad \text { or } \quad f(x)=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence for the surface we have

$$
-\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2} R^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda-\frac{G m}{R}=\text { constant } .
$$

At the poles, $\lambda=\pm \frac{\pi}{2}, R=R_{p}$. We thus have

$$
\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda R^{3}-\frac{G M}{R_{p}} R+G M=0 .
$$

(d) At the equator, $\lambda=0, R=R_{e}$, and the above equation becomes

$$
\omega^{2} R_{e}^{3}=2 G M\left(\frac{R_{e}-R_{p}}{R_{P}}\right) .
$$

The deviation of the surface from sphericity is therefore

$$
\frac{R_{e}-R_{p}}{R_{p}}=\frac{\omega^{2} R_{e}^{3}}{2 G M} .
$$

(e) For the earth,

$$
\begin{gathered}
R=6400 \mathrm{~km}, \quad R_{e} \approx R_{p}=6400 \mathrm{~km}, \quad M=6 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{~kg}, \\
\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{24 \times 3600} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \quad G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
R_{e}-R_{p}=11 \mathrm{~km} .
$$

\section{9}

The compressibility $K$ of a gas or liquid is defined as $K=-(d V / V) / d p$, where $-d V$ is the volume decrease due to a pressure increase $d p$. Air (at STP) has about 15,000 times greater compressibility than water.

(a) Derive the formula for the velocity $v$ of sound waves, $1 / v^{2}=K \rho$, where $\rho$ is the mass density. Use any method you wish. (A simple model will suffice.)

(b) The velocity of sound in air (at STP) is about $330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Sound velocity in water is about $1470 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Suppose you have water filled with a homogeneous mixture of tiny air bubbles (very small compared with sound wavelengths in air) that occupy only $1 \%$ of the volume. Neglect the effect the bubbles have on the mass density of the mixture (compared with pure water). Find the compressibility $K$ of the mixture, and thus find $v$ for 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-464.jpg?height=171&width=415&top_left_y=216&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.247.

the mixture. Compare the numerical value of $v$ for the given $1 \%$ volume fraction with $v$ for pure water or air.

(UC,Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Without loss of generality, we can consider the problem in one dimension and suppose the front of the compressed region, i.e. the wavefront, propagates from left to right at speed $v$. For convenience we use coordinates such that the compressed region is at rest, then the gas particles in the region not reached by the wave will move from left to right at speed $v$ in this frame. Let the pressure and density in the latter region be $p$ and $\rho$ respectively. When the particles enter the compressed area, their velocity changes to $v+d v$, pressure changes to $p+d p$, and density changes to $\rho+d \rho$, as shown in Fig. 1.247. The mass of gas passing through a unit area of the wavefront is

$$
\rho v=(\rho+d \rho)(v+d v),
$$

yielding, to first-order quantities,

$$
v d \rho=-\rho d v .
$$

The change of momentum per unit time crossing the unit area is

$$
(\rho+d \rho)(v+d v) \cdot(v+d v)-\rho v \cdot v=v^{2} d \rho+2 \rho v d v .
$$

By Newton's second law this corresponds to the excess pressure of the right-hand side over the left-hand side. Thus

$$
v^{2} d \rho+2 \rho v d v=p-(p+d p)=-d p .
$$

The above two equations give

$$
v^{2} d p=d p
$$

For a given mass $m$ of the gas,

$$
m=\rho V
$$

or

$$
d \rho=-\rho \frac{d V}{V}
$$

Hence

$$
v^{2} d \rho=-v^{2} \rho \frac{d V}{V}=d p,
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=-\left(\frac{d V}{V}\right)^{-1} \frac{d p}{\rho}=\frac{1}{K \rho}
$$

i.e.

$$
v=\frac{1}{\sqrt{K \rho}} .
$$

(b) For the mixture given,

$$
K=-\frac{d V}{V d p}=-\frac{d V_{1}+d V_{2}}{V d p}=\frac{K_{1} V_{1}+K_{2} V_{2}}{V} .
$$

For water and air we have respectively

$$
v_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{K_{1} \rho_{1}}, \quad v_{2}^{2}=\frac{1}{K_{2} \rho_{2}},
$$

and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{K_{2}}{K_{1}} &=\left(\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}\right)^{2} \frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{2}} \\
&=\left(\frac{1470}{330}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{1.293 \times 10^{-3}} \\
&=1.53 \times 10^{4} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for the mixture,

$$
\begin{aligned}
K &=\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V}+\frac{K_{2} V_{2}}{K_{1} V}\right) K_{1}=(0.99+153) K_{1} \approx 154 K_{1}, \\
v &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{K \rho}} \approx \frac{1}{\sqrt{154 K_{1} \rho_{1}}}=\frac{1470}{\sqrt{154}}=118 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is much less than the velocity of sound in pure water or air. 

\section{0}

Consider the spherically symmetric expansion of a homogeneous, selfgravitating gas with negligible pressure. The initial conditions of expansion are unspecifed; instead, you are given that when the density is $\rho_{0}$, a fluid element at a radius $R_{0}$ from the origin has a velocity $v_{0}$.

(a) Find $v(R)$.

(b) Describe the ultimate fate of the gas in terms of $v_{0}, R_{0}$ and $\rho_{0}$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider the motion of a unit mass at the surface of the gas, conservation of mechanical energy gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} v_{0}^{2}-\frac{G M}{R_{0}}=\frac{1}{2} v^{2}-\frac{G M}{R},
$$

where $M=4 \pi \rho_{0} R_{0}^{3} / 3$ is the total mass of the gas. Hence the speed of the unit mass when the radius of the volume of gas is $R$ is

$$
v=\sqrt{v_{0}^{2}+\frac{8}{3} \pi G \rho_{0} R_{0}^{3}\left(\frac{1}{R}-\frac{1}{R_{0}}\right)} .
$$

(b) As $R$ increases, $v$ decreases, and finally $v=0$ and expansion stops when the radius becomes

$$
R=\left[\frac{1}{R_{0}}-\frac{3 v_{0}^{2}}{8 \pi G \rho_{0} R_{0}^{3}}\right]^{-1}
$$

\section{1}

An incompressible fluid of mass density $\rho$, viscosity $\eta$ is pumped in steady-state laminar flow through a circular pipe of internal radius $R$ and length $L$. The pressure at the inlet end is $p_{1}$, the pressure at the exit is $p_{2}$, $p_{1}>p_{2}$.

Let $Q$ be the mass of fluid that flows through the pipe per unit time. Compute $Q$. 

\section{Solution:}

Use cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ with the $z$-axis along the axis of the pipe. For laminar flow the velocity $v$ of the fluid has components

$$
v_{r}=v_{\varphi}=0, \quad v_{z}=v .
$$

Furthermore, because of symmetry, $v=v(r)$. Then in the Navier-Stokes equation

$$
\rho \frac{\partial \mathbf{v}}{\partial t}+\rho(\mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla) \mathbf{v}-\eta \nabla^{2} \mathbf{v}+\nabla p=\mathbf{F}
$$

$\partial \mathbf{v} / \partial t=0$ for steady-state motion,

$$
(\mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla) \mathbf{v}=v_{z} \frac{\partial v_{z}}{\partial z} \mathbf{e}_{z}=0,
$$

as $v=v_{z}(r)$, and the external force per unit volume $\mathbf{F}$ is zero provided gravity can be neglected, we have

$$
\nabla p=\eta \nabla^{2} \mathbf{v} .
$$

This becomes

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial z}=\frac{\eta}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r \frac{\partial v}{\partial r}\right), \quad \frac{\partial p}{\partial r}=\frac{\partial p}{\partial \varphi}=0
$$

for $\mathbf{v}=v(r) \mathbf{e}_{z}$. As the right-hand side of the first equation depends on $r$ while $p$ is a function of $z$, either side must be a constant, which is

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial z}=\frac{p_{2}-p_{1}}{L}=-\frac{\Delta p}{L},
$$

where $\Delta p=p_{1}-p_{2}$. Hence

$$
\frac{d}{d r}\left(r \frac{d v}{d r}\right)=-\left(\frac{\Delta p}{\eta L}\right) r .
$$

Integration gives

$$
v=-\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{\Delta p}{\eta L}\right) r^{2}+C_{1} \ln r+C_{2}
$$

$C_{1}, C_{2}$ being constants. As

$$
v(r)=\text { finite }, \quad v(R)=0,
$$

we require

$$
C_{1}=0, \quad C_{2}=\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{\Delta p}{\eta L}\right) R^{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
v=\frac{\Delta p}{4 \eta L}\left(R^{2}-r^{2}\right) .
$$

The mass of the fluid flowing through the pipe per unit time is then

$$
Q=\rho \int_{0}^{R} v \cdot 2 \pi r d r=\frac{\pi \rho R^{4} \Delta p}{8 \eta L} .
$$

\section{2}

A sphere of radius $R$ moves with uniform velocity $\mathbf{u}$ in an incompressible ( $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{v}(x)=0, \mathbf{v}(x)$ being the velocity of the fluid), non-viscous, ideal fluid.

(a) Determine the velocity $v$ of the fluid passing any point on the surface of the sphere.

(b) Calculate the pressure distribution over the surface of the sphere.

(c) What is the force necessary to keep the sphere in uniform motion?

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-468.jpg?height=215&width=498&top_left_y=1237&top_left_x=544)

Fig. $1.248$.

\section{Solution:}

We can consider the sphere as being at rest while the fluid flows past it with velocity $v=-u$ as shown in Fig. 1.248. Use spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ with origin at the center of the sphere such that the velocity of the fluid is in the direction $\theta=\pi$. Define the velocity potential $\phi$ by

$$
\mathbf{v}=-\nabla \phi .
$$

The incompressibility of the fluid means that

$$
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{v}=-\nabla^{2} \phi=0
$$

Thus $\phi$ satisfies Laplace's equation. The boundary conditions are

$$
-\left(\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r}\right)_{R}=-u \cos \theta
$$

as the surface of the sphere is impenetrable, and

$$
\phi=0 \quad \text { for } \quad r \rightarrow \infty
$$

as $v=-u=$ constant at large distances from the sphere.

The general solution of Laplace's equation is

$$
\phi=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m=0}^{n}\left(a_{n m} r^{n}+b_{n m} r^{-n-1}\right) P_{n}^{m}(\cos \theta) e^{\pm i m \varphi} .
$$

As the geometry is cylindrically symmetric, $\phi$ is independent of $\varphi$ and we have to take $m=0$. Thus we have

$$
\phi=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(a_{n} r^{n}+b_{n} r^{-n-1}\right) P_{n}(\cos \theta),
$$

where $P_{n}(\cos \theta)$ are the Legendre polynomials, and $a_{n}, b_{n}$ are arbitrary constants. As $\phi=0$ for $r \rightarrow \infty$, we require $a_{n}=0$. As

$$
\left(\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r}\right)_{R}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-n-1) b_{n} R^{-n-2} P_{n}(\cos \theta)=u P_{1}(\cos \theta)
$$

we require

$$
b_{n}=0 \text { for all } n \neq 1
$$

and

$$
b_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} u R^{3} .
$$

Hence

$$
\phi=-\frac{u R^{3}}{2 r^{2}} \cos \theta
$$

(a) At a point $(R, \theta)$ on the sphere the velocity of the fluid is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{v} &=-\nabla \phi=\left[-\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r} \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{\partial \phi}{r \partial \theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}\right]_{r=R} \\
&=-\frac{1}{2} u R^{3}\left[\frac{2}{r^{3}} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}+\frac{\sin \theta}{r^{3}} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}\right]_{r=R} \\
&=-u \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{1}{2} u \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Bernoulli's equation for the irrotational steady flow of a nonviscous, incompressible fluid is

$$
\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+p+U=\text { constant },
$$

where $U=$ constant if there is no external force. Consider a point $(R, \theta)$ on the surface of the sphere and a point at infinity, where the pressure is $p_{0}$. Then

$$
\frac{\rho}{2} u^{2}\left(\cos ^{2} \theta+\frac{1}{4} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+p=\frac{1}{2} \rho u^{2}+p_{0}
$$

or

$$
p(R, \theta)=\frac{3}{8} \rho u^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+p_{0} .
$$

This gives the distribution of the pressure over the surface of the sphere.

(c) The net total force exerted by the pressure on the sphere is in the direction of $u$ and has magnitude

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{z} &=\int p \cos \theta d S \\
&=\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(\frac{3}{8} \rho u^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+p_{0}\right) \cdot 2 \pi R \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta \cdot R d \theta \\
&=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence no force is required to keep the sphere in uniform motion. This can be anticipated as the sphere moves uniformly without friction. 

\section{PART II}

ANALYTICAL MECHANICS 

\section{LAGRANGE'S EQUATIONS (2001-2027)}

\section{1}

A massless spring of rest length $l_{0}$ (with no tension) has a point mass $m$ connected to one end and the other end fixed so the spring hangs in the gravity field as shown in Fig. 2.1. The motion of the system is only in one vertical plane.

(a) Write down the Lagrangian.

(b) Find Lagrange's equations using variables $\theta, \lambda=\left(r-r_{0}\right) / r_{0}$, where $r_{0}$ is the rest length (hanging with mass $m$ ). Use $\omega_{s}^{2}=k / m, \omega_{p}^{2}=g / r_{0}$.

(c) Discuss the lowest order approximation to the motion when $\lambda$ and $\theta$ are small with the initial conditions $\theta=0, \dot{\lambda}=0, \lambda=A, \dot{\theta}=\omega_{p} B$ at $t=0$. $A$ and $B$ are constants.

(d) Discuss the next order approximation to the motion. Under what conditions will the $\lambda$ motion resonate? Can this be realized physically?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-473.jpg?height=295&width=204&top_left_y=1034&top_left_x=654)

Fig, 2,1.

\section{Solution:}

(a) In polar coordinates $(r, \theta)$ as shown in Fig. 2.1, the mass $m$ has velocity $\mathbf{v}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta})$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right), \\
&V=-m g r \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2} k\left(r-l_{0}\right)^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

$k$ being the spring constant. The Lagrangian of $m$ is therefore

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+m g r \cos \theta-\frac{1}{2} k\left(r-l_{0}\right)^{2} .
$$

(b)

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial r}=0
$$

gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{r}-m r \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g \cos \theta+k\left(r-l_{0}\right)=0 . \\
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

gives

$$
m r^{2} \ddot{\theta}+2 m r \dot{r} \dot{\theta}+m g r \sin \theta=0 .
$$

The rest length of the spring with mass $m$ hanging, $r_{0}$, is given by Hooke's law

$$
k\left(r_{0}-l_{0}\right)=m g .
$$

Thus with $\lambda=\left(r-r_{0}\right) / r_{0}$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
r-l_{0}=\lambda r_{0}+\frac{m g}{k}, \\
r=r_{0}(1+\lambda), \quad \dot{r}=r_{0} \dot{\lambda}, \quad \ddot{r}=r_{0} \ddot{\lambda},
\end{gathered}
$$

and the equations of motion becone

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\ddot{\lambda}+\frac{k \lambda}{m}-(1+\lambda) \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{g}{r_{0}}(1-\cos \theta)=0, \\
(1+\lambda) \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{\lambda} \dot{\theta}+\frac{g}{r_{0}} \sin \theta=0
\end{array}
$$

or, with $\omega_{s}^{2}=\frac{k}{m}, \omega_{p}^{2}=\frac{g}{r_{0}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\lambda}+\left(\omega_{s}^{2}-\dot{\theta}^{2}\right) \lambda-\dot{\theta}^{2}+\omega_{p}^{2}(1-\cos \theta) &=0, \\
(1+\lambda) \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{\lambda} \dot{\theta}+\omega_{p}^{2} \sin \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) When $\lambda$ and $\theta$ are small, we can neglect second order quantities in $\theta, \lambda, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\lambda}$, and the equations of motion reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\lambda}+\omega_{s}^{2} \lambda=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}+\omega_{p}^{2} \theta=0
\end{aligned}
$$

in the lowest order approximation. For the given initial conditions, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\lambda=A \cos \left(\omega_{s} t\right), \\
&\theta=B \sin \left(\omega_{p} t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\lambda$ and $\theta$ each oscillates sinusoidally with angular frequencies $\omega_{s}$ and $\omega_{p}$ respectively, the two oscillations differing in phase by $\pi / 2$.

(d) If we retain also terms of the second order, the equations become

$$
\begin{gathered}
\ddot{\lambda}+\omega_{s}^{2} \lambda=\dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{p}^{2} \theta^{2}, \\
(1+\lambda) \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{\lambda} \dot{\theta}+\omega_{p}^{2} \theta=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Using the results of the lowest order approximation, the first equation above can be approximated as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\lambda}+\omega_{s}^{2} \lambda & \approx \frac{1}{2} B^{2} \omega_{p}^{2}\left[2 \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{p} t\right)-\sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{p} t\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{4} B^{2} \omega_{p}^{2}\left[3 \cos \left(2 \omega_{p} t\right)+1\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\lambda$ may resonate if $\omega_{s}=2 \omega_{p}$. However this is unlikely to realize physically since as the amplitude of $\lambda$ increases toward a resonance the lowest order approximation no longer holds and higher order effects will take place. Furthermore the nonlinear properties of the spring will also come into play, invalidating the original simplified model.

\section{2}

A disk of mass $M$ and radius $R$ slides without friction on a horizontal surface. Another disk of mass $m$ and radius $r$ is pinned through its center to a point off the center of the first disk by a distance $b$, so that it can rotate without friction on the first disk as shown in Fig. 2.2. Describe the motion and identify its constants.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Take generalized coordinates as follows: $x, y$, the coordinates of the center of mass of the larger disk, $\theta$, the angle of rotation of the larger disk 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-476.jpg?height=442&width=436&top_left_y=248&top_left_x=257)

Fig, 2.2.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-476.jpg?height=257&width=415&top_left_y=394&top_left_x=875)

Fig. 2,3.

and $\varphi$ the angle of rotation of the smaller disk as shown in Fig. 2.3. The center of mass of the smaller disk has coordinates

$$
x+b \cos \theta, \quad y+b \sin \theta
$$

and velocity components

$$
\dot{x}-b \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, \quad \dot{y}+b \dot{\theta} \cos \theta .
$$

Hence the total kinetic energy of the system of the two disks is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T=& \frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}-b \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)^{2}+(\dot{y}+b \dot{\theta} \cos \theta)^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{4} m r^{2} \dot{\phi}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V=T \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-2 b \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta+2 b \dot{\theta} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right]+\frac{1}{4} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0 .
$$

As

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0, \quad \frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)=0
$$

we have

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=\text { constant },
$$

or

$$
(M+m) \dot{x}-m b \dot{\theta} \sin \theta=\text { constant } .
$$

As $\partial L / \partial y=0$, we have $\partial L / \partial \dot{y}=$ constant, or

$$
(M+m) \dot{y}+m b \dot{\theta} \cos \theta=\text { constant } .
$$

As $\partial L / \partial \varphi=0$, we have $\partial L / \partial \dot{\varphi}=$ constant, or

$$
\dot{\varphi}=\text { constant } .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=-m b \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta-m b \dot{\theta} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}+m b^{2} \dot{\theta}-m b \dot{x} \sin \theta+m b \dot{y} \cos \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

we have the equation of motion

$$
\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} \ddot{\theta}+m b^{2} \ddot{\theta}-m b \ddot{x} \sin \theta+m b \ddot{y} \cos \theta=0 .
$$

Equations (1)-(4) describe the motion of the system. Since $V=0$ and $T+V=$ constant as there is no external force, the total kinetic energy of the system, $T$, is a conserved quantity. Conservation of the angular momentum about the center of mass of the system requires that, as $\dot{\varphi}=$ constant, $\dot{\theta}=$ constant too.

\section{3}

A uniform solid cylinder of radius $R$ and mass $M$ rests on a horizontal plane and an identical cylinder rests on it, touching it along the highest generator as shown in Fig 2.4. The upper cylinder is given an infinitesimal displacement so that both cylinders roll without slipping. (a) What is the Lagrangian of the system?

(b) What are the constants of the motion?

(c) Show that as long as the cylinders remain in contact

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{12 g(1-\cos \theta)}{R\left(17+4 \cos \theta-4 \cos ^{2} \theta\right)},
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle which the plane containing the axes makes with the vertical.

(Wisconsin)
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-478.jpg?height=348&width=552&top_left_y=648&top_left_x=524)

Fig. 2.4.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The system possesses two degrees of freedom so that two generalized coordinates are required. For these we use $\theta_{1}$, the angle of rotation of the lower cylinder, and $\theta$, the angle made by the plane containing the two axes of the cylinders and the vertical.

Initially the plane containing the two axes of the cylinders is vertical. At a later time, this plane makes an angle $\theta$ with the vertical. The original point of contact, $A$, now moves to $A^{\prime}$ on the lower cylinder and to $A^{\prime \prime}$ on the upper cylinder. With the angles so defined we have from Fig. 2.4

$$
\theta_{1}+\theta=\theta_{2}-\theta,
$$

or

$$
\theta_{2}=\theta_{1}+2 \theta .
$$

Taking Cartesian coordinates $(x, y)$ in the vertical plane normal to the axes of the cylinders and through their centers of mass, as shown in Fig. 2.4, we have, at $t>0$, for the lower cylinder

$$
x_{1}=-R \theta_{1}, \quad y_{1}=R,
$$

and for the upper cylinder

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{2}=x_{1}+2 R \sin \theta, \\
&y_{2}=3 R-2(R-\cos \theta)=R+2 R \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding velocity components are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{x}_{1}=-R \dot{\theta}_{1}, \quad \dot{y}_{1}=0, \\
&\dot{x}_{2}=-R \dot{\theta}_{1}+2 R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, \quad \dot{y}_{2}=-2 R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The kinetic energy of the lower cylinder is thus

$$
T_{1}=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}=\frac{3}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2},
$$

and that of the upper cylinder is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{2} &=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}-4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+4 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}+4 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4} M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+12 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The potential energy of the system, taking the horizontal plane as level of reference, is

$$
V=M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)=2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+6 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right]-2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As only gravity is involved, the total mechanical energy of the system is a constant of the motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=T+V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+6 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right]+2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g \\
&=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, if $\partial L / \partial q_{i}=0$, Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

requires that $\partial L / \partial \dot{q}_{i}$ is conserved. For the system under consideration, $\partial L / \partial \theta_{1}=0$ so that

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}_{1}}=M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}+\dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)\right]=\text { constant } .
$$

(c) As long as the cylinders remain in contact the results of (b) hold. Initially, $\theta=0, \dot{\theta_{1}}=\dot{\theta}=0$, so that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left\{3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+6 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right\}+2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g=4 M R g, \\
M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}+\dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)\right]=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

These combine to give

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}\left[18-(1-2 \cos \theta)^{2}\right]=\frac{12}{R}(1-\cos \theta) g,
$$

i.e.

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{12(1-\cos \theta) g}{R\left(17+4 \cos \theta-4 \cos ^{2} \theta\right)} .
$$

\section{4}

Two particles of the same mass $m$ are constrained to slide along a thin rod of mass $M$ and length $L$, which is itself free to move in any manner. Two identical springs link the particles with the central point of the rod. Consider only motions of this system in which the lengths of the springs (i.e. the distances of the two particles from the center of the rod) are equal. Taking this to be an isolated system in space, find equations of motion for it and solve them (up to the point of doing integrations). Describe qualitatively the motion.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Use a fixed Cartesian coordinate frame, and a moving frame with origin at the midpoint $O$ of the rod and its Cartesian axes parallel to those of 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-481.jpg?height=282&width=464&top_left_y=206&top_left_x=495)

Fig. 2.5.

the former respectively. Let $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ be the spherical coordinates of a point referring to the moving frame, as shown in Fig. 2.5. Then the point $O$ has coordinates $(x, y, z)$ in the fixed frame and the two masses have spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ and $(-r, \theta, \varphi)$ in the moving frame.

The kinetic energy of a system is equal to the kinetic energy it would have if all its mass were concentrated at the center of mass plus the kinetic energy of motion about the center of mass. As $O$ is the center of mass of the system, we have

$$
T=\frac{1}{2}(M+2 m)\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+T_{\text {rot }},
$$

where $T_{\text {rot }}$ is the rotational kinetic energy of the rod. The angular velocity of the rod about $O$ is

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta}-\dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi},
$$

resolved along its principal axes, the corresponding moments of inertia being

$$
I_{r}=0, \quad I_{\theta}=\frac{1}{12} M L^{2}, \quad I_{\varphi}=\frac{1}{12} M L^{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{\text {rot }} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(I_{r} \omega_{r}^{2}+I_{\theta} \omega_{\theta}^{2}+I_{\varphi} \omega_{\varphi}^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{24} M L^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The system is in free space so the only potential energy is that due to the action of the springs,

$$
V=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2}=K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2},
$$

where $K$ and $r_{0}$ are the spring constant and the natural length of each spring respectively. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(M+2 m)\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
&+\frac{1}{24} M L^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the following constants of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+2 m) \dot{x} &=\text { constant } \\
(M+2 m) \dot{y} &=\text { constant } \\
(M+2 m) \dot{z} &=\text { constant } \\
\left(2 m r^{2}+\frac{1}{12} M L^{2}\right) \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta &=\text { constant }
\end{aligned}
$$

The first three equations show that the velocity $(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, \dot{z})$ of the center of mass of the system is a constant vector. Thus the center of mass moves in a uniform rectilinear motion with whatever velocity it had initially. The last equation shows that the component of the angular momentum about the $z^{\prime}$-axis is a constant of the motion. Since the axis has been arbitrarily chosen, this means that the angular momentum is conserved.

Lagrange's equations also give the following equations of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{K}{m}\left(r-r_{0}\right)=0, \\
&\left(r^{2}+\frac{M L^{2}}{24 m}\right) \ddot{\theta}+2 r \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-\left(r^{2}+\frac{M L^{2}}{24 m}\right) \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

These and the $\dot{\varphi}$ equation above describe the motion about the center of mass of the system.

Thus under the constraint that the two masses $m$ slide along the rod symmetrically with respect to the midpoint $O$, the motion of the center of mass $O$ of the system is a uniform rectilinear motion, and the motion of the system about $O$ is such that the total angular momentum about $O$ is conserved.

\section{5}

A rectangle coordinate system with axes $x, y, z$ is rotating relative to an inertial frame with constant angular velocity $\omega$ about the $z$-axis. A particle of mass $m$ moves under a force whose potential is $V(x, y, z)$. Set up the Lagrange equations of motion in the coordinate system $x, y, z$. Show that their equations are the same as those for a particle in a fixed coordinate system acted on by the force $-\nabla V$ and a force derivable from a velocity-dependent potential $U$. Find $U$.

\section{(Wisconsin)}

\section{Solution:}

Let the inertial frame have the same origin as the rotating frame and axes $x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}$. Denote the velocities of the particle in the two frames by $\mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}$. As

$$
\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}
$$

with

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega), \quad \mathbf{r}=(x, y, z), \quad \mathbf{v}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, \dot{z}),
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
v^{\prime 2} &=v^{2}+2 \mathbf{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}+(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})^{2} \\
&=\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}+2 \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)+\omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Lagrangian of the particle in the inertial frame, expressed in quantities referring to the rotating frame,

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)-V .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}-2 m \omega \dot{y}-m \omega^{2} x+\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=0, \\
&m \ddot{y}+2 m \omega \dot{x}-m \omega^{2} y+\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}=0, \\
&m \ddot{z}+\frac{\partial V}{\partial z}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a particle of mass $m$ moving in a fixed frame $(x, y, z)$ under a force $-\nabla V$ and an additional velocity-dependent potential $U$, the Lagrangian is

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-V-U .
$$

A comparison of this with the Lagrangian obtained previously gives

$$
U=-m \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) .
$$

This Lagrangian would obviously give rise to the same equations of motion.

\section{6}

(a) Show that the moment of inertia of a thin rod about its center of mass is $m l^{2} / 12$.

(b) A long thin tube of negligible mass is pivoted so that it may rotate without friction in a horizontal plane. A thin rod of mass $M$ and length $l$ slides without friction in the tube. Choose a suitable set of coordinates and write Lagrange's equations for this system.

(c) Initially the rod is centered over the pivot and the tube is rotating with angular velocity $\omega_{0}$. Show that the rod is unstable in this position, and describe its subsequent motion if it is disturbed slightly. What are the radial and angular velocities of the rod after a long time? (Assume the tube is long enough that the rod is still inside.)

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) By definition the moment of inertia is 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-485.jpg?height=250&width=384&top_left_y=218&top_left_x=527)

Fig. 2.6.

$$
I=\sum_{i} R_{i}^{2} \Delta m_{i}=\int_{-\frac{1}{2}}^{\frac{l}{2}} x^{2} \rho d x=\frac{1}{12} \rho l^{3}=\frac{1}{12} m l^{2} .
$$

(b) Take the angle $\theta$ between the thin tube and a fixed horizontal line through the pivot and the distance $x$ of the center of mass of the thin rod from the pivot of the tube, as shown in Fig. 2.6, as the generalized coordinates. We have

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+x^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{24} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}, \quad V=0,
$$

and the Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+x^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{24} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}=x \dot{\theta}^{2} \\
&M\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{12} l^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }=C, \quad \text { say. }
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The initial conditions $x=0, \dot{\theta}=\omega_{0}$ give

$$
C=\frac{1}{2} M l^{2} \omega_{0},
$$

i.e.

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{l^{2} \omega_{0}}{12 x^{2}+l^{2}} .
$$

We then have

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{x}^{2}}{d x}=\frac{l^{4} \omega_{0}^{2} x}{\left(12 x^{2}+l^{2}\right)^{2}} .
$$

Integrating we obtain, as initially $x=0, \dot{x}=0$,

$$
\dot{x}^{2}=\frac{l^{2} \omega_{0}^{2} x^{2}}{12 x^{2}+l^{2}} .
$$

It is noted that the speed of the rod in the tube,

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{l \omega_{0}}{\sqrt{12+\frac{l^{2}}{x^{2}}}},
$$

increases as its distance from the initial position increases. Thus the rod is unstable at the initial position. For $t \rightarrow \infty, x \rightarrow \infty, \dot{\theta} \rightarrow 0$ and $\dot{x} \rightarrow l \omega_{0} / \sqrt{12}$. Hence, after a long time, the rotation will slow down to zero while the speed of the rod in the tube will tend to an upper limit. The distance $x$ however will be ever increasing.

\section{7}

A block of mass $M$ is rigidly connected to a massless circular track of radius $a$ on a frictionless horizontal table as shown in Fig. 2.7. A particle of mass $m$ is confined to move without friction on the circular track which is vertical.

(a) Set up the Lagrangian, using $\theta$ as one coordinate.

(b) Find the equations of motion.

(c) In the limit of small angles, solve that equations of motion for $\theta$ as a function of time.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-486.jpg?height=246&width=520&top_left_y=1562&top_left_x=459)

Fig. 2.7. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the motion of the system is confined to a vertical plane, use a fixed coordinate frame $x, y$ and choose the $x$ coordinate of the center of the circular track and the angle $\theta$ giving the location of $m$ on the circular track as the generalized coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.7. The coordinates of the mass $m$ are then $(x+a \sin \theta,-a \cos \theta)$. As $M$ is rigidly connected to the circular track its velocity is $(\dot{x}, 0)$. Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}+a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta)^{2}+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right]+m g a \cos \theta \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 a \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right]+m g a \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0 \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=M \dot{x}+m \dot{x}+m a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=-m a \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta-m g a \sin \theta, \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m a^{2} \dot{\theta}+m a \dot{x} \cos \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(M+m) \ddot{x}+m a \ddot{\theta} \cos \theta-m a \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin \theta=0, \\
&a \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) For small oscillations, $\theta$ and $\dot{\theta}$ are small quantities of the 1st order. Neglecting higher order terms the equations of motion become

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+m) \ddot{x}+m a \ddot{\theta} &=0, \\
a \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x}+g \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Eliminating $\ddot{x}$ we have

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{(M+m) g \theta}{M a}=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
\theta=A \sin (\omega t)+B \cos (\omega t),
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{(M+m) g / M a}$ is the angular frequency of oscillation and $A$ and $B$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions.

\section{8}

Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in a bound orbit with potential $V(r)=-k / r$. Using polar coordinates in the plane of the orbit:

(a) Find $p_{r}$ and $p_{\theta}$ as functions of $r, \theta, \dot{r}$ and $\dot{\theta}$. Is either one constant?

(b) Using the virial theorem show that

$$
J_{r}+J_{\theta}=\oint \frac{k}{r} d t,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
&J_{r}=\oint p_{r} d r, \\
&J_{\theta}=\oint p_{\theta} d \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Show that

$$
\left(J_{r}+J_{\theta}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{-2 \pi^{2} m k^{2}}{E}},
$$

using

$$
\int_{r_{-}}^{r_{+}} \frac{d r}{\sqrt{-r^{2}+a r-b}}=\pi, \quad r_{\pm}=\frac{1}{2}\left(a \pm \sqrt{a^{2}-4 b}\right) .
$$

(d) Using the results of (c) show that the period of the orbit is the same for the $r$ and $\theta$ motions, namely,

$$
\tau=\pi k \sqrt{\frac{m}{-2 E^{3}}} .
$$



\section{Solution:}

(a) We have

$$
