(c) If, alternatively, the middle mass is driven harmonically at a frequency $\omega_{0}=2 \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$, will it move in or out of phase with the driving motion? Explain.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-541.jpg?height=95&width=417&top_left_y=1231&top_left_x=523)

Fig. 2.28.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}$ be the displacements of the three masses, counting from the left, from their equilibrium positions. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{3}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)^{2} .
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M \ddot{x}_{1}+k\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)=0, \\
&m \ddot{x}_{2}+k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)+k\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)=0, \\
&M \ddot{x}_{3}+k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
x_{i}=x_{i 0} e^{i \omega t} .
$$

Substitution gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(k-\omega^{2} M\right) x_{10}-k x_{20} &=0 \\
-k x_{10}+\left(2 k-\omega^{2} m\right) x_{20}-k x_{30} &=0 \\
-k x_{20}+\left(k-\omega^{2} M\right) x_{30} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution where not all amplitudes vanish, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
k-\omega^{2} M & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-\omega^{2} m & -k \\
0 & -k & k-\omega^{2} M
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

which has solutions

$$
\omega=0, \quad \pm \sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \pm \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 M}{m}\right)} .
$$

Hence the system has three normal-mode (angular) frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 M}{m}\right)} .
$$

(b) For $\omega=\omega_{1}$, Eqs. (2) give

$$
x_{10}=x_{20}=x_{30}, \quad \text { or } \quad x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3} \text {. }
$$

Equations (1) then give

$$
x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}=a t+b,
$$

where $a, b$ are constants, showing that in this mode the three masses undergo translation as a rigid body without oscillation.

For $\omega=\omega_{2}$, Eqs. (2) give

$$
x_{2}=0, \quad x_{3}=-x_{1},
$$

and Eqs. (1) give

$$
\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega_{2}^{2} x_{1}=0, \quad \ddot{x}_{3}+\omega_{2}^{2} x_{3}=0 .
$$

The solutions are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right) \\
&x_{2}=0 \\
&x_{3}=-x_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In this mode the middle mass stays stationary while the two end masses oscillate harmonically exactly out of phase with each other.

For $\omega=\omega_{3}$, we have, similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right), \\
&x_{2}=-\frac{2 M x_{1}}{m}, \\
&x_{3}=x_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the two outer masses oscillate with the same amplitude and phase, while the inner one oscillates out of phase and with a different amplitude.

The general longitudinal motion of the system is some linear conibination of the normal-modes:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=a t+b+A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right), \\
&x_{2}=a t+b-\frac{2 M}{m}\left[C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right], \\
&x_{3}=a t+b-A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)-B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial conditions that at $t=0$,

$$
x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}=0, \quad \dot{x}_{1}=\frac{P_{0}}{m}, \quad \dot{x}_{2}=\dot{x}_{3}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
a &=\frac{P_{0}}{m+2 M}, \\
A &=\frac{P_{0}}{2 M \omega_{2}}, \\
C &=\frac{P_{0} m}{2 M(m+2 M) \omega_{3}}, \\
b &=B=D=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the motion of the left-hand mass is given by

$$
x_{1}=P_{0}\left[\frac{t}{m+2 M}+\frac{\sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)}{2 M \omega_{2}}+\frac{m \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)}{2 M(m+2 M) \omega_{3}}\right] \text {. }
$$

(c) Suppose the middle mass has motion given by

$$
x_{2}=x_{20} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
$$

The first equation of $(1)$ now becomes

$$
\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega_{2}^{2} x_{1}=\omega_{2}^{2} x_{20} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
$$

In steady state $x_{1}$ moves with the same frequency as the driving motion:

$$
x_{1}=x_{10} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \text {. }
$$

Substitution in the above gives

$$
x_{1}=\left(\frac{\omega_{2}^{2}}{\omega_{2}^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}}\right) x_{20} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)=\left(\frac{m}{m-4 M}\right) x_{20} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
$$

As $m-4 M<0$, the left-hand mass will move out of phase with the driving motion.

\section{3}

Two pendulums of equal length $l$ and equal mass $m$ are coupled by a massless spring of constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.29. The unstretched length of the spring is equal to the distance between the supports.

(a) Set up the exact Lagrangian in terms of appropriate generalized coordinates and velocities. (b) Find the normal coordinates and frequencies of small vibrations about equilibrium.

(c) Suppose that initially the two masses are at rest. An impulsive force gives a horizontal velocity $v$ toward the right to the mass on the left. What is the motion of the system in terms of the normal coordinates?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Assume the masses are constrained to move in a vertical plane. Let the distance between the two supports be $d$, which is also the unstretched length of the spring, and use Cartesian coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.29. The masses have coordinates

$$
\left(l \sin \theta_{1},-l \cos \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(d+l \sin \theta_{2},-l \cos \theta_{2}\right)
$$

and velocities

$$
\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right),
$$

respectively. The length of the spring is the distance between the two masses:

$$
\sqrt{\left(d+l \sin \theta_{2}-l \sin \theta_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(l \cos \theta_{2}-l \cos \theta_{1}\right)^{2}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-545.jpg?height=376&width=419&top_left_y=1188&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 2.29.

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}\right)+m g l\left(\cos \theta_{1}+\cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k\left(\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

534

Problems \& Solutions on Mechanics

(b) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_{1}} \\
& =m g l \sin \theta_{1}-k\left(\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right) \\
& \times \frac{d l \cos \theta_{1}+l^{2} \sin \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}} \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left[\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right] \times \frac{d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}} \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{2 l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{d}}}\right)\left[d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)\right] \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left[\frac{l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{d}\right]\left[d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)\right] \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting second and higher order terms in $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ which are small quantities. Similarly,

$$
-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_{2}}=m g l \theta_{2}+k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right) .
$$

Thus the equations of motion for small oscillations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\frac{g \theta_{1}}{l}-\frac{k\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{m}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g \theta_{2}}{l}+\frac{k\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{m}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)
$$

and the above give

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\ddot{\eta}+\frac{g \eta}{l}=0, \\
\ddot{\xi}+\left(\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}\right) \xi=0 .
\end{array}
$$

These show that $\eta$ and $\xi$ are the normal coordinates with the corresponding normal (angular) frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}} .
$$

(c) The solutions of the equations of motion in the normal coordinates are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\eta=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right)+B \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \\
&\xi=C \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+D \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

At $t=0, \theta_{1}=\theta_{2}=0$, giving $\eta=\xi=0$; and $\dot{\theta}_{1}=\frac{v}{l}, \dot{\theta}_{2}=0$, giving $\dot{\eta}=\dot{\xi}=\frac{v}{2 l}$. Thus

$$
A=C=0, \quad B=\frac{v}{2 l \omega_{1}}, \quad D=\frac{v}{2 l \omega_{2}},
$$

and

$$
\eta=\frac{v \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right)}{2 l \omega_{1}}, \quad \xi=\frac{v \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)}{2 l \omega_{2}},
$$

giving the motion of the system in terms of the normal coordinates.

\section{4}

Four identical masses are connected by four identical springs and constrained to move on a frictionless circle of radius $b$ as shown in Fig. 2.30.

(a) How many normal-modes of small oscillations are there?

(b) What are the frequencies of small oscillations?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-547.jpg?height=235&width=225&top_left_y=1570&top_left_x=606)

Fig. 2.30. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Take the lengths of $\operatorname{arc} s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{3}$, and $s_{4}$ of the four masses from their initial equilibrium positions as the generalized coordinates. The kinetic energy of the system is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{s}_{1}^{2}+\dot{s}_{2}^{2}+\dot{s}_{3}^{2}+\dot{s}_{4}^{2}\right) .
$$

As the springs are identical, at equilibrium the four masses are positioned symmetrically on the circle, i.e. the arc between two neighboring masses, the $n$th and the $(n+1)$ th, subtends an angle $\frac{\pi}{2}$ at the center. When the neighboring masses are displaced from the equilibrium positions, the spring connecting them will extend by

$$
2 b \sin \left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{s_{n+1}}{b}-\frac{s_{n}}{b}+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right]-2 b \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \approx \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(s_{n+1}-s_{n}\right)
$$

for small oscillations for which $s_{n}$ are small.

Thus the potential energy is

$$
V=\frac{k}{2}\left(s_{1}^{2}+s_{2}^{2}+s_{3}^{2}+s_{4}^{2}-s_{1} s_{2}-s_{2} s_{3}-s_{3} s_{4}-s_{4} s_{1}\right) .
$$

This system has four degrees of freedom and hence four normal-modes.

(b) The $T$ and $V$ matrices are

$$
\mathbf{T}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
m & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & m & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & m & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & m
\end{array}\right), \quad \mathbf{V}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
k & -\frac{k}{2} & 0 & -\frac{k}{2} \\
-\frac{k}{2} & k & -\frac{k}{2} & 0 \\
0 & -\frac{k}{2} & k & -\frac{k}{2} \\
-\frac{k}{2} & 0 & -\frac{k}{2} & k
\end{array}\right)
$$

so the secular equation is

$$
\left|\mathbf{V}-\omega^{2} \mathbf{T}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{cccc}
k-m \omega^{2} & -\frac{k}{2} & 0 & -\frac{k}{2} \\
-\frac{k}{2} & k-m \omega^{2} & -\frac{k}{2} & 0 \\
0 & -\frac{k}{2} & k-m \omega^{2} & -\frac{k}{2} \\
-\frac{k}{2} & 0 & -\frac{k}{2} & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

which has four roots $0,0, \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, \sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}$. Hence the angular frequencies of small oscillations are $\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$ and $\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}$. 

\section{5}

A simple pendulum of length $4 l$ and mass $m$ is hung from another simple pendulum of length $3 l$ and mass $m$. It is possible for this system to perform small oscillations about equilibrium such that a point on the lower pendulum undergoes no horizontal displacement. Locate that point.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Use Cartesian coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.31. The upper and lower messes have, respectively, coordinates

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(3 l \sin \theta_{1},-3 l \cos \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(3 l \sin \theta_{1}+4 l \sin \theta_{2},-3 l \cos \theta_{1}-4 l \cos \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and velocities

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(3 l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, 3 l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(3 l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+4 l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, 3 l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+4 l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-549.jpg?height=502&width=273&top_left_y=1096&top_left_x=572)

Fig. 2.31.

The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[18 l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+16 l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+24 l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\right] \\
&+m g\left(6 l \cos \theta_{1}+4 l \cos \theta_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
3 \ddot{\theta}_{1}+2 \ddot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)+2 \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)+\frac{g \sin \theta_{1}}{l}=0 \text {, }
$$

or, retaining only first order terms for small oscillations,

$$
3 \ddot{\theta}_{1}+2 \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g \theta_{1}}{l}=0 \text {, }
$$

and, similarly,

$$
3 \ddot{\theta}_{1}+4 \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g \theta_{2}}{l}=0 .
$$

$\operatorname{Try} \theta_{1}=\theta_{10} e^{i \omega t}, \theta_{2}=\theta_{20} e^{i \omega t}$. The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{g}{l}-3 \omega^{2}\right) \theta_{10}-2 \omega^{2} \theta_{20} &=0 \\
-3 \omega^{2} \theta_{10}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-4 \omega^{2}\right) \theta_{20} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{g}{l}-3 \omega^{2} & -2 \omega^{2} \\
-3 \omega^{2} & \frac{g}{l}-4 \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2}\right)\left(\frac{g}{l}-6 \omega^{2}\right)=0
$$

has roots

$$
\omega=\pm \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \pm \sqrt{\frac{g}{6 l}} .
$$

Hence there are two normal-mode frequencies. For

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \theta_{20}=-\theta_{10} \quad \text { or } \quad \theta_{2}=-\theta_{1}
$$

for

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{6 l}}, \quad \theta_{20}=\frac{3}{2} \theta_{10} \quad \text { or } \quad \theta_{2}=\frac{3}{2} \theta_{1} .
$$

The general small oscillations are a linear combination of the two normalmodes.

A point on the lower pendulum at distance $\xi$ from the upper mass has $x$-coordinate $3 l \sin \theta_{1}+\xi \sin \theta_{2}$ and thus $x$-component velocity

$$
\dot{x}=3 l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+\xi \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2} \approx 3 l \dot{\theta}_{1}+\xi \dot{\theta}_{2} \text {. }
$$

For it to have no horizontal displacement, $\dot{x}=0$. For the $\omega_{1}$ mode, $\dot{\theta}_{2}=-\dot{\theta}_{1}$, this requires

$$
(3 l-\xi) \dot{\theta}_{1}=0, \quad \text { or } \quad \xi=3 l .
$$

For the $\omega_{2}$ mode, $\dot{\theta}_{2}=\frac{3}{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}, \dot{x}=0$ would require

$$
3\left(l+\frac{\xi}{2}\right) \dot{\theta}_{1}=0 .
$$

As $\xi$ is positive this is not possible unless $\dot{\theta}_{1}=0$, i.e. there is no motion. Therefore when the system undergoes small oscillations with angular frequency $\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}$, a point on the lower pendulum at distance $3 l$ from the upper mass has no horizontal displacement.

\section{6}

(a) Find the Lagrangian equations of motion for the coplanar double oscillator shown in Fig. $2.32$ in the vibration limit, assuming massless strings or connecting rods. From them find the normal frequencies of the system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-551.jpg?height=367&width=293&top_left_y=1168&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 2.32.

(b) Now consider a simple pendulum of mass $m$, again in the smallvibration limit. Suppose the string of length $l$ is shortened very slowly (by being pulled up through a frictionless hole in the support as shown in Fig. 2.33), so that the fractional change in $l$ over one period is small. How does the amplitude of vibration of $m$ vary with $l$ ?

(Wisconsin) 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-552.jpg?height=384&width=199&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=675)

Fig. 2.33.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The coordinates of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \sin \theta_{2},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}-l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and their velocities are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V=\frac{1}{2} m_{1}\left[l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\right] \\
&+m_{1} g l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+m_{2} g\left(l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2}\left(l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2}\right) \\
&+\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g l_{1}\left(1-\frac{\theta_{1}^{2}}{2}\right)+m_{2} g l_{2}\left(1-\frac{\theta_{2}^{2}}{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting terms higher than second order in the small quantities $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ in the small vibration limit. Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\left(\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) \frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}} \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g}{l_{1}} \theta_{1}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}} \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g}{l_{1}} \theta_{2}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\theta_{1}=\theta_{10} e^{i \omega t}, \theta_{2}=\theta_{20} e^{i \omega t}$ and obtain the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{g}{l_{1}}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{m_{2} l_{2} \omega^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}} \\
-\omega^{2} & \frac{g-l_{2} \omega^{2}}{l_{1}}
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

or

$$
\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{4}-g\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right) \omega^{2}+g^{2}=0 .
$$

The normal frequencies $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ are given by the solutions of this equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left.\begin{array}{c}
\omega_{1}^{2} \\
\omega_{2}^{2}
\end{array}\right\}=\frac{g}{2 m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}} \\
&\times\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left(l_{2}+l_{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}-4\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As shown in Fig. 2.33. The forces on $m$ are the tension $f$ in the string and the gravity $m g$. These provide for the centripetal force:

$$
f-m g \cos \theta=m r \dot{\theta}^{2} .
$$

When the string is shortened by $d r$, the work done by $f$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
d W &=\mathbf{f} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=-f d r \\
& \approx-m g d r+\left(\frac{1}{2} m g \theta^{2}-m r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d r \\
&=-m g d r+d E,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d E$ is the part relating to the oscillations, for small angle oscillations. As the change in $r$, the length of the string, is small over a period, we can take average

$$
d \bar{E}=\left(\frac{1}{2} m g \bar{\theta}^{2}-m r \overline{\dot{\theta}^{2}}\right) d r .
$$

Also, the vibration can be considered simple harmonic, i.e.

$$
\theta=\theta_{0} \cos (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{r}}$. Then if $T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}$ is the period we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\overline{\theta^{2}}=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \theta^{2} d t=\frac{1}{2} \theta_{0}^{2}, \\
&\overline{\dot{\theta}^{2}}=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \dot{\theta}^{2} d t=\frac{\omega^{2}}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \theta^{2} d t=\omega^{2} \overline{\theta^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e.

$$
m r \overline{\dot{\theta}^{2}}=m g \overline{\bar{\theta}^{2}} .
$$

The energy of the pendulum is

$$
\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g r \cos \theta \approx-m g r+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m g r \theta^{2},
$$

so that

$$
\bar{E}=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \overline{\dot{\theta}^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} m g r \overline{\bar{\theta}^{2}}=m g r \overline{\theta^{2}} .
$$

Hence

$$
d \bar{E}=\left(\frac{1}{2} \bar{E}-\bar{E}\right) \frac{d r}{r},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d \bar{E}}{\bar{E}}=-\frac{d r}{2 r} .
$$

Integrating we have

$$
\bar{E} r^{\frac{1}{2}}=\text { constant },
$$

or

$$
\theta_{0}^{4} r^{3}=\text { constant } .
$$

Let the amplitudes at string lengths $r, l$ be $\theta_{r}, \theta_{l}$ respectively, then

$$
\theta_{r}^{4}=\frac{\theta_{l}^{4} l^{3}}{r^{3}} .
$$

\section{7}

A particle in an isotropic three-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential has a natural angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. Find its vibration frequencies if it is charged and is simultaneously acted on by uniform magnetic and electric fields. Discuss your result in the weak and strong field limits.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Assume that the uniform magnetic and electric fields, $B$ and $E$, are mutually perpendicular and take their directions as along the $z$ - and $x$-axes respectively. Then as

$$
B \mathbf{k}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}, \quad E \mathbf{i}=-\nabla \Phi,
$$

we can take the vector and scalar potentials as

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{2}(-B y \mathbf{i}+B x \mathbf{j}), \quad \Phi=-E x .
$$

As the particle is an isotropic harmonic oscillator of natural augular frequency $\omega_{0}$ and has charge $e$, say, its potential energy is

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{0}^{2} r^{2}+e \Phi-e \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \mathbf{A},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}=(x, y, z)$ is the displacement of the particle from the origin, in $\mathrm{SI}$ units. Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{0}^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right) \\
&+e E x+\frac{1}{2} e B(-\dot{x} y+x \dot{y}) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0 .
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{x}+\omega_{0}^{2} x-\frac{e B \dot{y}}{m}-\frac{e E}{m} &=0, \\
\ddot{y}+\omega_{0}^{2} y+\frac{e B \dot{x}}{m} &=0, \\
\ddot{z}+\omega_{0}^{2} z &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation shows that the vibration in the $z$-direction takes place with the natural angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. Letting $x=x^{\prime}+\frac{e E}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}$, the first two equations become

$$
\begin{gathered}
\ddot{x}^{\prime}+\omega_{0}^{2} x^{\prime}-\frac{e B \dot{y}}{m}=0, \\
\ddot{y}+\omega_{0}^{2} y+\frac{e B \dot{x}^{\prime}}{m}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
x^{\prime}=A^{\prime} e^{i \omega t}, \quad y=B^{\prime} e^{i \omega t}
$$

and we obtain the matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{i e B \omega}{m} \\
\frac{i e B \omega}{m} & \omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A^{\prime} \\
B^{\prime}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{i e B \omega}{m} \\
\frac{i e B \omega}{m} & \omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{e B \omega}{m}\right)^{2}=0
$$

then gives

which has two positive roots

$$
\omega^{2} \pm \frac{e B \omega}{m}-\omega_{0}^{2}=0
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{+}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{e B}{m}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{e B}{m}\right)^{2}+4 \omega_{0}^{2}}\right), \\
&\omega_{-}=\frac{1}{2}\left(-\frac{e B}{m}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{e B}{m}\right)^{2}+4 \omega_{0}^{2}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the three normal-mode angular frequencies are $\omega_{0}, \omega_{+}$and $\omega_{-}$. Note that the last two modes of oscillations are caused by the magnetic field alone, whereas the electric field only causes a displacement $\frac{e E}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}$ along its direction.

For weak fields, $\frac{e B}{m} \ll \omega_{0}$, we have

$$
\omega_{+}=\omega_{0}+\frac{e B}{2 m}, \quad \omega_{-}=\omega_{0}-\frac{e B}{2 m} .
$$

For strong fields, $\frac{e B}{m} \gg \omega_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{+} & \approx \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{e B}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 m^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{e^{2} B^{2}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{e B}, \\
\omega_{-} & \approx \frac{1}{2}\left[-\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{e B}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 m^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{e^{2} B^{2}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{e B} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{8}

Three particles of equal mass $m$ move without friction in one dimension. Two of the particles are each connected to the third by a massless spring of spring constant $k$. Find normal-modes of oscillation and their corresponding frequencies.

$(C U S P E A)$

\section{Solution:}

Number the masses from the left as shown in Fig. $2.34$ and let $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}$ be the displacements of the respective masses from their equilibrium positions. The Lagrangian of the system is

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-557.jpg?height=93&width=354&top_left_y=1443&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 2.34.

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{x}_{3}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)^{2}\right] .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x}_{1}+k\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) &=0, \\
m \ddot{x}_{2}+k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)+k\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right) &=0, \\
m \ddot{x}_{3}+k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right) &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Trying a solution of the type

$$
x_{1}=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad x_{2}=B e^{i \omega t}, \quad x_{3}=C e^{i \omega t},
$$

we can write the above as a matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
k-m \omega^{2} & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-m \omega^{2} & -k \\
0 & -k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B \\
C
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
k-m \omega^{2} & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-m \omega^{2} & -k \\
0 & -k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=m \omega^{2}\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right)\left(m \omega^{2}-3 k\right)=0
$$

has three non-negative roots

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} .
$$

These are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system. The corresponding normal-modes are as follows.

(i) $\omega_{1}=0$

Equation (2) gives $A=B=C$ and thus $x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}$. The first of Eqs. (1) then gives

$$
\ddot{x}_{1}=0, \quad \text { or } \quad x_{1}=a t+b,
$$

where $a, b$ are constants. Hence in this mode the three masses undergo uniform translation together as a rigid body and no vibration occurs.

(ii) $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$

Equation (2) gives $B=0, A=-C$. In this mode the middle mass remains stationary while the outer masses oscillate symmetrically with respect to it. The displacements are 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi\right) \\
&x_{2}=0 \\
&x_{3}=-A \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\varphi$ being a constant.

(iii) $\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}}$

Equation (2) gives $B=-2 A, C=A$. In this mode the two outer masses oscillate with the same amplitude and phase while the middle mass oscillates exactly out of phase with twice the amplitude with respect to the other two masses. The displacements are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{3} t+\varphi\right), \\
&x_{2}=-2 A \cos \left(\omega_{3} t+\varphi\right), \\
&x_{3}=A \cos \left(\omega_{3} t+\varphi\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The three normal-modes are shown in Fig. 2.35.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-559.jpg?height=202&width=498&top_left_y=977&top_left_x=445)

Fig. 2.35.

\section{9}

A rectangular plate of mass $M$, length $a$ and width $b$ is supported at each of its corners by $a$ spring with spring constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.36. The springs are confined so that they can move only in the vertical direction. For small amplitudes, find the normal-modes of vibration and their frequencies. Describe each of the modes.

(UC, Berkeley)

Solution:

Use Cartesian coordinates with origin at the center of mass $C$ of the plate when the plate is in equilibrium, the $z$-axis vertically upwards, the $x$ - 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-560.jpg?height=275&width=421&top_left_y=247&top_left_x=280)

Fig. 2.36.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-560.jpg?height=318&width=422&top_left_y=219&top_left_x=861)

Fig. 2.37.

and $y$-axes along the axes of symmetry in the plane of the plate, and let the angles of rotation about the $x$ - and $y$-axes be $\varphi, \theta$ respectively, as shown in Fig. 2.37. If $z$ is the vertical coordinate of $C$, the vertical coordinates of the four corners are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&z_{A}=z-\frac{1}{2} a \varphi+\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{B}=z-\frac{1}{2} a \varphi-\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{D}=z+\frac{1}{2} a \varphi-\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{E}=z+\frac{1}{2} a \varphi+\frac{1}{2} b \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

for small angle oscillations.

As the coordinates are relative to the equilibrium positions, the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(z_{A}^{2}+z_{B}^{2}+z_{D}^{2}+z_{E}^{2}\right)-M g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(4 z^{2}+a^{2} \varphi^{2}+b^{2} \theta^{2}\right)-M g z .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{z}+4 k z+M g &=0, \\
\frac{1}{12} M \ddot{\varphi}+k \varphi &=0, \\
\frac{1}{12} M \ddot{\theta}+k \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

By putting $z=z^{\prime}-\frac{M g}{4 k}$, the first equation can be written as

$$
M \ddot{z}^{\prime}+4 k z^{\prime}=0 .
$$

The equations show that the normol-mode angular frequencies are

$$
\omega_{1}=2 \sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\omega_{3}=2 \sqrt{\frac{3 k}{M}} .
$$

If we define

$$
\xi_{1}=\sqrt{M} z^{\prime}, \quad \xi_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{M}{12}} a \varphi, \quad \xi_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{M}{12}} b \theta,
$$

we can, neglecting a constant term in the potential energy, write

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\dot{\xi}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\xi}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\xi}_{3}^{2}\right), \\
V &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\omega_{1}^{2} \xi_{1}^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2} \xi_{2}^{2}+\omega_{3}^{2} \xi_{3}^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These are both in quadratic form, slowing that $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \xi_{3}$ are the normalmode coordinates.

Denoting the amplitudes of $z^{\prime}, \varphi, \theta$ by $z_{0}^{\prime}, \varphi_{0}, \theta_{0}$ respectively, we obtain from the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(4 k-M \omega^{2}\right) z_{0} &=0, \\
\left(k-\frac{1}{12} M \omega^{2}\right) \varphi_{0} &=0, \\
\left(k-\frac{1}{12} M \omega^{2}\right) \theta_{0} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

It can be seen that if $\omega=\omega_{1}$ then $z_{0} \neq 0, \varphi_{0}=\theta_{0}=0$. If $\omega=\omega_{2}$ or $\omega_{3}$, then $z_{0}=0$, and one or both of $\varphi_{0}, \theta_{0}$ are not zero. 

\section{0}

A particle moves without friction on the inside wall of an axially symmetric vessel given by

$$
z=\frac{1}{2} b\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)
$$

where $b$ is a constant and $z$ is in the vertical direction, as shown in Fig. 2.38.

(a) The particle is moving in a circular orbit at height $z=z_{0}$. Obtain its energy and angular momentum in terms of $z_{0}, b, g$ (gravitational acceleration), and the mass $m$ of the particle.

(b) The particle in the horizontal circular orbit is poked downwards slightly. Obtain the frequency of oscillation about the unperturbed orbit for very small oscillation amplitude.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-562.jpg?height=455&width=337&top_left_y=857&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 2.38.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.38. As $x=r \cos \theta, y=r \sin \theta$, the vessel can be represented by

$$
z=\frac{1}{2} b\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} b r^{2} .
$$

The Lagrangian of the particle is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+b^{2} r^{2} \dot{r}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m g b r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{Lagrange's equation for $r$ then gives}

$$
\left(1+b^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}-b^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}+g b r=0 .
$$

As the particle motion is confined to a circle of height $z_{0}$ and radius $r_{0}$, say, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
r &=r_{0}, \quad \dot{r}=\ddot{r}=0, \quad z_{0}=\frac{1}{2} b r_{0}^{2}, \\
\dot{\theta}^{2} &=g b=\Omega^{2}, \quad \text { say. }
\end{aligned}
$$

The total energy of the particle is then

$$
T+V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(r_{0}^{2} \Omega^{2}+g b r_{0}^{2}\right)=m g b r_{0}^{2}=2 m g z_{0},
$$

and the angular momentum about the center of the circle is

$$
J=m r \cdot r \dot{\theta}=m r_{0}^{2} \Omega=2 m z_{0} \sqrt{\frac{g}{b}} .
$$

(b) For the perturbed motion, let $r=r_{0}+\rho$ where $\rho \ll r_{0}$, Lagrange's equation for $\theta$ shows that the angular momentum $m r^{2} \dot{\theta}$ is conserved. Hence.

$$
r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{r^{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{r^{3}}=\frac{r_{0}^{4} \Omega^{2}}{r^{3}}=\frac{r_{0}^{4} g b}{r^{3}},
$$

and Eq. (1) becomes

$$
\left(1+b^{2} r_{0}^{2}\right) \ddot{\rho}+4 g b \rho=0
$$

by neglecting terms of order higher than the first in the small quantities $\rho, \dot{\rho}, \ddot{\rho}$. The angular frequency of small amplitude oscillations about $r_{0}$ is therefore

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{4 g b}{1+b^{2} r_{0}^{2}}}=2 \sqrt{\frac{g b}{1+2 b z_{0}}} .
$$

\section{1}

A block of mass $m$ is attached to a wedge of mass $M$ by a spring with spring constant $k$. The inclined frictionless surface of the wedge makes an angle $\alpha$ to the horizontal. The wedge is free to slide on a horizontal frictionless surface, as shown in Fig. 2.39. (a) Given the relaxed length of the spring alone is $d$, find the value $s_{0}$ when both the block and the wedge are at rest.

(b) Find the Lagrangian for the system as a function of the $x$ coordinate of the wedge and the length of the spring $s$. Write the equations of motion.

(c) What is the natural frequency of vibration?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-564.jpg?height=190&width=468&top_left_y=582&top_left_x=542)

Fig. 2.39.

\section{Solution:}

(a) When the block is in equilibrium, the sum of forces parallel to the inclined surface is zero:

$$
m g \sin \alpha-k\left(s_{0}-d\right)=0,
$$

yielding

$$
s_{0}=\frac{m g \sin \alpha}{k}+d .
$$

(b) Let the height of the wedge be $h$. Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.39$ and let the horizontal coordinate of the left side of the wedge be $x$. Then the mass $m$ will have coordinates

$$
(x+s \cos \alpha, h-s \sin \alpha) \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}+\dot{s} \cos \alpha)^{2}+(\dot{s} \sin \alpha)^{2}\right] \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(m+M) \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{s}^{2}+m \dot{x} \dot{s} \cos \alpha-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations then give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(m+M) \ddot{x}+m \ddot{s} \cos \alpha=0, \\
&m \ddot{x} \cos \alpha+m \ddot{s}+k s-(k d+m g \sin \alpha)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Setting

$$
s=s^{\prime}+\frac{k d+m g \sin \alpha}{k},
$$

we can write the above equations as

$$
\begin{aligned}
(m+M) \ddot{x}+m \ddot{s}^{\prime} \cos \alpha &=0, \\
m \ddot{x} \cos \alpha+m \ddot{s}^{\prime}+k s^{\prime} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider a solution of the form

$$
x=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad s^{\prime}=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

the above give the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-(m+M) \omega^{2} & -m \omega^{2} \cos \alpha \\
-m \omega^{2} \cos \alpha & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

yielding

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k(m+M)}{m\left(M+m \sin ^{2} \alpha\right)}} .
$$

As the motion related to $\omega_{1}$ is not oscillatory but as a whole translational along the $x$-axis, there is only one natural frequency of vibration, $\omega_{2}$.

\section{2}

An uniform $\log$ with length $L$, cross-sectional area $A$ and mass $M$ is floating vertically in water $(\rho=1.0)$ and is attached by a spring with spring constant $K$ to a uniform beam which is pivoted at the center as shown in Fig. 2.40(a). The beam has the same mass and is twice the length of the log. The $\log$ is constrained to move vertically and the natural length of the spring is such that the equilibrium position of the beam is horizontal.

(a) Find the normal-modes (frequencies and ratio of displacements) for small displacements of the beam. (b) Discuss the physical significance of the normal-modes in the limit of a very strong spring.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-566.jpg?height=316&width=651&top_left_y=371&top_left_x=410)

(a)

(b)

Fig. 2.40.

\section{Solution:}

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.40(b) with $x$ denoting the displacement of the top of the vertical rod from its equilibrium position (the downward direction being taken as positive), and $\theta$ the angle of rotation of the beam. At equilibrium (Fig. 2.40(a)), the spring is in its natural length $x_{0}$ and does not exert a force on the rod. With $\rho=1$ we have

$$
M g=\left[L-\left(h-x_{0}\right)\right] A g .
$$

When the beam has rotated an angle $\theta$ (Fig. 2.40(b)) the spring is extended by $x-L \theta$ and the upward thrust of the water is

$$
-\left[L-\left(h-x_{0}-x\right)\right] A g=-\frac{\partial V_{t}}{\partial x},
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
V_{t} &=A g \int_{0}^{x}\left\{\left[L-\left(h-x_{0}\right)\right]+x^{\prime}\right\} d x^{\prime} \\
&=\left[L-\left(h-x_{0}\right)\right] A g x+\frac{1}{2} A g x^{2} \\
&=M g x+\frac{1}{2} A g x^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the total potential energy is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
V &=-M g x+M g x+\frac{1}{2} A g x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K(x-L \theta)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} A g x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K(x-L \theta)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The beam has moment of inertia $\frac{1}{3} M L^{2}$, so the total kinetic energy is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{6} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} .
$$

Thus the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{6} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} A g x^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K(x-L \theta)^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M \ddot{x}+A g x+K(x-L \theta)=0, \\
&M L \ddot{\theta}-3 K(x-L \theta)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Try a solution of the type $x=D e^{i \omega t}, \theta=B e^{i \omega t}$ and write the above as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(K+A g-M \omega^{2}\right) D-K L B=0, \\
&-3 K D+\left(3 K L-M L \omega^{2}\right) B=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The secular equation is then

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
K+A g-M \omega^{2} & -K L \\
-3 K & 3 K L-M L \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

or

$$
M^{2} \omega^{4}-M(4 K+A g) \omega^{2}+3 K A g=0
$$

The two positive roots

$$
\omega_{\pm}=\sqrt{\frac{4 K+A g \pm \sqrt{(4 K+A g)^{2}-12 K A g}}{2 M}}
$$

are the two normal-mode angular frequencies of the system for small oscillations of the beam. The ratios of the displacements are

$$
\frac{x}{L \theta}=\frac{D}{B L}=\frac{3 K-M \omega^{2}}{3 K}=\frac{2 K-A g \mp \sqrt{(4 K+A g)^{2}-12 K A g}}{6 K}
$$

with the top sign for $\omega_{+}$and the bottom sign for $\omega_{-}$.

(b) In the limit of a very strong spring, $K \rightarrow \infty$. As $M \ddot{x}, \operatorname{Agx}, M L \ddot{\theta}$ are all finite, this requires that $x-L \theta \rightarrow 0$, i.e. $x \rightarrow L \theta$. Eliminating the $K(x-L \theta)$ terms from the equations of motion and making use of $L \ddot{\theta} \approx \ddot{x}$, we find

$$
4 M \ddot{x}+3 A g x=0
$$

and hence the angular frequency of oscillation

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 A g}{4 M}} .
$$

The ratio of the displacements is

$$
\frac{x}{L \theta} \approx 1,
$$

and they are in the same phase. Note that these results cannot be obtained from the previous ones by putting $K \rightarrow \infty$ because the constraint relations are different. Physically, the constraint $x \approx L \theta$ means that the system oscillates with the spring keeping its length constant, which is expected for a very strong spring.

\section{3}

Two unequal masses $M$ and $m(M>m)$ hang from a support by strings of equal lengths $l$. The masses are coupled by a spring of spring constant $K$ and of unstretched length equal to the distance between the support points as shown in Fig. 2.41. Find the normal-mode frequencies for the small oscillations along the line between the two masses. Give the relation between the motion of $M$ and that of $m$ in each mode. Write down the most general solution.

Now specialize for the case where at $t=0, m$ is at rest at its equilibrium position, and $M$ is released from rest with an initial positive displacement. If the total energy of the system is $E_{0}$ and the spring is very weak, find the 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-569.jpg?height=279&width=351&top_left_y=214&top_left_x=576)

Fig. 2.41.

maximum energy acquired by $m$ during the subsequent motion for the case $\frac{M}{m}=2$. (Where did you use the assumption that the spring is weak?)

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.41$ with origin $O$ at the equilibrium position of the mass $m$ and the $x$ - and $y$-axes along the horizontal and vertical directions respectively and let the distance between the two supports be $L$. The masses $m$ and $M$ then have coordinates

$$
\left(l \sin \theta_{1}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{1}\right)\right), \quad\left(L+l \sin \theta_{2}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{2}\right)\right)
$$

and velocities

$$
\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K l^{2}\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)^{2} \\
&-m g l\left(1-\cos \theta_{1}\right)-M g l\left(1-\cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} g l\left(m \theta_{1}^{2}+M \theta_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for small oscillations in the horizontal direction.

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m l \ddot{\theta}_{1}+(m g+K l) \theta_{1}-K l \theta_{2}=0 \\
M l \ddot{\theta}_{2}+(M g+K l) \theta_{2}-K l \theta_{1}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type $\theta_{1}=A e^{i \omega t}, \theta_{2}=B e^{i \omega t}$ and write the above as

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
m g+K l-m l \omega^{2} & -K l \\
-K l & M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation is then

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
m g+K l-m l \omega^{2} & -K l \\
-K l & M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

yielding the normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{m M g+K l(m+M)}{m M l}} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{A}{B}=\frac{M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}}{K l},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{A}{B} &=1 \quad \text { for } \quad \omega=\omega_{1}, \\
\frac{A^{\prime}}{B^{\prime}} &=-\frac{M}{m} \quad \text { for } \quad \omega=\omega_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for $\omega=\omega_{1}$,

$$
\theta_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right), \quad \theta_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right),
$$

for $\omega=\omega_{2}$,

$$
\theta_{1}=A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right), \quad \theta_{2}=-\frac{m}{M} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)
$$

and the most general solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\theta_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right) \\
&\theta_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right)-\frac{m}{M} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Initially at $t=0, \dot{\theta}_{1}=\dot{\theta}_{2}=0$, giving $\dot{\varphi}_{1}=\dot{\varphi}_{2}=0$, and $\theta_{1}=0, \theta_{2}=\theta_{0}$, giving

$$
A=\frac{M}{m+M} \theta_{0}, \quad A^{\prime}=-A .
$$

If the initial total energy is $E_{0}$, then as

$$
E_{0}=\frac{1}{2} K l^{2} \theta_{0}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M g l \theta_{0}^{2},
$$

we have, as $\theta_{0}$ is positive,

$$
\theta_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{0}}{(K l+M g) l}} .
$$

If in addition, $M=2 m$, the general solution reduces to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\theta_{1}=\frac{2}{3} \theta_{0}\left[\cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right], \\
&\theta_{2}=\frac{2}{3} \theta_{0}\left[\cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m g+3 K l}{2 m l}}, \quad \theta_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{0}}{(2 m g+K l) l}} .
$$

The energy of $m$ is

$$
E_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta_{1}^{2} .
$$

If the spring is very weak, we can take $K l \ll m g$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{2} &=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}\left(1+\frac{3 K l}{2 m g}\right)} \approx \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}\left(1+\frac{3 K l}{4 m g}\right)=\omega_{1}(1+\delta), \\
\theta_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{E_{0}}{m g l}}\left(1-\frac{\delta}{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\delta=\frac{3 K l}{4 m g} \ll 1 .
$$

We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}=& \frac{2}{9} m g l \theta_{0}^{2}\left[1+(1+\delta)^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)+\cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right.\\
&\left.\quad-2(1+\delta) \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)-2 \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \\
\approx & \frac{4}{9} E_{0}\left[1-\cos \left(\omega_{1} \delta t\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting $\delta$ as compared with unity. Hence the maximum energy of $m$ is $\frac{8}{9} E_{0}$

\section{4}

Two small spheres of mass $M$ are suspended between two rigid supports as shown in Fig. 2.42. We assume that both particles can move in the plane of the figure, sideways and up and down. The three springs are equal, of spring constant $K$. The springs are under tension: in its unstretched condition each spring would be of length $\frac{a}{2}$. The springs are assumed massless and perfectly elastic. Assuming small oscillations about the equilibrium configuration shown above, find the frequencies for the four normal-modes of the system.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-572.jpg?height=120&width=360&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=291)

Fig. 2.42.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-572.jpg?height=219&width=479&top_left_y=1283&top_left_x=857)

Fig. 2.43.

\section{Solution:}

Since the motion is confined to the plane of the diagram of Fig. 2.42, the sideway motion is to be interpreted as longitudinal along the springs.

Let $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ be the horizontal and vertical displacements of the spheres, numbered from the left, from their respective positions of equilibrium. Using coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.43, m_{1}, m_{2}$ have coordinates $\left(a+x_{1}, y_{1}\right),\left(2 a+x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ respectively. Talking the equilibrium configuration (Fig. 2.42) as the state of zero potential, we have for the system the potential energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
V=& \frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{1}\right)^{2}+y_{1}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a-x_{2}\right)^{2}+y_{2}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Consider}

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{1}\right)^{2}+y_{1}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} K\left[a^{2}+x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}+\frac{a^{2}}{4}-a \sqrt{a^{2}+x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}\right]-\frac{1}{8} K a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As the term involving the square-root sign can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a^{2}\left(1+\frac{x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
&\approx a^{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2 !}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) \frac{4 x_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right] \\
&=a^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} x_{1}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

retaining only terms of orders up to the second in the small quantities $x_{1}, y_{1}$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2} K\left(x_{1}^{2}+a x_{1}+\frac{1}{2} y_{1}^{2}\right) .
$$

The same approximation is taken over the other terms. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
V \approx & \frac{1}{2} K\left[x_{1}^{2}+a x_{1}+\frac{y_{1}^{2}}{2}+\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+a\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{1}{2}\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}+x_{2}^{2}-a x_{2}+\frac{1}{2} y_{2}^{2}\right]+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{2} K\left(2 x_{1}^{2}+2 x_{2}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}-y_{1} y_{2}\right)+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(2 x_{1}^{2}+2 x_{2}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}-y_{1} y_{2}\right)-M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x}_{1}+2 K x_{1}-K x_{2} &=0, \\
M \ddot{x}_{2}+2 K x_{2}-K x_{1} &=0, \\
M \ddot{y}_{1}+K y_{1}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{2}+M g &=0, \\
M \ddot{y}_{2}+K y_{2}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{1}+M g &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

It is seen that the equations naturally separate into two groups, those in $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and those in $y_{1}, y_{2}$. Let

$$
x_{i}=A_{i} e^{i \omega t}
$$

Then the first two equations give the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 K-M \omega^{2} & -K \\
-K & 2 K-M \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(3 K-M \omega^{2}\right)\left(K-M \omega^{2}\right)=0
$$

yielding two normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{M}}
$$

for longitudinal oscillations.

For the second group of two equations, let

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=y_{1}+\frac{2 M g}{K}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=y_{2}+\frac{2 M g}{K} .
$$

They can then be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M \ddot{y}_{1}^{\prime}+K y_{1}^{\prime}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{2}^{\prime}=0, \\
&M \ddot{y}_{2}^{\prime}+K y_{2}^{\prime}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{1}^{\prime}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Trying a solution of the type

$$
y_{i}^{\prime}=B_{i} e^{i \omega t},
$$

we obtain the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
K-M \omega^{2} & -\frac{K}{2} \\
-\frac{K}{2} & K-M \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\frac{3}{2} K-M \omega^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} K-M \omega^{2}\right)=0,
$$

which yields the normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{2 M}}, \quad \omega_{4}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{2 M}}
$$

for vertical oscillations.

\section{5}

A simple pendulum of length $L$ is suspended at the rim of a wheel of radius $b$ which rotates within the vertical plane with constant angular velocity $\Omega$ (Fig. 2.44). We consider only the motion in which the bob of the pendulum swings in the plane of the wheel.

(a) Write an exact differential equation of motion for the angular displacement $\theta$ of the bob. Also write a simplified form valid when the oscillation amplitude is very small. (b) Assume that both the radius $b$ and the oscillation amplitude of the bob are very small. Give an approximate steady-state solution of the equation of motion valid under the assumptions.

(You may ignore transients which will die out if there is a slight dissipation.) $(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-576.jpg?height=280&width=338&top_left_y=527&top_left_x=295)

Fig. $2.44$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-576.jpg?height=332&width=321&top_left_y=503&top_left_x=925)

Fig. $2.45$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.45. The mass $m$ has coordinates

$$
(b \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)+L \sin \theta, b \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+L \cos \theta)
$$

and velocity

$$
(b \Omega \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+L \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-b \Omega \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)-L \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)
$$

where $\varphi$ is a constant.

The Lagrangian of $m$ is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[b^{2} \Omega^{2}+L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 b L \Omega \dot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\Omega t-\varphi)\right] \\
&+m g[b \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+L \cos \theta] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
L \ddot{\theta}+b \Omega^{2} \sin (\theta-\Omega t-\varphi)+g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

For small-amplitude oscillations, $\sin \theta \approx \theta, \cos \theta \approx 1$,

$$
\sin (\theta-\Omega t-\varphi) \approx \theta \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)-\sin (\Omega t+\varphi),
$$

and the equation of motion becomes

$$
L \ddot{\theta}+\left[b \Omega^{2} \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+g\right] \theta-b \Omega^{2} \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)=0 .
$$

(b) For $b$ and $\theta$ small, we have, retaining terms of only up to the first order of $b, \theta, \dot{\theta}$,

$$
L \ddot{\theta}+g \theta-b \Omega^{2} \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)=0 .
$$

In the steady state, the pendulum will swing with the same frequency as the rotation of the wheel, so we can assume

$$
\theta=\alpha \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+\beta \sin (\Omega t+\varphi),
$$

where $\alpha, \beta$ are constants. Substitution in the equation of motion gives

$$
\left(-L \Omega^{2}+g\right)[\alpha \cos (\Omega t+\varphi)+\beta \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)]-b \Omega^{2} \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)=0 .
$$

As this equation must be true for any arbitrary time, the coefficients of $\cos (\Omega t+\varphi)$ and $\sin (\Omega t+\varphi)$ must separately vanish:

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\alpha L \Omega^{2}+g \alpha &=0, \\
g \beta-\beta L \Omega^{2}-b \Omega^{2} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\Omega$ is given, we must have $\alpha=0$ in the first equation. The second equation gives

$$
\beta=\frac{b \Omega^{2}}{g-L \Omega^{2}} .
$$

Hence the steady-state solution is

$$
\theta=\frac{b \Omega^{2} \sin (\Omega t+\varphi)}{g-L \Omega^{2}} .
$$

\section{6}

Three equal point masses $m$ move on a circle of radius $b$ under forces derivable from the potential energy

$$
V(\alpha, \beta, \gamma)=V_{0}\left(e^{-\alpha}+e^{-\beta}+e^{-\gamma}\right) \text {. }
$$

where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are their angular separations in radians, as shown in Fig. 2.46. When $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=\frac{2 \pi}{3}$, the system is in equilibrium. Find the normal-mode frequencies for small departure from equilibrium.

(Note that $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are not independent since $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=2 \pi$.) $(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-578.jpg?height=331&width=347&top_left_y=539&top_left_x=295)

Fig. 2.46.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-578.jpg?height=335&width=372&top_left_y=549&top_left_x=919)

Fig. $2.47$

\section{Solution:}

Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$ be the angular displacements of the three masses from their equilibrium positions as shown in Fig. 2.47. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\alpha=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}, \\
&\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}, \\
&\gamma=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{1}-\theta_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
e^{-x} \approx 1-\frac{x}{1 !}+\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}-\cdots,
$$

we can write the potential energy as 

$$
\begin{aligned}
V=& V_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}\left[e^{-\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{2}\right)}+e^{-\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)}+e^{-\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)}\right] \\
\approx & V_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}\left[3-\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)-\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)-\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)\right.\\
&\left.\quad+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)^{2}\right] \\
=& A\left(3+\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}+\theta_{3}^{2}-\theta_{1} \theta_{2}-\theta_{2} \theta_{3}-\theta_{3} \theta_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $A=V_{0} \exp \left(-\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$, retaining terms of orders up to the second in the small quantities $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$.

As the velocities are $b \dot{\theta}_{1}, b \dot{\theta}_{2}, b \dot{\theta}_{3}$, the kinetic energy is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} B\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)
$$

with $B=m b^{2}$.

The Lagrangian is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=B\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)-A\left(3+\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}+\theta_{3}^{2}-\theta_{1} \theta_{2}-\theta_{2} \theta_{3}-\theta_{3} \theta_{1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&B \ddot{\theta}_{1}+A\left(2 \theta_{1}-\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=0, \\
&B \ddot{\theta}_{2}+A\left(2 \theta_{2}-\theta_{3}-\theta_{1}\right)=0, \\
&B \ddot{\theta}_{3}+A\left(2 \theta_{3}-\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Trying a solution of the type $\theta_{i}=C_{i} e^{i \omega t}$, we find the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A & -A \\
-A & 2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A \\
-A & -A & 2 A-B \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or, after some arithmetic manipulations,

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -2 A & A-B \omega^{2} \\
0 & 2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A \\
-3 A+B \omega^{2} & -A & 2 A-B \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=B \omega^{2}\left(-3 A+B \omega^{2}\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

Hence the normal-mode angular frequencies are

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 A}{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 V_{0} \exp \left(\frac{-2 \pi}{3}\right)}{m b^{2}}} .
$$

Note that $\omega_{1}$ does not give rise to oscillations, for in this case the equations of motion give $\theta_{1}=\theta_{2}=\theta_{3}$ and the system as a whole rotates with a constant angular velocity. The other two normal-modes are degenerate and there is only one normal-mode frequency

$$
\frac{1}{b} \sqrt{\frac{3 V_{0}}{m}} \exp \left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) .
$$

\section{7}

Three point particles, two of mass $m$ and one of mass $M$, are constrained to lie on a horizontal circle of radius $r$. They are mutually connected by springs, each of constant $K$, that follow the arc of the circle and that are of equal length when the system is at rest as shown in Fig. 2.48. Assuming motion that stretches the springs only by a small amount from the equilibrium length $(2 \pi r / 3)$,

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-580.jpg?height=336&width=353&top_left_y=1187&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 2.48.

(a) describe qualitatively the modes of motion that are simple harmonic in time (the normal-modes);

(b) find a precise set of normal coordinates, one corresponding to each mode;

(c) find the frequency of each mode.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$ 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the system is not acted upon by external torque, its angular momentum is conserved. This means that there is a normal-mode in which the system rotates as a whole. Consequently there are only two vibrational degrees of freedom. Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$ be respectively the angular displacements of $m, M, m$ from their equilibrium positions and let their amplitudes be $c_{1}, c_{2}, c_{3}$. When considering the vibration of the masses relative to their equilibrium positions, we can take the total angular momentum of the system to be zero. Then the two vibrational normal-modes correspond to

$$
c_{2}=0, \quad c_{1}=-c_{3} \quad \text { and } \quad c_{1}=c_{3}=-\frac{M c_{2}}{2 m} .
$$

(b) Let the natural length of each spring be $a$ and denote the equilibrium length by $b$, i.e.

$$
b=\frac{2 \pi r}{3} \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\left(b+r \theta_{2}-r \theta_{1}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{3}-r \theta_{2}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{1}-r \theta_{3}-a\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the differential equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+K\left(2 \theta_{1}-\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=0, \\
&M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+K\left(2 \theta_{2}-\theta_{3}-\theta_{1}\right)=0, \\
&m \ddot{\theta}_{3}+K\left(2 \theta_{3}-\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The above sum up to

$$
m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+m \ddot{\theta}_{3}=0,
$$

and the first and third equations give

$$
m\left(\ddot{\theta}_{1}-\ddot{\theta}_{3}\right)+3 K\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)=0 .
$$

These can be written as

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{\xi}=0, \\
m \ddot{\eta}+3 K \eta=0
\end{gathered}
$$

if we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\xi=\theta_{1}+\frac{M \theta_{2}}{m}+\theta_{3}, \\
&\eta=\theta_{1}-\theta_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\xi$ and $\eta$ are normal-mode coordinates of the system.

Equation (1) shows that $\omega_{1}=0$. Thus corresponding to this mode in which the system rotates as a whole and there is no oscillation.

Equation (2) shows that

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{m}} .
$$

To find the third normal coordinate, we choose the coordinate transformation

$$
q_{1}=\theta_{1}, \quad q_{2}=\theta_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, \quad q_{3}=\theta_{3}
$$

to make the kinetic energy a sum of squares:

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{q}_{1}^{2}+\dot{q}_{2}^{2}+\dot{q}_{3}^{2}\right) .
$$

$q_{1}, q_{2}, q_{3}$ are just like Cartesian coordinates. The transformation between the three normal coordinates and the three "Cartesian" coordinates $q_{1}, q_{2}$, $q_{3}$ must be linear. We already have

$$
\xi=q_{1}+q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+q_{3}, \quad \eta=q_{1}-q_{3} .
$$

Assume the third normal coordinate to be

$$
\zeta=A q_{1}+B q_{2}+C q_{3} .
$$

It should be orthogonal to the $\xi_{-}, \eta$-axes. Resolving along the $q_{i}$-axes we have

$$
\boldsymbol{\xi}=\left(1, \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, 1\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\eta}=(1,0,-1), \quad \boldsymbol{\zeta}=(A, B, C)
$$



\section{Orthogonality means that}

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\xi}=A+B \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+C=0 \\
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\eta}=A-C=0
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield $A=C, B=-2 A \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}$. Since a normal coordinate remains so after multiplying it with a nonzero constant, we can set $A=1$, then

$$
\zeta=q_{1}-2 q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}+q_{3}=\theta_{1}-2 \theta_{2}+\theta_{3} .
$$

The equations of motion then give

$$
\ddot{\zeta}+\left(\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}\right) \zeta=0,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}} .
$$

(c) $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ are the normal-mode angular frequencies corresponding to the three normal coordinates $\xi, \eta, \zeta$ respectively.

\section{8}

A ring of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is supported from a pivot located at one point of the ring, about which it is free to rotate in its own vertical plane. A bead of mass $m$ slides without friction about the ring (Fig. 2.49).

(a) Write the Lagrangian for this system.

(b) Write the equations of motion.

(c) Describe the normal-modes for small oscillations in the limits $m \gg M$ and $m \ll M$.

(d) Find the frequencies of the normal-modes of small oscillations for general $m$ and $M$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.49. The mass $m$ and the center of mass of the ring have coordinates 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-584.jpg?height=318&width=320&top_left_y=238&top_left_x=588)

Fig. $2.49$.

$$
(R \sin \theta+R \sin \varphi, R \cos \theta+R \cos \varphi), \quad(R \sin \theta, R \cos \theta)
$$

and velocities

$$
(R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+R \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta-R \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi), \quad(R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)
$$

respectively. The ring has moment of inertial $2 M R^{2}$ about the pivot. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}\left[\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+(M+m) g R \cos \theta+m g R \cos \varphi,
\end{aligned}
$$

taking the pivot as the reference level of potential energy.

(b) Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(2 M+m) R \ddot{\theta}+m R \ddot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi) \\
&\quad+m R \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+(m+M) g \sin \theta=0, \\
&R \ddot{\varphi}+R \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\varphi)-R \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$
to

(c), (d) For small oscillations, $\theta, \varphi, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}$ are small and the above reduce

$$
\begin{gathered}
(2 M+m) R \ddot{\theta}+m R \ddot{\varphi}+(M+m) g \theta=0, \\
R \ddot{\varphi}+R \ddot{\theta}+g \varphi=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type $\theta=A e^{i \omega t}, \varphi=B e^{i \omega t}$ and write these equations as a matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
(M+m) g-(2 M+m) R \omega^{2} & -m R \omega^{2} \\
-R \omega^{2} & g-R \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
(m+M) g-(2 M+m) R \omega^{2} & -m R \omega^{2} \\
-R \omega^{2} & g-R \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right| \\
=\left(2 R \omega^{2}-g\right)\left[M R \omega^{2}-(m+M) g\right]=0
\end{gathered}
$$

has positive roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{(m+M) g}{M R}},
$$

which are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system. The ratio of the amplitudes is

$$
\frac{A}{B}=\frac{g-R \omega^{2}}{R \omega^{2}}= \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{1}, \\ -\frac{m}{M+m} & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{2} .\end{cases}
$$

If $m \gg M$

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude and phase;

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{m g}{M R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=-1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude but opposite phases.

If $m \ll M$,

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude and phase as in the above;

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=-\frac{m}{M},
$$

i.e. $\theta$ has a much smaller amplitude than $\varphi$ and the two oscillations are opposite in phase.

\section{9}

A particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move on the parabola $z=\frac{x^{2}}{a}$ in the plane, $a$ is a constant length, and there is a constant gravitational force acting in the negative $z$ direction.

(a) Define a suitable generalized coordinate for the problem.

(b) Write the Lagrangian in terms of your generalized coordinate and velocity.

(c) Where is the equilibrium position for the particle?

(d) Write the equation for small oscillations about this equilibrium.

(e) Solve the equations you get in (d).

(Columbia $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) We choose $x$ as the generalized coordinate of the particle.

(b) The particle has coordinates $(x, z)=\left(x, \frac{x^{2}}{a}\right)$ and velocity $(\dot{x}, \dot{y})=$ $\left(\dot{x}, \frac{2 x \dot{x}}{a}\right)$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}\left(1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{a^{2}}\right) \\
&V=m g z=\frac{m g x^{2}}{a}
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is therefore

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}\left(1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)-\frac{m g x^{2}}{a} .
$$

(c) The equilibrium position is given by

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=\frac{2 m g x}{a}=0,
$$

or

$$
x=0 .
$$

Then $z=0$ also. Thus the equilibrium position is $(0,0)$.

(d) For small oscillations about equilibrium, $x, \dot{x}$ are small quantities.

Neglecting terms of orders greater than two we obtain 

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{m g x^{2}}{a} .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0
$$

then gives

$$
\ddot{x}+\frac{2 g x}{a}=0 .
$$

(e) This equation has general solution

$$
x=A \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{a}} t+\varepsilon\right),
$$

where $A, \varepsilon$ are constants of integration to be determined from the initial conditions.

\section{0}

A thin uniform bar of mass $m$ and length $\frac{3 l}{2}$ is suspended by a string of length $l$ and negligible mass. Give the normal frequencies and normalmodes for small oscillations in a plane.

\section{Solution:}

(Columbia)

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.50. The center of mass of the bar has coordinates $\left(l \sin \varphi+\frac{3}{4} l \sin \theta,-l \cos \varphi-\frac{3}{4} l \cos \theta\right)$ and velocity $(l \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi+$ $\left.\frac{3}{4} l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, l \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi+\frac{3}{4} l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta\right)$. The bar has moment of inertia

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-587.jpg?height=354&width=254&top_left_y=1459&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 2.50. 

$$
\frac{1}{12} m\left(\frac{3 l}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{3}{16} m l^{2} .
$$

Hence its Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left[\dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{9}{16} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{3}{2} \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+\frac{3}{32} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g l\left(\cos \varphi+\frac{3}{4} \cos \theta\right) \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left(\frac{3}{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{3}{2} \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi}\right)+\frac{7}{4} m g l-\frac{1}{2} m g l\left(\varphi^{2}+\frac{3}{4} \theta^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for small oscillations, retaining only terms of up to the second order of the small quantities $\theta, \varphi, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}$.

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{3}{4} l \ddot{\theta}+l \ddot{\varphi}+g \varphi &=0, \\
l \ddot{\theta}+l \ddot{\varphi}+g \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

With a solution of the form

$$
\theta=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad \varphi=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

the above give

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{3}{4} l \omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2} \\
g-l \omega^{2} & -l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{3}{4} l \omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2} \\
g-l \omega^{2} & -l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

i.e.

$$
l^{2} \omega^{4}-8 l g \omega^{2}+4 g^{2}=0,
$$

has solutions

$$
\omega^{2}=(4 \pm 2 \sqrt{3}) \frac{g}{l}=(1 \pm \sqrt{3})^{2} \frac{g}{l},
$$

or

$$
\omega=(\sqrt{3} \pm 1) \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}},
$$

since $\omega$ has to be positive. Hence the normal-mode angular frequencies are

$$
\omega_{1}=(\sqrt{3}+1) \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=(\sqrt{3}-1) \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}} .
$$

The ratio of amplitudes is

$$
\frac{B}{A}=\frac{g-l \omega^{2}}{l \omega^{2}}= \begin{cases}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{1}, \\ \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{2} .\end{cases}
$$

Thus in the normal-mode given by $\omega_{1}, \theta$ and $\varphi$ are opposite in phase, while in that given by $\omega_{2}, \theta$ and $\varphi$ are in phase. In both cases the ratio of the amplitude of $\varphi$ to that of $\theta$ is

$$
\sqrt{3}: 2 \text {. }
$$

\section{1}

A simple pendulum consisting of a mass $m$ and weightless string of length $l$ is mounted on a support of mass $M$ which is attached to a horizontal spring with force constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.51.

(a) Set up Lagrange's equations.

(b) Find the frequencies for small oscillations.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-589.jpg?height=215&width=300&top_left_y=1607&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 2.51. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use coordinates with origin at the position of $m$ when the system is in equilibrium, and the $x$ - and $y$-axes along the horizontal and vertical directions respectively as shown in Fig. 2.51. Then $M$ and $m$ have coordinates and velocities

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
(x, l), & (x+l \sin \theta, l-l \cos \theta) \\
(\dot{x}, 0), & (\dot{x}+l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)
\end{array}
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 l \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)-M g l-m g l(1-\cos \theta)-\frac{1}{2} k x^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+m) \ddot{x}-m l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin \theta+m l \ddot{\theta} \cos \theta+k x &=0, \\
\ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) For small oscillations, $x, \theta, \dot{x}, \dot{\theta}$ are small quantities. Neglecting terms of orders higher than two, the equations of motion become

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+m) \ddot{x}+m l \ddot{\theta}+k x &=0, \\
\ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x}+g \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Set

$$
x=A \exp (i \omega t), \quad \theta=B \exp (i \omega t) .
$$

These equations become

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
k-(M+m) \omega^{2} & -m l \omega^{2} \\
-\omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
k-(M+m) \omega^{2} & -m l \omega^{2} \\
-\omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=M l \omega^{2}-[g(M+m)+k l] \omega^{2}+g k=0
$$

has two positive roots

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{1}=\left[\frac{g(M+m)+k l+\sqrt{[g(M+m)+k l]^{2}-4 M l g k}}{2 M l}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}, \\
&\omega_{2}=\left[\frac{g(M+m)+k l-\sqrt{[g(M+m)+k l]^{2}-4 M l g k}}{2 M l}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

which are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system.

\section{2}

Two masses, $2 m$ and $m$, are suspended from a fixed frame by elastic springs as shown in Fig. 2.52. The elastic constant (force/unit length) of each spring is $k$. Consider only vertical motion.

(a) Calculate the frequencies of the normal-modes of oscillations of this system.

(b) The upper mass $2 m$ is slowly displaced downwards from the equilibrium position by a distance $l$ and then let go, so that the system performs free oscillations. Calculate the subsequent motion of the lower mass $m$.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-591.jpg?height=250&width=209&top_left_y=1296&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 2.52.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let the natural lengths of the upper and lower springs be $l_{1}, l_{2}$, and denote the positions of the upper and lower masses by $y_{1}, y_{2}$ as shown in Fig. 2.52, respectively. The Lagrangian is then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=m \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{y}_{2}^{2}+2 m g y_{1}+m g y_{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(2 \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right)+m g\left(2 y_{1}+y_{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}+2 k y_{1}-k y_{2} &=2 m g+k l_{1}-k l_{2} \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}+k y_{2}-k y_{1} &=m g+k l_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $y_{1}=y_{1}^{\prime}+\eta_{1}, y_{2}=y_{2}^{\prime}+\eta_{2}$.

The above can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}^{\prime}+2 k y_{1}^{\prime}-k y_{2}^{\prime} &=0, \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}^{\prime}+k y_{2}^{\prime}-k y_{1}^{\prime} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

if we set

$$
\eta_{1}=\frac{3 m g+k l_{1}}{k}, \quad \eta_{2}=\frac{4 m g+k l_{1}+k l_{2}}{k} .
$$

Note that $y_{1}=\eta_{1}, y_{2}=\eta_{2}$ are the equilibrium positions of the masses $2 m$ and $m$ respectively, as can be seen from the force equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 m g &=k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right) \\
m g &=k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

With a solution of the type

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

we have

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

has two positive roots

$$
\omega_{\pm}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1 \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)},
$$

which are the angular frequencies of the normal-modes of oscillation. As

$$
\frac{B}{A}=\frac{2 k-2 m \omega^{2}}{k}=\mp \sqrt{2},
$$

the corresponding normal-modes are $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -\sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ \sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$.
