(b) The general motion of the system is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y_{1}^{\prime}=A \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varphi_{2}\right) \\
&y_{2}^{\prime}=-\sqrt{2} A \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+\sqrt{2} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varphi_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial condition is that at $t=0$,

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=y_{2}^{\prime}=l, \quad \dot{y}_{1}^{\prime}=\dot{y}_{2}^{\prime}=0 .
$$

This gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}=0, \\
A=\frac{l}{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right), \quad A^{\prime}=\frac{l}{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence the motion of the mass $2 m$ is described by

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{2}=(&\left.\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right] \\
&+\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right]+l_{1}+l_{2}+\frac{4 m g}{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{3}

Three massless springs of natural length $\sqrt{2}$ and spring constant $K$ are attached to a point particle of mass $m$ and to the fixed points $(-1,1),(1,1)$ and $(-1,-1)$ as shown in Fig. 2.53. The point mass $m$ is allowed to move in the $(x, y)$-plane only.

(a) Write the Lagrangian for the system.

(b) Is there a stable equilibrium for the point mass? Where is it?

(c) Give the Lagrangian appropriate for small oscillations.

(d) Introduce normal coordinates and solve for the motion of the particle in the small oscillation approximation.

(e) Sketch the normal-modes of vibration.

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-594.jpg?height=320&width=331&top_left_y=650&top_left_x=295)

Fig. 2.53.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-594.jpg?height=219&width=207&top_left_y=721&top_left_x=820)

(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-594.jpg?height=243&width=217&top_left_y=719&top_left_x=1118)

(b)

Fig. $2.54$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let the coordinates of the mass $m$ be $(x, y)$. Its Lagrangian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{y}^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{(x-1)^{2}+(y-1)^{2}}-\sqrt{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{(x+1)^{2}+(y-1)^{2}}-\sqrt{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{(x+1)^{2}+(y+1)^{2}}-\sqrt{2}\right]^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) From the conditions of a stable equilibrium

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=0, \quad \frac{\partial V}{\partial y}=0, \quad \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}+\frac{2 \partial^{2} V}{\partial x \partial y}+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial y^{2}}>0
$$

we find one stable equilibrium position $(0,0)$. (c) For small oscillations, $x, y, \dot{x}, \dot{y}$ are small quantities. Expanding $L$ and retaining only the lowest-order terms in these small quantities we have

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{y}^{2}-\frac{1}{4} K\left(3 x^{2}+2 x y+3 y^{2}\right) .
$$

(d) The kinetic and potential energies can respectively be represented by matrices

We have the matrix equation

$$
\mathbf{T}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
m & 0 \\
0 & m
\end{array}\right), \quad \mathbf{V}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{3}{2} K & \frac{1}{2} K \\
\frac{1}{2} K & \frac{3}{2} K
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$
\left(\mathbf{V}-\omega^{2} \mathbf{T}\right) \mathbf{U}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{3}{2} K-m \omega^{2} & \frac{1}{2} K \\
\frac{1}{2} K & \frac{3}{2} K-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
U_{1} \\
U_{2}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

For nonvanishing solutions we require that

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{3}{2} K-m \omega^{2} & \frac{1}{2} K \\
\frac{1}{2} K & \frac{3}{2} K-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
\left(2 K-m w^{2}\right)\left(K-m \omega^{2}\right)=0 .
$$

Its two positive roots give the normal frequencies and the corresponding normal-modes of vibrations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 K}{m}}, \quad U_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\1\end{array}\right), \\
& \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}, \quad U_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\-1\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The general motion of the particle for small oscillations is then

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
x \\
y
\end{array}\right)=A\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+B\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right) \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)
$$

where $A, B, \varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions. The normal coordinates are given by

$$
\bar{q}_{s}=\sum_{i, j} U_{i} a_{i j} q_{j},
$$

where $a_{i j}$ are the elements of the matrix $\mathbf{T}$. Thus for the $\omega_{1}$ mode, the normal coordinate is

$$
\xi=U_{1} m x+U_{2} m y=U_{1} m(x+y) .
$$

The constant factor $U_{1} m$ is immaterial and we can take

$$
\xi=x+y
$$

Similarly for the $\omega_{2}$ mode

$$
\eta=U_{1} m(x-y)
$$

and we can take

$$
\eta=x-y
$$

$\xi, \eta$ are the normal coordinates of the system.

(e) For $\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 K}{m}}$

$$
U_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right),
$$

so the point mass oscillates along the line $y=x$ as shown in Fig. 2.54(a).

For $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}$

$$
U_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right)
$$

and the point mass oscillates along the line $y=-x$ as shown in Fig. 2.54(b).

\section{4}

One simple pendulum is hung from another; that is, the string of the lower pendulum is tied to the bob of the upper one. Using arbitrary lengths for the strings and arbitrary masses for the bobs, set up the Lagrangian of the system. Use the angles each string makes with the vertical as generalized coordinates. Discuss small oscillations of this system. What are the normal-modes? What are the corresponding frequencies? Show that in the special case of equal masses and equal lengths the frequencies are given by $\sqrt{\frac{g(2 \pm \sqrt{2})}{l}}$. Under what conditions will the system move as a single piece? 

\section{Solution:}

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-597.jpg?height=377&width=265&top_left_y=259&top_left_x=647)

Fig. 2.55.

Let $m_{1}, m_{2}$ be the masses of the bobs and $l_{1}, l_{2}$ the lengths of the two strings, as shown in Fig. 2.55. The two bobs $m_{1}, m_{2}$ have coordinates

$$
\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \sin \theta_{2},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}-l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right)
$$

and velocities

$$
\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
$$

respectively. Then the kinetic energy $T$ of the system is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 T &=m_{1} l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+m_{2}\left[l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)\right] \\
&=\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+m_{2} l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right) \\
& \approx\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+m_{2} l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the potential energy $V$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 V &=-2 m_{1} g l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}-2 m_{2} g\left(l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
& \approx-2\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g l_{1}\left(1-\frac{1}{2} \theta_{1}^{2}\right)-m_{2} g l_{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{2} \theta_{2}^{2}\right) \\
&=V_{0}+\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g l_{1} \theta_{1}^{2}+m_{2} g l_{2} \theta_{2}^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For small oscillations, we have retained only terms of up to the order two of the small quantities $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \dot{\theta}_{1}, \dot{\theta}_{2}$. The Lagrangian of the system is given by $L=T-V$. To find the normal-modes we write these in matrix form: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&2 T=\sum_{i, j=1}^{2} M_{i j} \dot{\theta}_{i} \dot{\theta}_{j}=\dot{\theta}^{\prime} \mathbf{M} \dot{\theta} \\
&2 V=V_{0}+\sum_{i, j=1}^{2} K_{i j} \theta_{i} \theta_{j}=V_{0}+\Theta^{\prime} \mathbf{K} \Theta
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M} &=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}^{2} & m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \\
m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} & m_{2} l_{2}^{2}
\end{array}\right), \\
\mathbf{K} &=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g l_{1} & 0 \\
0 & m_{2} g l_{2}
\end{array}\right), \\
\Theta &=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\theta_{1} \\
\theta_{2}
\end{array}\right), \quad \dot{\Theta}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{\theta}_{1} \\
\dot{\theta}_{2}
\end{array}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\Theta^{\prime}, \dot{\theta}^{\prime}$ being the transpose matrices of $\Theta, \dot{\theta}$ respectively. Considering a solution of the type

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
\theta_{2} \\
\theta_{2}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{l}
A_{1} \\
A_{2}
\end{array}\right) \cos (\omega t+\varepsilon),
$$

we have

$$
\left(\mathbf{K}-\omega^{2} \mathbf{M}\right) \mathbf{A}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}\left(g-l_{1} \omega^{2}\right) & -m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{2} \\
-m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{2} & m_{2} l_{2}\left(g-l_{2} \omega^{2}\right)
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A_{1} \\
A_{2}
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

For $A_{1}, A_{2}$ not to be zero identically we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}\left(g-l_{1} \omega^{2}\right) & -m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{2} \\
-m_{2} l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{2} & m_{2} l_{2}\left(g-l_{2} \omega^{2}\right)
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

or

$$
m_{1} l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{4}-\left(l_{2}+l_{2}\right)\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g \omega^{2}+\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g^{2}=0 .
$$

Its positive roots

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{\pm}=& {\left[\frac { g } { 2 l _ { 1 } l _ { 2 } m _ { 1 } } \left\{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)\right.\right.} \\
&\left.\left.\pm \sqrt{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left[m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}\right]}\right\}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}} &=\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}}\left(\frac{g}{l_{2} \omega^{2}}-1\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2 l_{1}}\left\{\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right) \mp \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}}\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

the normal-modes are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{l}
\theta_{1} \\
\theta_{2}
\end{array}\right)=&\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{l_{1}-l_{2}}{2 l_{1}} \mp \frac{1}{2 l_{1}} \sqrt{\left[m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}\right] /\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}
\end{array}\right) \\
& \times A_{\pm} \cos \left(\omega_{\pm} t+\varepsilon_{\pm}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where the top and bottom signs correspond to $\omega_{+}$, and $\omega_{-}$respectively. The general solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \theta_{1}=\left\{\frac{l_{1}-l_{2}}{2 l_{1}}-\frac{1}{2 l_{1}} \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}}\right\} A_{+} \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varepsilon_{+}\right) \\
& +\left\{\frac{l_{1}-l_{2}}{2 l_{1}}+\frac{1}{2 l_{1}} \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}}\right\} A_{-} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varepsilon_{-}\right), \\
& \theta_{2}=A_{+} \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varepsilon_{+}\right)+A_{-} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varepsilon_{-}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A_{+}, A_{-}, \varepsilon_{+}$and $\varepsilon_{-}$are constants to be determined from the initial conditions.

In the special case of equal masses and equal lengths, $m_{1}=m_{2}=m$, $l_{1}=l_{2}=l$, the normal frequencies are

$$
\omega_{\pm}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}(2 \pm \sqrt{2})} .
$$

For the system to move as a single piece, we require $\theta_{1}=\theta_{2}$, i.e.

$$
\frac{1}{2 l_{1}}\left[\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right) \mp \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}+m_{1}\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}}\right]=1 \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)=\mp \sqrt{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}-4 m_{1}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1} l_{2}} .
$$

As the left-hand side is positive, the bottom sign of the right-hand side has to be used. Furthermore, squaring both sides gives

$$
l_{1} l_{2} m_{1}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)=0 .
$$

This requires either $l_{1}=0$, or $l_{2}=0$, or $m_{1}=0$. Each of these cases will reduce the two-pendulum system into a one-pendulum one. Hence the two-pendulum system cannot move as a single piece.

\section{5}

(a) Consider two simple pendulums each of mass $m$ and length $l$ joined by a massless spring with spring constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.56(a). The distance between the pivots is chosen so that the spring is unstreched when the pendulums are vertical. Find the frequencies and normal-modes for the small oscillations of this system about equilibrium.

(b) Now consider an infinite row of pendulums with each pendulum connected to its neighbors just as the pair in part (a) is connected, as shown in Fig. 2.56(b). Find the normal-modes and the corresponding frequencies for this new system.

(Columbia $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-600.jpg?height=169&width=217&top_left_y=1190&top_left_x=179)

(a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-600.jpg?height=173&width=465&top_left_y=1188&top_left_x=443)

(b)

Fig. $2.56$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-600.jpg?height=188&width=351&top_left_y=1195&top_left_x=938)

Fig. $2.57$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $a$ be the natural length of each spring. Number the pendulums from the left, and use coordinates with the origin at the equilibrium position of the bob of pendulum 1 and the $x$-, $y$-axes along the horizontal and vertical directions, as shown in Fig. 2.57. Then the two bobs have coordinates

$$
\left(l \sin \theta_{1}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{1}\right)\right), \quad\left(a+l \sin \theta_{2}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{2}\right)\right)
$$

and velocities 

$$
\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left(l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}\right)-m g l\left(2-\cos \theta_{1}-\cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k\left(a+l \sin \theta_{2}-l \sin \theta_{1}-a\right)^{2} \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m g l\left(\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for small oscillations.

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}_{1}+m g l \theta_{1}-k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)=0 \\
&m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2}+m g l \theta_{2}+k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\xi=\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}, \eta=\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}$. The sum and difference of the above two equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
l \ddot{\xi}+g \xi &=0, \\
m l \ddot{\eta}+(m g+2 k l) \eta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\xi$ and $\eta$ are the two normal coordinates of the system with the normal angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}} .
$$

As

$$
\theta_{1}=\frac{1}{2}(\xi+\eta), \quad \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{2}(\xi-\eta),
$$

their amplitudes $u_{1}, u_{2}$ have the ratio

$$
u_{1}: u_{2}=1: 1
$$

for the $\omega_{1}$ mode, for which $\eta=0$, and

$$
u_{1}: u_{2}=1:-1
$$

for the $\omega_{2}$ mode, for which $\xi=0$.

(b) The same treatment gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+\cdots+\dot{\theta}_{n}^{2}+\cdots\right)-\frac{1}{2} m g l\left(\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}+\cdots+\theta_{n}^{2}+\cdots\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k l^{2}\left[\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}+\cdots\right.\\
&\left.+\left(\theta_{n}-\theta_{n-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\theta_{n+1}-\theta_{n}\right)^{2}+\cdots\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations then give

$$
m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}_{n}+m g l \theta_{n}+k l^{2}\left[\left(\theta_{n}-\theta_{n-1}\right)-\left(\theta_{n+1}-\theta_{n}\right)\right]=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
m l \ddot{\theta}_{n}+m g \theta_{n}+k l\left(2 \theta_{n}-\theta_{n+1}-\theta_{n-1}\right)=0 .
$$

Since $\theta_{n}$ remains finite as $n \rightarrow \infty$, assume the amplitude varies periodically along the $x$-axis and try

$$
\theta_{n}=A e^{i(\kappa n a-\omega t)},
$$

where the "wave number" $\kappa=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}$, with the "wavelength" $\lambda$ being integral multiples of $a$, i.e. $\lambda=p a, p=1,2,3, \ldots$. Substitution gives

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}[1-\cos (\kappa a)]} .
$$

The first few normal angular frequencies are for 

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p=1, \quad \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \\
& p=2, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{4 k}{m}} \text {, } \\
& p=3, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{3 k}{m}}, \\
& p=4, \quad \omega_{4}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}},
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding normal-modes (for $p=1,2,3,4, \ldots$ ) are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{c}
\theta_{1} \\
\theta_{2} \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right)=&\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
1 \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right) A e^{-i \omega t},\left(\begin{array}{r}
-1 \\
1 \\
-1 \\
1 \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right) A e^{-i \omega t}, \\
&\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{i \frac{2}{3} \pi} \\
e^{i \frac{4}{3} \pi} \\
1 \\
e^{i \frac{2}{3} \pi} \\
e^{i \frac{4}{3} \pi} \\
1 \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right) A e^{-i \omega t}, \quad\left(\begin{array}{c}
e^{i \frac{1}{2} \pi} \\
e^{i \pi} \\
e^{i \frac{3}{2} \pi} \\
1 \\
e^{i \frac{1}{2} \pi} \\
e^{i \pi} \\
e^{i \frac{3}{2} \pi} \\
1 \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right) A e^{-i \omega t}, \ldots .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{6}

Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in two dimensions in a potential

$$
V(x, y)=-\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \lambda_{0} x^{2} y^{2}+\frac{1}{4} \lambda_{1} x^{4}, \quad k, \lambda_{0}, \lambda_{1}>0 .
$$

(a) At what point $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is the particle in stable equilibrium?

(b) Give the Lagrangian appropriate for small oscillations about this equilibrium position. (c) What are the normal frequencies of vibration in (b)?

(Columbia )

\section{Solution:}

(a) A point where $\partial V / \partial x=0, \partial V / \partial y=0, \partial^{2} V / \partial x^{2}>0, \partial^{2} V / \partial y^{2}>0$ and

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}(d x)^{2}+2 \frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x \partial y} d x d y+\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial y^{2}}(d y)^{2}>0
$$

is a point of stable equilibrium. For the given potential we find two such points, $\left(\sqrt{k / \lambda_{1}}, 0\right)$ and $\left(-\sqrt{k / \lambda_{1}}, 0\right)$.

(b) $V$ is a minimum at a point of stable equilibrium $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$. At a neighboring point $(x, y)$, we have, to second order of the small qualities $x-x_{0}, y-y_{0}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(x, y)=& V\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}, y_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}\right.\\
&\left.+2\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x \partial y}\right)_{x_{0}, y_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)\left(y-y_{0}\right)+\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial y^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}, y_{0}}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}\right]+\cdots \\
\approx &-\frac{k^{2}}{4 \lambda_{1}}+\frac{1}{2}\left[2 k\left(x-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{1}}}\right)^{2}+\frac{k \lambda_{0} y^{2}}{\lambda_{1}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

for the equilibrium point $\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{1}}}, 0\right)$.

Translate the coordinate system to the new origin $\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{1}}}, 0\right)$

$$
x^{\prime}=x-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda}}, \quad y^{\prime}=y,
$$

and take the new origin as the reference level for potential energy. Then

$$
V\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)=\frac{1}{2} k\left(x^{\prime 2}+\frac{\lambda_{0}}{\lambda_{1}} y^{\prime 2}\right)
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{\prime 2}+\dot{y}^{\prime 2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k\left(x^{\prime 2}+\frac{\lambda_{0}}{\lambda_{1}} y^{\prime 2}\right) .
$$

Similarly for the other point of equilibrium, we set

$$
x^{\prime \prime}=x+\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda}}, \quad y^{\prime \prime}=y
$$

and obtain the same Lagrangian, but with $x^{\prime \prime}, y^{\prime \prime}$ replacing $x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}$.

(c) The secular equation

$$
\left|V-\omega^{2} T\right|=0,
$$

or

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-m \omega^{2} & 0 \\
0 & \frac{k \lambda_{0}}{\lambda_{1}}-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

has positive roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k \lambda_{0}}{m \lambda_{1}}} .
$$

These are the normal angular frequencies for small oscillations of the system, about either of the points of equilibrium.

\section{7}

A negligibly thin piece of metal of mass $m$ in the shape of a square hangs from two identical springs at two corners as shown in Fig. 2.58. The springs can move only in the vertical plane. Calculate the frequencies of vibration of the normal-modes of small amplitude oscillations.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-605.jpg?height=258&width=268&top_left_y=1548&top_left_x=275)

Fig. 2.58.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-605.jpg?height=273&width=266&top_left_y=1555&top_left_x=906)

Fig. 2.59. 

\section{Solution:}

Let $x$ be the vertical displacement of the center of mass of the square from its equilibrium position and $\theta$ the angle of rotation of the square in the vertical plane containing the springs as shown in Fig. 2.59. The square has moment of inertial $\frac{1}{6} m s^{2}, s$ being the length of each side of the square. For small $\theta$, the extensions of the springs are $x+\frac{1}{2} s \theta$ and $x-\frac{1}{2} s \theta$. Hence the kinetic and potential energies are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m s^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \\
&V=-m g x+\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(x+\frac{1}{2} s \theta\right)^{2}+\left(x-\frac{1}{2} s \theta\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k$ is the spring constant, taking the potential reference level at the equilibrium position, and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m s^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g x-k\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{4} s^{2} \theta^{2}\right) .
$$

\section{Lagrange's equations}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}+2 k x-m g=0, \\
&\frac{1}{6} m s^{2} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{1}{2} k s^{2} \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x^{\prime}=x-\frac{m g}{2 k}$ and we can write the first equation as

$$
m \ddot{x}^{\prime}+2 k x^{\prime}=0 .
$$

Thus $x^{\prime}$ and $\theta$ are the normal coordinates of the system with the corresponding normal angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} .
$$



\section{8}

A small sphere, mass $m$ and radius $r$, hangs like a pendulum between two plates of a capacitor, as shown in Fig. 2.60, from an insulating rod of length $l$. The plates are grounded and the potential of the sphere is $V$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-607.jpg?height=429&width=540&top_left_y=506&top_left_x=407)

Fig, $2.60$.

The position of the sphere is displaced by an amount $\Delta x$. Calculate the frequency of small oscillations and specify for what conditions of the voltage $V$ such oscillations occur. Make reasonable approximations to simplify the calculation.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

We assume that the mass of the insulating rod and the radius of the sphere are very small and can be neglected. The charge on the sphere is

$$
q=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r V
$$

$\varepsilon_{0}$ being the permittivity of free space. According to the method of images, the forces between the sphere and the plates of the capacitor are the same as those between the charges on the sphere and its images symmetrically located at positions as shown in Fig. 2.60. Take $x$-axis along the horizontal with origin at the equilibrium position. The kinetic and potential energies of the system are respectively 

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2} \\
V &=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{1}{b+2 x}+\frac{1}{b-2 x}\right]+m g l(1-\cos \theta) \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{2 b}{b^{2}-4 x^{2}}+m g l(1-\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

For small $x, x \approx l \theta$,

$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}-4 x^{2}} \approx \frac{1}{b^{2}}\left(1+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2}}{b^{2}}\right),
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b}\left(1+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2}}{b^{2}}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}-\frac{4 q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{l^{2} \theta}{b^{3}}+m g l \theta=0 .
$$

Hence the angular frequency of small oscillations is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{4 q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{1}{m b^{3}}}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} V^{2}}{m b^{3}}} .
$$

The condition for such oscillations to take place is that $\omega$ be real, i.e.

$$
V<\sqrt{\frac{g m b^{3}}{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} l}}
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-609.jpg?height=483&width=1010&top_left_y=217&top_left_x=197)

Fig. $2.61$

Note that the above solution is only approximate since the images themselves will produce more images, some of which are shown in Fig. 2.61, which also have to be taken into account. Thus the potential due to electrostatic interactions is

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b-2 x}+\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b+2 x}-\frac{2}{2 n b}\right] \\
& \approx-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left\{\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b}\left[1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{(2 n-1)^{2} b^{2}}\right]-\frac{1}{2 n b}\right\} \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left[\left(\frac{1}{2 n-1}-\frac{1}{2 n}\right)+\frac{4 x^{2}}{(2 n-1)^{3} b^{2}}\right] \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b}\left(\alpha+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2} \beta}{b^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2 n(2 n-1)}, \quad \beta=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2 n-1)^{3}} .
$$

This would give

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} V^{2} \beta}{m b^{3}}}
$$

and the condition for oscillations 

$$
V<\sqrt{\frac{g m b^{3}}{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} l \beta}} .
$$

The $\beta$ series converges rapidly. With maximum $n=3, \beta=1.05$ and the third decimal remains unchanged when more terms are added. As $\beta^{-\frac{1}{2}}=0.98$, the two-image calculation gives a good approximation.

\section{9}

A smooth uniform circular hoop of mass $M$ and radius $a$ swings in a vertical plane about a point $O$ at which it is freely hinged to a fixed support. A bead $B$ of mass $m$ slides without friction on the hoop. Denote the inclination $O C$ (where $C$ is the center of the hoop) to the downward vertical by $\varphi$.

(a) Find the equations of motion for $\theta$ and $\varphi$.

(b) Find the characteristic frequencies and normal-modes for small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium.

(Chicago )

\section{Solution:}

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-610.jpg?height=338&width=301&top_left_y=1127&top_left_x=661)

Fig. $2.62$

(a) The moment of inertia of the hoop about $O$ is

$$
I=M a^{2}+M a^{2}=2 M a^{2} .
$$

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.62. The coordinates and velocity of the bead are respectively

$(a \sin \theta+a \sin \varphi,-a \cos \theta-a \cos \varphi),(a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, a \dot{\theta} \sin \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi)$. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& M a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2}\left[\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+M g a \cos \theta+m g a(\cos \theta+\cos \varphi) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(2 M+m) a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m a^{2} \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi) \\
&+(M+m) g a \cos \theta+m g a \cos \varphi
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(2 M+m) a \ddot{\theta}+m a \ddot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+m a \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+(M+m) g \sin \theta=0, \\
&a \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+a \ddot{\varphi}-a \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) For small oscillations, retaining terms up to second order in the small quantities $\theta, \varphi, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}$, we have from the above

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{M+m}{2 M+m}\right) \frac{g \theta}{a}+\frac{m}{2 M+m} \ddot{\varphi}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}+\frac{g}{a} \varphi+\ddot{\varphi}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution of the type $\theta=A \exp (i \omega t), \varphi=B \exp (i \omega t)$, the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\left(\frac{M+m}{2 M+m}\right) \frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}\right] A-\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2 M+m} B } &=0 \\
-\omega^{2} A+\left(\frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}\right) B &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For nonzero solutions the determinant of the coefficients must vanish. Thus

$$
\left[M \omega^{2}-\frac{(M+m) g}{a}\right]\left(2 \omega^{2}-\frac{g}{a}\right)=0
$$

whose two positive roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 a}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{M+m}{M}\right) \frac{g}{a}}
$$

are the characteristic angular frequencies of the system for small oscillations. As $\frac{A}{B}=\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}-1$, we have for $\omega=\omega_{1}, \frac{A}{B}=1$ and the normal-mode $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$, for $\omega=\omega_{2}, \frac{A}{B}=-\frac{m}{M+m}$ and the normal-mode $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -\frac{M+m}{m}\end{array}\right)$.

\section{0}

A small body of mass $m$ and charge $q$ is constrained to move without friction on the interior of a cone of opening angle $2 \alpha$. A charge $-q$ is fixed at the apex of the cone as shown in Fig. 2.63. There is no gravity. Find the frequency of small oscillations about equilibrium trajectories of the moving body in terms of $\dot{\varphi}_{0}$, the equilibrium angular velocity of the body around the inside of the cone. Assume $v \ll c$ so that radiation is negligible.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-612.jpg?height=487&width=297&top_left_y=779&top_left_x=659)

(UC, Berkeley)

Fig. $2.63$

\section{Solution:}

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.63. In the Cartesian system, $m$ has coordinates $(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z)$, or, as $z=r \cot \alpha,(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, r \cot \alpha)$, and velocity

$(\dot{r} \cos \varphi-r \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi, r \sin \varphi+r \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, \dot{r} \cot \alpha)$.

The Lagrangian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{r}^{2} \cot ^{2} \alpha\right)+\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\sin \alpha}{r} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2} \csc ^{2} \alpha+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}\right)+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Analytical Mechanics

601

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{r} \csc ^{2} \alpha-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}=0 \\
m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=J \text { (constant) }
\end{gathered}
$$

or, combining the above,

$$
m \ddot{r} \csc ^{2} \alpha-\frac{J^{2}}{m r^{3}}+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}=0
$$

For the equilibrium trajectory,

$$
\ddot{r}=0, \quad r=r_{0}, \quad \dot{\varphi}=\dot{\varphi}_{0},
$$

the above becomes

$$
\frac{J^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}=\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{2}}
$$

For small oscillations about equilibrium, let $r=r_{0}+\xi$, where $\xi \ll r_{0}$. Then

$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \approx \frac{1}{r_{0}^{2}}\left(1-\frac{2 \xi}{r_{0}}\right), \quad \frac{1}{r^{3}}=\frac{1}{r_{0}^{3}}\left(1-\frac{3 \xi}{r_{0}}\right)
$$

and Eq. (1) becomes

$$
m \ddot{\xi}+\frac{q^{2} \sin ^{3} \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{3}} \xi=0 .
$$

Hence the angular frequency for small oscillations is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{q^{2} \sin ^{3} \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m r_{0}^{3}}}=\dot{\varphi}_{0} \sin \alpha,
$$

as

$$
\dot{\varphi}_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{J^{2}}{m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}}=\sqrt{\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m r_{0}^{3}}} .
$$



\section{1}

A flywheel of moment of inertia I rotates about its center in a horizontal plane. A mass $m$ can slide freely along one of the spokes and is attached to the center of the wheel by a spring of natural length $l$ and force constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.64.

(a) Find an expression for the energy of this system in terms of $r, \dot{r}$, and the angular momentum $J$.

(b) Suppose the flywheel initially has a constant angular velocity $\Omega_{0}$ and the spring has a steady extension $r=r_{0}$. Use the result of part (a) to determine the relation between $\Omega_{0}$ and $r_{0}$ and the frequency of small oscillations about this initial configuration.

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-614.jpg?height=304&width=312&top_left_y=867&top_left_x=629)

Fig. 2.64.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $r$ be the distance of $m$ from the center and $\dot{\theta}$ the angular velocity of the flywheel at time $t$. The system has angular momentum

$$
J=I \dot{\theta}+m r^{2} \dot{\theta}
$$

and energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
T+V &=\frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2} \\
&=\frac{J^{2}}{2\left(I+m r^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{r}-m r \dot{\theta}^{2}+k(r-l)=0, \\
&\left(I+m r^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }=J,
\end{aligned}
$$

or, combining the two,

$$
m \ddot{r}-\frac{m r J^{2}}{\left(I+m r^{2}\right)^{2}}+k(r-l)=0 .
$$

Initially, $\ddot{r}=0, r=r_{0}, \dot{\theta}=\Omega_{0}, J=\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right) \Omega_{0}$. For small oscillations about this equilibrium configuration, let $r=r_{0}+\rho$, where $\rho \ll r_{0}$. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{m r J^{2}}{\left(I+m r^{2}\right)^{2}} & \approx \frac{m\left(r_{0}+\rho\right) J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}+2 m r_{0} \rho\right)^{2}} \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}\left(1+\frac{\rho}{r_{0}}-\frac{4 m r_{0} \rho}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[1-\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \frac{\rho}{r_{0}}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}-\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) m \Omega_{0}^{2} \rho, \\
\frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}} &=m r_{0} \Omega_{0}^{2}=k\left(r_{0}-l\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (2) becomes

$$
\ddot{\rho}+\left[\frac{k}{m}+\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}\right] \rho=0 .
$$

Therefore, provided that $I$ is such that

$$
\left(\frac{I-3 m r_{0}^{2}}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}<\frac{k}{m},
$$

the system will oscillate about the initial configuration with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}+\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}}
$$

after a small perturbation. Note that Eq. (1) implies

$$
r_{0}=\frac{k l}{k-m \Omega_{0}^{2}},
$$

i.e. $r_{0}$ itself is related to $\Omega_{0}$.

\section{2}

Three point-like masses (two of them equal) and the massless springs (constant $K$ ) connecting them are constrained to move in a frictionless tube of radius $R$. This system is in gravitational field (g) as shown in Fig. 2.65. The springs are of zero length at equilibrium and the masses may move through one another. Using Lagrangian methods, find the normal-modes of small vibration about the position of equilibrium of this system and describe each of the modes.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-616.jpg?height=206&width=308&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=323)

Fig. 2.65.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-616.jpg?height=312&width=369&top_left_y=1265&top_left_x=935)

Fig. 2.66.

\section{Solution:}

Use Cartesian coordinates $(\xi, \eta)$ as shown in Fig. 2.66. The $i$ th mass has coordinates $\left(R \sin \theta_{i}, R\left(1-\cos \theta_{i}\right)\right)$. For small oscillations these can be approximated as $\left(R \theta_{i}, \frac{1}{2} R \theta_{i}^{2}\right)$, or $\left(x_{i}, \frac{1}{2} x_{i}^{2}\right)$ with $x_{i}=R \theta_{i}$. Then, neglecting terms of orders greater than two of the small quantities $x_{i}, \dot{x}_{i}$, we have for the kinetic and potential energies

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{3}^{2}, \\
&V=\frac{1}{2} K\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} M x_{2}^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Lagrangian

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& \frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{3}^{2} \\
&-\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(K+\frac{m g}{R}\right)\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(2 K+\frac{M g}{R}\right) x_{2}^{2}-K\left(x_{1} x_{2}+x_{2} x_{3}\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{array}{r}
m \ddot{x}_{1}+\left(K+\frac{m g}{R}\right) x_{1}-K x_{2}=0, \\
M \ddot{x}_{2}+\left(2 K+\frac{M g}{R}\right) x_{2}-K\left(x_{1}+x_{3}\right)=0 \\
m \ddot{x}_{3}+\left(K+\frac{m g}{R}\right) x_{3}-K x_{2}=0 .
\end{array}
$$

\section{Letting}

$$
x_{j}=A_{j} e^{i \omega t}
$$

in the above we obtain the matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
K+\frac{m g}{R}-m \omega^{2} & -K & 0 \\
-K & 2 K+\frac{M g}{R}-M \omega^{2} & -K \\
0 & -K & K+\frac{m g}{R}-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A_{1} \\
A_{2} \\
A_{3}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

For solutions in which not all $A_{i}$ are zero, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
K+\frac{m g}{R}-m \omega^{2} & -K & 0 \\
-K & 2 K+\frac{M g}{R}-M \omega^{2} & -K \\
0 & -K & K+\frac{m g}{R}-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

whose three non-negative roots are the angular frequencies of the normalmodes of the system: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}+\frac{K}{m}}, \\
& \left.\begin{array}{l}\omega_{2} \\\omega_{3}\end{array}\right\}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}+\frac{K}{2 m}+\frac{K}{M} \pm K\left(\frac{1}{4 m^{2}}+\frac{1}{m M}+\frac{1}{M^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Equation (1) gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{A_{2}}{A_{1}}=\frac{A_{2}}{A_{3}}=1+\frac{m g}{R K}-\frac{m \omega^{2}}{K}, \\
K A_{1}-\left(2 K+\frac{M g}{R}-M \omega^{2}\right) A_{2}+K A_{3}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

These equations give for $\omega_{1}: A_{3}=-A_{1}, A_{2}=0$;

for $\omega_{2}: \quad B_{3}=B_{1}, \quad \frac{B_{2}}{B_{1}}=$ negative;

for $\omega_{3}: \quad C_{3}=C_{1}, \quad \frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}}=$ positive.

Hence the three corresponding normal-modes are

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
A_{1} \\
0 \\
-A_{1}
\end{array}\right), \quad\left(\begin{array}{c}
B_{1} \\
B_{2} \\
B_{1}
\end{array}\right), \quad\left(\begin{array}{l}
C_{1} \\
C_{2} \\
C_{1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

for $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ respectively, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
B_{2} &=\left[\frac{1}{2}-\frac{m}{M}-m \sqrt{\frac{1}{4 m^{2}}+\frac{1}{m M}+\frac{1}{M^{2}}}\right] B_{1}, \\
C_{2} &=\left[\frac{1}{2}-\frac{m}{M}+m \sqrt{\frac{1}{4 m^{2}}+\frac{1}{m M}+\frac{1}{M^{2}}}\right] C_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The three normal modes are depicted in Fig. 2.67.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-618.jpg?height=197&width=421&top_left_y=1652&top_left_x=511)

Fig. 2.67. 

\section{3}

In the theory of small oscillations one frequently encounters Lagrangian of the form $L=T-V$, where

$$
T=\sum_{i, j=1}^{N} \dot{q}_{i} a_{i j} \dot{q}_{j}, \quad V=\sum_{i, j=1}^{N} q_{i} b_{i j} q_{j} .
$$

The matrices $\mathbf{A}=\left(a_{i j}\right)$ and $\mathbf{B}=\left(b_{i j}\right)$ are real and symmetric.

(a) Prove that $\mathbf{A}$ is positive definite, i.e.

$$
\mathbf{x}^{+} \mathbf{A x} \geq 0
$$

for an arbitrary column matrix $\mathbf{x}$. Prove that in general the eigenvalues of such a matrix are greater than or equal to zero. Show that we need not be concerned with zero eigenvalues.

(b) Prove the existence of the matrices $\mathbf{A}^{\pm \frac{1}{2}}$.

(c) Introduce new coordinates $\theta_{j}$ by

$$
q_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S}\right)_{i j} \theta_{j}
$$

where $\mathbf{S}$ is an $N \times N$ matrix. Show that $\mathbf{S}$ can be chosen so that $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B}$ are diagonalized. Interpret the diagonal elements of the transformed $\mathbf{B}$.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) By definition,

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{k} m_{k} \dot{x}_{k}^{2} \geq 0
$$

in Cartesian coordinates. After a linear transformation

$$
x_{k}=x_{k}\left(q_{1}, q_{2}, \ldots, q_{N}\right)
$$

it becomes

$$
T=\sum_{i, j}^{n} \dot{q}_{i} a_{i j} \dot{q}_{j},
$$

but is still $\geq 0$. In matrix form,

$$
\mathbf{T}=\dot{\mathbf{q}}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A} \dot{\mathbf{q}},
$$

where

$$
\dot{\mathbf{q}}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{q}_{1} \\
\dot{q}_{2} \\
\vdots \\
\dot{q}_{N}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and the dagger denotes its transpose matrix. As the velocities $\dot{x}_{1}, \dot{x}_{2}, \ldots$ and hence the generalized velocities $\dot{q}_{1}, \dot{q}_{2}, \ldots$ are arbitrary, we have

$$
\mathbf{T}=\mathbf{x}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A x} \geq 0
$$

for an arbitrary column matrix $\mathbf{x}$. That is, $\mathbf{A}$ is positive definite.

Suppose $\mathbf{x}_{g}$ is an eigenvector of $\mathbf{A}$ with eigenvalue $\lambda_{g}$. By definition,

$$
\mathbf{A x _ { g }}=\lambda_{g} \mathbf{x}_{g},
$$

where $\lambda_{g}$ is a real number as $\mathbf{A}$ is symmetrical and real. Then

$$
\mathbf{x}_{g}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{x}_{g}=\mathbf{x}_{g}^{\dagger} \lambda_{g} \mathbf{x}_{g}=\lambda_{g} \mathbf{x}_{g}^{\dagger} \mathbf{x}_{g}=\lambda_{g} \sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{g i}^{2} .
$$

As this is greater or equal to zero as shown above, the eigenvalues $\lambda_{g} \geq 0$.

If $\lambda_{g}=0$, there is no oscillation for the corresponding mode, which then does not concern us. The vibrational degrees of freedom are simply reduced by one.

(b) For the matrices $\mathbf{A}^{\pm \frac{1}{2}}$ to exist we require that

$$
\operatorname{det}|\mathbf{A}|>0 \text {. }
$$

A real symmetrize matrix can be diagonalized by an orthogonal matrix $\mathbf{S}$, i.e. one for which $\mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{S}=I$, the unit matrix:

$$
\mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A S}=\boldsymbol{\lambda},
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ is a diagonal matrix elements $\lambda_{i j}=\lambda_{i} \delta_{i j}$. Writing $|\mathbf{A}|$ for $\operatorname{det}|\mathbf{A}|$, we have

$$
|\mathbf{A}|=|\mathbf{A}|\left|\mathbf{S}^{\dagger}\right||\mathbf{S}|=\left|\mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A S}\right|=|\boldsymbol{\lambda}|=\prod_{i=1}^{N} \lambda_{i}>0
$$

by the result of (a) (any zero $\lambda$ has been eliminated). Hence $\mathbf{A}^{\pm \frac{1}{2}}$ exists.

(c) Introduce new coordinates $\theta_{j}$ by

$$
q_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S}\right)_{i j} \theta_{j}
$$

where $\mathbf{S}$ which diagonalizes $\mathbf{A}$ is orthogonal. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{T} &=\dot{\boldsymbol{q}}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A} \dot{\mathbf{q}}=\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\right)^{\dagger} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \\
&=\dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{\dagger} \mathbf{S}^{\dagger}\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\dagger} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\mathbf{A}$ is real symmetric, $\mathbf{A}^{\dagger}=\mathbf{A}$ and

$$
\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\dagger}=\left(\mathbf{A}^{\dagger}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}},
$$

the above becomes

$$
\mathbf{T}=\dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{\dagger} \mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{S} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{\dagger} \mathbf{I} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}} .
$$

Similarly

$$
\mathbf{V}=\mathbf{q}^{\dagger} \mathbf{B}_{\mathbf{q}}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\dagger} \mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S} \boldsymbol{\theta} .
$$

As $\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}$ are real symmetric,

$$
\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\dagger}=\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\dagger} \mathbf{B}^{\dagger}\left(\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{\dagger}=\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} .
$$

$\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B A}-\frac{1}{2}$ is real symmetric and can be diagonalized by the orthogonal matrix S. We therefore have

$$
T=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \dot{\theta}_{j}^{2}, \quad V=\sum_{j=1}^{N} B_{j} \theta_{j}^{2},
$$

where $B_{j}$ are the diagonal elements of the diagonalized matrix of $\mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B A}^{-\frac{1}{2}}$, i.e.

$$
\left(\mathbf{S}^{\dagger} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{S}\right)_{i j}=B_{j} \delta_{i j} .
$$

The Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\dot{\theta}_{j}^{2}-B_{j} \theta_{j}^{2}\right)
$$

and Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\ddot{\theta}_{i}+B_{i} \theta_{i}=0, \quad i=1,2, \ldots, N .
$$

Hence $B_{i}$ are the squares of the normal angular frequencies $\omega_{i}$ of the system.

\section{4}

A flyball governor consists of two masses $m$ connected to arms of length $l$ and a mass $M$ as shown in Fig. 2.68. The assembly is constrained to rotate around a shaft on which the mass $M$ can slide up and down without friction. Neglect the mass of the arms, air friction, and assume that the diameter of the mass $M$ is small. Suppose first that the shaft is constrained to rotate at an angular velocity $\omega_{0}$.

(a) Calculate the equilibrium height of the mass $M$.

(b) Calculate the frequency of small oscillations around this value.

Suppose the shaft is now allowed to rotate freely.

(c) Does the frequency of small oscillation change? If so, calculate the new value.

(Princeton $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-622.jpg?height=432&width=283&top_left_y=1143&top_left_x=643)

Fig. 2.68.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use a rotating coordinate frame with the $x$-axis in the plane of the governor arms as shown in Fig. 2.68. In this frame the masses $m, m$ and $M$ have coordinates $(-l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta),(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta),(0,0,-2 l \cos \theta)$ respectively. In a fixed coordinate frame with the same origin and $z$-axis, the velocity is given by $\dot{\mathbf{r}}^{\prime}=\dot{\mathbf{r}}+\boldsymbol{\omega}_{0} \times \mathbf{r}$, where $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{0}=\left(0,0, \omega_{0}\right)$. Hence the corresponding velocities are $\left(-l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta_{1} l \omega_{0} \sin \theta, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta\right),\left(l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-l \omega_{0} \sin \theta\right.$, $l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta),(0,0,-2 l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)$. Thus the kinetic energy, potential energy and Lagrangian of the system are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=m l^{2} \omega_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
&V=-2 m g l \cos \theta-2 M g l \cos \theta, \\
&L=T-V=m l^{2} \omega_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2(M+m) g l \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{Lagrange's equation}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
2\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \ddot{\theta}+2 M l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin 2 \theta-m l \omega_{0}^{2} \sin 2 \theta+2(m+M) g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

At equilibrium, $\ddot{\theta}=0, \dot{\theta}=0, \theta=\theta_{0}$ and the above becomes

$$
m l \omega_{0}^{2} \sin 2 \theta_{0}=2(m+M) g \sin \theta_{0} .
$$

Solving for $\theta_{0}$ we obtain two equilibrium positions:

(i) $\theta_{0}=0$

(ii) $\cos \theta_{0}=\frac{(m+M) g}{m l \omega_{0}^{2}}$.

The distances of the mass $M$ at the two equilibrium positions from the top of the shaft are respectively

(i) $2 l \cos \theta_{0}=2 l$,

(ii) $2 l \cos \theta_{0}=\frac{2(m+M) g}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}$.

(b) When $\theta_{0}=0$, the governor collapses and there is no oscillation. Consider the equilibrium given by (ii). Let $\theta^{\prime}=\theta-\theta_{0}$, then $\dot{\theta}=\dot{\theta}^{\prime}$. For small oscillations, $\theta^{\prime} \ll \theta_{0}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin \theta & \approx \sin \theta_{0}+\theta^{\prime} \cos \theta_{0} \\
\sin 2 \theta & \approx \sin 2 \theta_{0}+2 \theta^{\prime} \cos 2 \theta_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The equation of motion becomes, retaining only first order terms of the small quantities $\theta^{\prime}, \dot{\theta}^{\prime}, \ddot{\theta}^{\prime}$ and taking account of (1),

$$
\left.\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right)\right) \ddot{\theta}^{\prime}+\left[(m+M) g \cos \theta_{0}-m l \omega_{0}^{2} \cos 2 \theta_{0}\right] \theta^{\prime}=0 .
$$

Hence the oscillation frequency is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{(m+M) g \cos \theta_{0}-m l \omega_{0}^{2} \cos 2 \theta_{0}}{\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right) l}} .
$$

(c) One would expect the oscillation frequency to be different since the angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ in the above is arbitrary. Let $\varphi$ be the angle of rotation about the shaft. Putting $\omega=\dot{\varphi}$ in the Lagrangian we have

$$
L=m l^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2(m+M) g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{gathered}
\dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta=c \quad \text { (a constant) } \\
2\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l \ddot{\theta}+2 M l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin 2 \theta-m l \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin 2 \theta+2(m+M) g \sin \theta=0,
\end{gathered}
$$

which combine to give

$$
\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l \ddot{\theta}+M l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin 2 \theta-m l c^{2} \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin ^{3} \theta}+(m+M) g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

At equilibrium, $\ddot{\theta}=0, \dot{\theta}=0$ and $\theta=\theta_{0}$, which is given by

$$
m l c^{2} \frac{\cos \theta_{0}}{\sin ^{3} \theta_{0}}=(m+M) g \sin \theta_{0} .
$$

For small oscillations about $\theta_{0}$, let $\theta=\theta_{0}+\theta^{\prime}$, where $\theta^{\prime} \ll \theta_{0}$. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
m l c^{2} \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin ^{3} \theta} & \approx m l c^{2} \frac{\cos \theta_{0}-\theta^{\prime} \sin \theta_{0}}{\left(\sin \theta_{0}+\theta^{\prime} \cos \theta_{0}\right)^{3}} \\
& \approx m l c^{2} \frac{\cos \theta_{0}}{\sin ^{3} \theta_{0}}\left(1-\theta^{\prime} \tan \theta_{0}-3 \theta^{\prime} \cot \theta_{0}\right) \\
&=(m+M) g \sin \theta_{0}\left[1-\left(\frac{1+2 \cos ^{2} \theta_{0}}{\sin \theta_{0} \cos \theta_{0}}\right) \theta^{\prime}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (2) becomes

$$
\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right) l \ddot{\theta}^{\prime}+(m+M) g \frac{\left(1+3 \cos ^{2} \theta_{0}\right)}{\cos \theta_{0}} \theta^{\prime}=0 .
$$

Hence the frequency of small oscillations is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{(m+M) g\left(1+3 \cos ^{2} \theta_{0}\right)}{\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right) l \cos \theta_{0}}} .
$$

\section{5}

A particle of mass $M$ moves along the $x$-axis under the influence of the potential energy $V(x)=-K x \exp (-a x)$, where $K$ and $a$ are positive constants. Find the equilibrium position and the period of small oscillations about this equilibrium position. Consider also the cases where $K$ and/or $a$ are negative.

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

Expand the potential near a point $x_{0}$ :

$$
V(x)=V\left(x_{0}\right)+\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\right)_{x_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\ldots .
$$

For $x_{0}$ to be an equilibrium position,

$$
\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\right)_{x_{0}}=K\left(a x_{0}-1\right) e^{-a x_{0}}=0
$$

giving

$$
x_{0}=\frac{1}{a} .
$$

As

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{V_{0}}=a K\left(2-a x_{0}\right) e^{-a x_{0}}=\frac{a k}{e}>0
$$

the equilibrium is stable.

Let

$$
\xi=x-x_{0}=x-\frac{1}{a}
$$

and take $x_{0}$ as the reference level of potential energy. Then the potential at $\xi$ is

$$
V(\xi)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}} \xi^{2}=\frac{a K}{2 e} \xi^{2} .
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{\xi}^{2}-\frac{a K}{2 e} \xi^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\xi}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \xi}=0
$$

yields

$$
M \ddot{\xi}+\frac{a K}{e} \xi=0 .
$$

This shows that the angular frequency of small oscillations about the equilibrium position is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{a K}{M e}},
$$

and the period is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M e}{a K}} .
$$

If both $a$ and $K$ are negative, then $a K$ is positive and the above results still hold.

If only one of $a, K$ is negative then

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}}<0,
$$

which means that the potential at equilibrium is a maximum and the equilibrium is unstable. Hence no oscillation occurs. This can also be seen from the equation of motion, which would give an imaginary $\omega$.

\section{6}

A particle of mass $m$ moves under gravity on a smooth surface the equation of which is $z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y$, the $z$-axis being vertical, pointing upwards.

(a) Find the equations of motion of the particle.

(b) Find the frequencies of the normal-modes for small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium. (c) If the particle is displaced from equilibrium slightly and then released, what must be the ratio of the $x$ and $y$ displacements to guarantee that only the higher frequency normal-mode is excited?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solntion:}

(a) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y \\
&\dot{z}=2 x \dot{x}+2 y \dot{y}-\dot{x} y-x \dot{y}=\dot{x}(2 x-y)+\dot{y}(2 y-x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)^{2}+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&-m g\left(x^{2}+y^{2}-x y\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{x}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)-\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-2 g x+g y, \\
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{y}+\dot{y}(2 y-x)^{2}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)-\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-2 g y+g x .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=m g(2 x-y), \quad \frac{\partial V}{\partial y}=m g(2 y-x),
$$

equilibrium occurs at the origin $(0,0)$. For small oscillations about the origin, $x, y, \dot{x}, \dot{y}$ are small quantities and the equations of motion reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}+2 g x-g y=0, \\
&\ddot{y}+2 g y-g x=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering a solution of the type

$$
x=x_{0} e^{i \omega t}, \quad y=y_{0} e^{i \omega t},
$$

we find the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 g-\omega^{2} & -g \\
-g & 2 g-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(g-\omega^{2}\right)\left(3 g-\omega^{2}\right)=0 .
$$

Its position roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{g}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{3 g}
$$

are the angular frequencies of the normal-modes of the system. Note that as $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ are real the equilibrium is stable.

(c) As

$$
\frac{y_{0}}{x_{0}}=\frac{2 g-\omega^{2}}{g},
$$

for the higher frequency mode to be excited we require $\frac{y_{0}}{x_{0}}=-1$. Hence the initial displacements of $x$ and $y$ must be equal in magnitude and opposite in sign. Note that under this condition the lower frequency mode, which requires $y_{0} / x_{0}=1$, is not excited.

\section{7}

A rigid structure consists of three massless rods joined at a point attached to two point masses (each of mass $m$ ) as shown in Fig. 2.69, with $A B=B C=L, B D=l$, the angle $A B D=D B C=\theta$. The rigid system is supported at the point $D$ and rocks back and forth with a small amplitude of oscillation. What is the oscillation frequency? What is the limit on $l$ for stable oscillations?

$(C U S P E A)$

\section{Solution:}

The structure oscillates in a vertical plane. Take it as the $x y$-plane as shown in Fig. $2.70$ with the origin at the point of support $D$ and the $y$-axis vertically upwards. We have

$$
\overline{A D}=\overline{C D}=b=\sqrt{L^{2}+l^{2}-2 L l \cos \theta},
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-629.jpg?height=418&width=289&top_left_y=219&top_left_x=608)

Fig. 2.69.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-629.jpg?height=459&width=339&top_left_y=781&top_left_x=579)

Fig. 2.70.

and the angles between $\overline{A D}$ and $\overline{C D}$ with the vertical are $\alpha+\varphi, \alpha-\varphi$ respectively, where $\alpha=\theta+\psi, \psi$ being given by

$$
\frac{b}{\sin \theta}=\frac{l}{\sin \psi} .
$$

The masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ have coordinates

$$
(-b \sin (\alpha+\varphi),-b \cos (\alpha+\varphi)),(b \sin (\alpha-\varphi),-b \cos (\alpha-\varphi))
$$

and velocities

$$
(-b \dot{\varphi} \cos (\alpha+\varphi), b \dot{\varphi} \sin (\alpha+\varphi)),(-b \dot{\varphi} \cos (\alpha-\varphi),-b \dot{\varphi} \sin (\alpha-\varphi))
$$

respectively. Thus the Lagrangian is 

$$
L=T-V=m b^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g b[\cos (\alpha+\varphi)+\cos (\alpha-\varphi)] .
$$

\section{Lagrange's equation}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \varphi}=0
$$

then gives

$$
2 m b^{2} \ddot{\varphi}+m g b[\sin (\alpha+\varphi)-\sin (\alpha-\varphi)]=0 .
$$

For small oscillations, $\varphi \ll \alpha$ and

$$
\sin (\alpha \pm \varphi) \approx \sin \alpha \pm \varphi \cos \alpha,
$$

so the equation of motion reduces to

$$
b \ddot{\varphi}+\varphi g \cos \alpha=0,
$$

giving the angular frequency as

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g \cos \alpha}{b}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \alpha &=\cos (\theta+\psi)=\cos \theta \cos \psi-\sin \theta \sin \psi \\
&=\frac{1}{b}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}-l^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta} \cos \theta-l \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{b}(L \cos \theta-l)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g(L \cos \theta-l)}{L^{2}+l^{2}-2 L l \cos \theta}} .
$$

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \varphi^{2}} &=m g b[\cos (\alpha+\varphi)+\cos (\alpha-\varphi)] \\
&=2 m g b \cos \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

at the equilibrium position $\varphi=0$, oscillations are stable if $\cos \alpha>0$. This requires that

$$
L \cos \theta-l>0,
$$

or

$$
l<L \cos \theta .
$$



\section{HAMILTON'S CANONICAL EQUATIONS (2068-2084)}

\section{8}

A flyball governor for a steam engine consists of two balls, each of mass $m$, attached by means of four hinged arms, each of length $l$, to sleaves located on a vertical rod. The lower sleeve has mass $M$ and negligible moment of inertial, and is free to slide up and down the rod without friction. The upper sleeve is fastened to the rod. The system is constrained to rotate with constant angular velocity $\omega$.

(a) Choose suitable coordinates and write the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian functions for the system. Neglect weights of arms and rod, and neglect friction.

(b) Discuss the motion.

(c) Determine the height $z$ of the lower sleeve above its lowest position, as a function of $\omega$, for steady motion. Find the frequency of small oscillations about this steady motion.

(Wisconsin )

\section{Solution:}

(a) The governor is as shown in Fig. $2.68$ of Problem 2064. Referring to the coordinates as shown and using the results obtained there, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2(m+M) g l \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\dot{\theta} p_{\theta}-L
$$

with the generalized momentum $p_{\theta}$ defined as

$$
p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=2\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta} .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=\dot{\theta} p_{\theta}-m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta-\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-2(m+M) g l \cos \theta \\
&=\frac{p_{\theta}^{2}}{4\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l^{2}}-m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta-2(m+M) g l \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
2\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta\right) l \ddot{\theta}+2 M l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin 2 \theta-m l \omega^{2} \sin 2 \theta+2(m+M) g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

The motion is discussed in Problem 2064. Briefly, $M$ will oscillate up and down the vertical rod about an equilibrium position given by

$$
\cos \theta_{0}=\frac{(m+M) g}{m l \omega^{2}} .
$$

(c) At equilibrium, $M$ has $z$ coordinate $-2 l \cos \theta_{0}$. Hence its height above the lowest point is

$$
2 l-2 l \cos \theta_{0}=2 l\left[1-\frac{(m+M) g}{m l \omega^{2}}\right] .
$$

The angular frequency of small oscillations about the equilibrium position is (Problem 2064)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Omega &=\sqrt{\frac{(m+M) g \cos \theta_{0}-m l \omega^{2} \cos 2 \theta_{0}}{\left(m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right) l}} \\
&=\omega \sqrt{\frac{m \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}}{m+2 M \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\sin ^{2} \theta_{0}=1-\left[\frac{(m+M) g}{m l \omega^{2}}\right]^{2}
$$

\section{9}

Consider the two-body system consisting of (1) a point particle of mass $m$ and (2) a rotator of finite size and mass $M$ (see Fig. 2.71). This rotator is a rigid body which has uniform density, has an axis of symmetry, and, like the particle of mass $m$, is free to move. Discuss the motion of this system if the particle is attracted to every element of the rotator by a Coulomb or gravitational force. Include in your discussion answers to the following questions.

(a) How many degrees of freedom does this system have?

(b) What would be a suitable set of coordinates?

(c) What is the Lagrangian (or Hamiltonian)? (Write it down or say how you would try.)

(d) On what coordinates does the interaction between the particle and the rotator depend?

(e) How many constants of motion can you infer, and what are they physically?

(f) What orbits of this system are closely similar to orbits of two point masses? Describe the nature of their (small) difference. What is the nature of the motion of the rotator relative to its center of mass?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-633.jpg?height=138&width=281&top_left_y=910&top_left_x=595)

Fig. $2.71$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) The system has 9 degrees of freedom, of which 3 belong to the mass $m$ and 6 belong to the rigid rotator.

(b) One may take generalized coordinates as follows: 3 coordinates $x, y$, $z$ describing the position of the mass $m, 3$ coordinates $X, Y, Z$ describing the position of the center of mass of the rigid rotator, 3 Euler's angles $\varphi, \theta$, $\psi$ describing rotation relative to the center of mass of the rotator, the axis of symmetry of the rotator being taken as the $Z^{\prime}$-axis of the rest coordinate system of the rotator.

(c) The kinetic energy of the system consists of three parts: kinetic energy of the point mass $m$ and the translational and rotational kinetic energies of the rotator, namely,

$$
T=T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3},
$$

with 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right), \\
&T_{2}=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{X}^{2}+\dot{Y}^{2}+\dot{Z}^{2}\right), \\
&T_{3}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
I_{11} & I_{12} & 0 \\
I_{21} & I_{22} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & I_{33}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\omega_{1} \\
\omega_{2} \\
\omega_{3}
\end{array}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ are related to Euler's angles (Problem 1212) by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{1}=\dot{\theta} \cos \psi+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \sin \psi, \\
&\omega_{2}=-\dot{\theta} \sin \psi+\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \psi, \\
&\omega_{3}=\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta+\dot{\psi},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the inertia tensor is with respect to the center of mass of the rotator with the $Z^{\prime}$-axis in the direction of the axis of symmetry. The calculation of the potential energy is more complex. Imagine a series of spherical shells centered at the mass $m$ and consider a shell of inner and outer radii $r$ and $r+d r$ respectively. The potential due to Coulomb interaction between the element $d M$ of the rotator in the shell and the particle is

$$
d V=-\frac{G m d M}{r},
$$

where $G$ is the gravitational constant. Then the total potential of the system is

$$
V=-G m \int \frac{d M}{r} .
$$

The Lagrangian of the system, $L=T-V$, can then be obtained.

(d) The interaction between the particle and the rotator depends on $X-x, Y-y, Z-z, \varphi$ and $\theta$.

(e) As the interaction is conservative and the space is uniform and isotropic, the constants of motion are the energy $T+V$, total angular momentum (each of the three components) and total momentum (each of the three components) of the system.

(f) When the mass and the rotator are far removed from each other, their orbits are closely similar to those of two point masses. The difference stems from the fact that for the rotator the center of mass and the center of gravitational force do not coincide, so the torque of the gravitational force about the center of mass makes the rotator revolve around its center of mass.

\section{0}

A motor turns a vertical shaft to which is attached a simple pendulum of length $l$ and mass $m$ as shown in Fig. 2.72. The pendulum is constrained to move in a plane. This plane is rotated at constant angular speed $\omega$ by the motor.

(a) Find the equations of motion of the mass $m$.

(b) Solve the equations of motion, obtaining the position of the mass as a function of time for all possible motions of this system. For this part use small angle approximations.

(c) Find the angular frequencies of any oscillatory motions.

(d) Find an expression for the torque that the motor must supply.

(e) Is the total energy of this system constant in time? Is the Hamiltonian function constant in time? Explain briefly.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-635.jpg?height=480&width=189&top_left_y=1135&top_left_x=659)

Fig. 2.72.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use rotating coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.72$ with the $x$ - and $z$-axes in the plane of oscillation of the pendulum. In this frame the mass $m$ has coordinates 

$$
(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta)
$$

and velocity

$$
(l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, 0, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta) .
$$

In the fixed frame $m$ has an additional velocity

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} &=(0,0, \omega) \times(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta) \\
&=(0, \omega l \sin \theta, 0) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2} \cos \theta\right) \sin \theta=0 .
$$

(b) For equilibrium, $\ddot{\theta}=0$. The equation of motion gives the equilibrium positions as

$$
\theta_{1}=0, \quad \theta_{2}=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{l \omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

For oscillation near $\theta_{1}=0$, in the small angle approximation the equation of motion reduces to

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2}\right) \theta=0 .
$$

If $\omega<\sqrt{\frac{9}{l}}$, the equilibrium is stable. $\theta$ is harmonic and can be represented by

$$
\theta(t)=A_{1} \cos \left(\Omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right),
$$

where $A_{1}, \varphi_{1}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions, and $\Omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{l}-\omega^{2}}$ is the angular frequency of small angle oscillations. If $\omega>\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}$, the equilibrium is unstable.

For oscillations near $\theta_{2}$, let $\theta=\theta_{2}+\alpha$, where $\alpha \ll \theta_{2}$. The equation of motion is then, in the first approximation,

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2} \cos \theta_{2}+\omega^{2} \alpha \sin \theta_{2}\right)\left(\sin \theta_{2}+\alpha \cos \theta_{2}\right)=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\alpha \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta_{2}=0
$$

The solution is

$$
\alpha(t)=A_{2} \cos \left(\Omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)
$$

where $\Omega_{2}=\omega \sin \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{l \omega} \sqrt{l^{2} \omega^{4}-g^{2}}$ is the angular frequency of small oscillations about $\theta_{2}, A_{2}, \varphi_{2}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions. Hence

$$
\theta(t)=A_{2} \cos \left(\Omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)+\theta_{2} .
$$

(c) For small angle oscillations about $\theta_{1}$, the angular frequency is $\Omega_{1}=$ $\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2}}$; and about $\theta_{2}, \Omega_{2}=\frac{1}{l \omega} \sqrt{l^{2} \omega^{4}-g^{2}}$.

(d) The angular momentum about the $z$-axis is

$$
J=m l \sin \theta \cdot l \sin \theta \cdot \omega=m l^{2} \omega \sin ^{2} \theta
$$

The torque the motor must supply is therefore

$$
M=\frac{d J}{d t}=m l^{2} \omega \sin (2 \theta) \frac{d \theta}{d t},
$$

where for $\theta$ the expressions obtained in $(b)$ are to be used.

(e) The kinetic energy in the fixed frame, $T$, is not a homogeneous quadratic function of the generalized velocity, so the mechanical energy is not conservative. Physically, the pendulum is constrained to oscillate in a plane which is rotating. So the constraint is not a stable one and the mechanical energy is not conserved. On the other hand, not being an explicit function of $t$, the Hamiltonian $H$ is conserved.

Note that while in the fixed frame the mechanical energy is not conserved, as the system is an unstable holomorphic one and all the external forces are conservative, the generalized energy $H$ is conserved. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=\dot{\theta} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta-m g l \cos \theta=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the rotating frame fixed to the motor, because of the fictitious centrifugal force

$$
m l \omega^{2} \sin \theta=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial(l \sin \theta)}
$$

the potential energy is

$$
V=-\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta-m g l \cos \theta
$$

so that the total energy is

$$
\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+V=H=\text { constant . }
$$

Therefore, whether the mechanical energy is conserved or not depends on the choice of reference frame.

\section{1}

The classical interaction between two inert gas atoms, each of mass $m$, is given by the potential

$$
V(r)=-\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}}, \quad A, B>0, \quad r=\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right| .
$$

(a) Give the Hamiltonian for the system of the two atoms.

(b) Describe completely the lowest energy classical state(s) of this system.

(c) If the energy is slightly higher than the lowest [part (b)], what are the possible frequencies of the motion of the system?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solntion:}

(a) The center of mass of the system is given by $\mathbf{R}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}+\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=$ $(x, y, z)$, the reduced mass is $\mu=\frac{m^{2}}{m+m}=\frac{m}{2}$, and the total mass is $M=2 m$. Let $\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}$. Then the kinetic energy of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{R}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mu \dot{\mathbf{r}} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{\mathbf{R}}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mu\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \mu\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}-\frac{B}{r^{12}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $r, \theta, \varphi$ are the spherical coordinates of a frame fixed at the center of mass. The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{x}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=M \dot{x}, \quad p_{y}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{y}}=M \dot{y}, \quad p_{z}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}}=M \dot{z} \\
& p_{r}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=\mu \dot{r}, \quad p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=\mu r^{2} \dot{\theta}, \quad p_{\varphi}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=\mu r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=\sum_{i} p_{i} \dot{q}_{i}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2 M}\left(p_{x}^{2}+p_{y}^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2 \mu}\left(p_{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{r^{2}} p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta} p_{\varphi}^{2}\right)-\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The lowest energy state corresponds to $p_{x}=p_{y}=p_{z}=p_{r}=p_{\theta}=$ $p_{\varphi}=0$ and an $\mathbf{r}_{0}$ which minimizes

$$
-\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}} .
$$

\section{Letting}

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(-\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}}\right)=0,
$$

we obtain $r_{0}=(B / A)^{\frac{1}{8}}$ as the distance between the two atoms for the lowest energy classical state. For this state the energy of the system is

$$
H=\frac{-A^{2}}{B} \text {. }
$$

(c) If the energy is only slightly higher than the lowest and the degrees of freedom corresponding to $x, y, z, \theta, \varphi$ are not excited yet $\left(p_{x}=p_{y}=p_{z}=\right.$ $\left.p_{\theta}=p_{\varphi}=0\right)$, we have

$$
H=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 \mu}-\frac{2 A}{r^{6}}+\frac{B}{r^{12}} .
$$

As

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} V}{d r^{2}}\right)_{r_{0}}=72 A\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{4}{3}},
$$

the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} \mu \dot{r}^{2}-36 A\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mu \dot{\rho}^{2}-36 A\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{4}{3}} \rho^{2}
$$

where $\rho=r-r_{0} \ll r_{0}$. Lagrange's equation gives

$$
\mu \ddot{\rho}+72 A\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{4}{3}} \rho=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{72 A}{\mu}\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{4}{3}}}=12\left(\frac{A}{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}} .
$$

\section{2}

Consider a particle of mass $m$ which is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere of radius $R$. There are no externol forces of any kind on the particle.

(a) What is the number of generalized coordinates necessary to describe the problem?

(b) Choose a set of generalized coordinates and write the Lagrangian of the system.

(c) What is the Hamiltonian of the system? Is it conserved? sphere.

(d) Prove that the motion of the particle is along a great circle of the

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the particle is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere, there are two degrees of freedom and hence two generalized coordinates are needed.

(b) Choose $(\theta, \varphi)$ of spherical coordinates as the generalized coordinates. As there are no external forces, $V=0$. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

(c) As $p_{i}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}$, we have

$$
p_{\theta}=m R^{2} \dot{\theta}, \quad p_{\varphi}=m R^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta,
$$

and

$$
H=p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L=\frac{1}{2 m R^{2}}\left(p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}\right) .
$$

Since the Hamiltonian $H$ is not an explicit function of time, it is a constant of the motion, or, in other words, conserved.

(d) Hamilton's equation

$$
\dot{p}_{\varphi}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial \varphi}
$$

gives

$$
p_{\varphi}=\dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta=\text { constant } .
$$

We can choose the set of coordinates $(\theta, \varphi)$ so that the initial condition is $\dot{\varphi}=0$ at $t=0$. Then the above constant is zero at all time: $\dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta=0$. As $\theta$ cannot be zero at all time, $\dot{\varphi}=0$, or $\varphi=$ constant, the motion of the particle is along a great circle of the sphere.

\section{3}

A light, uniform U-shaped tube is partially filled with mercury (total mass $M$, mass per unit length $\rho$ ) as shown in Fig. 2.73. The tube is mounted so that it can rotate about one of the vertical legs. Neglect friction, the mass and moment of inertia of the glass tube, and the moment of inertia of the mercury column on the axis of rotation.

(a) Calculate the potential energy of the mercury column and describe its possible motion when the tube is not spinning.

(b) The tube is set in rotation with an initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ with the mercury column at rest vertically with a displacement $z_{0}$ from equilibrium.

1) Give the Lagrangian for the system.

2) Give the equation of motion.

3) What quantities are conserved in the motion? Give expressions for these quantities. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-642.jpg?height=368&width=469&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=575)

Fig. $2.73$.

4) Describe the motion qualitatively as completely as you can. (Wisconsin)
