\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $z$ be the distance of the top of the mercury column from its equilibrium position. Suppose an external force $F$ acting on the descending top causes it to descend slowly a distance $d z$. Then $F=2 \rho z g$ and its work done is

$$
d W=F d z=2 z \rho g d z .
$$

This work is stored as potential energy $d V$. Hence the potential energy of the mercury column is $V=\rho g z^{2}$. If the tube is not spinning, the mercury column will oscillate about the equilibrium position and the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} \rho s \dot{z}^{2}-\rho g z^{2}
$$

where $s=l+2 h$. Lagrange's equation gives

$$
\ddot{z}+\frac{2 g}{s} z=0 .
$$

Hence the mercury column will oscillate with an angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{s}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{l+2 h}} .
$$

(b) The system has 2 degrees of freedom when the U-shaped tube is spinning. $z$ and the angle of rotation $\theta$ are taken as the generalized coordinates. 1) We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} \rho(h-z) \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho \int_{0}^{l}\left(\dot{z}^{2}+x^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d x+\frac{1}{2} \rho(h+z)\left(\dot{z}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right), \\
&V=\rho g z^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

so the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} \rho s \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\rho g z^{2} .
$$

2) Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
s \ddot{z}+2 g z-\frac{1}{2} l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}=0, \\
\rho\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant } .
\end{gathered}
$$

As $p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\dot{\theta}}$, the last equation can be written as $p_{\theta}=$ constant. With the initial conditions $\dot{\theta}=\omega_{0}, \dot{z}=0, z=z_{0}$ at $t=0$, we have

$$
p_{\theta}=\rho\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z_{0}\right) l^{2} \omega_{0} .
$$

3) The Hamiltonian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{z} \dot{z}+p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} \rho s \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\rho g z^{2}=T+V,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{z}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}}=\rho s \dot{z}$. Thus $H$ is equal to the total energy of the system. In terms of the canonical variable we have

$$
H=\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 \rho s}+\frac{p_{\theta}^{2}}{2\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right) \rho l^{2}}+\rho g z^{2} .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $t$ explicitly, it is a constant of the motion, in addition to the constant

$$
p_{\theta}=\rho\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right) l^{2} \dot{\theta} .
$$

Using the initial conditions given we obtain

$$
H=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z_{0}\right) \rho l^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}+\rho g z_{0}^{2} .
$$

4) The motion of the mercury column consists of two components. One is the rotation together with the tube. The angular velocity of rotation changes in connection with the up-and-down motion of the column. When $z$ increases the rotation slows down, and vice verse, to keep the angular momentum about the vertical axis constant. The other component is the motion of the column in the tube. The equation of motion in $z$ is

$$
s \ddot{z}+2 g z=\frac{A}{\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right)^{2}}
$$

where $A=\frac{p_{\theta}^{2}}{2 \rho^{2} l^{2}}$ is a constant. Generally speaking, there are three equilibrium positions corresponding to the three roots of the equation

$$
2 g z=\frac{A}{\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z\right)^{2}} .
$$

Near each equilibrium position, the column undergoes small oscillations. Suppose $z_{1}$ is one of the equilibrium positions, i.e.

$$
2 g z_{1}=\frac{A}{\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z_{1}\right)^{2}} .
$$

For small oscillations let $z=z_{1}+z^{\prime}$ where $z^{\prime}$ is a small quantity. The equation of motion becomes

$$
s \ddot{z}^{\prime}+2 g z^{\prime}=\frac{-2 A z^{\prime}}{\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z_{1}\right)^{3}},
$$

giving the angular frequency of oscillations 

$$
\Omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{s}+\frac{2 A}{s\left(\frac{l}{3}+h+z_{1}\right)^{3}}} .
$$

As $\Omega$ is real, the equilibrium positions are all stable.

\section{4}

A particle under the action of gravity slides on the inside of a smooth paraboloid of revolution whose axis is vertical. Using the distance from the axis, $r$, and the azimuthal angle $\varphi$ as generalized coordinates, find

(a) The Lagrangian of the system.

(b) The generalized momenta and the corresponding Hamiltonian.

(c) The equation of motion for the coordinate $r$ as a function of time.

(d) If $\frac{d \varphi}{d t}=0$, show that the particle can execute small oscillations about the lowest point of the paraboloid, and find the frequency of these oscillations.

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the paraboloid of revolution is generated by a parabola which in cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ is represented by

$$
z=A r^{2},
$$

where $A$ is a positive constant.

(a) The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{r} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r} \\
p_{\varphi} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+A m g r^{2} \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right)}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}+4 m A^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 A m g r=0, \\
&m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting the constant be $m h$ and eliminating $\dot{\varphi}$ from the first equation, we obtain the equation for $r$ :

$$
\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) r^{3} \ddot{r}+4 A^{2} r^{4} \dot{r}^{2}+2 A g r^{4}=h^{2} .
$$

(d) If $\dot{\varphi}=0$, the first equation of (c) becomes

$$
\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}+4 A^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}+2 A g r=0 .
$$

The lowest point of the paraboloid is given by $r=0$. For small oscillations in its vicinity, $r, \dot{r}, \ddot{r}$ are small quantities. Then to first approximation the above becomes

$$
\ddot{r}+2 A g r=0 .
$$

As the coefficient of $r$ is positive, the particle executes simple harmonic motion about $r=0$ with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{2 A g} .
$$

\section{5}

A nonrelativistic electron of mass $m$, charge $-e$ in a cylindrical magneton moves between a wire of radius $a$ at a negative electric potential $-\phi_{0}$ and a concentric cylindrical conductor of radius $R$ at zero potential. There is a uniform constant magnetic field $B$ parallel to the axis. Use cylindrical coordinates $r, \theta, z$. The electric and magnetic vector potentials can be written as

$$
\phi=-\phi_{0} \frac{\ln (r / R)}{\ln (a / R)}, \quad \mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{2} B r \mathbf{e}_{\theta}
$$

( $\mathbf{e}_{\theta}$ is a unit vector in the direction of increasing $\theta$ ).

(a) Write the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian functions.

(b) Show that there are three constants of the motion. Write them down, and discuss the kinds of motion which can occur.

(c) Assuming that an electron leaves the inner wire with zero initial velocity, there is a value of the magnetic field $B_{c}$ such that for $B \leq B_{c}$ the electron can reach the outer cylinder, and for $B>B_{c}$ the electron cannot reach the outer cylinder. Find $B_{c}$ and make a sketch of the electron's trajectory for this case.

You may assume that $R \gg a$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In SI units, the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\mathbf{r}}^{2}+e \phi-e \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \mathbf{A} .
$$

As

$$
\dot{\mathbf{r}}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta}, \dot{z}), \quad \mathbf{A}=\left(0, \frac{1}{2} B r, 0\right),
$$

the above becomes

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+e \phi-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2} \dot{\theta} .
$$

The generalized momenta are

$$
p_{r}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m \dot{r}, \quad p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}, \quad p_{z}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}}=m \dot{z},
$$

and the Hamiltonian is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}+p_{z} \dot{z}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-e \phi \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2 m r^{2}}\left(p_{\theta}+\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m}-e \phi \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{p_{\theta}}{r}+\frac{1}{2} e B r\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-e \phi .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) As $H$ is not an explicit function of time, it is a constant of the motion. Also, as

$$
\dot{p}_{i}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{i}},
$$

if $H$ does not contain $q_{i}$ explicitly, $p_{i}$ is a constant of the motion. Hence $p_{\theta}, p_{z}$ are constants of the motion. Explicitly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{p_{\theta}}{r}+\frac{1}{2} e B r\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-e \phi=E \\
&p_{\theta}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}=C_{1}, \\
&p_{z}=m \dot{z}=C_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E, C_{1}, C_{2}$ are constants.

(c) The initial conditions $r=a, \dot{r}=\dot{\theta}=\dot{z}=0$ at $t=0$ give

$$
E=-e \phi=e \phi_{0}, \quad C_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} e B a^{2}, \quad C_{2}=0 .
$$

$p_{z}=C_{2}=0$ means that there is no motion along the $z$-direction. $H=E$ gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} e B\right)^{2}\left(r-\frac{a^{2}}{r}\right)^{2}\right]+e \phi_{0}\left[\frac{\ln \left(\frac{r}{R}\right)}{\ln \left(\frac{a}{R}\right)}\right]=e \phi_{0} .
$$

Suppose a value $B_{c}$ of the magnetic field will just make the electron reach the outer cylinder. As then $p_{r}=0$ at $r=R$, the above gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\frac{1}{2} e B_{c}\right)^{2}\left(R-\frac{a^{2}}{R}\right)^{2}=e \phi_{0} \text {. }
$$

If we assume that $a \ll R$, this reduces to

$$
B_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{2}{R} \sqrt{\frac{2 m \phi_{0}}{e}} .
$$

At $r=R, p_{r}$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} e B R\right)^{2}\right]=e \phi_{0}
$$

or

$$
p_{r}^{2}=2 m e \phi_{0}-\left(\frac{1}{2} e B R\right)^{2}=\left(B_{c}^{2}-B^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} e R\right)^{2} .
$$

$p_{r}$ is real at $r=R$ if $B \leq B_{c}$. Hence under this condition the electron can reach the outer cylinder. If $B>B_{c}, p_{r}$ is imaginary at $r=R$ and the electron cannot reach the outer cylinder. For the latter case the trajectory of the electron is as sketched in Fig. 2.74.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-649.jpg?height=242&width=253&top_left_y=999&top_left_x=608)

Fig. $2.74$.

\section{6}

Consider the Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}-\omega^{2} x^{2}\right) e^{\gamma t}
$$

for the motion of a particle of mass $m$ in one dimension $(x)$. The constants $m, \gamma$ and $\omega$ are real and positive.

(a) Find the equation of motion.

(b) Interpret the equation of motion by stating the kinds of force to which the particle is subject. (c) Find the canonical momentum, and from this construct the Hamiltonian function.

(d) Is the Hamiltonian a constant of the motion? Is the energy conserved? Explain.

(e) For the initial conditions $x(0)=0$ and $\dot{x}(0)=v_{0}$, what is $x(t)$ asymptotically as $t \rightarrow \infty$ ?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=-\gamma \dot{x} .
$$

(b) The particle moves as a damped harmonic oscillator. It is subject to an restoring force $-m \omega^{2} x$ and a damping force $-m \gamma \dot{x}$ proportional to its speed.

(c) The canonical momentum is

$$
p=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p \dot{x}-L \\
&=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \omega^{2} x^{2} \\
&=\frac{p^{2} e^{-\gamma t}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} e^{\gamma t} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) Since $H$ depends explicitly on time, it is not a constant of motion. It follows that energy is not conserved also. Physically, in the course of the motion, the damping force continually does negative work, causing dissipation of energy.

(e) Try a solution of the type $x \sim e^{i \Omega t}$. Substitution in the equation of motion gives

$$
\Omega^{2}-i \gamma \Omega-\omega^{2}=0,
$$

which has solutions

$$
\Omega=\frac{i}{2}\left(\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
x=A \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\gamma+\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) t\right]+B \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\gamma-\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) t\right] .
$$

The initial conditions $x=0, \dot{x}=v_{0}$ at $t=0$ give

$$
B=-A, \quad A=-\frac{v_{0}}{\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}} .
$$

If $\gamma<2 \omega$, let $\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}=i \omega_{1}$. Then

$$
x=-\frac{v_{0}}{2 i \omega_{1}} e^{-\frac{\gamma t}{2}}\left(e^{-i \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right)=\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{1}} e^{-\frac{\gamma t}{2}} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right)
$$

so that $x \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$.

If $\gamma>2 \omega$, both $\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}$ are real and positive so that there will be no oscillation and $x$ will decrease monotonically to zero as $t \rightarrow \infty$.

\section{7}

A particle is confined inside a box and can move only along the $x$-axis. The ends of the box move toward the center with a speed small compared with the particle's speed (Fig. 2.75).

(a) If the momentum of the particle is $p_{0}$ when the walls of the box are at a distance $x_{0}$ apart, find the momentum of the particle at any later time. Collisions with the walls are perfectly elastic. Assume that at all times the speed of the particle is much less than the speed of light.

(b) When the walls are a distance $x$ apart what average external force must be applied to each wall in order to move it at constant speed $V$ ?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a collision of the particle with one of the walls. As the collision is perfectly elastic, the relative speeds before and after the collision are equal. If the particle is incident with speed $v$ and reflected back with speed $v^{\prime}$ and the wall has speed $V$ towards the particle, we have 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-652.jpg?height=213&width=436&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=571)

Fig. $2.75$.

$$
v+V=v^{\prime}-V
$$

i.e.

$$
v^{\prime}=v+2 V .
$$

Thus after each collision, the magnitude of the particle momentum gains an amount $2 m V, m$ being the mass of the particle. When the walls are at a distance $x$ apart, as $V$ is much smaller than the speed of the particle, the interval between two consecutive collisions is

$$
T=\frac{x}{\left(\frac{p}{m}\right)}=\frac{x m}{p},
$$

$p$ being the particle momentum. The change of momentum in time $d t$ is

$$
d p=2 m V \frac{d t}{T}=\frac{2 V p d t}{x} .
$$

As the walls move toward each other with speed $V$,

$$
x=x_{0}-2 V t,
$$

measuring time from the moment $x=x_{0}$. Then

$$
d p=-\frac{p d x}{x} .
$$

As $p=p_{0}$ when $x=x_{0}$, its integration gives

$$
p=\frac{p_{0} x_{0}}{x}=\frac{p_{0} x_{0}}{x_{0}-2 V t} .
$$

(b) Consider a collision of the particle with one wall. The momentum acquired by the particle is

$$
\mathbf{p}+2 m \mathbf{V}-(-\mathbf{p})=2 \mathbf{p}+2 m \mathbf{V}
$$

The interval between two consecutive collisions with the wall is

$$
T^{\prime}=\frac{2 x}{\left(\frac{p}{m}\right)}=\frac{2 x m}{p},
$$

so that the change of momentum due to collisions with the wall in a time $d t$ is

$$
d p=2(p+m V) \frac{d t}{T^{\prime}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{(p+m V) p}{x m} \approx \frac{p^{2}}{x m}=\frac{p_{0}^{2} x_{0}^{2}}{m x^{3}}
$$

as $\frac{p}{m} \gg V$. This is the force exerted by the wall on the particle. To keep the walls moving at constant speed, a force of the same magnitude must apply to each wall. The problem can also be solved using the Hamiltonian formalism. Use a reference frame attached to one of the walls, say the left-hand wall. As shown in Fig. 2.75, the particle has velocity $-\frac{p}{m}-V$. The Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{p}{m}+V\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m}(p+m V)^{2} \approx \frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{p_{0}^{2} x_{0}^{2}}{2 m x^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The force on the particle is $\dot{p}$ which is given by Hamilton's equation:

$$
\dot{p}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial x}=\frac{p_{0}^{2} x_{0}^{2}}{m x^{3}} .
$$

\section{8}

The Poisson bracket is defined by

$$
[a, b]=\sum_{k}\left(\frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial p_{k}}-\frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial q_{k}}\right) .
$$

(a) Show that for a dynamical quantity $a(q, p, t)$

$$
\frac{d a}{d t}=[a, H]+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} .
$$

A two-dimensional oscillator has energies

$$
\begin{aligned}
T(\dot{x}, \dot{y}) &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right), \\
V(x, y) &=\frac{1}{2} K\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)+C x y,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ and $K$ are constants.

(b) Show by a coordinate transformation that this oscillator is equivalent to a nonisotropic harmonic oscillator. (a).

(c) Find two independent constants of the motion and verify using part

(d) If $C=0$ find a third constant of the motion.

(e) Show that for the isotropic oscillator the symmetric matrix

$$
A_{i j}=\frac{p_{i} p_{j}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K x_{i} x_{j}
$$

is a constant of the motion by expressing each element in terms of the known constants of motion.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Using Hamilton's canonical equations

$$
\dot{q}_{k}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}, \quad \dot{p}_{k}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}},
$$

we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d a}{d t} &=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \dot{q}_{k}+\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \dot{p}_{k}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}-\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=[a, H]+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) Introducing the new variables

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x+y), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x-y),
$$

we have 

$$
x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta+\xi), \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta-\xi) .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{4} m\left[(\dot{\eta}+\dot{\xi})^{2}+(\dot{\eta}-\dot{\xi})^{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{\eta}^{2}+\dot{\xi}^{2}\right), \\
V &=\frac{1}{4} K\left[(\eta+\xi)^{2}+(\eta-\xi)^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} K\left(\eta^{2}+\xi^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2}, \\
L &=L_{1}+L_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\eta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \\
&L_{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\xi}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the form of $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ indicates that $\eta$ and $\xi$ are normal coordinates. Hence the system is equivalent to two harmonic oscillators with angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K+C}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K-C}{m}}
$$

respectively. As the frequencies are different the system acts as a nonisotropic harmonic oscillator.

(c) As the canonical momenta are by definition

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{\eta} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\eta}}=m \dot{\eta}, \quad p_{\xi}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\xi}}=m \dot{\xi}, \\
H &=p_{\eta} \dot{\eta}+p_{\xi} \dot{\xi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\eta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This can also be written as

$$
H=H_{1}+H_{2}
$$

with $H_{1}, H_{2}$ corresponding to $L_{1}, L_{2}$ respectively, i.e.

$$
H_{1}=\frac{p_{\eta}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \quad H_{2}=\frac{p_{\xi}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
$$

As $H_{1}, H_{2}$ do not contain $t$ explicitly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d H_{1}}{d t} &=\left[H_{1}, H\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}+H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}\right]+\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\eta}}+\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \xi} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\xi}}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\eta}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \eta}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\xi}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \xi}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and, similarly,

$$
\frac{d H_{2}}{d t}=0 .
$$

Hence $\mathrm{H}_{1}, \mathrm{H}_{2}$ are two independent constants of the motion.

(d) If $C=0, \omega_{1}=\omega_{2}$ and the oscillator becomes an isotropic one. The Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\eta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \xi^{2} .
$$

Let $J=m\left(\eta p_{\xi}-\xi p_{\eta}\right)$. Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d J}{d t} &=[J, H] \\
&=\frac{\partial J}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{\eta}}-\frac{\partial J}{\partial p_{\eta}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \eta}+\frac{\partial J}{\partial \xi} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{\xi}}-\frac{\partial J}{\partial p_{\xi}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \xi} \\
&=p_{\xi} p_{\eta}+m K \xi \eta-p_{\eta} p_{\xi}-m K \eta \xi=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

$J$ is also a constant of the motion.

(e) For the isotropic oscillator, $C=0$ and $x, y$ already are normal coordinates. As shown above, there are three known constants of the motion:

$$
E_{1}=\frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K x^{2}, \quad E_{2}=\frac{p_{y}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K y^{2}, \quad J=m\left(x p_{y}-y p_{x}\right) .
$$

As $A_{11}=E_{1}, A_{22}=E_{2}$, the diagonal elements of the matrix $A_{i j}$ are constants of the motion. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} E_{2}-\frac{K J^{2}}{4 m^{3}} &=\left(\frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K x^{2}\right)\left(\frac{p_{y}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K y^{2}\right)-\frac{K}{4 m}\left(x p_{y}-y p_{x}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(\frac{p_{x} p_{y}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} K x y\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the left-hand side is a constant, $A_{12}=A_{21}=$ constant. Hence $\mathbf{A}$ is a matrix of constant elements.

\section{9}

Consider the system of particles $m_{1}=m_{2}$ connected by a rope of length $l$ with $m_{2}$ constrained to stay on the surface of an upright cone of half-angle $\alpha$ and $m_{1}$ hanging freely inside the cone, the rope passing through a hole at the top of the cone as shown in Fig. 2.76. Neglect friction.

(a) Give an appropriate generalized coordinate system for the problem.

(b) Write the Lagrangian of the system and the equation of motion for each generalized coordinate.

(c) Write the Hamiltonian for the system.

(d) Express the angular frequency for $m_{2}$ moving in a circular orbit in terms of the variables of the problem.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-657.jpg?height=293&width=203&top_left_y=1349&top_left_x=638)

Fig. $2.76$.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use spherical coordinates with origin at the top of the cone as shown in Fig. 2.76. The coordinates of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ are respectively $(r, 0, \varphi)$, $(l-r, \pi-\alpha, \beta)$. The variables $r, \theta, \varphi, \beta$ are taken to be the generalized coordinates.

(b) The velocities of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ are respectively $(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta}, r \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta),(-\dot{r}, 0,(l-$ $r) \dot{\beta} \sin (\pi-\alpha))$. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[2 \dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+(l-r)^{2} \dot{\beta}^{2} \sin ^{2}(\pi-\alpha)\right] \\
&-m g r \cos \theta+m g(l-r) \cos \alpha .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta=p_{\varphi}, \quad \text { a constant } \\
&m(l-r)^{2} \dot{\beta} \sin ^{2}(\pi-\alpha)=p_{\beta}, \quad \text { a constant } \\
&2 \ddot{r}-r\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+(l-r) \dot{\beta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha+g(\cos \theta+\cos \alpha)=0, \\
&r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta-g \sin \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) Two other canonical momenta are

$$
p_{r}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=2 m \dot{r}, \quad p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta} .
$$

The Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H=& p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}+p_{\beta} \dot{\beta}-L \\
=& \frac{p_{r}^{2}}{4 m}+\frac{p_{\theta}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}+\frac{p_{\beta}^{2}}{2 m(l-r)^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha} \\
&+m g r \cos \theta-m g(L-r) \cos \alpha .
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) If $m_{2}$ moves in a circular orbit, $r=$ constant and the angular frequency of revolution is

$$
\dot{\beta}=\frac{p_{\beta}}{m(l-r)^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha} .
$$



\section{0}

The transformation equations between two sets of coordinates are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&Q=\ln \left(1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p\right) \\
&P=2\left(1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p\right) q^{\frac{1}{2}} \sin p .
\end{aligned}
$$

(a) Show directly from these transformation equations that $Q, P$ are canonical variables if $q$ and $p$ are.

(b) Show that the function that generates this transformation between the two sets of canonical variables is

$$
F_{3}=-[\exp (Q)-1]^{2} \tan p .
$$

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $[Q, Q]=0,[P, P]=0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[Q, P]=} & \frac{\partial Q}{\partial q} \frac{\partial P}{\partial p}-\frac{\partial P}{\partial q} \frac{\partial Q}{\partial p} \\
=& \frac{q^{-\frac{1}{2}} \cos p}{1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p}\left[-q \sin ^{2} p+\left(1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p\right) q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p\right] \\
&+\frac{q^{\frac{1}{2}} \sin ^{2} p}{1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p}\left[\cos p+\left(1+q^{\frac{1}{2}} \cos p\right) q^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right]=1
\end{aligned}
$$

the transformation is canonical. Then if $q, p$ are canonical variables, so are $Q, P$

(b) Solving the transformation equations for $q$ and $p$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
q &=\left(e^{Q}-1\right)^{2} \sec ^{2} p, \\
P &=2 e^{Q}\left(e^{Q}-1\right) \tan p .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the transformation is canonical, there exists a generating function $F_{3}(Q, p)$ such that

$$
q=-\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial p}, \quad P=-\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial Q} .
$$

give the transformation equations. As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
d F_{3} &=\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial Q} d Q+\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial p} d p=-P d Q-q d p \\
&=-d\left[\left(e^{Q}-1\right)^{2}\right] \tan p-\left(e^{Q}-1\right)^{2} d \tan p \\
&=-d\left[\left(e^{Q}-1\right)^{2} \tan p\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

we obtain

$$
F_{3}=-\left(e^{Q}-1\right)^{2} \tan p .
$$

\section{1}

A particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension $q$ in a potential energy field $V(q)$ and is retarded by a damping force $-2 m \gamma \dot{q}$ proportional to its velocity.

(a) Show that the equation of motion can be obtained from the Lagrangian

$$
L=\exp (2 \gamma t)\left[\frac{1}{2} m \dot{q}^{2}-V(q)\right]
$$

and that the Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{p^{2} \exp (-2 \gamma t)}{2 m}+V(q) \exp (2 \gamma t),
$$

where $p=m \dot{q} \exp (2 \gamma t)$ is the momentum conjugate to $q$.

(b) For the generating function

$$
F_{2}(q, P, t)=\exp (\gamma t) q P
$$

find the transformed Hamiltonian $K(Q, P, t)$. For an oscillator potential

$$
V(q)=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} q^{2}
$$

show that the transformed Hamiltonian yields a constant of the motion

$$
K=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q+\gamma Q P .
$$

(c) Obtain the solution $q(t)$ for the damped oscillator from the constant of the motion in (b) in the underdamped case $\gamma<\omega$. You may need the integral 

$$
\int \frac{d x}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}=\sin ^{-1} x
$$

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q}=0
$$

gives

$$
m \ddot{q}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial q}-2 m \gamma \dot{q} .
$$

The particle is seen to be subject to a potential force $-\frac{\partial V}{\partial q}$ and a damping force $-2 m \gamma \dot{q}$ proportional to its speed. Hence the given Lagrangian is appropriate. The Hamiltonian is given by

$$
H=p \dot{q}-L
$$

with

$$
p=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}=m \dot{q} e^{2 \gamma t}
$$

Thus

$$
H=\left(\frac{1}{2} m \dot{q}^{2}+V\right) e^{2 \gamma t}=\frac{p^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t}}{2 m}+V(q) e^{2 \gamma t}
$$

(b) For the generating function $F_{2}(q, P, t)$ we have

$$
p=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial q}, \quad Q=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial P}, \quad K=H+\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t} .
$$

As $F_{2}=q P e^{\gamma t}$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
p=P e^{\gamma t}, \quad Q=q e^{\gamma t}, \\
K=\frac{p^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t}}{2 m}+V(q) e^{2 \gamma t}+\gamma q P e^{\gamma t}
\end{gathered}
$$

For an oscillator of potential

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} q^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t},
$$

the transformed Hamiltonian is

$$
K=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q^{2}+\gamma Q P .
$$

As it does not depend on time explicitly, $K$ is a constant of the motion.

(c) Hamilton's canonical equations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{P}=-\frac{\partial K}{\partial Q}=-m \omega^{2} Q-\gamma P, \\
&\dot{Q}=\frac{\partial K}{\partial P}=\frac{P}{m}+\gamma Q .
\end{aligned}
$$

Differentiating the second equation and making use of the original equations we have

$$
\ddot{Q}+\left(\omega^{2}-\gamma^{2}\right) Q=0 .
$$

In the underdamped case, $\omega>\gamma$ and we may set

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\omega^{2}-\gamma^{2}},
$$

where $\omega_{1}$ is real positive. The solution is then

$$
Q=A \sin \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi\right)
$$

where $A, \varphi$ are constants. As

$$
P=m(\dot{Q}-\gamma Q),
$$

we have

$K=\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{Q}-\gamma Q)^{2}+\omega^{2} Q^{2}+2 \gamma Q(\dot{Q}-\gamma Q)\right]=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{Q}^{2}+\omega_{1}^{2} Q^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{1}^{2} A^{2}$, giving

$$
A=\frac{1}{\omega_{1}} \sqrt{\frac{2 K}{m}} .
$$

Hence the solution is

$$
q=Q e^{-\gamma t}=\frac{1}{\omega_{1}} \sqrt{\frac{2 K}{m}} e^{-\gamma t} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi\right) .
$$



\section{2}

Suppose that a system with time-independent Hamiltonian $H_{0}(q, p)$ has imposed on it an external oscillating field, so that the Hamiltonian becomes $H=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin \omega t$, where $\varepsilon$ and $\omega$ are given constants.

(a) What is the physical interpretation of $\varepsilon \sin \omega t$ ?

(b) How are the canonical equations of motion modified?

(c) Find a canonical transformation which restores the canonical form of the equations of motion. What is the "new" Hamiltonian?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) A possible interpretation is shown in the following example. A particle of charge $e$ moves in an electric field uniform in space but oscillating in time, namely an electrical field whose strength is represented by $(\varepsilon / e) \sin \omega t$. Then $\varepsilon \sin \omega t$ is the force exerted on the particle by the electric field.

(b) Hamilton's canonical equations of motion are now

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{q}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial p}=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p}, \\
&\dot{p}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q}=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q}+\varepsilon \sin (\omega t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) We have

$$
H(q, p, t)=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t)
$$

and wish to find a new Hamiltonian

$$
K(Q, P)=H_{0}(q, p)
$$

by a canonical transformation. Let the generating function be $F_{2}(q, P, t)$. As

$$
\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t}=K-H=\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t),
$$

we take

$$
F_{2}=q P-\frac{\varepsilon q}{\omega} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

The transformation equations are

$$
p=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial q}=P-\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)
$$

or

$$
P=p+\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and

$$
Q=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial P}=q
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
K(Q, P) &=H+\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t} \\
&=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t)+\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t) \\
&=H_{0}\left(Q, P-\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)\right) \\
\frac{\partial K}{\partial P} &=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p} \frac{\partial p}{\partial P}=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p}=\dot{q}=\dot{Q}, \\
-\frac{\partial K}{\partial Q} &=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q} \frac{\partial q}{\partial Q}=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q}=\dot{p}-\varepsilon \sin (\omega t)=\dot{P}
\end{aligned}
$$

use having been of the results in (b). Hence the transformation restores the canonical form of the equations of motion with the Hamiltonian $H_{0}$.

\section{3}

(a) Solve the Hamilton-Jacobi equation for the generating function $S(q, \alpha, t)$ in the case of a single particle moving under the Hamiltonian $H=\frac{1}{2} p^{2}$. Find the canonical transformation $q=q(\beta, \alpha)$, and $p=p(\beta, \alpha)$, where $\beta$ and $\alpha$ are the transformed coordinate and momentum respectively. Interpret your result.

(b) If there is a perturbing Hamiltonian $H^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} q^{2}$, then $\alpha$ will no longer be constant. Express the transformed Hamiltonian $K$ (using the same transformation found in part $(a)$ in terms of $\alpha, \beta$ and $t$. Solve for $\beta(t)$ and $\alpha(t)$ and show that the perturbed solution

$$
q[\beta(t), \alpha(t)], \quad p[\beta(t), \alpha(t)]
$$

is simple harmonic. You may need the integrals 

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \frac{d x}{x^{2}+1}=\tan ^{-1} x \\
-\int \tan x d x=\ln (\cos x) .
\end{gathered}
$$

(Wisconsin)

Solution:

(a) The Hamilton-Jacobi equation

$$
\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}+H(q, p, t)=0
$$

with $p=\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}$ becomes, for this case,

$$
\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $q, t$ explicitly, we can take the two terms on the left-hand side as equal to $-\gamma, \gamma$ respectively, where $\gamma$ is at most a function of $p$. Then

$$
S=\sqrt{2 \gamma} q-\gamma t .
$$

Setting $\alpha=\sqrt{2 \gamma}$, we have the generating function

$$
S=\alpha q-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} t
$$

The constant $\alpha$ can be taken to be the new momentum $P$. The transformation equations are thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}=\alpha \\
Q &=\frac{\partial S}{\partial P}=\frac{\partial S}{\partial \alpha}=q-\alpha t=\beta, \quad \text { say } .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $g=\beta+\alpha t$, the particle moves with uniform velocity $\beta$ in the $q, p$ system.

(b) The perturbed Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{2} .
$$

It is transformed to

$$
K=H+\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}=\frac{p^{2}}{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{2}-\frac{\alpha^{2}}{2}=\frac{1}{2}(\beta+\alpha t)^{2}
$$

by the transformation equations in (a). Hamilton's equations

$$
\dot{Q}=\frac{\partial K}{\partial P}, \quad \dot{P}=-\frac{\partial K}{\partial Q}
$$

give

$$
\dot{\beta}=(\beta+\alpha t) t, \quad \dot{\alpha}=-(\beta+\alpha t) .
$$

Note that $\alpha \equiv P, \beta \equiv Q$ can no longer be considered constant as $H$ has been changed. The last equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\alpha=0,
$$

showing that $\alpha$ is harmonic:

$$
\alpha=\alpha_{0} \sin (t+\varphi),
$$

where $\alpha_{0}, \varphi$ are constants, and thus

$$
\beta=-\dot{\alpha}-\alpha t=-\alpha_{0}[\cos (t+\varphi)+t \sin (t+\varphi)] .
$$

The transformation equations then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&p=\alpha=\alpha_{0} \sin (t+\varphi), \\
&q=\beta+\alpha t=-\dot{\alpha}=-\alpha_{0} \cos (t+\varphi) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the solution for the perturbed system is harmonic.

2084

(a) Let us apply a shearing force on a rectangular solid block as shown in Fig. 2.77. Find the relation between the displacement $u$ and the applied force within elastic limits.

(b) The elastic properties of a solid support elastic waves. Assume a transverse plane wave which proceeds in the $x$-direction and whose oscillations are in the $y$-direction. Derive the equations of motion for the displacement.

(c) Find the expression for the speed of the transverse elastic wave.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Hooke's law for shearing 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-667.jpg?height=340&width=514&top_left_y=232&top_left_x=496)

Fig. 2.77.

$$
\frac{F}{A}=n \varphi,
$$

where $F$ is the shearing force, $n$ the shear modulus of the material of the block, $\varphi$ the shear angle, and $A$ the cross sectional area of the block parallel to $F$, gives the resulting displacement as

$$
u=l \varphi=\frac{l F}{A n},
$$

as $\varphi$ is a small angle.

(b) The potential energy of a unit volume of the block due to shear strain is

$$
\frac{1}{l A} \int_{0}^{u} F d u^{\prime}=\frac{1}{l A} \int_{0}^{\varphi} A n \varphi^{\prime} l d \varphi^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} n \varphi^{2}=\frac{1}{2} n\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2}
$$

The kinetic energy of the block during shearing is

$$
\int_{0}^{l} \frac{1}{2} \rho A\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2} d x
$$

$\rho$ being the density of the block. Within the elastic limits, energy is considered and Hamilton's principle

$$
\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} L d t=0
$$

applies. Thus

$$
\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}}(T-V) d t=\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \int_{0}^{l}\left[\frac{n}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2}-\frac{\rho}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2}\right] A d x d t=0 .
$$

As, integrating by parts, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{l} \delta\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2} d x &=2 \int_{0}^{l}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(\delta u) d x \\
&=\left.2\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right) \delta u\right|_{0} ^{l}-2 \int_{0}^{l} \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}} \delta u d x, \\
\int_{0}^{l} \delta\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2} d t &=\left.2\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right) \delta u\right|_{t_{1}} ^{t_{2}}-2 \int_{0}^{l}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}\right) \delta u d t,
\end{aligned}
$$

and as $\delta u=0$ at $y=0, l$ and $t=t_{1}, t_{2}$, the above becomes

$$
-\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \int_{0}^{l}\left(n \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}-\rho \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}\right) \delta u A d x d t=0
$$

giving

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\rho}{n} \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}=0
$$

as the equation of motion for the displacement $u$.

(c) The equation shows that $u$, which is in the $y$-direction, propagates along the $x$-direction as a transverse wave with speed

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{n}{\rho}} \text {. }
$$



\section{PART III}

\section{SPECIAL RELATIVITY}



\section{SPECIAL RELATIVITY (3001-3054)}

\section{1}

(a) Briefly describe the dilemma which necessitated the development of the special theory of relativity.

(b) Describe an earlier theory which could have eliminated the need for special relativity and name an experiment which proved this theory to be wrong.

(c) Describe one modern experiment which lends credence to the special theory of relativity.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) According to Maxwell's electromagnetic theory, the velocity of propagation of electromagnetic waves in free space, $c$, is a constant independent of the velocity of the source of the electromagnetic radiation. This is contrary to the Galilean transformation which was known to apply between inertial frames. If Maxwell's theory holds in one inertial frame, it would not hold in another inertial frame that has relative motion with respect to the first. The dilemma was that either Maxwell's electromagnetic theory or Newtonian mechanics holds but not both, even though both appeared to be well established.

(b) An earlier theory which attempted to resolve the dilemma was the theory of ether. It presupposed that the universe was filled with a fictitious all-pervasive medium called the ether and that Maxwell's theory holds only in a frame at rest relative to the ether. But Michelson's experiment purported to measure the velocity of the earth relative to the ether always gave a zero result even though the earth moves in the solar system and the solar system itself moves. Thus the presence of ether cannot be demonstrated and the ether theory has to be abandoned.

(c) Take as example Herter's experiment measuring the time of arrival of two photons emitted in the annihilation of a positron in flight. The detectors were at different locations which had the same distance from the place where the annihilation took place. It was found that the two photons arrived at the detectors simultaneously. This indicates that light emitted in different directions from a rapidly moving source has a constant speed. 

\section{2}

A space traveler with velocity $v$ synchronizes his clock $\left(t^{\prime}=0\right)$ with his earth friend $(t=0)$. The earthman then observes both clocks simultaneously, $t$ directly and $t^{\prime}$ through a telescope. What does $t$ read when $t^{\prime}$ reads one hour?

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be inertial frames attached to the earth and spaceship respectively with the $x$-axes along the direction of relative velocity, and set $t_{1}=t_{1}^{\prime}=0, x_{1}=x_{1}^{\prime}=0$ when the clocks are synchronized. Consider the event that the spaceship clock reads $t_{2}^{\prime}$. The transformation equations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
c t_{2} &=\gamma\left(c t_{2}^{\prime}+\beta x_{2}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma c t_{2}^{\prime}, \\
x_{2} &=\gamma\left(x_{2}^{\prime}+\beta c t_{2}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma \beta c t_{2}^{\prime},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$, as $x_{2}^{\prime}=x_{1}^{\prime}=0$. Light signal takes a time

$$
\Delta t=\frac{x_{2}}{\mathrm{c}}=\gamma \beta t_{2}^{\prime}
$$

to reach the earthman. Hence his clock will read

$$
t_{2}+\Delta t=\gamma(1+\beta) t_{2}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}} t_{2}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{c+v}{\mathrm{c}-v}}
$$

when he sees $t_{2}^{\prime}=1$ hour through a telescope.

\section{3}

A light source at rest at position $x=0$ in reference frame $S$ emits two pulses (called $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ ) of light, $P_{1}$ at $t=0$ and $P_{2}$ at $t=\tau$. A frame $S^{\prime}$ moves with velocity $v \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ with respect to $S$. An observer in frame $S^{\prime}$ receives the initial pulse $P_{1}$ at time $t^{\prime}=0$ at $x^{\prime}=0$.

(a) Calculate the time $\tau^{\prime}$ between the reception of the pulses at $x^{\prime}=0$ as a function of $\tau$ and $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$.

(b) From (a) determine an exact expression for the longitudinal Doppler effect, that is, calculate $\lambda^{\prime}$ in terms of $\lambda$ and $\beta$, where $\lambda$ and $\lambda^{\prime}$ are the vacuum wavelengths of light as measured in $S$ and $S^{\prime}$ respectively. (c) Calculate to first and second order in $\frac{v}{c}$ the Doppler shift of the $H_{\beta}$ emission $(\lambda=4861.33 \AA)$ from the neutralization to $H$ atoms of protons accelerated through a potential of $20 \mathrm{kV}$. Assuming that emission occurs after acceleration and while the protons drift with constant velocity. Also, assume that the optical axis of the spectrometer is parallel to the motion of the protons.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-673.jpg?height=232&width=632&top_left_y=700&top_left_x=512)

Fig. 3.1.

(a) The inertial frames $S, S^{\prime}$ are as shown in Fig. 3.1. Assume that the origins $O$ and $O^{\prime}$ coincide at $t=t^{\prime}=0$ so that the emission of $P_{1}$ and its arrival at the observer both occur at $x=0, t=0, x^{\prime}=0, t^{\prime}=0$ as given. The emission of $P_{2}$ is at $x=0, t=\tau$ in $S$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime} &=\gamma(x-\beta c t)=-\gamma \beta c \tau, \\
t^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(t-\frac{\beta x}{c}\right)=\gamma \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

in $S$. The signal take a time

$$
\Delta t^{\prime}=\frac{\left|x^{\prime}\right|}{\mathrm{c}}=\gamma \beta \tau
$$

to arrive at the observer. Hence the observer records the time of arrival as

$$
t^{\prime}+\Delta t^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta) \tau,
$$

or

$$
\tau^{\prime}=\tau \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}
$$

(b) As $\tau, \tau^{\prime}$ are the intervals between two consecutive pulses in $S, S^{\prime}$ respectively, we have the frequencies

$$
\nu=\frac{1}{\tau}, \quad \nu^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\tau^{\prime}}
$$

and wavelengths

$$
\lambda=\frac{\mathrm{c}}{\nu}=c \tau, \quad \lambda^{\prime}=c \tau^{\prime}=\lambda \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}
$$

in $S$ and $S^{\prime}$ respectively.

(c) The protons have energy $20 \mathrm{keV}$ each, much smaller that the rest mass energy of $936 \mathrm{MeV}$, so that their velocity can be obtained nonrelativistically. Thus

$$
\beta=\frac{v}{\mathrm{c}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{m c^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{40 \times 10^{-3}}{936}}=0.00654 .
$$

As $\beta$ is small, we can expand $\lambda^{\prime}(\beta)$ as a power series

$$
\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}} \approx \lambda\left(1+\beta+\frac{1}{2} \beta^{2}+\cdots\right)
$$

The first order shift of the $H_{\beta}$ emission is

$$
\Delta \lambda=\lambda \beta=4861 \times 6.54 \times 10^{-3}=31.8 \AA,
$$

and the second order shift is

$$
\Delta \lambda=\frac{1}{2} \lambda \beta^{2}=0.10 \AA
$$

\section{4}

(a) Consider Lorentz transformations (LT) between the frames $S, S^{\prime}$ and $S^{\prime \prime}$ indicated in Fig. 3.2, where the $x$-axes are all parallel, and $S^{\prime}$ and $S^{\prime \prime}$ are moving in the positive $x$-direction. Prove that for this type of transformation the inverse of an LT is an LT, and that the resultant of two LT's is another LT. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-675.jpg?height=215&width=537&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=473)

Fig. 3.2.

If the velocity of $S^{\prime}$ relative to $S$ is $v_{1}$, and the velocity of $S^{\prime \prime}$ relative to $S^{\prime}$ is $v_{2}$, derive the expression for the velocity of $S^{\prime \prime}$ relative to $S$.

(b) In particle physics, the interaction between particles is thought of as arising from the exchange of a particle as shown in Fig. 3.3. Prove that the particle exchanged is not real but virtual.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-675.jpg?height=149&width=374&top_left_y=919&top_left_x=243)

Fig. 3.3.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-675.jpg?height=151&width=370&top_left_y=920&top_left_x=819)

Fig. 3.4.

Solution:

The Lorentz transformation between the frames $S, S^{\prime}$ is given by

$$
x^{\prime}=\gamma_{1}\left(x-\beta_{1} c t\right), \quad y^{\prime}=y, \quad z^{\prime}=z, \quad c t^{\prime}=\gamma_{1}\left(c t-\beta_{1} x\right),
$$

where

$$
\beta_{1}=\frac{v_{1}}{\mathrm{c}}, \quad \gamma_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}} .
$$

According to the principle of relativity, all inertial frames are equivalent, so the transformation from $S$ to $S^{\prime}$ should have the same form as the transformation from $S^{\prime}$ to $S$. However, as the velocity of $S^{\prime}$ relative to $S$ is $v_{1}$ the velocity of $S$ relative to $S^{\prime}$ is $-v_{1}$. The transformation from $S^{\prime}$ to $S$, i.e. the inverse transformation, is therefore

$$
x=\gamma_{1}\left(x^{\prime}+\beta_{1} c t^{\prime}\right), \quad y=y^{\prime}, \quad z=z^{\prime}, \quad c t=\gamma_{1}\left(c t^{\prime}+\beta_{1} x^{\prime}\right),
$$

which is seen to be also a Lorentz transformation. Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime \prime} &=\gamma_{2}\left(x^{\prime}-\beta_{2} c t^{\prime}\right)=\gamma_{2} \gamma_{1}\left[\left(x-\beta_{1} c t\right)-\beta_{2}\left(c t-\beta_{1} x\right)\right] \\
&=\gamma_{2} \gamma_{1}\left[\left(1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}\right) x-\left(\beta_{1}+\beta_{2}\right) c t\right] \\
c t^{\prime \prime} &=\gamma_{2}\left(c t^{\prime}-\beta_{2} x^{\prime}\right)=\gamma_{2} \gamma_{1}\left[\left(1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}\right) c t-\left(\beta_{1}+\beta_{2}\right) x\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where

Writing

$$
\beta_{2}=\frac{v_{2}}{c}, \quad \gamma_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{2}}} .
$$

$$
\beta=\frac{\beta_{1}+\beta_{2}}{1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}}, \quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}},
$$

we have

$$
\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}=1-\left(\frac{\beta_{1}+\beta_{2}}{1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}}\right)^{2}=\frac{\left(1-\beta_{1}^{2}\right)\left(1-\beta_{2}^{2}\right)}{\left(1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{\gamma_{1}^{2} \gamma_{2}^{2}\left(1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}\right)^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\gamma=\gamma_{1} \gamma_{2}\left(1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}\right) .
$$

Hence the transformation from $S$ to $S^{\prime \prime}$ is given by

$$
x^{\prime \prime}=\gamma(x-\beta c t), \quad y^{\prime \prime}=y, \quad z^{\prime \prime}=z, \quad c t^{\prime \prime}=\gamma(c t-\beta x),
$$

showing that it is also a Lorentz transformation. Thus the resultant of two LT's is also an LT.

Note that $\beta \mathrm{c}$ is the velocity of $S^{\prime \prime}$ relative to $S$. This can be shown directly as follows. Consider the transformation between $S$ and $S^{\prime}$. Differentiating we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d x &=\gamma_{1}\left(d x^{\prime}+\beta_{1} c d t^{\prime}\right) \\
c d t &=\gamma_{1}\left(c d t^{\prime}+\beta_{1} d x^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
v=\frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{v^{\prime}+v_{1}}{1+\frac{v_{1} v^{\prime}}{c^{2}}} .
$$

Thus with $v^{\prime}$, the velocity of a point relative to $S^{\prime}$, and $v_{1}$, the velocity of $S^{\prime}$ relative to $S$, the velocity of the point relative to $S$ is given by the above relation. If the point is at rest in $S^{\prime \prime}$, then $v^{\prime}=v_{2}$ and the relation gives 

$$
\beta=\frac{\beta_{1}+\beta_{2}}{1+\beta_{1} \beta_{2}}
$$

as expected.

(b) As shown in Fig. 3.4, by exchanging a particle of 4-momentum $q$ in the interaction, the 4-momenta of particles 1 and $2, p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ change to $p_{1}^{\prime}$ and $p_{2}^{\prime}$, respectively. The conservation of 4-momentum requires

$$
p_{1}^{\prime}=p_{1}+q, \quad p_{2}^{\prime}=p_{2}-q .
$$

Let the mass of particle 1 be $m_{1}$ and that of the exchange particle of 4-momentum $q$ be $m$ and consider the first 4-momentum equation. The momentum part gives

$$
q=p_{1}^{\prime}-p_{1},
$$

or

$$
q^{2}=p_{1}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}-2 \mathbf{p}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{p}_{1}^{\prime}
$$

i.e.

$$
m^{2} \gamma^{2} \beta^{2}=m_{1}^{2} \gamma_{1}^{\prime 2} \beta_{1}^{\prime 2}+m^{2} \gamma_{1}^{2} \beta_{1}^{2}-2 m^{2} \gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime} \beta_{1} \beta_{1}^{\prime} \cos ^{2} \theta,
$$

$\theta$ being the angle between $\mathbf{p}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{p}_{1}^{\prime}$, and

$$
m \gamma=m_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}-m_{1} \gamma_{1},
$$

or

$$
m^{2} \gamma^{2}=m_{1}^{2} \gamma_{1}^{\prime 2}+m_{1}^{2} \gamma_{1}^{2}-2 m_{1}^{2} \gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime} .
$$

Equations (1) and (2) combine to give

$$
m^{2}=2 m_{1}^{2}\left(1-\gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}+\gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime} \beta_{1} \beta_{1}^{\prime} \cos \theta\right) .
$$

We have to show that $m^{2}<0$ so that the interaction cannot be real, but has to be virtual. As $\gamma^{2} \beta^{2}=\gamma^{2}-1$, we have to show

$$
\sqrt{\gamma_{1}^{2}-1} \sqrt{\gamma_{1}^{\prime 2}-1} \cos \theta<\gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}-1,
$$

or

$$
\left(\gamma_{1}^{2}-1\right)\left(\gamma_{1}^{\prime 2}-1\right) \cos ^{2} \theta<\left(\gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2} .
$$

This would be true if the following is true:

$$
\left(\gamma_{1}^{2}-1\right)\left(\gamma_{1}^{\prime 2}-1\right)<\left(\gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2},
$$

i.e.

$$
-\gamma_{1}^{2}-\gamma_{1}^{\prime 2}<-2 \gamma_{1} \gamma_{1}^{\prime},
$$

or

$$
-\left(\gamma_{1}-\gamma_{1}^{\prime}\right)^{2}<0 .
$$

Since this always holds, the interaction has to be virtual.

\section{5}

(a) Given that (r, ct) is a relativistic 4-vector, justify the statement that $(c k, \omega)$ is a relativistic 4 -vector.

(b) Given that an atom at rest emits light of angular frequency $\omega_{0}$ and that this atom is traveling at velocity $v$ either directly towards or away from an observer, use the Lorentz transformation to derive a formula for the frequency observed by the observer for the two cases (towards or away from the observer).

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a plane electromagnetic wave

$$
\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}_{0} e^{i(k \cdot \mathbf{r}-\omega t)}, \quad \mathbf{H}=\mathbf{H}_{0} e^{i(k \cdot \mathbf{r}-\omega t)}
$$

in an inertial frame $\Sigma$. In another inertial frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with relative velocity $v$ along the $x$-direction, the field vectors $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}, \mathbf{H}^{\prime}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\|}^{\prime} &=E_{\|}, \quad H_{\|}^{\prime}=H_{\|}, \\
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mu_{0} \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{H}_{\perp}\right), \\
\mathbf{H}_{\perp}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\mathbf{H}_{\perp}-\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These relations require that the exponential function in $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{H}$ be invariant:

$$
\mathbf{k}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}-\omega^{\prime} t^{\prime}=\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}-\omega t
$$

Since $(\mathbf{r}, \mathrm{ct})$ is a 4-vector, its components transform according to

$$
x^{\prime}=\gamma(x-\beta c t), \quad y^{\prime}=y, \quad z^{\prime}=z, \quad c t^{\prime}=\gamma(\mathrm{ct}-\beta x) .
$$

Letting $\mathbf{k}=\left(k_{1}, k_{2}, k_{3}\right), \mathbf{k}^{\prime}=\left(k_{1}^{\prime}, k_{2}^{\prime}, k_{3}^{\prime}\right)$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{k}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{r}^{\prime}-\omega^{\prime} t^{\prime} &=k_{1}^{\prime} \gamma(x-\beta \mathbf{c} t)+k_{2}^{\prime} y+k_{3}^{\prime} z-\omega^{\prime} \gamma\left(t-\frac{\beta x}{\mathbf{c}}\right) \\
&=\gamma\left(k_{1}^{\prime}+\frac{\beta \omega^{\prime}}{c}\right) x+k_{2}^{\prime} y+k_{3}^{\prime} z-\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta \mathbf{c} k_{1}^{\prime}\right) t \\
&=k_{1} x+k_{2} y+k_{3} z-\omega t .
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing the coefficients of the independent variables $x, y, z, t$ on the two sides of the equation, we find

$$
c k_{1}=\gamma\left(c k_{1}^{\prime}+\beta \omega^{\prime}\right), \quad c k_{2}=c k_{2}^{\prime}, \quad c k_{3}=c k_{3}^{\prime}, \quad \omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{1}^{\prime}\right) .
$$

These relations are exactly the same as those for $(\mathbf{r}, \mathrm{ct})$ :

$$
x=\gamma\left(x^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right), \quad y=y^{\prime}, \quad z=z^{\prime}, \quad c t=\gamma\left(c t^{\prime}+\beta x^{\prime}\right) .
$$

Hence $(\mathrm{ck}, \omega)$ is a relativistic 4-vector.

(b) Let the observer be at the origin of $\Sigma$ and the atom be at the origin of $\Sigma^{\prime}$ (the atom is moving away from the observer with velocity $\beta \mathrm{c}$ ). The angular frequency as measured by the observer is $\omega$. As light from the atom that reaches the observer must have been emitted in the $-x$ direction, we have

$$
\mathbf{k}^{\prime}=\left(-k^{\prime}, 0,0\right)=\left(-\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}, 0,0\right)
$$

by definition. The transformation relation then gives

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}-\beta \omega^{\prime}\right)=\gamma(1-\beta) \omega_{0}=\omega_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}=\omega_{0} \sqrt{\frac{c-v}{c+v}} .
$$

If the atom is moving towards the observer, $\beta$ c in the above is to be replaced by $-\beta \mathrm{c}$ and we have

$$
\omega=\omega_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}=\omega_{0} \sqrt{\frac{c+v}{c-v}} .
$$



\section{6}

A spaceship is moving away from the earth at a speed $v=0.8 c$. When the ship is at a distance of $6.66 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~km}$ from earth as measured in the earth's reference frame, a radio signal is sent out to the spaceship by an observer on earth. How long will it take for the signal to reach the ship:

(a) As measured in the ship's reference frame?

(b) As measured in the earth's reference frame?

(c) Also give the location of the space ship when the signal is received, in both frames.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

Let the observer on earth be at the origin of the inertial frame $\Sigma$ and the spaceship be at rest in the inertial frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $\beta$ c relative to $\Sigma$ along the $x$ direction. For convenience consider (b) first.

(b) Consider the problem in $\Sigma$. At time $t=t_{0}$ when the ship is at $x_{s}$, a radio signal is sent out by the observer. It is received by the spaceship at time $t_{1}$. As the velocity of propagation of the signal is $\mathrm{c}$ we have

$$
\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) \mathrm{c}=x_{s}+\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) \beta \mathrm{c},
$$

yielding

$$
t_{1}-t_{0}=\frac{x_{s}}{(1-\beta) \mathrm{c}}=\frac{6.66 \times 10^{8}}{0.2 \times 3 \times 10^{5}}=1.11 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~s}
$$

as the time taken for the signal to reach the ship.

(a) Consider the two events

$E_{0}$ : sending out of signal by the observer on earth,

$E_{1}$ : arrival of the signal at the ship.

In $\Sigma$ the $x$ and $t$ coordinates are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{0}:\left(x_{0}, t_{0}\right)=\left(0, t_{0}\right) \\
&E_{1}:\left(x_{1}, t_{1}\right)=\left(\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) c, t_{1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ 

$$
\begin{aligned}
t_{0}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(t_{0}-\frac{\beta x_{0}}{\mathrm{c}}\right) &=\gamma t_{0}, \\
t_{1}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(t_{1}-\frac{\beta x_{1}}{\mathrm{c}}\right) &=\gamma\left[(1-\beta) t_{1}+\beta t_{0}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the time of travel of the signal in the ship's frame is

$$
t_{1}^{\prime}-t_{0}^{\prime}=\gamma(1-\beta)\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right)=3.7 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~s} .
$$

(c) The location of the spaceship when the signal is received is

$$
x_{1}=\left(t_{1}-t_{0}\right) \mathrm{c}=1.11 \times 10^{4} \times 3 \times 10^{5}=3.33 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~km}
$$

in the earth's frame, and $x_{1}^{\prime}=0$ in the ship's frame.

\section{7}

A globe of (rest) radius $R_{0}$, with identifiable markings on it, is moving with a speed $v$ with respect to an observer located a large distance away. The observer takes a picture of the globe at the time that he sees the globe moving perpendicular to the line joining himself with the globe. What does he see when he develops the film?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Consider a thin square $A B C D$ of (rest) side $l$ moving with velocity $v$ relative to an observer $P$ at a large distance $l$ away such that the plane of the square contains the line of sight as shown in Fig. 3.5, and the instant when $A B$ is perpendicular to the line of sight. Light from $D^{\prime}$ emitted at an earlier time when $D$ was at $D^{\prime}$ intersects the extension of the line $A B$ at $E^{\prime}$ at the instant under consideration. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\overline{D^{\prime} D}}{v}=\frac{\overline{D^{\prime} E^{\prime}}}{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{l}{\cos \theta}, \\
&\overline{E^{\prime} A}=\overline{D^{\prime} D}-l \tan \theta=l\left(\frac{v}{c} \sec \theta-\tan \theta\right) \approx \frac{l v}{\mathrm{c}}=\beta l
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$, since for $L \gg l, \theta \approx 0$. As $\overline{A B}$ is moving with velocity $v$, on account of Lorentz contraction, it will be seen as $\overline{A B^{\prime}}=\frac{\overline{A B}}{\gamma}=l \sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}$, where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-682.jpg?height=820&width=318&top_left_y=462&top_left_x=275)

Fig. 3.5.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-682.jpg?height=285&width=320&top_left_y=436&top_left_x=889)

Fig. 3.6.

Consider now the square $A B C D$ after rotating through an angle $\alpha$, as shown in Fig. 3.6, with $\alpha$ given by $\sin \alpha=\beta$. We have

$$
\overline{E^{\prime} A}=l \sin \alpha=l \beta, \quad \overline{A B^{\prime}}=l \cos \alpha=l \sqrt{1-\beta^{2}} .
$$

The relationship among the points $E^{\prime}, A, B^{\prime}$ in the above two cases are exactly the same. Hence the inoving square in Fig. $3.5$ will be photographed as the stationary square shown in Fig. 3.6. As the object is a sphere, it will still be photographed as a sphere. 

\section{8}

An atomic clock is carried once around the world by a jet plane and then compared with a previously synchronized and similar clock that did not travel. Approximately how large a discrepancy does special relativity predict?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the jet plane moves with velocity $\beta$ c. Let its rest frame be $S^{\prime}$ and the earth's frame be $S$. The two frames can be considered as approximately inertial. Lorentz transformation $c t=\gamma\left(c t^{\prime}+\beta x^{\prime}\right)$ give for $\Delta x^{\prime}=0$, since the clock is fixed in $\Sigma^{\prime}, \Delta t=\gamma \Delta t^{\prime}$, where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Then for $\beta \ll 1$, we have

$$
\Delta t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \Delta t^{\prime} \simeq\left(1+\frac{1}{2} \beta^{2}\right) \Delta t^{\prime},
$$

or

$$
\Delta t-\Delta t^{\prime} \simeq \frac{1}{2} \beta^{2} \Delta t^{\prime} .
$$

Take for example a jet fighter flying at $1000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, about three times the speed of sound. The earth has radius $6400 \mathrm{~km}$, so the fighter takes

$$
\frac{2 \pi \times 6400 \times 10^{3}}{1000}=4.02 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~s}
$$

to fly once around the earth. The clock carried by the fighter will be slower by

$$
\Delta t-\Delta t^{\prime} \approx\left(\frac{1000}{3 \times 10^{8}}\right)^{2} \times \frac{4.02 \times 10^{4}}{2}=2.2 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}
$$

\section{9}

(a) Write down the Lorentz transformation for the position 4-vector and derive the transformation for the momentum 4-vector.

(b) Show that the Doppler effect on light frequency can be expressed as

i) $\nu=\nu_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}$ when the source and observer are approaching; ii) $\nu=\nu_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}$ when the source and observer are receding;

iii) $\nu=\frac{\nu_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$ when the source and observer are in perpendicular directions passing each other.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider two inertial frames $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ with the corresponding axes parallel to each other such that $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moves with a velocity $v=\beta$ c along the $x$ direction and that the origins coincide at $t=t^{\prime}=0$. The Lorentz transformation for the position 4-vector $x^{\alpha} \equiv(\mathbf{r}, c t) \equiv(x, y, z, c t)$ is

$$
x^{\prime \alpha}=Q_{\beta}^{\alpha} x^{\beta},
$$

where

$$
Q_{\beta}^{\alpha}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\gamma & 0 & 0 & -\beta \gamma \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
-\beta \gamma & 0 & 0 & \gamma
\end{array}\right)
$$

with $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$

The momentum 4-vector is defined as

$$
p^{\alpha} \equiv(\mathbf{p c}, E),
$$

where $E=m c^{2}$ is the total energy. As all 4-vectors transform in the same way, its transformation is given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
p_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c} \\
p_{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{c} \\
p_{z}^{\prime} \mathrm{c} \\
E
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\gamma & 0 & 0 & -\beta \gamma \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
-\beta \gamma & 0 & 0 & \gamma
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
p_{x} \mathrm{c} \\
p_{y} \mathrm{c} \\
p_{z} \mathrm{c} \\
E
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\gamma\left(p_{x} \mathrm{c}-\beta E\right) \\
p_{y} \mathrm{c} \\
p_{z} \mathrm{c} \\
\gamma\left(E-\beta p_{x} \mathrm{c}\right)
\end{array}\right)
$$

(b) The wave 4-vector is defined by

$$
k^{\alpha} \equiv(k c, \omega) \text {. }
$$

Its transformation

$$
k^{\prime \alpha}=Q_{\beta}^{\alpha} k^{\beta}
$$

can be written as

$$
k_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(k_{x}-\frac{\beta \omega}{\mathrm{c}}\right), \quad k_{y}^{\prime}=k_{y}, \quad k_{z}^{\prime}=k_{z}, \quad \omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta k_{x} \mathrm{c}\right) .
$$

To obtain the Doppler effect, let the frames of the light source and observer be $\Sigma^{\prime}, \Sigma$ respectively.

i) When the source and observer approach each other let $\beta_{0}$ c be the relative velocity of the former relative to the latter. Then $\beta=-\beta_{0}$. The inverse transformation is

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta k_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}\right)=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}-\beta_{0} k_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}\right) .
$$

As $k_{y}^{\prime}=k_{z}^{\prime}=0, k_{x}^{\prime}=-k^{\prime}=-\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{c}$, we have

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(1+\beta_{0}\right) \omega^{\prime}=\omega^{\prime} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta_{0}}{1-\beta_{0}}},
$$

or

$$
\nu=\nu_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta_{0}}{1-\beta_{0}}},
$$

where $\omega^{\prime}=2 \pi \nu_{0}$ is the proper angular frequency of the light and $\omega$ is the angular frequency as measured by the observer. Note that $k_{x}=-k$ as the light has to be emitted backwards to reach the observer.

ii) When the source and observer are receding from each other, we have $\beta=\beta_{0}, \beta_{0}$ c being the velocity of the former relative to the latter. Thus

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(1-\beta_{0}\right) \omega^{\prime}=\omega^{\prime} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta_{0}}{1+\beta_{0}}},
$$

or

$$
\nu=\nu_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta_{0}}{1+\beta_{0}}} .
$$

iii) When the source and observer are in perpendicular directions passing each other, let the source be at $\left(0, y^{\prime}, 0\right)$ in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and the observer be at $(0,0,0)$ in $\Sigma$. They pass each other at $t=t^{\prime}=0$, when $k_{x}^{\prime}=0, k_{y}^{\prime}=-k, k_{z}^{\prime}=0$. The transformation equation for $\omega$ then gives

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta k_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}\right)=\gamma \omega^{\prime}=\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}},
$$

or

$$
\nu=\frac{\nu_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} .
$$

\section{0}

A monochromatic transverse wave with frequency $\nu$ propagates in a direction which makes an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with the $x$-axis in the reference frame $K$ of its source. The source moves in the $x$-direction at speed $v=\frac{4}{5} c$ towards an observer at rest in the $K^{\prime}$ frame (where his $x^{\prime}$-axis is parallel to the $x$-axis). The observer measures the frequency of the wave.

(a) Determine the measured frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ in terms of the proper frequency $\nu$ of the wave.

(b) What is the angle of observation in the $K^{\prime}$ frame? (SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

The frame $K$ of the light source moves with velocity $\beta$ c relative to $K^{\prime}$, the observer's frame. The (inverse) transformation of the components of the wave 4 -vector is given by

$$
k_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=\gamma\left(k_{x} \mathrm{c}+\beta \omega\right), \quad k_{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=k_{y} \mathrm{c}, \quad k_{z}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=k_{z} \mathrm{c}, \quad \omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega+\beta k_{x} \mathrm{c}\right)
$$

where $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. The angular frequency of the wave in $K$ is $\omega=2 \pi \nu$. If the angle between the light and the $x$-axis is $\theta$, then

$$
k_{x}=k \cos \theta, \quad k_{y}=k \sin \theta, \quad k_{z}=0, \quad \omega=k \mathrm{c} .
$$

Thus

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma(\omega+\beta \omega \cos \theta)=\gamma(1+\beta \cos \theta) \omega,
$$

or

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\frac{(1+\beta \cos \theta) \nu}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} .
$$

The above can also be written as

$$
k^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta \cos \theta) k
$$

As

$$
k_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(k_{x}+\frac{\beta \omega}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\gamma k(\cos \theta+\beta),
$$

the angle $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ makes with the $x^{\prime}$-axis is given by

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=\frac{k_{x}^{\prime}}{k^{\prime}}=\frac{\cos \theta+\beta}{1+\beta \cos \theta} .
$$

With $\beta=0.8, \theta=60^{\circ}$, we have

(a)

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1+0.8 \cos 60^{\circ}}{\sqrt{1-0.8^{2}}}\right) \nu=\frac{1.4}{0.6} \nu=\frac{7}{3} \nu,
$$

(b)

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=\frac{0.5+0.8}{1+0.8 \times 0.5}=\frac{13}{14},
$$

giving $\theta^{\prime}=21.8^{\circ}$

\section{1}

Consider two twins. Each twin's heart beats once per second, and each twin broadcasts a radio pulse at each heartbeat. The stay-at-home twin remains at rest in an inertial frame. The traveler starts at rest at time zero, very rapidly accelerates up to velocity $v$ (within less than a heartbeat, and without perturbing his heart!). The traveler travels for time $t_{1}$ by his clock, all the while sending out pulses and receiving pulses from home. Then at time $t_{1}$ he suddenly reverses his velocity and arrives back home at time $2 t_{1}$. How many pulses did he send out altogether? How many pulses did he receive during the outgoing trip? How many did he receive on the ingoing half of his trip? What is the ratio of total pulses received and sent? Next consider the twin who stays at home. He sends out pulses during the entire trip of the traveler. He receives pulses from the traveler. From time zero to $t_{2}$ (by his clock) he receives Doppler-lowered-frequency pulses. At time $t_{2}$ he starts receiving Doppler-raised-frequency pulses. Let $t_{3}$ be the time interval from time $t_{2}$ till the end of the trip. How many pulses does he receive during interval $t_{2}$ ? During $t_{3}$ ? What is the ratio between these? What is the ratio of the total number of pulses he sends to the total he receives? Compare this result with the analogous result for the traveler.

(UC, Berkeley) 

\section{Solution:}

Consider inertial frames $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $v$ relative to $\Sigma$ in the direction of the $x$-axis. The transformation relations for space-time and angular frequency four-vectors are

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime} &=\gamma(x-v t), & & x=\gamma\left(x^{\prime}+v t^{\prime}\right), \\
y^{\prime} &=y, & z^{\prime} &=z, \\
t^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(t-\frac{v x}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right), & & t=\gamma\left(t^{\prime}+\frac{v x^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right), \\
\omega^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\omega-v k_{x}\right), & \omega &=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+v k_{x}^{\prime}\right), \\
k_{y}^{\prime} &=k_{y}, & k_{z}^{\prime} &=k_{z},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \quad \text { with } \quad \beta=\frac{|v|}{\mathrm{c}}, \quad|\mathrm{k}|=\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{c}}, \quad \omega=2 \pi \nu,
$$

$\nu$ being the frequency.

Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the twin $A$ who stays at home and the twin $B$ who travels, respectively, with $A, B$ located at the respective origins. As the times of acceleration and deceleration of $B$ are small compared with the time of the trips, $\Sigma^{\prime}$ can still be considered inertial. Measure time in seconds so that $\nu$ has numerical value one in the rest frame. At the start of the journey of $B, t=t^{\prime}=0$.

Consider from the point of view of $B$.

(i) The total trip takes time $\Delta t^{\prime}=2 t_{1}$. Thus $B$ sends out $2 t_{1}$ pulses for the entire trip.

(ii) For the outgoing trip, $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, k_{x}=\frac{\omega}{c}$, and the pulses received by $B$ have frequency

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\nu-\frac{1}{2 \pi} \beta c k_{x}\right)=\gamma(1-\beta) \nu=\gamma(1-\beta)
$$

since $\nu=1$ as $\Sigma$ is the rest frame of $A$. Hence $B$ receives

$$
\nu^{\prime} t_{1}=\gamma(1-\beta) t_{1}=t_{1} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}
$$

pulses during the outgoing trip. (ii) For the ingoing trip, $\beta=-\frac{v}{c}, k_{x}=\frac{\omega}{c}$, and

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta) \nu=\gamma(1+\beta) \text {. }
$$

Hence $B$ receives

$$
\nu^{\prime} t_{1}=\gamma(1+\beta) t_{1}=t_{1} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}
$$

pulses during the ingoing trip.

(iv)

$\frac{\text { total pulses received by } B}{\text { total pulses sent by } B}=\frac{\gamma(1-\beta) t_{1}+\gamma(1+\beta) t_{1}}{2 t_{1}}=\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$.

Consider from the point of view of $A$

(i) In the interval $t=0$ to $t=t_{2}, A$ receives Doppler-lowered-frequency pulses indicating that $B$ is moving away during the interval, i.e. $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$. As the pulses have to be emitted in $-x^{\prime}$ direction to reach $A, k_{x}^{\prime}=-\frac{\omega}{c}$. Thus

$$
\nu=\gamma\left(\nu^{\prime}-\beta \nu^{\prime}\right)=\gamma(1-\beta) \nu^{\prime}=\gamma(1-\beta),
$$

since $\nu^{\prime}=1$ as $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is the rest frame of $B$, and the number of pulses received is $\gamma(1-\beta) t_{2}$. The interval of time during which $B$, starting at $t=t^{\prime}=0$, moves away from $A$ is transformed by

$$
\Delta t=\gamma\left(\Delta t^{\prime}+\frac{\beta \Delta x^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\gamma \Delta t^{\prime}=\gamma t_{1}
$$

since $\Delta x^{\prime}=0, B$ being stationary in $\Sigma^{\prime}$. However, $A$ and $B$ communicate by light pulses, whose time of travel

$$
\frac{x}{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\gamma\left(x^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right)}{\mathrm{c}}=\gamma \beta t^{\prime}=\gamma \beta t_{1},
$$

where $x$ is the coordinate of $B$ in $\Sigma$, must be taken into account. Hence

$$
t_{2}=\Delta t+\frac{x}{\mathrm{c}}=\gamma(1+\beta) t_{1}=t_{1} \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}},
$$

i.e. the number of pulses received is

$$
\gamma(1-\beta) t_{2}=t_{2} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}=t_{1} .
$$

(ii) In the time interval $t_{3}$ from $t=t_{2}$ to the end of journey, $A$ receives Doppler-raised-frequency pulses, indicating that $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moves toward $\Sigma$, i.e. $\beta=-\frac{v}{c}$. As $k_{x}^{\prime}=-\frac{\omega}{c}$,

$$
\nu=\gamma\left(\nu^{\prime}+\beta \nu^{\prime}\right)=\gamma(1+\beta) \nu^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta) \text {. }
$$

By a similar argument as that in (i) we have

$$
t_{3}=\gamma t_{1}-\gamma \beta t_{1}=\gamma(1-\beta) t_{1} .
$$

Hence the number of pulses received is

$$
\gamma(1+\beta) t_{3}=t_{1} .
$$

(iii)

$$
\frac{\text { lowered-frequency pulses received by } A}{\text { raised-frequency pulses received by } A}=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{1}}=1 \text {. }
$$

(iv)

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\text { total number of pulses sent by } A}{\text { total number of pulses received by } A} \\
&=\frac{t_{2}+t_{3}}{2 t_{1}}=\frac{\gamma(1+\beta) t_{1}+\gamma(1-\beta) t_{1}}{2 t_{1}}=\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This is the same as the ratio of the number of pulses received by $B$ to that sent by $B$ during the entire trip, as expected since counting of numbers is invariant under Lorentz transformation.

\section{2}

A spaceship has a transmitter and a receiver. The ship, which is proceeding at constant velocity directly away from the mother earth, sends back a signal pulse which is reflected from the earth. Forty seconds later on the ship's clock the signal is picked up and the frequency received is one half the transmitter frequency.

(a) At the time when the radar pulse bounces off the earth what is the position of the earth as measured in the spaceship frame?

(b) What is the velocity of the spaceship relative to the earth? (c) At the time when the radar pulse is received by the spaceship where is the ship in the earth frame?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Let the spaceship and the earth be at the origins of inertial frames $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and $\Sigma$ respectively with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $\beta$ c relative to $\Sigma$ in the $x$ direction such that $x^{\prime}=x=0$ at $t=t^{\prime}=0$.

(a) The velocity of the radar pulse is c in all directions. So in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the pulse takes a time $\frac{40}{2}=20 \mathrm{~s}$ to reach the earth. Hence the position of the earth when the pulse bounces off the earth is $x^{\prime}=-20 \mathrm{c}=-6 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~m}$ as measured in the ship's frame.

(b) In $\Sigma$ the angular frequency $\omega$ of the signal is observed to be

$$
\omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

with $\omega^{\prime}=\omega_{0}$, the proper angular frequency of the signal, $k_{x}^{\prime}=-\frac{\omega_{0}}{c}$ as the signal has to go in the $-x^{\prime}$ direction to reach the earth, and $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Thus

$$
\omega=\gamma(1-\beta) \omega_{0} .
$$

After reflection from the earth's surface, the angular frequency will be observed in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ as

$$
\omega^{\prime \prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right)
$$

with $k_{x}=\frac{\omega}{c}, \omega=\gamma(1-\beta) \omega_{0}$. Thus

$$
\omega^{\prime \prime}=\gamma(1-\beta) \omega=\gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} \omega_{0}=\left(\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}\right) \omega_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \omega_{0},
$$

yielding

$$
\beta=\frac{1}{3} .
$$

Hence the velocity of the spaceship relative to the earth is

$$
v=\frac{1}{3} \times 3 \times 10^{8}=10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
$$

(c) In $\Sigma^{\prime}$, when the signal bounces off the earth the time is

$$
t^{\prime}=\frac{-20 \mathrm{c}}{-\beta \mathrm{c}}=60 \mathrm{~s}
$$

as the earth moves with relative velocity $-\beta$ c. When the signal is received by the ship, the time is $t^{\prime}=60+20=80 \mathrm{~s}$. As the ship is stationary at the origin of $\Sigma^{\prime}, x^{\prime}=0$. This instant is perceived in $\Sigma$ as a time

$$
t=\gamma\left(t^{\prime}+\frac{\beta x^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\gamma t^{\prime}=80 \gamma .
$$

As the ship moves away from the earth at a velocity $\beta c=\frac{1}{3} c$, its position in $\Sigma$ at this instant is

$$
x=\beta c t=\frac{80}{3} \gamma c=8.5 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~m} .
$$

\section{3}

A point source $S$ of monochromatic light emits radiation of frequency $f$. An observer $A$ moves at constant speed $v$ along a straight line that passes at a distance $d$ from the source as shown in Fig. 3.7.

(a) Derive an expression for the observed frequency as function of the distance $x$ from the point of closest approach $O$.

(b) Sketch an approximate graph of your answer to (a) for the case of $\frac{v}{c}=0.80$.

(UC, Berkeley)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-692.jpg?height=266&width=374&top_left_y=1358&top_left_x=309)

Fig. 3.7.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-692.jpg?height=342&width=633&top_left_y=1314&top_left_x=741)

Fig. 3.8.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let the rest frames of the light source $S$ and the observer $A$ be $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ respectively, taking the direction of the relative velocity $v$ as along the $x, x^{\prime}$-axes. The transformation of the wave 4-vector components is

$$
