c k_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(c k_{x}-\beta \omega\right), \quad k_{y}=k_{y}^{\prime}, \quad k_{z}^{\prime}=k_{z}, \quad \omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right) \text {, }
$$

where $|\mathbf{k}|=\frac{\omega}{c}, \beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. As $k_{x}=k \sin \theta, k=\frac{\omega}{c}$, we have

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma(\omega-\beta \omega \sin \theta)=\gamma \omega(1-\beta \sin \theta) .
$$

With $\sin \theta=\frac{x}{\sqrt{d^{2}+x^{2}}}, \omega=2 \pi f^{\prime}, \omega=2 \pi f$, the above gives the observed frequency as

$$
f^{\prime}=\left(1-\frac{\beta x}{\sqrt{d^{2}+x^{2}}}\right) \frac{f}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} .
$$

(b) If $\beta=0.8, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\frac{10}{6}$ and

$$
f^{\prime}=\frac{1}{3}\left(5-\frac{4 x}{\sqrt{d^{2}+x^{2}}}\right) f .
$$

To find the shape of $\frac{f^{\prime}}{f}$, consider the following:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x \rightarrow-\infty, \quad \frac{f^{\prime}}{f}=\frac{1}{3}\left(5+\frac{4}{\sqrt{\left(\frac{d}{x}\right)^{2}+1}}\right) \rightarrow 3 \\
& x \rightarrow \infty, \quad \frac{f^{\prime}}{f}=\frac{1}{3}\left(5-\frac{4}{\sqrt{\left(\frac{d}{x}\right)^{2}+1}}\right) \rightarrow \frac{1}{3}, \\
& x=0, \quad \frac{f^{\prime}}{f}=\frac{5}{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

An approximate sketch of the graph of $\frac{f^{\prime}}{f}$ is given in Fig. 3.8.

3014

Consider monochromatic radiation emitted at the sun with frequency $\nu_{s} \mathrm{cps}$, and received at the earth with frequency $\nu_{e}$ cps. Use the Riemannain matrix form

$$
g_{00}=\left(1+\frac{2 \Phi}{c^{2}}\right), \quad g_{11}=g_{22}=g_{33}=-1, \quad g_{\mu \neq \nu}=0,
$$

where $\Phi$ is the gravitational potential energy per unit mass, to derive the "gravitational red shift" $\frac{\left(\nu_{e}-\nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right)}{\nu_{s}}$ as a function of the difference of gravitational potentials at the sun and earth.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

\section{Solution:}

In a gravitational field it is always possible to define a frame relative to which the field vanishes over a limited region and which behaves as an inertial frame. A frame freely falling in the gravitational field is such a frame. A standard clock at rest in such a frame measures the local proper time interval.

Consider the emission of monochromatic radiation by an atom at rest at point $P_{1}$ in a gravitational field and use a coordinate frame in which the atom is at rest. If the period is $t$ in the coordinate time, the period $\tau$ in the local proper time is

$$
\tau=t \sqrt{g_{00}\left(P_{1}\right)} .
$$

Suppose successive crests of the radiation emitted from $P_{1}$ at coordinate times $t_{0}, t_{0}+t$ are received at another fixed point $P_{2}$ at coordinate times $t_{0}+T$ and $t_{0}+T+t$, where $T$ is the difference between the coordinate times of emission at $P_{1}$ and reception at $P_{2}$. If the gravitational field is static, $T$ is a constant and the period measured in the coordinate time is

$$
\left(t_{0}+T+t\right)-\left(t_{0}+T\right)=t .
$$

However, a standard clock measuring the local proper time at $P_{2}$ will give the period as

$$
\tau^{\prime}=t \sqrt{g_{00}\left(P_{2}\right)} .
$$

Hence the frequency $\nu$ of the line emitted at $P_{1}$ and the frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ observed at $P_{2}$, as measured by identical standard clocks, are related by

$$
\frac{\nu^{\prime}}{\nu}=\frac{\tau}{\tau^{\prime}}=\sqrt{\frac{g_{00}\left(P_{1}\right)}{g_{00}\left(P_{2}\right)}} .
$$

If $P_{1}, P_{2}$ are on the sun and the earth respectively, this gives the gravitational red shift as 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\nu_{e}-\nu_{s}}{\nu_{s}} &=\sqrt{\frac{g_{00}\left(\mathbf{r}_{s}\right)}{g_{00}\left(\mathbf{r}_{e}\right)}-1} \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{1+\frac{2 \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{s}\right)}{c^{2}}}{1+\frac{2 \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{e}\right)}{c^{2}}}}-1 \\
& \approx \frac{\Phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{s}\right)-\Phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{e}\right)}{c^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{5}

A mirror is moving through vacuum with relativistic speed $v$ in the $x$ direction. A beam of light with frequency $\omega_{i}$ is normally incident (from $x=+\infty$ ) on the mirror, as shown in Fig. 3.9.

(a) What is the frequency of the reflected light expressed in terms of $\omega_{i}$, $\mathrm{c}$ and $v ?$

(b) What is the energy of each reflected photon?

(c) The average energy flux of the incident beam is $P_{i}$ (watts $/ \mathrm{m}^{2}$ ). What is the average reflected energy flux?

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-695.jpg?height=271&width=404&top_left_y=1264&top_left_x=593)

Fig. 3.9.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the light source and observer, and of the mirror respectively. The transformation for angular frequency is given by

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right), \quad \omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right),
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. For the incident light, $\omega=\omega_{i}, k_{x}=-\frac{\omega_{i}}{c}$, the mirror perceives

$$
\omega_{i}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega_{i}+\beta \omega_{i}\right)=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{i} .
$$

On reflection, $\omega_{r}^{\prime}=\omega_{i}^{\prime}$. The observer in $\Sigma$ will perceive

$$
\omega_{r}=\gamma\left(\omega_{r}^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

with $k_{x}^{\prime}=\omega_{r}^{\prime} / \mathrm{c}$, or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{r} &=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{r}^{\prime}=\gamma^{2}(1+\beta)^{2} \omega_{i} \\
&=\left(\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}\right) \omega_{i}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \dot{\omega}_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

as the angular frequency of the reflected light.

(b) The energy of each reflected photon is

$$
\hbar \omega_{r}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \hbar \omega_{i} .
$$

(c) If $n$ is the number of photons per unit volume of the beam, its average energy flux is $n c \hbar \omega$. The average energy flux of the reflected beam is therefore

$$
P_{r}=n \mathrm{c} \hbar \omega_{r}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{c}+v}{\mathrm{c}-v}\right) n \mathrm{c} \hbar \omega_{i}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{c}+v}{\mathrm{c}-v}\right) P_{i} .
$$

\section{6}

As seen by an inertial observer $O$, photons of frequency $\nu$ are incident, at an angle $\theta_{i}$ to the normal, on a plane mirror. These photons are reflected back at an angle $\theta_{r}$ to the normal and at a frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ as shown in Fig. 3.10. Find $\theta_{r}$ and $\nu^{\prime}$ in terms of $\theta_{i}$ and $\nu$ if the mirror is moving in the $x$ direction with velocity $v$ relative to $O$. What is the result if the mirror were moving with a velocity $v$ in the $y$ direction?

(Princeton $)$

\section{Solution:}

Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the observer and the mirror, as shown in Figs. $3.10$ and $3.11$ respectively and use the transformation relations 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-697.jpg?height=297&width=421&top_left_y=254&top_left_x=196)

Fig. 3.10.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-697.jpg?height=294&width=324&top_left_y=249&top_left_x=873)

Fig. 3.11.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& c k_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathrm{c} k_{x}-\beta \omega\right), \quad c k_{x}=\gamma\left(c k_{x}^{\prime}+\beta \omega^{\prime}\right) \text {, } \\
& \quad c k_{y}^{\prime}=c k_{y}, \quad c k_{z}^{\prime}=c k_{z} \text {, } \\
& \omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right), \quad \omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right) \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

With $k_{i}=\frac{\omega_{i}}{c}=\frac{2 \pi \nu}{c}, k_{r}=\frac{\omega_{r}}{c}=\frac{2 \pi \nu^{\prime}}{c}$, we have for the incident light

$$
\begin{aligned}
-k_{i}^{\prime} \cos \theta_{i}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(-k_{i} \cos \theta_{i}-\frac{\beta \omega_{i}}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=-\gamma k_{i}\left(\cos \theta_{i}+\beta\right) \\
\omega_{i}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\omega_{i}+\beta c k_{i} \cos \theta_{i}\right)=\gamma \omega_{i}\left(1+\beta \cos \theta_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
k_{i}^{\prime} \cos \theta_{i}^{\prime}=\gamma k_{i}\left(\cos \theta_{i}+\beta\right), \quad k_{i}^{\prime}=\gamma k_{i}\left(1+\beta \cos \theta_{i}\right) .
$$

On reflection, $\omega_{r}^{\prime}=\omega_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{r}^{\prime}=\theta_{i}^{\prime}$, so for the reflected light we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{r} &=\gamma\left(\omega_{r}^{\prime}+\beta c k_{r}^{\prime} \cos \theta_{r}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma\left(\omega_{i}^{\prime}+\beta \omega_{i}^{\prime} \cos \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
k_{r} \cos \theta_{r} &=\gamma k_{r}^{\prime}\left(\cos \theta_{r}^{\prime}+\beta\right)=\gamma k_{i}^{\prime}\left(\cos \theta_{i}^{\prime}+\beta\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
k_{r} &=\gamma k_{i}^{\prime}\left(1+\beta \cos \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
&=\gamma^{2} k_{i}\left(1+\beta \cos \theta_{i}\right)+\gamma^{2} \beta k_{i}\left(\cos \theta_{i}+\beta\right) \\
&=\gamma^{2} k_{i}\left(1+2 \beta \cos \theta_{i}+\beta^{2}\right), \\
k_{r} \cos \theta_{r} &=\gamma^{2} k_{i}\left[\left(1+\beta^{2}\right) \cos \theta_{i}+2 \beta\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e. 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu^{\prime}=& \frac{\nu\left(1+2 \beta \cos \theta_{i}+\beta^{2}\right)}{1-\beta^{2}}, \\
\cos \theta_{r}=& \frac{\left(1+\beta^{2}\right) \cos \theta_{i}+2 \beta}{1+2 \beta \cos \theta_{i}+\beta^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the mirror moves in the $y$-direction, the motion will have no effect on the reflection process and we still have

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\nu, \quad \theta_{r}=\theta_{i} .
$$

\section{7}

In a simplified version of the ending of one of Fred Hoyle's novels, the hero, traveling at high Lorentz factor at right angles to the plane of our galaxy (Fig. 3.12), said he appeared to be inside and heading toward the mouth of a "goldfish bowl" with a blue rim and a red body (Fig. 3.13). Feynman betted 25 cents that the light from the galaxy would not look that way. We want to see who was right. Take the relative speed to be $\beta=0.99$ and the angle $\varphi$ in the frame of the galaxy to be $45^{\circ}$ (Fig. 3.12).

(a) Derive (or recall) an expression for the relativistic aberration and use it to calculate (Fig. 3.13) the direction from which light from the edge of the galaxy appears to come when viewed in the spacecraft.

(b) Derive (or recall) the relativistic Doppler effect and use it to calculate the frequency ratio $\nu^{\prime} / \nu$ for light from the edge.

(c) Calculate $\varphi^{\prime}$ and $\nu^{\prime} / \nu$ at enough angles $\varphi$ to decide who won the bet. (UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma^{\prime}, \Sigma$ be inertial frames attached to the spaceship and the galaxy respectively with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $v$ along the $x$-direction which is perpendicular to the galactic plane as shown in Fig. 3.12. The velocities of a point, $\mathbf{u}$ and $\mathbf{u}^{\prime}$, in $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ are related by the transformation for velocity

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{x}-v}{1-\frac{v u_{x}}{c^{2}}}, \quad u_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{y}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{v u_{x}}{c^{2}}\right)}, \quad u_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{z}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{v u_{x}}{c^{2}}\right)},
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-699.jpg?height=352&width=449&top_left_y=248&top_left_x=262)

Fig. 3.12.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-699.jpg?height=143&width=302&top_left_y=376&top_left_x=888)

Fig. 3.13.

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$ with $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$. Consider light coming from a point at the rim of the galactic circle as shown in the figure, for which

$$
u_{x}=\cos \varphi, \quad u_{y}=\operatorname{csin} \varphi, \quad u_{z}=0 .
$$

Then

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=\cos \varphi^{\prime}=\frac{c \cos \varphi-v}{1-\beta \cos \varphi},
$$

or

$$
\cos \varphi^{\prime}=\frac{\cos \varphi-\beta}{1-\beta \cos \varphi}=\frac{0.707-0.99}{1-0.99 \times 0.707}=-0.943 \text {, }
$$

giving $\varphi^{\prime}=160.6^{\circ}$. This is the angle the direction of the light makes with the direction of motion of the spaceship as seen by the traveler. This angle is supplementary to the angle $\varphi^{\prime}$ shown in Fig. 3.13.

(b) The transformation for angular frequency,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right) \\
&=\gamma(\omega-\beta \cos \cos \varphi) \\
&=\gamma \omega(1-\beta \cos \varphi),
\end{aligned}
$$

gives

$$
\frac{\nu^{\prime}}{\nu}=\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{\omega}=\gamma(1-\beta \cos \varphi)=\frac{1-0.99 \times 0.707}{\sqrt{1-0.99^{2}}}=2.13 .
$$

(c) The above result shows that the light from the rim is blue-shifted. For light from the center, $\varphi=0$ and

$$
\frac{\nu^{\prime}}{\nu}=\gamma(1-\beta)=0.071 \text {, }
$$

showing that it is red-shifted. The critical direction between blue shift and red shift is given by $\nu^{\prime}=\nu$, or

$$
\cos \varphi=\frac{1}{\beta}\left(1-\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=0.868,
$$

i.e. $\varphi=29.8^{\circ}$.

As the spaceship leaves the center of the galaxy, at first $\varphi=90^{\circ}$ and

$$
\frac{\nu^{\prime}}{\nu}=\gamma=7.09 \text {, }
$$

so all the light from the galaxy appears blue-shifted. As it gains distance from the galaxy, light from the center starts to become red-shifted. As the spaceship goes further out, light from a larger and larger central region will appear red-shifted. Only light from the rim is blue-shifted. Finally at a large distance away, $\varphi=0$ and $\frac{\nu^{\prime}}{\nu}=0.071$, so all the light from the galaxy is red-shifted. Thus the statement of Fred Hoyle's hero is correct and Feynman loses the bet.

\section{8}

As observed in an inertial frame $S$, two spaceships are travelling in opposite directions along straight, parallel trajectories separated by a distance $d$ as shown in Fig. 3.14. The speed of each ship is $\mathrm{c} / 2$, where $\mathrm{c}$ is the speed of light.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-700.jpg?height=345&width=384&top_left_y=1480&top_left_x=556)

Fig. 3.14. (a) At the instant (as viewed from $S$ ) when the ships are at the points of closest approach (indicated by the dotted line in the figure), ship (1) ejects a small package which has speed 3c/4 (also as viewed from $S$ ). From the point of view of the observer in ship (1), at what angle must the package be aimed for it to be received by ship (2)? Assume the observer in ship (1) has a coordinate system whose axes are parallel to those of $S$ and, as shown in the figure, the direction of motion is parallel to the $y$-axis. (1)

(b) What is the speed of the package as seen by the observer in ship

$(C U S P E A)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider the events in the frame $S$. The package must have $u_{y}=\frac{c}{2}$ so that after traveling a distance $\Delta x=d$ it will have the same $y$-coordinate as ship (2). Thus in $S$, the package must have velocity components

$$
u_{y}=\frac{c}{2}, \quad u_{x}=\sqrt{u^{2}-u_{y}^{2}}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{3 c}{4}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{c}{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{5} c}{4} .
$$

Let $S^{\prime}$ be the inertial frame attached to ship (1) with its coordinate axes $x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}$ parallel to the corresponding axes $x, y, z$ of $S$. As $S^{\prime}$ has a velocity $v_{1}=-\frac{c}{2}$, which is in the $y$-direction, relative to $S$, the transformation for velocity is given by

$$
u_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{y}-v_{1}}{1-\frac{v_{1} u_{y}}{c^{2}}}, \quad u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{x}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{v_{1} u_{y}}{c^{2}}\right)},
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{y}^{\prime} &=\frac{\frac{c}{2}+\frac{c}{2}}{1+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}}=\frac{4}{5} \mathrm{c}, \\
u_{x}^{\prime} &=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4} \mathrm{c}}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\left(1+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}\right)}=\frac{\sqrt{15}}{10} \mathrm{c} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus ship (1) must aim the package at an angle $\alpha$ with the direction of ship (2) given by 

$$
\tan \alpha=\frac{u_{y}^{\prime}}{u_{x}^{\prime}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{15}}
$$

or

$$
\alpha=64.2^{\circ} \text {. }
$$

(b) The speed of the package as seen by the observer in ship (1) is

$$
u^{\prime}=\sqrt{u_{x}^{\prime 2}+u_{y}^{\prime 2}}=\sqrt{\frac{16}{25}+\frac{15}{100}} c=\sqrt{\frac{79}{100}} c=0.889 c .
$$

\section{9}

Two particles with the same mass $m$ are emitted in the same direction, with momenta $5 m c$ and $10 m c$ respectively. As seen from the slower one, what is the velocity of the faster particle, and vice verse? ( $c=$ speed of light).

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

In the laboratory frame $K_{0}$, the slower particle has momentum

$$
m \gamma_{1} v_{1}=m \gamma_{1} \beta_{1} c=5 m c
$$

giving

$$
\gamma_{1} \beta_{1}=\sqrt{\gamma_{1}^{2}-1}=5
$$

or

$$
\gamma_{1}^{2}=26
$$

Hence

$$
\beta_{1}^{2}=1-\frac{1}{26}=\frac{25}{26}, \quad \text { or } \quad v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{25}{26}} c \text {. }
$$

Similarly for the faster particle, the velocity is

$$
v_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{100}{101}} c
$$

Let $K_{1}, K_{2}$ be the rest frames of the slower and faster particles respectively. The transformation for velocity between $K_{0}$ and $K$, which moves with velocity $v$ in the $x$ direction relative to $K_{0}$, is 

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{x}-v}{1-\frac{u_{x} v}{c^{2}}} .
$$

Thus in $K_{1}$, the velocity of the faster particle is

$$
v_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{v_{2}-v_{1}}{1-\frac{u_{2} v_{1}}{c^{2}}}=\left(\frac{\sqrt{\frac{100}{101}}-\sqrt{\frac{25}{26}}}{1-\sqrt{\frac{100}{101} \cdot \frac{25}{26}}}\right) \mathrm{c}=0.595 \mathrm{c}
$$

In $K_{2}$, the velocity of the slower particle is

$$
v_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{v_{1}-v_{2}}{1-\frac{v_{1} v_{2}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}=-0.595 \mathrm{c} \text {. }
$$

\section{0}

Observer 1 sees a particle moving with velocity $v$ on a straight-line trajectory inclined at an angle $\varphi$ to his $z$-axis. Observer 2 is moving with velocity $u$ relative to observer 1 along the $z$-direction. Derive formulas for the velocity and direction of motion of the particle as by seen observer 2 . Check that you get the proper result in the limit $v \rightarrow \mathbf{c}$.

$$
\text { (UC,Berkeley) }
$$

\section{Solution:}

Let $K, K^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the observers 1 and 2 respectively with parallel axes such that the $x$-axis is in the plane of $v$ and $u$ as shown in Fig. 3.15. The transformation for velocity gives
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-703.jpg?height=268&width=816&top_left_y=1518&top_left_x=390)

Fig. 3.15. 

$$
\begin{gathered}
v_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{v_{z}-u}{1-\frac{u v_{z}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}=\frac{v \cos \varphi-u}{1-\frac{u v \cos \varphi}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}, \\
v_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{v_{x}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{u v_{z}}{c^{2}}\right)}=\frac{v \sin \varphi \sqrt{1-\frac{u^{2}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}}{1-\frac{u v \cos \varphi}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}, \quad v_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{v_{y}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{u v_{z}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}\right)}=0,
\end{gathered}
$$

with $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2}}}$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
v^{\prime} &=\sqrt{v_{z}^{\prime 2}+v_{x}^{\prime 2}} \\
&=\frac{\sqrt{v^{2}+u^{2}-2 v u \cos \varphi-\frac{u^{2} v^{2} \sin ^{2} \varphi}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}}{1-\frac{u v \cos \varphi}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}} \\
\tan \varphi^{\prime} &=\frac{v_{x}^{\prime}}{v_{z}^{\prime}}=\frac{v \sin \varphi \sqrt{1-\frac{u^{2}}{\mathrm{c}^{2}}}}{v \cos \varphi-u} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus observer 2 sees a particle moving with velocity $v^{\prime}$ on a straight-line trajectory inclined at an angle $\varphi^{\prime}$ to the $z^{\prime}$-axis.

In the limit $v \rightarrow \mathrm{c}$

$$
v^{\prime} \rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{c^{2}+u^{2}-2 c u \cos \varphi-u^{2} \sin ^{2} \varphi}}{1-\frac{u \cos \varphi}{\mathrm{c}}}=\frac{\mathrm{c}-u \cos \varphi}{1-\frac{u \cos \varphi}{\mathrm{c}}}=\mathbf{c} \text {. }
$$

This shows that $\mathrm{c}$ in any direction is transformed into $\mathrm{c}$, in agreement with the basic assumption of special relativity that $\mathrm{c}$ is the same in any direction in any inertial frame. This suggests that our answer is correct.

\section{1}

(a) A photon of energy $E_{i}$ is scattered by an electron, mass $m_{e}$, which is initially at rest, as shown in Fig. 3.16. The photon has a final energy $E_{f}$. Derive, using special relativity, a formula that relates $E_{f}$ and $E_{i}$ to $\theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle between the incident photon and the scattered photon. (b) In bubble chambers, one frequently observes the production of an electron-positron pair by a photon. Show that such a process is impossible unless some other body, for example a nucleus, is involved. Suppose that the nucleus has mass $M$ and an electron has mass $m_{e}$. What is the minimum energy that the photon must have in order to produce an electron-positron pair?

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-705.jpg?height=249&width=433&top_left_y=586&top_left_x=523)

Fig. 3.16.

Solution:

(a) The scattering is known as the Compton effect. Conservation of energy gives

$$
E_{i}+m_{e} \mathrm{c}^{2}=E_{f}+E_{e}
$$

where $E_{e}$ is the energy of the electron after scattering. Conservation of momentum gives

$$
\mathbf{P}_{i}=\mathbf{P}_{f}+\mathbf{P}_{e},
$$

where $\mathbf{P}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{f}$ are the momenta of the photon before and after scattering respectively, $\mathbf{P}_{e}$ is the momentum of the electron after scattering. We also have from the contraction of the momentum 4-vector of the electron

$$
E_{e}^{2}=m_{e}^{2} \mathrm{c}^{4}+P_{e}^{2} \mathrm{c}^{2},
$$

or

$$
\left(m_{e} \mathbf{c}^{2}+E_{i}-E_{f}\right)^{2}=m_{e}^{2} \mathbf{c}^{4}+\left(\mathbf{P}_{i}-\mathbf{P}_{f}\right)^{2} \mathbf{c}^{2} .
$$

For the photon, $E_{i}=P_{i} \mathrm{c}, E_{f}=P_{f} \mathrm{c}$, and this becomes

$$
2 m_{e} \mathrm{c}^{2}\left(E_{i}-E_{f}\right)+\left(E_{i}-E_{f}\right)^{2}=E_{i}^{2}+E_{f}^{2}-2 E_{i} E_{f} \cos \theta,
$$

or

$$
\left(\frac{1}{E_{f}}-\frac{1}{E_{i}}\right) m_{e} c^{2}=1-\cos \theta
$$

(b) Suppose the reaction $\gamma \rightarrow e^{-}+e^{+}$is possible. Then the energy and momentum of the system must be conserved in all inertial frames. Consider a frame attached to the center of mass of the created pair. In this frame, the electron and positron will move in a straight line passing through the origin away from each other with the same speed $v$ and the total momentum in zero. Conservation of momentum requires that the momentum of the original photon is also zero. However, each particle has energy $m_{e} \gamma c^{2}$, where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$, and the system has total energy $2 m_{e} \gamma c^{2}$. This must also be the energy of the original photon, by energy conservation. It follows that the original photon must have a momentum $2 m_{e} \gamma c$, contradicting the result obtained by momentum conservation. Hence the reaction is not possible.

Energy and momentum can both be conserved if another particle, say a nucleus of mass $M$, is involved. In the case the photon just has enough energy $E$ to create such a pair and $M$ is initially at rest, the pair will be created at rest, i.e.

$$
E+M c^{2}=M \gamma c^{2}+2 m_{e} c^{2}
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$ with $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, v$ being the velocity of the nucleus after the pair creation. Momentum conservation give

$$
\frac{E}{c}=M \gamma \beta \mathrm{c} \text {. }
$$

As $\gamma \beta=\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}$, this gives

$$
\gamma^{2}=1+\left(\frac{E}{M \mathrm{c}^{2}}\right)^{2}
$$

and the energy equation becomes

$$
\left(E+M c^{2}-2 m_{e} c^{2}\right)^{2}=E^{2}+M^{2} c^{4}
$$

giving

$$
E=2\left(\frac{M-m_{e}}{M-2 m_{e}}\right) m_{e} c^{2}
$$

As $M \gg m_{e}$, the minimum photon energy required is just slightly more than the rest energy of the created pair, $2 m_{e} c^{2}$.

\section{2}

(a) A cosmic ray proton collides with a stationary proton to give an excited system moving highly relativistically $(\gamma=1000)$. In this system mesons are emitted with velocity $\bar{\beta}$ c. If in the moving system a meson is emitted at an angle $\bar{\theta}$ with respect to the forward direction, at what angle $\theta$ will it be observed in the laboratory?

(b) Apply the result you obtained in (a) above to mesons (rest energy $140 \mathrm{Mev})$ emitted in the moving system with momentum $0.5 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}$. What will $\theta$ be if $\bar{\theta}$ is $90^{\circ}$ ? What will be the maximum value of $\theta$ observed in the laboratory?

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the laboratory frame and a frame attached to the center of mass of the excited system respectively with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $\beta c$ relative to $\Sigma$ in the $x$-direction. The velocity of a meson emitted in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ with velocity $\bar{\beta} c$ at angle $\bar{\theta}$ to the $x^{\prime}$-axis is transformed to $\Sigma$ as

$$
u_{x}=\frac{u_{x}^{\prime}+\beta \mathrm{c}}{1+\frac{u_{x}^{\prime} \beta}{\mathrm{c}}}=\frac{(\bar{\beta} \cos \bar{\theta}+\beta) \mathrm{c}}{1+\beta \bar{\beta} \cos \bar{\theta}}, \quad u_{y}=\frac{u_{y}^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(1+\frac{u_{x}^{\prime} \beta}{c}\right)}=\frac{\bar{\beta} c \sin \bar{\theta}}{\gamma(1+\beta \bar{\beta} \cos \bar{\theta})} .
$$

Hence the meson is emitted in $\Sigma$ at an angle $\theta$ to the $x$-axis given by

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{\bar{\beta} \sin \bar{\theta}}{\gamma(\bar{\beta} \cos \bar{\theta}+\beta)},
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma &=1000, \\
\beta &=\frac{\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}}{\gamma}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}} \approx 1-\frac{1}{2 \gamma^{2}} \\
&=1-0.5 \times 10^{-6}=0.9999995 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) If $\bar{\theta}=90^{\circ}$, the angle of emission $\theta$ in $\Sigma$ is given by

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{\bar{\beta}}{\gamma \beta}=\frac{\bar{\beta}}{\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}} .
$$

The momentum of the emitted meson is

$$
\bar{p}=m \bar{\gamma} \bar{\beta} \mathrm{c}=0.5 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \text {, }
$$

with $\bar{\gamma}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\bar{\beta}^{2}}}, m$ being the rest mass of the meson. Then

$$
\bar{\gamma} \bar{\beta}=\frac{0.5}{0.14}=3.571,
$$

or

$$
\bar{\beta}=\frac{3.571}{\bar{\gamma}}=\frac{3.571}{\sqrt{1+3.571^{2}}}=0.963
$$

since

$$
(\bar{\gamma} \bar{\beta})^{2}=\bar{\gamma}^{2}-1 .
$$

Hence

$$
\theta \approx \tan \theta=\frac{0.963}{\sqrt{10^{6}-1}}=9.63 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{rad}=5.52 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{deg}=3.31^{\prime} .
$$

The maximum value of $\theta$ is given by

$$
\frac{d \tan \theta}{d \dot{\theta}}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
(\bar{\beta} \cos \bar{\theta}+\beta) \cos \bar{\theta}+\bar{\beta} \sin ^{2} \bar{\theta}=0,
$$

or by

$$
\cos \bar{\theta}=-\frac{\bar{\beta}}{\beta} .
$$

Hence

$$
\bar{\theta}=\arccos \left(-\frac{0.963}{0.9999995}\right)=164.4^{\circ},
$$

which gives

$$
\theta=\arctan \left[\frac{0.963 \times \sin 164.4^{\circ}}{1000 \times\left(0.963 \cos 164.4^{\circ}+0.9999995\right)}\right]=0.205^{\circ}=12.3^{\prime} .
$$

This is obviously the maximum angle observed in the laboratory since the minimum angle is $0^{\circ}$ for $\bar{\theta}=0^{\circ}$ and $\bar{\theta}=180^{\circ}$.

\section{3}

(a) Calculate the momentum of pions $(\pi)$ that have the same velocity as protons having momentum $400 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}$. This is the most probable momentum that the produced pions have when $400 \mathrm{GeV} / c$ protons strike the target at Fermilab. The pion rest mass is $0.14 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$. The proton rest mass is $0.94 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.

(b) These pions then travel down a decay ppe of $400 \mathrm{~m}$ length where some of them decay to produce the neutrino beam for the neutrino detector located more than $1 \mathrm{~km}$ away as shown in Fig. 3.17. What fraction of the pions decay in the $400 \mathrm{~m}$ ? The pions' proper mean lifetime is $2.6 \times 10^{-8}$ sec.

(c) What is the length of the decay pipe as measured by observers in the pion rest frame?

(d) The pion $(\pi)$ decays into a muon $(\mu)$ and a neutrino $(\nu)$. (The neutrino has zero rest mass.) Using the relationship between total relativistic energy and momentum show that the magnitude of the decay fragments' momentum in the pion rest frame, $q$, is given by

$$
\frac{q}{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{M^{2}-m^{2}}{2 M},
$$

where $M$ is the pion rest mass and $m$ is the muon rest mass.

(e) The neutrino detectors are, on the average, approximately $1.2 \mathrm{~km}$ from the point where the pions decay. How large should the transverse dimension (radius) of the detectors be in order to have a chance of detecting all the neutrinos that are produced in the forward hemisphere in the pion rest frame?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The momentum of a particle of rest mass $m$ and velocity $\beta c$ is

$$
p=m \gamma \beta \mathrm{c},
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. For the same velocity $\frac{p}{m}$ is a constant. Hence the pion momentum is 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-710.jpg?height=277&width=1134&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=177)

Fig. 3.17.

$$
p_{\pi}=\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{m_{p}}\right) p_{p}=\frac{0.14}{0.94} \times 400=59.6 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \text {. }
$$

(b) Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the laboratory frame and the rest frame of the pions respectively. As

$$
\Delta t=\gamma\left(\Delta t^{\prime}+\frac{\beta \Delta x^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\gamma \Delta t^{\prime},
$$

the laboratory lifetime $\tau$ of the pions is equal to $\gamma \tau_{0}$; where $\tau_{0}$ is the proper lifetime of the pions and $\gamma$ its Lorentz factor in $\Sigma$. If $n$ is the number of pions in the beam, we have

$$
-\frac{d n}{n}=\frac{d t}{\tau}
$$

or

$$
n=n_{0} \exp \left(-\frac{t}{\tau}\right),
$$

$n_{0}$ being the number of pions at $t=0$. For a pion of momentum $59.6 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}$,

$$
\gamma \beta=\frac{59.6}{0.14}=425.5 \text {, }
$$

and

$$
\frac{t}{\tau}=\frac{l}{\gamma \beta \mathrm{c} \tau_{0}}=\frac{400}{425.5 \times 3 \times 10^{8} \times 2.6 \times 10^{-8}}=0.1205 .
$$

Hence the fraction of pions that decays in the pipe is

$$
1-e^{-0.1205}=0.1135=11.35 \% .
$$

(c) The length of the decay pipe in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is by definition $l^{\prime}=x_{2}^{\prime}-x_{1}^{\prime}$, where $x_{1}^{\prime}, x_{2}^{\prime}$ are the coordinates of its two ends taken at the same instant $t^{\prime}$. As

$$
x_{1}=\gamma\left(x_{1}^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right), \quad x_{2}=\gamma\left(x_{2}^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right),
$$

we have

$$
x_{2}-x_{1}=\gamma\left(x_{2}^{\prime}-x_{1}^{\prime}\right)
$$

or

$$
l=\gamma l^{\prime},
$$

i.e.

$$
l^{\prime}=\frac{l}{\gamma}=\frac{400}{\gamma} \approx \frac{400}{\gamma \beta}=\frac{400}{425.5}=0.94 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

(d) The energy of a particle of rest mass $m$, momentum $p$, velocity $\beta \mathrm{c}$, Lorentz factor $\gamma$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=m \gamma c^{2}=m c^{2} \sqrt{\gamma^{2} \beta^{2}+1}=\sqrt{m^{2} c^{4} \gamma^{2} \beta^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}} \\
&=\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

since $p=m \gamma \beta c$. Consider the decay $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$ in the rest frame of the pion. As the momentum is initially zero, the momenta of the $\mu$ and $\nu$ must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, $\left|\mathbf{p}_{\mu}\right|=\left|\mathbf{p}_{\nu}\right|=q$. Energy conservation gives

$$
M c^{2}=\sqrt{q^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}}+q c,
$$

use having been of the fact that the pion is at rest in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and that the neutrino has zero rest mass, which in turn yields

$$
q=\left(\frac{M^{2}-m^{2}}{2 M}\right) c .
$$

(e) A neutrino emitted with velocity $\beta^{\prime} c$ at angle $\theta^{\prime}$ to the $x^{\prime}$-axis in the rest frame of the pion, $\Sigma^{\prime}$, is observed to move in a direction at angle $\theta$ to the $x$-axis in the laboratory frame $\Sigma$, where $\theta$ is given by (Problem 3022)

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{\beta^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(\beta^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\beta\right)}=\frac{\sin \theta^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(\cos \theta^{\prime}+\beta\right)},
$$

as the neutrino, having zero rest mass, must always move with velocity $c$. For $\theta^{\prime} \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$

$$
\tan \theta \leq \frac{1}{\gamma\left(\cos \theta^{\prime}+\beta\right)} \leq \frac{1}{\gamma \beta}=\frac{1}{425.5} .
$$

Hence $\theta \leq 2.35 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{rad}$. For a detector at $1.2 \mathrm{~km}$ away to detect all the neutrinos with $\theta^{\prime} \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$, it must have a transverse dimension

$$
R=1.2 \times 10^{3} \times 2.35 \times 10^{-3}=2.82 \mathrm{~m} .
$$



\section{4}

In a simplified model of a relativistic nucleus-nucleus collision, a nucleus of rest mass $m_{1}$ and speed $\beta_{1}$ collides head-on with a target nucleus of mass $m_{2}$ at rest. The composite system recoils at speed $\beta_{0}$ and with center of mass energy $\varepsilon_{0}$. Assume no new particles are created.

(a) Derive relativistically correct relations for $\beta_{0}$ and $\varepsilon_{0}$.

(b) Calculate $\beta_{0}$ and $\varepsilon_{0}$ (in $\mathrm{MeV}$ ) for a ${ }^{40} \mathrm{Ar}$ nucleus impinging at $\beta_{1}=0.8$ on a ${ }^{238} \mathrm{U}$ nucleus.

(c) A proton is emitted with $\beta_{c}=0.2$ at $\theta_{c}=60^{\circ}$ to the forward direction in the frame of the recoiling Ar $+U$ system. Find its laboratory speed $\beta_{l}$ and laboratory direction $\theta_{l}$ to within a few percent, making nonrelativistic approximations if they are warranted.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

As implied by the question the velocity of light is taken to be one for convenience.

(a) For a system, $E^{2}-p^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation. In the laboratory frame $\Sigma$, writing $\gamma_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}$,

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}\right)^{2} .
$$

In the center of mass frame $\Sigma^{\prime}, E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2}=\varepsilon_{0}^{2}$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon_{0}^{2} &=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}\right)^{2} \\
&=m_{1}^{2} \gamma_{1}^{2}\left(1-\beta_{1}^{2}\right)+2 m_{1} m_{2} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}^{2} \\
&=m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+2 m_{1} m_{2} \gamma_{1},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\varepsilon_{0}=\sqrt{m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+\frac{2 m_{1} m_{2}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}} .
$$

In the laboratory, the system of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ has total momentum $m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}$ and total energy $m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}$. These are conserved quantities so that after the collision the composite system will move with velocity

$$
\beta_{0}=\frac{m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{m_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2} \sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}} .
$$

(b) The masses are approximately

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m_{1}=40 \times 0.94=37.6 \mathrm{GeV}, \\
&m_{2}=238 \times 0.94=223.7 \mathrm{GeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon_{0} &=\sqrt{37.6^{2}+223.7^{2}+\frac{2 \times 37.6 \times 223.7}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}} \\
&=282 \mathrm{GeV}=2.82 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MeV}, \\
\beta_{0} &=\frac{37.6 \times 0.8}{37.6+223.7 \times \sqrt{1-0.64}}=0.175
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) The velocity components are transformed according to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\beta_{l x}=\frac{\beta_{c x}+\beta_{0}}{1+\beta_{c x} \beta_{0}}=\frac{0.2 \cos 60^{\circ}+0.175}{1+0.2 \cos 60^{\circ} \times 0.175}=0.270, \\
&\beta_{l y}=\frac{\beta_{c y} \sqrt{1-\beta_{0}^{2}}}{1+\beta_{c x} \beta_{0}}=\frac{0.2 \sin 60^{\circ} \sqrt{1-0.175^{2}}}{1+0.2 \cos 60^{\circ} \times 0.175}=0.168,
\end{aligned}
$$

so the laboratory speed and direction of emission are respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
\beta_{l}=\sqrt{0.27^{2}+0.168^{2}}=0.318, \\
\theta_{l}=\arctan \left(\frac{0.168}{0.27}\right)=31.9^{\circ} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Note that as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{1}{1+\beta_{c x} \beta_{0}}=\frac{1}{1+0.1 \times 0.175}=0.983, \\
&\frac{\sqrt{1-\beta_{0}^{2}}}{1+\beta_{c x} \beta_{0}}=\frac{\sqrt{1-0.175^{2}}}{1+0.1 \times 0.175}=0.968,
\end{aligned}
$$

both differing from 1 by less than $4 \%$, applying nonrelativistic approximations we can still achieve an accuracy of more than $96 \%$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{l x} & \approx \beta_{c x}+\beta_{0}=0.275, \\
\beta_{l y} &=\beta_{c y}=0.173, \\
\theta_{l} &=\arctan \left(\frac{0.173}{0.275}\right)=32.2^{\circ} .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{5}

In high energy proton-proton collisions, one or both protons may "diffractively dissociate" into a system of a proton and several charged pions. The reactions are

(1) $p+p \rightarrow p+(p+n \pi)$,

(2) $p+p \rightarrow(p+n \pi)+(p+m \pi)$.

Here $n$ and $m$ count the number of produced pions.

In the laboratory frame, an incident proton of total energy $E$ (the projectile) strikes a proton at rest (the target). Find the incident proton energy $E_{0}$ that is

(a) the ninimum energy for reaction (1) to take place when the target dissociates into a proton and 4 pions,

(b) the minimum energy for reaction (1) to take place when the projectile dissociates into a proton and 4 pions,

(c) the minimum energy for reaction (2) to take place when both protons dissociate into a proton and 4 pions.

$$
m_{\pi}=0.140 \mathrm{GeV}, \quad m_{p}=0.938 \mathrm{GeV} .
$$

\section{Solution:}

The quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$ for a system, where we have taken $c=1$ for convenience, is invariant under Lorentz transformation. If the system undergoes a nuclear reaction that conserves energy and momentum, the quantity will also remain the same after the reaction. In particular for a particle of rest mass $m$,

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=m^{2} .
$$

(a) The energy for the reaction

$$
p+p \rightarrow p+(p+4 \pi)
$$

is minimum when all the final particles are at rest in an inertial frame, particularly the center of mass frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$. Then in the laboratory frame $\Sigma$,

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=\left(E_{0}+m_{p}\right)^{2}-\left(E_{0}^{2}-m_{p}^{2}\right)=2 m_{p} E_{0}+2 m_{p}^{2},
$$

and in $\Sigma^{\prime}$,

$$
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2}=\left(2 m_{p}+4 m_{\pi}\right)^{2}
$$

so that

$$
2 m_{p} E_{0}=2 m_{p}^{2}+16 m_{p} m_{\pi}+16 m_{\pi}^{2}
$$

giving

$$
E_{0}=\frac{m_{p}^{2}+8 m_{p} m_{\pi}+8 m_{\pi}^{2}}{m_{p}}=2.225 \mathrm{GeV}
$$

as the minimum energy the incident proton must have to cause the reaction.

(b) Since both the initial particles are protons and the final state particles are the same as before, the minimum energy remains the same, $2.225 \mathrm{GeV}$.

(c) For the reaction

$$
p+p \rightarrow(p+4 \pi)+(p+4 \pi)
$$

we have

$$
\left(E_{0}+m_{p}\right)^{2}-\left(E_{0}^{2}-m_{p}^{2}\right)=\left(2 m_{p}+8 m_{\pi}\right)^{2},
$$

giving the minimum incident energy as

$$
E_{0}=\frac{m_{p}^{2}+16 m_{p} m_{\pi}+32 m_{\pi}^{2}}{m_{p}}=3.847 \mathrm{GeV} .
$$

\section{6}

Consider the elastic scattering of two spinless particles with masses $m$ and $\mu$ as shown in Fig. 3.18. The Lorentz-invariant scattering amplitude (S-matrix element) may be considered as a function of the two invariant variables

$$
s=\left(K_{0}+P_{0}\right)^{2}-(\mathbf{K}+\mathbf{P})^{2}
$$

and

$$
t=\left(K_{0}^{\prime}-K_{0}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{K}^{\prime}-\mathbf{K}\right)^{2}
$$

with $K^{2}=K^{\prime 2}=\mu^{2}$ and $P^{2}=P^{\prime 2}=m^{2}$. Obtain the physical (i.e. allowed) region in the $(s, t)$ manifold. Compute the boundary curve $t(s)$ and make a quelitative drawing.

(Chicago) 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-716.jpg?height=307&width=319&top_left_y=232&top_left_x=628)

Fig. 3.18.

\section{Solution:}

In the elastic scattering

$$
k+p \rightarrow k^{\prime}+p^{\prime},
$$

if the system is isolated, the total energy-momentum 4-vector is conserved:

$$
K+P=K^{\prime}+P^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

In the center of mass frame of the system, the total momentum is zero:

$$
\mathbf{K}^{\prime}+\mathbf{P}^{\prime}=\mathbf{K}+\mathbf{P}=0 \text {. }
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
s &=\left(K_{0}+P_{0}\right)^{2}-(\mathbf{K}+\mathbf{P})^{2}=\left(K_{0}+P_{0}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(\sqrt{\mathbf{K}^{2}+\mu^{2}}+\sqrt{\mathbf{P}^{2}+m^{2}}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(\sqrt{\mathbf{K}^{2}+\mu^{2}}+\sqrt{\mathbf{K}^{2}+m^{2}}\right)^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{P}^{2}=\mathbf{K}^{2}$ in the center of mass frame, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
t &=\left(K_{0}^{\prime}-K_{0}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{K}^{\prime}-\mathbf{K}\right)^{2} \\
&=-\left(\mathbf{K}^{\prime}-\mathbf{K}\right)^{2} \\
&=-\left(\mathbf{K}^{\prime 2}+\mathbf{K}^{2}-2 \mathbf{K}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{K}\right) \\
&=-2 \mathbf{K}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle of scattering of $k$, as the scattering is elastic.

To find the physical region in the $(s, t)$ manifold, consider $\cos \theta$, where $\theta$ varies from 0 to $\pi$ : 

$$
\begin{array}{llrl}
\theta & =0, & & \cos \theta=1, \quad t=0 ; \\
\theta & =\pi, & \cos \theta=-1, & t=-4 \mathbf{K}^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Hence the physical region is given by

$$
t \leq 0 \quad \text { and } \quad s \geq\left(\sqrt{\mu^{2}-\frac{t}{4}}+\sqrt{m^{2}-\frac{t}{4}}\right)^{2},
$$

the boundaries being $t=0$ and that given by

$$
s=\left(\sqrt{\mu^{2}-\frac{t}{4}}+\sqrt{m^{2}-\frac{t}{4}}\right)^{2}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
t &=\frac{4 m^{2} \mu^{2}-\left(s-m^{2}-\mu^{2}\right)^{2}}{s} \\
&=-\frac{1}{s}\left[s-(m+\mu)^{2}\right]\left[s-(m-\mu)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The physical region is shown as shaded area in Fig. 3.19.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-717.jpg?height=223&width=430&top_left_y=1140&top_left_x=512)

Fig. 3.19.

\section{7}

Consider the pion photoproduction reaction

$$
\gamma+p \rightarrow p+\pi^{\circ}
$$

where the rest energy is $938 \mathrm{MeV}$ for the proton and $135 \mathrm{MeV}$ for the neutral pion. (a) If the initial proton is at rest in the laboratory, find the laboratory threshold gamma-ray energy for this reaction to "go".

(b) The isotropic $3 K$ cosmic blackbody radiation has an average photon energy of about $10^{-3} \mathrm{eV}$. Consider a head-on collision between a proton and a photon of energy $10^{-3} \mathrm{eV}$. Find the minimum proton energy that will allow this pion photoproduction reaction to go.

(c) Speculate briefly on the implications of your result [for part (b)] for the energy spectrum of cosmic-ray protons.

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation and for an isolated system is the same before and after a reaction. The threshold $\gamma$-ray energy is that for which the final state particles are all at rest in the center of mass frame. Thus

$$
\left(E_{\gamma}+m_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{E_{\gamma}}{c}\right)^{2} c^{2}=\left(m_{p}+m_{\pi}\right)^{2} c^{4}
$$

where $E_{\gamma}$ is the energy of the photon and $\frac{E_{\gamma}}{c}$ its momentum, giving

$$
E_{\gamma}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}+2 m_{\pi} m_{p}\right) c^{4}}{2 m_{p} c^{2}}=144.7 \mathrm{MeV}
$$

as the threshold $\gamma$-ray energy.

(b) That the proton collides head-on with the photon means that their momenta are opposite in direction. Then

$$
\left(m_{p} \gamma c^{2}+E_{\gamma}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{p} \gamma \beta c-\frac{E_{\gamma}}{c}\right)^{2} c^{2}=\left(m_{p}+m_{\pi}\right)^{2} c^{4}
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}, \beta c$ being the velocity of a proton with the minimum energy to initiate the photoproduction reaction, giving

$$
\gamma(1+\beta)=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}+2 m_{\pi} m_{p}\right) c^{4}}{2 E_{\gamma} m_{p} c^{2}}=1.447 \times 10^{11}
$$

with $E_{\gamma}=10^{-9} \mathrm{MeV}$. As this implies $\gamma \gg 1$, we can take $\beta=1$. Hence $\gamma=7.235 \times 10^{10}$ and the minimum proton energy is

$$
E_{p}=0.938 \times 7.235 \times 10^{10}=6.787 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{GeV} .
$$

(c) The result implies that the part of the energy spectrum of cosmic-ray protons with $E>6.79 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{GeV}$ will be depleted to some degree due to interaction with the cosmic blackbody radiation.

\section{8}

A beam of $10^{6} K_{l}^{\circ}$ mesons per second with $\beta \equiv \frac{v}{c}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ is observed to interact with a lead brick according to the reaction

$$
K_{l}^{\circ}+\text { Brick } \rightarrow K_{s}^{\circ}+\text { Brick }
$$

with the internal state of the lead brick identical before and after the reaction. The directions of motion of the incoming $K_{l}^{\circ}$ and outgoing $K_{s}^{\circ}$ may also be considered to be identical. (This is called coherent regeneration.)

Using

$$
\begin{aligned}
m\left(K_{l}\right) &=5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{eV} / \mathrm{c}^{2} \\
m\left(K_{l}\right)-m\left(K_{s}\right) &=3.5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{eV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

give the magnitude and direction of the average force (either in dynes or in newtons) exerted on the brick by this process.

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Denote $m\left(K_{l}\right), m\left(K_{s}\right)$ by $m_{l}, m_{s}$ respectively. For an incoming $K_{l}$ meson, the energy and momentum are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{l}=m_{l} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{m_{l} c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{2}}}=\sqrt{2} m_{l} c^{2}, \\
&P_{l}=m_{l} \gamma \beta c=\sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} m_{l} c=m_{l} c .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the internal state of the lead brick remains the same after the reaction, the energies of the beam before and after the reaction must also be the same. Thus

$$
E_{l}=E_{s} .
$$

As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{s}^{2} c^{2} &=E_{s}^{2}-m_{s}^{2} c^{4} \\
&=E_{l}^{2}-m_{s}^{2} c^{4}=2 m_{l}^{2} c^{4}-\left[m_{l}-\left(m_{l}-m_{s}\right)\right]^{2} c^{4} \\
& \approx m_{l}^{2} c^{4}+2 m_{l}\left(m_{l}-m_{s}\right) c^{4},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
P_{s} c \approx m_{l} c^{2}+\left(m_{l}-m_{s}\right) c^{2}=P_{l} c+\left(m_{l}-m_{s}\right) c^{2},
$$

as $m_{l}-m_{s} \ll m_{l}$. Hence

$$
\left(P_{s}-P_{l}\right) \approx\left(m_{l}-m_{s}\right) c=3.5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{eV} / \mathrm{c} .
$$

The change of momentum per second of the beam due to the reaction is

$$
\left(P_{s}-P_{l}\right) \times 10^{6}=3.5 \mathrm{eV} / \mathrm{c} / \mathrm{s}=\frac{3.5 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{3 \times 10^{8}}=1.87 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~N} \text {. }
$$

This is the average force exerted by the brick on the beam. As the momentum of the beam becomes larger after the interaction, this force is in the direction of the beam. Consequently the force exerted by the beam on the brick is opposite to the beam and has a magnitude $1.87 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~N}$.

\section{9}

A $\pi$ meson with a momentum of $5 m_{\pi} \mathrm{c}$ makes an elastic collision with a proton $\left(m_{p}=7 m_{\pi}\right)$ which is initially at rest (Fig. 3.20).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-720.jpg?height=219&width=322&top_left_y=1363&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 3.20.

(a) What is the velocity of the c.m. reference frame?

(b) What is the total energy in c.m. system?

(c) Find the momentum of the incident pion in the c.m. system.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$ 

\section{Solution:}

(a) The system has total momentum $P=p_{\pi}=5 m_{\pi} c$ and total energy

$$
E=\sqrt{p_{\pi}^{2}+m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}}+m_{p} c^{2}=\sqrt{26} m_{\pi} c^{2}+7 m_{\pi} c^{2} .
$$

Hence it moves with a velocity $\bar{v}$, which is also the velocity of the c.m. system, in the laboratory given by

$$
\bar{v}=\frac{P c^{2}}{E}=\frac{5 c}{\sqrt{26}+7}=0.413 c .
$$

(b) $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation, so the total energy $E^{\prime}$ in the c.m. frame is given by

$$
E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

as the total momentum in the c.m frame is by definition zero. Hence

$$
E^{\prime 2}=(\sqrt{26}+7)^{2} m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}-25 m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}=(14 \sqrt{26}+50) m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}
$$

or

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{14 \sqrt{26}+50} m_{\pi} c^{2}=11.02 m_{\pi} c^{2} .
$$

(c) The total energy in the c.m. frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime} &=\sqrt{p_{\pi}^{\prime 2}+m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}}+\sqrt{p_{p}^{\prime 2}+m_{p}^{2} c^{4}} \\
&=\sqrt{p_{\pi}^{\prime 2}+m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}}+\sqrt{p_{\pi}^{\prime 2}+49 m_{\pi}^{2} c^{4}}
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\left|\mathbf{p}_{p}^{\prime}\right|=\left|\mathbf{p}_{\pi}^{\prime}\right|$ in the c.m. frame and $m_{p}=7 m_{\pi}$. From (b) we have $E^{\prime}=\sqrt{50+14 \sqrt{26}} m_{\pi} c^{2}$. Substituting this in the above and solving for $p_{\pi}^{\prime}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}^{\prime}=\frac{35 m_{\pi} \mathbf{c}}{\sqrt{50+14 \sqrt{26}}}=3.18 m_{\pi} \mathbf{c}
$$

\section{0}

High-energy neutrino beams at Fermi laboratory are made by first forming a monoenergetic $\pi^{+}$(or $K^{+}$) beam and then allowing the pions to decay by $\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+}+\nu$. Recall that the mass of the pion is $140 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ and the mass of the muon is $106 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.

(a) Find the energy of the decay neutrino in the rest frame of the $\pi^{+}$.

In laboratory frame, the energy of the neutrino depends on the decay angle $\theta$ (Fig. 3.21). Suppose the $\pi^{+}$beam has an energy of $200 \mathrm{GeV}$.

(b) Find the energy of a neutrino produced in the forward direction $(\theta=0)$

(c) Find the angle $\theta$ at which the neutrino's energy has fallen to half of its maximum energy.

(Chicago)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-722.jpg?height=149&width=285&top_left_y=766&top_left_x=628)

Fig. 3.21.

\section{Solution:}

(a) For convenience use units such that $c=1(m, E, p$ are all in $\mathrm{MeV})$. Consider the Lorentz-invariant and conserved quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$. In laboratory frame, before the decay

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=E_{\pi}^{2}-p_{\pi}^{2}=m_{\pi}^{2} .
$$

In the rest frame of the pion, after the decay

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2} &=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}+\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}} \\
&=2 p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$, and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}$ assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Equating the above two expressions gives

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=29.9 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

(b) In the laboratory frame (Fig. 3.21), momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{\pi}=p_{\nu} \cos \theta+p_{\mu} \cos \alpha, \quad p_{\nu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu} \sin \alpha,
$$

or

$$
p_{\mu}^{2}=p_{\pi}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{2}-2 p_{\pi} p_{\nu} \cos \theta,
$$

and energy conservation gives

$$
E_{\pi}=E_{\nu}+E_{\mu} .
$$

As $p_{\nu}=E_{\nu}, p_{\mu}^{2}=E_{\mu}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}$, the last two equations give

$$
p_{\nu}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2\left(E_{\pi}-p_{\pi} \cos \theta\right)} .
$$

As $E_{\pi} \gg m_{\pi}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}=E_{\pi} \sqrt{1-\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}}{E_{\pi}^{2}}} \approx E_{\pi}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

and hence

$$
E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)+m_{\pi}^{2} \cos \theta} .
$$

For neutrinos emitted in the forward direction, $\theta=0$ and

$$
E_{\nu} \approx\left[1-\left(\frac{m_{\mu}}{m_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] E_{\pi}=85.4 \mathrm{GeV} \text {. }
$$

(c) As

$$
E_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-\left(2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right) \cos \theta},
$$

$E_{\nu}$ is maximum for neutrinos emitted at $\theta=0$. For $E_{\nu}$ at half the maximum value, i.e.

$$
\left(\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{m_{\pi}^{2}}\right) \frac{E_{\pi}}{2}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-E_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-\left(2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right) \cos \theta},
$$

we have

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{2\left(E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right)}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}} \approx 1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2} \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2}
$$

as $\theta$ is obviously small. Hence

$$
\theta=\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}=0.0007 \mathrm{rad}=2.4^{\prime} .
$$

\section{1}

(a) A particle of mass $m_{1}=1 \mathrm{~g}$ traveling at $0.9$ times the speed of light collides head-on with a stationary particle of mass $m_{2}=10 \mathrm{~g}$ and is embedded in it. What is the rest mass and velocity of the resulting composite particle?

(b) Now suppose $m_{1}$ to be stationary. How fast should $m_{2}$ be moving in order to produce a composite with the same rest mass as in part (a)?

(c) Again, if $m_{1}$ is stationary, how fast should $m_{2}$ be traveling in order to produce a composite that will have the same velocity that you found for the composite in part (a)?

(SUNY, Buffalo )

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let the composite have mass $m$ and velocity $\beta c$. Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
m \gamma c^{2}=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right) c^{2}, \quad m \gamma \beta c=m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1} c .
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$, etc. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\frac{m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{m_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2} \sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}=\frac{0.9}{1+10 \sqrt{1-0.9^{2}}}=0.168, \\
m^{2} &=(m \gamma)^{2}-(m \gamma \beta)^{2}=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}\right)^{2} \\
&=m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+2 \gamma_{1} m_{1} m_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $(\gamma \beta)^{2}=\gamma^{2}-1$, etc., or

$$
m=\sqrt{m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+\frac{2 m_{1} m_{2}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}}=\sqrt{1+100+\frac{20}{\sqrt{1-0.9^{2}}}}=12.1 \mathrm{~g} .
$$

Thus the composite has rest mass $12.1 \mathrm{~g}$ and velocity $0.168 \mathrm{c}$. (b) The roles of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are now interchanged so that

$$
m=\sqrt{m_{2}^{2}+m_{1}^{2}+\frac{2 m_{2} m_{1}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{2}}}},
$$

which is the same expression as before with $\beta_{1} \rightarrow \beta_{2}$. Then as $m_{1}, m_{2}, m$ remain the same, $\beta_{2}$ must have the value of $\beta_{1}$ before, that is, $m_{2}$ must move with velocity $0.9 \mathrm{c}$.

(c) As in (b), we have

$$
\beta=\frac{m_{2} \beta_{2}}{m_{2}+m_{1} \sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{2}}},
$$

or

$$
\left(m_{2}^{2}+m_{1}^{2} \beta^{2}\right) \beta_{2}^{2}-2 m_{2}^{2} \beta \beta_{2}+\left(m_{2}^{2}-m_{1}^{2}\right) \beta^{2}=0 .
$$

As $m_{2}^{2} \gg m_{1}^{2} \beta^{2}$, the above can be reduced to

$$
m_{2}^{2} \beta_{2}^{2}-2 m_{2}^{2} \beta \beta_{2}+\left(m_{2}^{2}-m_{1}^{2}\right) \beta^{2}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\left[m_{2} \beta_{2}-\left(m_{2}+m_{1}\right) \beta\right]\left[m_{2} \beta_{2}-\left(m_{2}-m_{1}\right) \beta\right]=0,
$$

giving

$$
\beta_{2}=\left(1+\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right) \beta=0.185, \quad \beta=\left(1-\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\right) \beta=0.151 .
$$

Hence $m_{2}$ should travel at $0.185 \mathrm{c}$ or $0.151 \mathrm{c}$.

\section{2}

A particle with mass $m$ and total energy $E_{0}$ travels at a constant velocity $\mathbf{V}$ which may approach the speed of light. It then collides with a stationary particle with the same mass $m$, and they are seen to scatter elastically at the relative angle $\theta$ with equal kinetic energies.

(a) Determine $\theta$, relating it to $m$ and $E_{0}$.

(b) Find the numerical value of $\theta$ in the following limits:

(i) low energy $(V \ll c)$,

(ii) high energy $(V \sim c)$. 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As the elastically scattered particles have the same mass and the same kinetic energy, their momenta must make the same angle $\frac{\theta}{2}$ with the incident direction and have the same magnitude. Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
m c^{2}+E_{0}=2 E, \quad p_{0}=2 p \cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right),
$$

where $E, p$ are the energy and momentum of each scattered particle. Squaring both sides of the energy equation we have

$$
m^{2} c^{4}+E_{0}^{2}+2 E_{0} m c^{2}=4\left(p^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}\right),
$$

or

$$
E_{0}^{2}+2 E_{0} m c^{2}-3 m^{2} c^{4}=\frac{p_{0}^{2} c^{2}}{\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)}=\frac{E_{0}^{2}-m^{2} c^{4}}{\cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)},
$$

giving

$$
\cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{E_{0}^{2}-m^{2} c^{4}}{\left(E_{0}-m c^{2}\right)\left(E_{0}+3 m c^{2}\right)}}=\sqrt{\frac{E_{0}+m c^{2}}{E_{0}+3 m c^{2}}} .
$$

(b) (i) $V \ll c, E_{0} \approx m c^{2}$,

$$
\cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \simeq \sqrt{\frac{2}{4}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\theta \approx \frac{\pi}{2} .
$$

(ii) $V \rightarrow c, E_{0} \gg m c^{2}$,

$$
\cos \left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right) \approx 1 \text {, }
$$

giving $\theta \approx 0$.

\section{3}

Of particular interest in particle physics at present are weak interactions at high energies. These can be investigated by studying high-energy neutrino interactions. One can produce neutrino beams by letting $\pi$ and $K$ mesons decay in flight. Suppose a $200 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \pi$ meson beam is used to produce neutrinos via the decay $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$. The lifetime of a $\pi$ meson is $\tau_{\pi^{\pm}}=2.60 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~s}$ in its rest frame, and its rest energy is $139.6 \mathrm{MeV}$. The rest energy of the muon is $105.7 \mathrm{MeV}$, and the neutrino is massless.

(a) Calculate the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay.

(b) Calculate the maximum angle of the muons (relative to the pion direction) in the laboratory.

(c) Calculate the minimum and maximum momenta the neutrinos can have.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $m$ be the rest mass of a pion. As $m \gamma \beta c^{2}=200 \mathrm{GeV}$, we have

$$
\gamma \beta=\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}=\frac{200}{0.1396}=1432.7
$$

and can take

$$
\beta \approx 1, \quad \gamma=1433 .
$$

On account of time dilation, the laboratory lifetime of a pion is $\tau=\gamma \tau_{\pi}=$ $1433 \times 2.6 \times 10^{-8}=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$. So the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay is

$$
\tau c=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \times 3 \times 10^{8}=1.12 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~m}=11.2 \mathrm{~km} \text {. }
$$

(b) The total energy of the system in the rest frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ of the pion is its rest energy $m_{\pi} c^{2}$. Conservation of energy requires that for $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$,

$$
m_{\pi} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime},
$$

the prime being used to denote quantities in the $\Sigma^{\prime}$ frame. As the total momentum is zero in $\Sigma^{\prime}, \mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$ and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime} c=p_{\mu}^{\prime} c$, assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Thus

$$
\left(m_{\pi} c^{2}-E_{\mu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\nu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}
$$

giving

$$
E_{\mu}^{\prime}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2}\right) c^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=109.8 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

Take the $x^{\prime}$-axis along the direction of motion of the pion. Transformation equations for the muon momentum are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&p_{\mu} \cos \theta=\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right) \\
&p_{\mu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right)} .
$$

For $\theta$ to be maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d \tan \theta}{d \theta^{\prime}}=0,
$$

which gives

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}} \approx-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-\frac{\sqrt{E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-0.271
$$

or $\theta^{\prime}=105.7^{\circ}$. This in turn gives

$$
\theta=0.0112^{\circ}=0.675^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

Note that this is the maximum angle of emission in the laboratory since the minimum angle is 0 , corresponding to $\theta^{\prime}=0$.

(c) The neutrino has energy

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=m_{\pi} c^{2}-E_{\mu}^{\prime}=139.6-109.8=29.8 \mathrm{MeV}
$$

and momentum $p_{\nu}^{\prime}=29.8 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}$ in $\Sigma^{\prime} . E_{\nu}^{\prime}$ can be transformed to the $\Sigma$ frame by

$$
E_{\nu}=\gamma\left(E_{\nu}^{\prime}+\beta p_{\nu}^{\prime} c \cos \theta^{\prime}\right) .
$$

As $E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} c, E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime} c$, the above can be written as

$$
p_{\nu}=\gamma\left(1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}\right) p_{\nu}^{\prime} .
$$

Hence neutrinos emitted in the forward direction of the pion rest frame, i.e. $\theta^{\prime}=0$, will have the largest momentum in the laboratory of

$$
\left(p_{\nu}\right)_{\max }=\gamma(1+\beta) p_{\nu}^{\prime} \approx \frac{2 \gamma E_{\nu}^{\prime}}{c}=8.54 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{MeV} / c
$$

while neutrinos emitted backward in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ will have the smallest momentum in the laboratory of

$$
\left(p_{\nu}\right)_{\min }=\gamma(1-\beta) p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\left(\gamma-\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}\right) p_{\nu}^{\prime} \approx \frac{1}{2 \gamma} \frac{E_{\nu}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}=1.04 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{MeV} / c
$$

\section{4}

A $K$ meson of rest energy $494 \mathrm{MeV}$ decays into a $\mu$ meson of rest energy $106 \mathrm{MeV}$ and a neutrino of zero rest energy. Find the kinetic energies of the $\mu$ meson and neutrino into which the $K$ meson decays while at rest.

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Conservation of energy gives

$$
m_{K} c^{2}=E_{\mu}+E_{\nu}=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}+p_{\nu} c=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}+p_{\mu} c
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}$, or $p_{\mu}=p_{\nu}$, for momentum conservation. Hence

$$
p_{\mu}=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\nu} &=p_{\nu} c=p_{\mu} c=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c^{2} \\
&=235.6 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
E_{\mu} &=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c^{2} \\
&=258.4 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the kinetic energy of the neutrino is $235.6 \mathrm{MeV}$, and that of the muon is $258.4-106=152.4 \mathrm{MeV}$. 

\section{5}

The dot product of two four-vectors

$$
A^{\mu}=\left(A^{\circ}, \mathbf{A}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad B^{\mu}=\left(B^{\circ}, \mathbf{B}\right)
$$

is here defined as

$$
A^{\mu} B_{\mu}=A^{\circ} B^{\circ}-\mathbf{A} \cdot \mathbf{B} \text {. }
$$

Consider the reaction shown in Fig. $3.22$ in which particles of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are incident and particles of masses $m_{3}$ and $m_{4}$ emerge. The $p$ 's and $q$ 's are their four momenta. The variables given below are commonly used to describe such a reaction:

$$
s=\left(q_{1}+p_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad t=\left(q_{1}-q_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad u=\left(q_{1}-p_{2}\right)^{2} .
$$

(a) Show that

$$
s+t+u=\sum_{i=1}^{4} m_{i}^{2} .
$$

(b) Assume the reaction is elastic scattering and let

$$
m_{1}=m_{3}=\mu, \quad m_{2}=m_{4}=m .
$$

In the c.m. frame let the initial and final three-momenta of the particle of mass $\mu$ be $\mathbf{k}$ and $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ respectively. Express $s, t$ and $u$ in terms of $\mathbf{k}$ and $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$, simplifying as much as possible. Interpret $s, t$ and $u$.

(c) Assume that in the laboratory frame the particle of mass $m$ is initially at rest. Express the initial and final laboratory energies of particle $\mu$, as well as the scattering angle, in terms of $s, t$ and $u$.

(SUNY, Buffalo)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-730.jpg?height=223&width=256&top_left_y=1588&top_left_x=638)

Fig. 3.22. 

\section{Solution:}

Use units for which the velocity of light $c=1$ for convenience.

(a) $q^{2}$ is defined as $q^{\alpha} q_{\alpha}$ with $q^{\alpha}=\left(q^{\circ}, \mathbf{q}\right), q_{\alpha}=\left(q^{\circ},-\mathbf{q}\right)$. The quantity $q^{\alpha} q_{\alpha}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation. Evaluating it in the rest frame of the particle:

$$
q^{2}=\left(q^{\circ}\right)^{2}-\mathbf{q}^{2}=E^{2}-\mathbf{q}^{2}=m^{2} .
$$

Now

$$
\begin{aligned}
s+t+u &=\left(q_{1}+p_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(q_{1}-q_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(q_{1}-p_{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=q_{1}^{2}+q_{2}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}+p_{2}^{2}+2 q_{1} \cdot\left(q_{1}-q_{2}+p_{1}-p_{2}\right) \\
&=m_{1}^{2}+m_{3}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+m_{4}^{2}+2 q_{1} \cdot\left(q_{1}-q_{2}+p_{1}-p_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the 4-momenta satisfy the energy-momentum conservation law

$$
q_{1}+p_{1}=q_{2}+p_{2},
$$

we have

$$
s+t+u=\sum_{i=1}^{4} m_{i}^{2} .
$$

(b) In the center of mass frame,

$$
\mathbf{q}_{1}+\mathbf{p}_{1}=\mathbf{q}_{2}+\mathbf{p}_{2}=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
q_{1}^{\alpha} &=\left(\sqrt{\mu^{2}+\mathbf{k}^{2}}, \mathbf{k}\right), & q_{2}^{\alpha}=\left(\sqrt{\mu^{2}+\mathbf{k}^{\prime 2}}, \mathbf{k}^{\prime}\right) \\
p_{1}^{\alpha}=\left(\sqrt{m^{2}+\mathbf{k}^{2}},-\mathbf{k}\right), & p_{2}^{\alpha}=\left(\sqrt{m^{2}+\mathbf{k}^{\prime 2}},-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
s &=\left(q_{1}+p_{1}\right)^{2}=q_{1}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}+2 q_{1} \cdot p_{1} \\
&=\mu^{2}+k^{2}-k^{2}+m^{2}+k^{2}-k^{2}+2 \sqrt{\left(\mu^{2}+k^{2}\right)\left(m^{2}+k^{2}\right)}+2 k^{2} \\
&=\mu^{2}+m^{2}+2 \sqrt{\left(\mu^{2}+k^{2}\right)\left(m^{2}+k^{2}\right)}+2 k^{2} \\
t &=\left(q_{1}-q_{2}\right)^{2}=q_{1}^{2}+q_{2}^{2}-2 q_{1} \cdot q_{2} \\
&=2 \mu^{2}-2 \sqrt{\left(\mu^{2}+k^{2}\right)\left(\mu^{2}+k^{\prime 2}\right)}+2 \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{k}^{\prime}, \\
u &=\left(q_{1}-p_{2}\right)^{2}=q_{1}^{2}+p_{2}^{2}-2 q_{1} \cdot p_{2} \\
&=\mu^{2}+m^{2}-2 \sqrt{\left(\mu^{2}+k^{2}\right)\left(m^{2}+k^{\prime 2}\right)}-2 \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{k}^{\prime} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
s=\left(\sqrt{\mu^{2}+k^{2}}+\sqrt{m^{2}+k^{2}}\right)^{2}
$$

is the square of the total energy of the incident particles in the center of mass frame, $t$ is the square of the forward transfer and $u$ is the square of the backward transfer of 4-momentum during the collision. $s, t, u$ which are Lorentz invariant quantities are known as Mandelstam variables.

(c) In the laboratory frame, we have

$$
q_{1}^{\alpha}=\left(q_{1}^{\circ}, \mathbf{q}_{1}\right), \quad q_{2}^{\alpha}=\left(q_{2}^{\circ}, \mathbf{q}_{2}\right), \quad p_{1}^{\alpha}=(m, 0)
$$

and

$$
\begin{gathered}
q_{1}^{2}=q_{1}^{\alpha} q_{1 \alpha}=\mu^{2}, \quad q_{2}^{2}=\mu^{2}, \\
q_{1}+p_{1}=q_{2}+p_{2} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
s &=\left(q_{1}+p_{1}\right)^{2}=q_{1}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}+2 q_{1} \cdot p_{1} \\
&=\mu^{2}+m^{2}+2 q_{1}^{\circ} m, \\
t &=\left(q_{1}-q_{2}\right)^{2}=q_{1}^{2}+q_{2}^{2}-2 q_{1} \cdot q_{2} \\
&=2 \mu^{2}-2 q_{1}^{\circ} q_{2}^{\circ}+2 q_{1} \cdot q_{2}, \\
u &=\left(q_{1}-p_{2}\right)^{2}=\left(q_{2}-p_{1}\right)^{2}=q_{2}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}-2 q_{2} \cdot p_{1} \\
&=\mu^{2}+m^{2}-2 q_{2}^{\circ} m .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the initial laboratory energy of particle $\mu$ is

$$
q_{1}^{\circ}=\frac{s-\mu^{2}-m^{2}}{2 m},
$$

the final laboratory energy of $\mu$ is

$$
q_{2}^{\circ}=\frac{-u+\mu^{2}+m^{2}}{2 m},
$$

and the scattering angle $\theta$ is given by

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{\mathbf{q}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{q}_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{q}_{1}\right|\left|\mathbf{q}_{2}\right|}=\frac{\frac{t}{2}-\mu^{2}+q_{1}^{\circ} q_{2}^{\circ}}{\sqrt{\left[\left(q_{1}^{\circ}\right)^{2}-\mu^{2}\right]\left[\left(q_{2}^{\circ}\right)^{2}-\mu^{2}\right]}} .
$$



\section{6}

The following question is a question on Newtonian gravity.

(a) Calculate the radius and density of a solar-mass $\operatorname{star}\left(M=2 \times 10^{33} \mathrm{~g}\right)$ from which light could not escape.

(b) The universe can be thought of as a sphere of gas of uniform density $\rho(t)$ and zero total energy expanding against its self-gravity. Show that if pressure can be neglected the interparticle distance increases as $t^{2 / 3}$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) By the equivalence of mass and energy, a photon of energy $E=m c^{2}$ has an equivalent mass $m$. The potential of a particle of mass $m$ at the surface of a star of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is

$$
V=-\frac{G M m}{R},
$$

where $G$ is the constant of gravitation. Hence for the photon to escape the star, we require $E+V \geq 0$, or $E \geq-V$. Conversely the photon will be confined to the star if $E \leq-V$, i.e.

$$
m c^{2} \leq \frac{G M m}{R},
$$

or

$$
R \leq \frac{G M}{c^{2}}=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-8} \times 2 \times 10^{33}}{\left(3 \times 10^{10}\right)^{2}}=1.48 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~cm}=1.48 \mathrm{~km}
$$

The density $\rho$ of the sun must then be

$$
\begin{aligned}
\rho & \geq M\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\right)^{-1}=\left(\frac{3}{4 \pi}\right) \times \frac{2 \times 10^{33}}{\left(1.48 \times 10^{5}\right)^{3}} \\
&=1.47 \times 10^{-1} \times \frac{10^{33}}{10^{15}}=1.47 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that this result is consistent with the gravitational red shift. A photon of frequency $\nu$ emitted by the star will have a frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ at a large distance from it, where

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\nu\left(1-\frac{G M}{R c^{2}}\right)
$$

For the photon to escape the gravitational field of the star we require that $\nu^{\prime} \geq 0$, or

$$
R \geq \frac{G M}{c^{2}} .
$$

(b) In the expansion of a gas under the condition of uniform density, the distance between two given particles is proportional to the linear dimension of the gas and the position of any gas particle can be taken to be the center of expansion. Consider two gas particles $A, B$ separated by a distance $R$. We can treat $A$ as at the center of expansion and $B$ as on the surface of a sphere with center at $A$. According to Newton's law of gravitation, $B$ will suffer an attractive gravitational force toward $A$ of $-\frac{G M}{R^{2}}$ per unit mass, where $M=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho, \rho$ being the density of the gas, is the mass of the sphere of gas. Note that the mass of the gas outside the sphere does not exert a net force on $B$. Neglecting pressure the equation of the motion of $B$ is

$$
\frac{d^{2} R}{d t^{2}}=-\frac{G M}{R^{2}} .
$$

\section{Writing}

$$
\frac{d^{2} R}{d t^{2}}=\frac{d \dot{R}}{d R} \frac{d R}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{R}^{2}}{d R}
$$

and noting that $M$ does not change during the expansion, we have by integration

$$
\frac{\dot{R}^{2}}{2}=\frac{G M}{R}+K,
$$

or

$$
K=\frac{\dot{R}^{2}}{2}-\frac{G M}{R}=T+V,
$$

$T, V$ being the kinetic and potential energies of the particle per unit mass. $K=0$ if the total energy is zero. Hence

$$
\frac{d R}{d t}=\pm \sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}} \text {. }
$$

The positive sign has to be taken for expansion. Integrating, we have, with $R=R_{0}$ at $t=t_{0}$

$$
\frac{2}{3}\left(R^{\frac{3}{2}}-R_{0}^{\frac{3}{2}}\right)=\sqrt{2 G M}\left(t-t_{0}\right) .
$$

At large $t \gg t_{0}, R \gg R_{0}$ and

$$
R \propto t^{\frac{2}{3}} .
$$



\section{7}

An astronaut takes an ordinary flashlight, turns it on, and leave it out in space (spin-stabilized by some rotation about its axis). What additional speed will this "photon-rocket" have gained by the time the batteries give out in two hours?

(Columbia)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the flashlight bulb is located at the focus of a paraboloid reflector so that almost the entire light output goes out in one direction. If the power of the flashlight is $N$ watts and the time interval it is turned on is $t$, the total energy of the photons emitted is $E=N t$. If the orientation of the flashlight does not change, it will gain a momentum

$$
m v=\frac{E}{c}=\frac{N t}{c},
$$

or an additional speed

$$
v=\frac{N t}{m c},
$$

$m$ being the mass of the flashlight, since a photon of energy $\varepsilon$ has a momentum $\frac{\varepsilon}{c}$.

For example, if $N=1 \mathrm{~W}, m=0.3 \mathrm{~kg}, t=2$ hours,

$$
v=\frac{1 \times 2 \times 3600}{0.3 \times 3 \times 10^{8}}=8 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

\section{8}

A hypothetical flashlight emits a well-collimated beam and is capable of converting a significant fraction of its rest mass into light. If the flashlight starts at rest with mass $m_{0}$, and is then turned on and allowed to move freely along a straight line, find its rest mass $m$ when it reaches a velocity $v$ relative to its original rest frame. Do not assume $c \gg v$.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

Let the total energy of all the photons emitted before the light reaches the velocity $v=\beta c$ be $E$. Then the total momentum of the photons is $\frac{E}{c}$ and is opposite in direction to $v$. Let the rest mass of the flashlight be $m$ when its velocity is $v$. Conservation of energy gives

$$
m \gamma c^{2}+E=m_{0} c^{2},
$$

and conservation of momentum gives

$$
m \gamma \beta c-\frac{E}{c}=0,
$$

with $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Eliminating $E$ from the above gives

$$
m \gamma(1+\beta)=m_{0},
$$

or

$$
m=\frac{m_{0}}{\gamma(1+\beta)}=m_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}=m_{0} \sqrt{\frac{c-v}{c+v}} .
$$

\section{9}

A particle of charge $q$, mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ in the $x y$-plane in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{z}}$.

(a) Find $B$ in terms of $q, R, m$, and the angular frequency $\omega$.

(b) The speed of the particle is constant (since the $\mathbf{B}$ field does no work on it). An observer moving with uniform velocity $\beta \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ does not, however, see the particle's speed as constant. What is $u_{0}^{\prime}$ ( the zero component of the particle's 4-velocity) as measured by this observer?

(c) Calculate $\frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}$ and, thus, $\frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}$. How can the energy of the particle change?

(Princeton $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The equation of motion of the particle in the laboratory is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=q \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

As $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are parallel,

$$
\mathbf{p} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d p^{2}}{d t}=q \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}=0 .
$$

Hence $p^{2}$ and thus the magnitude of $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are constant. It follows that

$$
\gamma_{u}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}
$$

is also a constant. Then, as $\mathbf{p}=m \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}$, the equation of motion can be written as

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{u}}{d t}=\mathbf{u} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\omega}=q \mathbf{B} / m \gamma_{u}$. As

$$
\mathbf{u}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, 0), \quad \boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega),
$$

it becomes

$$
\ddot{x}=\dot{y} \omega, \quad \ddot{y}=-\dot{x} \omega, \quad \ddot{z}=0 .
$$

Since the motion is confined to the $x y$-plane, the $z$ equation need not be considered. The other two equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{\xi}+i \omega \dot{\xi}=0
$$

by putting $x+i y=\xi$. It has general solution

$$
\xi=\rho e^{-i(\omega t+\varphi)}+\xi_{0},
$$

where $\rho, \varphi$ are real constants and $\xi_{0}$ is a complex constant. This solution is equivalent to

$$
x-x_{0}=R \cos (\omega t+\varphi), \quad y-y_{0}=-R \sin (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

showing that the motion is circular with a radius $R$ given by

$$
u=\sqrt{\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}}=R \omega,
$$

$\omega$ being the angular velocity of revolution. Hence

$$
B=\frac{m \gamma_{u} \omega}{q}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{R \omega}{c}\right)^{2}}} .
$$

(b) Let $S, S^{\prime}$ be respectively the laboratory frame and the rest frame of the moving observer. The zeroth component of the velocity four-vector, defined as $u^{\alpha}=\left(\gamma_{u} c, \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}\right)$, transforms according to

$$
\gamma_{u}^{\prime} c=\gamma\left(\gamma_{u} c-\beta \gamma_{u} u_{1}\right),
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{0}^{\prime} \equiv \gamma_{u}^{\prime} c &=\gamma \gamma_{u}(c-\beta \dot{x}) \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}[c+\beta \omega R \sin (\omega t+\varphi)] \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}\left[c+\beta u \sin \left(\omega \gamma_{u} \tau+\varphi\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tau$ is the proper time of the particle. Thus $u_{0}^{\prime}$ is not constant in $S^{\prime}$.

(c)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau} &=\gamma \gamma_{u}^{2} \beta \omega u \cos \left(\omega \gamma_{u} \tau+\varphi\right) \\
&=R\left(\frac{q B}{m}\right)^{2} \frac{\beta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \cos \left(\frac{q B \tau}{m}+\varphi\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the four-momentum is defined as $p^{\alpha}=\left(m u_{0}, \mathbf{p}\right)$, then, as $m$ is a constant,

$$
\frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}=m \frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}=\frac{R q^{2} B^{2}}{m} \frac{\beta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \cos \left(\frac{q B \tau}{m}+\varphi\right),
$$

which signifies a change of energy

$$
\frac{d E}{d \tau}=c \frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau} .
$$

Note that in the $S^{\prime}$ frame, the electromagnetic field is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\|}^{\prime} &=E_{\|}=0 \\
E_{\perp}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right) \\
&=\gamma \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp} \\
&=\gamma \beta \hat{\mathbf{x}} \times B \hat{\mathbf{z}}=-\gamma \beta B \hat{\mathbf{y}},
\end{aligned}
$$

so that there is also an electric field in the $S^{\prime}$ frame which does work on the particle.

\section{0}

When two beams of protons of kinetic energy $T$ collide head-on, the available energy for reactions is the same as for a single beam of what kinetic energy colliding with stationary protons? (Use relativistic expressions). 

\section{Solution:}

The quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$ for a system is invariant under Lorentz transformation. Consider the head-on collision of two protons, each of kinetic energy $T$, and suppose that in the rest frame $S^{\prime}$ of one of the protons the other proton has total energy $E^{\prime}$ and momentum $p^{\prime}$. As in the laboratory frame the total momentum of the two protons is zero, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(2 m c^{2}+2 T\right)^{2} &=\left(E^{\prime}+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2} \\
&=\left(E^{\prime}+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(E^{\prime 2}-m^{2} c^{4}\right) \\
&=2 E^{\prime} m c^{2}+2 m^{2} c^{4},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
E^{\prime}=\frac{2 T^{2}+4 T m c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}}{m c^{2}}
$$

where $m$ is the rest mass of the proton. Hence the energy available for reactions is

$$
E^{\prime}-m c^{2}=\frac{2 T^{2}+4 T m c^{2}}{m c^{2}} .
$$

\section{1}

A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

(a) What is the total relativistic energy of photon plus particle in the center of mass frame of reference?

(b) What is the magnitude of the particle's momentum in the center of mass frame?

(c) If elastic backward scattering of the photon occurs, what is the momentum of the final photon in the laboratory frame?

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$

(b) In the center of mass frame, the total momentum $P^{\prime}=0$ and $p$ the momentum of the particle is equal and opposite to that of the photon $p^{\prime}$. Momentum transformation

$$
P^{\prime}=0=\gamma\left(P-\frac{\beta E}{c}\right)
$$

gives

$$
