\beta=\frac{P c}{E}=\frac{p c}{p c+m c^{2}}, \quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}
$$

for the center of mass frame. The particle momentum in the center of mass frame is then, using the transformation equation again,

$$
p^{\prime}=\gamma(0-\beta m c)=-\gamma \beta m c=\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$

(c) Let the final momenta of the photon and the particle be $-p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ respectively. Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
\begin{aligned}
p c+m c^{2} &=p_{1} c+\sqrt{p_{2}^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}} \\
p &=-p_{1}+p_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

These combine to give

$$
\left(p-p_{1}\right)^{2}+2\left(p-p_{1}\right) m c=\left(p+p_{1}\right)^{2},
$$

or

$$
p_{1}=\frac{p m c}{2 p+m c} .
$$

\section{2}

We consider the possibility that one of the recently discovered particles, the $\psi^{\prime}(3.7)$, can be produced when a photon collides with a proton in the reaction

$$
\gamma+p \rightarrow p+\psi^{\prime}
$$

In this problem we shall take the mass of $\psi^{\prime}$ to be $4 M_{p}$, where $M_{p}$ is the proton mass, which is a reasonable approximation. The target proton is initially at rest and the incident photon has energy $E$ in the laboratory system.

(a) Determine the minimum energy $E$ that the photon must have for the above reaction to be possible. The answer can be given in units of $M_{p} c^{2}$ $(=938 \mathrm{MeV})$

(b) Determine the velocity, i.e. $v / c$, for the $\psi^{\prime}$ particle when the photon energy $E$ is just above the threshold energy $E_{0}$.

\section{(UC, Berkeley)}

\section{Solution:}

(a) At threshold, the final-state particles $p, \psi^{\prime}$ are stationary in the center of mass frame. Using the fact that the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation and for an isolated system is conserved, we have, as a photon of energy $E$ has momentum $\frac{E}{c}$,

$$
\left(E_{0}+M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2}-E_{0}^{2}=\left(M_{p} c^{2}+4 M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2},
$$

giving

$$
E_{0}=12 M_{p} c^{2}
$$

as the threshold photon energy.

(b) Near threshold, the $\psi^{\prime}$ is produced at rest in the center of mass frame, so its velocity in the laboratory is the velocity of the center of mass, i.e. of the system:

$$
v=\frac{P c^{2}}{E}=\frac{E_{0} c}{E_{0}+M_{p} c^{2}}=\frac{12}{13} \mathrm{c} .
$$

\section{3}

An antiproton of energy $E_{0}$ interacts with a proton at rest to produce two equal mass particles, each with mass $m_{x}$. One of these produced particles is detected at an angle of $90^{\circ}$ to the incident beam as measured in the laboratory. Calculate the total energy $\left(E_{s}\right)$ of this particle and show that it is independent of $m_{x}$ as well as of $E_{0}$. 

\section{Solution:}

Antiproton and proton have the same mass $m$, say. The collision is depicted in Fig. 3.23. Momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{0}=p_{2} \cos \theta, \quad p_{1}=p_{2} \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
p_{2}^{2}=p_{0}^{2}+p_{1}^{2} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-742.jpg?height=273&width=502&top_left_y=609&top_left_x=505)

Fig. $3.23$.

\section{Energy conservation gives}

$$
E_{0}+m c^{2}=E_{s}+\sqrt{p_{2}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}} .
$$

Combining the last two equations gives

$$
\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right)^{2}+E_{s}^{2}-2\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right) E_{s}=p_{0}^{2} c^{2}+p_{1}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}
$$

or

$$
2 m^{2} c^{4}+2 E_{0} m c^{2}=2\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right) E_{s},
$$

since $E_{0}^{2}=p_{0}^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}, E_{s}^{2}=p_{1}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}$. Hence

$$
E_{s}=m c^{2} \text {. }
$$

It is seen that $E_{s}$ depends only on the proton mass but is independent of either $m_{x}$ or $E_{0}$.

\section{4}

(a) A particle of mass $m$ and charge $e$ moves at relativistic speed $v$ in a circle of radius $R$, the orbit being normal to a static, homogeneous magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ as shown in Fig. 3.24. Find $R$ in terms of the other parameters (radiation may be ignored).

(b) An observer $O^{\prime}$ moving at fixed velocity $v$ along the $y$-axis sees an orbit that looks like Fig. 3.25. The points $a, b, c, d, e$ on the two figures correspond.

(i) What is the distance $y_{d}^{\prime}-y_{b}^{\prime}$ measured by $O^{\prime}$ ?

(ii) What is the acceleration $\frac{d^{2} x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime 2}}$ of the particle at $c$, where it is instantaneously at rest?

(iii) What causes the acceleration at $c$ as seen by $O^{\prime}$ ?

(Princeton $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-743.jpg?height=307&width=407&top_left_y=747&top_left_x=226)

Fig. 3.24.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-743.jpg?height=227&width=568&top_left_y=824&top_left_x=769)

Fig. 3.25.

\section{Solution:}

(a) If $\mathbf{p}$ is the momentum of the particle, we have

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B},
$$

and thus

$$
\mathbf{p} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d p^{2}}{d t}=e m \gamma \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}=0
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. Hence $\mathbf{p}$ and so $\gamma$ and $v$ have constant magnitudes. As shown in Problem 3039, the orbit is a circle of radius $R$ given by $v=R \omega$, where

$$
\omega=\frac{e B}{m \gamma} .
$$

(b) Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the laboratory frame and the frame of the moving observer respectively, with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving relative to $\Sigma$ in the $y$-direction with velocity $-v$. Lorentz transformation becomes 

$$
\begin{aligned}
y^{\prime} &=\gamma(y-\beta c t)=\gamma(y+v t), \\
z^{\prime} &=z, \quad x^{\prime}=x, \\
c t^{\prime} &=\gamma(c t-\beta y)=\gamma\left(c t+\frac{v y}{c}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\beta=-\frac{v}{c}$.

(i) As

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{d}-y_{b} &=-2 R, \quad t_{d}-t_{b}=\frac{\pi}{\omega}, \\
y_{d}^{\prime}-y_{b}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(y_{d}-y_{b}\right)+\gamma v\left(t_{d}-t_{b}\right) \\
&=\gamma\left(-2 R+\frac{v \pi}{\omega}\right) \\
&=\frac{(\pi-2) \gamma v}{\omega}=\frac{(\pi-2) m v}{e B\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) At point $c, \frac{d x}{d t}=0, \frac{d y}{d t}=-v$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=\frac{-v^{2}}{R} & \quad \text { (centripetal acceleration) }, \\
\frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}=0 & \quad(\text { tangential acceleration) } .
\end{array}
$$

The velocity component $\frac{d x}{d t}$ transforms according to

$$
\frac{d x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=\frac{d x}{d t} /\left(\frac{d t^{\prime}}{d t}\right)=\frac{\frac{d x}{d t}}{\gamma\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right)}
$$

In a similar way, 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^{2} x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime 2}} &=\frac{d}{d t^{\prime}}\left(\frac{d x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}\right)=\frac{1}{\gamma\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right)} \cdot \frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{d x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\gamma\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right)} \cdot \frac{d}{d t}\left[\frac{\frac{d x}{d t}}{\gamma\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right)}\right] \\
&=\frac{\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right) \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}-\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}} \frac{d x}{d t}}{\gamma^{2}\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}\right)^{3}} \\
&=\frac{-\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) \frac{v^{2}}{R}}{\gamma^{2}\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3}} \\
=&-\gamma^{2} v \omega=\frac{-\gamma e v B}{m} .
\end{aligned}
$$

At point $c$

$$
\frac{d y^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{d y}{d t}+v}{1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} \frac{d y}{d t}}=\frac{-v+v}{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}=0 .
$$

As $\frac{d x^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=0, \frac{d z^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=0$ also, the particle velocity $\mathbf{u}^{\prime}=0$.

(iii) The transformation equations for the electromagnetic field are

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{y}^{\prime} &=E_{y}=0, \quad B_{y}^{\prime}=B_{y}=0 \\
E_{z}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(E_{z}-\beta c B_{x}\right)=0 \\
E_{x}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(E_{x}+\beta c B_{z}\right)=-\gamma v B \\
B_{z}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(B_{z}+\frac{\beta}{c} E_{x}\right)=\gamma B \\
B_{x}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(B_{x}-\frac{\beta}{c} E_{z}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

(In the usual geometry let $y$ replace $x, z$ replace $y, x$ replace $z$ to obtain the above). Then in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the Lorentz force acting on the particle at $c$ is

$$
\mathbf{F}^{\prime}=e\left(\mathbf{E}^{\prime}+\mathbf{u}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{B}^{\prime}\right)=e \mathbf{E}^{\prime},
$$

or

$$
F^{\prime}=F_{x}^{\prime}=-\gamma e v B,
$$

and the acceleration is $-\frac{\gamma e v B}{m}$, in agreement with (b). Hence the acceleration arises because of the presence of an electric field in $\Sigma^{\prime}$.

\section{5}

A charged particle (with charge $e$ and rest mass $m$ ) moves in an electromagnetic field which is constant in space and time and whose components are $\mathbf{E}=(a, 0,0)$ and $\mathbf{B}=(0,0, b)$ in a Lorentz frame $S$. It is assumed that $|\mathbf{E}| \neq|\mathbf{B}|$. State the differential equations for the particle's four-vector velocity (as function of the proper time). Show that the solutions may be expressed as superpositions of exponentials, and determine the exponents. Under what conditions (on $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{B}$ ) are all components of the four-velocity bounded along every trajectory?

\section{(Princeton $)$}

\section{Solution:}

The motion of the particle is described by the 4 -vector equation

$$
\frac{d p^{\alpha}}{d s}=F^{\alpha},
$$

where $d s=c d \tau, \tau$ being the proper time of the particle,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p^{\alpha} &=m c^{2} u^{\alpha}=m c^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{c} \mathbf{u}, \gamma\right) \\
F^{\alpha} &=\left(\gamma \mathbf{F}, \frac{\gamma}{c} \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{F}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ being the velocity of the particle.

The force acting on the particle is the Lorentz force

$$
\mathbf{F}=e(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}) .
$$

With $\mathbf{u}=\left(u_{x}, u_{y}, u_{z}\right), \mathbf{E}=(a, 0,0), \mathbf{B}=(0, \mathbf{0}, b)$, and $\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{F}=e \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{E}=e a u_{x}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F^{\alpha} &=e \gamma\left(a+b u_{y},-b u_{x}, 0, \frac{a u_{x}}{c}\right) \\
&=e\left(a u_{4}+c b u_{2},-c b u_{1}, 0, a u_{1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the equations of motion are 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \frac{d u_{1}}{d \tau}=\frac{e}{c}\left(c b u_{2}+a u_{4}\right) \\
&m \frac{d u_{2}}{d \tau}=-e b u_{1} \\
&m \frac{d u_{3}}{d \tau}=0 \\
&m \frac{d u_{4}}{d \tau}=\frac{e a u_{1}}{c}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $u_{3}$ is a constant and need not be considered further. To solve the other equations, try

$$
u_{j}=A_{j} e^{\lambda \tau}, \quad j=1,2,4 .
$$

The equations now become

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \lambda A_{1}-e b A_{2}-\frac{e}{c} a A_{4} &=0, \\
e b A_{1}+m \lambda A_{2} &=0, \\
-\frac{e}{c} a A_{1}+m \lambda A_{4} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution where not all $A^{\prime}$ s vanish, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
m \lambda & -e b & -\frac{e a}{c} \\
e b & m \lambda & 0 \\
-\frac{e a}{c} & 0 & m \lambda
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
m \lambda\left(m^{2} \lambda^{2}+e^{2} b^{2}-\frac{e^{2} a^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)=0
$$

The roots are

$$
\lambda_{1}=0, \quad \lambda_{2}=\frac{e}{m c} \sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2} b^{2}}, \quad \lambda_{3}=-\frac{e}{m c} \sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2} b^{2}} .
$$

The general solution for the equation of motion is a superposition of exponentials with these exponents. For all components of the 4-velocity to be bounded along every trajectory we require that the $\lambda$ 's are either zero or imaginary, i.e.

$$
a \leq c b, \quad \text { or } \quad|\mathbf{E}| \leq c|\mathbf{B}| .
$$



\section{6}

A particle of charge $e$, energy $E$, and velocity $v$ moves in a magnetic field generated by a magnetic dipole of strength $M$ located at the origin and directed along the $z$-axis. If the particle is initially in the $x y$-plane at a distance $R$ from the origin and moving radially outward, give the minimum and maximum radii it will reach (assume the orbit is bounded).

\section{Solution:}

A particle of charge $e$, rest mass $m$ and velocity $\mathbf{u}$ moving in an electromagnetic field of scalar potential $\Phi$ and vector potential $\mathbf{A}$ has Lagrangian

$$
L=-\frac{m c^{2}}{\gamma}-e \Phi+e \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{A} .
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. Since there is no electric field, $\Phi=0$. The vector potential due to a magnetic dipole of moment $M$ at the origin is

$$
\mathbf{A}=-\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \mathbf{M} \times \nabla\left(\frac{1}{r}\right)=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{\mathbf{M} \times \mathbf{r}}{r^{3}} .
$$

In spherical coordinates as shown in Fig. 3.26, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M} &=(M \cos \theta,-M \sin \theta, 0), \\
\mathbf{r} &=(r, 0,0),
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{M \sin \theta}{r^{2}} \mathbf{i}_{\varphi} .
$$

With $\mathbf{u}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta}, r \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta)$, the Lagrangian is

$$
L=-\frac{m c^{2}}{\gamma}+\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M \sin ^{2} \theta}{r} \dot{\varphi} .
$$

Note that as $u^{2}=\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, L$ does not depend on $\varphi$ explicitly. Hence

$$
p_{\varphi}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=\left(m \gamma r^{2} \dot{\varphi}+\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M}{r}\right) \sin ^{2} \theta=\text { constant } .
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-749.jpg?height=376&width=415&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=540)

Fig. 3.26.

Initially the particle is at $r=R$ and moves with velocity $v=\dot{r}$ in the $x y$-plane, i.e. $r=R, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}, \dot{\varphi}=0$ initially, giving $\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M}{R}$ for the constant. Furthermore, as the only force on the particle is that due to the magnetic dipole at the origin whose magnetic lines of force at the $x y$-plane are perpendicular to the plane, the magnetic force is also in this plane and the motion is confined to the plane. Hence $\dot{\theta}=0, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$ at all times. Thus

$$
m \gamma r^{2} \dot{\varphi}+\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M}{r}=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M}{R} .
$$

At the maximum and minimum radii, $\dot{r}=0$ and $\mathbf{u}=r \dot{\varphi} \mathbf{i}_{\varphi}$. Since magnetic force does no work as

$$
\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{u} \times(\nabla \times \mathbf{A})=0
$$

the magnitude of $\mathbf{u}$ is equal to the initial speed $v$, i.e. $r \dot{\varphi}=\pm v$, and $\gamma$ is a constant. Letting

$$
\alpha=\frac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \frac{e M}{m \gamma v},
$$

we have

$$
\pm R r^{2}-\alpha r+\alpha R=0 .
$$

For the upper sign the roots are

$$
r=\frac{\alpha}{2 R}\left(1 \pm \sqrt{1-\frac{4 R^{2}}{\alpha}}\right)
$$

For the lower sign the roots are 

$$
r=\frac{\alpha}{2 R}\left(-1 \pm \sqrt{1+\frac{4 R^{2}}{\alpha}}\right),
$$

where the positive sign is to be used since $r$ is positive. Examining these roots we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
&r_{\max }=\frac{\alpha}{2 R}\left(1+\sqrt{1-\frac{4 R^{2}}{\alpha}}\right) \\
&r_{\min }=\frac{\alpha}{2 R}\left(-1+\sqrt{1+\frac{4 R^{2}}{\alpha}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{7}

It is well known that planets move in elliptical orbits around the sun and the derivation of the orbit equation is a standard exercise in classical mechanics. However, if the effects of special relativity only are taken into account, the orbit is a precessing ellipse of the form

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{r_{0}}\left\{1+\epsilon \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]\right\},
$$

where $\alpha=1$ corresponds to the classical result of zero precession.

(a) Derive this equation and express $\alpha$ and $r_{0}$ in terms of fundamental constants of the orbit (such as energy, angular momentum, etc.)

(b) Given that the mean radius of the orbit of Mercury is $58 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and that its orbital period is 88 days, calculate the precession of Mercury's orbit in seconds of arc per century. (This effect does not, of course, account for the total precession rate of Mercury.)

(Chicago

\section{Solution:}

(a) Consider a planet of mass $m$ and velocity $\mathbf{v}$. As it moves in an elliptical orbit, i.e. in a plane, use polar coordinates $(r, \theta)$ with the sun at the origin. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=-\frac{m c^{2}}{\gamma}+\frac{G m M}{r},
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$ with

$$
\beta^{2}=\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}=\frac{\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{c^{2}},
$$

$M$ being the mass of the sun. As

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial \dot{r}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma \dot{r}}{c^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma r^{2} \dot{\theta}}{c^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma r \dot{\theta}^{2}}{c^{2}},
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{r})-m \gamma r \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{G m M}{r^{2}}=0, \\
m \gamma r^{2} \dot{\theta}=b, \text { a constant } .
\end{gathered}
$$

Letting $u=\frac{1}{r}$, the last two equations combine to give

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{b}{\dot{\theta}} \frac{d u}{d t}\right)+b u \dot{\theta}-G m M u^{2}=0,
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+u=\frac{G m M u^{2}}{b \dot{\theta}},
$$

as

$$
\frac{d u}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \frac{d u}{d \theta} .
$$

The total energy of the planet is

$$
E=m \gamma c^{2}-\frac{G m M}{r} .
$$

Thus

$$
\frac{G m M u^{2}}{b \dot{\theta}}=\frac{G m M}{b^{2} c^{2}}(E+G m M \mu)
$$

and Eq. (1) becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+\alpha^{2} u=\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2}},
$$

where

$$
\alpha^{2}=1-\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2} .
$$

A special solution of Eq. (2) is

$$
u=\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}},
$$

and its general solution is thus

$$
u=A \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]+\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}},
$$

where $A$ and $\theta_{0}$ are constants. The orbit is therefore given by

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{r_{0}}\left\{1+\epsilon \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]\right\}
$$

with

$$
r_{0}=\frac{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}}{G m M E}=\frac{(b c)^{2}-(G m M)^{2}}{G m M E}, \quad \epsilon=A r_{0}, \quad \alpha=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}},
$$

$A, \theta_{0}$ being constants, and $b, E$ being the angular momentum about the sun and the total energy of the planet respectively.

(b) Suppose $r$ is minimum at $\theta_{1}$ and it next returns to this minimum at $\theta_{2}$. Then $\alpha\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)=2 \pi$. Hence the perihelion advances an angle

$$
\Delta \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{\alpha}-2 \pi=2 \pi\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}-1\right)
$$

in one period of revolution. Note that there is no precession if $\alpha=1$. Since the amount of precession is small compared with $2 \pi, \alpha$ is close to unity and can be expressed as

$$
\alpha \approx 1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}
$$

and we have

$$
\Delta \theta \approx \pi\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}
$$

per period of revolution. From a consideration of the gravitational attraction we have

$$
\frac{G m M}{\bar{r}^{2}}=m \gamma \bar{r} \dot{\theta}^{2},
$$

where $\bar{r}$ is the mean radius of the orbit of Mercury. As

$$
\begin{gathered}
b=m \gamma \bar{r}^{2} \dot{\theta}, \\
\frac{G m M}{b c}=\frac{\vec{r} \dot{\theta}}{c}=\frac{2 \pi \bar{r}}{\tau c},
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\tau=88$ days is the period of one revolution. In a century there are

$$
\frac{100 \times 365}{88}=414.8
$$

revolutions, so that the total precession per century is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Theta &=414.8 \times 4 \pi^{3} \times\left(\frac{58 \times 10^{6}}{88 \times 24 \times 3600 \times 3 \times 10^{5}}\right)^{2} \\
&=3.326 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{rad} \\
&=6.86 \text { seconds of arc. }
\end{aligned}
$$

This is about $\frac{1}{6}$ of the observed value, which can only be accounted for if general relativity is used for the calculation.

\section{8}

Derive the Hamiltonian of a particle traveling with momentum $\mathbf{p}=$ $\frac{m_{0} \mathbf{v}}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$ when it is placed in the fields defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{E}=-\nabla \Phi-\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t}, \\
&\mathbf{H}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l o)$

\section{Solution:}

The Lagrangian of the particle, assumed to have charge $q$, is in Gaussian units

$$
L=-\frac{m_{0} c^{2}}{\gamma}-q \Phi+\frac{q}{c} \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A},
$$

and its Hamiltonian is defined as

$$
H=\sum_{i} \dot{x}_{i} p_{i}-L,
$$

where $\dot{x}_{i}$ is the velocity component given, in Cartesian coordinates, by $\mathbf{v}=\left(\dot{x}_{1}, \dot{x}_{2}, \dot{x}_{3}\right)$ and $p_{i}$ is the canonical momentum given by $p_{i}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}_{i}}$. As

$$
\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}=1-\frac{\dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{x}_{3}^{2}}{c^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial \dot{x}_{i}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=-\frac{\gamma \dot{x}_{i}}{c^{2}},
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A}=\sum_{i} \dot{x}_{i} A_{i},
$$

we have

$$
p_{i}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}_{i}}=m_{0} \gamma \dot{x}_{i}+\frac{q A_{i}}{c}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=\sum_{i} \dot{x}_{i} p_{i}-L=m_{0} \gamma \sum_{i} \dot{x}_{i}^{2}+\frac{m_{0} c^{2}}{\gamma}+q \Phi \\
&=\frac{m_{0} c^{2}}{\gamma}\left(\frac{\gamma^{2} v^{2}}{c^{2}}+1\right)+q \Phi \\
&=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}+q \Phi .
\end{aligned}
$$

To write $H$ in terms of $\mathbf{p}$, we note that

$$
\sum_{i}\left(m_{0} \gamma \dot{x}_{i}\right)^{2}=\sum_{i}\left(p_{i}-\frac{q A_{i}}{c}\right)^{2},
$$

or

$$
m_{0}^{2} \gamma^{2} v^{2}=\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q \mathbf{A}}{c}\right)^{2}
$$

and thus

$$
m_{0}^{2} \gamma^{2} c^{4}=m_{0}^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma^{2} v^{2}}{c^{2}}+1\right) c^{4}=\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q \mathrm{~A}}{c}\right)^{2} c^{2}+m_{0}^{2} c^{4}
$$

Therefore

$$
H=\sqrt{\left(\mathbf{p}-\frac{q \mathrm{~A}}{c}\right)^{2} c^{2}+m_{0}^{2} c^{4}}+q \Phi .
$$

\section{9}

What is the velocity of a particle if its kinetic energy equals its rest energy?

(Wisconsin) 

\section{Solution:}

The kinetic energy of a particle of rest mass $m_{0}$ is

$$
T=E-m_{0} c^{2}=m_{0} c^{2}(\gamma-1)
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. As this equals $m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=2$. Hence

$$
\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4}},
$$

or

$$
v=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} c .
$$

\section{0}

A beam of electrons is scattered by a fixed scattering target as shown in Fig. 3.27. The electrons are elastically scattered. Each electron has an energy $E=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}$ and the beam has a flux of $Q$ electrons per second.

(a) What is the velocity of the incident electrons?

(b) What are the magnitude and direction of the force on the scattering target due to the electrons?

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-755.jpg?height=323&width=271&top_left_y=1511&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 3.27 

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $E=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=\frac{5}{3}$ and $\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\frac{4}{5}$. Hence the electron velocity is $0.8 c$.

(b) Since the electrons are elastically scattered, they have the same speed before and after scattering and conservation of the momentum parallel to the target requires that the incident and scattering angles are equal. Then after scattering the normal component of the momentum changes sign but remains the same in magnitude. Hence

$$
\Delta p=2 p_{n}=2 m_{0} \gamma v \cos 45^{\circ}=\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3} m_{0} c .
$$

The force $F$ on the target due to the beam of electrons is equal to the impulse given to it per unit time by the beam. As $Q$ electrons impinge on the target in unit time,

$$
F=2 p_{n} Q=\frac{4 \sqrt{2}}{3} Q m_{0} c,
$$

and it acts vertically onto the target.

\section{1}

The principle of equivalence asserts that gravitational and inertial masses are equal. Does a photon have nonzero gravitational mass? Explain. Suppose a photon is falling toward the earth and it falls a distance of $10 \mathrm{~m}$. Calculate the effect on the frequency of the photon. What experimental technique could be used to measure this frequency change?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The gravitational mass of a photon is not zero but is equal to the inertial mass

$$
m=\frac{E}{c^{2}}=\frac{h \nu}{c^{2}},
$$

in accordance with the principle of equivalence, even though its rest mass is zero. When the photon falls a distance $l$ in a gravitational field g, its energy increases and so does its frequency: 

$$
h \nu^{\prime} \approx h \nu+m g l=h \nu\left(1+\frac{g l}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

Writing $\nu^{\prime}=\nu+\Delta \nu$, we have

$$
\frac{\Delta \nu}{\nu} \approx \frac{g l}{c^{2}}=\frac{9.8 \times 10}{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}=1.1 \times 10^{-15} .
$$

Thus falling through a distance of $10 \mathrm{~m}$ in the gravitational field of the earth, the frequency of a photon will increase (blue shift) by a factor $1+1.1 \times 10^{-15}$. The slight increase in frequency can be detected experimentally using the Mssbauer effect.

\section{2}

Consider a very high energy scattering experiment involving two particles with the same rest mass $m_{0}$, one initially at rest and the other incident with momentum $p$ and total energy $E$.

(a) Find the velocity of the center of mass $\beta^{*}=\frac{v^{*}}{c}$.

(b) In the extreme relativistic limit $p c \gg m_{0} c^{2}$, find the total energy $E^{*}$ of the system in the center of mass frame (i.e. the frame in which the total 3-momentum is zero).

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) The system of two particles has total energy $E+m_{0} c^{2}$ and total momentum $p$ in the laboratory system. The velocity of the center of mass, which is the velocity of the system as a whole, in units of $c$, is then

$$
\beta^{*}=\frac{p c}{E+m_{0} c^{2}} .
$$

(b) The quantities $E^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}$ of a system is invariant under Lorentz transformation. In the laboratory frame it is

$$
\left(E+m_{0} c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=2 E m_{0} c^{2}+2 m_{0}^{2} c^{4}
$$

as $E^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=m_{0}^{2} c^{4}$. In the center of mass frame it is $(2 \bar{E})^{2}$, where $\bar{E}$ is the total energy of each particle. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{*} &=2 \bar{E}=\sqrt{2 E m_{0} c^{2}+2 m_{0}^{2} c^{4}} \\
& \approx \sqrt{2 E m_{0} c^{2}} \approx \sqrt{2 p m_{0} c^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

in the extreme relativistic limit for which $p c \gg m_{0} c^{2}$, since in this case

$$
E=\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m_{0}^{2} c^{4}} \approx p c \gg m_{0} c^{2} .
$$

\section{3}

A particle of rest mass $m$ and initial velocity $v_{0}$ along the $x$-axis is subject after $t=0$ to a constant force $F$ acting in the $y$-direction. Find its velocity at any time $t$, and show that $|\mathbf{v}| \rightarrow c$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The equation of motion

$$
\mathbf{F}=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \mathbf{v})
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$, can be written as

$$
0=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{x}), \quad F=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{y})
$$

with $\mathbf{v}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}), \mathbf{F}=(0, F)$. As $F$ is constant for $t>0$ and initially $\dot{x}=v_{0}$, $\dot{y}=0, F=0$, the above integrate to give

$$
m \gamma \dot{x}=m \gamma_{0} v_{0}, \quad m \gamma \dot{y}=F t,
$$

where $\gamma_{0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. Hence

$$
\beta^{2} c^{2}=\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}=\frac{1}{m^{2} \gamma^{2}}\left(m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}\right),
$$

or

$$
\gamma^{2} \beta^{2}=\frac{\beta^{2}}{1-\beta^{2}}=\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} c^{2}}
$$

giving

$$
\beta^{2}=\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+m^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}} .
$$

As $\gamma_{0}^{2} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{c^{2}}=\gamma_{0}^{2}-1$, we have

$$
v=\beta \mathrm{c}=\sqrt{\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}} \mathbf{c} .
$$

The velocity components are

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{\gamma_{0} v_{0}}{\gamma}, \quad \dot{y}=\frac{F t}{m \gamma},
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$

For $t \rightarrow \infty$, as $m \gamma_{0} v_{0}, m \gamma_{0}$ c remain constant we have

$$
v \rightarrow\left(\frac{F t}{F t}\right) \mathrm{c}=\mathrm{c} .
$$

\section{4}

An electron of energy $E \gg m c^{2}$ and a photon of energy $W$ collide.

(a) What is $W^{\prime}$, the energy of the photon in the electron (e) frame of reference?

(b) If $W^{\prime} \ll m c^{2}$, the electron recoil can be neglected and the energy of the photon in the $e$-frame is unchanged as a result of the scattering process. What are the minimum and maximum values of the energy of the scattered photon in the laboratory $(L)$ frame?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Suppose the photon makes angles $\theta, \theta^{\prime}$ with the initial direction of motion of the electron, which is taken to be the direction of the $x$-axis, in the $L$ - and $e$-frames respectively. As $(\mathbf{p c}, E)$ forms a 4-vector, the photon energy transforms according to 

$$
W^{\prime}=\gamma\left(W-\frac{\beta W}{\mathrm{c}} \cdot c \cos \theta\right)=\gamma(1-\beta \cos \theta) W,
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{E}{m c^{2}}, \beta=\frac{p c}{E}$ with $p=\frac{1}{c} \sqrt{E^{2}-m^{2} c^{4}}$ being the momentum of the electron in the $L$-frame. As $E \gg m c^{2}$,

$$
p c \approx E\left(1-\frac{m^{2} c^{4}}{2 E^{2}}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
W^{\prime} & \approx \frac{E}{m \mathrm{c}^{2}}\left[1-\left(1-\frac{m^{2} c^{4}}{2 E^{2}}\right) \cos \theta\right] W \\
&=\left[\frac{E}{m c^{2}}(1-\cos \theta)+\frac{m c^{2}}{2 E} \cos \theta\right] W .
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) In the $e$-frame, the electron is initially at rest. If its recoil can be neglected, the incident photons must be scattered back along the line of incidence with the same energy in accordance with the conservation of energy and of momentum. The transformation of energy and momentum of the photon is given by

$$
W^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}=\gamma W(\cos \theta-\beta), \quad W^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}=W \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\tan \theta^{\prime}=\frac{\sin \theta}{\gamma(\cos \theta-\beta)},
$$

and

$$
W=\gamma\left(1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}\right) W^{\prime} \approx\left[\frac{E}{m c^{2}}\left(1+\cos \theta^{\prime}\right)-\frac{m c^{2}}{2 E} \cos \theta^{\prime}\right] W^{\prime} .
$$

Equation (1) shows that for $W^{\prime}$ to be maximum, $\cos \theta=-1$ or $\theta=\pi$ and

$$
W_{\max }^{\prime} \approx \frac{2 E}{m c^{2}} .
$$

Equation (2) gives $\theta^{\prime}=\pi$. The photon is scattered back so that after the collision $\theta^{\prime}=0$. Equation (3) then gives the corresponding energy in L-frame:

$$
W_{\max } \approx \frac{2 E}{m \mathrm{c}^{2}} W_{\max }^{\prime} \approx\left(\frac{2 E}{m c^{2}}\right)^{2} W .
$$

Similarly, for the minimum energy, $\cos \theta=1$, or $\theta=0$, and

$$
W_{\min }^{\prime} \approx \frac{m c^{2}}{2 E} W, \quad \theta^{\prime}=0 .
$$

After scattering $\theta^{\prime}=\pi$ and

$$
W_{\min } \approx \frac{m c^{2}}{2 E} W_{\min }^{\prime} \approx\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{2 E}\right)^{2} W .
$$
